If there is an upside to the downside of losing business, perhaps, in the case of Lower Manhattan's bars, it is no-wait restrooms.
At happy hour last Tuesday at the Raccoon Lodge on Warren Street, a man visited the ladies room, simply because he could.

The pins in the Pro Bowler game strained for a strike that never came, the pool table resembled a vacant cemetery plot and the jukebox wailed whenever it dawned on one of the two clusters at the bar that nobody else was tossing in quarters.
Among bar owners in Lower Manhattan, the keening of their dying bars is by now a familiar tale but one with alternating villains.
First there was Sept. 11, 2001, and days of cleaning up the terrible dust.
But then followed six months of drawing pitchers and uncapping bottles for packs of rescue workers thirsting for distraction. ''
Those six months after were the busiest of my life,'' said Karen Ulrich, a bartender at the Raccoon Lodge. ''
We lost a lot of regulars.
Then we got all the firemen, the cops and the militia.
And the girls who came looking for them.''
FIDELITY INVESTMENTS, already dominant in the $3 trillion mutual fund industry, is heading straight for Middle America.
This week, it will begin running a $25 million television advertisement campaign, according to a person familiar with the effort.
Network television is  a departure for Fidelity, which mostly runs print ads highlighting the performance of specific funds.
The new ads focus primarily on the company's image and are intended to increase awareness of Fidelity's discount brokerage firm as well as its funds.
They are scheduled to make their debut on Thursday during CBS broadcasts of the  N.C.A.A. basketball tournament and will run throughout the year during sports and other special events.

Donald Dion Jr., publisher of the independent newsletter Fidelity Adviser in  Williamstown, Mass., said increases in Fidelity's television and print advertising budget would raise the company's total ad spending to $45 million from $6 million last year.
A spokeswoman for Fidelity declined to comment.
John Jelilian, a senior vice president at Competitrack, which follows advertising by financial companies, said the campaign was Fidelity's first on network television in recent memory.

Other fund companies, including Janus and Kemper Financial, have run brief network television campaigns, but generally have found that ads promoting a warm and fuzzy image have not built assets as well as more performance-oriented ads.

Therefore, Mr. Jelilian said, fund companies tend to place their ads with "very targeted financial programming" like that on CNBC, the cable business channel whose time is far less expensive than that of the major networks.

It is not surprising that Boris Eifman chose not to set ''The Seagull'' in the late-19th-century Russia of the Chekhov play from which the ballet is drawn, though it is disappointing, given the beauty of the Eifman Ballet's costumes and the extravagance of its sets.
Mr. Eifman likes to turn tradition and the familiar on their heads.

And so the new ballet, performed on Wednesday as the centerpiece of the Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg's 30th-anniversary season at City Center, is set for the most part in a glass-and-steel ballet studio.
Mr. Eifman's lavish theatrical imagination and gift for staging seem to have deserted him.
Chekhov's play is short on action.
Its heart lies in the words and images with which the themes of art and genius -- favorites of Mr. Eifman -- are addressed in interactions between the characters.
With no strong narrative to transform, the ballet, set to Rachmaninoff and Scriabin, reduces the themes to bursts of hollow agony and bad dance through which the ballet staggers.
Irina Arkadina, the play's aging actress, has become an aging ballerina, danced by Nina Zmievets.
Her wayward lover, the famous writer Trigorin, is now a famous choreographer, portrayed by Yuri Smekalov.
Her son, the would-be writer Constantine Treplev, is now a struggling young choreographer (danced by Dmitri Fisher in a bowl haircut), a would-be artist who is eager to push dance into the future.
YOUR FUTURE, a new magazine from Time Inc. aimed at readers 40 and younger who are just discovering the importance of personal finance, is anything but tedious -- visually.
The first issue, on sale now through June 4, looks like a knock-off of the hot cyber journal, Wired, with articles framed by huge red headlines and sidebars set in greenish type.
Obviously the design editors borrowed from Time's Money magazine worked hard to make Your Future inviting, at least to people they think of as visual sophisticates.
But Your Future is a snoozer where it counts.
Most of the articles are quick takes, and the magazine wastes an amazing amount of ink on feeble attempts at humor.

In a feature called Moneysomethings -- "Ideas to fill your head and your wallet" -- Your Future includes a Washington man who's serving a life sentence in prison for running a $2-million-a-week drug ring.
The magazine lists baby-sitting and cleaning carpets among 11 second jobs "almost anyone can do" to bolster his or her income.
Another feature explains how to choose a PIN, or personal identification number.
And it devotes an entire page to answering the burning question, "Is it more expensive to be a woman or a man?" (
Not that anyone can choose -- at least not without racking up staggering medical bills.)
CONSIDER the acorn: a small thing.
Produced by the millions by uncaring oaks, most rot on the ground.
But under the right conditions, dirt and light and water conspire to make the most of the little seed, and it becomes a mighty oak.
History is the story of the mighty oaks; the acorns get little ink.
There are too many seeds, and their existence is too transient.
So historians, in professional retrospect, tell us which of the acorns got lucky.
We go forward armed with the lessons of the past: it's not always the obvious things that change the course of the world.
Sometimes they are small, or overlooked.
The best sellers of pre-Revolutionary France were largely ignored by literati of the time and by literary tradition since.
They tended to be roughly drawn and raw, even pornographic.
Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan has been flirting with racism in his effort to win control of the company that owns grocery stores, hotels and other concessions in Yosemite National Park.
Yesterday Mr. Lujan wisely sought to cool his anti-Japanese rhetoric.
His earlier behavior had done little to help Japanese-American commercial relations, or the park.
The Yosemite Park & Curry Company is a subsidiary of MCA, which was recently acquired by the Japanese electronics concern Matsushita.
Having failed to strike a negotiated settlement, Mr. Lujan launched an inflammatory public campaign against Matsushita.
He said he wanted to keep the concessions out of "foreign hands," and sounded hysterical and xenophobic warnings about the Japanese "buying up" the country.
The secretary is frustrated with the national parks' concession system, and he should be.
The hundreds of contracts his department has with concessionaires are outmoded and place the U.S. Government at a great disadvantage.
The Yosemite deal is the largest single contract in the system and, in its current form, dates back 30 years.
It's a poor bargain: the company passes on only three-fourths of 1 percent of its earnings to the Government, just 75 cents on every $100.

The GPA Group P.L.C. expects to complete a deal within a few days under which it would be rescued from its financial difficulties by a subsidiary of the General Electric Company, aviation industry executives said today.

The executives said that on completion of the deal, to which the companies agreed in principle in May, Tony Ryan, GPA's founder and chairman, would relinquish his duties overseeing the finances of the aircraft-leasing company.

But they said he would be appointed chairman of a new company, GE Capital Aviation Management Ltd., which would be in charge of the commercial aircraft-leasing activities of both GPA and GE Capital, which is based in Stamford, Conn. GPA has been the world's largest aircraft-leasing company, supplying many carriers with planes from the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation of the United States and the Airbus Industrie consortium of Europe.
GE Capital, through its Polaris leasing operation, is also a leading provider of planes to airlines, though most of its customers are smaller carriers seeking older planes than those leased by GPA.
Together, the companies lease nearly 1,000 planes to airlines around the world.

General Electric is already a dominant force in another sector of the aviation industry as one of the two leading suppliers of jet engines, along with the Pratt & Whitney division of the United Technologies Corporation.
The two companies sell to both commercial and military aircraft builders.
Mr. Ryan started GPA in 1975, believing that airlines would find it attractive to lease some of their planes rather than buy them outright.
He was proved right over the next decade and a half, as GPA, which is based in Shannon, Ireland, rode the boom in the airline industry.

But Mr. Ryan failed several years ago to spot what has become a deep downturn in the airline industry, and he lost credibility when his attempt to take GPA public collapsed last year amid declining demand for new planes.
CALL it the home-team advantage. ''
We're able to keep close tabs on our investments,'' said Conrad B. Herrmann, lead manager of the $1.58 billion Franklin California Growth fund, which focuses on California companies. ''
We read local newspapers in California and socialize and interact with people who might be employed in the companies in our universe.''
For Mr. Herrmann, cultivating his own backyard has paid off.

The fund has returned 29.2 percent a year, on average, in the three years through Nov. 26, compared with 22.5 percent for its midcap growth peers, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher.
The fund holds 135 stocks, generally of small to midsized companies with market capitalizations of up to $2.5 billion; technology issues make up about half the assets.

In picking stocks, Mr. Herrmann, 39, and his second in command, Canyon A. Chan, 30, divide the 1,400-plus publicly traded California companies into four groups, and look at different criteria for each.
The fund also owns a few companies that are based outside California but that  have major business in the state.

The biggest portion of the fund,  about 70 percent, is invested in somewhat out-of-favor growth companies, selling at a 20 percent to 25 percent discount to what the managers believe they are worth. ''
These are companies with good upside prospects,'' Mr. Herrmann said, ''not just because of the growth of the business but because they trade at a lower value than we think they deserve.''

The stock market closed essentially unchanged yesterday despite factors that ought to have prompted a rally, notably a drop in long-term interest rates and fresh employment data that indicated inflation was still under control.

Ahead of today, when most financial markets in the United States will be closed in memory of former President Richard M. Nixon, both the stock and bond markets had below-normal trading volume, probably signaling that many traders were declining to buy or sell.
The number of shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 288.1 million, or 6 percent below this year's average of 305 million shares.

The exception was tobacco stocks, where the news that Britain's B.A.T Industries planned to buy American Brands' domestic tobacco business for $1 billion lifted the prices of the leading tobacco stocks, American Brands, Philip Morris and RJR Nabisco, which was the most-active stock yesterday, at 11 million shares.
The food and cigarette company rose 3/8 to 6 7/8.
The benchmark 30-year bond continued its rise in price, as its yield fell to 7.10 percent, down 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, from Monday.
In less than a week and a half, the long bond's yield has fallen more than 30 basis points, but traders doubted that the market rally would be long-lived.
The value of United States Government bonds rose early after a Labor Department report that wages and benefits were rising at a slower rate than economists expected.
The employment cost index rose 3.2 percent, the smallest gain since 1982, when the department began publicizing the report.
The slight rise meant that workers were having a tough time getting raises and therefore that businesses' operating costs were stable, helping to damp inflationary pressures.

Roger John Tayler, who helped advance modern understanding of stellar evolution and served for 18 years as secretary, treasurer and finally president of the Royal Astronomical Society in Britain, died on Jan. 23 in a London hospital.
He was 67 and lived in Lewes, England.
The cause was cancer, the society said.
Dr. Tayler was a leading investigator of stars, following up on the pioneering work of Sir Fred Hoyle of Britain and Martin Schwarzschild of Princeton University.
His contributions furthered the knowledge of stellar structures, plasma stability, nucleogenesis and cosmology.
Besides many scientific articles, he wrote and edited textbooks used by students worldwide.
His recent works included ''The Sun as a Star'' (1996), ''The Hidden Universe'' (1995), ''The Structure and Evolution of Galaxies'' (second edition, 1993) and ''Stellar Astrophysics'' (1992).
Also still in print are ''The Stars: Their Structure and Evolution'' (second edition, 1994) and ''The Origin of the Chemical Elements'' (1977).
Dr. Tayler was educated at Clare College, Cambridge, where he received his master's and Ph.D. degrees.
He is survived by his wife of 41 years, Moya Elizabeth Fry Tayler, and a brother, Judge Harold Clive Tayler of Tamworth, England.
Feng Youlan, China's leading contemporary philosopher, died on Monday, the New China News Agency said today.
He was 94 years old.

Professor Feng is best known for his two-volume "History of Chinese Philosophy" and for a series of books that developed his philosophical system, which combined elements of Chinese philosophy, particularly neo-Confucianism, with Western ideas.
In the fall of 1982, Professor Feng, who received his Ph.D. from Columbia University in 1923, returned to receive an honorary Doctor of Letters.

Professor Feng, whose name is often spelled Fung Yu-lan, studied with John Dewey and Frederick J. E. Woodbridge at Columbia before returning to China, where he taught primarily at Qinghua University and at Peking University.

At the Columbia ceremony, Wing-tsit Chan, another scholar of Chinese philosophy, said he thought Professor Feng deserved acclaim because "at a time when Chinese intellectuals saw little value in the Chinese tradition, Professor Feng upheld it." "
Since the New Culture Movement of 1917, 'new thinkers' in China had rejected Chinese thought as unworthy and decadent," Professor Chan said. "
Anything that is good must be Western.
But Dr. Feng took Chinese thought seriously and he wrote a scholarly history to show it." "
But Professor Feng's excursions in philosophy caused problems after the Communist takeover in 1949.
After expansion plans for its building in the John-Witherspoon neighborhood were rejected, the Arts Council of Princeton is considering other sites for a new arts center.
The Princeton Regional Planning Board ruled in a 6-to-5 vote that the new center would be disruptive to the community. ''
Obviously we're disappointed,'' said Chris Ludwig, president of the Arts Council board. ''
We were drowned out in a very real, emotional debate that occurred.''
The proposed site was the Arts Council building at Paul Robeson Place and Witherspoon Street.
The planning board ruled against the council after residents testified that the new building would be too big and imposing. ''

In the end, more than half the board thought the size of the center is much greater than the surrounding buildings and its use would contrast with the neighborhood,'' said Wanda Gunning, chairwoman of the planning board.
The council took pains to make revisions that would ''minimize the impact on the neighborhood,'' Mr. Ludwig said.
The council is now looking at 5 to 10 alternative sites, Mr. Ludwig said, and will also consider revisions in the rejected plans. ''
We are going to investigate and select the ones that best meet our needs without breaking us financially,'' Mr. Ludwig said.
Twice in the past year, Muhammad Said has survived assassination attempts that left his car riddled with bullets.
He works part time as a bodyguard for his father, a Baghdad city councilman, and helps a friend who has contracts with the American military.
Both are very dangerous jobs.

So last month, Mr. Said, a slim, baby-faced 23-year-old, did what a small but growing number of Iraqis are doing: He walked into the offices of the Iraq Insurance Company and bought a terrorism insurance policy.

It looked like an ordinary life insurance policy, but with a one-page rider adding coverage for ''the following dangers: 1) explosions caused by weapons of war and car bombs; 2) assassinations; 3) terrorist attacks.''
It cost him 125,000 dinars, about $90.
Mr. Said paid more than most people because of his risky occupation.
The payout, if he dies, is five million dinars, around $3,500, or about what an Iraqi policeman earns in a year.
That guarantee appears to be the first off-the-shelf terrorism policy in the world, insurance experts say.
In most countries, of course, there is no need for it: death by terrorism is rare enough that it is usually covered by ordinary accident insurance.
The University of Miami, college football's controversial fallen dynasty, is officially starting over.

The Hurricanes were overwhelmed by the U.C.L.A. Bruins tonight, 31-8, in their first game under their new coach, Butch Davis, a jarring demonstration of how far they have fallen from their championship days.
Karim Abdul-Jabbar, the senior Bruin tailback who adopted his new Muslim name this summer, ran for 180 yards and 2 touchdowns to lead U.C.L.A. The Hurricanes had not lost an opening game since 1990.
Miami did not move inside the Bruin 29-yard line until nine minutes remained and the Bruins had built a 24-point lead.
U.C.L.A. gained 345 yards, 256 of which came on the ground.
Miami converted just 4 of 14 third-down situations.
And in a symbolic and confusing finish, Ryan Collins, the Hurricane quarterback, spiked the ball on the fourth-down play that ended Miami's final possession.
That confusion followed the Hurricanes into their dressing room, where they understood what had happened, but not why. "
It seemed like we were ready to play," Collins said. "
I don't know what went wrong," said Ray Lewis, Miami's junior middle linebacker. "
Josh Hall, a 32-year-old British sailor competing in the BOC yacht race round the world, called by radio for help yesterday afternoon after hitting an unknown object at sea.
Hall, who was in ninth place among the 19 solo sailors, said that his boat was taking on water quickly and that he was in danger of sinking. "
He said that his boat was severely holed," said Herb McCormick, a BOC race spokesman in a telephone interview from Cape Town, South Africa, the port where Hall and the other BOC racers are headed. "
He has a pump on board, but said he was barely able to stay ahead of the water coming in."
Hall, who is skipper of the 60-foot sailboat Gartmore Investment Managers, was midway in the South Atlantic Ocean, about 2,800 miles northwest of Cape Town and 800 miles east of Salvador, Brazil.
The nearest ship to Hall is reportedly about 200 miles away.
McCormick said that the closest BOC racer to Hall, the Australian competitor, Alan Nebauer, had diverted from his southerly course in an effort to help Hall.
Nebauer's boat, the 50-foot racer Newcastle, Australia, was traveling at about 7.5 knots at the time and was about 90 miles north of Gartmore Investment.
It is estimated that Nebauer would take as much as 11 hours to get to the stricken boat.
BOC racers carry survival suits and life rafts.
The letters keep coming -- tens of thousands of them by now, Esther Waxman says -- so many that she had to hire a private company to sort them.
In Israel, the correspondents include her 12th-grade students at Hebrew University High School in Jerusalem, where she teaches English. "
I do not believe in God," one of them wrote. "
I come from an atheistic family.
Nevertheless, we lit candles on Friday night, and my sister and I even looked in Psalms about the release of prisoners.
It didn't help, or so it seems at least, and so I wanted to ask you how can you still have faith after this." "
This" was the kidnapping and killing last month of her soldier son, Nahshon, by members of the Islamic group known as Hamas.
And the answer to the student's question, says Mrs. Waxman, an Orthodox Jew, is that faith still burns brightly for her and her husband, Yehuda, even if it has been sorely tested. "
My husband is interested in opening an educational center now to get them young, to teach these children, these Hamas people, about human life and values universal to all religions," she said. "
He feels that by the time they're teen-agers -- however old these kids were who took Nahshon -- it's too late.

More than two years after American Airlines and British Airways P.L.C. announced an alliance that would dominate air traffic across the Atlantic, European regulators proposed preliminary conditions yesterday that appeared to clear the the way for its approval.

At the same time, the European Commission, which represents 15 countries, angered the UAL Corporation's United Airlines, Lufthansa and Scandinavian Air System by proposing retroactive restrictions on their two-year-old alliance.

Yesterday's moves sharpened simmering tensions between the European Commission and the Clinton Administration as well as between the commission and its own member states concerning international aviation competition at a time when an increasing number of the world's airlines have entered into cross-border alliances that have received exemptions from United States antitrust laws.
The partnerships are seen as the only way for international airlines to provide global service because of regulations that limit the rights of carriers to operate outside their home countries.

The commission's proposed conditions would require American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, and British Airways to give up rights to 267 weekly landings and takeoffs at London's two principal airports, Heathrow and Gatwick, without receiving any compensation.
They would also require United, Lufthansa and S.A.S. to give up 108 of these so-called slots at airports in Frankfurt and Copenhagen.

In addition, the commission would also force the carriers to reduce their flights for six months on certain routes that they now dominate in order to give competitors a chance to establish themselves.
That proposal is directly at odds with the approach taken by American regulators, who have already approved three international alliances, including the United-Lufthansa-S.A.S. link, since 1993.

Executives at American and British Airways raised objections to the commission proposals but said they were generally encouraged because they were now convinced that their partnership, which has been in regulatory limbo since June 1996, would finally move forward. ''
This is very positive news,'' said Robert Ayling, the British Airways chief executive. ''
The Federal Government is investigating possible antitrust violations in the nation's oil and gas drilling bit industry, officials said yesterday.
News of the investigation sent shares of some drill bit manufacturers tumbling, analysts said.
Baker Hughes Inc. lost $1.25 to close at $21.625 on the New York Stock Exchange, while Smith International Inc. lost $1 to close at $12.
News of the inquiry leaked from drill bit companies early in the day and was confirmed late in the afternoon by a spokeswoman for the Treasury Department in Washington.
She would not elaborate on what prompted the Federal grand jury investigation into possible violations of antitrust laws in the industry.
Herb Ryan, a spokesman for Dresser Industries, said he was unsure why there was an investigation of drill bit manufacturers. "
We have no indication that we are a target of the investigation," Mr. Ryan said.
Dresser gained 25 cents to end the day at $19.375.
Isaac Kerridge, vice president at Baker Hughes, said the Justice Department was seeking price information dating back to about 1985 but had not made any specific allegations.
The requests for information do not necessarily mean a company is under investigation, said George Gaspar of Robert W. Baird & Company. "

A day after spring seemed to burst out of hiding, winter came charging back to the New York region yesterday with a storm that brought plunging temperatures and wind-whipped snow that appeared strangely immune to gravity -- blowing up and sideways as well as down.
From street corners, office windows and front porches, many watched in dismay as the blizzard-like storm raged with intensity.
Some said it seemed like a cruel joke on those who only hours earlier had doffed jackets and looked eagerly for crocus shoots. ''
It's completely unacceptable,'' said Louisa DeRose, a 24-year-old student at New York Law School, as she sipped coffee during a break outside on Worth Street. ''
I would rather that yesterday didn't happen.
It was like a false ray of hope.''

The storm created hazardous conditions and resulted in major delays and frustration for thousands of drivers leaving work yesterday afternoon, just as standing water and slush on streets and highways was turning to ice.
Last night, strong winds battered the region, pushing pedestrians off sidewalks in Midtown and toppling trees.
There were delays and cancellations at all three New York area airports, with wind gusts posing more of a problem than snow on the runways.
Several planes were diverted to Baltimore and Washington, but the decisions were made by pilots, not air traffic controllers, said James Peters, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration.
Manually Adjusting Windows AutoPlay Q. Is there any way to turn off that Windows XP alert box that pops up when you put a CD in the drive, listing a bunch of tasks like ''copy files'' or ''play''?
A. The AutoPlay box is intended to be helpful by presenting options like ''Open folder to view files'' or ''Play using Windows Media Player'' when you insert a disc into the CD drive.
The box also appears when you connect your PC to a pocket U.S.B. drive, digital camera or other device containing files that Windows XP recognizes.
The box also offers a ''Take no action'' option that, if checked, will prevent Windows from taking any action on the kind of disc or drive you inserted.
You can temporarily bypass the AutoPlay box when you insert a disc or connect a device by holding down the Shift key on the keyboard.
You can fine-tune your AutoPlay preferences for different kinds of discs by right-clicking on the icon for your PC's disc drive in the My Computer window and selecting Properties from the menu.
Next, click on the AutoPlay tab.
At the top of the AutoPlay Properties box, you can choose a type of media file, like music, movies or photos, and then select an action to perform when Windows encounters this type of file.
Click on the O.K. button when you have things the way you want them.

Unruffled by Asia's crisis and buoyed by the exceptionally promising job market, American consumers approach 1998 with the most confidence about their economic future that they have expressed in nearly three decades. ''

The strength of the United States economy, especially of the labor market, continues to lift consumers' spirits and bolster their expectations,'' Lynn Franco, associate director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center, said today in reporting that confidence surged in December to its highest level since mid-1969.
Those calling jobs ''plentiful'' reached a record 40.6 percent of respondents to the monthly survey conducted for the business-supported research group.
The optimism in the survey was viewed as a strong signal that the economy would  remain vibrant, partly because consumer spending accounts for a large portion of domestic growth.
The survey results also contributed to the second consecutive surge in the stock market, where the Dow Jones industrial average rose 123.56 points or 1.6 percent, adding to a 1.5 percent gain Monday.

Although financial and economic turmoil in Asia is widely expected to hurt certain parts of the economy, especially American exporters, consumers seem to be regarding it nonchalantly or even as a likely benefit to them, economists said.

One reason is that lower costs loom for imported goods, reflecting the dollar's strength in relation to devalued Asian currencies and the need by South Korea and other stricken countries with faltering domestic markets to bolster sales abroad.
Moreover, many economists think that whatever slowing effects the Asian crisis has on the American economy will allow the Federal Reserve to avoid raising interest rates.
Consumers, said James E. Annable, chief economist at First Chicago-NBD, ''are putting together all these things as it pertains to them and they're coming up with the right answer.''
In other words, households seem somehow to be recognizing that what economists call the terms of trade have shifted in their favor.
The commander of Israeli forces in central Ramallah said today that he is trying to relax the siege on Yasir Arafat's compound here, ''at least for the time being.''
During a quick tour of the site with a military escort this afternoon, the atmosphere appeared calm, although an armored cordon remained. ''
It has been so sensitive and tense that we have stepped back a little bit,'' said Col.
Uzi Moskowitz, who commands Israeli forces in the most important parts of this city. ''
There was just too much friction, and shooting.''
He took two reporters on a tour of Bethlehem today in armored military jeeps, the first such tour the army has offered. ''
I have nothing to hide,'' the colonel said.
Mr. Arafat has been under siege for two weeks now.
On Sunday he is to meet with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, plans that may have affected the Israeli military's attitude.
Tanks still ringed the building this afternoon.
He may be a top figure in the supposedly stuffy world of insurance, but Jacques Blondeau never goes anywhere without his Bugs Bunny key chain. ''
I've always been a great fan of American cartoons,'' said Mr. Blondeau, chief executive of the SCOR Group, a big commercial insurance company based in Paris.
His soft black-leather satchel holds a potpourri of other mementos and gadgets.
Because the electricity sometimes goes dead in countries like China and the Ivory Coast, Mr. Blondeau, 54, carries a cigarette-sized flashlight on his travels.
His penknife, with a handle shaped like an antique roadster, serves as a bottle opener and screwdriver.
Attached to the knife is a tiny brass crocodile, a gift from an African businessman.
The keys to his Paris apartment dangle from a metal rendition of Jumbo the elephant, the mascot of Tufts University, which his son Guillaume, 26, attended.
The serious stuff -- notes and charts for conferences, board meetings and sessions with brokers and customers -- can be found in color-coded folders.
As a member of the Institut Francais des Relations Internationales, he also carries a paper on French-Russian relations.
Then there is his cellular phone, programmed for most countries, a spare pair of eyeglasses and ''The Proud Tower,'' a history of Europe on the eve of World War I, by Barbara W. Tuchman.

The Genamerica Corporation, one of the first mutual life insurers to sell shares to the public under a hybrid structure two years ago, said yesterday that it was becoming a company owned completely by stockholders.
Half a dozen mutual companies have converted to hybrids, which can sell shares worth up to 49 percent of their value while 51 percent of the company remains with the policyholders.
Because the majority ownership of the hybrids, known as mutual holding companies, stays with policyholders, they became immune from hostile takeovers.
And the minority public stake gave the hybrid some insulation from shareholder demands for performance that pure stock companies faced.
For those reasons, consumer advocates and executives of stock companies allied as critics of the hybrids predicted that the hybrids would never move toward full stock ownership.
Genamerica, one of the top 40 life insurers, with assets around $20 billion, is the first to take that step.
One reason for the shift, said Richard A. Liddy, chief executive of Genamerica, was to be able to raise unlimited amounts of capital. ''
We could have raised enough capital to last us awhile,'' he said, ''but sooner or later we would have to'' find ways to raise more.
Critics of the hybrids pointed out that while the new company could sell stock, none of it would go to the policyholders.
Not only were they denied any tangible benefit from the hybrid structure, the critics argued, but the new structure created a struggle over profit between policyholders and shareholders.

Five weeks after an agreement put the YES Network on Cablevision, ending a yearlong blackout, the companies disputed yesterday how many of the cable operator's subscribers had elected to add YES to their monthly bill.

In the deal, about 1.9 million of Cablevision's three million subscribers were given the choice of paying $1.95 a month for YES, $4.95 a month for YES, MSG Network and Fox Sports New York, or upgrading to a premium tier.

Charles F. Dolan, the chairman of Cablevision, said yesterday during testimony at a Senate Commerce Committee hearing on soaring cable television fees that ''less than 9 percent'' of the 1.9 million had elected to add YES.
Cablevision officials subsequently said the range was 5 percent to 9 percent, or 95,000 to 171,000 subscribers.
But YES said the number was greater, although it was not sure of the total. ''

Our analysis of Cablevision subscribers suggests that more than half of all Cablevision subscribers get YES, which is clearly at odds with Cablevision's lowball estimate,'' Leo J. Hindery Jr., the YES chairman, said in a statement.
Hindery also said that steadily rising ratings for Yankees games substantiated his belief that YES had more subscribers than Dolan claimed.
But a definitive number will not be known until mid-June, when Cablevision reports to YES on business in April.
The dispute echoes the one in which YES cited a far higher number of Cablevision converts to the DirecTV satellite service to get Yankee games than Cablevision did.
YES's deal with Cablevision immediately placed the channel, at no extra charge, with 1.1 million subscribers who subscribe to a premium package.
Shaquille O'Neal squared his body and grabbed the  rebound.
Dropping back like a quarterback, he went long, aiming for his favorite receiver.

There were other, more awesome sequences, dunks more scintillating than the one Kobe Bryant threw down in Game 3 of the Western Conference finals tonight -- like the frightening, two-handed reverse he deposited over Tim Duncan in the opening minutes of the fourth quarter.

But the O'Neal-Bryant connection illustrated a disturbing pattern for the almost-done San Antonio Spurs: No matter how close Duncan and David Robinson come to the Los Angeles Lakers and their dynamic duo, no matter how hard they try to crawl back into this series, it is no use.

Building a lead of 22 points after three quarters, controlling the game throughout and eventually running the Spurs off the Staples Center floor, O'Neal and Bryant combined for 71 points, and the Lakers moved within a victory of their second straight trip to the N.B.A. finals, blitzing San Antonio, 111-72.
Taking a 3-0 lead in the four-of-seven-game series, they won their 10th straight playoff game -- and their 18th over all.

With a dominating performance that left San Antonio, the team with the league's best regular-season record, one victory away from a stunning postseason sweep, the Lakers seem to be chasing not only their second straight title but also a piece of history. ''
We loved the feeling we had last year and we're trying to get back to it,'' said O'Neal, whose 35 points and 17 rebounds complemented Bryant's impressive line of 36 points, 9 rebounds and 8 assists.
A victory in Game 4 on Sunday would tie the Shaq-and-Kobe Lakers with the Magic Johnson-led Lakers of 1989, who opened the postseason with a record 11 straight victories.
No team has ever won all its playoff games en route to a title -- a feat the Lakers are only five victories from achieving.
LEAD: To the Editor: To the Editor: Having read ''Forest Murders: Ours and Theirs'' (editorial, Sept. 20), on the Tongass National Forest, I find it incredible that you could be so misinformed.
Only 10 percent of the Tongass will ever be harvested and then only at a rate of 1/100th annually.
That is not the case in the Amazon, which is in essence a land-clearing project.
There is no comparison!
Your claim that money cannot be made on Southeast Alaska timber is absurd.
Private landowners within the Tongass make money on their timber, and the remote site and poor weather affect the profits, but not to the point of making the operations uneconomical.
In 1947 the Government encouraged the forest products industry to come to Alaska and invest.
If now the Government wants the industry to leave, it should simply buy out the contracts at a fair market value.
What happened to old-fashioned ethics that say ''a deal is a deal''?
People like you sit in your big-city offices without the slightest idea what it takes to give Americans the standard of living they demand and now enjoy.

Reporting sales that were weaker than expected, Coca-Cola Enterprises, the Coca-Cola Company's largest soft-drink bottler, said yesterday that first-quarter volume rose just 1 percent, one of the smallest increases in years.
Fountain volume -- the soft drinks sold in restaurants, movie theaters, sports arenas and other public places -- grew just 2 percent in the quarter.

Despite the unimpressive volume growth, Coca-Cola Enterprises said cash flow rose 11 percent, to $417 million in the quarter, after the company raised prices in several distribution channels, including many supermarkets.
Net losses, however, widened to $61 million; in the comparable quarter of 1998, the company lost $51 million.
Revenues per case increased 3 percent in the quarter, reflecting the higher prices as well as product, packaging and distribution changes. ''
They appear to be making good progress on raising prices in the take-home channel,'' said Marc Cohen, a beverage analyst for Goldman, Sachs.
However, he said, Coca-Cola soft drinks are facing increased competition from Pepsico's Pepsi-Cola.

In March, he said, citing data released on Monday by Information Resources Inc., which tracks sales in supermarkets, drugstores and mass merchandisers, Coca-Cola's market share declined 1.7 percent, while Pepsi's market share grew nine-tenths of 1 percent.
Both companies have been locked in a price war for more than two years, and Coca-Cola Enterprises moved in January to raise prices.
In March, the bottler raised prices 3.4 percent, compared with a 2.3 percent rise made by Pepsi bottlers, according to Information Resources.

For more than a decade, John Houldsworth lived a quiet life on a quiet cul-de-sac here in one of Dublin's most affluent suburbs, where children kick soccer balls on the sidewalks, bay windows overlook front yards and sport utility vehicles sit in just about every driveway.

Mr. Houldsworth, 46, a British executive, is now at the center of an international investigation into possible financial manipulation in the insurance industry, a surprise to colleagues and acquaintances who describe him as circumspect and reserved.
He is also known as a family man and an avid hobbyist -- he played on a local field hockey team and has a golf membership at the exclusive Glen-of-the-Downs club.

But priorities have changed for Mr. Houldsworth, the former chief executive of Cologne Reinsurance, a Dublin subsidiary of Berkshire Hathaway that is suspected of helping the American International Group manipulate accounts.

He sold his two-story row house in October -- homes in Wyvern Estates where he lived do not change hands for less than $1 million -- about the time Australian insurance regulators banned him for improprieties related to the collapse of a major insurer.

Soon after, financial investigators and reporters started calling to ask him about a transaction he helped arrange in 2000 between General Reinsurance, which owns Cologne Re, and A.I.G. That transaction is critical to the broader investigation that has hit the highest levels at both companies.
On April 11, regulators questioned the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, Warren E. Buffett, who they said was a cooperating witness, not a target of the investigation.

The next day, they sought to question Maurice R. Greenberg, who resigned as chief executive of A.I.G., about his possible role in financial manipulation at A.I.G. The transactions under investigation appear to have been arranged without Mr. Buffett's knowledge, investigators say.
Mr. Greenberg invoked his legal right not to incriminate himself and declined to answer questions.
People with direct knowledge of the transaction between A.I.G. and General Re said that in December 2000, Mr. Houldsworth oversaw changes to the deal's documentation.

A government agency briefed members of a House committee this afternoon on the safety of the tires that the Ford Motor Company is using to replace those made by Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. after the committee chairman said the automaker might be using tires with even higher failure rates than the Firestones.

On Tuesday, the chairman, Representative Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana, said that seven of the tire models that Ford was using to replace 13 million Firestone tires on its Explorer sport utility vehicles might have higher failure rates than those they were replacing.
A spokesman for the Republican majority on the committee, Ken Johnson, raised that number to 11 today but said that the higher rates did not necessarily mean that the tires were unsafe.
The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration provided a briefing on the matter to the committee today but did not say anything publicly.

After the briefing, the ranking Democrat on the committee, John Dingell of Michigan, said that the highway agency ''could not and would not now say that any tires on Chairman Tauzin's list, including the Ford replacement tires, were bad.''
But Mr. Tauzin, in a statement issued a few minutes later, said that the agency ''could not and would not say that any of the replacement tires in question were safe.''
Ford said it had no new information from the agency and was proceeding with its replacement program.
Before the hearing on Tuesday, held by two subcommittees of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Mr. Tauzin had said that some of the replacement tires had a higher failure rate.
The analysis was done by the committee's Republican staff.
Today he said that the highway agency needed more time to analyze the data and that he was asking Ford to test the replacement tires the same way it had tested the Firestone tires.
NEXT year, thoroughbred racing's biggest day, the Breeders' Cup, will be at Monmouth Park.
This could either be a positive symbol of growth for the sport in New Jersey, or it could be its last hurrah.
Horse racing -- both standardbred, or harness, and thoroughbred -- has been an important business in New Jersey since the 19th century as well as part of the culture (the state animal is the horse).
But racing's future in the state is in jeopardy.
Unless a way to substantially increase revenue is found, the competition from neighboring states whose racetracks are armed with slot machines could cripple New Jersey's racing business.
In recent years, the competitive landscape of horse racing has changed.
Slot machines are about to begin operating or are already in use at Delaware, New York and Pennsylvania racetracks, greatly supplementing their revenue.
This extra money has allowed them to increase racing purses.
The only way that New Jersey racing has been able to stay competitive to this point is through what is known as the casino deal.
In 2004, the Atlantic City casinos agreed to pay the racing industry $86 million over four years to increase prize money and breeding incentives for standardbreds and thoroughbreds.
In recent weeks the Pro Bowl was all Giants cornerback Phillippi Sparks had thought about.
To some extent he had become obsessed with it, talking about it for weeks with fellow players, coaches and some members of the news media.
Sparks had Hawaii on the brain.
Needless to say, Sparks was one of the more disappointed players in the National Football League today.
For the second consecutive season, no Giants player made the Pro Bowl.
You don't have any control over it," Giants Coach Dan Reeves said. "
A lot of times it's a reflection of how you play."
And the Giants, with a 5-9 record, haven't played very well.
Still, some of their players deserved consideration.
The best shots belonged to Sparks and offensive tackle Jumbo Elliott.
Office workers who happen to be lunching in Bryant Park later this month will be able to enjoy a little haute couture with their turkey wraps, thanks to Vogue magazine.
The fashion magazine, which just published a 750-page September issue that the average runway waif can barely lift, decided that even hoi polloi need an early look at designers' spring collections.

So while passers-by will not be able to enter the fashion shows going on inside the soon-to-be-erected tent in Bryant Park, they will be able to watch on Vogue-sponsored televisions set up around the perimeter. ''
In Milan and Paris, Fashion Week is a big part of life in the city,'' said Thomas A. Florio, vice president and publisher of Vogue, which is owned by Conde Nast, part of Advance Publications. ''
This will remind people that fashion is a very important industry in the city.''

In addition to coverage of the fashion shows, which will take place Sept. 18-23, the televised feed will include plugs for clients who have advertised in the September issue of Vogue, as well as sponsors of Fashion Week.

The annual fashion ritual is the occasion of much silliness -- hotshot designers can be depended on to come up with metaphysical rationales for the garments they have created -- and not a small amount of business.
But this year, Fashion Week will also serve as a reminder that business as usual is not necessarily a bad place to be.
Fashion Week last September was among the events in New York that were canceled because of the attacks on the World Trade Center.
But those who stop by this year's event for a little televised glamour should not look for reaction shots from Anna Wintour, the supreme queen of all fashionistas and Vogue's editor in chief. ''
THE giant of e-commerce is dipping its toe into another new market, and, as usual, the ripple effects are considerable.
Amazon, of course, is the giant.

And its official entry into the $1.5 billion online sporting goods market last week capped a yearlong effort to add a group of products that have posed difficult challenges for offline merchandisers but have proved well suited to online commerce.
Now, the e-commerce companies that have been finding success in sporting goods are watching to see whether Amazon emerges as competitor, a partner or both.

One keenly interested party is GSI Commerce, which operates Web sites on behalf of big sporting goods retailers like the Sports Authority and Dick's Sporting Goods, as well as other merchants like Estee Lauder, Linens 'n Things and Kmart's Bluelight.com.

Michael G. Rubin, the chief executive of GSI, predicted that the company's sporting good revenues, roughly 40 percent of its projected sales of $265 million this year, will continue to climb steadily even with competition from Amazon.

But Amazon's presence is formidable, drawing upon the retailing might of outside retailers like Eastbay, Golfsmith and Altrec.com to supply and ship to Amazon customers hundreds of thousands of items they also carry on their Web sites.
The merchants are showcasing their items on Amazon's site in exchange for an undisclosed commission on each sale.
Amazon itself will not stock or ship any sporting goods items.
The names and the numbers are not daunting, Mr. Rubin said in an interview last week. ''
Walking down a dock on his way to dinner in Portsmouth, England, last Wednesday evening, the veteran offshore sailor Stan Honey lifted his face toward the first cool drops of falling rain. ''
That cold front's getting here just about now,'' he said.
It was a weather system with which Honey was on extremely personal terms.

Earlier that day, with the American adventurer Steve Fossett and eight other crewmen on the maxi-catamaran PlayStation, Honey was in the navigator's seat when the 125-foot boat put the finishing touches on the fastest voyage across the Atlantic Ocean ever recorded under sail.

In establishing a trans-Atlantic speed record of 4 days 17 hours 28 minutes 6 seconds -- an average of nearly 26 knots -- the PlayStation crew obliterated by 44 hours the old mark of six and a half days set by the French cat Jet Services V in 1990.
While en route they also set a record for the fastest 24-hour run by a sailboat: 687.17 nautical miles.
They did so by latching on to the strong southwesterly winds in advance of the frontal passage off New York City and riding the single system for all it was worth. ''
It was remarkable,'' Honey said via cellphone. ''
We didn't tack or jibe once.
The conditions were ideal.''
Under pressure to make its fast food healthier, McDonald's said today that it was reducing the amount of saturated fat and trans fatty acids in its French fries and other fried foods.

The company said that beginning in October, its more than 13,000 restaurants nationwide would use a new variety of cooking oil that significantly reduced saturated fats and trans fatty acids, which scientists believe raise cholesterol levels and increases the risk of heart disease.
The change, first reported today in USA Today, will not affect the taste or the number of calories in any particular menu item, the company says.
But by altering the cooking oil, McDonald's said it hoped to cut by nearly half the amount of trans fatty acids in French fries and reduce the amount of saturated fats by 16 percent.

McDonald's said the new variety of vegetable oil -- which will also be used to prepare Chicken McNuggets, Filet-0-Fish and Hash Browns -- would be significantly higher in polyunsaturated fats, which experts say tends to lower cholesterol levels. ''

We're not afraid to do something different and something new to build on our track record of nutrition,'' said Walt Riker, a spokesman at McDonald's, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill. ''We're reducing bad fats and increasing good fats.''
Health and nutrition experts applauded the announcement today. ''
We're very pleased to see McDonald's take this step,'' said Margo Wootan, director of nutrition at the Center for Science in the Public Interest in Washington. ''
It will help reduce the risk of their customers' getting heart disease, and because McDonald's is an industry leader the change should be followed by other fast-food chains and food processors.''

For McDonald's, the action comes at a time of growing concern about obesity in America, and increasing pressure on food companies to offer more healthful and nutritional foods to consumers who eat on the run.
Dr. Jeanne-Marie Lopez and Matthew Joseph Holstein were married yesterday at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Hartsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Divya Paul performed the ceremony.
The bride, 30, is keeping her name.
She is a fellow in neuropsychology at the University of Medicine and Dentistry in Newark.
She graduated from Swarthmore College and received a master's degree and a Ph.D. in clinical psychology from the Pacific Graduate School of Psychology.
She is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond H. Lopez of Scarsdale, N.Y. Her father is a professor of economics and finance at Pace University in New York.

The bridegroom, 28, is an information technology developer at Deutsche Bank Securities in New York.
