Just before surgery to repair an inguinal hernia, my friend and colleague Justin said he wanted to be the first one to greet me in the recovery room.
His enthusiasm made me suspect that there might be more to his offer than just compassion. ''
I want to ask you some tough questions I'm dying to know the truth about,'' he joked.
It made me wonder, though.
Do people spill their secrets on the operating room table under the influence of anesthesia?

From Mesmer, an early pioneer of hypnosis, to ''The Manchurian Candidate,'' with its brainwashed killers, the idea of techniques or drugs that could usurp human will has captured people's imaginations.
Truth serum, common wisdom has it, should simply make us dish up our darkest secrets.
A tantalizing idea, but is it true?
I walked into the operating room and lay down on the table.
As a joke, I had drawn a blue arrow on my right side and written ''cut here'' -- just so there was no mistake.
Stanford University has proposed a research overhead rate for the next fiscal year that is almost as high as the one that got it into trouble with the Federal Government earlier this year. "
It shows a lot of chutzpah," James Collman, a chemistry professor at Stanford, said Tuesday. "
It certainly would appear to be a little bit arrogant.
It's politically impossible."

Robert Dean, the university's dean of research, said that Stanford did not expect the Government to approve the rate it proposed, but that Federal regulators required the university to give an accurate projection of costs.
At issue is how much the university charges for indirect costs of federally sponsored research.

Auditors have accused Stanford of overcharging the Federal Government millions of dollars and including as research-related costs personal extravagances for the university's president, Donald Kennedy, like cedar-line closets and a 72-foot yacht.
While he has not been directly accused of wrongdoing, his critics say he did nothing to stop the improper practices.

Federal research grants consist of two components: direct costs for a specific project, like laboratory equipment and professors' salaries, and indirect costs, for items like use of buildings, utilities, libraries and administrative services.
Rate is Well Above Average Since indirect costs are not easily attributed to specific research, universities charge the Government a percentage of the grant for all costs related to the research.
It is virtually impossible for two blue-eyed people to have a brown-eyed baby, a fact that led some Norwegian researchers to wonder if such romantic pairings might have an evolutionary advantage.
Blue-eyed men and women carry genes for only blue eyes, meaning that two blue-eyed partners can only have blue-eyed children.
But brown-eyed men and women can carry genes for both eye colors and can have either blue-eyed or brown-eyed children.

The researchers, whose study was published online earlier this month in the journal Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology, theorized that for a blue-eyed man, finding a blue-eyed mate might have a Darwinian payoff: as a father, he could be more certain that a blue-eyed child was his own.
To test this idea, the researchers showed a group of 88 college students head shots of male and female models, their eye colors digitally manipulated to appear either blue or brown.
The students were asked to rank the photos by attractiveness on a scale of one to five.
Blue-eyed men -- or at least the male Norwegian students -- preferred blue-eyed women, rating them an average 3.29, compared with 2.79 for the brown-eyed women.
Female students and brown-eyed men registered no preference by eye color.
Dr. Bruno Laeng, the study's lead author and a professor of psychology at the University of Tromso, said evolutionary theory very nicely explained the findings. ''
There is strong evolutionary pressure for a man not to invest his paternal resources in another man's child,'' he said.
The funeral home industry's largest attempted deal appears to be turning hostile.
The Service Corporation International said yesterday that it would pursue its takeover of the Loewen Group, despite the Loewen board's rejection late Tuesday of a $3.1 billion buyout offer.
Given the Loewen board's stern response and refusal so far to negotiate, executives of the Service Corporation are considering an appeal to the owners of Loewen stock. ''

It's still going to get down to price at the end of this thing, and whether our price is attractive enough to shareholders,'' L. William Heiligbrodt, the Service Corporation's president, said in an interview.
He paused, then hedged, adding: ''If we go that far.
If we take it to a formal bid.''
The Service board plans to meet on Tuesday to consider its next move.
The company's stock offer of $43 a share was made in a Sept. 17 letter to Raymond L. Loewen, founder and chief executive of the Loewen Group.
Even then, executives of the Service Corporation said that they had executed hostile acquisitions before, once against a funeral home chain in Britain, where a single family had a majority stake.
While Loewen dismissed the Service Corporation's offer as inadequate, Mr. Loewen stopped just short of ruling out negotiations on any other offer. ''
Jeffrey Toback, a Nassau County legislator, has decided that he may have better luck getting Google to change its ways if he talks to it instead of suing it.
Mr. Toback dropped a federal lawsuit last month that accused Google of profiting from child pornography.
He filed the suit in early May, but now he says he hopes he can negotiate with Google to get it to improve its filtering system to keep child pornography links off its site.
Mr. Toback said Google had sent him a letter saying ''they would be willing to talk to us but not under threat of litigation.''
He agreed to withdraw his complaint, he added, ''because the whole point of this was to get them to better publicize their filtering system and to try to get them to beef up its capability.''
Steve Langdon, a Google spokesman, said the company was pleased that the suit had been dropped, calling it irresponsible and without merit. ''
The claims he made in his lawsuit are some of the most far-fetched accusations we've ever heard,'' Mr. Langdon said in a statement.
Mr. Toback said that Google could do much more to promote its filtering system. ''
Google should be setting the standard for keeping child pornography out of the hands of people who are looking for it and of people who stumble on it accidentally,'' he said.

Mr. Toback, who is a lawyer and the father of three children, ages 15, 13 and 10, said that he filed the lawsuit as a private citizen because the County Legislature has no jurisdiction over the Internet.
The most galling part of watching the New York Legislature in action is the sight of thousands of students innocently touring the State Capitol.
Their teachers are usually telling them about how democracy works, how Teddy Roosevelt and Al Smith once roamed these very halls, how Mr. Bill becomes Mr. Law in Albany.
In reality, what these crowds of young people see is men and women on public salaries, going through the motions.
The whole place might as well be made out of cardboard.
As a report released last week from the Brennan Center for Justice at N.Y.U. School of Law has documented, New York's Capitol houses a Potemkin legislature.
The Capitol's splendid chambers are for show; voting is automatic once a legislator swipes a card or waves at a clerk at the beginning of each putative workday.
Legislation that goes to the floor always passes -- always -- because the leader in each house has more power than most dictators.
The other 210 members either follow their leaders or watch their backs.
Public debate is rare.

When Assembly members began a verbal exchange on the floor last month about the horrors of junk food versus the joys of chocolate, the moment was viewed by Albany veterans as an extremely good day for democracy.
How much influence would the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. wield today had he not been assassinated?
Not much, I suspect.
Dr. King's moral authority rested upon the indisputable fact that African-Americans in the South were disfranchised by a white power structure that stopped at nothing to keep its power.
The savagery was evident on the evening news, as when children were set upon with dogs and water cannons in the streets of Birmingham.
The passing of racism's most visible forms -- and the corresponding rise of a black elite -- would have required Dr. King to become more than just a champion of the African-American oppressed.
His condemnation of the Vietnam War foreshadowed what might have become a broader strategy.
So did his failed fair-housing campaign in Chicago in 1966.
There were no dogs and water cannons in Chicago to inspire public outrage.
Civil rights rhetoric by itself was no match for a patronage machine that could appear in blackface when it needed to.
Dr. King's rallies were anemically attended.

The Rangers are scheduled to begin their annual organizational meetings on Monday at Glen Sather's home in La Quinta, Calif. The major topic, apparently, will be who Sather, the team's president and general manager, should select as the team's head coach.
Heading into the meetings, Herb Brooks, who coached the legendary 1980 United States Olympic team and who was the Rangers' coach from 1981 to 1985, appears to be the favorite.
But Ken Hitchcock, former coach of the Dallas Stars, wants the Rangers to know that he is still interested.

Responding to an article in The New York Post on Thursday that said his first choice would be the Philadelphia Flyers, Hitchcock said that as far as he knew, everything was going as planned in the Rangers' search process. ''
I don't have any idea why something like that would come out,'' said Hitchcock, who returned Thursday from Sweden, where he had served as an assistant coach for Canada in the world championships. ''
Everything that Glen told me he was going to do when I interviewed with the Rangers is exactly what Glen is doing.
He's doing his due diligence, and I'll wait on it.
The feeling I had was that our first interview went really well.
Hopefully, I'll get a chance to come in for a second interview.''
That figures to be decided early next week, after Sather discusses the list of candidates with his staff.
In some ways, USA Swimming's five-day summer national championships, which ended here Saturday night, were unusual.
Because the nationals followed the world championships in Barcelona, Spain, by barely a week, many stars stayed home to rest.

Among them were Aaron Peirsol, Brendan Hansen, Natalie Coughlin, Jenny Thompson, Amanda Beard and Lindsay Benko, who all won medals at the world championships and could be contenders for gold medals next year at the Olympics in Athens.
Yet so much excitement was stirred up by one swimmer here that the missing were hardly mentioned.
The swimmer of the meet, by a point system or by any other measure, was 18-year-old Michael Phelps of Baltimore.
He won 5 of the 14 individual titles for men, becoming the first to win five men's events at one nationals.
All this after winning four gold and two silver medals in Barcelona.
He had the only world record of the meet, swimming the 200-meter individual medley Saturday night in 1 minute 55.94 seconds.
That was the fourth time he had lowered the world record in that race in the last six weeks.
He broke two other American records here -- the only ones set -- in events he seldom swims, the 400 freestyle and the 200 backstroke.

Two days after President Clinton announced a huge American-led effort to rescue the Mexican economy, there have still been no marches to the United States Embassy here by Mexicans wishing to show their gratitude. "
Really, we are not so convinced about all this money," said Victor Gonzalez, 31, a street vendor who was trying to sell plastic Flintstone dolls today near the Embassy. "
I am not one of those who thinks the United States is giving us this money just because they want Pemex," he said, referring to the state oil company. "
But in the end, we are just going to owe more money, and it is money that the people on the street are never going to see."
Despite a widespread sense of relief in Mexico at the $50 billion deal, many Mexicans continue to harbor concerns, resentment and even anger about the American aid.

Their feelings, sampled in interviews today around the Mexican capital and in other parts of the country, underscored a rising anguish at the country's economic straits and growing frustration with its new President, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon.
They also suggested some continuing mistrust about the 1993 trade accord with the United States and Canada.

Rather than bringing higher standards of living, many Mexicans say, the North American Free Trade Agreement has coincided with lower real wages, tighter credit and now a probable return to recession and higher inflation. "
Nobody gives a loan without wanting something in return," said Fernando Avila, 34, who was selling cowboy boots at the vast Tepito market near the center of Mexico City.

As finally packaged, the loans and loan guarantees from the United States, the International Monetary Fund and the Bank of International Settlements were probably far less offensive to Mexican sensibilities than the original, all-American plan.
Pakistani police officers arrested 29 Taliban fighters in a private hospital in the southwestern town of Quetta on Tuesday, the Interior Ministry said.

The arrests came after growing pressure from NATO countries on the Pakistani government to do more to round up Taliban fighters and commanders, who, the local police say, rest and recover in Pakistan between bouts of fighting in Afghanistan.
British, Canadian and Dutch troops are in southern Afghanistan as part of a NATO force and have encountered fierce resistance from Taliban insurgents, losing 36 soldiers in six months.

Ten of the arrested Taliban fighters had been wounded in combat with NATO forces in Helmand Province in Afghanistan last week and the others were caring for them, said Chaudhry Mohammed Yacoub, the local police chief.
He said they were all Afghans.
Two local Taliban commanders were among the arrested, said the interior minister, Aftab Khan Sherpao.
Pakistan has twice rounded up Afghans in and around Quetta, most recently last month, but most were students at religious colleges or refugees rather than fighters, and many were later released.
The arrests on Tuesday, at the privately run Al Khair Hospital in downtown Quetta, were the first of wounded fighters, local journalists said.
The Taliban had been there for two or three days when the police learned of their presence, the police chief said.
A Western diplomat in Pakistan said that while the threat from the Taliban remained largely inside Afghanistan, a significant element was based in Pakistan.
WRITING for a newspaper is like putting your child on the kindergarten bus.
You send your words out into the world where they have their own adventures, make their own impressions, then report back, or not, come day's end.
Some articles have longer (and bumpier) rides than others.
Of everything I have written, an article called ''The Opt-Out Revolution,'' which ran three years ago in The New York Times Magazine, has had the most interesting journey.
Not a week goes by that I am not asked about that article, which explored why highly educated, accomplished women were leaving their fast-track careers.
Now the UC Hastings College of the Law has released a 67-page study titled '' 'Opt Out' or Pushed Out?:
How the Press Covers Work/Family Conflict.''

It begins: ''Coined in 2003 by New York Times journalist Lisa Belkin, the so-called 'Opt-Out Revolution' attempts to explain many women's decisions to leave the paid work force for full-time care of their children.''
It then goes on to explain how I (among others) was wrong.
The author, Joan C. Williams, is someone I deeply respect.

At a time when the corner store has a touch-screen machine capable of dispensing $20 bills while deducting them from your bank account, how can millions of American votes still be cast using relics from the time of Sputnik, and be counted by equipment that is almost guaranteed to get the numbers wrong?
The simple answer is money.

A combination of events -- a razor-thin election with huge stakes in a state where counties count ballots with four technologies, each with its own margin of error -- has put punch-card voting systems at the heart of historic uncertainty over the presidential election.
Yet the controversy presents no new issues about a technology that has always had serious shortcomings.
As a technological revolution, the punch-card voting system was a putsch, rapidly supplanting rival technologies in the late 1960's, shortly after it was introduced.
And state and local governments have continued to use punch-card systems even though alternatives have surpassed them in ease of use and accuracy.
Punch-card voting systems are cheap.
They are fast.
And, before the words ''dimpled chad'' became a part of the national lexicon, elections officials thought they were accurate enough.
A lever-operated machine, the technology most commonly used in the early 1960's and still used by counties in New York State and elsewhere, cost $5,000 then and weighed nearly half a ton.
Many people suffering under Communism dreamed that someday they would live in what they called a ''normal'' country, one with the troubles of a Western democracy.
The end of Communism has left many nations as far from normalcy as ever, as they fall into ethnic disputes, gangsterism and authoritarianism.
But Poland today more closely resembles Spain or Portugal than it does most former East Bloc nations.
All sides in Poland are facing firmly west, embracing democracy, the free market and good relations with the nation's neighbors.
A new Constitution limits the power of the president and strengthens the rule of law.
The economy is vibrant, the media free.

In addition to completing privatizations, the challenges facing the new Government that went to work this fall are to lower the budget deficit, save the pension system, control crime and finance education and health care.
Those are the same problems faced by almost every Western government.
Extremist views have little sway in Polish politics.
The previous Government, led by former Communists, was pro-NATO and so dedicated to a free market that Moody's, the financial ratings agency, informally endorsed it before the recent elections.

From the time they met in 1906, Picasso and Matisse were fiercely competitive, and ''Matisse and Picasso: A Gentle Rivalry,'' which opened last Sunday at the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, is the first major exhibition to examine their sparring.
It brings together more than 100 paintings, drawings and sculptures from around the world, juxtaposing many for the first time.
The show, which runs through May 2, will not travel.

Arranged chronologically, the exhibit picks up the rivalry around 1930, with Matisse recovering from a bout of artist's block, while Picasso was enjoying a highly productive period, even teasing his rival with parodies of his odalisques, dancers, studio scenes and other paintings.

In 1930, Matisse began working again, and Picasso, apparently fascinated by a Matisse retrospective and an exhibition of his sculptures, represented in this show by works like ''Jeannette III,'' responded with sculptures of heads and bathers and his ''sleeping beauty'' canvases, like ''Woman with Yellow Hair.''
Matisse then rose to the challenge with such paintings as ''The Dream'' from 1935, prompting Picasso's gradual mellowing toward the decorative aspects of Matisse's work.
By the end of the 1930's, the two observed a truce, with each exploring the other's pictorial language in his own terms.
During the war years, they exchanged some paintings and drawings, most of which will be on view.
In peace, the two began to meet often and exhibit together, producing works like Matisse's ''Blue Nude II'' (1952) and ''Seated Woman'' by Picasso (1953).

Finally, following Matisse's death in 1954, Picasso began to reinvent his colleague, painting elegies -- first, thematic works like ''Women of Algiers'' and then a series of empty studios reminiscent of Matisse's Vence interiors.

Several cottages that were used by Dorothy Day, a founder of the Catholic Worker movement, were bulldozed yesterday on Staten Island, despite the opposition of preservationists who had fought a developer's plans to knock them down.

The cottages were destroyed as preservationists were still holding out hope that they would be declared landmarks because of their tie to Ms. Day, who is under consideration for sainthood by the Vatican because of her work for the poor.

Before she died in 1980, Ms. Day lived in one of the modest cottages, built in the late 1940's and situated in a bungalow community known as Spanish Camp, on the South Shore neighborhood of Annadale near Raritan Bay.
But developers bought the property and began tearing down the more than 70 cottages that made up the camp, a community of people who were united by their culture and their interest in vegetarianism.

A group formed in 1998, called Friends of Dorothy Day Cottages, tried to save at least the three cottages that had once been owned by the Catholic Worker organization, which sought to help the poor and homeless.
As late as last week, the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission was in talks with John DiScala, who owned the property.
But the commission had not set a date for a landmarks hearing.
Mr. DiScala said he grew tired of waiting. ''
They never landmarked the cottages,'' Mr. DiScala said. ''
They never even had a hearing on it.
Bud Harrelson insisted yesterday that he just wanted to get started.
If the Mets could win just one game, they could win a dozen.
They could make people forget about their 10-game losing streak.
He wanted to manage last night, manage the rest of this season, manage next season in New York.
But the bad luck would not go away.
It was raining hard at Shea Stadium, so the game against the St. Louis Cardinals was postponed and became a part of a twilight-night doubleheader today.
Hubie Brooks, Harrelson's starting outfielder, was placed on the 15-day disabled list with a possible pinched nerve in the neck.
And the reporters crowded into Harrelson's office were demanding to know, with some incredulity, whether the Mets' manager really believed he would have the same job description next season.
Harrelson never flinched.
Feeling Secure "I don't feel the decision has been made," Harrelson said. "

The City Council unanimously approved a bill yesterday that increases protections for nannies and housekeepers by seeking to make sure that families who hire them know these workers' rights on overtime and other matters.

The bill, which passed 49 to 0, requires employment agencies to inform domestic workers in writing of their rights and to get families that hire them to sign statements outlining the employee's rights and the employer's responsibilities. ''
This is great,'' said Erline Brown, who has worked as a nanny for 18 years. ''
It's not going to help only the nannies, but also the employers, because it brings clarity.
There won't be so many misunderstandings.''
Advocates for domestic workers said the bill should help stop the many abuses faced by these workers.
Many domestic workers complain about being paid for 40 hours' work when they work 50- or 60-hour weeks.
Some also complain about having to work seven days in a row, about not being given any paid vacation and about not having private rooms when they are live-ins. ''
The Council has heard numerous horror stories from domestic workers,'' Council Speaker Gifford Miller said. ''
It is our hope that this bill will help put a stop to these practices.''
In a heated reaction to its first substantive discussions with the Bush administration, North Korea said today that Washington had approached the talks with a ''hard-line policy of hostility.''
The United States was also accused of seeking to ''bring North Korea to its knees by force and high-handed practices.''
The comments were made public after the assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, James A. Kelly, ended a visit to North Korea on Saturday.
He described the visit as ''frank but useful,'' which in diplomatic terms usually suggests limited progress.
The impression that the talks were difficult was heightened by Mr. Kelly's refusal to take questions during a stopover in South Korea and his cancellation of a news conference in Tokyo the next day.

In a response to the North Korean comments today, the State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said that although Washington was committed to talks with North Korea, serious difficulties remained.

Mr. Boucher said Mr. Kelly had ''raised, in a frank manner, our concerns on a full range of issues, including weapons of mass destruction, missile-development programs, missile exports, North Korea's threatening conventional force posture, human rights failings and the dire humanitarian situation.''
The two countries issued their statements as reports emerged in Japan that North Korea was considering redeploying some troops and conventional weapons along the border with South Korea.
Mr. Boucher said he could not confirm the reports, which quoted Russian diplomats as saying that North Korea was discussing the withdrawal of 20,000 to 50,000 troops from the border.
Although modest in scale, such a move would represent an important step toward satisfying a Bush administration demand.

Israel's hopes for an orderly withdrawal from its security zone in Southern Lebanon this summer were jolted yesterday by the sudden disintegration of large sections of the Southern Lebanon Army, a pro-Israeli militia.

With Syria's blessing, Lebanese Hezbollah guerrillas quickly moved into the vacuum left by the militia's collapse, seizing fortified positions laden with Israeli munitions and occupying a slice of the zone reaching to the Israeli border.
Hezbollah's advance, which seems to have caught Israel unprepared, has increased the danger to Israeli troops still in Lebanon and to Israeli civilians across the border.
Prime Minister Ehud Barak must respond to these dangers in a way that allows the Israeli withdrawal to proceed without delay.
Overnight his security cabinet authorized him to speed the withdrawal timetable, to minimize the chance for further chaos.
Meanwhile, Syria, as the dominant military power in Lebanon, must see to it that Hezbollah does not use its new positions to launch rocket attacks on Israeli territory.
Any such shellings could bring Israeli reprisals that could spread beyond the immediate border area and involve both Lebanon and Syria.
Mr. Barak promised during his election campaign last year to withdraw Israeli troops from Lebanon within a year of his taking office.
That deadline runs out in early July.
Most Israelis oppose maintaining the 22-year-old security zone.
EVERY bartender has a story -- typically delivered with an aggrieved rolling of the eyes -- about a customer who drank way beyond his capacity, shorted a fuse in the brain and passed out.
But Chris Schlesinger, the chef at the East Coast Grill in Cambridge, Mass., tells one with a twist.
His customer passed out after the night's first drink, and it wasn't necessarily the alcohol that felled him.

This happened last year during one of the restaurant's infamous Hell Nights, when the menu is taken over by dishes -- and cocktails -- so hot and loaded with chilies that even Schlesinger admits they're ''inedible.'' (
The next Hell Nights are scheduled for Oct. 30 to Nov. 1.)

To accompany the culinary infernos, diners can pick from the Martini From Hell, a vodka martini made with habanero-infused Absolut; the Margarita From Hell, mixed with a similarly infused tequila; or knock back a shot of the atomic vodka. ''
He just passed out in the bathroom,'' Mr. Schlesinger recalled of the fallen customer. ''
We couldn't figure it out.
The E.M.T.'s came and put him back together, and he ended up staying for dinner.
I guess he just had a reaction to it.''
Don't depend on rain for transplants, annuals or container plants.
Plants without enough water will be under stress and subject to marauding insects.
Insufficient water will also encourage the growth of surface roots, making plants vulnerable to drought.
If you are uncertain how long to water trees, shrubs and roses, water early in the morning, as you would normally to conserve water, then dig into the soil in the evening.
If only the top six inches are moist, double the watering time to reach deeper to the roots.
Cut roses for indoors, and begin deadheading spent blooms, both to maintain appearance and to spur repeat blooming.
Removing spent flowers and watering in the morning also minimize outbreaks of fungal disease.
Rose experts report that spraying leaves with Miracid helps control the spread of black spot.
Mix as recommended for fertilizing, and test on a few healthy leaves.
If there is no sign of burn after several days, spray every 7 to 10 days and only when temperatures are below 80 degrees.

If you want to catch wild trout without burning a pile of calories, Wyoming's Wind River Mountain Range, where granite peaks thrust 13,000 feet into the sky and its fish grow to massive proportions, is not the place to be.
The Wind River Range, which stretches 100 miles across western Wyoming's sage-covered expanse, is considered some of the most remote and beautiful terrain in North America.
Pine trees and aspens cover the foothills until those granite monoliths take over.

But most of its trout lakes rest in designated wilderness areas, five or more miles away from roads, attainable only via foot power or horsepower, the kind that doesn't come with a set of reins and spurs.
As I recently found, the Winds require a measure of dedication and a healthy dose of lung power to appreciate.

During a trek into any of the Wind River's 200 or so lakes, anglers may be required to negotiate several thousand feet of elevation gain, accompanied by a 40-pound backpack and maybe a blister or two.
Those who prefer their angling with a bottle of wine and a plate of cheese and crackers resting on the tailgate need not apply.
But do keep in mind, remote lakes don't see much, if any, angling pressure and the trout contained within them grow to large size.
The Winds hold rainbow, brook, cutthroat and golden trout, and all achieve or even exceed the magical 20-inch mark, a length that separates a nice western trout from a true hog.

And the Wind Rivers remain one of the last bastions for golden trout, a fish so painted in pastel, a combination of subtle gold and orange, highlighted by a penetrating red slash, that they become almost impossible to describe accurately.
November's last dinner and December's first, a densely spiced curried lamb with yogurt, would normally invite a cold lager beer, but two untasted Castello di Borghese reds beckoned more persuasively.
First, because reds become increasingly a comfort food as the calendar winds down.
And, second, because watching Marco Borghese's wine style acquire definition as he moves away from his property's former Hargrave Vineyard tendencies is an interesting exercise.

Inexperienced in the wine business, the new owner, on assuming responsibility for the local wine industry's founding estate, imposed a burden on himself to succeed, fast, on its own terms -- no easy chore.
Castello di Borghese is not a shy pricer.
Its 1999 cabernet sauvignon reserve is $30.
The 2000 Meritage Red Table Wine is $45.
Both reds are ready for immediate drinking.
Dark, somber and with an herbal bouquet, the cabernet sauvignon had what critics like to call good varietal definition, which means the wine tastes exactly the way it is supposed to taste.
The cabernet, almost sweet in the bouquet, is mouth-filling and offers softening tannins, the aroma of pencil shavings, beetlike flourishes, a pleasing oakiness and a long finish.
An astonishing victory emerged from the Royal Viking Instant Matchpoint game, which was organized by the American Contract Bridge League and played in clubs throughout North America Thursday night.
The winners, playing at the Winfield Hall Club in Westchester, Pa., were Carole Siegel, who has 20 master points, and Susan Strauss, who has none at all and does not belong to the national group.
They scored almost 75 percent in the North-South line, and are surely the least experienced pair ever to win on such an occasion.

The East-West winners, with 73 percent, were Bill Cook and Annette McHann of Jackson, Miss. The best scores in the New York metropolitan area were: North-South, Gladys Collier of East Hampton, L.I., and Albert Barbanel of Riverhead, L.I., with 67 percent; and East-West, Robert and Hanneke Gold of Amagansett, L.I., with 65 percent.
On the diagramed deal, North normally overcalled the weak two-spade opening with four no-trump, showing both minor suits.
If South guessed to bid five clubs rather than five diamonds the play was tricky.
If West led his singleton diamond to the queen and ace, East had to return a spade, resisting the temptation to give his partner a ruff.
South could then win in his hand and lead the diamond ten, tempting West to ruff.
He had to throw a heart, not a spade, so that he could throw another heart if South won the diamond king and ruffed a diamond with the club queen.
With that defense South failed.
It was time to leave the ice, but the Italian hockey team would not halt its spirited scrimmage in a mountaintop practice rink.
French officials wearing badges on astronaut jackets climbed above the Plexiglas, pointed to the clock, and told Coach Gene Ubriaco to remove his squad to the locker room.
Ubriaco paid no attention.
There was still so much to learn before the tournament opener Sunday against the United States. "
They'll try to push you wide," Ubriaco told the team in English, and his warning about the Americans was translated into Italian by an assistant coach, Alberto Darin. "
You've got to keep your heads."
Ubriaco used to coach in Pittsburgh, before the Penguins fired him two seasons ago and Mario Lemieux called him "a minor league coach for 15 years, who will always be a minor league coach."
Ubriaco still bristles a bit at that, reminds people that the Penguins "had talent up the wazoo" when they won the Stanley Cup without him last year.
But nothing looks so bad to him from an Alpine peak. '
The One You Dream About' Ubriaco is now a Canadian citizen unofficially residing in Lutherville, Md., coaching Italy in a tournament in Meribel, France, against the United States.
Nikolaj Hubbe's triumphal debut in the title role of "Apollo" at the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night was an obvious focus of interest.
But the entire program -- devoted to Balanchine and Stravinsky -- was a highlight of the season. "
Apollo" (1928), "Orpheus" (1948) and "Agon" (1957) have been seen together before.
But rarely have these three entries in the company's Greek trilogy (agon means contest in Greek) look so integrated. "
Apollo" was performed with the opening scene that Balanchine had cut in the late 1970's, now restored.
Aura Dixon, seated on a platform and rotating her hair in the air, gave birth to Apollo; Mr. Hubbe, torso swaddled, popped out from under her platform as an oversized infant.
Unlike his fellow Danes who have danced the role in the past, Mr. Hubbe does not strive for a noble image.
His young sun god is rough-hewn, forceful from the start.
His phrasing gathers power from a mix of naturalism and classical form but it is an approach that works better in his second solo than the first.
Punching his fist into the air and narrowing his eyes, Mr. Hubbe builds his dancing with increasing intensity in that final variation.
For almost two decades, the 149-year-old Trinity Lower East Side Lutheran Parish has been a church without a home.
In 1975, its building at 139 Avenue B, at Ninth Street, in Manhattan (but not the brownstone parish house next door) was demolished because of structural problems.
Services since have since been at held in a small rented room at 630 East Sixth Street.
This fall, though, the parish will begin construction of a new church on the site of the old one.
The three-story, $900,000 structure will have a 100-seat chapel and a community center adjoining the parish house.

The building will also permit an expansion of the soup kitchen, which now operates out of the parish house, and there will be room for an after-school program, services for the homeless and a pastor's residence. "
It is a masonry building with materials from the neighborhood, used old brick and an assortment of concrete block," said Robert Litchfield of Manhattan, the architect for the project.
About $200,000 has been raised through church contributions thus far.
The church is also asking for contributions from other Lutheran churches in the area. "
We are optimistic about raising the rest," said C. Carlson, a spokesperson for the church. "
George Balanchine's production of "The Nutcracker" worked its magic once again when the New York City Ballet danced it on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.
As usual, the children in the audience gasped at its fantastical stagecraft.
But what made the performance especially interesting for grownups was the opportunity to see a new cast in the leading roles.
The Sugarplum Fairy can be interpreted in several ways.
Some dancers turn her into a dainty sprite.
Monique Meunier, in contrast, resembled a glamorous and gracious hostess presiding over an elegant party.
She was especially at ease in the choreography's grandly scaled sequences.
Although she made the jewel-like steps in her solo clear, they could have been sharper and more sparkling.
But her pas de deux with Erlends Zieminch had a spaciousness marred only by an apparent tension in her neck and shoulders.
Mr. Zieminch was exuberant in the Cavalier's few solo passages.
Anita Nall had it all.
In the spring of 1992, at age 15, she was a world-record-breaking swimmer.
Less than five months later, she won a gold, a silver and a bronze medal at the Barcelona Olympics.
That winter, she became sick.
She had no energy, she was always tired.
It took almost a year and a half to learn that her trouble came, not from mononucleosis or anemia or worse, but from an iron deficiency.
Now, three weeks after she turned 18, Nall feels good again.
Tonight, on the second day of the Phillips 66 national championships and world championship trials, she faced a major hurdle.
She did not quite clear it.
The race was the women's 200-meter breast-stroke final.
Because of the wiring of his brain, Ozem Goldwire must account for every minute in an hour.
Asked what happened on the day he came home from work in January 2006 and found his sister dead in bed, Mr. Goldwire reports that his alarm went off at 5 a.m., and he took the B-20 bus at 6:18. ''
I got to work at 7:04,'' he says, and so his narrative spools, one precise moment after the next, until he gets off the bus at night and opens the door to his house in Brooklyn.
A man possessed of normal intelligence and above-normal politeness, Mr. Goldwire, 28, has a ''developmental disability with autistic features,'' his school records show.
Though he now speaks in the deep tones of an old-time broadcaster, at the age of 6 he had not yet uttered a complete sentence.
On Jan. 3, 2006, he confessed to strangling his sister, an act of violence that all who know him say would have been completely out of character, had he really done it.
Last week, at the request of his lawyer, Gary Farrell, and a Brooklyn assistant district attorney, Robert Lamb, a judge dismissed the case and said Mr. Goldwire was ''actually innocent.''
How did an innocent man come to confess, and conversely, how has the guilty person gotten away with murder?
There is no record of the interrogation of Mr. Goldwire.
He was in custody for 17 hours and questioned by six detectives before he gave an incriminating statement.
As a 5-year-old during the Korean War, Dr. Jong Wook Lee had to walk 250 miles for 60 days through snow, ice and bitter cold with his mother and two brothers.
They marched to join Dr. Lee's father, a civil servant who had earlier been sent from Seoul to Taegu.

The trek left the Lee family so scrawny that ''my father thought we were beggars when he first saw us walking down the street,'' said Dr. Lee, 58, who became the World Health Organization's sixth director general here today. ''
The first thing he did was take us to a bakery for cookies,'' said Dr. Lee. ''
I cried.''
His father's reaction was understandable because many other people were begging at the time, Dr. Lee recalled as a fan tried to cool his temporary office on a hot, humid day.
The lasting impression of the episode and the hardship and poverty he has witnessed led Dr. Lee to champion the poor.
In a series of interviews over recent days, Dr. Lee described himself as ''a doer'' who prefers colleagues who are more interested in rolling up their sleeves than collecting degrees.

He plans to rely on such ''doers'' to make the W.H.O. a more active and visible player in the health arena and is asking his aides to improve the ways that staff can rotate between Geneva and member countries during their careers.
One reason for moving staff into the field is to help improve the vital statistics that form the backbone of health systems.

Last week's wave of confrontations between Israeli settlers and security forces had many tactical hallmarks of the protests of the 1960's -- the deliberate acts of civil disobedience, the passive resistance before the police.
That was no coincidence.
The rabbi of the demonstrators was an American veteran of civil rights marches in Selma, Ala., and some of the most militant protesters were also immigrants from the United States.

Rabbi Shlomo Riskin, the charismatic former leader of the Lincoln Square Synagogue in Manhattan, has recently emerged as one of the staunchest opponents of the Government's proposal to give Palestinians control over much of the West Bank.

He and other members of his community have given the resistance a distinctly American accent, not only in their Hebrew, but also in the modern camping tents, Coleman camping stoves and portable toilets that they used to occupy contested hilltops in the West Bank.
Indeed, Efrat, the settlement just south of Bethlehem that Rabbi Riskin helped found and now serves as chief rabbi, is a distinctly yuppie variant of the Israeli settlements that dot the West Bank.

A large number of the 1,200 families who inhabit the neat rows of tile-roofed stucco houses are immigrants from the United States, many of them physicians and other professionals who commute to jobs in Jerusalem.

But behind the familiar patina of suburbia is a determination as fierce as in any other West Bank settlement to block the Government from giving away lands that the settlers regard as intrinsically Jewish.
The basic tactic of the demonstrators last week, organized by a group of women from Efrat, consisted of occupying vacant hilltops in the West Bank and getting evicted by security forces.
The "battle of the hills," rich in emotion, dominated the news all week, and quieted only when the demonstrators agreed to a truce for the Sabbath and the Jewish holiday of Tisha b'Av on Sunday.
The bright promise of last year's Good Friday agreement turned into tangible political reality on Thursday with the inauguration of Northern Ireland's new power-sharing cabinet.
For the first time, political authority in the province is equitably apportioned between its Protestant and Roman Catholic communities.

Following a carefully negotiated timetable, Britain transferred home rule powers to Belfast, Ireland gave up its constitutional claim to the North, and the Irish Republican Army named a senior officer to join the independent panel in charge of assuring disarmament of the province's private militias.
Presumably, the I.R.A. will follow this step by beginning to turn over its arsenal of guns and bombs, a process it is obliged to complete by May 2000.
Past efforts to end sectarian violence in Ulster proved disappointing.
But no earlier initiative was as inclusive as this and none progressed so far.
Northern Ireland now has its best chance in more than a generation to move from fear and economically paralyzing turmoil to a future premised on hope and pragmatic cooperation for the common good.

Considerable praise for this achievement should go to former Senator George Mitchell, whose patient mediation taught leaders on both sides of the religious divide to talk to each other directly for the first time and thereby begin to build up a modest degree of personal trust.
But the main credit must go to Northern Ireland's political leaders themselves, particularly John Hume, David Trimble and Gerry Adams.
Mr. Hume, from the Social Democratic and Labor Party, Ulster's largest Catholic group, played a decisive role in encouraging the I.R.A. to move away from terror toward electoral politics.
The Nets were not a depressed team after their 95-89 loss to the Bulls in Chicago on Saturday night.
Incredibly enough, they were somewhat buoyant.
A loss is a loss, but sometimes there are good ways to lose.
New Jersey hung with the Bulls, the National Basketball Association's defending champions, until the final six minutes of the game.
At that point, Michael Jordan picked up the defensive intensity and the other Bulls followed his lead.
The Nets, still without Derrick Coleman, wilted under the pressure and lost.
Jordan, as he often does, led all scorers with 38 points.
Forward Scottie Pippen had 15 and center Bill Cartwright had 12 for Chicago.
The Nets were led by Drazen Petrovic, who scored 25 points. "
A win is a win," said Jordan. "
And so, after Al Pirro's federal tax fraud trial and Jeanine Pirro's closer-than-expected re-election as district attorney, we find Westchester's power couple heading back to the future.
Or is the present looking a lot like the past?

Mr. Pirro, 54, plans to return to the office of his powerful lobbying firm in White Plains on Monday, after spending 11 months in a minimum-security federal prison camp in Florida that left him buff from weight lifting and running.
His 29-month sentence was cut short a year for good behavior and completing a drug and alcohol treatment program, and he must now live the next six months in a halfway house in the Bronx.
But nobody, not even critics, expects that to diminish his luster among his powerful fans.

His wife, Jeanine Pirro, 50, the charismatic and newly re-elected district attorney, whose future political aspirations are an open question, shows little sign of slowing down, the very thought bringing out a chuckle in one ally.

She is continuing to go after sexual predators on the Internet -- a priest she prosecuted was sentenced to jail this week for soliciting sex with a boy online -- and she finds herself embroiled in new political controversies involving the resignation of a top aide to the Democratic county executive, Andrew J. Spano.
Somehow, the doom and gloom of prognosticators over the Pirros' future in light of Mr. Pirro's legal troubles appear to be fading fast. ''
My sense is he is going to pick up where he left off,'' said Bennett L. Gershman, a law professor at Pace University who has closely followed the Pirro case. ''
I don't see any appreciable difference in the way he conducts his business, his lifestyles, his contacts.
WEDNESDAY -- The New York Public Library raised $250,000 at its fifth Table of Contents, an evening of private dinners on various themes.
This year there were 66 dinners in private homes, in restaurants and in museums.
Sonny Sloan, one of the originators of the idea 10 years ago, gave an Algonquin round-table dinner in her Park Avenue apartment.
Timothy and Anne Forbes gave a dinner at the Forbes Magazine Galleries on Fifth Avenue near 12th Street; Christopher Forbes filled in as host for his brother Timothy, who was ill with a cold.
TUESDAY -- The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater benefited from a supper dance at the New York Hilton to celebrate the world premiere of its new work "Rift."
George Stevens Jr., the Emmy Award-winning producer, was the honored guest at the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund dinner at the Board Room Club, Park Avenue at 48th Street.

MONDAY -- For the first time the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art held its annual fund-raising dinner-dance without an accompanying costume exhibition because the Costume Institute's galleries are closed.
An exhibition is promised for next Christmas.
The party began with 500 guests for dinner, and 1,000 more guests arrived after dinner for Champagne and dancing.
Prompted by an entry in Senator Bob Packwood's diaries, the Senate Ethics Committee is examining whether Senator Phil Gramm illegally diverted $100,000 to Mr. Packwood's 1992 re-election campaign.

The committee asked Mr. Gramm late Thursday for an explanation for the entry, which describes a meeting between the two men and concludes that they may have been skirting a law that limits the amount of general campaign money that a political party spends on a particular candidate's race.
In response, Mr. Gramm, Republican of Texas, wrote the committee today that he had done nothing improper and that the diary entry "reflects a misunderstanding of the election law."
He also cited Ethics Committee testimony in which Mr. Packwood, disavowing the accuracy of the entry, said that any suggestion that a law had been broken "was simply wrong."

At the time of the entry, on March 6, 1992, Mr. Gramm headed the National Republican Senatorial Committee, a party fund-raising arm, and Mr. Packwood faced a tough re-election challenge in Oregon from Representative Les AuCoin.

Mr. Packwood said in that passage, which was made public by the Ethics Committee on Thursday along with many other excerpts from the diaries, that in a brief meeting Mr. Gramm "again promised $100,000 for party-building activities." "
And what was said in that room would be enough to convict us all of something," Mr. Packwood continued. "
He says, 'Now, of course, you know there can't be any legal connection between this money and Senator Packwood, but we know that it will be used for his benefit.'
[ Name deleted by Ethics Committee ]  said, 'Oh, yes.' "
Referring to one of his aides, Elaine Franklin, Mr. Packwood went on: "God, there's Elaine and I sitting there.
WHEN Jesse Powers-Patey was 10, and living in foster care, a Boston television station did a ''Wednesday's Child'' feature on him, in hopes of getting the boy adopted.
A local newspaper printed an article emphasizing his friendliness and love for baseball.
Still, no family responded.
By then, he'd been to six schools, could barely read and was in special education.
He'd lived in a homeless shelter with his drug-addicted birth mother and in eight foster homes.
At 4, he was adopted by a single mother, but when he was 8, that woman returned him to the state.
She claimed that he was hard to manage.
Jesse said, ''She dumped me because she was getting married and moving into a big house and the guy didn't want me around.''
Finally, one couple who heard about Jesse at their church showed an interest: Laura Patey and Leigh Powers.
The two began going to his baseball games, then having him visit their place, a few blocks from his foster home.
N 1994, 16 million women who had voted in the 1992 presidential election stayed home.
The campaigning was nasty and negative, and these ''drop-off'' women -- women with jobs, children, aging parents, busy lives -- found no compelling reason to cast ballots.
The unanswered question for 2006 is whether such drop-off women will vote.
Since women disproportionately vote for Democrats, their decision could determine which party will control the next Congress.
Getting women to the polls won't be easy.
The demands on their time and the pressures on their families can overwhelm any interest in politics.
But we can convince them to vote by talking about issues that directly affect their families and showing them how voting for Democrats -- especially women candidates -- can make a difference.
They'll be receptive to Democratic policies like protecting Social Security, making college affordable and finding an end to the morass in Iraq.
If Democrats -- party leaders, candidates and progressive allies -- communicate with enough women, we can counter negative Republican campaigns that aim to get women to stay home.
Women will find a reason to vote.

The Olympic Alpine skier Picabo Street announced her retirement last spring, but she made it official today at a teary ceremony at the Chevy Truck America's Opening, this year's first World Cup stop on American soil.
Street took one last ceremonial run down the World Cup course.
At the finish line, the president of the United States Ski Association, Bill Marolt, presented her with a ski team letter jacket, an honor reserved for team alumni.
Surrounded by friends and family, Street, 31, watched her career highlights on a video screen, grinning at clips of her Nagano gold medal run and wincing at her horrendous crash in 1998. ''
Those videos are tough,'' she said. ''
It tugs on my cords and in 15 seconds I'm crying.
By the time it's done I'm thinking I shouldn't have worn mascara.
It's tough to absorb it.
I just want to be worthy of it.''
Street smiled as a scrum of young girls swarmed around her for autographs. ''
Christmas and commerce at the Roxbury Mall are mixed this year with threats of sniper fire, extra police patrols, bitter merchants, jittery shoppers and the angry residue of financial trouble.

Someone shot out at least 14 windows at the mall late one November night and -- a few days later -- left on car windshields, in neighborhood mailboxes and at the Shop Rite supermarket about 100 hand-lettered fliers warning shoppers of sniper fire during business hours. "
Your life will be in danger," the leaflets said. "
This is your only warning!"

The police say the shootings and the leaflets are the work of one or two among the 100 or so subcontractors who helped enlarge the mall from 14 to 46 stores 15 months ago and have not been paid for about $5 million worth of work and material.
No More Gunfire No one has been hurt so far, and there has been no more gunfire in the night.
But an edgy mood prevails among shoppers and store managers, part bravado and defiance and part anxiety. "
No way I'm saying anything," said the owner of a card shop. "
This is the time of year that makes or breaks us for the whole year, and it's lousy that this is coming up now." "
We're just sitting here like dead ducks," said another shopkeeper who sought anonymity. "
Norm Alvis is one of America's best international bicycle riders.

From 1988 to 1994, he rode for the 7-Eleven team and its successor, Motorola, and in 1990 he helped his teammate, Steve Bauer of Canada, keep the leader's yellow jersey in the Tour de France for 10 days even though Alvis finished only 134th.
Today, in the 11th annual Core States United States professional championship, Bauer unintentionally repaid the favor to Alvis, who now rides for the Saturn team.
With 19 miles remaining in the 156-mile race, Bauer slammed his brakes to avoid what might have been a recreational rider and went flying over the handlebars.
By the time Bauer got back into the race, the field was gone.
It was too late for teammates to drag behind to help him catch up because they were trying to help their team star and race favorite, Lance Armstrong, win.
Armstrong did take the lead moments later.
But near the end, his other teammates had fallen behind, and Bauer was not there to provide a slipstream to save Armstrong's energy for the final miles.
The 31-year-old Alvis, now living in Colorado Springs, had a teammate with him in Brian Walton of Canada.
Walton, as a teammate should, helped Alvis win.
THE presidency of the European Union will rotate anew on Tuesday.
Since it does so every six months, the change is a formality often greeted with glazed eyes and gargantuan yawns.

But this time around, the prospect quickens the pulse, at least for anyone who relishes political soap opera, because Italy's imminent turn at the helm -- technically, it will be head of the union's Council of Ministers -- is sure to provide a sudsy bounty of drama.

With his government leading the council from July through December, Silvio Berlusconi, the current Italian prime minister, will be expected to link arms and cooperate with Romano Prodi, a former Italian prime minister who already presides over the other main branch of the European Union's government, the European Commission.
There is a minor, tiny, pesky kink.
Mr. Berlusconi and Mr. Prodi are past and probably future political rivals, and they appear to abhor each other.
This clash has potentially serious implications for the European Union, which faces some especially difficult bits of business, like the drafting of its first constitution.

But the clash also, on a juicier and more aesthetically engrossing note, brings together two men who almost perfectly represent opposite poles of political style, competing sides of the Italian character and conflicting strains of European political thought.

To wax Rumsfeldian and rather broad, Mr. Prodi might be cast as a contemplative, well-mannered citizen of the old Europe, while Mr. Berlusconi blusters into the picture as a convention-smashing adventurer in the New World. ''
It will be fun to watch,'' said Giuliano Ferrara, a friend of Mr. Berlusconi's who edits a conservative newspaper here. ''

After months of dealing in broad concepts, the planners of the new World Trade Center are devising guidelines that will prescribe the actual forms of the buildings -- in inches and feet, metal and stone.

A recent draft of the guidelines by Studio Daniel Libeskind, the master planners of the site, dictated the shape and size of every office tower so precisely that other architects would have had little leeway to pursue significantly different designs of their own.

While those proposed controls have already been relaxed, with more changes to come, the draft offers unusually detailed glimpses of features that are often overlooked -- including museum buildings that would overhang the footprints of the twin towers.

Mr. Libeskind has proposed to ''buffer the memorial space from the everyday activities of the city'' by extending one museum, like a bridge, over the site of the north tower and cantilevering another museum above the site of the south tower.
This is not a new idea.
But seeing it rendered in a diagram is likely to surprise anyone who thought the footprints would be unimpeded, as many families of Sept. 11 victims have demanded.
As it happens, these overhanging museums and a proposed waterfall may disappear entirely under an independent design for the memorial.
Eight prospective memorial plans are to be unveiled in two weeks.
What is not likely to go away is a large ramp along Liberty Street leading to the service roads under the trade center.
It would be separated from the memorial by a 60-foot-wide green space.
On Saturday, Monica Seles is scheduled to step back onto the world stage for the first time since a knife-wielding stalker stabbed her during a tennis match more than two years ago.
That sort of danger is not new to athletes or other high-profile celebrities, but it is increasingly in the spotlight as the lunatic fringe becomes more aggressive in its thirst for attention.
All sports must deal with the increased aggression of a public that no longer covets, but demands, a certain intimacy with its heroes.

A breach of security at the Dallas Cowboys' training camp last week enabled a woman to run onto the field after quarterback Troy Aikman, a nationally televised incident that forced the football team to define and defend its security system.

No professional sport has a bigger security headache than Major League Baseball, according to John Lane, the founder of Los Angeles's Threat Management Unit, the nation's most longstanding anti-stalker police unit.

All sports face what he called a three-headed monster -- identifying, investigating and warding off the deranged and the dangerous -- and baseball handles it better than any other sport, says Lane, a Los Angeles police lieutenant and 23-year veteran. "

Kevin Hallinan of the Commissioner's office and the baseball people are certainly aware of these kinds of issues and certainly are prepared to do something about it," Lane said, referring to baseball's head of security. "
Baseball is more aggressive in this area than the other sports."
Baseball needs to be.
For no sport conducts its business in open arenas so frequently, or puts its athletes, coaches, managers and even its management and labor executives on display away from the ball parks so often.
It's summertime, you've rented your house on Long Beach Island, resolved not to cook, and now you wonder where to go for good food.
You can waste time and confuse yourself by paging through The SandPaper or you can try to figure out where the locals eat.
This year, Barry Baxter prepared for his 19th summer at Barry's Do Me A Flavor in Beach Haven by hanging a new ceiling and giving the place some cozy wainscoting.
He rehung his mounted trophy fish along with dozens of photographs of generations of local characters.
But the children lined up on bicycles provide the best clue that this is a favorite spot of those who know where to go.
Order at the counter, grab a table inside or outside and wait for your tray.
Mr. Baxter's mother is responsible for many of the recipes, including Pat's Famous Friday Pot Roast Special ($8.95 with gravy, choice of potato and coleslaw).
No offering at the Shore would be complete without cheese steaks, burgers and hoagies.
Barry's house special cheese steak hoagie has half an eight-ounce hamburger on either side of the hoagie for $6.95.
Other sandwiches and wraps cost $3.95 -- $5.95 when served as platters; chicken, flounder or shrimp (with fries and coleslaw) are $8.95, and $10.95.

A few minutes after Gary Sheffield said yesterday that Major League Baseball should strongly penalize fans who interfere with players or infringe on their safety, the Boston Red Sox announced punishments for two fans who were involved in an incident with Sheffield at Fenway Park last Thursday.
The Red Sox said they would revoke the season tickets of Chris House, who reached over the three-foot-high fence in right field and touched Sheffield as he was trying to field a ball.
Team officials also said that a second fan, who dumped beer on Sheffield, would not be permitted to buy tickets this season. ''
That just proves one thing: I wasn't in the wrong,'' Sheffield said. ''
That's what this is all about.
You try to represent the game the right way.
But then being told that you're in the wrong for something you didn't start -- that's disturbing.
That just makes me feel like this is a hypocritical society.''
Sheffield is scheduled to meet today with Bob Watson, the vice president for discipline in the commissioner's office, to discuss his role in the incident.
Rufus Williams, Sheffield's business manager, and Lonn Trost, the Yankees' chief operating officer, will also attend the meeting at Yankee Stadium.
Four months from now, the world's population is expected to hit six billion.
Although it will continue to soar for decades to come, the population would be far higher if the last 30 years had not brought a significant drop in fertility in many regions.
The drop is not surprising in rich countries and newly wealthy East Asian nations such as Taiwan and Singapore.
More remarkable is the fertility drop in Latin America.
A Times article last week detailed the change in Mexico, and similar gains have been made throughout the region.
In the mid-1960's, Latin American women averaged more than 6 children.
Today the average is 2.9.
The benefits of smaller families are seen not only in a better life for children and their parents, but also in an increased savings rate and less cost to the state.
Latin America today is not markedly wealthier than in 1965.
But its women have much higher levels of education, access to health care and employment.
While cold-war frost still chills U.S. diplomacy in Korea, Japan and North Korea have begun breaking the ice.
Their first round of talks on normalizing relations ended inconclusively last week.
But North Korea's new flexibility offers promise when talks resume next month.
Washington now needs to follow Tokyo's lead, establishing ties with the North and scaling down its military exercises and nuclear arsenal in Korea.
The Japan-North Korea talks are the latest warming sign in northeast Asian diplomacy.
Last September, South Korea opened full diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.
A month later it signed a commercial treaty with China.
Now North Korea is reaching out.
Two differences are holding up ties between Tokyo and Pyongyang.
Japan has formally apologized for its brutal colonial domination from 1910 until 1945.
