ONE of the biographical facts emerging from the exhibition ''Fifty Years of Beetle Bailey'' at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center is that the creator of the long-lived comic strip, Mort Walker, lives in what was formerly the Stamford studio of Gutzon Borglum.
It was Borglum who created the figures on Mount Rushmore and, likewise, Mr. Walker has created a durable American icon.
Comic strips are strangely potent cultural presences.
Because many people encounter them every day in a newspaper, the characters take on a real life.
Even when one no longer reads the funnies, a chance reference can summon a wealth of memories and associations.
Moreover, even people who have never read the major comic strips know who the main characters are. ''
Beetle Bailey'' is certainly one of these creations.

Like Dagwood with his tall sandwiches and tufts of hair and Snoopy on top of his doghouse, there is a wide familiarity with the lanky man, still a boy really, who has stayed a private in the army for half a century.
The exhibition is delightful entertainment because it is so engagingly presented.
Mr. Walker himself drew the large panels, complete with ''name, rank and trivia,'' that chronicle when each major character entered -- or, in his appropriate term, enlisted in -- the strip.
A PART-BLACK, part-Chinese lesbian immigrant from Jamaica, Staceyann Chin finds poetry in belonging everywhere and no place in particular. ''
I was born with an otherness attached to me,'' said Ms. Chin, a thin 32-year-old with a fat cloud of dark, kinky hair.
She sat on an overstuffed sofa in her Crown Heights apartment on a day off from her new Off Broadway show, ''Border/Clash: A Litany of Desires,'' an autobiographical, one-woman play. ''
I never belong to any one space, but I have a place in all the others' spaces,'' she added in her pronounced Jamaican lilt. ''
The gay-lesbian community is so white here.
I am in the black community, but I am queer.
I have a foot in the Asian community.''

As her fans from Broadway, where she stood out in ''Russell Simmons Def Poetry Jam,'' or devotees from her early days at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe probably know by now, Ms. Chin was born into poverty and abandoned by her parents.
Growing up an outsider, a smart, light-skinned girl who loved girls, floating in a sea of dark bodies that embraced convention and questioned her choices, she imagined New York as a kind of refuge.
And in 1997, she came to claim her place in it.

James Patrick Cooney, a retired major general who was one of the Army's top authorities on radiology and the medical effects of atomic explosions, died on Tuesday at Wesley Woods Health Center in Atlanta.
He was 90.
His son, Dr. James P. Cooley Jr., dean of the College of Health Sciences at Georgia State University, said the cause was complications related to Alzheimer's disease.
At the close of World War II, General Cooney served as medical director of a special mission to Japan to study the effects of the atomic bomb on the survivors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
Later, as a radiologist attached to the Atomic Energy Commission, he lectured widely on the biological effects of radiation from atomic explosions.
General Cooney served for 33 years with the Army Medical Corps.
He became Deputy Surgeon General of the Army in 1955 and chief surgeon of the United States forces in Europe in 1959.
Retiring from the military in 1960, he was named vice president for medical affairs of the American Cancer Society in New York City.
He moved to Atlanta in 1969.
He was born in Parnell, Iowa, and received his medical degree from the University of Iowa in 1927.
For three years, Rocky Butler practiced behind Hofstra's record-setting quarterback, Giovanni Carmazzi.
If you could call it practice.
Butler took about 10 percent of the snaps during workouts and got occasional mop-up duty in games. ''
I was taking mental reps,'' Butler said today.
All that brainwork apparently translated onto the field.
In his first season as a starter, Butler has guided Hofstra to the exact place where it was last year with Carmazzi: in the Division I-AA quarterfinals.
The 11th-seeded Pride (9-3) visits No.
3-seeded and defending champion Georgia Southern (10-2) on Saturday in Statesboro, Ga. One reason Hofstra thinks it can end Georgia Southern's 30-game home winning streak is Butler's development.

His statistics are comparable to Carmazzi's in 1999, when Hofstra's career passing-yardage leader earned all-American honors before the San Francisco 49ers drafted him in the third round of the National Football League draft this past April.
Butler completed 162 of 286 passes for 2,341 yards and 22 touchdowns (with 9 interceptions) despite missing nearly two games because of a shoulder sprain.
To the Editor: ''Are There Any Iraqis in Iraq?''
asks the headline for Thomas L. Friedman's April 8 column.
Of course there are.
They were always there.
And they are the only ones who can bring democracy to Iraq.
But they have to want and ask for help; we can't shove it at them.
Has any democracy ever been created by outside intervention?
No, they all evolved from within.
Our efforts in Iraq were doomed from conception, as well as being unrelated to 9/11.
The first President Bush must have known that we couldn't create democracy in Iraq.

The United Nations admitted yesterday that misjudgments and deliberate evasions had marred its handling of a videotape related to the kidnapping of three Israeli soldiers last October by Arab guerrillas in Lebanon.

But United Nations investigators said the tape, which was made one day after the abduction and showed armed guerrillas with two suspected getaway cars, did not contain information about the kidnapping itself, or shed light on the condition of the three Israelis.
Secretary General Kofi Annan, who had ordered the investigation, said in a statement after the report's release that he regretted the errors by United Nations staff members.
The release of the 18-page report appeared to end one of the more contentious episodes in the often troubled relations between the United Nations and Israel.
Israel's ambassador to the United Nations, Yehuda Lancry, expressed satisfaction with the inquiry.
In an abrupt change of tone from previous Israeli assessments of the United Nations' handling of the matter, he said the report was done in a ''rigorous way.''
Mr. Lancry also said Israel would accept a United Nations offer to view an edited version of the video, with the faces of the guerrillas obscured.
Israel had insisted on seeing an undoctored version.
He explained the change of heart as a response to what he called Mr. Annan's good will.
Israel still believes the videotape may contain valuable data about the abduction, he added. ''
The Iraqi cabinet approved a draft of a law on Monday that would set guidelines for nationwide distribution of oil revenues and foreign investment in the immense oil industry.
The endorsement reflected a major agreement among the country's ethnic and sectarian political blocs on one of Iraq's most divisive issues.

The draft law approved by the cabinet allows the central government to distribute oil revenues to the provinces or regions based on population, which could lessen the economic concerns of the rebellious Sunni Arabs, who fear being cut out of Iraq's vast potential oil wealth by the dominant Shiites and Kurds.
Most of Iraq's crude oil reserves lie in the Shiite south and Kurdish north.

The law also grants regional oil companies or governments the power to sign contracts with foreign companies for exploration and development of fields, opening the door for investment by foreign companies in a country whose oil reserves rank among the world's three largest.

Iraqi officials say dozens of major foreign companies, including ones based in the United States, Russia and China, have expressed strong interest in developing fields or have done some work with the Iraqi industry.

The national oil law would allow regions to enter into production-sharing agreements with foreign companies, which some Iraqis say could lead to foreigners reaping too much of the country's oil wealth.

Iraqi officials say all such contracts will be subjected to a fair bidding process, but American inspectors have reported that the upper echelons of the government, including the senior ranks of the Oil Ministry, are rife with corruption.
There are also fears among non-Americans that American companies could be favored.
But oil industry analysts in the United States say it is unclear whether companies will rush to sign contracts because the law is vague about what legal protections investors would be given.

Ending months of speculation and intense competition among the world's leading investment bankers, Goldman, Sachs & Company was named today to coordinate the sale of Deutsche Telekom, the state telephone monopoly, to investors outside Germany.

The appointment will mean huge investment banking fees for Goldman as the sale of Deutsche Telekom, valued at up to $60 billion, will be the largest privatization in Europe and the second largest globally, after the $70 billion privatization of Japan's Nippon Telegraph and Telephone.

The deal will also solidify Goldman's position as one of the leading sellers of telecommunications securities at a time when the industry in Europe is undergoing great change, as governments sell off large holdings. "
We believe this is one of the most important business opportunities that Goldman, Sachs has had," said Scott Mead, a partner and head of Goldman's European telecommunications business.
In addition to Goldman, Sachs, the German Government named Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank, Germany's two largest financial institutions, as the other two global coordinators of the 1996 stock sale.
The German Government plans to sell some $10 billion in stock in the first half of 1996, another $10 billion in 1998 and its remaining company holdings beginning in the year 2000.
Dresdner Bank will coordinate all German sales, which is expected to account for 60 percent of the first offering, and Deutsche Bank will oversee global marketing.
More than $1 billion of investment banking fees will be paid in the next five years, with the bulk divided among the global coordinators.

But for the 22 foreign banks that sought roles in the privatization, it seemed to go beyond fees, into a competition for prestige and credibility as the premier international seller of telecommunications stocks.
Europe is entering a period of about five to eight years in which vast telecommunications assets, mostly state owned, will be sold to the public.
Call it confidence or hubris, but if officials in Greenwich, Conn., are worried that the state's highest court will open the town's public beach to nonresidents, they are not letting on.
With a court ruling expected any day, officials said they were planning even stricter enforcement of beach access rules this summer.
In previous summers, residents of the town had to show a pass, bought for $18 from the town's Department of Parks and Recreation, to use the park and beach at Greenwich Point.
A resident not carrying a pass could gain admission by showing a driver's license and paying a daily fee.
But this year, the town will not allow this practice, said Lorraine Cofone, the supervisor of the beach pass office at Town Hall.
The change in enforcement policy was first reported yesterday in Greenwich Time, the local daily newspaper.
Greenwich's residents-only beach policy has been the subject of a long-running court battle that is soon to be resolved by the Connecticut Supreme Court.

The court heard oral arguments in the case last month and is expected to issue a decision before the end of its current session in May. Brenden Leydon, a lawyer who lives in neighboring Stamford, sued Greenwich in 1995 to gain access to the beach, saying that state law required towns to hold parks and beaches in trust for all Connecticut residents.
Mr. Leydon lost the first round but won in Appellate Court; the town appealed.
Although the beach at Greenwich Point looks very much like other beaches along Long Island Sound, nonresidents of Greenwich have frequently sought entry.
Baseball officials will consider starting World Series and other post-season games earlier at night, Bud Selig said today, but he did not seem to hold out much promise. ''
That's something we're going to talk about this off season, but that's tough,'' Selig told reporters before the fourth game of the World Series. ''
We need to rethink that problem, but we are not completely masters of our own destinies.''

The acting commissioner alluded to the television networks, which do not want games to begin before prime time, which starts at 8 P.M. Starting time also affects viewership in the western part of the country.
The networks feel they would rather take their chances with Eastern time zone viewers after 11 o'clock than with those in the West before 5 P.M. Pacific time.
Selig said he was appalled at the length of Game 3 Tuesday night, 4 hours and 12 minutes. ''
I thought the Unfinished Symphony had a better chance of finishing than that game last night.''
Saying he kept looking at his watch, Selig added: ''There's no question the pace needs to be quickened.
The rules are there.
This doesn't benefit anyone.''

Marv Albert, the NBC Sports announcer who is charged with assaulting and sexually abusing a Virginia woman last February, was booked, fingerprinted and photographed today by the Arlington County police, and the judge in the case set Sept. 22 as the trial date.
In his first court appearance, Albert sat silently through a hearing that lasted less than five minutes, after which he was released without bail, on personal recognizance.

Gerard Treanor, Albert's lawyer, tried to enter a plea of not guilty to the two charges brought against Albert last week by a state grand jury -- sodomy, which is a felony in Virginia, and assault and battery, which is a misdemeanor.
A conviction on the more serious charge could result in a prison term of five years to life.
But Judge Benjamin Kendrick of the Arlington County Circuit Court said that in Virginia, it was customary to plead at the time a jury is selected.
Both Treanor and the Commonwealth Attorney, Richard E. Trodden, requested a jury trial, which suggests that the case would not conclude with a settlement.
Twice last week, in a statement and at a news conference in New York when he took no questions, Albert proclaimed his innocence.

Albert, 53, was accompanied in court by his fiancee, Heather Faulkiner, a television sports producer who held his hand as they walked into the courtroom; his four children from a previous marriage, and his brother Steve, who is also a sportscaster.
The charges stem from events that police investigators say happened on the night of Feb. 12.

Soon after, the police say, Albert threw the woman on the bed and forced her to perform oral sex.
AMONG ''Star Wars'' fanatics, George Lucas's student film ''Electronic Labyrinth: THX-1138 4EB'' is something of a legend.

The 15-minute film, about an escapee from a futuristic, authoritarian society, won first prize at the 1967-68 National Student Film Festival and made Mr. Lucas a star at the University of Southern California's film school.
On one level, the film can be seen as the director's declaration of independence from, if not outright hostility toward, the Hollywood system.

So it is fitting that the original short, which has never been exhibited before a mass audience, had its ''premiere'' in May on the small screen at AtomFilms (www .atomfilms.com), an exhibitor, producer and distributor of digital movies.

AtomFilms, Ifilm (www.ifilm.com), Pop.com (www.pop.com) and many other digital entertainment start-ups are betting that short films, once relegated to the fringe by the rigid formats of cinema (two-hour movies) and television (30-minute sitcoms and game shows), may be tailor-made for a growing number of small screens.

Mika Salmi, the founder and chief executive of AtomFilms, says the audience is to be found not just in front of desktop and notebook computers but also on airplanes, in shopping malls and even in elevators. ''

Electronic Labyrinth: THX 1138-4EB'' is part of the site's ongoing series of student films called USC Cinema Yearbook, which includes dozens of shorts from alumni like the director Robert Zemeckis (''The Lift'') and the animator Hal Barwood (''The Great Lost City of Xan'').

The Lucas short film, which became the basis for his feature-length film ''THX-1138,'' has been downloaded more than 86,000 times since its debut on AtomFilms, becoming the 10th-most-popular film on the site. (''
Bikini Bandits Episode 7,'' a comedy about bikini-clad bandits, takes first place with more than 400,000 views.)
Those early rough efforts mesh well with the underground flavor of AtomFilms' other short films.

Dr. Heinz L. Fraenkel-Conrat, whose research in biochemistry allowed scientists to peer into the innermost workings of viruses, died on April 10 at Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in Oakland, Calif. He was 88 and lived in Berkeley.

Dr. Fraenkel-Conrat, a professor emeritus at the University of California at Berkeley, made scientific history in the mid-1950's, when he dismantled a tobacco mosaic virus and then put it back together again, still living.

The accomplishment garnered Dr. Fraenkel-Conrat, who disdained publicity, considerable attention along the lines of ''life created in a test tube,'' recounted in the 1959 book ''Virus Hunters,'' by Greer Williams.
But for scientists, the value of Dr. Fraenkel-Conrat's work lay in its proof that the genetic information controlling viral reproduction was contained in the RNA at the core of each piece of a virus.
This was not an entirely happy discovery for Dr. Fraenkel-Conrat, who had sided with those scientists who believed that the tobacco virus's infectivity was contained it its protein coat. ''
I'm a protein chemist,'' he told Mr. Williams when he was being interviewed for the book. ''
I hoped protein was the determining factor.
It was against my personal inclinations to have a greater interest in nucleic acid.''

While other scientists before Dr. Fraenkel-Conrat had taken viruses apart in an effort to understand how they worked, he was the first to put one back together -- in effect, making the world's first synthetic virus.
His goal was to determine which part of the virus infected tobacco plants.
A front-page article on Thursday described a report by a committee at Columbia University formed to investigate complaints that pro-Israel Jewish students were harassed by pro-Palestinian professors.

The report found ''no evidence of any statements made by the faculty that could reasonably be construed as anti-Semitic,'' but it did say that one professor ''exceeded commonly accepted bounds'' of behavior when he became angry at a student who he believed was defending Israel's conduct toward Palestinians.

The article did not disclose The Times's source for the document, but Columbia officials have since confirmed publicly that they provided it, a day before its formal release, on the condition that the writer not seek reaction from other interested parties.
Under The Times's policy on unidentified sources, writers are not permitted to forgo follow-up reporting in exchange for information.
In this case, editors and the writer did not recall the policy and agreed to delay additional reporting until the document had become public.
The Times insisted, however, on getting a response from the professor accused of unacceptable behavior, and Columbia agreed.
Last Wednesday night, after the article had been published on The Times's Web site, the reporter exchanged messages with one of the students who had lodged the original complaints.
The student was expecting to read the report shortly.

But because of the lateness of the hour, and concern about not having response from other interested parties, the reporter did not wait for a comment for later versions, including the printed one, after the student had read the report.
Without a response from the complainants, the article was incomplete; it should not have appeared in that form.
Ravel at home was small, fastidious, obsessively elegant in dress and well satisfied that visitors walking through his rooms could find no trace, other than a piano, that he was connected to music.
Ravel also collected figurines and porcelain ranging, his friends said, from the discreet to the ''quite bad.'' ''
L'Heure Espagnole'' and ''L'Enfant et les Sortileges,'' which played at the New York City Opera on Friday night, would have fit nicely on his shelves.
Aside from the more graphic songs, these brief one-acters constitute the composer's adventures into musical theater. ''
L'Heure Espagnole'' is by far the thinner of the two.
The adulterous triangle of a Paisiello or Rossini comic opera is expanded to five sides (three lovers, one husband, one wife), all choreographed to the ticking of many clocks.

In the Maurice Sendak-Frank Corsaro production, the Clockmaker (ominously named Torquemada but gently played by John Lankston) acts as a magical ringmaster, summoning his mechanical devices to action with a wave and directing the people around him with similar omniscience.
Gonzalve the tenorial poet, done agreeably here by Thomas Trotter, competes with the overweight charms of Don Inigo Gomez, sung in a lovely baritone by Kevin Glavin.
Kurt Ollmann and Amy Burton take the principal parts.
Both sing with great competence and occasionally with real charm, and would have made an even better effect without the self-referential smirks and slightly exaggerated gestures imposed upon them.

IN the busy market for initial public offerings -- especially for volatile Internet-related companies -- analysts tend to be wary, which makes their enthusiasm for a planned $2.83 billion stock sale announced last week by KPMG Consulting Inc. all the more remarkable.

Through an alliance with Cisco Systems, which invested $1 billion in KPMG Consulting a year ago, the consulting group has specialized in what it calls ''e-business services'' to a client list that includes blue-chip companies, the Pentagon, the State Department and Yale University. ''
It will be the largest technology services I.P.O. in history,'' said Karl Keirstead, vice president for equity research at Lehman Brothers. ''
I think Wall Street will find it quite attractive,'' he added, in comparison with its competition.
Two other big information-technology services companies, Electronic Data Services and the Computer Science Corporation, ''have been going through tough transitions,'' he said. ''

I think KPMG will be the first of the Big Five accounting firms'' to sell part of its consulting business to the public, said Moshe Katri, managing director at SG Cowen Securities, who follows the Sapient Corporation, a KPMG competitor. ''
We expect the others to follow.''
Indeed, federal regulators are hammering out tough new limits on accounting firms' ability to perform lucrative consulting work for their audit clients.
Last Monday, an arbitrator separated Andersen Consulting from Arthur Andersen, the tax and auditing firm.
Earlier this year, Ernst & Young sold its consulting unit to Cap Gemini for roughly $11 billion, and PricewaterhouseCoopers is considering divesting itself of its consulting unit by year-end.
Tengiz Abuladze, a Georgian who became one of the Soviet Union's most highly regarded flm directors, died on March 6 in Tbilisi, Georgia.
He was 70.
Mr. Abuladze was best known for his 1984 film "Repentance," a fierce satire of Stalinism that won the special jury prize at the 1987 Cannes International Film Festival.
It was withheld from the Soviet public for two years before being released in the new climate of openness.
The film, which uses fantasy, surrealism and caricature in its portrayal of a dictatorial mayor, has been praised as a complex, coherent metaphor of the evil of tyranny.
The director's wife, a stage actress, as well as his daughter, daughter-in-law and grandson, had roles in the film.
Mr. Abuladze, whose father was a doctor and mother an economist, was born in Tblisi.
He studied directing there and did advanced studies at the Higher State Institute of Cinematography in Moscow.
The first films he worked on were documentaries about Georgian folklore.
He won his first award at Cannes in 1956, for the feature "Magdana's Donkey."
LEAD: It is hard to find a ballet troupe that children and adults can love with equal fervor and affection.

But on its current brief engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Royal Danish Ballet is just that company, deliciously pulling magic tales out of the treasure house of 19th-century works by August It is hard to find a ballet troupe that children and adults can love with equal fervor and affection.

But on its current brief engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Royal Danish Ballet is just that company, deliciously pulling magic tales out of the treasure house of 19th-century works by August Bournonville that make it a troupe unlike any other.
No true balletomane can afford to miss this season, with its spate of new young male stars in the making.
The run ends tomorrow with New York's first view of ''Abdallah,'' still another of Bournonville's Romantic ballets that has been revived from oblivion.
Nonetheless, the company from Copenhagen, last in New York in 1982, has led off with the full three-act version of ''Napoli,'' the great Danish choreographer's signature work.
And on Wednesday night the second cast was led by Heidi Ryom and Alexander Kolpin, already a standout amid the new male talent on display.
Mr. Kolpin is a wonder, a thrillingly Romantic hero with the boisterous passion and impetuous youthfulness of a young dancer who revels in the very act of dancing.
At the age of 23, he exudes romance and energy; young audiences will identify with his contemporary style and approach to tradition.
He throws his entire body into the final tarantella and, seemingly, his entire soul into his acting.
To the Editor: "Spare the Horses," the headline on your Nov. 16 editorial about New York City carriage horses, is misleading.
What exactly are we sparing the horses from?
Animal rights activists would have you believe that there are consistent and chronic problems that no amount of legislation can solve.
Nothing could be further from the truth.
Don't take my word for it.
Take the word of the New York City Department of Transportation, which has repeatedly testified that moving horse carriages do not obstruct traffic.
Take the word of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which in 1988 conducted more than 7,500 inspections and found only some 200 violations.
As the leading proponent of stronger regulations, the A.S.P.C.A. ticketed only 10 percent of drivers for time-area restrictions and animal health codes in the last 12 months.
Horse and carriage drivers are primarily hard-working immigrants who come to this country to make an honest living.
These laws do not protect horses, but hurt drivers.
If John Cook needed excuses today, he had plenty of them.
Cook had to deal with the distraction of playing with Tiger Woods, who attracted his typically huge gallery at the Mercedes Championships.
To make matters worse, Woods and Cook were the last twosome of the day, giving Cook even more time to get nervous, thinking about his first round of the new year.
But when Cook and Woods finally teed off, it was Cook who took command at La Costa Resort and Spa.
Shooting a seven-under-par 65, in a round that featured seven birdies and no bogeys, Cook grabbed the first-round lead in the opening event of the 1998 PGA Tour.
Nick Price was one stroke behind (66) in second place, while Ernie Els and Frank Nobilo were tied for third place, both at five under par (67).
While Cook was steady, Woods had a difficult beginning to a new season.
The defending Mercedes champion struggled to an even par 72, leaving Woods tied for 20th place, seven strokes behind Cook.
Meanwhile, David Duval, who is trying to win his fourth consecutive start, was very much in contention after a first-round 68, tied for fifth place just three strokes off the lead.
Although it may have surprised some to see Cook's name atop a big-name leader board, it was hardly a stunning development to Cook.
Kerry McCoy awoke this morning, rubbed the tattoo on his right arm and whispered to himself, ''This is what's it's all about.''
The five Olympic rings had faded a bit since McCoy got the tattoo four years ago as a college wrestler who had one goal.
He got the tattoo after he lost the Olympic trials in 1996, a bold reminder of a hope unfulfilled.
Tonight the rings glistened in the crevices of his biceps. ''
I'm glad I got it,'' McCoy said smiling. ''
It's a little bit lighter, but still just as powerful.''

McCoy, the reigning national heavyweight champion from Middle Island, N.Y., captured a berth on the United States Olympic freestyle wrestling team by defeating his nemesis, Stephen Neal, in two matches of the two-of-three-match final in Reunion Arena, 4-1 and 6-4.
McCoy won by balancing the images on his arms.
Written in Japanese on his left biceps are two characters that mean ''to dominate.''
McCoy, 25, a former New York high school champion, did just that.

The north end of the new World Trade Center is to meet its Lower Manhattan surroundings across a triangular park that will be ablaze with pink azaleas in springtime and sheltered under a yellow-orange canopy of star-shaped sweet gum leaves in fall.

When it opens late next year or in early 2006, this privately owned plaza at the confluence of Greenwich Street and West Broadway will be the first new public open space on ground zero and a forecourt to 7 World Trade Center, now under construction.
With that in mind, Ken Smith Landscape Architect designed the space, about one-third of an acre, with an oblique cross axis.
A spare and formal east-west approach to the building lobby will intersect a more playful and irregular north-south array of parallel planting beds and benches.
They will follow the angle of Greenwich Street, which was eliminated by the old 7 World Trade Center but is now being restored as a private way. ''
There's a great ambition downtown, with the re-creation of Greenwich Street, to connect the neighborhood through the trade center site,'' Ken Smith said. ''
Our park is done in a way that fosters that connection.''

Though not exactly a secret, the design received little public attention until yesterday when Larry A. Silverstein, the developer of 7 World Trade Center, showed renderings of the park and discussed the project in some detail at a conference sponsored by Business for Social Responsibility, a nonprofit organization.
Mr. Silverstein told the conference that he could have built a profitable apartment tower on the park site and that if he were 10 years younger (that is, 63), he probably would have.
But instead, he said, because 7 World Trade Center serves as a gateway to the greater trade center site, ''it became instantly obvious to me that what we needed to do was develop a jewel of a park.''

David Glauberman delivers comfort to weary mothers, lazy bachelors and anyone else who would rather starve than turn on the stove.
For some, it takes the form of onion rings and a triple cheeseburger.
Others choose something more refined -- veal scaloppine, perhaps, or crawfish etouffee.
Since 1992, Mr. Glauberman has tried to satisfy countless cravings with a delivery service called Carry-Out Cab, shuttling food from 20 restaurants to homes and offices around Middlesex County.
In New York City, where delivery is considered the birthright of the harried urban dweller, Mr. Glauberman would go largely unnoticed.
In suburbia, he is something rare but increasingly popular.
Businesses like his are starting to crop up throughout New Jersey in response to the growing number of commuters and dual-income families.
Most counties have at least one delivery service, and in densely populated suburbs like Paramus, in Bergen, or Cherry Hill, in Camden, several services compete for customers.
Mr. Glauberman said he knew of 40 delivery services nationwide when he started Carry-Out Cab; now he counts about 800. "
People in this state are working harder and later than they ever did before," Mr. Glauberman said. "
You can still get a haircut and a shave at Hussein Ali Ahmed's tiny barbershop, although he wishes you couldn't.
You can still hear the Palestinian men sitting on his worn vinyl couches argue politics, although he is sick of their discussions.
What you can't do anymore, according to the 56-year-old barber, is dream. "
This is the end for us," he said wistfully, as he churned shaving soap and water in a small metal bowl. "
This deal Yasir Arafat cut with the Israelis means that people like me do not exist, that we will never go home.
We have been sacrificed."
There are some three million Palestinians like Mr. Ahmed living in refugee camps in Syria, Lebanon and Jordan.
Many of them left Palestinian villages in what is now Israel at the end of the 1948 war.
For many of the refugees, the agreement that brought Palestinian rule to Gaza and Jericho and removed the Israeli soldiers is as welcome as the plague. "

The Palestinian refugees are slowly awakening to the fact that neither the Palestine Liberation Organization nor the Israelis are anxious for them to return in large numbers," said a senior Western diplomat, "and for many of these refugees, who have been trapped in camps for decades, this is a painful realization."
The Supreme Court ruled today that state officials can be sued and found personally liable for damages for violating an individual's civil rights.

The 8-to-0 opinion was a restatement of a principle that most legal scholars and lower court judges had already assumed to be correct: that a state's immunity from lawsuits of this type does not shield state officeholders who are sued in their personal capacity.

But a 1989 Supreme Court decision had created some confusion in what is inherently a complex and confusing area of Federal law, liability for actions taken "under color of state law" that violate rights guaranteed by the Constitution or Federal statutes.

Different rules apply depending on whether the target of the lawsuit is a state or a municipality, on whether a state official is sued in his or her official or personal capacity and on whether damages or an injunction is sought.
First Opinion of Term The decision today, the first formal opinion of the Court's new term, resolves the confusion but does not change the existing law in most of the country.
Written by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the decision affirmed a 1990 ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia.

The appeals court ruling permitted a civil rights suit to proceed against Pennsylvania's Auditor General, Barbara Hafer, who was sued by 18 employees whom she dismissed after winning election to the office in 1988.

The employees sued Ms. Hafer in her personal capacity, alleging that she had violated their First Amendment rights of free speech and association by dismissing them in retaliation for their support of her opponent in the election.
Ms. Hafer is a Republican and the dismissed employees are Democrats.
They sought damages of up to $3.5 million apiece.

To the Editor: Mayor Ernest D. Davis's contention that Pelham's opposition to his plan to build a 285,000-square-foot mall next to our schools is based in racism is so outrageous and ludicrous as to defy credulity (''At Odds with Affluent Neighbor,'' Sept. 9).
This is a safety and traffic congestion issue, not a color one.
For Mayor Davis to define it as such is a cheap shot.
The dispute here involves the economic revitalization of Mount Vernon at the expense of the safety of its children and the children of Pelham.
The proposed mall site abuts several school playing fields, while being way outside the downtown area of Mount Vernon.
Hundreds of children use those facilities every day.
Additionally, the proposed mall would substantially increase the traffic on the already heavily congested Hutchinson River Parkway.
Anyone who travels that parkway knows that it cannot handle more traffic.
Although Mayor Davis states that this increased traffic could be managed effectively, there has yet to be an effective solution put forth by him or the developer.
I think Mayor Davis ought to look a little more closely at himself and the facts before he starts calling his neighbors racists.
For the last four years, one of New York City's familiar rites of spring has been the cat-and-mouse game the Mayor and the City Council play with the budget of the Department of Cultural Affairs.
The Mayor cuts the budget to show fiscal responsibility, the Council restores it to show support for the arts, and politics is served.
To the arts organizations that rely in part on city money, this budgetary game is an annual source of anxiety.
At the very least it is a hindrance to planning, and the fear remains that one day the City Council will balk.
That day may have come.
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has proposed a cut of $22.2 million from the current $101 million Cultural Affairs budget.
The cuts will fall especially heavily upon the Program Group -- a diverse array of some 450 large and small theaters, neighborhood groups and art programs -- which may lose half its city funding.
The Cultural Institution Group -- organizations like the Brooklyn Museum and Carnegie Hall, which operate out of city-owned buildings -- stands to lose 20 percent of its budget.
Meanwhile, the City Council has hinted that it cannot be relied upon to restore the cuts and may undertake a case-by-case review.
This has been a fat season for the city generally, but not so in public arts funding.

His music survives, even prospers.
It remains an object of respect and often affection.
Most important, it is played - lacking the huge following of such contemporaries as Sibelius, Bartok and Ravel, but played.
Nielsen was a Dane, and it was the Danish Music Information Center that put on Wednesday's concert of his music at Alice Tully Hall.

Ostensibly, this was a 125th birthday celebration, and in this most international of cities, the presenters seem to have had little trouble rounding up an audience of Nielsen's countrymen to mix with his American admirers.
Victor Borge was there to speak in the composer's behalf.

Dream Come True: New Hair Salon Susanna Romano, one of the new owners of A.K.S. Salon, explained that for its founders the opening of the new beauty shop was ''about doing the American dream,'' being your own boss.
Ms. Romano and her partners, Alain Pinon, 32, and Kao Hui, 35, met when they worked at Beaute de Provence, the salon owned by Frederic Fekkai in the Chanel store on East 57th Street.
On June 10, they opened their new full-service shop on the second floor of 694 Madison Avenue, between 63d and 62d Streets.
A.K.S. Salon offers services ranging from facials and body treatments to coloring and haircuts.
Haircuts cost $90 to $150.
The owners said their shop was designed to be unintimidating and to appeal to clients who want small salons that offer personal attention.

The Bronx Gets A Home Depot Sales receipts from its New Rochelle store in Westchester County told Home Depot that it had a strong customer base in the Bronx, even though the Atlanta-based home improvement chain had no outlets in the borough. ''
There was a void in the area that we needed to correct,'' said Mohamed Khan, the district manager for the New York area of Home Depot.
Correct it they did.
The new Home Depot, at 1806 East Gun Hill Road between Bartow and Ely Avenues, has a 114,000-square-foot main store and a 17,000-square-foot garden center.

The prestigious Reisinger Knockout Teams, which began at the Vista Hotel on Monday, will end on Saturday, and the District Grand National Team final will be played on Sunday.
Skillful defense by Bob Jones of Auburndale, Queens, sitting West on the diagramed deal, helped his team win in the Grand National semifinal played May 5.
He led the diamond queen against three no-trump, and was in some difficulty when he was allowed to win the first trick.
Continuing diamonds would help declarer establish a trick in that suit, and a shift to a black suit, where South was known to have strength, was risky.
He therefore chose to play the heart king, hoping his partner held the jack of that suit.
South won with the ace in dummy and cashed two diamond winners.
Another diamond lead put West in again, and he persevered with the heart ten.
South won with dummy's queen and cashed the last diamond, reaching this tricky ending: [ DIAGRAM ] Needing four tricks, South led a spade to his nine.
West won with the queen and was about to return a spade when he paused to think.
''THE sun is setting,'' the announcer said, ''but we're just getting started.''
It's time for N.F.L. football at Raymond James Stadium in Tampa, Fla., and the bleachers are throbbing with fans.
As the palm trees sway in the breeze, players for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Miami Dolphins gather at the 50-yard line for the coin toss.
The competition is real, but the game -- not quite.

The action unfolding on the television screen is a complex illusion, a multimillion-dollar collaboration between science and industry that produced the video game NFL 2K3, to be released this summer by Sega.

Sports video games are a best-selling genre in the $10.8 billion interactive entertainment business, representing 22 percent of video game sales over all, according to the NDP Group, a market research firm.
Sports gaming is primed to get even bigger as Sony's PlayStation 2, Microsoft's Xbox and Nintendo's GameCube prepare to offer online versions of the games later this year.
Soon, players will be able to compete with others from across the country via the Internet.
Or across the state: a player in, say, Tampa may pit his beloved Bucs against another player's Dolphins.
Online play is the most important technological leap in the quest for authenticity and realism, the genre's bywords.

At the end of an upperfloor back hall on the north side of the Metropolitan Opera, far from the ground-floor, south-side offices of James Levine and Joseph Volpe, the company's artistic and administrative leaders, one comes suddenly upon a painting of Christoph Willibald Ritter von Gluck.
He sits calmly, even placidly, staring out at the few passers-by over a gulf of 200 years.
Is he awaiting a return call to glory, or just moldering away into the dustbin of history.
Despite the portrait still hanging at the Met, however obscurely, the company has not performed a Gluck opera since 1972.

That opera was "Orfeo ed Euridice" (1762), which remains easily his most popular and which Berlin's Komische Oper will perform this week at the Brooklyn Academy in a well-traveled production by Harry Kupfer. "
Orfeo" plays with some regularity on the world's stages, especially if you count concert performances designed as vehicles for famous mezzo-sopranos. (
The Komische Oper performance stars Jochen Kowalski, a countertenor with unusual box-office appeal, given his James Dean-ish good looks.)

Dame Janet Baker sang Orfeo in a concert performance at Carnegie Hall in 1988 with the Oratorio Society, and there were other concert "Orfeos" in New York in 1984 (the Philadelphia Orchestra and Concert Royal) and 1980 (with Marilyn Horne).
In New York, Gluck's other major operas are hardly heard at all; the City Opera did "Alceste" in 1982, but has no plans for any other Gluck.

It is left to smaller companies to handle his lesser-known works, as in a concert version of "Telemacco" in 1989 by the Pro Arte Chorale or a "Paride ed Elena" next month from the Mannes College of Music, conducted by Will Crutchfield.

On summer evenings, when the sun sets on the grassy slopes of Riverside Park between Grant's Tomb and 125th Street, the bushes rustle and the trash cans shake, and dozens of creatures with sharp teeth and claws scurry out of the shadows.
It's feeding time for the rats, and for many nearby residents it's the time each night when they retreat indoors, leaving the sidewalks and streets to their four-legged neighbors. ''
We're co-existing with them,'' said Darlene Wakefield, 43, who lives on Broadway and takes her 16-month-old son to the park every day. ''
I know in a few minutes, it's their time.
I'm going to swing my baby a few times, and then I'm going.''
Ms. Wakefield and others say that the local rat population has multiplied in the last year, a time when city officials say they have been gnawing away at the problem.
Last August, Mayor Giuliani and the Health Department began an $8 million-a-year rat extermination program in all five boroughs.
But the program targets specific areas, and this section of the park is not among them.

Jerome Hauer, director of the Mayor's Office of Emergency Management and coordinator of the rat program, said that the Health Department had not received any complaints from area residents, and that the department would send workers to evaluate the problem.
In areas where the extermination program has been carried out, he said, the rat population has decreased. ''

Senator John Kerry has suggested, though never explicitly stated, that the Bush administration has an improper relationship with Halliburton, the company where Dick Cheney was chief executive from 1995 until he left in 2000 to run for vice president.
The Bush campaign maintains that Mr. Cheney has cut his ties with Halliburton and that the administration has given the company no special treatment.

WHAT KERRY SAYS At a community center in Albuquerque on Sept. 17, Mr. Kerry declared: ''Dick Cheney's old company Halliburton has profited from the mess in Iraq at the expense of American troops and taxpayers.
While Halliburton has been engaging in massive overcharging and wasteful practices under this no-bid contract, Dick Cheney has continued to receive compensation from his former company.''

After listing some instances of Halliburton overcharging alleged by Pentagon auditors, Mr. Kerry asserted: ''While Dick Cheney claims that he has gotten rid of all of his financial interests in Halliburton, he's actually received $2 million in bonuses and deferred compensation from his former company since taking office in 2001.
And the independent Congressional Research Service found that under federal ethics law, Dick Cheney did have a lingering financial interest in Halliburton.''
THE FACTS Halliburton's business with the military has grown substantially since Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney took office.
The company rose to seventh-largest military contractor in 2003 from 22nd-largest in 2000.
The contracts did not prove to be as profitable as executives had hoped, however, and accusations of political favoritism led to a public relations nightmare.
On Thursday, Halliburton said it was considering selling its subsidiary that holds the contracts in Iraq.

Before setting out for a few hours of sightseeing through the steel canyons of this city's Loop, Diane Tupper and her 16-year-old son, Lee, spent much of this morning in their hotel room watching Judge Clarence Thomas testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee. "
It's all very confusing," she said. "
It's so black and white.
Either she's really bad or he's really bad.
I have no idea who's telling the truth."
Even after another morning of testimony, confusion echoed through the streets of the Loop about "who's telling the truth?" --
Judge Thomas, the Supreme Court nominee or Anita F. Hill, the Oklahoma law professor who said she was sexually harassed by him. "
But it's giving my son and I a chance to talk about about sexual harassment," said Mrs. Tupper, of Richmond, Va. "I told Lee about a couple of experiences I've had."
A Chance to Think Her son shrugged his lanky shoulders. "
I never really thought about it before" he said. "
We've been waiting for well over two years for the Senate Intelligence Committee to finally hold the Bush administration accountable for the fairy tales it told about Saddam Hussein's weapons.
Republican leaders keep saying it is a waste of time to find out whether President Bush and other top officials deliberately misled the world.

But Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld's bizarre responses the other day to questions about that very issue were a timely reminder of why this investigation needs to be completed promptly, thoroughly and fairly.
Unfortunately, Pat Roberts, the chairman of the Senate panel, is running it in a way that makes it unlikely that anything useful will come of it.
It is bad enough that Mr. Rumsfeld and others did not tell Americans the full truth -- to take the best-case situation -- before the war.
But they are still doing it.
Just look at the profoundly twisted version of events that the defense secretary offered last week at a public event in Atlanta.
Ray McGovern, an analyst for 27 years at the Central Intelligence Agency, stood in the audience and asked why Mr. Rumsfeld lied about weapons of mass destruction in Iraq.
The secretary shot back, ''I did not lie.''

Then, even though no one asked about them, he said Colin Powell and Mr. Bush offered ''their honest opinion'' based on ''weeks and weeks'' of time with the C.I.A. ''I'm not in the intelligence business,'' he said, adding, ''It appears that there were not weapons of mass destruction there.''
Ron Dayne's immediate future with the Giants has been decided.
He just does not know what it is yet.
Giants Coach Jim Fassel said yesterday that he had made all the decisions concerning his final cut to a 53-man roster, but he would not tell the players until today.
And the team does not intend to make the cuts public until 4 p.m. tomorrow, the N.F.L deadline.
This tortured process holds the fate of many players in suspended animation, but the drama surrounding Dayne, the Giants' No.
1 draft pick in 2000, is the thickest.
Fassel started Dayne in the final preseason game Thursday against Baltimore.
That was a surprise move because Fassel had said Dorsey Levens would be the first back whose name is not Tiki Barber to get the ball.
Dayne turned the opportunity into a 5-carry, 13-yard, one-fumble flop.
With roster spots at a premium, Dayne's future with the team seems precarious. ''
Tiger Woods can't win every single time he tees it up.
It only seemed that way.

Woods, who had captured three straight major championships this year, lost to Spain's Sergio Garcia, 1-up, in the Battle at Bighorn tonight, a special made-for-television match-play event on ABC that finished under the lights at Bighorn Country Club.
Garcia, who took the lead for the first time with a long birdie putt at 16, clinched the victory with another birdie at the 18th.
In all, Garcia, who earned $1.1 million, made eight birdies.
Woods, suffering from the flu, took home $400,000.
Both players donated $200,000 to charity. ''
It was a great match, very exciting,'' Garcia said. ''
We both played very well.''
Woods added, ''Unfortunately, I wasn't able to make enough putts to keep the pressure on Sergio.''

Arrayed like an eager, overlooked platoon, the 10 Democratic candidates for president engaged in a rapid-fire debate yesterday about the nation's economic troubles and managed to keep their sights on President Bush more than on one another.
The few voters who could spare two hours in late afternoon to find the debate on television saw little internecine savaging.
Less sensational and more substantive, the event was steeped in the nation's record budget deficits, persistent unemployment, uncertain recovery and costly adventure in Iraq.
Important distinctions emerged on President Bush's tax cuts and on the domestic impact of free-trade agreements.
The candidates split on whether to repeal some tax cuts, keeping middle-class voters in mind, or all of them, a riskier option backed by Representative Richard Gephardt and former Gov. Howard Dean.
Almost all agreed that some tax cuts should be repealed to help pay for postwar efforts in Iraq.
But the candidates differed on how much the nation should pay for reconstruction when there are pressing needs at home.
Representative Dennis Kucinich of Ohio took the misguided view that funds for the postwar effort should be eliminated and the troops brought home immediately.
The newcomer, retired Gen. Wesley Clark, was more affable than forthcoming about his unformed policy views.
He insisted that he was a Democrat at heart, despite previous votes for Republican presidents, and would prove it in position papers.

The Port Authority last week unveiled designs for a new terminal linking a planned elevated rail line from Kennedy International Airport with the Long Island Rail Road and subway lines at Jamaica, Queens.
The announcement prompted a coalition of community groups, supported by major airlines, to announce an effort to derail the proposal.

The city approval process starts later this month, but the public relations tussle began on Tuesday when the Port Authority showed off models of a transfer station at 94th Street and Sutphin Boulevard, which would contain a baggage check and ticketing area.
An arching glass and steel canopy would connect existing Long Island Rail Road and E, J and Z subway lines, as well as the planned rail link to Kennedy.
In April, the Port Authority awarded contracts for the $1.5 billion project.
Travelers would take the subway or L.I.R.R. to the new station -- about a 40-minute trip from Manhattan -- then take the rail line, 55 feet above the Van Wyck Expressway, to the airport.
The elevated ride would cost $5.
A private-bus ride between Manhattan and the airport costs $13. ''
We will be able to check your bags and get you to the airport in eight minutes,'' the Port Authority's executive director, Robert Boyle, said, calling the planned station ''an off-airport terminal.''

Mayor Giuliani had opposed the plan, but a spokesman said the administration relented last month when it was guaranteed that no city money would be needed, and that the Port Authority would pay for a study of the extension of another rail line to La Guardia Airport.
The ethnic politics of the future are germinating here in a race for a State Assembly seat from a crowded immigrant neighborhood that some politicians call the new Ellis Island.

Fifteen candidates, some representing tiny immigrant constituencies, are maneuvering for votes in the 46th District in central Los Angeles, but as in the state at large, the heavily registered white voters are expected to determine the outcome.
Political analysts say this immigrant point of entry, where nearly 50 languages can be heard among the schoolchildren, offers a lesson in the gap between population numbers and political power. "

I contend that, like it or not, my district is what all of California is going to look like by the year 2025, if not before," said Michael Roos, the incumbent, whose resignation touched off this special election, scheduled for Tuesday.
Diversity of Candidates "It seems like every faction in the community has fielded a candidate," said Mr. Roos, a Democrat. "
The gays have a candidate, the Jews have a candidate, the Filipinos have a candidate, the Latinos have a candidate, the Koreans have a candidate, the Japanese have a candidate."
But while the district has a population of more than 360,000 people, mostly immigrants and their children, it has only 63,000 registered voters, and fewer than 15,000 of them are expected to vote.
Whites, though they account for only 15 percent of the residents, make up at least 60 percent of the electorate in this district.

Thus, political analysts predict that even though California's exploding Hispanic and Asian populations are expected to put minority groups in the majority by the turn of the century, their political power will continue to lag behind their numbers for some time. "
Every time I read an article about how something dramatic is going to change, I want to laugh," said James Hayes, a political consultant who said he was advising 12 of the candidates here.
To the Editor: Re ''Can Meetings Restore Trust?'' (

May 11), which described how many companies try to keep shareholders' involvement at a minimum at annual meetings: Consider the differences in democratic practices between corporations and labor unions.

Generally speaking, labor unions practice a basic form of democracy in which the membership or the elected executive committee -- or both -- vote on officers as well as contracts born of negotiations with management.
Even the negotiators are usually democratically chosen.
Unlike corporate stockholders, the unions rarely try to evade a democratic, close-to-home vote on new contracts.
By contrast, large corporations systematically cultivate a culture of evasion and exclusion toward their stockholders, in the knowledge that the corporations control the votes to stifle dissent.

While stockholders are widely unable to exercise a substantive vote on either management personnel or company policies, union members are empowered to periodically replace their officers and radically alter their policies, political activities and spending, including political spending.
Long ago, when corruption was detected among some labor unions, Congress responded with strict laws.
But in recent years, when corruption has been detected on a vastly broader scale among corporations and executives, Congress has done little to rein in the malefactors.
The difference must lie in the political clout (read contributions) of the two forces.
Overcharge Dispute Question: I live in a rent-stabilized brownstone and have a rent dispute with the landlord.
I filed an overcharge claim with the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal and an expedite order to process the claim has been issued.
The department, however, has told me the process will take 60 to 90 days and my landlord has told me he is going to sell the building.
He also asked me to show the apartment.
What is my position?
What kind of things do I need to prepare for? . . .

Helen Parker, Manhattan Answer: According to Lou J. Ganim, a spokesman for the Divisiion of Housing and Community Renewal, which oversees rent-regulated and rent-stabilized apartments, the owner at the time an order is issued is responsible for settlement of the overcharge. "

That means," he said, "that if the place gets sold and there is a new owner before there is a decision, then the new owner will, if there is an order to pay the overcharge, be the one responsible for paying it."
He added that you need not fear being evicted unless the owner planned to live in your unit.
And if the new owner does, then the owner has to go to housing court and get its approval not to renew your lease.
Q Two large portions of the ceiling in my condominium collapsed on separate occasions two weeks apart.
There was no leak in the unit above or other obvious cause, and the building's super said it was probably the original plaster drying out with age.
Our insurance company refused to pay for the damage, so we asked the condominium board to assume some responsibility.
The board's lawyer at first said the plaster was the building's responsibility and the paint was ours.
On the board's instruction, I had the ceiling repaired at a cost of $2,500.
Now the board is disclaiming all responsibility, leaving me stuck with the entire bill.
Is this correct? . . .

Richard Horwich, Manhattan A Dennis H. Greenstein, a Manhattan lawyer, said that under the state's real property law, the rights and obligations of unit owners and the condominium's board of managers are governed by a condominium's bylaws.
And typically, Mr. Greenstein said, the bylaws will provide that all repairs to the interior of an apartment -- including the walls, ceilings and floors -- are the responsibility of the unit owner.

The board, on the other hand, is generally responsible for repairs to common elements -- as described by the condominium declaration -- which usually consist of areas outside the residential units. ''
As has often been the case in Cambodia's tragic history, the country is once again ruled by a tyrant determined to cling to power.
Hun Sen is no Pol Pot, but he is a violent, autocratic leader who seized control of Cambodia in a coup in July.

The United Nations and Western and Asian countries have decided that the best way to unseat him is to move ahead with parliamentary elections scheduled for next May. Mr. Hun Sen, who is deeply unpopular, would likely lose a fair election.
But nothing in his past indicates that he would allow one, and flawed elections are worse than none at all.
The international community must proceed cautiously, lest a rigged election give Mr. Hun Sen a veneer of legitimacy.
Mr. Hun Sen has always shown a talent for staying in power.
Once a member of the genocidal Khmer Rouge, in 1985 he became Prime Minister in a government installed by neighboring Vietnam.

In U.N.-sponsored elections in 1993, Mr. Hun Sen lost to Prince Norodom Ranariddh's royalist party, but by threatening to take up arms got himself installed as co-Prime Minister with Prince Ranariddh.
Last July, he ousted Prince Ranariddh.
At least 41 people were executed during and after the coup.

Several hundred protesters stormed the main government building in Bishkek on Friday in support of a minor presidential candidate, but riot police officers using tear gas and batons retook the building hours later.

In events reminiscent of the ousting of President Askar Akayev in an uprising on March 24, a crowd of around 2,500 supporters of the candidate, Urmatbek Baryktabasov, a wealthy businessman, rallied in the capital to demand that he be allowed to run in the July 10 elections.
Then an estimated 500 forced their way inside the building.
Friday's events are an ominous sign of the potential for unrest three weeks before the first presidential elections since 2000.
The latest instability comes less than a week after a member of Parliament was killed in Bishkek.
Although 12 candidates, including Mr. Baryktabasov, say they have each collected the 50,000 signatures necessary to run, the front-runner is Kurmanbek Bakiyev, the interim president.
Mr. Bakiyev and a former rival, Felix Kulov, have agreed to support each other in the elections.
Mr. Baryktabasov has been barred from running on the grounds that he has dual citizenship with Kazakhstan, although he has challenged that finding in court.
According to witnesses, the protesters briefly occupied the seventh-floor presidential office, along with a Central Election Commission office on the third floor.
By 11 a.m., 1,000 riot police officers had arrived and begun evacuating the building.
To the Editor: You suggest (Week in Review, May 11) that it has become harder to hold America responsible for assaults on cultures elsewhere in the world.

Perhaps you should review recent news: The United States wins a ruling in the World Trade Organization and forces Europe to accept American beef grown with hormones, although many European consumers are worried in the wake of mad cow disease.
We hope the ruling will set a precedent for pushing other genetically engineered products on world markets despite local opposition.

With the support of the United States Embassy, a delegation of American investment bankers and mining executives arrives in Zaire to sign contracts with the rebel leader Laurent Kabila, although human rights officials charge his forces with atrocities against refugees.
American tobacco companies expand in Asia, with the support of American diplomacy.
We force Thailand to repeal smoking regulations.
We force countries to open their markets to American agricultural exports.

While this benefits some consumers, it ruins an impoverished countryside, accelerates migration to overcrowded slums and destroys food self-sufficiency just when global climate disturbance should prompt caution.
Although we preach globalism, we don't hesitate to impose our foreign policy on reluctant allies and trading partners.

We threaten foreign companies that deal with Cuba and prolong the embargo of food and medicine to Iraq long after the U.N. has approved shipments, so that we can punish helpless civilians for their rulers.

The number of college women who drink abusively has tripled in the last 20 years, to the point that as many college women as men engage in drinking to get drunk, according to a Columbia University study released yesterday.
The study, conducted by the university Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse, said 35 percent of the college women polled last year said they drank to get drunk, compared with 10 percent in 1977.
It did not report how often college women engaged in this type of drinking. "
We must respond to this wake-up call," said Judge Pamela Ann Rymer of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit and a member of the 17-member commission that produced the report. "
It is a calling critical enough to engage us all."

The findings themselves did not surprise college and university administrators, who said studies have indicated that drinking by all college students is very high compared with people of the same age in the work force.
Anecdotal evidence has also been mounting that college women are drinking more often and more abusively for a variety of reasons.
Pressure and Drinking College administrators said female students were enjoying the freedom of the relaxed social mores of the last few decades.

And college women themselves have said they drink to relieve the pressure they feel to succeed and to fit into campus life, in which alcohol remains very much a fixture despite aggressive efforts by the institutions to ban alcohol from dormitories and campus events. "

This clearly confirms what all of us are reporting," said Thomas G. Goodale, senior vice president for student affairs at Virginia Tech in Blacksburg, Va., and a national expert on alcohol abuse among college students. "

As President Bush prepares for talks with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq, an unusual coalition of liberal Democrats and moderate-to-conservative Republicans is urging the Administration to make the elimination of Iraq's weapons ability an explicit goal of American policy in the Persian Gulf.

The group, which calls itself the Committee for Peace and Security in the Gulf, has scheduled a news conference on Monday where it plans to argue that the United States should be willing to use force if necessary to see that Iraq's chemical, biological and potential nuclear weapons ability is dismantled or destroyed.

Formation of the coalition comes at a time of increasing partisan division over the Administration's conduct of gulf policy, particularly the issue of whether the United States should take military action within the next few months to force Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait.

A majority of Congressional Democrats, including such traditional party conservatives as Sam Nunn of Georgia, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, have argued that the Administration should allow more time for economic sanctions to persuade Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, to leave Kuwait voluntarily.

Divisions in the Party But the willingness of some Democrats to join a coalition that advocates use of force to disarm Mr. Hussein underscores what may be even more significant divisions in the party itself.

Members of the new group include prominent liberals like Tony Coelho, the former House Democratic Whip; Ann Lewis, a former political director of the Democratic National Committee, and Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat who serves on the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

Among the Republicans are Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, a senior member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee; former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee; former Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci and such vocal Reagan Administration conservatives as Jeane J. Kirkpatrick. "
For someone who has been very vocal in the past about criticizing Administration policy on intervention overseas, I think it is important to speak out when I support it," Mrs. Lewis said. "
That is not to say that this is a blanket endorsement of every aspect of Administration strategy."
Richard Perle, a conservative Democrat who served as an Assistant Secretary of Defnese in the Reagan Administration, said the purpose of the coalitin was not to deal with partisan politics. "

While Giants linebacker Jessie Armstead said he was going to sleep with the football that he intercepted and returned for the game-winning touchdown against the Arizona Cardinals, one of his teammates might be having nightmares.
There was a time when Giants cornerback Thomas Randolph thought he was fast.
That has changed.

When Armstead picked off a Dave Krieg pass with 4 minutes 5 seconds elapsed  in overtime and ran so fast he looked like the cartoon character Flash, Randolph tried to catch up with Armstead to help with the blocking.
But even though Randolph can run the 40-yard dash in about 4.3 seconds and he is more than 50 pounds lighter than Armstead, he could not catch him on the 58-yard return. "
I had the angle on him, I was seriously trying," said Randolph, "but he has  never run that fast.
Thank God he did, because he may just have saved us.
I may  suffer serious psychological problems because a linebacker beat me, but it's our season that counts."
Safety Tito Wooten explained it this way. "
Jessie looked like someone took $1 million in cash, put it in the end zone, and said, 'First one to it, gets it.' "
If only it was always this easy.
The Devils have had 16 games this season in which they have scored one goal or less.
But the heretofore anemic New Jersey offense erupted for five third-period goals tonight to put away the Dallas Stars by a 7-2 score, thanks largely to Scott Stevens and a resurgent power play.
Go figure.
After going scoreless in their first four power-play opportunities, the Devils connected on five of their next six chances, tying a Devils record for most power-play goals in a game.

They broken open a tight game by scoring three  times early in the final period on a five-minute major that had been assessed to Shane Churla for his vicious slash on Stevens's left hand with 28.2 seconds remaining in the second period. "
He said he couldn't feel his hand," Devils Coach Jacques Lemaire said. "
He said it's still there, but I can't feel it."
Stevens, who originally feared his wrist was broken, said: "He should be suspended for that.
It was ridiculous.
Barry Bonds had already told reporters that he would not be talking after Monday night's game, and now he was one simple act away from bolting out of the Giants' clubhouse.
All he had to do was put on his white sneakers.
But these days, nothing seems simple for Bonds.
As he sat in a chair, he hunched forward while carefully slipping his right foot into a sneaker.
Then he tried to do the same thing with his left foot.
But he had to place his hand on the huge television near his locker to steady himself before he could slide his foot into place.

The snapshot, only about a minute in the day of a player with seven Most Valuable Player awards, was another reminder that Bonds's body was weakening and that 41, in baseball years, could be very old.
He has had three operations on his right knee since last year and has bone chips in his left elbow.
He looks and acts old. ''
It doesn't matter what has happened to him in the past,'' first baseman Lance Niekro said. ''
The State Board of Education has approved science textbooks that teach evolution, despite objections from those who say alternative views get short shrift.
Textbooks for Texas schools have long been the focus of opposition by creationists, who believe that species originated from acts of God as described in the Bible.
Texas, as one of the nation's largest buyers of textbooks, influences what publishers put in books that are sold to schools all over the country. "

These are the best biology textbooks that have ever been presented to the public schools of this state," said one board member, Will Davis, after the books were approved Saturday by a vote of 11 to 4.
But another board member, Jane Nelson, said most of the books offer insufficient evidence rebutting the evolution of life on earth from primitive to complex forms.
The board had asked publishers to include such evidence, she said.
The science books approved by the board are for grades 1 through 12.
They will be used for six years.

The state has previously limited coverage of evolution in biology textbooks, said Michael Hudson, general counsel of People for the American Way, which has lobbied for expanded coverage of evolution in science textbooks. "
Students in every state will benefit from the Texas decision," Mr. Hudson said.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's chief of staff, Peter Madonia, said yesterday that he would leave City Hall in the coming weeks, to become the chief operating officer of the Rockefeller Foundation.
His departure brings to three the number of ranking, seasoned officials who will not serve the mayor in his second term.

Mr. Madonia said in an interview yesterday that the offer from the Rockefeller Foundation was too good to pass up, though, he said, the mayor had already offered him a new job with a ''substantive deputy mayor's portfolio,'' which he declined.

City Hall announced Mr. Madonia's resignation yesterday afternoon, just a few days after the mayor's longtime communications strategist, William T. Cunningham, confirmed that he would not serve in the mayor's second administration.
Yesterday, Dan Klores Communications, a public relations firm based in New York, announced that it had hired Mr. Cunningham as an executive vice president.
And several weeks ago the mayor announced that his deputy mayor for operations, Marc V. Shaw, would be leaving to seek more lucrative work.
Mr. Madonia, Mr. Shaw and Mr. Cunningham have decades of experience in government between them.
Taken together, their departures leave a hole at the center of the administration's top ranks.
Mr. Cunningham, 55, had worked for two governors, Hugh L. Carey and Mario M. Cuomo, and for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan before joining Mr. Bloomberg in 2001.

His duties as City Hall communications director were taken over by the mayor's press secretary, Edward Skyler, 32, when Mr. Cunningham, whom the mayor also asked to return to City Hall, left the administration to work for Mr. Bloomberg's campaign.

Mieczyslaw Horszowski, a pianist whose performances were admired for their elegance, reflectiveness and clarity of musical intent in a career that lasted more than nine decades, died on Saturday at his home in Philadelphia.
He was 100.
John G. Zawadziski, a friend of the family, said the cause was heart failure.
Mr. Horszowski made his debut as a child prodigy, playing a Beethoven concerto in Warsaw in 1901, and continued giving concerts and making recordings until last year.
He was not so famous as Arthur Rubinstein, Vladimir Horowitz or other elder statesmen of the keyboard in the late 20th century.

But he always had a strong cult following, and in recent years his reputation and audience blossomed anew as a younger generation discovered him through a recent series of recordings that reveal his special mastery of the works of Chopin, Mozart, Schubert, Debussy and Bach.
He was also greatly esteemed by his colleagues.
He was a frequent chamber-music partner of the cellist Pablo Casals.
He first performed with Arturo Toscanini in 1906 and continued appearing with him until 1953.
When he was seeking an American foothold at the start of World War II, Rudolf Serkin invited him to join the faculty of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia.

To the Editor: Your Dec. 28 front-page article on the decrease in college acceptance of Advanced Placement credits did not sufficiently pursue the critical question of why an increasing number of colleges refuse to accept them.
You quote Kathy Christie of the Education Commission of the States giving two reasons for this: The tests don't match the college curriculums, or too many students are learning by rote.
But you found that most college administrators and professors don't question the rigor of the Advanced Placement tests.
Indeed, college professors are the very people the Educational Testing Service employs to create, revise and update the tests.
The implication that colleges are immune from learning by rote suggests your reporter hasn't visited a college classroom recently.
Perhaps something else is going on.
According to Ms. Christie, the financial windfall that colleges receive by having students repeat courses they took in high school is not a factor.
Even though 400,000 students took the tests last May?
Though annual college costs are more than $20,000 at a great many colleges, and though each Advanced Placement test can potentially replace a semester's credit in the test's area?
Only the colleges that argue the courses or tests one at a time can have any validity in not accepting Advanced Placement credits.

After voting against President Clinton's original proposal to overhaul the nation's health care system, a Congressional subcommittee today approved an alternative plan to achieve his goal of universal insurance coverage but supply a more modest package of medical benefits.
The subcommittee voted 6 to 5 to approve the alternative and send it to the full House Ways and Means Committee for further action.

The alternative drops the idea of a payroll tax on all employers, which had been proposed by Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who is chairman of the subcommittee considering the legislation. "

The payroll tax has been dropped and is not included in this substitute amendment," Mr. Stark said in announcing a compromise on the alternative devised over the last few days in quiet negotiations among Democrats on the panel, the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health.
Moving to the Center Mr. Stark had earlier proposed an alternative to the ambitious health care proposal offered by Mr. Clinton in October.

But Mr. Stark had to make concessions to gain the support of some Democrats on his panel like Representative Sander M. Levin of Michigan, who said he would not vote for any bill with a general increase in payroll taxes.
The tax proposed by Mr. Stark, equal to eight-tenths of 1 percent of payroll, would have raised $24 billion a year.
But the Democrats found other ways to raise the same amount of money, with a variety of new taxes and cutbacks in the growth of Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly.
The taxes are similar to those proposed by Mr. Clinton.

The new proposal, like one devised by Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, moves toward the center of the political spectrum in an effort to find votes for health legislation, which President Clinton has described as his top priority.
''My secrets have become overwhelming,'' the Olympic diver Greg Louganis wrote two years ago in his best-selling autobiography, ''Breaking the Surface.''
Any one of those secrets holds enough drama for a movie.
In the book, he revealed his long-rumored homosexuality and the fact that he has AIDS.
He looked back to a difficult boyhood.
His father was a tyrant and Greg's dyslexia was not diagnosed until he was in college.
And even while he was winning two gold medals in Seoul in 1988, his private life was in turmoil.
