Ernest S. Leiser, a television news reporter and producer for CBS who won acclaim for his coverage of Eastern Europe during the cold war and helped direct the network's transition to television from radio, died on Tuesday at his home in South Nyack, N.Y. He was 81.
The cause was congestive heart failure, a daughter, Nancy Leiser Foster, said.
Mr. Leiser was already a veteran war reporter when he joined CBS in 1953, having served as a reporter for the Army newspaper Stars and Stripes in World War II.
He soon distinguished himself as a foreign correspondent, becoming the only reporter to obtain film coverage of the 1956 uprising in Hungary.

In the early 1960's, Mr. Leiser was a central figure in the network's transition to television, and he proposed expanding the evening newscast to 30 minutes from 15, a change that was quickly followed by the other networks.
He also helped select Walter Cronkite as anchor of the ''CBS Evening News,'' which became TV's most popular evening news program during Mr. Cronkite's long tenure. ''
Ernie almost single-handedly brought CBS News from radio into television,'' said Dan Rather, the current anchor of the ''CBS Evening News,'' who was hired by Mr. Leiser in 1961.

Mr. Leiser also helped to direct the network's documentaries, and starting in the late 1960's he won Emmy awards for three consecutive years for producing features on subjects including the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. and life in Charlie Company, an infantry unit in Vietnam.
Mr. Leiser was born in Philadelphia in 1921, the son of a salesman and a teacher.
He graduated from the University of Chicago in 1941, and worked briefly as a reporter in that city before serving in the Army as a translator and correspondent.
The mayors of some of the world's biggest cities have every reason to feel especially anxious about climate change.
Their populations are the biggest polluters but also among the most vulnerable to weather-related catastrophes.
And they are far ahead of their national governments in giving urgency to global warming.
So, for the second time since 2005, the leaders of dozens of cities, representing 400 million people, have stepped up.
Meeting in New York this week, they produced a plan that should shame G-8 leaders into at least saying something about the issue at their meeting next month.
Most significantly, 15 cities, including New York, Chicago, Karachi, Toronto and Tokyo, signed on to a $5 billion program to make older buildings more energy efficient.
Energy-gluttonous cities account for three-fourths of greenhouse gas emissions the world over, and buildings are responsible for 40 percent of emissions and much more in older cities.
The project could reduce global carbon emissions by 10 percent.
It may be that the mayors, aware their powers end at the city limits, are more willing than holders of higher offices to take to innovation.
When Mayor Clover Moore of Sydney asks residents to turn off lights for an hour, the city goes dark.

Still, the incidents are expected to raise further concerns about the difficulty of isolating genetically modified crops from others because of cross-pollination or the mixing of seeds in processing or during shipment.

The strange career of Bill Brandt (1904-83), the German-born British photographer, invariably raises questions about a rift.

Why did the photojournalist who documented the stark contrast between England's rich and poor before World War II suddenly abandon his social mission and start creating surreal, high-contrast nudes and landscapes?
What links the man who photographed miners with coal-blackened faces and white teeth to the man who photographed women's blurry white limbs against black rocky cliffs?
The quick answer is: contrast.
Contrast was his weakness: between rags and riches in prewar Britain, grandeur and ruin in bomb-shattered Europe, black and white in a parlormaid's uniform, white skin against black rocks.
And when the world did not present enough contrast, Brandt created it.
Where did the lust for contrast come from?

The retrospective of Brandt's work at the International Center of Photography does not really answer the question, but it suggests that Brandt's taste for contrast determined even his documentary shots.
In 1929 Brandt worked briefly as an assistant in Man Ray's Paris darkroom.
There he picked up the Surrealists' repertory of uncanny shots -- mannequins without limbs, hats without heads, shops without customers and statues suffering in the frost and rain.

IT began in 1929 as ''The Town for the Motor Age,'' an exercise in creating a green, suburban utopia.
Even on a day when rain cascades across its glistening parks and winding footpaths, it still feels that way.

Created by some of the most celebrated planners and architects of its time, studied by design students around the world, Radburn exists as a model suburb where green spaces replace streets, yards become parks and instead of sprawl, there's a vision of the English garden city.

But three-quarters of a century after people first moved in, it seems there's a catch to this suburban idyll of about 2,400 people in about 700 homes within Fair Lawn, N.J. Utopia, or at least this version of it, never apparently included democracy: open meetings, reasonable disclosure, meaningful elections.

And so as Radburn's traditional amity unravels before people's eyes, there seem to be two main camps here -- those who say Radburn can't really live up to its ideals without open government and those who say Radburn can't remain Radburn with it. ''
Look around you,'' said Robert Gulack, gesturing toward the gardens outside the riot of Halloween decor at June Meyerson's house. ''
You'd think this is utopia.
People visit from around the world just to look at it.
Now, all we need is the right to vote, and we're good to go.''

Avoiding the 'E' Word "We want to forget '93," Green said. "

Yields on money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report declined for the week ended yesterday.
It was the second consecutive week that yields had fallen.
Analysts at Donoghue's said the downward pressures was coming from seasonal inflows from savings, bonuses and new pension fund allocations.
The latest week also saw a flight to safety as investors concerned about the prospect of war in the Persian Gulf moved money into the funds and Treasury securities from stocks and other investments.
This added more downside pressure and lowered yields further.

Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue's, said, "The current yield decline is faster in the tax-exempt sector, where concern over municipal creditworthiness has prompted a shift to very-short-term paper by fund managers to increase safety and liquidity."
The demand for shorter paper has pushed tax-exempt yields to below 5 percent for the first time since August 1988.
Mr. Frank added that dealers of municipal securities said there was virtually no action in the long end of the municipal market.
The average number of days that securities were held in tax-exempt portfolios declined by one, to 51 days.
Assets in these funds rose by $1.9 billion, to $90.8 billion, in the latest week.
The Xerox Corporation, which spent much of the last two years cutting jobs, selling assets and fighting off allegations of accounting irregularities, said yesterday that the pain had paid off.
Although revenue in the fourth quarter fell 13 percent, the company announced operating profit of 15 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of 25 cents a share in the quarter a year earlier.
And Xerox reiterated that it would turn a profit this year despite the recession. ''
Our people have worked outrageously hard, and they've finally fixed Xerox and restored its strength,'' said Anne M. Mulcahy, the chief executive of Xerox.

Including currency fluctuations and restructuring charges, Xerox posted a net loss of $4 million, or a penny a share, on revenue of $4.3 billion, compared with a loss of $20 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
For the full year, Xerox lost $293 million, or 43 cents a share, on revenue that dropped $2.2 billion, to $16.5 billion.
Investors seemed more focused on Xerox's improved chances for a profitable future than on signs of a bleak past.
They went on a buying spree, sending shares of Xerox  up $1.34, or 13.5 percent, to $11.24. ''
They did a great job on costs, and they're in a great position heading into 2002,'' said Jonathan Rosenzweig, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.
Xerox did wring $1.1 billion out of its annual costs in 2001.
When Chi Loek, a respected social worker, was charged this month with robbery and menacing with a weapon, his colleagues at the Chinese-American Planning Council quickly rallied to his support.

Although the police said Mr. Loek was suspected of joining a Hispanic man in  a spate of armed robberies of small grocery stores in Queens, Mr. Loek and his colleagues insist that it was a case of mistaken identity laced with racial overtones.

Police officers familiar with the case who spoke on the condition of anonymity pointed out that Mr. Loek was first identified by photographs by two of the robbery victims -- one from Astoria and one from Flushing -- and was later picked out in a lineup by the same two victims.
The Astoria victim, however, said that his assailant had a Korean accent and  that he could not be sure if Mr. Loek was the man who robbed him.
And law enforcement officials said a crime that matched the pattern of the robberies took place shortly after Mr. Loek's arrest.
The Queens District Attorney's Office is investigating to determine whether the latest robbery was linked to the others.
Mr. Loek's trouble began in January when he went to a building in Queens to collect unpaid rent for a friend.
Hours after he left the building, the tenants  called the police and said he threatened them with a gun.
Mr. Loek's lawyer, Regina Darby, said his client does not own a gun.

After Mr. Loek was charged with menacing with a gun and released on his own recognizance, the police showed his pictures at the grocery stores, because his  physical appearance -- Asian, 5-foot-9 and 150 pounds -- fit the description of  the Asian suspect in the robberies committed in December.
Businesses across Venezuela closed today, and millions of workers stayed home in a stunning display of opposition to President Hugo Chavez's economic program.

The daylong strike paralyzed the Venezuelan economy, Latin America's fourth largest, while raising the specter of more politically charged conflict between the left-leaning president and the country's increasingly antagonized elite.
Shopping malls, factories, banks and small businesses joined a 6 a.m.-to-6 p.m. ''paro,'' or stoppage, that affected practically every region in this oil-producing nation of 24 million people.

Highways, usually jammed in the capital during the morning rush hour, were mostly empty of cars, and the city's usually bustling downtown was ghostly, with shop shutters drawn and office towers empty.
Newspapers did not circulate today.
While oil production was largely unaffected, private schools and the Caracas stock exchange closed, some hospitals offered only emergency services, and professional baseball was suspended.
The protest was called by the country's most powerful business group, Fedecamaras, and supported by the largest labor confederation, which represents more than one million workers.
Fedecamaras claimed success while calling for Mr. Chavez's government to negotiate a series of recently approved economic laws that had angered entrepreneurs. ''
We are reaffirming this historic victory of all the Venezuelan society,'' said Pedro Carmona, the group's president. ''
There is a civil society that awakened today.

A series of murky Supreme Court decisions have left the agencies responsible for enforcing the Clean Water Act in a state of confused paralysis, exposing millions of acres of wetlands and thousands of miles of streams to illegal and destructive development.
Companion bills in the House and Senate would solve this problem by reaffirming the broad protections intended by Congress when it passed the law nearly 35 years ago.
These bills deserve prompt passage.
Two factors have caused the confusion -- ambiguity in the law itself, and a Supreme Court looking for any excuse to narrow the regulatory reach of the federal government.
There is little doubt that Congress originally intended to extend federal protection to all the waters of the United States, from small streams and wetlands to large rivers.

But because the word ''navigable'' pops up in the act from time to time, developers and other opponents of the law have argued that it should apply only to large, clearly navigable waters or streams immediately adjacent to such waters -- thus excluding most of the waters of the United States from federal jurisdiction.
A Supreme Court decision last June left the matter more tangled than ever.

One result is that for nearly a year the agency responsible for carrying out the law -- the Environmental Protection Agency -- has not been able to issue guidance to its field staff, opening the way to the pollution of waters that should have been protected.

The bills before Congress would resolve the issue in favor of the broadest possible protection by removing the word ''navigable'' from the law and by specifying in detail the waters -- large rivers, tiny streams, ponds, lakes and wetlands -- to be protected.
All of which, of course, makes perfect hydrological and ecological sense.
Q. My high-bush blueberries look quite sad with pale leaves and no flowers or fruit.
Could you say what's ailing them? --
Lucy L.-H. Yee, Flushing, Queens A. To look their best -- and be most fruitful -- blueberries must have direct sun at least half the day.
The soil must be moist, rich in organic matter and well drained.
But most important, the soil must be distinctly acid -- it should have a pH value between 4 and 5.2.
You can achieve this acidity most readily by adding around the plant a small amount of a solution of aluminum sulphate, following package directions precisely.
You can then maintain the soil acidity with regular applications of leftover coffee grounds and tea leaves.
To inspire flowering, also use a granulated complete 5-10-5 fertilizer (look for these hyphenated numbers on the package label).
Begin fertilizer applications in late winter, continuing at three- to four-week intervals through the growing season but stopping in late summer.
And finally, don't forget to keep your blueberries well watered when the days are hot and dry.
I WOULD like to take issue with two common complaints about car design today.
The first is that cars now all look alike.
Even if this were true, I don't see why it should be considered a problem.
Variety and choice are very fine and democratic, but as the essayist William Hazlitt put it bluntly, the principle of universal suffrage does not apply to matters of taste.
Why shouldn't ugly cars do their best to look like prettier models?
It is also commonly said that this is not a great moment in the history of car design.
Again, I disagree.

We're so accustomed to thinking of the car as a vehicle for the razzmatazz of bold innovation that we may be overlooking the rewards of simplicity and restraint, of subtle forms brought together in an organic, understated whole.
There is a class of car, the luxury sedan, that I think has been vastly underrated as an object of esthetic appeal in recent years.

In particular, I think the designs of the Jaguar XJ8, the Mercedes S-Class, the Infiniti Q45 and even the Buick Park Avenue and Cadillac DeVille -- two models usually thought of as stodgy, even dated -- reach something quite close to Platonic perfection.
THIS community and the Village of Great Neck to the north are experiencing sizable building booms even though both villages are already fully developed.
Four major residential projects totaling 402 units are under construction on parcels that had served a variety of other purposes.
One had been occupied by a school, another by a storage yard, another by a car dealership and the fourth by private houses and a doctor's office.

The fourth, a one-acre parcel at the corner of Middle Neck and Old Mill Roads in the Village of Great Neck, has become the site of Versailles Court, a four-story, 42-unit rental that will be the first of the four projects to open for occupancy.
Tenants will begin moving in tomorrow.
Rents start at $2,200 a month for an 800-square-foot one-bedroom.
The 1,200-square-foot two-bedroom units start at $2,800, and there is also one 1,600-square-foot three-bedroom apartment available at $3,550.
The  architect is the Newman Design Group of Melville and Sandsport Real Estate of Port Washington is the leasing agent.
While rents in the doorman building do not include heat, or even individual washers and dryers, they do include a treasured  commodity in the Great Neck area -- parking.
Each apartment is allocated two free parking spots, one in the garage.
IN assorted corners and crannies of the Wesley United Methodist Church in New Haven, people were making music.
Pianists pounded keys in the chapel, in an upstairs cubbyhole and in the basement.
Flutists and saxophone players also shared the basement; violinists played in a meeting room.
All were teachers and students in the Hill outreach program of the Neighborhood Music School, which brings music lessons -- and more -- to youngsters in one of New Haven's poorest neighborhoods. "
This is the Hill community," said the pastor of the church, the Rev. Amos Kwamenn.
He noted that in the mostly black and Hispanic neighborhood, many earned low wages and many others were on welfare. "
They are suffering," he said. "
The crime rate is very high, families are broken because of the conditions, our children are perishing." "

The church has to amass whatever resources there might be for the sake of the children," Mr. Kwamenn continued, "and so we see this program as a salvation and a sincere contribution, not only for the families but for the future.
The program offers the children the opportunity to raise up their hopes."
JUST as dessert puts a sweet exclamation to a meal, sweet wines can add luscious layers to any celebration.
Made in almost every wine region and with almost any grape, they range from relatively simple wines like muscats to some of the most complex and expensive wines in the world.
The methods for making these wines can be painstaking.
Good Sauternes are made from grapes infected with the botrytis mold, which shrivels them and concentrates the sweetness.
The best of these wines are made from handpicked grapes, ensuring that each is at maximum ripeness.
While many German sweet wines, like the luxurious Muller-Catoir, are also botrytized, the sweetest of all, Eiswein, is made by another method.
The grapes are allowed to freeze on the vine, which separates water from the concentrated grape essence, and are then pressed, resulting in a wine of great intensity.
The United States produces some of these wines, called ice wines, but I've never found one that matched the German combination of sweetness and acidity.
Tokay, Hungarian sweet wines, are part of a centuries-old tradition, made by combining a base wine with aszu, botrytized grapes kneaded into a paste.
The aszu is stored in a barrel called a putton (the plural is puttonyos) and then added to the wine one putton at a time.
The National Conference of Catholic Bishops oversees matters of religious doctrine for the Roman Catholic Church in the United States.

But some Catholics were alarmed when the bishops voted this week to extend their authority to the nation's Catholic colleges and universities, which educate large numbers of non-Catholics as well and historically have been independent of Rome.
The bishops say the goal is to get schools that define themselves as Catholic to meet the responsibility of safeguarding and strengthening the religion's identity.
But a new rule requiring theology professors to seek a formal certification -- or mandatum -- from the local bishops has raised fears of censorship and abridgment of academic freedoms.
The new rules emerged last week at the National Conference of Bishops' meeting in Washington.
The rules are a response to Rome's call for giving American Catholic colleges a closer connection with the church hierarchy.
The effort has drawn protests from faculty members at some of the leading Catholic universities.
Some university presidents are worried that the finances and reputation of their institutions would be harmed by a perceived threat to intellectual life on the campuses.

Among other things, the new rules say that Catholic colleges and universities should have Catholic presidents and that ''to the extent possible'' the majority of their trustees should also be Catholic.
These targets should be easy to meet, given that Catholics make up a quarter of the American population, span the political spectrum and include a variety of races and ethnic groups.

A national security bill that could undermine international peacekeeping operations and fundamentally change Washington's relations with the United Nations is arousing concern among officials here, in the capital and abroad.
The legislation, sponsored by Republicans, could be approved by the House of Representatives as early as next week, House aides and Administration officials say.

Worried that the bill will pick up support among Democratic critics of the United Nations in both houses, Clinton Administration officials and leading foreign policy experts are campaigning to organize opposition to the legislation in the Senate and among the public.

The bill, the National Security Revitalization Act, would cut United States contributions to peacekeeping operations, bar Americans from serving under foreign commanders except under specific conditions requiring White House certification and demand 15 days notice from the Administration when new missions are to be established by the United Nations.
It would also require that additional costs incurred by the Pentagon in support of United Nations actions be charged to the United Nations.

Such costs, even if they did not involve direct peacekeeping costs, would be credited against Washington's regular peacekeeping assessment; the United States now pays 31.7 percent of United Nations peacekeeping costs, which are estimated at more than $3 billion last year.
Parallel legislation in the Senate, where foreign policy action has been slower, has not yet reached the stage of floor debate.
But similar restrictions on United States participation in peacekeeping operations were proposed last month by Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, in his Peace Powers Act of 1995.
The Clinton Administration has already set set limits on placing American troops under foreign command in any peacekeeping operation.

Two former high-ranking State Department officials representing past Democratic and Republican administrations warned here today that if the bill was passed, it could not only bankrupt peacekeeping but threaten a young and already shaky post-cold-war international security system.
MANY companies this year have proclaimed that their annual reports disclose more financial information than ever before.
But that is not a trend being followed by a company that wants to go public, the Nasdaq stock market.
Nasdaq's first annual report, released last week, has almost no financial information printed in it, and what information it does contain is misleading.

The report does have page after page of photographs, including four of Hardwick Simmons, who became Nasdaq's chief executive last year after he stepped down as chief executive of Prudential Securities.
One photo showed him with Michael Jackson, another with Martina Navratilova.
There is also no shortage of slogans. ''
The Power of an Idea'' is the phrase on the cover.

Inside, across other photos, Nasdaq proclaimed itself to be ''the democratization of capitalism and the desire to move mankind forward'' and ''an energizing force at the center of the global economy.''
But the pages include no balance sheet, no earnings statement, no cash flow statement.

In his letter to shareholders, which follows 11 pages of photos, Mr. Simmons did briefly mention profits but offered few details beyond saying that net income rose to $40.5 million in 2001 from $23.2 million in 2000.
Androstenedione is legal in the United States, and Mark McGwire, a remarkably muscular man who hits home runs for a living, has a right to use it.
Whether it's a good idea to use it is another matter.
Mr. McGwire, a first baseman for the St. Louis Cardinals, has had a glorious summer and is now closing in on the single-season home run marks of Babe Ruth and Roger Maris.
Kids idolize him.
Fans have been filling ball parks from coast to coast to watch him swing his mighty bat.
When he comes to town, it's not enough to see the ball game.
You have to show up early enough to catch batting practice, to watch his screaming line drives and long, towering flies.
Even when Mr. McGwire is on the road he gets standing ovations.
After a McGwire home run on Sunday at Pittsburgh's Three Rivers Stadium, the delirious Pittsburgh fans demanded a curtain call, an extremely rare honor for a visiting player.
Mr. McGwire, somewhat embarrassed, obliged.

The abrupt and indefinite postponement of the Arab League summit meeting that was to have been held in Tunis last weekend was a more eloquent statement about Arab politics than any proclamation that might have come from the gathering.
The rulers-for-life who gather at these extravaganzas usually produce grand declarations that are quickly forgotten, or buried under the rubble of the Middle East.

Two years ago, the Beirut declaration, based on the Saudi peace initiative, was killed, in part, by a suicide bombing in Israel aimed at torpedoing any hope of a two-state solution for the Israeli-Palestinian standoff.
This time, under pressure from the Bush administration and from domestic dissidents to get serious about democracy, the Arab potentates were unable to agree even on a way to mark time.
There were other explanations for the collapse of the meeting.

The American-led occupation of Iraq has generated powerful anti-American sentiments throughout the Arab world, and Arab leaders are wary of appearing to fall in line behind President Bush at this time.
Israel's recent assassination of Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the founder and spiritual leader of Hamas, also fired up strong passions.

It is unfortunate that the Bush administration's arrogant foreign policies have alienated so many potential allies, and tragic that the Arab-Israeli conflict continues to feed hatreds across the region.
But while Mr. Bush is wrong to believe that he can impose democracy by force, he is right to demand that the Middle East begin cleaning its house.
The Arab world's need to defy Washington and revile Israel is not a valid excuse to perpetuate medieval autocracies and repressive dictatorships.

MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI paid a hugely successful visit to Albany earlier this week, and the happy results were written all over his face.
Sitting in the office of Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver on Monday, he spoke of his deep concern for New York's rent laws and his campaign to save them.
As the cameras whirred, he smiled contentedly.

Later that afternoon, the Mayor held a second news conference, this one to keep reporters apprised of how he had made out in meetings with the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and other lawmakers.

Once again, he beamed as he reasserted his commitment to preserving the rent laws and protecting tenants who are ''very, very afraid that they are not going to be able to afford to live in New York City.''
But while Mr. Giuliani toured Albany in a cheerful -- by mayoral standards even exuberant -- mood, the Capitol regulars he had come to visit were either conspicuously absent or downright dyspeptic.
Seated next to Mr. Giuliani at their joint news conference, Mr. Silver looked positively afflicted.

As Mr. Giuliani spoke, the Democratic Speaker averted his eyes, grimaced and made it very clear that posing beside the Republican Mayor was not really his idea, or, if it was, that he now deeply regretted it.

The Republican Senate majority leader did not appear publicly with Mr. Giuliani -- perhaps at the Mayor's request -- but he did give his own news conference to announce that no progress whatsoever had been made toward resolving the rent dispute. (
When Mr. Bruno released his rent plan yesterday -- calling for ending rent limits on apartments as they become vacant -- it seemed clear that the Mayor's visit had had little practical effect.)
BASKETBALL has always been easy for LaShannen Hogue.

She has excelled from the time she took it up, playing in pickup games with boys in the summer before the seventh grade, until now, and as a senior, led the Roosevelt High School team to the top seed in the Section 1 playoffs.
But schoolwork has not always been easy for Hogue, 18.
In her freshman year at Roosevelt, a school in Yonkers' inner city, Hogue failed two courses.
After taking night school courses and extra classes during the school day, she is not only graduating on time but has also pulled her average up to 90.
Her academics have been strong enough to help her get an athletic scholarship to the University of Delaware.
Eileen Torres, a social worker assigned to Roosevelt, is also the girls' basketball coach at the school.
She has observed Hogue's progress with satisfaction. ''
She is an absolutely terrific kid, and a bright kid, too,'' Ms. Torres said. ''
Shannen has a very supportive family but as a freshman she got caught up in that ninth-grade freedom: everything but academics.''
