LOGICALLY, THERE shouldn't be any such thing as a classic cocktail.
Mixed drinks tend to be invented on a whim, named as an afterthought, consumed on the spot and forgotten in an instant.
Like other products of American popular culture -- from movies and cartoons to television commercials and funny T-shirts -- most cocktails earn their oblivion.
Who will mourn the Fluffy Ruffles, a Prohibition favorite?
Or the Locomotive, a rebarbative mixture of claret, curacao, honey and egg yolk that oozed its way into cocktail glasses just before the turn of the century?
But the democratic process has dealt some injustices along the way.
Genuinely distinguished drinks have suffered the same fate as their emetic colleagues, tossed down the drain of history along with the Ants in the Pants, the Maiden's Blush and the Pacemaker.
These forgotten classics deserve to be rescued, not for antiquarian reasons but because they are fine drinks.
Perhaps the most puzzling case of neglect is the Bronx -- a tasty shake-up of gin, orange juice, and sweet and dry vermouth.
Created in the early 1900's, reputedly at the old Waldorf-Astoria bar, it instantly caught the public fancy.
ONE of the first things Hank Paine does when he unlocks his department store every morning is watch out for Ruth Synnott, the most faithful of faithful customers.
It's like clockwork. "
I get here at 7:15 and Ruthie follows 15 minutes later," Mr. Paine said.
Then they go down to the Coach Room Express, the diner in the basement, for coffee.
The Howland-Hughes Company doesn't really open until 10, but "Ruthie's part of the family," said Mr. Paine, the third generation of his family to run the business.
Mrs. Synnott, 84, lives around the corner.
She eats all her meals here and spends the rest of the day sitting with her home health aide and a friend near the front doors, by Men's Clothes. "
This is my house," said Mrs. Synnott, standing her full four and a half feet tall to wave to a store clerk from accessories. "
I wouldn't say that about another store.
If it goes -- I can't bear to think about it."
Like so many culture-war battles of the past decade, Rudy vs. the Elephant Dung is misunderstood as a dispute about art, free expression and public funds.
It is really about theater.
The various participants play parts as ritualized and predictable as those in Japanese No drama or commedia dell'arte.
Stock characters feign emotions of hurt and outrage.

Behind all the masks, though, the principal feeling is glee -- glee at the publicity, at the opportunity for demagogic posturing and, perhaps most supremely, the special glee that accompanies contempt for those with views contrary to one's own.

That is not to say that the groups that profit in one way or another from the culture wars -- the politicians, artists, cultural bureaucrats, art dealers, A.C.L.U. lawyers, critics and journalists -- share precisely the same motivation.
For a conservative politician, the appearance of obscene or sacrilegious art that can be linked to public funds is an opportunity to create an issue.
In less prosperous times, a Republican candidate might bait a liberal opponent over taxes, crime or welfare.
But those issues have been settled for the moment by a potent combination of Clintonism and Rudyism.
In boom times, as Pat Buchanan has recently discovered, the only real opportunities for populist rabble-rousing are in the realm of culture.
IN many 19th-century English novels, the country house and its gardens and outlying lanes play a leading role.
Like many of the novelists of that era, Wilson Eyre, a Philadelphia architect who lived from 1858 to 1944, let inspiration, and not the prevalent theories of the day, motivate his work.
Mr. Eyre was a leading architect in an American suburban style that exuded the warmth of hearth and home on a grand but never pretentious scale.
An exhibition on his work, "Graced Places: The Architecture of Wilson Eyre," runs through Sunday at the Arthur Ross Gallery at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia.

In the exhibition, spanning a 60-year career centering on the turn of the century, Mr. Eyre's houses and public buildings are revealed in 150 drawings, along with photographs, journals and travel scrapbooks.

Mr. Eyre stopped designing the popular Queen Anne house in favor of a more rustic style with gables, gambrel roofs and fieldstone walls arranged in what the show's curator, Jeffrey A. Cohen, refers to as "a dynamic asymmetry."
Inside, rooms served multiple functions in a kind of informality that centered around an oversized fireplace.

In his time, an architect planning a house with servants' wings and stable blocks would plan the surrounding landscape as well, "the garden forming as much a part of the house as the roof," Mr. Eyre told other architects. .

Since many of Mr. Eyre's drawings are aerial perspectives, the lay of the land carries equal importance to the architecture, and the settings show how, Mr. Cohen said, "the patterns of living were extended into the garden."
In line with the movement away from the city into nature, many of the landscapes were made to look as if they had preceded the houses.

The Federal Reserve Board has lowered short-term interest rates by six full percentage points over the last 34 months, but a substantial number of credit market analysts say the Fed has not yet finished easing monetary policy.
Last week's cut in the overnight Federal funds rate was seen by some analysts as insurance against possible renewed weakness in the economy.
At 3.75 percent, the funds rate now sits at its lowest level in 20 years.
But many analysts said the economic benefits of the quarter-point cut engineered by the Fed last week were negligible.
Moreover, the conditions that prompted the Fed to move last week show few signs of evaporating anytime soon.

Significant, but Not in Size The Fed's action "was more significant in the message than the size of the move," Thomas J. Sowanick, senior fixed-income strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company, wrote in a weekly letter to clients.
He continued: "That message underscores the fragility of the global financial markets, assorted political uncertainties and tenuous domestic economic growth.
The method of easing also indicates a return to an approach of gradualism.
That, in turn, suggests the Fed remains biased toward additional easing."

Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers, said the 25 basis points would not do much for the economy because it would not move the prime rate at all. "
One might think that a scathing critique of Japan by a Dutchman who speaks only limited Japanese and has no college degree would sell about as well here as a primer on styling blond hair.
But such a book, "The System That Makes Japanese Unhappy," by Karel van Wolferen, has become a best seller in Japan, with 240,000 copies in print so far.
The sales may be a tribute either to Mr. van Wolferen's perspicacity or to the masochism of the Japanese public.

Or perhaps Mr. van Wolferen is right when  he describes Japan as a neurotic country -- it is one of his gentler criticisms  -- because the book's sales have benefited from Japan's longtime fascination with what foreigners are saying about it.
Mr. van Wolferen is both widely admired and reviled as one of the most original thinkers about Japan in many years.
There is a wide range of views about whether his analysis is accurate as well as original.
In person he is not quite the raging tiger that his reputation as a commentator may suggest.
A 53-year-old classical music aficionado, he slumped in a chair at a hotel coffee shop in Tokyo, and spoke intensely but calmly about a  range of Japanese issues. "

I feel a little bit happy about this," Mr. van Wolferen said, not looking very happy, as he acknowledged the success of his book and the way in which some of his views have been echoed by opinion makers within Japan. "
But the situation is hopeless.

Under a clear sky lit by a three-quarters moon, a steady bombardment of Kabul began Sunday night, sending bright flashes of light and loud concussions rolling across this farming plain just 35 miles north of the Afghan capital.
The American strikes involved single heavy bombs thunderously detonating on targets.
Each impact lit up small sections of the plain and sent  concussions echoing off the surrounding mountains for 15 seconds.
American jets could not be seen or heard here, so the bombs fell silently from the sky, their detonations resounding with no warning and their flashes appearing unannounced.

The strikes, which began just before 9 p.m. Sunday here, prompted cheers and excited chatter from scores of Northern Alliance fighters manning mountainside positions in this village 2,000 feet above the strategic Shamali Plain that separates the main Afghan opposition force from Kabul.

Since the attacks in the United States on Sept. 11, the Northern Alliance has become a chief focus of American-led efforts to topple the militant Islamic Taliban government that harbors the terrorism suspect Osama bin Laden.

Indications of close recent coordination between the alliance and the Bush administration were reinforced Sunday when, hours before the bombing started, an alliance leader said the American military action was imminent.
That coordination was also evident on the ground.
Several hours after the American bombing began, forces of the Northern Alliance, which has been battling the ruling Taliban for six years, began firing rocket salvos at Taliban positions.
The salvos of Soviet-made rockets -- fired half a dozen at a time -- looked like fireworks at first and left long red tails of fire streaming behind each projectile.
If you suddenly discovered that everything you thought you knew about your family was a lie, how much of a psychological foundation would you have left?

That's the excruciating question facing Giovanni Orzan (Sergio Rubini), the central character of Piergiorgio Gay's film ''The Power of the Past,'' after a ghost of yesterday pays him an unwelcome visit.

A married 40-something writer of children's books with an 8-year-old son, Giovanni finds his world turning upside down when he is importuned by Gianni Bogliasco (Bruno Ganz), a pesky stranger who says he was a close friend of Giovanni's recently deceased father.
Wearing a sly smile, Gianni alarms Giovanni by offering intimate details about Giovanni's family that only the most dedicated stalker could have unearthed. ''

The Power of the Past,'' which is being screened today, tomorrow and June 8 at the Walter Reade Theater, is the initial salvo of the Film Society of Lincoln Center's series Open Roads: New Italian Cinema.
Now in its third year, the series continues through June 12 with 17 programs showcasing the talents of a new generation of Italian filmmakers.
Bit by bit, Gianni convinces Giovanni that he really was his father's friend.
But he also imparts information that the son finds almost beyond belief.
Instead of a conservative army general whom Giovanni despised as a fascist bigot, his father was a dedicated Communist and a spy (with Gianni) for the KGB.
The conversations between Giovanni and Gianni are heated sparring matches in which the older man gradually but relentlessly pulls the rug out from under the younger one's beliefs.

As Iraqis and occupation soldiers began their Christmas celebrations on Wednesday and early Thursday, guerrilla fighters unleashed a string of intense rocket and bomb attacks across the country, killing at least four American soldiers and six Iraqi civilians and wounding dozens of people, military and government officials said.

Christmas morning began in spectacular fashion, as insurgents fired more than a half dozen rockets at dawn in different parts of Baghdad, including at the American compound at the old Republican Palace.
At least one rocket slammed into the Sheraton Hotel around the eighth floor, shattering glass and damaging part of the building, but apparently injuring no one, witnesses said.
Another rocket hit a building east of the hotel, injuring several Iraqi civilians, said an American soldier guarding the hotel.
The soldier also said several rockets were fired at the adjacent Baghdad Hotel, but all missed.
He said some of the guerrilla fighters fired the rockets from several blocks east of the hotels, and occupation forces found anti-American fliers scattered around the area.
The whooshing of the rockets and their explosions could be heard for miles.

On Wednesday night, a round of powerful ordnance -- most likely a rocket-propelled grenade, the military said -- exploded at 8:30 above the roof of the Sheraton Hotel, a favorite of Western journalists and contractors.
The blast damaged part of the upper wall and the huge white S on the hotel sign.

The Coalition Provisional Authority said in a message to employees on Wednesday that it had indications that guerrilla fighters were planning operations to ''demonstrate that they are still a significant force.''
Early last summer, two days after arriving in Belgrade, I was summoned to an interview with Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian leader I consider a war criminal and a mass murderer.
I was led past a squad of thugs into an ornate chamber and told to wait.
Presently, the stocky English-speaking politician came in smiling.
He extended his hand and I took it.
It is a troubling memory.
Milosevic was not my first despot.

Over the years I had interviewed Idi Amin of Uganda, Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia, and the two men who brought Communist rule to Afghanistan, Noor Mohammad Taraki and Hafizullah Amin.
But each of them had maintained autocratic aloofness, showing a contempt for a lowly scribe that I thought was just fine.
I could do my job and they could do theirs.
They never offered their hands.

The Clinton Administration is taking a reasonable if controversial approach toward solving a worrisome problem caused by the dismantling of nuclear weapons in Russia and the United States -- how to get rid of thousands of plutonium ''pits'' from the warheads that are rapidly accumulating in each country.
America will need to dispose of more than 50 tons of excess plutonium.
Russia has an even greater stockpile.
Until these softball-shaped nuclear cores, now under guard at selected sites in each country, are somehow neutralized, they pose a double threat.
Either nation could reverse the course of disarmament and stick the plutonium right back into new weapons.
Or thieves, especially in economically distressed Russia, might steal some pits for use in bombs by terrorists or renegade nations.
The Administration has been reviewing dozens of possible solutions, ranging from firing the plutonium into space to burying it in holes so deep as to make the material virtually irretrievable.
This week the Energy Department announced two preferred alternatives that will be explored more thoroughly in a ''dual-track'' approach over the next two years.
One approach is to mix the plutonium with highly radioactive nuclear wastes and vitrify the material into glass or ceramic logs, making it difficult, costly and dangerous to extract the plutonium.

The other approach is to convert the plutonium into a mixed-oxide fuel that can be burned in nuclear power reactors, a process that leaves a form of spent fuel that is also difficult, costly and dangerous to reprocess.
The growth in medical spending by employers is easing, but their costs are still rising much faster than the 3 percent general inflation rate, according to a national survey released yesterday.
The survey showed that the average cost of care was $3,781 an employee last year, an increase of 8 percent, compared with 10.1 percent in 1992 and ending a five-year string of dougle-digit growth.
Corporate benefits managers said that in spite of efforts to control costs, health care continued to be a big problem for them and their employees.
Costs 'Out of Line' "We still have a crisis," said Margaret Jordan, a vice president for health care and employee services at Southern California Edison, a unit of SCEcorp. "
Costs that are almost three times the rate of inflation are out of line."
Employers and politicians are closely watching the cost trends as Congress weighs proposals for sweeping changes in the health care system.
David Rahill, a principal at Foster Higgins, the benefits consulting firm that conducted the survey, suggested that some Clinton Administration cost estimates were unrealistically low.
He said an employer's average insurance premium for a single employee would be $2,175 in 1994, nearly 13 percent higher than the Administration's projection of $1,932.
But Walter Zelman, a senior health care adviser in the Administration, said premiums were high "because millions of uninsured people are being paid for by those who are insured."
In the new system, he said, "more people will be insured and the cost of each policy will come down."

LEAD: To the Editor: To the Editor: ''Bargain hunters can relax,'' you say in ''The Sunshine in Gray Markets'' (editorial, June 3), because the Supreme Court ''upheld the right of discount stores to import most 'gray market' goods.''
Reports of the victory may be exaggerated.
The Court's ruling removed only one weapon, though powerful, from the anti-gray market arsenal.
Aside from the Tariff Act question, there are numerous lawsuits charging trademark infringement, unaffected by the Court's decision.
The result of these suits most often favors enjoining gray-market sales.
A Florida case holds that gray-market sellers lack good title to certain products imported in violation of manufacturer-imposed restrictions.
That theory, if adopted by other states, would effectively halt most gray-market sales.
Finally, a movement is under way in Congress to reverse the Supreme Court decision and change Customs regulation of gray-market imports.
Much needs to be accomplished before gray-market seller and consumers can relax.
SETH E. LIPNER  Assoc.
Except for the final score, Charles Smith's return was more successful than he had anticipated.
Smith tossed in 14 points and blocked 2 shots in 18 minutes of impressive play during New York's 106-103 loss to the Magic in Orlando Friday night.
It was Smith's first game action in seven weeks.
To Smith, it seemed as if he had waited seven months.
After undergoing arthroscopic surgery on his left knee on Dec. 7, Smith worked hard at rehabilitation, hastening his recovery.
But missing 23 consecutive games bothered Smith as much as the injury.
He knew the Knicks needed his 6-foot-10-inch size, his low-post scoring threat, his versatility, his shot-blocking, and his ability to draw double-teams.
Smith displayed those qualities Friday.
And looking ahead, it is difficult to imagine the Knicks winning a championship without a major contribution from him.
The organization did not trade for Smith or sign him to a seven-year, $26 million contract thinking that Smith would be a role player.
It is often said that bad cases make bad law.

Tuesday's Supreme Court ruling narrowing the scope of the Americans With Disabilities Act shows that a well-intentioned but imprecise law can generate valid court decisions that nevertheless frustrate the spirit of the statute.
There is little to fault in the unanimous decision.
The problem lies in the law's language.
Congress can and should find a way to eliminate the confusion it inadvertently sowed.
The disabilities act was passed in 1990 with broad bipartisan support and much acclaim.

It recognized that those with a range of physical and emotional limitations had been increasingly marginalized in American society both because of prejudice and failure to make simple modifications for them.
Regarding the workplace, the idea was that if someone is qualified for a job but has a disability or develops one while working, an employer should make a reasonable accommodation.
The law makes clear that bigger companies must accommodate more than smaller ones but no company should be unduly burdened.
The case of Ella Williams and Toyota that was reviewed by the Supreme Court fits the law's aims and requirements well.

The Nassau County Clerk, Harold W. McConnell, has taken steps to retire later this month, ending his 45-year career in the County Clerk's office under an avalanche of criticism for logjams in its operations.

Mr. McConnell, who is 73 years old, sent papers to the State Comptroller on Aug. 25 announcing his intention to leave, a decision he may rescind anytime before his retirement would become effective on Sept. 25. "
This is not the way I wanted to go out," Mr. McConnell said today, adding that the decision to step down before his term ends next year was "very difficult." "
I thought I would go out after serving my full term," he said. "
But the problems got to be too much.
I'm not 30 years old anymore."
Mr. McConnell's decision came as his office was struggling against budget cuts that reduced his staff by almost 50 percent.
Backlogs in the two branches of his office's operations -- court services and recording mortgages -- quickly mounted, since the office functioned largely without computers.
Because of the backlogs, the county and its towns and villages were temporarily deprived of millions of dollars in undeposited fees.

2 Lawsuits Lost The clerk's office lost two lawsuits in recent months -- one filed by the New York State Land Title Association and one by the county Bar Association -- for failing to record mortgages, deposit taxes and fees and enter court judgments in a timely fashion.
A Call From Uncle Sam Efforts by the United States Embassy in Paris to organize a fall showing by five American designers in the fashion tents outside the Louvre this March have been heavy going.
Nine designers were approached: Bill Blass , Bob Mackie , Calvin Klein , Donna Karan, Geoffrey Beene , Isaac Mizrahi , Michael Kors , Norma Kamali and Ralph Lauren .
In enlisting their support, Ambassador Walter Curley said he felt the time was right for Americans to make a splash in the European market.
So far, the response has not been overwhelming.
Ms. Karan and Mr. Klein declined because of scheduling problems.
In the normal design cycle, a Paris showing would require putting together a collection six to eight weeks in advance of when it would ordinarily be shown in New York in April.
Another obstacle: the 400,000 francs (about $80,000) each company would pay to underwrite the event.
Mr. Kors said that would preclude his participation.
Mr. Beene, who has shown in Europe, said the venture seemed too commercial.
Mr. Blass gave his regrets, too. "

Mohamed ElBaradei, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, infuriated the Bush administration a few years ago by challenging its baseless claims that Iraq was preparing to resume nuclear weapons work.
It turns out that Dr. ElBaradei can also be usefully outspoken about real nuclear dangers.

In his speech accepting the Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo last Saturday, Dr. ElBaradei spoke of the need to give his agency new tools to deal with countries, like Iran, that exploit their legal right to experiment with civilian nuclear technologies to master all the steps necessary to build nuclear bombs.
But he also stressed the importance of global nonproliferation efforts, including the need for the established nuclear powers to make sharper reductions in their cold war arsenals.
He noted that there were still about 27,000 nuclear warheads lying around, many of them on hair-trigger alert.
An overwhelming majority are located in Russia or the United States.
Americans have wrongly come to view nonproliferation as involving only countries like Iran and North Korea.
Eliminating those countries' programs is essential.
But to look only at rogues, as the Bush administration prefers, is a serious mistake.
The Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty is built around a grand bargain.
TURN on the television, and there's John Coltrane's resonant saxophone in commercials for Jeep Cherokee and Burger King.
Turn the channel, and there's Dinah Washington singing ''Destination Moon'' to sell Nike sneakers.
Open a magazine, and there's Lena Horne looking sharp in Gap jeans, or perhaps Cassandra Wilson smiling prettily next to a luxurious Coach handbag.

No one would have guessed that music once identified with the demimonde of smoky bars and drug addicts would become mainstream, capable, at least in the minds of advertisers, of selling almost anything.
Yet, for the last few years, that is exactly what has happened. ''
Jazz is a great untapped resource,'' said Peter Greco, a senior vice president and music director at the Young & Rubicam advertising agency. ''
Its freshness breaks through the clutter.
We look to legends like Miles Davis, Count Basie and John Coltrane for classicism.''
The changed perception of jazz may explain why so many commercials for expensive cars, among them Cadillacs, Mercedes and Jaguars, use the music. ''

We chose Nat King Cole singing 'The Very Thought of You' because we wanted to convey the timeless quality of Jaguar,'' said Lisa Kirschner, the senior music producer at Ogilvy & Mather, the agency that created the commercial.

Barbara Schwartz, an artist whose painted plaster reliefs were tangentially associated with the Pattern and Decoration movement in New York in the late 1970's, died on Monday in Manhattan, where she lived.
She was 58.
The cause was leukemia that developed from chemotherapy for ovarian cancer 12 years ago, said her companion, Richard Johnson.
Ms. Schwartz was born in Philadelphia and received her B.F.A. from Carnegie Mellon University.

After moving to New York, Ms. Schwartz had her first solo show at the Willard Gallery on East 72nd Street in Manhattan in 1975 and was subsequently represented by Hirschl & Adler Modern and then the Andre Zarre Gallery, where her most recent exhibition took place earlier this year.
She was in the 1979 Whitney Biennial.
In the late 1970's Ms. Schwartz was one of several artists who sought to vitalize abstract painting by making it more dimensional and also linking it to non-Western decorative traditions.
Her works balanced organic and geometric forms and sometimes reflected an Islamic influence.
In the 1990's she began to make some of her pieces from glazed ceramic.
Ms. Schwartz had taught at the School of Visual Arts since 1978.
Crammed with debris and tangles of electrical wire, the three long-condemned buildings on Park Avenue between 126th and 127th Streets are the epitome of urban blight.
Broken appliances and garbage spill onto the sidewalk, where dogs -- the four-story buildings' only permanent residents -- feed daily.
Passers-by might assume that the city owns these buildings and has let them rot, or that they belong to absentee landlords.
And on the heels of a building collapse on West 140th Street that killed three, the vision is frightening.
But the city cannot be blamed for these buildings, and their owner is so close at hand that he even occasionally sleeps on one of his rooftops.
He is Erling Rohde, a political advocate and jack-of-all-trades whose willingness to help people has endeared him even to some of his buildings' worst critics. "
This man is solid gold," said Marie Runyon, director of the Harlem Restoration Project. "
He will go anywhere, any time, for a cause he believes in."
Jay Lewin, a lawyer who until recently owned two nearby buildings, said that Mr. Rohde always helped with mechanical and heating problems. "
To watch him use his tools is a delight, because he is a truly resourceful craftsperson," he said.

On the eve of the entry draft for amateurs, the focus today was on a significant arbitration decision that cost the Devils a former first-round draft choice but added to their stash of picks on Saturday.
The case involved Mike Van Ryn, a defenseman who was 19 years old and playing for the University of Michigan when the Devils drafted him two years ago in the first round.
Van Ryn never signed with the Devils and spent one more year at Michigan before moving to play junior hockey for Sarnia of the Ontario Hockey League.
The Devils declared him a ''defected'' player under what they said were the provisions of the collective bargaining agreement.
The defected status would have kept Van Ryn's rights with the Devils, as if he had decided to turn professional in Europe.
Van Ryn and the N.H.L. Players Association countered by saying that he should not be classified as defected but rather should be an unrestricted free agent.
The arbitrator, Lawrence Holden, sided with the union and against the league.
As a result, Van Ryn can sign with any of the league's 30 teams.
He will remain subject to the rookie salary cap, about $1 million next season.
However, rookies can also negotiate performance bonuses, and the leverage of unrestricted free agency could increase the potential size of such bonuses.
Continental Airlines, long considered to be the leanest of the major airlines, said yesterday that it must cut wages and benefits by $500 million a year.
Otherwise, it said, it saw ''no prospect'' of becoming profitable, given industry conditions.
The announcement by Continental means that all the industry's traditional airlines have announced plans this year to reduce pay, jobs and costs.
All have been battered by high jet fuel prices and intense competition that has kept them from increasing fares.
Analysts expect the airlines to lose a total of $5.5 billion this year, on top of $30 billion in losses since 2000.
Just one big airline, Southwest, the biggest among the low-fare carriers, is expected to be profitable this year.
But at the start of 2004, Continental and other airlines hoped they could break even or post a profit for the year, as traffic returned to levels before the September 2001 attacks.
Instead, Continental said in a statement yesterday, it expected to lose ''hundreds of millions of dollars'' in 2004, on top of its previous losses. ''
Continental must adjust its costs to a level that will let it prosper and grow,'' said the airline, based in Houston. ''
Otherwise, it will have no prospect of returning to profitability under prevailing market conditions.''
IN Pelham, out-of-towners pay a premium to park at the train station: $390 a year compared with the $350 it costs villagers.
It is a similar story in Port Chester, where commuters from nearby towns like Rye Brook and Greenwich pay $470 annually, compared with the $256 that local residents pay.
All that, however, is likely to change as the Metro-North Railroad takes over parking lots in places along its lines.

With Westchester's rail commuters lining up for parking permits like Giants fans for season tickets, Metro-North has decided to enter the parking lot business and level the playing field for all customers. ''

It's a fairness issue,'' Marjorie Anders, a spokeswoman for the railroad, said, explaining why the railroad is taking over some of the parking lots it owns, instead of leasing them to the municipalities. ''
The goal is to improve access to our stations for all people, regardless of where they live.''
She added: ''Not everyone realizes that we don't control all the parking lots.
They assume that if it's our station, it's also our lot.
So we've decided that what we can control we will.''
An estimated 79,000 customers commute on Metro-North's lines every weekday during the morning rush.
Electric bills in New York have hit record highs in the last year, but Consolidated Edison and state regulators say they should have been a tad higher.

State officials have given Con Edison the go-ahead to raise its rates by $6 million a month, to correct what they and the company say was a mathematical error the utility made a year ago, but did not catch until recently.
The higher charge was included in March bills, they said.
The company said that last year, when it reached agreement with the state Public Service Commission on a new rate structure, it miscalculated when translating that structure into actual bills. ''
It was an error and we have to correct it,'' said Michael S. Clendenin, a spokesman for Con Edison. ''
It comes to 57 cents a customer per month for the typical residential customer.''
That represents about a 1 percent increase on the typical bill of $55, he said.
Con Edison notified the Public Service Commission staff of the error and asked for permission to adjust its rates upward.
The commission's staff agreed a few weeks ago.
The company did not ask to collect the adjustment retroactively, which would have required a vote of the full commission.

After a year of diminishing city, state and Federal support, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board voted yesterday to raise New York City subway and bus fares 20 percent, to $1.50, and increase most Long Island and Metro-North railroad fares 9 percent.
The board's 9-to-4 vote fell along expected lines; Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's four board appointees were in opposition.
And while the decision followed 90 minutes of angry comments from riders and elected officials, the board members discussed the fare proposal for just three minutes.
But the day was not without surprises.

The board dropped a planned fare increase for express buses, a service used mostly on Staten Island, handing an unexpected gift to residents of a borough that voted heavily for Mr. Giuliani for mayor and George E. Pataki for governor.
The board also postponed the increase by a week, to Nov. 12.
Board members said the added time was needed to cope with the mechanics of a fare change and a new token.
But transit officials immediately disputed that and said they were not consulted about pushing back the date.

Responding to questions from reporters, the board member who asked for the delay, James S. Simpson, said it was not intended to give added time for M.T.A., city and state officials to make a deal to reduce the size of the fare increase.
But he added, "There's always something that might happen, you never know."
THE most volatile part of the American economy has slowed significantly in the last nine months, providing a warning of both recession and lower stock prices.

The measure looks at growth in three broad areas that are the most sensitive to economic changes and to interest rates -- consumer purchases of durable goods, residential construction spending and business investment in equipment and computer software.
They can be called the sensitive sector.

In the fourth quarter of 2005, and again in the second quarter of this year, that part of the economy actually shrank, although a strong first-quarter performance meant that even that sector was up a little for the nine months.
As the accompanying charts show, the sensitive sector is more than three times as volatile as the rest of the economy.
But it has usually been a better performer.
Since the end of 1954, a period of more than half a century, the sensitive sector has grown at an average rate of 4.6 percent a year, compared with 3 percent for the rest of the economy.
Over time, a good indicator of both the economy and the stock market has been the relative performance of the two parts of the economy over nine-month periods.
Most of the time, the sensitive sector does better.
But when that sector turns in poorer performance after a sustained period of outperformance, it is a warning.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 4 -- John Franco did his best to tune out the circumstances.
He screened his calls, watched television and tried to relax, trying most of all not to think about how close he was to finally making the playoffs.
But tonight, wearing a drenched orange New York City Department of Sanitation shirt, Franco finally embraced what had for so long eluded him.
Franco was a Cincinnati Red until December 1989, when the Reds sent him to the Mets.
Unfortunately for Franco, the Reds went to the World Series the next season.
Since then, Franco has worked for the Mets, through lean years and near misses.
But until now, his only winning experience had been in college, at St. John's University, when the baseball team went to the regional championships that lead to the College World Series. ''
Now I don't have to answer the questions anymore,'' Franco said. ''
It feels great.
Every time you watch on TV and you watch teams celebrate, you wonder what it feels like.
An unlikely truck driver showed up on Tuesday night for the premiere of "Hoffa," the film about the legendary Teamsters boss Jimmy Hoffa. "

My husband and I just bought our first truck, a red Chevy with a stretch cab," said the socialite Blaine Trump, who keeps the vehicle in the barn of her new weekend home in Millbrook, N.Y. "I drive all over New England and go antiquing.
The last thing I bought was a pot rack.
Trucks come in real handy when you have a big pot rack for the kitchen."

The promise of a free pair of eyeglasses lured Anna Wintour, Liz Tilberis, Tina Brown and Sandy Gallin to the Tony Shafrazi Gallery in SoHo on Monday night for Calvin Klein's introduction of his new line of eyewear. "
I love a party that legitimizes looking in the mirror," said Monica Lynch, the president of Tommy Boy Records.
At a benefit for the Henry Street Settlement, Katharina Otto (in photo), a 27-year-old German film director, enthralled guests with tales of her high-speed adventures on the West Side Highway. "

We were driving 70," Ms. Otto said, explaining how she had filmed several bikers hanging on to her car for "The Need for Speed," a documentary for German television about New York City bike messengers. "
It was nerve-racking.
These guys will jump from driving car to driving car."
THE Blackwood was supposed to be exclusive, but perhaps not this exclusive.
Lincoln says it will stop building its luxurious pickup by next April, making it one of the shortest-lived models in memory.
The news came just five months after the Blackwood went on sale at prices of $52,500 to $54,495.
Although Lincoln now says it intended to make Blackwoods for only 18 months, it had once projected sales of some 10,000 a year.
Only 549 Blackwoods had been sold through March, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.
About 800 had been built but not sold -- about twice the inventory that would be expected, given the sales rate.
In a similar time frame, Cadillac sold 3,128 of the Blackwood's main competitor, the Escalade EXT.
Lincoln attributes part of the slow sales on problems that delayed the start of production for months.

In any case, the Blackwood will have a shorter run than market failures like the DeLorean DMC-12, which lasted two and a half years in the early 1980's, or the Edsel, which was produced for three years, as 1958-60 models.
On the other hand, Tucker built only 51 cars before it collapsed in scandal in 1948.
A Brooklyn grand jury has ruled out criminal charges for a city bus driver who fatally stabbed a passenger who had attacked him in May with a knife, the authorities said.
The driver, Clinton Phillip, 33, was not arrested after the incident.
Prosecutors said Mr. Phillip was driving a B60 bus in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn on May 5 when a passenger, Christopher Barton, 31, urged Mr. Phillip to hurry.
Mr. Phillip explained that he had to adhere to a schedule.
The two men argued, and Mr. Phillip stopped the bus, prosecutors said.
Mr. Barton pulled out a three-inch pocketknife and stabbed Mr. Phillip in the back, the police said.
In the ensuing scuffle, Mr. Phillip wrested the knife from his assailant and stabbed him in the chest, they said.
Mr. Barton then hailed a livery cab, and was driven to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where he died shortly afterward.
A Brooklyn grand jury spent six weeks investigating the incident and concluded yesterday that no criminal charges were warranted, said a spokesman for District Attorney Charles J. Hynes.
Reached at his home in Queens last night, Mr. Phillip declined to comment.
President Bush's appointment of 11 directors for the Legal Services Corporation brings to 53 the number of recess appointments he and President Reagan have made to the agency.
That must be some kind of record for cynical mismanagement.

Like other agencies, the corporation, which subsidizes antipoverty law programs across the country, is supposed to be governed by qualified directors nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate.
But the Reagan Administration tried to scuttle the program by appointing directors determined to wreck it, and the Bush Administration, buffeted by conservatives, has been reluctant to save it.
So many White House candidates have been hostile to the program that only once in a decade has a full slate of directors been both nominated and confirmed.

Although the Constitution provides for recess appointments as an emergency exception to the confirmation process, a hostile President Reagan and an indifferent President Bush have abused the process, contemptuous of Congress's shared role in staffing the corporation.
The new slate, like previous ones, includes a number of supporters and opponents of a system of vigorous antipoverty law offices.
The Administration's apparent goal is that friends of this embattled program be outvoted by enemies and self-styled "reformers" who want to curb its activism on behalf of the poor.
These candidates must be quickly nominated so their fitness can be tested in Senate confirmation hearings.
Otherwise the United States will embark upon another decade of neglect and government by recess appointment.

Mike Tyson faces a disciplinary hearing at the Montgomery County jail in Maryland today after he lost his temper Friday night and threw a television set against bars in a communal room at the facility.
Depending on the outcome of the hearing, Tyson could have some privileges, such as visitation, restricted.
The incident also complicates negotiations for a reduction in the one-year jail sentence that Tyson drew on Feb. 5 for assaulting two men after a traffic accident in Gaithersburg, Md., last Aug. 31.
Tyson, 32, pleaded no contest to the two misdemeanor assault charges on Dec. 1.
Tyson has been confined to an isolated cell since Friday's incident.

Eric Seleznow, the acting public information officer for the Montgomery County Detention Center, said the former heavyweight champion will go before members of the correctional staff for a hearing to determine disciplinary action.
Seleznow said it appeared that Tyson's act was not directed at any inmates or members of the staff.
A person close to Tyson said he had not had his prescribed dosage of Zoloft since Wednesday.
Tyson has taken the antidepressant every day for the last four months -- except the week of his fight against Francois Botha on Jan. 16.

The person said Tyson's medication was cut off because of a dispute over his treatment between the Montgomery County detention center psychiatrist and Tyson's personal psychiatrist, Dr. Richard Goldberg, who heads the Georgetown University Medical School Department of Psychiatry.
In the aftermath of this civil war that our nation has just fought, one result is clear: the Democratic Party's first priority should be to reconnect with the American heartland.
I'm writing this on tenterhooks on Tuesday, without knowing the election results.

But whether John Kerry's supporters are now celebrating or seeking asylum abroad, they should be feeling wretched about the millions of farmers, factory workers and waitresses who ended up voting -- utterly against their own interests -- for Republican candidates.
One of the Republican Party's major successes over the last few decades has been to persuade many of the working poor to vote for tax breaks for billionaires.
Democrats are still effective on bread-and-butter issues like health care, but they come across in much of America as arrogant and out of touch the moment the discussion shifts to values. ''
On values, they are really noncompetitive in the heartland,'' noted Mike Johanns, a Republican who is governor of Nebraska. ''
This kind of elitist, Eastern approach to the party is just devastating in the Midwest and Western states.
It's very difficult for senatorial, Congressional and even local candidates to survive.''
In the summer, I was home -- too briefly -- in Yamhill, Ore., a rural, working-class area where most people would benefit from Democratic policies on taxes and health care.
But many of those people disdain Democrats as elitists who empathize with spotted owls rather than loggers.

About 3.3 million American consumers discovered within the last year that their personal information had been used to open fraudulent bank, credit card or utility accounts, or to commit other crimes, according to the Federal Trade Commission's first national survey on identity theft.
The commission, in a report issued today, said these cases had collectively cost businesses $32.9 billion and consumers $3.8 billion.
In addition, 6.6 million people fell victim to account theft in the last year.

Unlike identity theft, in which the criminal uses personal information to open and use accounts that are in the victim's name, account theft entails using stolen credit or A.T.M. cards, or financial records, to steal from the victim's existing accounts.
Such account-theft cases, the survey found, caused $14 billion in business losses and $1.1 billion in consumer losses.
The vast majority of these cases, almost 80 percent, involved credit card fraud.
Though account theft and identity theft are often lumped together in popular perception, data from the survey showed that the consequences of identity theft were more severe.

In identity theft, which accounted for nearly 10 million of the 27 million cases of both types in the last five years, the financial losses were greater, and it took victims longer to resolve the cases.

On average, losses to businesses and financial institutions in instances of fraudulent new accounts were $10,200 a case, and the average cost to consumers was $1,180, in addition to 60 hours spent repairing their credit history.
In contrast, theft involving a victim's established accounts cost businesses $2,100 a case, and consumers $160 plus the average of 15 hours spent clearing up the situation.
The MetroStars lost three players in yesterday's expansion draft by Major League Soccer's two new teams.
Chicago and Miami drafted 24 players apiece from the 10 existing teams.
The three MetroStars who were taken -- midfielder Manny Lagos, defender Andrew Lewis and goalkeeper Zach Thornton -- all went to the Chicago Fire.
Defender Danny Pena of the Los Angeles Galaxy was the first player selected and he went to the Fire.
Pena was the first player taken in the supplemental draft last winter.
When he was made available by the Galaxy, Pena said he would not move from Los Angeles, but he has no choice because the league owns his contract.

The Miami Fusion made defender Dave Vaudreuil of D.C. United its first selection, before goalkeeper Kevin Hartman of Los Angeles went to Chicago as the third pick in the draft, which was conducted by a conference call presided by Deputy Commissioner Sunil Gulati.
Three of the first six players selected were from D.C. United, the champion in the league's two years, and all three went to Miami.
Midfielder John Maessner was taken fourth and defender Kris Kelderman was chosen sixth, after the MetroStars' Lagos was taken by Chicago as the fifth choice over all.
Chicago and Miami will be allocated five players each by the league, which owns the contracts of all the players.
A wide variety of household objects like children's raincoats, Barbie toys and telephone cords contain dangerously high levels of lead, Greenpeace said in a report today.
Greenpeace cited tests it had commissioned by an independent laboratory that frequently works for Government agencies.
The Consumer Products Safety Commission, which has the power to recall such manufactured goods, said a quick check of some of the products did not show any problem.
But in the few days before the Greenpeace report was issued, the commission did not test the products that Greenpeace found to be most heavily contaminated.
The commission also did not expose the objects to heat and sunlight, as Greenpeace did to simulate aging.
Some experts said the issue was not how much lead was in the products but how likely it was to come out and be available for ingestion.
That would depend in part on how much the plastics were broken down over time by sunlight, the experts said, and how likely some would be exposed to sunlight for long periods.
Ingestion of lead causes health ailments, depressed intelligence, irritability, insomnia, infertility and, in large enough doses, death.

William C. Walsh, who heads Greenpeace's efforts on toxic substances, said swallowing an extremely small part of some of the objects would cause poisoning by lead or by cadmium, a cancer-causing heavy metal in some of the toys.
Federal law sets a maximum of 600 parts per million for lead in paint or other surface coatings.
Japan's economy, after more than a decade of fitful starts, is once again growing smartly.

Instead of rejoicing, however, Japan is engaged in a nationwide bout of hand-wringing over increasing signs that the new economy is destroying one of the nation's most cherished accomplishments: egalitarianism.

Today, in a country whose view of itself was once captured in the slogan, ''100 million, all-middle class society,'' catchphrases harshly sort people into ''winners'' and ''losers,'' and describe Japan as a ''society of widening disparities.''
Major daily newspapers are running series on the growing gap between rich and poor, with such titles as ''Divided Japan'' and ''Light and Darkness.''
The moment of reckoning has come as the man given credit for the economic revival, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, prepares to retire in September after more than five years in office.

Mr. Koizumi's Reaganesque policies of deregulation, privatization, spending cuts and tax breaks for the rich helped lift the national economy, but at a social cost that Japan's more 127 million residents are just beginning to grasp.
Thanks to a growing economy and rising corporate profits, companies hired several hundred thousand more young Japanese for the start of the fiscal year on April 1.
The broad Topix stock index closed recently on a 14-year-high.
Commercial land prices in the country's three biggest metropolitan areas rose for the first time in 15 years, and high-rise luxury apartment buildings have kept sprouting across Tokyo.
At the same time, the number of Japanese without any savings has doubled in the last five years, and the number receiving welfare payments or educational assistance have spiked by more than a third.
THE brown ducks swimming in the inlets, the gulls swooping low in the sky, the herons stalking fish in the shallows -- all are testimony to the diverse ecology of Long Island Sound.
They could also be advertisements for the environmental center about to open in a 200-year-old converted house in Cove Island Park in Stamford.
The Sound is a delicate estuary within 50 miles of 25 million people.

Those humans -- and the threats their activities pose to the health of the Sound -- motivated Len Miller to found an organization in 1989 to educate people about the wonders of Long Island Sound and the dangers it faces.
SoundWaters began with a schooner that serves as a floating classroom where students learn through a hands-on curriculum.
The ship also offers programs for adults, including lectures presented by ecologists,  musicians, artists and historians; teacher-training workshops; and weekend ecology sails.
SoundWaters then expanded to offer land-based programs, including classroom workshops and field trips, summer camp, community gardens, and nature programsfor older residents. ''
I felt that if there is going to be any improvement in Long Island Sound,'' Mr. Miller said, ''there must be two things: education and cooperation between corporations, government and individuals.

There was criticism of me back in '89, people who said you could not have cooperation between environmentalists and corporations,'' but he pointed out that today the groups more commonly work together.

He said the SoundWaters Community Center for Environmental Education, which will have its grand opening next weekend, will greatly enhance the opportunities to  provide education to people of all ages.
IF a person is happening, they are because of what they're like on the inside," said Chris Brick, an owner of Smylonylon, a clothing store that opened last year in SoHo.
Terminal hipness, in other words, can't be achieved by imitating someone or by spending a lot of money.
Still, times are tough. "
From the looks of it," he lamented, "everybody's going to be in baby pink and powder blue T-shirts this summer."
Smylonylon (pronounced SMILE-on-NY-lon), at 222B Lafayette Street, near Spring Street, offers a tawdry alternative to whatever look is on the soon-to-be-dead list.
Nylon is the fabric of choice in this store, which specializes in men's and women's clothing produced in the 1960's and 70's but never worn.
Mr. Brick, who owns the shop with his wife, Judy, is no stranger to the business, having run a clothing shop, Demob, in both New York and London.
The dozens of fake pearls and random toys glued to the storefront make it difficult for passers-by to ignore Smylonylon, but the interior is truly striking.

Entering this shop, which is embellished with brightly lighted slabs of colored plastic and pulsing with what Mr. Brick calls "uneasy listening music" (including belly-dancing and go-go records), is like stepping into another time.
Together, the Bricks fight against a dowdy world.
The pitching-starved Texas Rangers contacted the Yankees and inquired about pitcher Esteban Loaiza last week, according to an executive with one of the teams.
Since the Yankees are temporarily employing a six-man rotation, the Rangers hope they can obtain the struggling pitcher at a modest price.
The team executive said the Rangers, who are the aggressors in these discussions, have not made the Yankees a concrete offer.
But the Rangers would like to get Loaiza for minor leaguers.
Although the Yankees will continue to listen to Texas, they have not been actively shopping Loaiza.
The Rangers have used a major league high 15 starting pitchers so far this season.
The 1989 San Francisco Giants are the only team that made the postseason after using that many starters.
That is why one official from an American league team described the Rangers as desperate to add a starter.
The Yankees exchanged Jose Contreras for Loaiza in a trade with the Chicago White Sox on July 31.

Although the Yankees talked optimistically about getting contributions from Loaiza, who won 21 games last season, they made the deal mostly because shedding Contreras allowed them to save $12 million in the difference in the remaining salaries.
This should be a happy time for Willis Reed.
Four of the players he has drafted in his five seasons as general manager of the Nets are on their way to the National Basketball Association All-Star weekend in Minneapolis.
But one of them, Derrick Coleman, is still unsigned.
And there's the rub. "

I'd rather not say where the negotiations are now, because I've put my foot in my mouth many times on this deal," Reed said after New Jersey's 106-95 victory over Cleveland in the Meadowlands on Wednesday night brought the Nets record to 22-24 at the All-Star break. "
I thought we had a deal at one time, so we're still trying to get him signed."
The deal Reed thought he had with his 6-foot-10-inch power forward before this season was a five-year contract extension for a reported $35 million.
Then Larry Johnson signed an eight-year extension for $68 million with Charlotte and suddenly all deals were off.

Within a week, Coleman had turned down an offer of $69 million for an eight-year extension, and recently there were rumors that he and Reed had agreed to a nine-year $90 million deal that needed only ownership approval.
Reed denied that was the case.

A federal magistrate judge has ordered The New York Times to disclose the identities of three confidential sources used by one of its columnists, Nicholas Kristof, for columns he wrote about the investigation of the deadly anthrax mailings of 2001.

The order, issued Friday by Magistrate Judge Liam O'Grady, requires the newspaper to disclose the identities of the three sources to lawyers for Dr. Steven J. Hatfill, who has brought a defamation suit against The Times.
The order was disclosed Monday.
Catherine Mathis, a spokeswoman for The Times, said the newspaper would appeal the ruling.

Dr. Hatfill, a germ warfare specialist who formerly worked in the Army laboratories at Fort Detrick, Md., has asserted that a series of columns by Mr. Kristof about the slow pace of the anthrax investigation defamed him because they suggested he was responsible for the attacks.
Five people died in the attacks.
Although the federal authorities identified Dr. Hatfill as a ''person of interest'' in the case, they have not charged him with any crimes.
At a deposition on July 13, Mr. Kristof declined to name five of his sources for the columns, but two have subsequently agreed to release him from his pledge of confidentiality.
Judge O'Grady's ruling identifies the remaining unnamed sources as two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and a former colleague or friend of Dr. Hatfill at Fort Detrick.
The judge ruled that the laws of Virginia applied and that under that state's law, reporters have only a qualified privilege to decline to name their sources that may be outweighed by other factors.

Led by Islamic nations, representatives of more than 40 countries took the floor at the General Assembly today to condemn what one of them called a "systematic campaign of genocide" against Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The two-day session was called to consider a resolution offered by Turkey that would invoke a section of the United Nations Charter permitting military intervention.
Turkey raised the issue of invoking Chapter 7 of the Charter on behalf of the 47-member Islamic Conference.
Chapter 7 authorizes the Security Council to "take such action by air, sea, or land forces as may be necessary to maintain or restore international peace and security."
But it specifies that such action can be employed only after economic embargoes have failed.
The Council has already approved the use of force in Bosnia for limited purposes.
On Aug. 13, it voted to allow military action to assure the delivery of food and medicine.
If the General Assembly adopts this new resolution on Tuesday, it will next be sent to the Security Council, which has sole authority to authorize force in what remains of Yugoslavia.
Few of today's speakers went as far as the proposed resolution.
Most, while decrying the horrors of the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, called for continued efforts toward a diplomatic solution.

We really have no idea what happened,'' said Al O'Leary, a spokesman for New York City Transit.
He said the machines' manufacturer was investigating a possible telecommunications problem.
Another suspect was the switch to standard time from daylight saving, but Mr. O'Leary noted that 250 machines were in use during last year's switch and there was no problem.
He said the machines would be in service by this morning. (

NYT) BROOKLYN: 7 FIREFIGHTERS HURT  Seven firefighters suffered second-degree burns yesterday when flames burst through the doorway of a burning apartment, said Firefighter Robert Calise, a Fire Department spokesman.
The firefighters quickly extinguished the fire, which started at 11:43 a.m. on the top floor of a four-story brick building at 3301 Farragut Road in Flatbush.
Six of the firefighters, who suffered cuts and second-degree burns, were treated and released, and Firefighter Mark Merrell was admitted to the burn unit of the New York-Presbyterian Hospital.

It used to be said that the rivalry for Britain's leadership between Prime Minister Tony Blair and the chancellor of the exchequer, Gordon Brown, was simply the open secret at the heart of the nation's politics.
But with politicians speculating about an election in May, the rivalry was depicted as nudging toward open warfare.

For several days, Britons have been treated to an unfolding, tit-for-tat tussle between Mr. Blair and his finance chief, even as opposition politicians charged that the two men were pursuing their feud at the expense of the tsunami relief effort.
Michael Howard, the leader of the opposition Conservatives, said they were ''squabbling like schoolboys.''

In addition, a new book excerpted in the anti-Blair Sunday Telegraph reopened a debate over whether Mr. Blair had promised Mr. Brown that if Mr. Blair became prime minister, he would step down to make way for Mr. Brown.
That pledge, dating from 1994 -- never publicly confirmed -- has haunted the prime minister.
According to the book ''Brown's Britain'' by a Sunday Telegraph editor, Robert Peston, Mr. Blair again told Mr. Brown in November 2003 that he would step down.
Then, in the fall of 2004, Mr. Blair changed his mind, according to the book.
He also said he would seek a third term.

The dispute has consumed so much of the attention of Britain's political class that Sir Nicholas Young, the head of the British Red Cross, said it was ''worrying that more papers feature the Blair-Brown saga on their front pages than they do the tsunami crisis.''
Stanley Salzman, an architect and industrial designer who received many honors as a teacher in both fields, died on Monday at the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.
He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.
He died of stomach cancer, a family spokesman said.
Professor Salzman taught architecture and design at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn for 46 years.

For distinction as a teacher, he was named a Fellow of the National Institute of Architectural Education, Pratt Institute's Distinguished Professor of Architecture, a Fellow of the American Institute of Collegiate Schools of Architecture and also Distinguished Professor there.
Professionally he was a Fellow of the American Institute of Architects.
He worked with major architectural firms, including that of Walter Gropius, Marcel Breuer and Skidmore Owings before helping to establish Salzman & Breger in Manhattan in 1947.
In 1955, he opened his own firm, Stanley Salzman, Architect.
From 1960 to 1979, he was a partner in Edelman & Salzman, which was then sold.
From 1979 on, he worked on special projects, including a book, "Drawing and Color," written in collaboration with Albert Lorenz, a colleague and former Salzman student at Pratt Institute.
Seashore Plantings Q.  I live at the beach.
Can you help me with some plants that will survive in a very sunny garden with very poor soil that is mostly sand?
A.  Before I help out with the plants, please promise you will help out your soil.

No amount of amendment will turn your place into English border territory, but if you choose a few planting pockets (or build raised beds) and add lots of organic matter to them, everything you plant in those favored spots will show its deep gratitude.
Since it's much too hot and dry right now to plant anything, you've got time to add compost and composted manure before cooler temperatures and autumn rains usher in the next planting season.
Since you're at the shore, it will be easy to add seaweed to the mix.
Just rake up that storm-delivered eelgrass and spread it for mulch.
You don't need to dig it in or wash the salt off.
Plan to use a balanced fertilizer at planting time.
Compost, manure and seaweed are wonderful soil builders, but they use nutrients while decaying and are not themselves rich in primary plant foods.

Two generations of Fordham University basketball players, separated by 20 years and an undetermined number of pounds, crossed paths at the edge of the basketball floor at Madison Square Garden last night.
The middle-aged gentlemen had gathered to celebrate their past.
A younger group, infants or toddlers when the 1971 Rams filled the Garden twice within eight days 20 years ago this week, continued their work near the end of a highly successful season.
Fordham's current Rams defeated Dayton, 73-63, to complete their regular season with a 22-6 record.
Going into the inaugural Patriot League tournament, the Rams have the third most victories in school history, behind the 1919 team, which won 24 of 29 games, and the 1971 group, which finished 26-3.
They are the seventh team in 85 years to win 20 games or more, but the first to win that many for two consecutive seasons.
The achievements of their 40-something predecessors were to be updated -- and in several cases, revised -- at a party late last night.

But the business of the current Rams, their pursuit of the school's first appearance in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in 20 years, was helped when the most successful of the 1971 Rams stopped by practice Friday afternoon.
Charlie Yelverton had returned from Italy, where he has coached since his playing career ended.
He received some of the loudest cheers yesterday evening when he was introduced with his former teammates during halftime.

The advertising push behind Michael Moore's new documentary critical of President Bush, ''Fahrenheit 9/11,'' is angering some Republicans, who say it is little more than a commercial campaign devised to help Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts.
For instance, one television commercial for the film, which opened nationally on Friday, shows Mr. Bush in mid-golf game, talking emphatically to news cameras that follow him around the course. ''
We must stop these terrorist killers,'' he says before turning his back to tee off and shouting back at the pack, ''Now watch this drive!''
The scene is one of many featured in the film that paint the president as cavalier, cynical and insincere in the war against terrorism.

Until the marketing campaign began, Republicans had been dismissive of the film, arguing that it would have little effect on the election because its audience would consist mostly of people already planning to vote against Mr. Bush.
But the advertising campaign has been a different story. ''

There's only a very small percentage of Americans that are going to go and see this movie,'' said David Bossie, head of Citizens United, a conservative group that has run advertisements to promote Mr. Bush. ''
A much larger number are going to be bombarded by these political ads run by Michael Moore, potentially all the way through the election.''

Mr. Bossie has asked the Federal Election Commission to classify the advertising as political and subject to rules that restrict broadcasts of commercials paid by unregulated money from corporations or unions.
Under those rules, the advertisements for the film would have to stop 30 days before the Republican National Convention begins on Aug. 30.

The Carlson Hospitality Group announced plans yesterday for three hotels and a restaurant in Branson, Mo., a country-music village of 3,700 in the Ozarks that is said to attract more than five million visitors a year.
The hotels, projected to be open in 1995, will add 725 rooms to the 12,000 now available in the southwestern Missouri community.
Still, Branson is isolated as things go, a four-hour drive from big cities, and it does not now have commercial air service.
That, plus the fact that its popularity as a tourist attraction has developed mostly in the last few years, means that few hotels in the area are now owned or managed by major hotel corporations.
With so many visitors and relatively few rooms, Branson hotels are all but sold out from May through October, during the week and on weekends.
One piece of relief due soon is a 500-room Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza, under construction and expected to open in the fall.

The development announced yesterday is part of a 53-acre project called Heartland America, which will include two new entertainment theaters with a total of 5,300 seats and a three-story office complex.
It is being jointly developed by the Presley family of Branson and by Talentino, Horn & Company.
Neither organization would disclose how much the venture might cost.
Vicki Bohlsen, a Heartland America spokeswoman, said she had been told not to discuss financial matters.
In the Piano Room of the Kew Gardens Community Center last week, Thelma Rodriguez, Wordmaster and Grammarian of the Queens Toastmasters, rose to perform her duty. ''
I'm so nervous!''
she said, almost whispering, as she approached the front of the fluorescent-lit room.
She took out a strip of paper with that night's vocabulary word on it and pronounced it slowly: ''IN-TER-LUDE,'' she said. ''
It's a noun which means an intervening episode.''
She taped ''interlude'' to the lectern and implored everyone to use it as many times as possible.
Ms. Rodriguez, who also holds the title of sergeant-at-arms, and a few dozen others make up the Queens Toastmasters, one of nearly 100 such clubs within New York City.
With 200,000 members in 80 countries, the Toastmasters are truly global: Denise Cummings, the treasurer of the Queens group, recently attended a meeting in China.
Toastmasters are not, as one might think, specialists in offering unsolicited praise at wedding receptions.
Some are diffident and quiet, others self-assured and loud, but all of them share an interest in perfecting their formal public speaking abilities.
Air Supply Q. When I sleep in a rather small hotel room with my rather large husband, and the windows and doors are tightly closed, are we in danger of using up the oxygen overnight?
A. If there is enough space to stand up and stretch out comfortably in the hotel room, there is very little danger of using up the air supply overnight.
One physiology book, "The Body," by Anthony Smith (Walker & Company), estimates  overnight air requirements at 1,100 gallons, the amount enclosed in a block 6 feet by 6 feet by 5 feet.
Just to be on the safe side, you might want to lie still.
A resting body uses far less oxygen than one doing vigorous exercise.
A normal day's breathing involves only about 3,300 gallons of air, or 530 cubic feet, the book estimates; vigorous exercise raises demand fifteeenfold or twentyfold, to 20 gallons every  minute.
A resting human body does use a significant amount of pure oxygen.
According  to another physiology text, "Human Physiology," by Bernard Houssay, et al. (
McGraw Hill), a resting body uses 226 to 242 cubic centimeters per minute, about 14 to 15 cubic inches.
Brisk walking raises demand nearly tenfold.

ANDREW FARKAS insists that he is still the ''mean, wicked geek'' he proclaimed himself to be about a year ago as he prepared to inaugurate the Edi ficeRex Internet residential service portal and other Internet-based products.

But with EdificeRex continuing to lose money and with other initiatives folded or fading, he said his company, Insignia Financial Services, was focusing less on the possibilities offered by technology and more on real estate.
The Internet term B2B, he said, now stands for ''back to business.''

The computer savvy Mr. Farkus, chairman of the company that owns the Douglas Elliman and Insignia/ESG retail and commercial brokerages in New York, said he is now painfully aware that people do not change as quickly as technology.
The Internet ventures have cost the company about $35 million over the last 18 months, Mr. Farkas says, and produced a change in corporate attitude. ''
We will look skeptically upon any new technology-related investment opportunities,'' the company said in its year-end earnings statement.
Insignia is not the only New York area real estate company to have stubbed its toe in the New Economy last year.

Companies associated with Vornado Realty Trust and the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, two of the largest owners of commercial property in the area, backed Internet start-ups that either failed outright or never came close to meeting expectations.
Although the companies that actually backed the start-ups are legally separate from the two real estate investment trusts, both are closely linked to their former parents.
In all three instances, the financial losses were not large enough to endanger the health of the overall companies.
It is no secret that some of the richest candidates are some of the most successful.
The combined net worth of Mayor Michael Bloomberg, Gov. Jon Corzine of New Jersey and Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York is enough to buy not just an election, but a small country.
The way to deal with this mega-millionaire's advantage is not to open the floodgates to large contributions from other wealthy people, companies and unions, the way New York State does now.
It is to offer public financing to candidates who are qualified but not rich.
Governor Spitzer and the New York Legislature are locked in a debate -- mostly behind doors, as usual -- about how to change the state's campaign financing system.

They are looking at ways to set contribution limits, which right now are, in the words of Rachel Leon of Common Cause New York, ''shameful,'' ''an embarrassment'' and ''among the very weakest laws in the nation.''
Progress on a campaign finance package has been slow, and it is not entirely clear which of the secretive agents in Albany is really holding things up.

Governor Spitzer, a Democrat, blamed the Republican leader Joseph Bruno and his Senate majority, and the governor last week began one of his campaign swings through legislative districts around the state to criticize Mr. Bruno's Republican colleagues.
Mr. Bruno accused the governor of having a ''tantrum'' because Republicans would not go along with the governor's plan to ''favor the wealthy.''
The real scandal, though, is not how the campaign finance systems -- current or proposed -- favor the wealthy.
John Coplans Andrea Rosen Gallery  130 Prince Street  SoHo  Through July 2 A new note of distress can be seen in John Coplans's latest nude self-portraits.
In all the photographs, Mr. Coplans appears upside down, as if he were suspended by his feet or falling.
But the hints of suffering are undercut by the cool, distanced presentation, which emphasizes formal considerations.
As in other recent work, Mr. Coplans presents each figure in three separate frames, here arranged vertically, forcing the viewer to scan the image in successive glimpses.
In each piece, Mr. Coplans is visible only from the neck down (or up, in this case).
And the anonymity of the figures is heightened by the fact that feet and hands have been cropped out of most of the pictures.
Occasionally a hand appears, in a stylized gesture: in one image, a fist punches out of the frame, while in another a hand reaches out as if in supplication.
Arms and legs, too, are presented in theatrical arrangements, twisted into carefully balanced compositions.
All of this gives the works the sense of decorous strain found in Mannerist art.
Mr. Coplans continues to extract a rich blend of emotional suggestions and art-historical references from his deceptively simple terms.
Ubu Gallery  16 East 78th Street  Through July 27 De Stijl, the design magazine that Theo van Doesburg founded in November 1917, became the term for Dutch modernism.
Wendingen, its chief competition, was not so lucky.
Founded three months later by the architect and graphic designer H. Th.
Wijdeveld as the mouthpiece for the Amsterdam School of architects and designers, it is largely forgotten, despite its important influence on modern typography.
This handsome, informative exhibition celebrates the first monograph on Wendingen, which means Changes.
From the looks of this show, the magazine lacked the purity to qualify as a modernist art movement because it accommodated so many different styles.
Focusing on graphic design, the decorative arts and architecture, its covers ranged from plain to fancy, from Arts and Crafts to Expressionism and even De Stijl.
The Constructivist El Lissitzky supplied one cover for the striking 13-inch-square format.
R. N. Roland Holst, who leaned toward Symbolism but was attuned to Wiener Werkstatte geometry, designed many.
Japanese art was a pervasive influence, as was Art Nouveau.
Only Veterans Stadium was scheduled for implosion this year, not the Phillies.
This was the season in which Philadelphia would finally usurp Atlanta in the National League East.
A once parsimonious franchise would aim for the World Series with a new ballpark, a $93 million payroll and a closer, Billy Wagner, who sealed games like Tupperware.
On July 5, the Phillies led the division by three games.
But futility for this club has become as dependable and familiar as the seventh-inning stretch.
Forty years after the infamous collapse of the 1964 Phillies, the team has again crumbled, reduced to pennant-race rubble like the demolished Vet.
In 1964, Philadelphia blew a six-and-a-half-game lead with 12 remaining.
The current flop is less excruciating, expected failure having become part of the sporting psyche here.
Still, a shivering aftershock from 1964 was felt this month when the Phillies finished 1-9 on the second-worst homestand in the franchise's 122-year history.

The Phillies trailed Atlanta by 10 1/2 games after Sunday's 10-0 victory over Milwaukee and the Braves' 9-5 loss to San Francisco on Sunday night, and Philadelphia hung in the wild-card race by the fingernail of mathematical possibility, with five teams to overtake.
AN ancient, fist-size skull discovered in South Africa sheds new light on the turtle's evolution, establishing a link between the most primitive fossil specimens and modern turtles.

Dr. Eugene S. Gaffney, curator of the American Museum of Natural History's department of vertebrate paleontology, said the find he and a colleague are reporting revealed that major structural changes in the turtle's cranium occurred much earlier than had been believed. "
The oldest turtles had a mobile skull, whereas all modern turtles have an unusually solid skull," Dr. Gaffney said.
Fossils of the most primitive known turtle, Proganochelys, which lived in the late Triassic period some 240 million years ago, show a flexible skull similar to that of modern birds.

Dr. Gaffney and his co-author, Dr. James W. Kitching of the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg, said that the fossil skull was from a previously unknown species, Australochelys africanus.
Although it has much in common with primitive turtles, they said, the fact that its braincase is fused to its palate clearly marks Australochelys as a link between Proganochelys and modern turtles.
The researchers believe that evolutionary adaptations of the turtle's hearing mechanism may have precipitated the solidification of the skull evident in Australochelys.
They reported their findings in the current issue of the journal Nature.
Dr. Kitching unearthed the skull in 1980 from a formation created in the early Jurassic period about 200 million years ago.
Its discovery also extends the history of turtles in Africa some 60 million years, Dr. Gaffney said.

When Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel addresses a gathering of American Jews in Baltimore on Thursday, he will be talking to philanthropic and community leaders who generally favor territorial compromise in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, a freeze on Jewish settlements and even the eventual creation of a Palestinian state.
All of these are ideas Mr. Shamir categorically rejects.
Members of the Council of Jewish Federations, before whom Mr. Shamir is to appear, will almost certainly applaud the Israeli leader, as they usually do.
