But a new poll indicates that most of the officers of the council, an assembly of the leaders of Jewish federations nationwide, disagree strongly with his Government's hard-line policies.
The poll is consistent with recent surveys that portray the private opinions of American Jews as largely dovish on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
But the new poll reflects a growing willingness by American Jewish leaders to articulate views contrary to those of Israel's Government.

An 'Outdated Concept' "There is an old and outdated concept of how American Jews should relate to Israel," said Jonathan Jacoby, president of Americans for Peace Now, a branch of an Israeli peace group. "
The concept is absolute support -- we do what the Israeli Government says we should do.
This new poll demonstrates that the concept is outdated.
It is not operative in terms of people's opinions, though it is still operative in the way Jewish organizations act."
THE mutual fund business is getting something that it's never really had before: glamour.
A few weeks ago, American Century Investments announced that it had teamed up with Lance Armstrong, the cycling legend, to create what have inevitably been called the LiveStrong funds.
These mutual funds, which will open for business in May, are known as life-cycle funds. (
Cycle -- get it?)
You invest with a retirement target year like 2025 in mind, and the fund becomes more conservative as you age.
The slogan, ''Put Your Lance Face On,'' doesn't have the zing of ''Our Prices Are In-saaane!''
But the product does call for a stolid dullness -- nobody is putting the nest egg down on wacky.
Mr. Armstrong isn't the only aging celebrity with a fund connection.
Since last fall, Sir Paul McCartney has been showing up in commercials for Fidelity Investments.
But Sir Paul has announced no plans for, say, an Eleanor Rigby fund. (''
Forty-year-old Frank Tanana hit his first career triple tonight.
It occurred with the bases loaded, and by the time he hoofed into third base, dizziness had set in.
By comparison, Tanana's 239th career pitching victory was unexhausting.
He yielded five hits in eight innings, had an eight-run cushion by the sixth inning and eventually a 12-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds at Riverfront Stadium.
The dozen runs tied the Mets' season high.
They leave town having taken two of three games from Cincinnati, winning a series for only the eighth time this season.
And just when momentum has set in, the team has a rare two days off in Denver.
The Mets are scheduled to play the National League's other last-place team, the Rockies, over the weekend.
But the Broncos need Mile High Stadium on Friday night for a game against the Miami Dolphins, so the Colorado series will begin Saturday with a doubleheader.
Barrage of Hits That gives the Mets time to savor tonight's game.

Nat Adderley, a jazz cornetist and trumpeter who was a frequent collaborator with his brother, the saxophonist Cannonball Adderley, and a composer whose style popularized a melodic, bluesy, secular gospel-jazz, died on Sunday at a hospice in Lakeland, Fla. He was 68 and lived in Lakeland.
The cause was complications from diabetes, said Fred Stuart, his publicist.
Mr. Adderley was born in Tampa, Fla., and began his career playing with bands in Florida.
In 1950 he changed from trumpet to cornet, and during the early 50's he played with a military band in the Army.
In 1954 he joined Lionel Hampton's group, and in 1956 he became part of the Adderley Brothers quintet started by his brother.
That group disbanded in 1957 and  the brothers reunited in the Cannonball Adderley Quintet before the end of the decade.

With Cannonball Adderley's buoyant, linear style and Nat Adderley's more dynamic sound, the quintet became one of the longest-running groups in postwar jazz, remaining active until Cannonball Adderley died in 1975 and making a series of hard-hitting records.
Three of the most popular songs in its repertory, which all became  standards, were written by Nat Adderley: ''The Work Song,'' ''Jive Samba'' and ''Hummin'.''

Mr. Adderley, who had also appeared as a sideman on other records by musicians including Kenny Clarke, Wynton Kelly and Jimmy Heath, started his own band shortly after his brother's death, modeled on the music they played together.
The alto saxophonist Vincent Herring often played the Cannonball Adderley role in the band.
A Federal judge has ruled that the Village of Airmont in Rockland County must change its zoning laws to permit synagogues in private homes.
The case has focused attention on cultural clashes that have flared in some New York suburbs  since Orthodox Jews began moving in in the 1980's.
The village board voted on Monday night to appeal the ruling, which was issued last week.
The village's position is, there has to be a balance between the right of worship and the right to plan," said Dennis Lynch, a lawyer representing Airmont. "
Public assembly for any purpose must be regulated."

Alan J. Straus, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, a group of Orthodox Jewish residents, said that he would file an application to force the village to pay the plaintiffs' legal fees, which he estimated to be $2 million.
Airmont's annual budget is $1.6 million.
Airmont was incorporated in 1991 as a village of 8,000 within the town of Ramapo, a municipality of 94,000 people, about a quarter of whom are Orthodox and Hasidic Jews.
Within a month, the Federal Government filed suit, contending that the purpose for establishing the village was to make it impossible for Orthodox Jews to live there.

The suit asserted that the new village's zoning policies would effectively exclude Orthodox Jews because they would not be able to use their homes as synagogues and it would be impractical for them to worship at synagogues elsewhere because Jewish law prohibits travel by car on the Sabbath and certain Jewish holidays.
It should not have taken a deluge of protest from women all over the country for the U.S. Senate finally to confront the sex harassment charges against Clarence Thomas, the Supreme Court nominee.
Logic alone argued against the senators voting as scheduled Tuesday.
Otherwise they would have contravened any sense of procedural fairness, cavalierly dismissing the complaint of Anita Hill, the Oklahoma law professor who had worked for Mr. Thomas in Washington.
Now the senators have probably learned a lesson about women's political power, their anger and perhaps even the cause of the anger.
Women drove the point home with calls, telegrams and demonstrations, forcing the vote to be postponed until after the Judiciary Committee gives the charges a proper hearing.
That leaves the question, what kind of hearing: Who has the burden of proof, and how much?
Must Professor Hill remove all doubt that her former boss, after unsuccessfully trying for a date, regaled her with unwanted sexual talk about pornographic movies and bizarre acts?
Or must Judge Thomas utterly demolish her story?
Though limited in scope to alleged misconduct in the Federal workplace, the inquiry must include a short course on the subject of sexual harassment.
The senators plainly need it.
Mayor Giuliani has approved the sale of a small park in Cobble Hill to Long Island College Hospital to build a parking garage, but a lawsuit threatens to delay the sale.
The site, Upper Van Voorhees Park, is now being assessed so a price can be agreed on.
If the sale goes through, it will bring to an end a long dispute that set the hospital and Cobble Hill residents against residents of nearby Brooklyn Heights.

Fran Reiter, Deputy Mayor for Planning and Community Relations, said last week that the city decided to sell the roughly one-acre park to the hospital because the residents who opposed the deal were not directly affected.
The hospital has promised to build three mini-parks using hospital land nearby, totaling an acre or more, to replace Upper Van Voorhees. "
We came to the conclusion that it is a well-thought-out plan and should be allowed to go forward," Ms. Reiter said. "
It would be improper to deny it unless there was something egregious going on."

But the dispute continues in the form of a lawsuit against the city, which was filed in Manhattan Supreme Court in December by Friends of Van Voorhees Park, a coalition of environmental and resident groups.
They charge that no serious alternative was ever considered for the site.
The battle began a decade ago when the hospital's administrators proposed to buy the land to build a 430-car garage there.
For the first time in years, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater opened without its customary and highly festive gala.
Not to worry: there will be two such benefits in a season that also features an unusually large number of premieres (four) and stretches through Jan. 3.
The company's opening on Wednesday night at the City Center (131 West 55th Street, Manhattan) was thus relatively subdued with respect to the atmosphere in the house.

But the dancing was hilariously hot in "District Storyville," Donald McKayle's distilled view of New Orleans bordello life, and the program was completed by two major Ailey works, "Revelations" and a revival of the "The River."
Created in 1970 for American Ballet Theater, "The River" has the distinction of being danced to a commissioned ballet score by Duke Ellington.

Working under deadline pressure (the ballet was presented as part of the inaugural celebration of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington), Ellington sent Ailey portions of the score as he continued writing it.
Clearly, Ellington had the upper hand.

Unlike Marius Petipa, who could tell Tchaikovsky what he required, Ailey had to fit the choreography to the rhythms that Ellington poured with such sophisticated diversity into what is actually a symphonic score.
Nonetheless, both composer and choreographer were agreed on the core concept of water imagery, in both music and dance, as a metaphor for a life-giving source, a cycle of birth and spiritual rebirth.
Ellington ends the piece with a hymn, which Ailey matches with a choral pattern that merges with an urban Adam and Eve, initially isolated in separate spotlights.
George Atkinson, who helped popularize home viewing of Hollywood films by opening the first video rental store in 1979, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles.
He was 69.
The cause was emphysema, the Video Software Dealers Association said. ''
He really gave birth to the rental business model,'' said Bo Andersen, president of the association, which represents video stores. ''
And rental really gave birth to home video as a packaged good.''

When Hollywood executives began making feature-length films available on video in the 1970's, they charged $50 each and envisioned affluent consumers building large libraries, just as they did with records.
Mr. Atkinson, a onetime stuntman and occasional actor, saw things differently.
As he told The Los Angeles Times Magazine in 1987: ''I said: 'You listen to Beethoven or the Beatles over and over again.
You don't watch Burt Reynolds over and over.'''

To start his rental business, Mr. Atkinson bought 50 movies that had recently been made available on video, including ''The French Connection,'' ''The Sound of Music'' and ''Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid.''
New positions for three editors at The New York Times were announced yesterday by Joseph Lelyveld, the executive editor.
James Gorman, editor of Circuits, the Thursday technology section, will move to Weekend on Feb. 1 to begin a column about the natural world and outdoor recreation.
He is also helping to create a Times radio program based on Circuits.
Mr. Gorman, 51, joined The Times in 1993 as an editor on the Sunday magazine, later becoming the deputy science editor.
He has written several books on science and nature.
The new editor of Circuits will be Kevin McKenna, who has been The Times's technology editor, overseeing coverage of the field for Business Day and other daily sections.
Mr. McKenna, 45, joined The Times in 1984 as an editor on the foreign desk.
From 1995 to 1997 he was editorial director of the newspaper's electronic media group and founding editor of The Times on the Web.
He attended Stanford in 1997-98 as a Knight journalism fellow.
Richard J. Meislin, 47, succeeds Mr. McKenna as technology editor, returning to the newsroom from New York Times Digital, the Internet division, where he was editor in chief.
Really Hard Floors Q. Since I moved from an old house to a modern apartment with wood floors over a concrete base, I have had joint aches and pains.
Could the surface I stand on make that much difference?
A. Based on industrial studies, it could, said Dr. Mark Redfern, professor of bioengineering at the University of Pittsburgh, though the physiological reasons are not clear.
Dr. Redfern, who studies human movement and ergonomics, published research in 1995 about people who stand to work for long periods of time.
In both the laboratory and on the assembly line, different kinds of floors and floor covering were rated based on the subjects' reports of discomfort, joint pain and fatigue.
The results varied, Dr. Redfern said, but the bottom line was that the harder the floor, the more discomfort people felt.
If the surface was too soft, however, people also experienced pain, apparently because of the energy required to pick up the feet and move around.
The joints closest to the floor hurt the most, he said, first the ankles, then the knees, hips and lower back.
The researchers did not test the different hypotheses for how cumulative trauma might cause discomfort and fatigue.
Dr. Redfern said the ideal surface would be medium in both firmness and thickness.
BARBIE has remained the world's most popular doll by constantly tweaking an old formula.
Mattel, which makes the doll, has embraced such an approach recently as an overall corporate strategy, and its shares have climbed.
The strength of Barbie and other important brands -- combined with two years of cost-cutting -- have lifted the stock of the company, the nation's largest toymaker.
The shares closed at $21 on Friday, up 9 percent over the last 52 weeks, compared with a decline of nearly 29 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
The holiday sales season tells the story.
Rapunzel Barbie, marketed as a doll with hair that grows, was largely responsible for a 17 percent increase in worldwide Barbie sales in the fourth quarter from the period a year earlier.
Dolls with growing hair have been around for decades, and Barbie made her debut in 1959, but for Barbie's fans, the old idea seemed fresh.
Mattel, based in El Segundo, Calif., has other core brands that sold well, like Hot Wheels, up 5 percent, and Fisher-Price, up 8 percent.

These gains offset declines in licensed products, like Harry Potter toys and games, which were off 12 percent in the fourth quarter, to around $140 million, said Linda Bolton Weiser, an analyst at Fahnestock & Company, an investment bank in Manhattan.
Sales of licensed products, like action figures based on cartoons or movie characters, can drop as much as 50 percent in one year, Ms. Bolton Weiser said. ''
ICE cream isn't the pliable substance it seems, as Peter Franklin discovered in late 2000.

When he first made a prototype of the Cool Dog, an ice-cream-and-sponge-cake novelty meant to resemble a frankfurter in a bun, testers complained about the bricklike shape of the ice cream: it looked more like a stick of butter than a wiener.
So Mr. Franklin searched for a manufacturer capable of churning out vanilla ice cream tubes with rounded, pleated ends.
He came up with nothing. ''
They all told me, 'Nice try, but you just can't make ice cream in the shape of a hot dog,''' said Mr. Franklin, who founded his company, Cool Dogs Inc., in 1999.
The problem, he learned, is that molded ice cream rolls off the assembly line at a relatively balmy 22 degrees Fahrenheit.
If it isn't stabilized by a stick or a cone, it tends to flatten out -- perfect for making rectangular treats like Klondike Bars, but a big problem for anyone with cylindrical ice-cream aspirations.
With the aid of a consultant, Mr. Franklin developed his own molding technology, one that sheaths each faux hot dog in an all-natural casing that keeps its tubular shape.
The ice cream is then transported from the manufacturer to Cool Dog's factory in Shirley, Mass., where the casings are stripped away. (
Citing two pending patents, Mr. Franklin declined to reveal more details about the casings, except to say that they're edible -- if not very tasty.)

A state assemblywoman from Brooklyn was charged yesterday with conspiracy and receiving bribes, accused of having sought a $500,000 home from a developer in return for helping the builder acquire city land.
The assemblywoman, Diane M. Gordon, Democrat of East New York, surrendered to the authorities at 6 a.m., her lawyer said.
Six hours later, at a hearing in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, she pleaded not guilty and was released on $35,000 bail.

The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said at a news conference that Ms. Gordon was confronted in April with evidence of bribery and agreed to resign from the Assembly, but that she had reneged.
Her lawyer, Bernard H. Udell, denied that any such agreement had existed.
He said that she still intended to run for re-election this year.
An indictment describes six meetings between Ms. Gordon and a developer between October 2004 and November 2005.
The developer, who was not named, wore a concealed camera when meeting Ms. Gordon in her district office, prosecutors said.
Portions of the videotapes shown at a news conference yesterday showed Ms. Gordon urging the developer to keep the deal a secret. ''
I've been around long enough to know, '' Ms. Gordon said on one recording, ''that if you want a dream to come true, you got to keep your mouth shut.''

With the Administration's backing, a bill will be introduced in Congress today to give permanent wilderness protection to one of America's great natural treasures, the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
The timing could not be more apt.

Today is also the 10th anniversary of the day the Exxon Valdez ran aground in Alaska's Prince William Sound, spreading 11 million gallons of crude oil over 3,000 square miles and causing horrendous damage to one of the nation's most sensitive ecosystems.
Placing 1.6 million acres of Alaskan wilderness permanently beyond the reach of the oil companies would provide a measure of expiation for a major calamity.
In a sense, the Exxon Valdez incident has already left an important mark on the long struggle to achieve a better balance between energy and the environment.

The spill forced President Bush to abandon his drive to allow drilling in the coastal plain and, in further repudiation of his friends in the oil business, to impose a 10-year moratorium on exploration in much of America's coastal waters, including the California coast and the Florida Keys.
The spill also led to the 1990 Oil Pollution Act, which imposed severe penalties on oil companies and shippers for negligence and required safer double-hulled tankers by 2015.
More broadly, the sheer scope of the disaster did much to raise the country's environmental consciousness and taught it that a single accident could effectively cripple an entire ecosystem.
In 1981, only 25 percent of Americans believed that the risks of offshore drilling outweighed the benefits.
A year after the spill, that figure had risen to 55 percent.

Czechoslovak voters sent a warning today to Civic Forum, President Vaclav Havel's political movement, by giving an unexpected salute to the Communist Party in this country's first free municipal elections in 52 years.
Civic Forum retained the widest support of any group, winning 35 percent of the votes, according to preliminary estimates issued by the Government.
The Communist Party, surprisingly, came in second in the large Czech region of the country, with 17 percent.
The Christian Democrats came in third with 12 percent.
Independent candidates won 10.5 percent but, since they contested races mostly in small villages, they managed to amass almost 27 percent of the seats on the local councils.
The expected growth in the support for other parties did not materialize.
Nationalist parties in Slovakia and Moravia did very poorly.
Civic Forum's Total Slips The elections, which were held on Friday and Saturday, were for newly reorganized municipal governments.
Final results are expected on Wednesday.

The outcome for Civic Forum compares unfavorably with the 49.5 percent that the movement won in June in elections to the Parliament of the Czech republic, which comprises the regions of Bohemia and Moravia.
Sometimes the only way to regard the enforcement of New York's campaign finance laws is with mouth agape.
The latest stunner comes from the State Board of Elections.

The board announced last month that it had closed an investigation into allegations that corporations were routinely abusing the limits on how much money they could donate statewide to political campaigns.
The board members ruled that they couldn't actually ''undertake'' the investigation because the investigation hadn't already been done for them.
To back up a bit: New York has a particularly antiquated system for tracking campaign contributions.
State law limits companies to $5,000 in total contributions in one calendar year for state and local elections.
But there is no central computerized databank in Albany for all contributions around the state.
Records are kept county by county -- a system that politicians and contributors may like, in part because it makes it so hard for anyone trying to follow the money trail.
Two years ago, Common Cause and the New York Public Interest Research Group sent volunteers across the state to try to do just that -- to determine which corporations had donated what statewide.
The two groups located 96 companies that had apparently exceeded the $5,000 limit by spreading their money around the state.
To the Editor: Prof. Henry Louis Gates Jr.'s July 20 Op-Ed essay is superb and very timely.
We have long considered it important for prominent figures among us African-American intellec tuals to speak out firmly and candidly against anti-Semitism among African-Americans.
Black anti-Semitism has been an important element of the tenacious fault line that has fissured blacks and Jews for nearly 20 years.

However, only a small number of black intellectuals have been willing to speak out forcefully on this issue, notably Bayard Rustin, Ralph Ellison, Albert Murray, Prof. Cornel West of Princeton, Prof. Adolph Reed of Northwestern, Prof. Jerry Watts of Trinity College and a few others.
Professor Gates's essay comes when important figures among blacks and Jews are seriously seeking a renewal of amiable relations.

The gathering that Rabbis Alexander Schindler and Arthur Hertzberg -- and Edgar Bronfman of the World Jewish Congress -- held in Berlin some weeks ago on renascent anti-Semitism in the West was related to this activity.
The Rev. Jesse Jackson was a keynote speaker there and helped lay a foundation for expanding and consolidating such a renewal.
But something else is, we suggest, required for this renewal process.

We need articles comparable to Professor Gates's that spell out the Jewish-American side of the tenacious fault line that has divided African-Americans and Jews over the last 20 years, and these articles should of course come from Jewish intellectuals.

We think it fair to say that allocation of blame for the division between Jews and African-Americans is hardly all in the direction of African-Americans, though we think it is also reasonable to say that the African-American contribution has been significant, as Professor Gates shows.

Susannah York, a movie heartthrob of the 1960's and 70's, brought ''The Loves of Shakespeare's Women'' to the Blue Heron Arts Center on Wednesday night, and if it is not quite a master class in the poet's gallery of women, it is as good an introductory course as any around.
From her debut in 1960 as Alec Guinness's daughter in ''Tunes of Glory,'' Ms. York has been a star, appearing in more than 60 films in roles that ranged from naive ingenues to Superman's mom.
Apart from being a namesake of Shakespeare's elder daughter, however, she has little on her resume to recommend her performing an evening of excerpts from his plays.
Ms. York acknowledges that gap in commentary on her life and career that she uses to bridge the selections.
Although she cut her acting teeth on Shakespeare, she returned to performing his plays only in recent years.

Sporting a soccer-star haircut that looks as if it were styled by a prison barber with hedge shears, she rips through the canon, offering brief glimpses of 15 of Shakespeare's women, from Juliet to Lady Macbeth and Portia to Cleopatra, and reading three of the more familiar sonnets.

Ms. York said her show, performed before a backdrop of three panels depicting one of the ''Lady and the Unicorn'' tapestries, was inspired by ''The Ages of Man,'' Sir John Gielgud's evening of soliloquies.
She said she found her title when she realized the common thread running through all of Shakespeare's women was love. ''

The Loves of Shakespeare's Women'' is not, however, without problems, and one of the chief among them may be Ms. York's attempt to force such diverse characters into one neat package tied to the theme of love.
Another is that while Shakespeare wrote strong female characters, there are not that many actual soliloquies for the women in his plays.

John W. Snow, President Bush's nominee for Treasury secretary, said today that he would sell or cash out of at least $80 million in stocks, options and retirement compensation from the CSX Corporation, the Virginia-based railroad operator of which he was chief executive.

Last month, after Mr. Bush fired Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill and tapped Mr. Snow to replace him, CSX officials said that Mr. Snow would forgo up to $15 million in salary, consulting fees, bonuses, restricted stock and options that he would have earned upon retirement.
But today it was shown that Mr. Snow will retain far more than he is giving up.

The biggest payout will come from lump-sum payments of $40 million to $125 million to cover life insurance benefits, special retirement benefits and deferred compensation, according to a copy of Mr. Snow's ethics agreement released this evening and Mr. Snow's new financial disclosure statement.
Mr. Snow said that the divestitures ''will ensure that I avoid even the appearance of a conflict of interest in the performance of my duties.''

Lawmakers who will question him at a confirmation hearing next Tuesday offered a mixed reaction today to revelations that Mr. Snow was arrested 21 years ago for driving under the influence and that his former wife sued him in 1988 contending that he had not paid child support.
Mr. Snow says that the D.U.I. charge was dropped by prosecutors, and that the dispute with his former wife was resolved.
Several senators said today that they wanted more information, but others, including at least one Democrat, said the revelations were unlikely to effect Mr. Snow's confirmation.
The White House said Mr. Bush ''remains confident'' that Mr. Snow ''is the right man for the job.''

A spokeswoman for Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said the senator was ''gathering additional information'' and had not come to a judgment about Mr. Snow's nomination.

The Board of Education plans to spend $100,000 to hire former Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and a team of consultants to investigate school security, a move Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sharply criticized yesterday.
The latest review would be the seventh study -- along with a soon-to-be-released state audit -- to examine the safety division since 1971.
Mr. Giuliani called the study, which would be completed by the consulting firm of Deloitte & Touche by Nov. 1, "one of the most absurd things that I've heard about in a long time in New York City."
The Mayor appointed his own Commission on School Safety in June.
It is slated to open public hearings in mid-September. "
It really is a shame what's happening here," Mr. Giuliani said. "
This is a classic exercise on the part of a bureaucracy to protect itself rather than protect the children of New York City."
The board voted 5 to 2 last night to approve the contract.
The members who voted against it were the two mayoral appointees, Ninfa Segarra and Irene H. Impellizzeri.
Board officials vigorously defended the contract, saying they would seek private financing for the study and calling it essential to help improve safety in the school system. "
With most of the vote counted, advocates of greater democracy appeared to have scored modest gains in elections here on Sunday, but fell short of winning a majority in the legislature.
Democracy proponents captured a less sizable majority than expected of the popular vote, which elects half the legislature.
But democracy supporters fared better than expected among previously pro-Beijing professional groups and industries that choose the rest of the legislature's members.
The pro-democracy opposition captured 24 seats.
Candidates leaning toward the democracy camp took two additional seats, while two independents who occasionally side with the democratic side were re-elected.
The democrats have controlled 22 seats for the past four years.

The loss of several seats in the 60-member Legislative Council still leaves Beijing fairly able to retain control of legislative developments in this former British colony, although local leaders may have to make more concessions to prevent defections.

Some businessmen representing industries in the legislature have treated their legislative work as part-time jobs, and the government will need to persuade them to show up regularly for votes to avoid defeats.
Democracy proponents gained some power to delay, but probably not block, legislative initiatives favored by Tung Chee-hwa, the territory's Beijing-backed chief executive.
A series of irregularities marred the election.

Glowing with pride as he showed off his new two-room apartment, Xu Yougui pointed out the spacious master bedroom, with its color television and huge wardrobe, and the children's bedroom, with two beds and embossed green wallpaper.
Then came the best thing of all: the indoor toilet.
Mr. Xu, a 47-year-old textile worker, noted that this was quite an improvement over his previous apartment, which was cramped and dilapidated and meant relying on a public bathroom around the corner.
But Mr. Xu and his family are not only moving up in the world; they are also joining a category of people that has scarcely existed in the last few decades in China.
They are home buyers. "
Originally, we were always allocated housing," Mr. Xu said as he sat on a bed in his children's room. "
When I first heard this talk about housing reform, about owning one's own home, I didn't understand.
But now I've got it figured out, and I think it's great."
Tens of millions of other Chinese are also grappling with revolutionary ideas like home purchases, mortgages and down payments.
The Government has talked for years about creating a free market for housing, and now it is expected to take major steps in that direction in the next few years.
A month ago, John O. Pickett Jr. said he had no intention of selling the Islanders.
Responding to rumors that the team might be on the market, Pickett then said it was "a subject I want to put to bed." "
There is absolutely not one iota of truth to it," Pickett said then. "
I love the organization.
I love the talent that we have.
I love where we play.
I love our fans.
Everything is positive."
Bids Are Sought On Tuesday night, the last-place team announced that it was now seeking bids from potential purchasers.

Bill Torrey, the chairman and general manager, said yesterday that he had many calls from people interested in buying the team but that it was too early to determine a favorite or a leading contender.

Three months after the chief executive of Henry Holt & Company parted with that literary publishing house to pursue a political career in Germany, the company's parent announced the appointment of a new publisher yesterday.

John Sterling, the editor in chief at Broadway Books, will take charge of Henry Holt in November, according to John Sargent, the president of the United States trade group for Verlagsgruppe Georg von Holtzbrinck, the German media conglomerate.

Mr. Sargent stressed that Mr. Sterling would have editorial independence, although the new publisher will report to him -- unlike Henry Holt's maverick former chief executive, Michael Naumann, who answered to the chairman, Dieter von Holtzbrinck.
Mr. Naumann resigned in September to become Minister of Culture in Germany's Social Democratic Government. ''
Am I going to be telling him what books to publish?
Absolutely not,'' Mr. Sargent said. ''
We will work together on the strategic stuff.''
In this case, that means trying to make the house that publishes Thomas Pynchon, Salman Rushdie and Sue Grafton profitable again.
Several publishing executives estimate that Henry Holt -- with annual revenue of about $45 million -- lost up to $8 million last year.
Mr. Sterling, 46, has had a varied career.
One baseball  one ordinary, slightly scuffed baseball -- did something Thursday night that few movie stars or politicians can ever pull off in this city.
It shut down a busy downtown street, lured camera crews from around the world and drew a mob of Chicagoans to stand, transfixed, for hours in the chill.
They came not so much to see the little ball as to see it blown up.
Or crushed, stomped or ripped to smithereens.
The form of demolition, a subject of hype and speculation for weeks, seemed to matter less than the promise that the hated ball, and all it meant, would be gone forever.
This was the ball from Game 6 of the National League Championship Series last October, the one that a Chicago Cubs outfielder stretched up to catch just as a fan, Steve Bartman, reached for it.
After that bobbled play, the Cubs, who had been just five outs from winning a trip to the World Series for the first time since 1945, collapsed.
They lost that game and the next to the Florida Marlins, who went on to win the pennant and the world championship.
Fans blamed Mr. Bartman.
They blamed the Cubs.
For Brooklyn Credit Union, New Site Has Built-In Bonus Once a bank, always a bank.
At least that's the prospect for the three-story Chemical Bank branch at 1205 Fulton Street near Bedford Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant.
The company has donated the building to two nonprofit development organizations -- the Consortium for Community Development and the nine-month-old Central Brooklyn Federal Credit Union.
For the credit union, the new site has some built-in banking advantages.
It will occupy the first floor and basement, including a vault and safe-deposit boxes. "

By taking over a facility that used to be a bank, our image, if you will, is enhanced and people begin to see us more as a fully functioning financial institution," said Mark Winston Griffith, the Central Brooklyn credit union's president.
The files and equipment in the Chemical bank will be moved to another Chemical branch just three blocks away.
The Fulton Street bank had been a branch of Manufacturers Hanover before that company merged with Chemical in 1991.

Small Shops Protest Plans for Mega-Stores Two Queens business groups are organizing a public forum to protest plans by the Department of City Planning to make it easier for mega-stores like Home Depot and Price Club to build in New York.
The Korean-American Small Business Service Center and the Neighborhood Small Business Center say the mega-stores' lower prices would threaten neighborhood markets and increase traffic congestion.
Sometimes it seems as though there's nothing left that someone won't ask.

It's no surprise to be asked one's age, income or marital state, how much a dress, suit or apartment cost, what the rent or maintenance is, and whether the facial glow, simply the result of 10 hours sleep, is due to love or plastic surgery.
And if it's love, who is it and if it's plastic surgery, who was it?
Still, all that is another matter because although rude, intrusive and downright nervy, these questions are often asked, generally with little hesitation.
There are, however, other questions that remain stillborn, some of which most of us would dearly love to pose on occasion.
Most are impersonal, though some aren't.
Why aren't these questions asked?
In some cases, it's lack of nerve and the fear of being looked at as a very odd person, a kook.
In other cases, it's because the questions really would be beyond the pale and even the insensitive, who generally don't think twice about querying intimate details, draw a line somewhere.
For instance, in the first category -- simple lack of nerve -- is a question tens of thousands of people would like to ask.
TWO weeks of spring rain kept the bees from pollinating the apple trees, cutting the normal crop by one-third.
The same wet weather swelled and then cracked the cherries, while the dull skies stunted the hothouse tomatoes.
Such is the lot of the small farmer and the reason so many have sold off the land of their fathers.
But Tom Wickham remains on the North Fork of Long Island, where his family has farmed for more than three centuries, in good years and bad.
This was a bad year for Wickham's Fruit Farm.
It reached its nadir when Columbus Day crowds seeking pick-your-own apples instead found empty trees, a blow to city folk but a fact of life to farmers.
Those who make it in this fickle profession, ruled by wind and weather, do not sulk at hardship.
Instead, they square their shoulders, take out another bank loan and make the best of a bad situation.
So last week Mr. Wickham, his niece Prudence Heston and her husband, Dan, had anticipated their nearly bare trees and decided to be creative.
For customers who made the bumper-to-bumper pilgrimage east on Route 25, Wickham Farms offered substitutes for the ritual of apple-picking.
To the Editor: In ''An Old Hand's View of TV News: Not Good'' [March 22], the ''60 Minutes'' creator Don Hewitt laments the road that TV news has taken.
I believe there are multitudes who share his opinion and concern.
I believe, as well, that ''60 Minutes'' would not be excluded.
One perceives pride in Mr. Hewitt's comment concerning the Bill Clinton appearance on ''60 Minutes'' in 1992: ''We made him President that night.
Before that night he was just another Gary Hart.
Gone, finished.
The next morning, he was virtually the nominee.''

Mr. Hewitt's concern for the decline of the news industry would be more believable had he followed with an apology to his viewers for providing an opportunity for Bill Clinton to gain that nomination by misleading the audience.
He must certainly be aware by now that President Clinton has admitted what he then denied.
Granted, political spinners have tried to use semantics to say he didn't ''technically'' lie, which only compounds the frustration of those who were influenced by the program.
America continues to make progress in racial tolerance.
At Bear Butte State Park in South Dakota, Indians have been protesting the number of whites (often called "New Age practitioners") frequenting sites they hold sacred.
A park official, responding to such concerns, has said that restricting access to the disputed butte is not feasible. "
I wouldn't know a New Age person from an Indian."
This is uplifting news.
From Maine to Montana whites used to hang signs on barbershops and other establishments saying "No Indians," confident that they could pick one out should he walk in the door.
Some whites still express hostility toward persons they "know" are Sioux or Pueblo or Navajo.
Thank heavens for South Dakota.
What the rest of the country needs to do is to figure out how this breakthrough was achieved.
One essential, it appears, is for the minority group to have something that whites prize, and to try to keep them away from it.
There were opportunities for both sides on the diagramed deal from the World Women's Team Championship in Hammamet, Tunisia, last year.
At both tables in a qualifying round match between Britain and one of the United States teams, three no-trump was reached after East had made a pre-emptive opening.
After the diagramed auction, the declarer was Nicola Smith of Britain, who has long been one of the world's best female players and has won two world titles.
The opening spade lead was ducked around to her king, and she made a good play by leading the heart jack and winning with dummy's king.
She then ran the club 10, losing to the jack.
West for the United States was Irina Levitina, and she made a fine play by shifting to the diamond nine, but it was too late.
This ran to the jack, and the defense was poised to score four diamond tricks.
But they had no opportunity.
South cashed the heart queen, revealing the bad split, and took the marked finesse of the heart nine.
She cashed the last heart in dummy and led the club nine for a winning finesse to make an overtrick.

Shareholders of the Digital Equipment Corporation had a rump session in Manhattan yesterday to examine the prospects of the troubled computer maker, but it was unclear what action, if any, the group would take.

Herbert Denton, the president of Providence Capital Inc., a New York brokerage firm and money manager that organized the meeting, said that he would poll the attendees over the next few days and ask them to endorse a letter that Providence would send to the nominating committee of Digital's board of directors.
The letter would ask the panel whether it would allow Providence to suggest candidates for some of the three board seats that will be filled at the company's annual meeting in November. ''
There is a great opportunity because over half the board is over 70,''  Mr. Denton said. ''
The problem is that if you look at the nominating committee, all four of the members are in the 70-plus bracket.''
But Digital, which declined an invitation to send a representative to the meeting, quickly rejected the suggestion. ''
To criticize the effectiveness of anyone based on age is simply naive,'' Dan Kaferle, a Digital spokesman, said.
Mr. Denton said that about 50 institutional investors attended the two-hour meeting at the University Club, and 20 more listened over the telephone.
Together, the group represented 35 percent to 40 percent of Digital's outstanding shares, he said.

The investors heard a lawyer and five industry and financial analysts present their views on the numerous challenges facing Digital, from questioning the wisdom of the company's recent multibillion-dollar patent-infringement suit against the Intel Corporation to the declining sales of its powerful Alpha microprocessor chip.
IN a joint project, Stamford and Norwalk will try to revitalize manufacturing in southwestern Connecticut by renovating 240,000 square feet of industrial space.
Backers say the project, which involves one industrial building in each of the two cities, will be undertaken in cooperation with private businesses.
And they say it could bring private investors back into the industrial real estate market.
The project will be financed by a combination of the state's Economic Diversification Fund, private investment and $200,000 in cash and/or services from each city.
The state's $60 million fund was enacted last year as a onetime effort to address problems created by Federal defense cutbacks. "
There is no speculative cycle right now," said James E. Banks, director of marketing and business development for the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency. "
The banks got burned and the developers got burned, so unless there's a tenant willing to sign a long-term lease and wait for construction, a project is not going to happen."

Joseph M. Ercolano, vice president of Sacia, The Business Council, said a recent survey by the organization had found 54 percent of the manufacturing companies contacted interested in expanding in the next few years.
Sacia stands for the group's former name, Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association. "
When they talked about what was preventing them from staying in southwestern Connecticut, the lack of available space was a major consideration," Mr. Ercolano said.

The 38-year-old French woman who received the world's first partial face transplant this week insisted on having the procedure because specialists had told her they could not reconstruct her face because of her severely disfiguring injuries, a leader of the surgical team said yesterday.
The woman, who was attacked by a dog last May, is recovering well from the operation, which was performed Sunday in Amiens, France, the surgeon, Dr. Jean-Michel Dubernard, said by telephone. ''
Everything is perfect,'' Dr. Dubernard said, adding that the woman had not experienced a rejection reaction.
But the potential of rejection remains. ''
I don't know what will happen,'' he cautioned.

In an effort to help strengthen her immune system's tolerance to keep another person's facial tissue, the patient received a transplant of bone marrow yesterday from the same donor, Dr. Dubernard said.
She is also receiving the standard immunosuppressive drugs used with transplants of other tissues and organs.

From other patients who are living with hand transplants performed as long as nearly six years ago, Dr. Dubernard said he had found evidence that marrow in the transplanted bone helped to reduce the amount of immunosuppressive drugs the patient needs.
Citing other specialists who had examined the woman, Dr. Dubernard said that reconstructive surgery would have been ''extremely difficult, if not impossible'' in her case. ''
We got her permission several times because we wanted to make sure she understood the risks,'' because of the highly experimental nature of the procedure, Dr. Dubernard said.

The Internal Affairs Division of the New York City Police Department, created to fight police corruption amid scandal two decades ago, now finds itself an object of criticism about how well it has done its job.

Since 1972, when the Knapp Commission recommended that the department centralize its internal policing efforts in a unit modeled after an agency of the Internal Revenue Service, Internal Affairs has become a model for other police departments trying to root out corruption and misconduct.

By using informers to find bad cops, corrupt officers who agreed to wear a wire to entrap corrupt colleagues and undercover officers who pretended to be criminals, Internal Affairs became a dreaded agency within the department and its officers have often been disdained as "rats" even by honest officers.

But beginning with the arrest six weeks ago of Police Officer Michael Dowd and four other officers and a former colleague in Brooklyn, a series of allegations of police corruption have marred Internal Affairs' reputation.
Internal Affairs was left with the embarrassing question: how did Officer Dowd elude a four-year investigation into buying and selling drugs only to be arrested by Suffolk County police?

Criticism from Outside Anonymous officials in the offices of the Manhattan District Attorney and Federal law-enforcement agencies were soon reported to have said that some Internal Affairs investigators were inept and often botched cases and that their supervisors often stopped investigations prematurely, finding a few bad officers but letting the rest go.

An onslaught of such news reports caused the Chief of Inspectional Services, Robert J. Beatty, who has been investigating the Dowd case, to grumble yesterday that news organizations were in "a feeding frenzy" and that anonymous sources were "destroying I.A.D. and this Police Department and our ability to police it."

Chief Beatty, who was appointed head of the Inspectional Services Bureau at the beginning of the year, oversees three divisions, mostly of police officers: Inspections, Intelligence and Internal Affairs.
Inspections, an auditing team of 44 people, assesses how the department is managed.
Intelligence, with the bulk of the personnel, 254, provides security for the mayor, the police commissioner and visiting dignitaries and also gathers information on criminal and terrorist groups.
As far as REGINA DiMARTINO is concerned, there's no such thing as too much of Erica Kane, the kittenish vixen on the soap opera "All My Children."
Ms. DiMartino, the director of marketing for ABC Daytime, is the executive producer of a new video, "All About Erica."
It is a compilation of the best scenes in the life of Erica, played by SUSAN LUCCI.
Ms. Lucci, 48, is still center stage on the soap opera and has been almost since its debut 25 years ago.
The video explores, among other themes, Erica's seven husbands, some of whom she married more than once, her innumerable tempestuous love affairs, her mother, her daughter and her varied careers.
It is expected to be in stores on Jan. 11.
Ms. DiMartino was determined "not just to do Erica and all her men or a chronology of her life," she said recently. "
We wanted to be a little psychoanalytic, to explore why this character does the things she does," she added.
To accomplish that, Ms. DiMartino and her colleagues sifted through almost 7,000 episodes of the show (a task made easier because the shows from 1970 to 1978 were erased).
They winnowed the list to 400 shows, then down to 140, and then sat down for serious viewing. "
In the second year of living with the memory, the simmering disquiet persists, a lengthening shadow that won't leave.
Twelve more months have passed since 9/11 and yet the antidote of 365 more days has left most New Yorkers feeling no safer, no more convinced that the terror won't come back.
The narrative of that day is older now, but the city still feels its amplitude.
It is as if the populace has stalled in its march toward fully being itself again.
A New York Times poll of 976 adult New Yorkers, taken last week, underscores how much lasting damage 9/11 inflicted on the city's psyche.
Two-thirds of the people questioned said they were very concerned about another attack in New York, slightly more than felt that way a year ago.
In their routine moments, New Yorkers indicated, they are thinking and talking less often about the terrorist attack than they were a year ago, but the subtext of discomfort is every bit as intense.
In measure after measure, the sampling found New Yorkers trapped in the same state of queasy normalcy that they found themselves in in the more immediate aftermath.
There continues to be a minority of people who avoid the subway, stay away from skyscrapers, sleep fitfully, find new solace in religion.
Many people still get teary at the memory.

This should be a time of high influence and major muscle flexing for organized labor, as the race for the Democratic nomination moves into the industrial Midwest, to places like Flint and Saginaw and Detroit.
Instead, many in the labor movement find themselves frustrated and divided.
The candidate of choice for much of labor, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, faltered in the early contests and finally left the race last Monday, just a week before the Michigan and Illinois primaries.
This left the United Automobile Workers, among other unions, without a candidate, and with little time to coalesce around a new favorite, even if it could agree on one.
Many people here say that none of the remaining candidates has captured the hearts of the labor movement.
There are no Walter F. Mondales, Edward M. Kennedys or Hubert H. Humphreys here, men with a a long and affectionate history with labor.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas has some potent union support, notably the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees' affiliates in Michigan and Illinois.
But some labor leaders talk openly of their disenchantment with this field. "

At this point, I'd prefer to see a brokered convention," said William Bywater, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, who complained bitterly of the impact of the New Hampshire primary on Mr. Harkin. "
My God, the way it is now doesn't make any sense, where you're letting a very tiny percentage of people in a very tiny state determine the outcome."
A drug developed by a big pharmaceutical company from a pioneering genomics collaboration has entered clinical trials, says William A. Haseltine, the chief executive of Human Genome Sciences.

GlaxoSmithKline said Thursday at an analyst meeting in London that it had seen some promise in early tests on humans for a drug for cardiovascular disease derived from its licensing of a database of genes from Human Genome Sciences in 1993.
Human Genome Sciences, based in Rockville, Md., already has four drugs of its own in clinical trials that it developed by searching its gene database.
But those drugs are proteins made directly from a gene.
Big drug companies tend to favor so-called small-molecule drugs, which can be taken as pills, whereas proteins must be injected because the digestive system would destroy them.

So the drug companies view the gene and its associated protein as targets, and try to synthesize a chemical that can be taken as a pill and will react with a protein that occurs naturally in the body.

Both Dr. Haseltine and Charles Duncan, an analyst at Prudential Securities, said they thought the GlaxoSmithKline drug was the first small-molecule drug developed from hunting in a gene database to enter clinical trials.
The 1993 deal, in which SmithKline Beecham paid $125 million to Human Genome Sciences, was one of the first big commitments to genomics by a drug company.
Glaxo Wellcome merged with SmithKline last year.
GlaxoSmithKline used the database to find the gene for an enzyme that studies have shown is associated with a higher risk of coronary heart disease.
KAMI LARRIPA ran her first five-kilometer race with her father when she was 4.
Now 27, she has given up racing, but she still loves to run.
She jogs with her parents and husband on trails that are part of the Pacific Coast Trail Runs series in the Bay Area of California.

She and her husband, Dr. Armand Prieditis, 45, run the 30-kilometer (18.6 miles) route through redwood forests and along the Marin Headlands, catching glimpses of the bay and Golden Gate Bridge, while her mother and father take the eight-kilometer, or five-mile, course.
They all meet at the finish line to swap stories as they eat soup, chili and crunchy pretzels. ''
It's a fun way to spend the morning and you don't feel that pressure like at the start of a race,'' said Ms. Larripa, a Ph.D. candidate at the University of California, Davis. ''
Everyone is supportive and I always meet new people along the trails.''
Operating under the slogan ''runs that aren't races in beautiful places,'' the Pacific Coast Trail Runs organizes 24 events in remote parts of the San Francisco Bay Area the year round.
Nearly 200 runners toe the line for each event, choosing among three or four courses from 8 kilometers to 50, or about 5 to 31 miles. ''

We're trying to get more people involved in trail running by offering a fun, nonintimidating atmosphere,'' said Wendell Doman, 46, an avid distance runner who founded the series with his wife 14 years ago. ''
More than 1,500 blacks, many dressed in traditional African dress and jewelry, gathered on the sun-baked planks of the Coney Island Boardwalk yesterday and looked into the Atlantic Ocean.
With prayers, speeches and song, they searched the hazy blue expanse for genetic memory of Africans engulfed by a sea voyage into slavery known as the Middle Passage. "
This is not about worshiping the dead, but paying tribute to our ancestors," said Tony Akeem, an organizer of the fifth annual Tribute to the Ancestors of the Middle Passage. "
We are here to remember and to know our history and know our greatness."
Mr. Akeem, a visual artist and an educator at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn, designed and wore a special T-shirt for the day.
It depicts captive Africans crammed into the bowels of a slave ship bracketed by the words "African Holocaust: Never Again."
In recent years increasing numbers of blacks, some inspired by a growing popularity of Afrocentric study, fashion and music, have been re-examining slavery.
Two black authors, Charles Johnson and Caryl Phillips, have made slavery the centerpieces of recent works.

And "Sankofa," a new feature film about a black woman's ultimately defiant slave experience, has been showing to enthusiastic audiences; it was written and directed by Haile Gerima, a Howard University film professor. '

A Strong Resistance' "The issue of slavery has been presented to black people in such a way as to give them the impression that they were helpless people," Mr. Gerima said in a telephone interview from his home in Washington. "
Sabrina Wilson is a 41-year-old mother of four and grandmother to four little ones.
She found out that she was H.I.V.-positive when she was pregnant eight years ago.
But to her, H.I.V. means ''high on victory'' as she roams the streets of Brooklyn in a battle to protect other women from the lethal virus.

Ms. Wilson is a peer educator with Life Force: Women Fighting AIDS, a nonprofit agency in Brooklyn that recruits and trains mostly black and Hispanic women in AIDS prevention, then sends them back into their gritty neighborhoods to spread the word.
Yesterday, Ms. Wilson was holding forth before some attentive women in the crowded waiting room of a small health clinic on Manhattan Avenue in Williamsburg.
She does this once a week.
A gregarious woman with tawny-brown dreadlocks, she tells them that she hopes her personal story will save one of them. ''
I cannot be selfish with myself,'' said Ms. Wilson, a former drug addict who has been clean for six years and now takes 24 pills a day to fight off AIDS. ''
Early prevention is the key.
I have to take medication for the rest of my life.
Scientists have long known that there is more to speech perception than meets the ear.
Humans, even infants who cannot yet speak, pick up visual cues from the movement of the lips and other parts of the face to help understand what it is they are hearing.
Now there is evidence that this ability may go back a long way.

Researchers in Germany say they have found that rhesus monkeys can also combine visual and auditory information to perceive vocal signals, suggesting that the ability had some kind of evolutionary precursor before humans and other primates diverged millions of years ago.

The researchers, Dr. Asif A. Ghazanfar and Dr. Nikos K. Logothetis of the Max Planck Institute for Biological Cybernetics in Tubingen, tested monkeys by showing them side-by-side video images of another monkey making two sounds, while playing a soundtrack of just one of the sounds.
Time after time, the test monkeys were able to match the sound with the correct video image.
The research was reported in the current issue of the journal Nature. ''
We know that for human speech perception, when you communicate one on one with someone, you glean a lot of information not only from sound, but from facial expressions,'' Dr. Ghazanfar said.
But with other animals, he said, ''we didn't know if perceivers use that multimodal means of perception as well.''

The experiment is very similar to the kind that has been done with infants as young as 18 to 20 weeks to show that even at a prelinguistic age, they use facial expressions as an aid to perceiving speech.
The top of the Yankees' rotation has not been a problem.
Randy Johnson and Mike Mussina have done their jobs.
It was the other half of the starting staff that has not been considered a sure thing.
But maybe there is nothing to worry about, after all.

One night after Chien-Ming Wang turned in a creditable outing, giving up just two runs in a 4-2 loss to Tampa Bay, Shawn Chacon delivered his second consecutive strong performance for the Yankees last night.
Behind his six and a third solid innings, the Yankees defeated the Devil Rays, 4-1, at Yankee Stadium. ''
What they did last year wasn't a fluke, because they have good stuff,'' Yankees Manager Joe Torre said of Wang and Chacon. ''
Wang may have a little more natural ability, but Chacon isn't afraid to throw any pitch at any time, and he seems to be getting his command.
We need this to happen.
And what will help it to happen is if our two big guys continue to build a foundation like they have.''

Trans World Airlines defiantly counterattacked its larger competitors yesterday, reducing fares below the range of lower fares they announced on Thursday, to remain 35 to 40 percent cheaper than its rivals.
In addition, the carrier will give passengers double "frequent flyer" mileage for the next three months for flights through its St. Louis hub.

It will soon add direct flights between some of its busiest destinations rather than route them through St. Louis, and it plans to open several mini-hubs, including one in Atlanta, where Delta Air Lines dominants.
Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of T.W.A., which has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection since Jan. 31, announced the changes at a news conference yesterday.
Like the new fares announced by competitors on Thursday, T.W.A.'s new fares take effect today.

Special Discounts Retained Mr. Icahn said T.W.A. would continue to give discounts to members of groups like the armed forces, government employees and corporations -- something that American Airlines, which instigated the industry-wide revision of air fares last week, said it would no longer do.

Mr. Icahn said T.W.A. would impose a "full-court press" by adding more sales people to negotiate discounts with corporate customers and by offering companies 10 percent cash rebates on any year-to-year increases in their business with the airline.
Last year, less than 5 percent of T.W.A.'s business came from discounted corporate fares, Mr. Icahn said, adding that he hopes to raise that share to 20 percent.

New Round-Trip Fees As an example of T.W.A.'s fare reductions, the airline will lower its unrestricted round-trip fare between Dallas and New York from $550 to $500; the comparable new round-trip fare of the major carriers is $720.
But T.W.A.'s round-trip coach fare between Los Angeles and New York, a route that T.W.A. flies nonstop, will remain at $700, compared with the $920 coach fare of the bigger airlines.
The largest Sunni Arab political group in Iraq unexpectedly moved close to agreement with Kurdish leaders Monday on a broad framework for a coalition government.
The group, the Iraqi Consensus Front, also said it would abandon claims that national elections last month had been rigged once international election monitors finish their review of the allegations.

The move drew a rebuke from other Sunni Arab political leaders who accused the Sunni consensus party of violating an agreement to press ahead with claims of Sunni disenfranchisement during the vote on Dec. 15 and to not bargain on their own for a role in the new government. ''

They violated an agreement with us that they will not go alone to talk about the government,'' Saleh Mutlak, a leader of the Iraqi National Trend, another leading Sunni Arab political group, said Monday night.

The Sunni consensus party and the Kurds remain far apart on at least one crucial issue: the Kurds support introducing federal states throughout Iraq, while the Sunnis, who fear the loss of revenue from large oil fields in the Shiite-dominated south, want only the Kurds in the north to have a semi-autonomous state.

A Sunni consensus party official, Ahmad Rushdi, said that meetings in Iraqi Kurdistan between the party and the Kurdish leader Massoud Barzani yielded ''an agreement that the results from the international monitoring committee'' -- which is examining the vote -- ''would be approved.''
After results are final, he said, ''discussion will continue about the formation of the upcoming government.''
Also late Monday, President Jalal Talabani, a Kurd, said he would not object if the dominant Shiite political alliance were to once again select Ibrahim al-Jaafari as prime minister.
Mr. Talabani and Mr. Jaafari have clashed, but Mr. Talabani said Monday that the problems were in the past.
Mr. Jaafari's top rival for the post is a fellow Shiite, Adel Abdul Mahdi, a member of the most influential Shiite party, the Supreme Council for Islamic Revolution in Iraq.
Hawaii's First Congressional District, which encompasses Honolulu, is normally solidly Democratic, as is just about all of Hawaii.

But Honolulu and the rest of Hawaii are suffering because of the faltering Asian economy, unlike most of the rest of the country, and as a result Democratic candidates all over the state are in political trouble, particularly the First District's Congressman, Neil Abercrombie.
National Republican leaders have put the First near the top of their target list.
They have promised to throw in money and manpower and whatever else it takes to steal away a Democratic seat and strengthen the party's hold on the House.
But on Wednesday Republican hopes for ousting Mr. Abercrombie suffered a setback.

State Representative Quentin K. Kawananakoa, who was expected to win the party's Sept. 19 primary, abruptly withdrew from the contest, explaining that he was suffering from hypertension, severe headaches and heart palpitations after an earlier bout with strep throat and pneumonia. ''
I am unable to lead the winning campaign we all wanted,'' said Mr. Kawananakoa, who is the Republican leader in the Hawaii House and descends from islands' royalty.
His withdrawal left the other primary contender, State Representative Gene R. Ward, to carry the fight.
In most recent polls, Mr. Ward did not run as strongly as Mr. Kawananakoa in theoretical pairings with Mr. Abercrombie.
For that matter, in one of the latest surveys, Mr. Abercrombie showed surprising strength against both men, beating Mr. Kawananakoa by 10 percentage points and Mr. Ward by more than 20.

As the police continue to allege unseemly ties between a Russian linked to organized crime and figure skating judges at the Salt Lake Winter Games, the stunned caretakers of the sport wonder if it can weather a scandal that could expose widespread corruption.

The plot that Tonya Harding hatched with a band of Keystone thugs to whack Nancy Kerrigan left people riveted, but the possible infiltration of organized crime into skating threatens to disengage audiences, to scare away future Olympians and to suspend the sport as an Olympic competition, skating officials agree. ''

So much has happened in the past -- Tonya and Nancy, everything -- but this could reach a whole new level as far as damage to the sport,'' said Claire Ferguson, who recently relinquished her seat on the International Skating Union's council. ''
It's very serious and frightening.
No one knows what is coming next.''
The Russian, Alimzhan Tokhtakhounov, was accused by United States prosecutors on Wednesday of fixing two skating events so he could obtain a visa to return to France.

Yesterday the Italian police said that he might have contacted as many as six judges in his efforts to arrange a gold medal for the Russians in the pairs competition in exchange for a victory by the French ice dancing team. ''
We have recorded a conversation in which the suspect indicates that six judges may have been involved,'' police Col.
Giovanni Mainolfi said yesterday in Venice. ''
However, we have no specific evidence against these judges at this time.''
Justice, the old cliche goes, is blind.
So at the Queens County Criminal Court building, Mabrouk Mabrouk and his colleagues serve as her eyes.

Every day court is in session, Mr. Mabrouk, 67, and about 20 other elderly Queens residents gather in the attorneys' conference room in the basement of the courthouse to divvy up the docket schedules.

They are court watchers for the Queens District Attorney's office, a group of recruits who monitor courtrooms for  things like cleanliness, noise levels and comfort, and keep track of whether judges and lawyers show up on time. ''
They give you a good reminder that the courts are a public forum,'' said Justice Alfred D. Lerner, administrative judge of State Supreme Court in Queens. ''
We've learned that we have to speak louder.''
Last Wednesday morning, a wet and cold one, Mr. Mabrouk was joined by Irving Warner, 77, for monitoring duty.
The weather kept the other volunteers away, and even Mr. Warner almost didn't make it.
The bus ride from Rego Park is a long one for him, and the weather bothered his legs.
But Mr. Mabrouk and Mr. Warner are die-hards.
IN countries like Norway and the Netherlands, where speed skaters are superstars, people turn and gawk at Bonnie Blair.
They are polite about it, in their generally excellent English, but they let her know they recognize her as the winner of three Olympic gold medals.
She thinks she likes the attention. "
It's very unique," Blair said recently. "
These people know you in your uniform, they know your skating style, they know your times, they know you in street clothes.
I can still go about my business, but it's nice."
People do not turn and gawk in her neighborhood near Milwaukee.
Some people recognize her, but many others just see her as the slim, energetic 29-year-old woman tossing items in her shopping cart.
And she thinks she likes the anonymity, too. "
Michael Jordan can't go to the grocery store," Blair said. "
No society, not even this city's Beltway political culture, has ever been more obsessed with rank than France in the early 18th century.
In its top-down cosmological view, hierarchy equaled harmony.
All was right with the world as long as nothing moved, and civilized life was a kind of stately fete, with the king and the court in the V.I.P. lounge and general admission closely policed.
But inevitably, party-crashers turned up.
A pushy haute bourgeoisie crowded the door, brandishing money and taking fashion notes.
Members of the artisan class, including painters, gained entry on talent alone.
Although peasants, the bulk of the French population, were still kept far away from the festivities, they were starting to grumble and, rumor had it, hatch plans.

This destabilizing situation is the background to ''The Age of Watteau, Chardin and Fragonard: Masterpieces of French Genre Painting,'' an alternately ravishing and offputting exhibition that opens on Sunday at the National Gallery of Art here.
As the show demonstrates, French art, like the society that produced it, was also organized on an official sliding scale of value, which was in the process of breaking down.
At the very top of the scale was history painting, with nationalist themes packaged in a language of classical mythology and epic drama.

Paul McCartney is known, to grossly understate his reputation, for songs of graceful melodic equilibrium, a plaintive quietness and above all a civility uncommon to either the rough edges of rock 'n' roll or the pervasive cruelties of postwar classical music.

From time to time he has tried to transfer these talents to bigger, heavier old-school formats, the latest example being ''Ecce Cor Meum,'' a kind of oratorio for mixed choirs, soprano and orchestra written in memory of his first wife, Linda, and played at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night.

From a center box, surrounded by fellow celebrities, the composer acknowledged the hoots and cries of a camera-crazy, banner-waving full house that seemed almost reluctant to turn its attention to the stage.
Someone who has done as much for music as Mr. McCartney deserves to write any piece of music he wants and have it respectfully listened to.
In ''Messiah'' land, however, he finds himself occupying alien territory.
The bigness of the McCartney sensibility lies in its smallness.
Increasing the weight it carries does not make it deeper in quality.
Rather it sinks both music and message into a kind of viscous sentimentality.
Using a vocabulary of singing strings, pounding timpani, brass flourishes and virtuoso outbursts from the organ, the Paul McCartney we value translates poorly.
The native wistfulness becomes portentous, the irony oratorical and overly sweet, the brevity of song form stretched beyond its bounds into tedium.
As N.B.A. transactions go, Alonzo Mourning for Lucious Harris may not sound like the fairest trade.
But the Nets, who must swallow Mourning's four-year, $23 million contract, will take whatever they can get in return.

When Harris, a backup shooting guard who started the season on the injured list because of a sore back, replaced Mourning on the active roster Tuesday night before the Nets' 93-70 victory at Seattle, the Nets realized immediately what they had been missing.
Harris is one of the few Nets who can make an outside shot with any regularity, and he enables the team to function when Jason Kidd is not on the court. ''
It's a hundred times easier with Lu back,'' Coach Byron Scott said Wednesday. ''
When everybody got hurt, our biggest loss was probably Lucious.''
Tired of testing backups for Kidd, who is still limping because of a sore left knee, Scott seems content letting two shooting guards handle the ball.

With Harris and Kerry Kittles in the backcourt for a significant stretch of the second half at Seattle, the Nets blew the SuperSonics away and won the first game of their five-game western trip, which continues Thursday night against the Los Angeles Clippers.
Scott will still use Robert Pack as a backup point guard, but the rookie Zoran Planinic has fallen out of the rotation.
As sorry as the Nets were to see Mourning leave because he needs a kidney transplant, they also have a sense that some order has been restored to their locker room.
Black Africa has much to teach its former masters in Europe.
This may surprise those who think the only news from Africa concerns famine, war, pestilence and tyranny.
Those scourges exist, but Africa has managed to keep a fifth affliction, ethnic separatism, from shattering national boundaries.
Black Africa offers a lesson on the wisdom of respecting the territorial integrity of all states, whatever the mix of peoples.
As in the Balkans and the former Soviet Union, the borders of sub-Saharan Africa were imposed to suit the convenience of past imperial masters.
Thus Britain lumped together peoples who were historically antipathetic in creating Nigeria and the Sudan, both with a Muslim north and a Christian or animist south.
Beginning in the 1950's, empires crumbled as Britain led the way in granting independence to African colonies.
Some called for political union and universal Socialism.
But the ruling elites found common ground in defending the integrity of existing states, a principle upheld by the Organization of African Unity since its founding in 1963.
This defense of existing frontiers was tested in Nigeria in 1967-70, when Ibo peoples fought unsuccessfully to form their own state, Biafra.
The rookie pitcher Sean Henn may have alarmed some Yankees fans Monday, when he allowed seven walks in less than five innings in the Devil Rays' 5-4 victory.
But Yankees Manager Joe Torre, the man whom Henn must impress the most, gave him a vote of confidence before last night's game. ''
It just came down to one inning where he walked four guys, and nothing good happens when you walk four guys,'' Torre said. ''
Aside from that, he kept the game in play.''
Henn was starting in place of Kevin Brown, who went on the 15-day disabled list Saturday with a strained lower back.
Brown is expected to miss one more start, this Saturday against the Mets at Yankee Stadium.
Torre said that Henn, a 24-year-old left-hander, would start again Saturday. ''

He just, I think, asked himself maybe to do too much last night in trying to be too perfect,'' said Torre, who said he told Henn, '''When you threw the ball over the plate and made them swing the bat, they didn't hit many balls hard.'''
The problem for Henn, making his second career start and his first at Yankee Stadium on Monday, was that he did not throw the ball over the plate often enough.
Of his 98 pitches, only 46 were strikes.

A Long Island man was killed yesterday when a fireworks launcher he had lighted went off in his face, in the most serious of many incidents as the region dealt with the annual carnage of Independence Day.

Robert Saueressig, 26, of Plainview, died at 9:30 P.M., moments after loading and lighting a mortar in a park at Princeton Drive and Cornell Drive in Plainview, said Officer Bruce Benson, a spokesman for the Nassau County police.
Mr. Saueressig stepped away from the illegal launcher -- essentially just a metal tube -- but it did not immediately go off. "
He looked into the tube, at which point the mortar detonated," Officer Benson said.
He was pronounced dead at the scene.
The mortar Mr. Saueressig used is of a commonly available kind, used to launch either a single, softball-sized firecracker or several smaller fireworks for midair explosions. "
This thing was like a cannon going off in his face," Officer Benson said.

Panic at a Celebration In Gloucester City, N.J., a celebration of patriotism and pyrotechnics became a scene of panic last night when a fireworks shell plunged into a crowd of spectators, injuring about 40 people.

And in New York City, at least three people lost parts of hands to firecrackers, and by 1 A.M. today, the Emergency Medical Service had come to the aid of about 100 people who had been hurt by the illegal explosives.

In Gloucester City, just south of Camden on the Delaware River, many of the community's 13,000 residents had gathered on an athletic field for a legal fireworks display when, at 9:20 P.M., something went awry and a shell careened at high speed into the spectators.
A South Carolina newspaper columnist yesterday called BOBBY CREMINS "wacky."
University of South Carolina trustees questioned his mental stability.

In barbershops and bars, the sometimes epithet-laced talk was about how Cremins had elated Gamecock fans with his announcement Wednesday that he would leave Georgia Tech to coach at his alma mater, and then how he had burst that bubble with his announcement Saturday that he was staying in Atlanta. "
Cremins, we all know, is a little wacky," columnist KEN BURGER wrote in The Post and Courier of Charleston.
BOB SPEAR, sports editor of The (Columbia) State, wrote: "Bobby Cremins's decision to renege on his commitment to Carolina left me amazed, stunned, flabbergasted and disgusted.
I suspect I am not alone."
South Carolina said it would not take action to force Cremins to honor his verbal commitment. "
If he's this unstable or this untrustworthy, then I guess it's better for us to find out now rather than later," school trustee LILY-ROLAND HALL said.
Cremins is still "a great guy" to trustee CHARLES E. SIMONS 3d, but someone going through tremendous distress. "
I'm concerned about his personal stability," Simons said. "

Sam Wyche knew that some time ago. ''
When you're under duress, you operate in near-panic,'' the coach of the Bengals said as a city prepared for the American Conference championship game against Buffalo. ''
You come home, you're wife's mad at you most of the time because nice things aren't being said,'' Wyche said. ''
I'm exaggerating a little bit, but you do operate in a position knowing that there's less room for error.
You can't take too many chances that have a big downside loss.
