The Knicks were still fighting last night, for everything that was left after they nearly destroyed their season two nights earlier.
There was a little mayhem on the court, but it was purely benign.

Hours after four teammates were suspended, and two nights after inciting a horrifying brawl on the same court, the Knicks somehow pulled together, kept their heads and fashioned a dramatic 97-96 overtime victory over the Utah Jazz, one of the league's elite teams.

Punctuating this unlikely storyline was an unlikely savior: Stephon Marbury, who has struggled all season, scored on a driving finger roll at the buzzer, delivering the victory and a rare burst of joy at the Garden.
The bodies flying after the buzzer were only the Knicks, bouncing and dancing off the court. ''

It's a great win for all of us -- our fans and everybody, considering what is going on with our team here at home,'' said Coach Isiah Thomas, who was widely criticized in the wake of Saturday's brawl with the Nuggets.
The victory was only the Knicks' fifth in 15 home games and bumped them to 10-17 over all.
It came against a team, the Jazz (18-7), that has been the N.B.A.'s best through the first month and a half of the season.
With their roster depleted, their season slipping away and Thomas's job security rapidly deteriorating, the Knicks rallied on all fronts.
Marbury, showing signs of his old dominant self, had 29 points and 8 assists.
With the death yesterday of Congressman Ted Weiss, New Yorkers lost a gentle, respected Representative who never strayed from his political roots as an unreconstructed liberal.
His unwillingness to compromise limited his effectiveness in an increasingly conservative capital.
But it also made him part of a valuable minority that gave voice to humanitarian concerns.
As chairman of a subcommittee that oversees major Federal health agencies, Mr. Weiss worked to pursue food and medical safety.
His Congressional hearings were the first to question seriously the safety of breast implants.
He was an early advocate of spending more to combat AIDS.
He sought to help the mentally ill and homeless.
Mr. Weiss was virtually guaranteed re-election to his ninth term in Congress.
It's unlikely that many voters paid much attention to his race against token opposition in the reconfigured Eighth District, which runs along Manhattan's West Side into Brooklyn.
But now, ironically, their votes really count.
What struck Sandra Davis about the two new clients who walked into her office one day recently were the similarities between them.

Both were men who had been married for a decade or more, and both were having affairs with old girlfriends they had found through Friends Reunited, a wildly popular British Web site that helps people track down long-lost acquaintances.
And both were divorcing their wives, having concluded that the heady allure of the past was more compelling than the familiar security of the present. ''

They had chosen not to engage in direct communication with their spouse about their marriages and had, as a fantasy leap, gone back into childhood,'' Ms. Davis, head of the family practice division at the British law firm Mishcon de Reya, said in an interview. ''
After a shortish period of time, they had made arrangements to meet, begun relationships and left their families.''
It is becoming a familiar story on Friends Reunited, which has 10 million members -- one-sixth of the British population -- and which in a typical month is visited by more than 3 million people.
Founded in 1999 to help people track down missing schoolmates, the Web site seems to have inserted itself into the culture here far more emphatically than have similar sites in the United States.

Not only has it spawned a host of sometimes facetious spinoffs -- another site, Convicts Reunited, for instance, helps people trace former prison friends -- but it has become an all-purpose people finder for long-lost relatives, co-workers and military buddies as well as school friends.
Last year, Nielsen NetRatings, which analyses Internet trends, named it one of Britain's 10 most influential Web sites.
Along the way, Friends Reunited has unexpectedly developed a secondary function.
COHEN-Andrew S. Age 44, of St. Paul, died unexpectedly on January 27, 2003.
Andrew was born March 3, 1958, in Washington, DC.
He grew up in Manhattan and attended The Dalton School and various colleges including Hampshire College, the University of Vermont and George Washington University.
Andrew moved to Minnesota in 1991 where he met and married Bridget Murphy.
Together they had two sons, Oliver, now age 6, and Benjamin, age 5.
Andrew worked for the past three years at GiftCerticates.com as a senior computer network engineer.
He volunteered many hours of his time for the Minnesota Literacy Council and Alcoholics Anonymous.

Andrew loved reading (even while in the shower), long motorcycle trips, talking about and eating great food, East Hampton, Bob Dylan, falling asleep virtually anywhere and being with his family and many friends.
But Andrew will be remembered most as a profoundly kind and gentle man who loved his sons above all else.
Embodying a unique and wonderful mix of intelligence, curiosity, wry humor, sweetness, and a limitless capacity for unconditional love, Andrew, a man like no other, will be greatly missed.

Four City Council members attacked Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, yesterday for using tax money to pay for radio commercials that they called blatant campaign ads aimed at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
A 60-second commercial, which will air on five different radio stations this weekend, harshly criticizes the Mayor for his zoning plan to allow more warehouse-style megastores in the city.
The Council will hold daylong hearings on the proposal on Monday and Tuesday.

The four Council members -- three of them allies of the Mayor and one a would-be successor to Ms. Messinger -- joined together in the City Hall press room to accuse Ms. Messinger of violating the City Charter by using government funds for political purposes.
Ms. Messinger, who has said she intends to run for Mayor next year, will spend about $7,400 from her Borough President's budget for the ads. ''

She has taken an issue and tried to put it in a good-government framework, but what she's really doing is using public funds to run against the Mayor,'' said Thomas V. Ognibene, the Council's Republican minority leader and an occasional ally of the Mayor.
Mr. Ognibene said that the Mayor could demand equal time on the radio to respond to Ms. Messinger and also could file a complaint with the city's Conflicts of Interest Board.
Colleen A. Roche, the Mayor's press secretary, said, ''Those are all interesting options and we'll take a look at them.''

Mr. Ognibene was joined by Andrew S. Eristoff, a Manhattan Republican with political ties to the Mayor; Priscilla A. Wooten, a Brooklyn Democrat who is close to the Mayor, and Antonio Pagan, a Manhattan Democrat who plans to run for Borough President.

In the commercial, Ms. Messinger suggests that the Mayor's plan would strip communities of control over where superstores go because as many as 57 such stores could be built without special permits or public review.
Scouring Space for Dust Space may look pristine, but the part of it near Earth, at least, is really quite trashy.
In orbit is the weightless flotsam of human exploration -- a used package of Tang here, a spent rocket stage there -- as well as enough dust to make a housekeeper weep.

The larger debris is generally accounted for and tracked, for even a lost spacesuit glove whizzing along at an orbital speed of 17,000 miles an hour can damage a satellite or other object in its path.
But dust bombardment can cause damage as well, and less is known about the scope of the dust problem.
An instrument being carried aboard an unclassified Air Force satellite is designed to get some answers.
The experiment, kind of a white-glove test in space, will measure the mass and speed of individual dust particles, as well as their trajectory, in order to determine their origin and distribution.
Some dust particles are left behind by comets; others are the result of human activity.
And by continually colliding with and abrading larger orbiting objects, dust begets more dust.
Speed is an indicator of origin, as cometary dust travels faster than the human variety -- about 25,000 miles an hour.
But the experiment, designed and monitored by scientists at the University of Chicago, should also be able to determine whether the dust is uniformly distributed, or concentrated in clouds.
It is more of a compliment than it might sound when people say that Daijiro Hashimoto is the best politician in his family.
His brother, after all, is the Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto.

But it is Daijiro, the Governor of Kochi Prefecture here on the forest-covered southern Japanese island of Shikoku, who is widely hailed as an example of the kind of dynamic leadership that Japan needs.
Shikoku is one of the poorest and most backward parts of Japan, but Mr. Hashimoto has shaken up the prefecture and made it a testing ground for the nation.
More to the point for a politician, opinion polls show Daijiro drawing public approval ratings of more than 70 percent.
Ryutaro, though, has slumped below 30 percent, and he could even be forced to resign if his Liberal Democratic Party loses ground in elections for the upper house of Parliament on Sunday.
Polls show the party struggling, in part because Ryutaro seems to be emblematic of the old-style politicians who have led Japan into its present economic mess and cannot lead it out.
The tale of the two brothers underscores the weaknesses of Japan's political system.

While Daijiro is widely praised by Japanese commentators and his own constituents, under the rigid seniority system in the Liberal Democratic Party, he and others like him stand almost no chance of ever playing a major role in national politics.
Moreover, he is pessimistic about the prospects of fundamental change in Japan in the coming years, in large part because he thinks the public does not want it. ''
ON the day he was designated Argentina's fifth president in two weeks, Eduardo Duhalde cautioned his countrymen not to try to fix blame for the country's chaos.
Then he did just that. ''
It's time to tell the truth,'' he told the Argentine Congress last week. ''
Argentina is bankrupt.
Argentina is destroyed.
This model has destroyed everything.''

Many Argentines had expected him to announce the end of their unique decade-old plan that pegged their  peso to the dollar -- a plan that shrank Argentina's hyperinflation to single digits before turning into a drag on the economy during the last four years of recession.
Mr. Duhalde still is expected to dump the peso peg.

But his speech could also be read as a condemnation of a much broader economic model, the one sold by Washington all over Latin America that consists of deregulated markets, privatized state businesses and liberalized trade rules for once-closed economies.

Regardless of how long he lasts in office, Mr. Duhalde has already raised questions sure to complicate American relations with Argentina and, perhaps, other Latin countries: What is the responsibility of the United States for the economic meltdown and the shadow it casts on Argentina's political future?
A Florida jury's strong ruling against the tobacco industry in the first class-action lawsuit to reach a verdict may prove a watershed in the history of tobacco legislation.
The cigarette makers earlier settled with all the states for $246 billion for Medicaid costs arising from smoking-related diseases.
But those settlements did not deal with the potential claims of millions of individual smokers, which may be far more expensive to resolve.
The current case was brought by nine plaintiffs representing the class of Florida residents injured by certain smoking-related illnesses.

The ruling delivered in the first phase of this case, which has lasted nearly a year, concludes that cigarette manufacturers marketed an unreasonably dangerous product and conspired to conceal the dangers and addictiveness of smoking.
The jury also ruled that smoking can cause 20 different diseases, ranging from lung cancer to heart disease -- facts that the industry has persistently denied.
The jury also ruled that compensatory and punitive damages could be awarded.
The next phase of the trial will determine the damages owed the nine plaintiffs.

The ruling means that other Floridians in the class, which may total hundreds of thousands of people, could potentially go to court to get compensation for their illnesses without re-litigating questions about the defendants' conduct.
The industry is likely to appeal the decision and seek to decertify the class.
At 4:30 a.m. on May 26, Carl Weston and William Green were in their Metropolitan Avenue apartment duplicating a 45-minute videotape of New York City graffiti writers in action.
As they slipped copies of the tape, called Videograf 2000, into cardboard covers, a knock sounded at the door.
The late-night visitors were members of the Police Department's Bronx Vandal Squad.
They had a warrant.

For the next four hours, the officers searched the four-room apartment, finally leaving, Mr. Weston said, with several hundred videotapes and about $20,000 worth of computers, videocameras and editing equipment.
During the last 10 years, Mr. Weston has produced a dozen videotapes showing graffiti writers ''bombing'' trains and ''tagging'' walls.
Although he films some scenes himself, Mr. Weston said, most of the footage is sent to him by graffiti writers who record their own actions.
Five days after the raid, Mr. Weston, 32, a freelance graphic designer,  sat in his ground-floor apartment, where clothes and papers were still strewn across the floor. ''
They cannot stand the graffiti underground,'' Mr. Weston said of the police. ''
And now they are trying to shut down a form of artistic expression because it's connected to something they don't like.''

The top state official in charge of local government services expressed regret today over the public release of a letter that harshly criticized Bret D. Schundler's fiscal management as mayor of Jersey City.
But the official, Marvin Corwick, did not retract any of the contents of the Tuesday letter, which accused Mr. Schundler of leaving a $54 million cash deficit when his term ended on June 30.

Mr. Corwick's statement came as Mr. Schundler, the Republican nominee for governor, and Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., the state Republican chairman, demanded that Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco dismiss Mr. Corwick from his post in the State Department of Community Affairs.

Mr. Schundler's campaign angrily noted that Mr. Corwick had once been on the payroll of Mayor James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge, who is now Mr. Schundler's Democratic opponent in the race for governor.
The Schundler campaign also said that Mr. Corwick's assessment of Jersey City's financial situation was a ''partisan whack job.''
In a seething two-and-a-half-page press release, Mr. Schundler's campaign manager, Bill Pascoe, said, ''He abused the power of a government office for political purposes.''
Mr. Pascoe accused Mr. Corwick of ''mislabeling a 'debt' as a 'deficit.' ''
Richard McGrath, a spokesman for Mr. McGreevey, said Mr. Schundler was trying to shirk responsibility for Jersey City's fiscal problems. ''
Bret Schundler may want to shoot the messenger because he doesn't like the facts, but the hard truth is these are problems of his own making,'' Mr. McGrath said. ''
The objective analysis by the Department of Community Affairs, as well as the low bond rating by Moody's, is documentation that he hasn't managed the city responsibly.
A group of TriBeCa residents, led by Community Board 1, plan to keep fighting plans for a high-rise hotel in the neighborhood.

The 19-story, 340-room Hudson Center Hotel, which would be partly in the TriBeCa North Historic District, was approved by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission last fall after being rejected by the Community Board, which objected to the project's height and use.

A hotel like this doesn't fit in with the character of the neighborhood, which is mostly artists and writers," said Anne A. Compoccia, chairwoman of Community Board 1, which has only advisory power. "
And if they address problems  like parking, trash and traffic, then maybe we would consider it -- maybe."

The developer, the Brewan Group of Companies, in Glen Cove, L.I., will seek a zoning variance from the city's Board of Standards and Appeals later this summer to accommodate the building's height and use.
If approved, construction could begin in the spring of 1996 and be finished within 18 months.

The project consists of a new high-rise at West and Laight Streets and the renovation of a five-story warehouse, at the corner of Vestry and Washington Streets, that would contain hotel rooms and a conference area.
The architect is  Ehrenkrantz & Eckstut of Manhattan. "
We are analyzing the environmental issues, and we believe that a hotel is an appropriate use," said Mark A. Levine, a lawyer for the developers. "
The downtown area is underserved with hotels."
LIZA LOU, the artist who has chosen to bead the world, to make it sparkle and glitter, is at it again.
From 1990 to 1995, she created a 200-square-foot kitchen in which everything was beaded, down to the pie in the oven.
Now, she is beading a 600-square-foot backyard with 300 oversize flowers, a picnic table set with ears of golden corn -- even a spilled can of beer.
She is also beading a lawn made of one million blades of grass.
First she makes the objects out of wire and papier-mache, then she glues on beads or threads them through wires.
The entire work will be exhibited at the Santa Monica (Calif.) Museum of Art from Sept. 13 through Nov. 23; (310) 586-6488.
But she is not beading alone.
Since April, the public has been invited to parties near the museum to help her. ''
It takes one hour to do 50 blades of grass,'' she said. ''
Someone did the math and figured that if I worked eight hours a day alone on the backyard, it would have taken me 40 years.''
Nikita Magaloff, one of the last representatives of the Romantic school of pianism, died on Dec. 26 at the Samaritans Hospital in the Swiss village of Vevey.
He was 80, and lived in Baugy, Switzerland.
He died after a long illness, hospital officials said.
During his long performing career, Mr. Magaloff was best known for his interpretation of Chopin, whose complete works he recently finished recording.
He also had an affinity for the music of Prokofiev, an early mentor, and performed the premiere of Prokofiev's Seventh Sonata.
Mr. Magaloff was born in St. Petersburg, but his family fled Russia in 1919, first moving to Finland and then to France.
He studied with Isidor Philipp at the Paris Conservatory and at 17 graduated with the school's first prize.
He first gained international recognition as the accompanist for the Hungarian violinist Joseph Szigeti, whose daughter, Irene, he later married.
The couple moved to Switzerland in 1939 to escape World War II.

Mr. Magaloff made his American debut in 1947 as a soloist with the San Francisco Symphony, but was better known throughout Europe, where he appeared with most of the major orchestras under such conductors as Otto Klemperer, Ernest Ansermet and Karl Bohm.

The State Court of Appeals ruled on Tuesday that a defendant's own body -- specifically, his tattoos exalting swastikas and skinheads -- could be used as evidence that he committed a crime fueled by hatred.

The 4-to-2 ruling in Albany, by the state's highest court, treads the ground between a defendant's right against self-incrimination and a prosecutor's obligation to present evidence to jurors, and it rekindles one of Long Island's most notorious cases of anti-immigrant violence.

The suit was brought by Christopher Slavin, one of two men convicted in 2001 of luring two Mexican laborers the previous year into an abandoned warehouse in Shirley and kicking, beating and stabbing them.
Mr. Slavin and his co-defendant, Ryan D. Wagner, had posed as employers.
Both men were sentenced to 25 years in prison.

To convince jurors that the attacks had been motivated by prejudice -- a crucial component of some of the charges -- prosecutors showed photographs of tattoos on Mr. Slavin's arms, chest and abdomen that featured black swastikas, a white fist and a skinhead kicking a large-nosed man wearing a skullcap.
Mr. Slavin had objected when the police took the photos, and his lawyer protested when they were shown in court, first to a grand jury to secure an indictment, and then during the trial.

Mr. Slavin's lawyer, Robert Del Col, said during the trial that prosecutors were using the tattoos to make the jury dislike Mr. Slavin and that the tattoos were not relevant to his guilt or innocence.
During the trial, an expert on hate speech explained the images' symbolism to jurors.
Mr. Slavin's argument before the Court of Appeals was that photographing his tattoos and displaying them on a projector screen violated his Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination.

New York regulators are investigating whether the American International Group, the insurance giant, failed to pay tens of millions of dollars to a New York state worker's compensation fund during the 1990's even after top management was told that the company's actions were improper, state officials said yesterday.

The New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, and the acting state insurance superintendent, Howard Mills, said yesterday that they would appoint an auditor to examine the practice at A.I.G.'s expense.
The consultant will determine if the state is owed any money.

A.I.G. booked premiums it received for workers' compensation coverage as premiums for general liability coverage, a practice the company continued for a number of years even after it was questioned internally.
In 1992, an employee wrote a memo saying the practice was illegal and that the ''unlawful benefit'' to A.I.G. was in the tens of millions. ''
The practice,'' said Chris Winans, an A.I.G. spokesman, ''largely had been corrected by 1997.''
He added, ''On all regulatory matters we are committed to being as cooperative as possible.''
Federal and state regulators are investigating various ways in which A.I.G. dressed up its financial position.
Late last month, the company acknowledged accounting errors that could lower its net worth by $1.7 billion.
An additional $1 billion restatement in net worth is expected, people briefed on the inquiry said.
Jean Morgan, five months pregnant with her third child, went to the Smith Haven Mall last Friday to buy a maternity dress.
She ended up the victim of a carjacking in which she was locked in the trunk of her car for more than six hours. "
I just kept thinking about my two children and the baby," Mrs. Morgan said today. "
I had reasons to come home and keep on fighting.
I kept picturing my husband raising my kids without me, so I tried everything I could think of to break open that trunk." "
Thank God I'm alive and my baby is healthy," she said.

Mrs. Morgan, 31, spoke today at Suffolk County police headquarters after the police announced that two young men, seniors at William Floyd High School in Mastic, had been arrested on Tuesday and charged with kidnapping, robbery and illegal use of a firearm in the case.

Detective Brian McNeil, who led the investigation, said the police believed that the suspects, Omar Benloss, 18, of Mastic, and Delvin Lyons, 17, of Shirley, had gone to the mall "shopping for a car -- a Lexus -- and had a customer ready to buy it." "
They picked out the Lexus they wanted and were sitting nearby in their own car and waiting for the owner to arrive with the keys," Detective McNeil said. "
The car they chose happened to belong to Mrs. Morgan."
Leonard Bernstein's landmark Young People's Concerts have at last returned to television, but not in the United States.
From 1954 to 1972, Bernstein's shows for young people, along with his "Omnibus" and New York Philharmonic specials, were cultural flagships on all three American television networks.
The Young People's Concerts have now been refurbished, and rebroadcasts have begun abroad.
But in the United States, where Sony Classical hopes to release 25 of them on videocassette as early as September, a television berth has proved hard to find.

This marginalization of Leonard Bernstein, of programs once a mainstay of commercial television yet now potentially exiled from even noncommercial television, encapsulates the marginalization of classical music in America today.
In all, 53 of Bernstein's Young People's Concerts were broadcast on CBS, beginning in 1958.
Each was an hour long, and incorporated live performances by the New York Philharmonic.
The topics and scripts were Bernstein's own.
The programs were widely admired as the best of their kind.
Bernstein himself believed that they helped cultivate a new generation of classical-music listeners.
IN 1861, on the way to his inauguration, Abraham Lincoln addressed the New Jersey State Senate and spoke about the spirit of Trenton.
He was referring to the Battle of Trenton, the turning point of the Revolutionary War -- an event that had burned itself into his consciousness when he was a boy.
While New Jersey was once at the crossroads of the American Revolution, we are now a state at the crossroads of an innovation revolution.
For years, New Jersey has been laying the groundwork to move from a manufacturing economy to a high-tech economy.

Today, we have one of the world's strongest pharmaceutical and biotech clusters, some of the nation's largest telecommunications companies, strong universities and more than our share of groundbreaking small businesses.
However, to make a successful transition to the information and innovation economy of this new era, we need an entirely different paradigm to guide us.
We must establish an innovation triangle of partnerships between the private sector, the research university community and the State of New Jersey.
We have reconfigured Prosperity New Jersey with William C. Weldon, chairman and chief executive of Johnson & Johnson, and Dr. Shirley Tilghman, president of Princeton University, as its leaders.
They will create a partnership between the private sector, the research university community and the state to leverage New Jersey's strengths and develop the Garden State as the Innovation State.
Prosperity New Jersey is working to ensure that New Jersey businesses have a corps of highly educated and highly skilled workers who can meet the demands of our new economy.

The Empire State Development Corporation formally approved the Jets' proposed $2.2 billion stadium yesterday, the team's second victory in two weeks in a bruising, four-year quest for a new home in Manhattan.
The 75,000-seat stadium over the West Side railyards is at the center of the city's bid for the 2012 Olympics and its plans for the neighborhood's redevelopment.
But it is also the subject of criticism and lawsuits from community organizations, major civic groups and Cablevision, which owns Madison Square Garden and views the stadium as competition.
The development corporation's decision, which was not unexpected given that Gov. George E. Pataki supports the project, set the stage for a showdown in Albany.
The project still needs the support of Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, before construction can begin.
The state's top two legislators have expressed misgivings about plans to build the stadium, which would be the most expensive in the world, and are reluctant to move quickly.

In an effort to prod them into action, the Jets sent a letter to Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno on Friday saying the city could lose the 2010 Super Bowl, now scheduled for the proposed stadium, if it does not get final approval by the end of May. Ultimately, the project needs approval by the state's Public Authorities Control Board, whose three members are appointed by the governor, Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno.
But in an interview yesterday, Mr. Silver remained unmoved. ''
I understand they're trying to close a deal,'' Mr. Silver said of the Jets' letter. ''
It doesn't mean I have to give it a lot of credibility.''
State prisons in California owe more than $600,000 to Vincent A. Valenzie, owner of the Produce Man in East Los Angeles, for lettuce, tomatoes and oranges.
And California is into Pacific Bid Supply of San Francisco for $47,000 worth of pickles, 20,000 jars of them.
So it goes across California on the 42d day in which the state has gone without a budget.

Because the state has run out of money to pay its bills, the thousands of vendors who supply state mental hospitals, schools, prisons and other institutions with nearly everything from syringes to eggnog are beginning to hurt.
Like Mr. Valenzie, many suppliers have had to lay off workers and beg creditors for extensions.
But for the most part they continue to supply the state, scraping by with a mix of patience, ingenuity and bank loans, not wanting to lose a good customer. "
We haven't been able to get our bouillon, and that's about it," said R. G. Borg, the warden of Folsom State Prison. "
I think we can do without bouillon for a while.
It hasn't had any major impact on us."
Budget Talks Drag On Against this backdrop, the painful deliberations over how to bridge a budget gap of nearly $11 billion drag on in Sacramento, the state capital.
IS Maguro the most expensive restaurant on the Island?''
asked the woman on the phone. ''
We spent more there than at Panama Hatties,'' she said.
That is easy to do when sushi assortments cost $30 to $70, the majority of hot entrees are $35 or more and appetizers (most in the teens) go as high as $25.
The only way that reader escaped with next week's grocery money was by ordering a few hand rolls. (
There are pitfalls here, too.
The dragon roll is $20.
It goes for $7 to $7.50 at nearby Japanese restaurants.)

Maguro, a pleasant-looking corner spot in a shopping center on Old Northern Boulevard in Roslyn, gives no hint that it is different from other Long Island Japanese restaurants until diners sneak a peek at the menu.
That menu calls the food nouvelle cuisine.

Hempstead has become the first village on Long Island to enact a law setting minimum pay at $9 an hour, or $10.25 an hour without medical benefits, for employees of companies receiving village subsidies or contracts.

The five trustees of the Village of Hempstead unanimously supported the law but set no date for it to take effect and left room for amendments that could reduce the number of individuals and companies it covers. ''
While the law has been adopted in a general sense, some of the specifics still have to be worked on,'' said David A. Vieser, a spokesman for the village.
Mr. Vieser said the village was also trying to determine how many employees would be affected.
Some village officials were said to be concerned that the measure, as  written, could have a detrimental effect on the village economy.
Suffolk County and the Town of Oyster Bay enacted similar laws last summer.
About 70 minimum wage laws have been enacted in other parts of the country.
In Suffolk, county legislators overrode a veto of the measure by the county executive, Robert J. Gaffney, who said the financial impacts of the law on the county were unclear.

Some companies that would be covered by the Suffolk law, which will take effect in July, said they could not afford to pay the higher wages to employees like home health aides, who earn about $7.50 an hour.
They said they would have to ask the county for larger contract payments to cover their higher costs.

It was the morning after the onslaught, but Tampa Bay Manager Lou Piniella was in no better mood than he was the night before, when his team was pounded for 13 runs in the eighth inning in a 20-11 steamrolling by the Yankees.

Most of the damage in that inning was inflicted on the right-handed reliever Travis Harper, who entered the game with the Devil Rays leading, 11-9, and was immediately bombarded, giving up a double to Hideki Matsui, a triple to Bernie Williams and a home run to Jorge Posada.
The Yankees led, 15-11, but Harper remained in the game.
After getting the second out of the inning, he surrendered two singles, then a three-run homer to Gary Sheffield.
The score was 18-11, but still no one moved to warm up in the bullpen.
Two more home runs followed -- by Alex Rodriguez and Matsui -- but Harper remained on the mound.
Finally, he got the third out of the inning, after allowing eight hits and nine earned runs.
When asked before the game yesterday if he had had a chance to speak with the 29-year-old Harper, who joined the Devil Rays in 2000, Piniella became annoyed. ''
Forget that, all right?''
Piniella said. ''

Backing off a much-criticized plan to dump 150,000 tons of dioxin-tainted sand a half mile off Coney Island, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is now proposing to deposit the material in an underwater pit three miles from Staten Island.
Federal and state officials say that the proposal is environmentally sound and that it has the support of the Environmental Protection Agency. "
This method, from an engineering and environmental standpoint, is effective in isolating this material," said Peter Shugert, a spokesman for the Army Corps of Engineers.

But officials on Staten Island were surprised by the decision, pointing out that a State Supreme Court justice in 1982 blocked the Corps of Engineers from dumping less toxic material into the same pit.
Assemblywoman Elizabeth A. Connelly, a Staten Island Democrat, said: "I'm quite shocked, because this is the original pit that we thought we had licked through a lawsuit."
At issue is what to do with 152,000 tons of sediment the Port Authority wants to dredge from Howland Hook, a long-dormant marine terminal on the northwest shore of Staten Island.
Howland Hook was a repository for a dioxin-laced byproduct dumped into the nearby Passaic River during 25 years of Agent Orange production by the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, now defunct.
The site was supposed to have been deepened, from 31 feet to about 40 feet, so ships could start docking there by the end of last year.
The sediment was to be deposited in what is called the Mud Dump, a federally regulated site off Sandy Hook.
But the Federal Environmental Protection Agency barred the use of the site after tests determined that the Howland Hook sediments fall into the highest category of toxins.

Galvanized by the closing of two massage parlors in Flushing, a citizens group called the Quality of Life Coalition is planning more protests over the next several weeks as it pushes forward with a brothel-busting campaign.
Beautiful Spa, a massage parlor on Colden Street in Flushing, closed on Sept. 8 after a protest by the group.
A second protest was planned for Sept. 23 outside the Mi Yo Ko Salon, which posed as a computer business at 162-15 Depot Road.
When demonstrators arrived, the brothel had already closed.

After Beautiful Spa directed some of its customers to another massage parlor at 44-29 College Point Boulevard, police officers with the Queens Vice Enforcement Squad raided the building twice, making a total of six arrests on Sept. 13 and Sept. 25, Detective Terrence O'Malley said.
The suspects were charged with prostitution or promoting prostitution, he said.
The Quality of Life Coalition was formed last year in northeastern Queens to  fight plans to reopen a homeless shelter in the Flushing Armory.

The battle against the armory was successful, and organizers of the group seeking to keep the coalition active came up with the idea to ferret out brothels, said Evan Stavisky, an aide to Assemblyman Brian M. McLaughlin.

An investigator working with Mr. McLaughlin's office has been scanning local  newspapers for massage parlor advertisements and then following up to determine  whether the parlors are prostitution houses.
Mr. Stavisky said that approximately four other brothels had been identified and will be the targets of future demonstrations. "

Under the governing Conservatives, unabashed promoters of free enterprise that they are, members of Parliament have increasingly -- and legally -- taken to selling their access, expertise and influence to anyone needing lobbying.

But faced with growing public criticism that Conservative members view their  jobs mostly as an opportunity to cash in, the House of Commons adopted an ethics package tonight that for the first time requires legislators to disclose their earnings from outside sources.

The vote was a humiliating defeat for Prime Minister John Major, and it is expected to lead some Tory members to resign, making it even more difficult for  Mr. Major to hold his slim Conservative majority in the House of Commons.

Some experts said the vote could also prompt a broader examination of the role of the politician in Britain, which has always clung to the notion that politics is not a career or even always a full-time job.
The major vote tonight was on an amendment offered by the opposition Labor Party to a proposed code of conduct for members of Parliament.
The amendment passed, 322 to 271. "
I am fed up with being called a sleaze bag," said one Tory member, David Wilshire, explaining why he was one of about 20 Conservatives who sided with the opposition parties to pass the amendment.

The amendment was directed at the widespread practice among Tory members of accepting "consulting" fees or other compensation from companies, trade associations and other groups that have business before Parliament.
Until now, the only requirement had been that members declare once a year which groups they were working for.
With tonight's vote, members will also have  to list how much they receive for each arrangement beginning on March 31.
With its old-money elegance, miles of winding horse trails and police officers wearing white gloves to assist pedestrians, Greenwich was never a town to suffer Democrats lightly.
But now one has been elected to the town's highest post.

When Richard Bergstresser defeated Lolly H. Prince, the incumbent, to become first selectman -- the town's equivalent of mayor -- it was the first time in nearly two decades that a Democrat had won the post.
A Democrat also won another position on the three-member board of selectmen, giving the party control of the local government for the first time in recent memory. ''
It's a big to-do here,'' Patrick Rhome, who has lived in Greenwich for five years, said while standing outside C. Stuttig Locksmith, where he works. ''
I know everyone's shocked.
Lolly Prince was considered a shoo-in.''
The upset has left feelings raw on Greenwich Avenue, which could pass for a sloping Rodeo Drive.
A 19-year resident who is a Republican described herself as very unhappy. ''
Bergstresser has two large standard poodles that he lets run free,'' she said. ''
In its most extensive rebellion in over two decades, New York's usually docile State Legislature replaced Gov. George Pataki's skinflint of a state budget with its own.
It was a heady moment for legislators and a humiliating defeat for Mr. Pataki.
In fact there were 119 separate defeats as members in the Democratically controlled Assembly and then in the Republican-led Senate voted to override his vetoes of their $92.8 billion budget package.
The governor and his supporters hope Mr. Pataki will be an anti-tax hero once the dust settles.
But as he tries to duck responsibility for the Legislature's tax hikes, New Yorkers can rightly fault him for a lack of leadership.
It is a rare achievement for a New York governor to be able to make a legislature this awful look so good.
Mr. Pataki spent money like mad during last year's re-election, denying there was any budget crisis in sight, then switched personalities as soon as he won a third term.
The budget he proposed in January drastically cut funds for health and education, shifting the burden onto local governments that could least afford it.
Many communities were facing steep rises in property taxes, some as high as 20 percent.
If the governor doesn't try to undermine the Legislature's will -- by fighting its budget in court or simply refusing to pay the bills -- most communities will get substantial relief.
One American crew after another lost in the finals of the Henley Royal Regatta in Henley-on-Thames, England, yesterday as the United States won only one of the 17 cup events.
And that one -- the Double Sculls Challenge Cup -- it could not lose.
Steve Tucker and Conal Groom, the American national lightweight doubles crew, faced their heavyweight teammates, Ian McGowan and Nick Peterson.
Tucker and Groom, outweighed by 15 pounds each and battling a strong headwind, could not really challenge their heavyweight teammates, who won by three lengths in 7 minutes 45 seconds.
German teams dominated the major events, the Grand Challenge Cup for eights and the Diamond Challenge Sculls.
The Hansa Dortmund Club won the Grand over England's Leander Club in 6:15, a half boat-length ahead.
In the final of the Diamonds, the most famous of single sculling events, the defending champion Jamie Koven of the United States lost to a newcomer from Germany, Marcel Hacker.
Hacker progressively lengthened his lead over Koven, who never mounted a countercharge, and won by nearly five boat-lengths.
In the Temple Challenge Cup, Henley's third-level eight-oared event, Princeton gave the best showing of any of the United States eights.

In a semifinal heat in the morning, Princeton, with a hodgepodge crew combining its junior varsity heavyweights and varsity lightweights, lost to Cambridge University's junior varsity heavyweights by 20 feet.
Top executives of General Motors, wrestling with one of the biggest financial crises in its history, have not had much to celebrate this year.

But they scored a big victory late Thursday when the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian retreated, selling off the last of $1.2 billion in shares he bought last year in a bid to shake up the company's strategy and possibly its management ranks.
He had caused them no end of consternation in the last 18 months, trying to push G.M. into an alliance with two foreign automakers, Renault of France and Nissan of Japan.
In many respects, this city has felt under siege from outsiders and, to many, Mr. Kerkorian's departure could not come too soon. ''
Goodbye and don't let the door hit you in the tushie,'' said one reader comment posted Friday on the Web site of The Detroit Free Press after an article about Mr. Kerkorian's decision.
But seen from another perspective, Mr. Kerkorian's departure represents not so much a surrender as a lack of faith in the future of G.M. And he has a lot of company.
About 35,000 workers decided last summer to take G.M.'s incentive packages to leave or retire early from jobs that have been a ticket to prosperity for generations of blue-collar workers.
This week, Ford Motor disclosed a preliminary tally that 36,000 of its workers were taking similar deals to leave the company.
With these buyouts, too, there is some good news for leaders at G.M. and Ford.
In a matter of months, they have been able to drastically reduce their long-term labor-cost structure.
AS a painter and keeper of nearly 100 birds, the artist Hunt Slonem is surrounded by his subjects.
The parrots, toucans and macaws that gaze out from his canvases also share his apartment in SoHo and his 10,000-foot studio in Chelsea.
The birds, all born in captivity and ranging in age from 1 to 20 years, contribute to his art, not only by posing colorfully atop antique cages but also by shedding feathers of every size and hue.
Twenty years' worth of these molted feathers travel in boxes with Mr. Slonem, who arranges them into wall sculptures at his exhibitions.
A feathered wall, along with the expressionistic bird art, can be seen here at the Hudson River Museum in ''Flights of Fancy: Paintings of Hunt Slonem,'' which will be on view through Sept. 19.
Mr. Slonem posed recently with Sybil, a year-old yellow-front Amazon parrot, amid the exotic plants he raises in his studio.
A raised pool set amid the banana trees, ferns and coconut palms sheltered turtles and fish.
A cat preened on a purple velvet sofa.
Sybil chewed on the artist's glasses as two attention-craving cockatoos emitted ear-piercing squawks.
The studio, with its collections of colored glass, Gothic Revival furniture, flora and fauna, is a favorite backdrop of international fashion photographers.

ALTHOUGH 10-year-old Autumn Manchester was impressed by the spinning belts and pulleys in a newly restored 1875 carriage shop at the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages, she remained skeptical about the shop's stated purpose. ''
It looks more like a place where you make coffee, or maybe popcorn,'' she said.

The thought doesn't seem so farfetched as you look at the whirling mechanical system that once supplied power for the Graves Brothers Carriage Works Shop in Williamsburg, Mass. The shop is one of two newly opened galleries at the Stony Brook carriage museum, which is recognized as having the country's most extensive collection of horse-drawn vehicles.
The second is a representation of the Transportation Building at the 1893 Chicago World's Fair, featuring 16 of the top carriages of that time.
Copied from a photograph of the event, it includes details like velvet curtains and brass wall sconces.

Autumn and her 9-year-old friend Alexis Depasquale, both of Setauket, were among about 1,000 visitors who attended the Dec. 3 opening of the new galleries to take in the wonders of the horse-drawn era.
The World's Fair display evokes yesteryear's equivalent of a car show at a convention center, according to Julie Diamond, a museum spokeswoman.
Reflecting the opulence of the day is a Park Drag built by Brewster & Company, a model that was the period's version of a Rolls-Royce.
Built to take a half-dozen people on excursions in luxury, it came equipped with mahogany wine coolers and a spacious trunk for provisions, including a table for oh-so-civil picnics.
The vehicle, originally owned by a Center Moriches resident, would cost about $60,000 in today's money, Ms. Diamond said.

Shortly before the government filed its antitrust suit against Microsoft two years ago, Joel I. Klein, the assistant attorney general in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division, explained in a private meeting his concept of ''surgical'' government intervention.
In the case of Microsoft, he said, it could well include breaking up the company. ''
It would be drastic surgery, but it's surgical,'' Mr. Klein said, according to a person who attended the meeting.

With its proposal yesterday, filed in a federal court in Washington, the government has formally opted for  surgery, a split-up of Microsoft into two companies and a variety of restraints on its business practices for three years.
But the government regards that surgery as the conservative treatment -- less regulatory and less likely to harm consumers or the industry than the alternatives.

The government proposal, supporting memorandum and affidavits from three economists, two computer experts and a pair of investment bankers are emphatically documents not only of persuasion, but also of education.

The thick pile of papers is intended to convince Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson that the breakup plan is likely to be the most effective and least regulatory way to ensure competition in software markets under the sway of a company that Judge Jackson has ruled is a ''predatory'' monopolist.

And they do so by going step by step through the same arduous intellectual trek that the government and states took in recent months to arrive at such a sweeping solution to ''the Microsoft problem.''

The government must give Judge Jackson -- and higher courts, since appeals are assured -- the confidence to take what would be a drastic step indeed: breaking up a company that is an American symbol of technological excellence and wealth creation.
It operates in a fast-moving, dynamic industry, suggesting further reason to hesitate before reshaping the software industry by court edict. ''
They crossed seas seeking a fresh start in a strange but abundant land.
There were people there already, to be sure, sometimes hostile natives with their own customs and language.

But much of the land seemed fallow, so the newcomers settled in lonely spaces and scratched out homes, sharing their tools and toil, lugging in fresh water and foraging to meet as many of their needs as they could.
Much of the Sheetrock, however, was donated.
And the televisions, of course, they bought.
Given the frenzied cooking, family tension, football games, marathon eating and other diversions that have become Thanksgiving traditions, gratitude can sometimes be an afterthought.
But for a group of immigrant families who have wrested homes from an abandoned building in the South Bronx, gratitude was about the only thing not in short supply yesterday.

The widely shared and hence rapidly consumed meal -- fried chicken, bread and rice and beans washed down with orange soda and cola -- was not too traditional, and the setting was a little peculiar, but the sentiment went straight back to the Pilgrims. "
From struggle, we have something here, and aren't living in the street," said Rosa Campbell, who sews clothing in a Brooklyn factory. "
We give thanks for where we live."

Duke University invited two former lacrosse players to return to school yesterday while they fight charges of sexual offense and kidnapping arising from a stripper's complaint after a team party last March.

Citing changed circumstances, Richard H. Brodhead, the university president, said in a statement, ''We have decided that the right and fair thing to do is to welcome back Reade Seligmann and Collin Finnerty to resume their studies at Duke for the spring semester.''
The invitation came less than two weeks after Michael B. Nifong, the Durham district attorney, dismissed rape charges in the case, saying the woman was not certain there had been penile penetration.
Mr. Nifong retained the other charges, which have similar punishment.
Lawyers for Mr. Finnerty and Mr. Seligmann said their clients had not decided whether to return for the new semester, which starts Tuesday.
The university also told the two men that they were eligible to rejoin the lacrosse team, whose season opens in late February.
The Finnerty family was ''delighted'' and praised Duke, their lawyer said.
The Seligmann family said in a statement, ''By now it should be plain to any person who has any objectivity that the charges against Reade are transparently false.''
The men, both sophomores, were suspended under a Duke policy regarding suspects of violent crimes.
A third defendant graduated the day before he was charged.

The World Health Organization, Doctors Without Borders and other international agencies have begun rushing medical teams, generators and other equipment to provide safe drinking water and sanitation and reduce threats of infectious-disease outbreaks in the Asian countries hit by the earthquake and tsunamis on Sunday.

Immediate health threats include wounds from stepping on nails and broken glass; dehydration and heat stroke from exposure in hot muggy weather; the possibility of electrocution from downed wires; and diarrheal and respiratory diseases caused by various bacteria and viruses that can spread rapidly because of poor sanitation and a lack of clean water.

As health workers carry out assessments to determine the immediate needs in each affected area, they also want to take steps to avoid outbreaks of mosquito-borne diseases like malaria and dengue fever that could surge in the next few weeks as the insects breed in pools of stagnant water.
W.H.O., a United Nations agency based in Geneva, recently built a new command center there that has only been mobilized a few times in response to outbreaks of infectious diseases.
On Sunday, a team of 13 health experts began using the command center for the first time to deal with a natural disaster.

To improve communications between field workers and the agency as they request aid, the command center has one set of telephone numbers for officials of governments and private health organizations to call.

The aim is to avoid much of the competition and lack of coordination that have hampered the response of governments and private organizations to earlier catastrophes, Robert Holden, a member of the command center team, said in a telephone interview.
In responding to the tsunami in South and Southeast Asia, he said: ''The biggest problem is ensuring that those who survived continue to survive and provide the materials they need.
We must avoid creating a secondary disaster because we can't get the necessary materials through.''

As international organizations fly in materials to set up temporary health centers to supplement the hospitals that are likely to be inundated with people seeking treatment, logistical problems abound.
After Mike Piazza ended the top of the sixth inning with a line drive into right fielder Matt Lawton's glove, he jogged to first base, leaned over and touched the bag.
The Mets were having another frustrating night at the plate and Piazza must have figured that was his best chance to touch first with Cleveland's Chuck Finley pitching tonight. ''
I was feeling a little down,'' said Piazza, who returned to the dugout, plopped down on the bench and leaned over in disgust. ''
I'm obviously not swinging great, but I thought I got a good swing on that ball.''
An inning later, he came up with the Mets suddenly leading and Indians reliever Paul Shuey pitching.
Piazza watched a curveball for a strike and swung over a split-finger fastball in the dirt, so he guessed fastball.
Piazza then hit another line drive, this one higher and harder than the first.
The ball cleared the right-field wall, sank into the caged bench housing the Mets' relievers and rattled around like a pinball.
Piazza capped a seven-run inning and gave the Mets a five-run lead in a game they would win, 8-6. ''
That's a prime example of why you get three strikes; trust me,'' Piazza said.
There is something about the Washington Redskins that makes the Dallas Cowboys see red.
There is something there that brings out the bully in the Cowboys.

It happened here again tonight, when Dallas blocked a Washington punt out of the end zone for a saftey, returned a punt 79 yards for a touchdown and scored on a running play and on a passing play, too.
Dallas did it all, winning, 23-10, before 63,538 fans at Texas Stadium.
It was a Dallas attack similar to ones featured in both its games last season, a 33-31 Redskins victory here and a 24-21 Cowboys victory in Washington.
Rypien Under Siege "I think the whole first series was awful for us," Joe Gibbs said. "
We couldn't hear a couple of things and we didn't block a couple people and then you get a punt blocked."
This time, Dallas completed the victory by putting more defensive pressure on Redskins quarterback Mark Rypien than he saw during most of last season.
Rypien was sacked only seven times last season.
Tonight he was sacked twice, hurried frequently and hit hard. "

A 27-year-old Brooklyn woman walking on a path in a wooded area of Prospect Park was grabbed from behind and raped yesterday afternoon, unnoticed by bicyclists, joggers and motorists passing nearby, park and police officials said.

The incident came about 15 hours after the rape of a woman in Riverside Park, Manhattan, and almost a year after another rape at Prospect Park, a 527-acre oasis of lakes and meadows, authorities said.

The latest incident occurred at 5:24 P.M., "rush hour" at the park, as the woman was carrying groceries on a slope above West Drive between Well and Center Drives in the southwest section of the park, said Tupper Thomas, the park's administrator.
From the area, near Lookout Hill and Prospect Park Southwest, the woman could see people, but they couldn't see her because of the slope, Ms. Thomas said.
The man approached the woman from behind, dragged her off the path to a tree about 20 feet away and raped her, said Officer Scott Bloch, a police spokesman.
The man threatened the woman with a knife, but never displayed it, he said.
The man also was carrying a cane or stick, he said.
The victim was treated at The Methodist Hospital.
Security at the park was tightened almost a year ago, following the slaying of a drama teacher who refused to give his bike to robbers in an isolated section of the park, Ms. Thomas said.
The police department had planned to increase the number of officers patrolling in the park in about two weeks, in preparation for summer, she said.

The masses may have been glued to CNN, but at alt.coffee, a shabby-chic cafe on Avenue A, the under-25 crowd was distracted by their laptops, assorted apolitical reading material and the Boredoms, a Japanese noise band that screamed through the speakers.
Discreet eavesdropping revealed conversations about summer employment, Proust and the pros and cons of electrolysis. ''
I think people are trying to hide from it,'' Greg Curley, cashier and cappucino maker, referring to the newborn attack on Iraq.
But none of the patrons could be described as apathetic.
A freshly made antiwar poster hung on one wall, and when prompted, just about everyone admitted to feeling a mixture of fury, sadness and fear.
But after months of agitating and speaking out against armed conflict, many customers said the time for distraction had arrived. ''
This war is so wrong, I'm completely against it, but there's nothing I can do about it,'' said Lucy Malii, 19, a sophomore at City College.
Ms. Malii had been home when President Bush announced the military's opening salvos and decided she had to get out of her family's Lower East Side apartment. ''
My mother is so worried, she was making me crazy,'' she said. ''
I know what's happening is horrible, but right now, I'd rather not know about it.''

To the Sports Editor: I couldn't disagree more with William C. Rhoden's rosy perspective of autumn in New York without the Yankees or Mets playing for a world championship (''A Time to Refocus Priorities,'' Oct. 10).
According to Rhoden, without baseball to focus on, New Yorkers have an opportunity to ''relax, reflect, listen, observe, clear their heads and get some much-needed sleep.''
Who is he kidding?
Rhoden sounds as if he just got out of therapy.
The Yanks' self-destruction at the hands of the upstart Angels was a shot in the gut to all New Yorkers.
Year after year, we await the electricity and passion that October baseball creates in this sports-crazed city.
I can't imagine a New Yorker breathing a sigh of relief when the Yankees were eliminated and thinking about sleeping and ''refocusing priorities.''
Sports, and the Yankees in particular, are a diversion, a very effective one that helped the city through its most difficult time last fall.
Rhoden is uncomfortable with sports being characterized this way.
With the Yankees gone, we can now, as Rhoden says, ''concentrate on the state of the nation and turn our attention to the dangers that lie ahead.''

Ann Hampton Callaway  Rainbow and Stars 30 Rockefeller Plaza Through Sept. 25 No New York cabaret singer approaches a classic pop ballad with the technical finesse and intensity of feeling that Ann Hampton Callaway brings to the repertory.

The singer has a multi-octave range, a luxuriant timbre that injects a lovelorn lament with an almost tearful commitment, and long-lined phrasing that draws out the last ounce of melodic splendor from a love song.

At Tuesday's opening-night show, Ms. Callaway, assisted by a trio led by the pianist Richard Rodney Bennett, offered renditions of "How Deep Is the Ocean," "Here's That Rainy Day" and "A Quiet Thing" that were as close to definitive as any to be heard nowadays.
Each had its own signature touches.
The most original embellishment was an extended, slightly bluesy passage of wordless singing that she inserted into "Here's That Rainy Day."
Ms. Callaway's ballad singing was so strong that much of the rest of her show paled by comparison.
When belting up-tempo songs, her voice loses much of its emotional edge.
Her attempts at jazz singing are ambitious but rhythmically ill at ease.
There are also times when her formidable technique can work against her.
Her scat singing in an up-tempo version of "All the Things You Are" was rangy but stiff.

The official history of the apartheid era in South Africa does not include Roelf Matlala's tales of the years he endured regular beatings by a cruel schoolteacher or the torment black children heaped on him for being racially mixed.
But his story, along with those of four other black South Africans, are coming alive in ''Amajuba: Like Doves We Rise,'' at the Culture Project in the East Village.
The play is a vivid rendition of how political realities, like racial oppression or war, are composed of countless personal tragedies.
The agony of apartheid, certainly, has been the subject of films, plays, novels, memoirs and nonfiction accounts. ''
Amajuba,'' a 90-minute drama performed on a spare stage, is a bit different: the cast of three men and two women, all in their 30's, play themselves.
This is not group therapy, though; these are professional actors who can also carry a tune, and many critics have found ''Amajuba'' both entertaining and moving.
The play is about childhood and adolescence in South Africa.
Bongeka Mpongwana was abandoned and hungry.
Phillip Tindisa, known as Tipo, saw his father leave home, unable to stomach the move imposed by the government's tribal relocation laws.
Jabulile Tshabalala was beaten by a gang and threatened with rape.
Now that Latin America is on the back burner as far as American diplomacy is concerned, hemispheric relations are once again increasingly driven by America's military.
This isn't healthy.

History shows that when military-to-military ties dominate the relationship, as they did for much of the cold war, generals in Latin America feel empowered to act in any way they want so long as they guarantee a semblance of stability.
American military leaders, unfortunately, are once again suggesting that their Latin American counterparts assume a more active role in their nations, especially in ensuring domestic security.
This time the ill-advised idea stems not from a concern about communism, but terrorism.
A return to outright military dictatorships is unlikely, but expanding the military's role in these nations will only diminish their fledgling democracies.
The terrorism concern is overstated.

Gen. James Hill, chief of the United States Southern Command, recently told senators, ''Terrorists throughout the Southern Command area of responsibility bomb, murder, kidnap, traffic drugs, transfer arms, launder money and smuggle humans.''
That does describe the situation in Colombia and, to some degree, Peru.
But terrorism is hardly a threat to the entire continent, and there are no known Islamic terror groups active in Latin America.
The Cambodian Government and rebel groups reached agreement here today to disband 70 percent of their military forces and put the rest under the supervision of the United Nations.
All sides and foreign diplomats agreed that the disarmament pact appeared to be a landmark in efforts to conclude the 12-year civil war, although hopes have been dashed before. "
I have good news," a beaming Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's exiled king and the leader of one of the three major rebel groups, said in announcing the agreement. "
Finally we have unexpectedly achieved the good solution to the main problem, our military problem."

The other rebel groups -- the Khmer Rouge, which was responsible for more than one million deaths when it presided over a reign of terror in Cambodia in the 1970's, and the rightist Khmer People's National Liberation Front -- also joined in the demobilization agreement.

Diplomats observing this week's peace talks in Pattaya, a Thai resort city 90 miles south of Bangkok, said that there was still the chance that the agreement would unravel, and that Cambodia would be thrown back into the turmoil and bloodshed that have characterized most of its modern history. "
But with each of these agreements and with so much international supervision, it becomes that much harder for anybody to back out," a senior Western diplomat said. "
Everybody is sick of the war.
The atmosphere is as constructive as I have ever seen."

Dangerous Side of an Accord An Asian diplomat agreed that all sides appeared to be moving toward a final settlement but said: "I hope it is remembered that we are also one step closer to a return of the Khmer Rouge to legitimacy in Phnom Penh.

Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc. said yesterday that it made a crucial $73.1 million debt payment that was coming due this weekend, giving the company a temporary respite from financial struggles that still threaten to force it into bankruptcy.
Trump Hotels, the centerpiece of Donald J. Trump's casino holdings, delayed payment of the debt when it originally came due on May 1, invoking a 30-day grace period.
Burdened with a $1.8 billion debt load and an inability to maintain or expand its Atlantic City operations adequately, Trump Hotels has been scrambling to rework its debt and raise outside capital.

One deal under consideration involves a $400 million cash infusion from Credit Suisse that would require Mr. Trump to reduce his equity stake in the company substantially and step aside as chief executive.
Bondholders would also have to accept a reduction in the value of their debt holdings for the deal to go through.

Trump Hotels was required to use cash generated this month to meet the May debt payment, which means it will have a shorter period for building up cash before the next $73.1 million payment is due in November.

One person briefed on the financial position of Mr. Trump's two largest Atlantic City casinos, the Trump Taj Mahal and the Trump Plaza, said those casinos were entering the Memorial Day weekend with operating funds of about $20 million and $10 million, respectively.
Those are perilously thin amounts given New Jersey regulations that insist on adequate cash cushions at casinos and the possibility that lucky gamblers could snare windfalls.

Scott C. Butera, executive vice president of Trump Hotels, declined to discuss the cash positions of the casinos, but said he was comfortable with their finances and was confident that the company would be able to meet its fall debt payment. ''

Obviously, the summer months are our best months, and we're optimistic about the November payment,'' said Mr. Butera, who added that negotiations with bondholders had been ''active and constructive.''
Elizabeth Anne Perry and Richard Maxwell Grant were married yesterday in Manhattan.
The Rev. Ben W. Curry, a United Methodist minister and an uncle of the bride, officiated at the Yale Club.
Ms. Perry, 32, will keep her name.

She is a high school English teacher at the Berkeley Carroll School in Brooklyn, and is a co-director of the Klingenstein Summer Institute, a program of Columbia University Teachers College that provides instruction and training to new teachers at private schools.
She graduated from Swarthmore and received a master's degree in education from Harvard.
She is the daughter of Kathleen and John J. Perry of Manhattan.
The bride's father retired as a vice president and the general manager of the consumer products division of the Block Drug Company, the health and beauty-aid manufacturer in Jersey City.
Her mother, a social worker, retired as the director of supportive and palliative care at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan.
Mr. Grant, 36, is known as Max.

In May, he received a master's degree in divinity from Yale, and was until June an assistant chaplain at Kent School in Kent, Conn. This month he is to begin training as a hospital chaplain in the clinical pastoral education program of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Hospital in Manhattan.

Striking a note of somber defiance, President Ezer Weizman of Israel tonight refused either to resign or to step down temporarily while the police pursue a criminal investigation of his receipt of hundreds of thousands of dollars from a French businessman and political supporter.
In a brief nationally televised address from his official residence, Mr. Weizman proclaimed that he ''committed no crime, committed no sin, and took nothing illegally.''

Pressure on Mr. Weizman to quit has increased in recent days, with calls for his resignation coming from former allies and every major newspaper as well as from his longtime foes on the political right.
But his stubborn insistence tonight that he should be investigated and judged like ''any other citizen'' seemed characteristic of a man who built a political career on contrarianism.
Looking weary but speaking firmly, the 75-year-old president said he would issue a statement about the facts of the affair when the investigation was over. ''
I have no intention of resigning,'' he said, reading from a prepared text. ''
A man whose conscience is clean is not afraid and does not run away.''
Several key government figures, including Justice Minister Yossi Beilin, have urged Mr. Weizman to step aside temporarily until the police investigation is concluded.
The president was widely expected to announce tonight that he was taking this advice.
Instead, he said he had concluded that ''a leave of absence is not a solution'' for a sitting president, who would nonetheless remain Israel's official head of state.

Denise Jack and other car owners thought they had it bad when a 75-foot retaining wall in Washington Heights in northern Manhattan collapsed on May 12, burying their parked vehicles beneath untold tons of debris.
But their ordeal was actually just beginning.
Their cars remain buried there today, and none are expected to be unearthed until the rest of the wall is stabilized and the rubble removed -- up to a year from now.
Until then, they are caught in the world of insurance limbo.
Mrs. Jack's policy, for example, has liability coverage that does not cover landslides.
For her and others whose insurance companies won't act until the presumably crushed cars are unearthed, lawsuits are being pursued against the wall's owner, the Castle Village apartments.

But because they cannot prove that their cars are buried until the debris is cleared away -- and the cars' vehicle identification numbers can be inspected -- legal experts say that such legal challenges are likely to take a long time. ''
These people have a bit of an uphill battle,'' said Anthony Michael Sabino, a law professor at St. John's University. ''

If an insurance company tells them they have to wait it out for a year to see that the cars are excavated, and to see their vehicle identification numbers, then technically speaking they have a decent argument.''
No one is even sure how many cars are beneath the rubble.
Kathleen Brown wants to be the third California governor in the Brown family.
But she comes across as very different from her father Pat, an old-fashioned liberal, and her brother Jerry, a cold futurist.
She is the essence of the New Democrat, pro-business, tough on crime and other problems: "Tough but smart," she says repeatedly as we talk in her State Treasurer's office. "
Contrary to some in my party," she says, "I support 'three strikes and you're out.' "
That is a proposal, likely to go to the voters here next fall, to put anyone convicted of three violent felonies in prison for life without parole. "
What distinguishes me from Pete Wilson  [ the Republican Governor ]  is that he plays on fears.
I have affirmative plans: a 33-point plan on crime. "
We've had 12 years of tough talk on crime, 12 long years.
And we've had a rising tide of random violence that is different from anything I can remember.
I want to break the cycle of violence. "
Tens of thousands of Egyptians gathered today in this city's main stadium for the largest protest so far in the Arab world, outside Iraq, against an American-led war to topple Saddam Hussein.

Egyptian authorities, who have in recent weeks arrested dozens of demonstrators and forcibly restricted several smaller protests against the war and against Israel, sanctioned today's rally in what appeared to be an effort by President Hosni Mubarak's government to carefully modulate public anger over the prospect of a conflict. ''
By our soul, by our blood, we will redeem you, Baghdad,'' protesters chanted in unison as speaker after speaker denounced the Bush administration's threat to overthrow Mr. Hussein.
The chant's coda changed to ''Palestine'' and back again, underscoring how many link the Iraqi crisis with the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. ''
Our gathering is a message to Arab leaders and America,'' Khaled Mohieddin, the leader of the leftist opposition party Tagamua, told the crowd. ''
The message is that Iraq and Palestine are questions of prime importance for us; they are more important than internal questions.''

The rally, held at Cairo International Stadium in Nasser City, a suburb of the capital, was organized by labor unions and opposition parties, as well as the Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamic political and social organization that is officially banned here.
Egypt's emergency laws -- in effect, with only a brief interruption, since the 1967 Middle East war -- bar public demonstrations, making today's one of the largest tolerated in Egypt in years.
With public sentiment strongly opposed to a war, even Mr. Mubarak's National Democratic Party announced that it, too, would organize an antiwar march next week. ''
I think the government felt it had to do something to allow the people to speak,'' Mamoun al-Hudaibi, the leader of the Muslim Brotherhood, said amid the rally's rhythmic din. ''
That excellent combination, ham and Champagne, has inspired Steven Schonwetter, the owner of Bilinski's, a ham and sausage company in Cohoes, N.Y., near Albany.
There is a distinctive Champagne aroma in his new hams for the Easter season.
That is because they have been marinated for three days in Glenora Brut Champenoise, a sparkling wine from the Finger Lakes region of New York.
The boneless hams are hickory smoked and have been glazed with pineapple juice and brown sugar.
The meat has a velvety texture and a rich, slightly winy flavor.
It is not particularly salty.
The hams are made from Canadian pork, and contain no water or filler.
Bilinski's, which has been making sausages and smoking hams since 1929, will sell the marinated hams for the next few weeks and at Christmastime at the 25 Kings Super Markets in New Jersey.
Whole hams, about 10 pounds, are $5.49 a pound; half hams are $5.99 a pound.
The hams are also available at the same price by mail, plus shipping, from (518) 237-0171 or www.bilinski.com.
Tiny, mobile and staggeringly abundant, microscopic organisms are premier colonists, famed for finding their way into any suitable habitat wherever it might exist.
In fact, a phrase coined early in the last century to describe their movement and distribution is this microbial motto: ''Everything is everywhere.''

But this month, two teams of biologists are independently reporting striking exceptions to that rule in what some scientists say are the strongest of a group of new studies challenging the longstanding dogma.
The two teams report genetic evidence that the microbes that live in far-flung hot springs from Yellowstone to Siberia to New Zealand are not freely moving across the globe, as expected.
Instead, populations in different regions are distinct, and the farther apart any two hot springs, the more genetically isolated are their microbes.
The work suggests that everything cannot get everywhere and that distance, at least in those species, matters.
One study appeared this month in Science and the other in Environmental Microbiology.
The fact that an organism too small to be seen with the unaided eye cannot easily travel from Wyoming to Siberia may not shock most people.
But researchers say the idea, which continues to encounter extensive skepticism, is a radical notion for microbiologists.
If that fact carries over to other species of bacteria, such a reversal will require a wholesale rethinking of how these numerous and ancient organisms diverge and evolve. ''

IT always seems to be raining in London in THE END OF THE AFFAIR (1999), Neil Jordan's intoxicating film version of Graham Greene's novel, but Ralph Fiennes and Julianne Moore managed to stay dry, perfectly pressed and immaculately gorgeous.
They play the passionate wartime lovers who can barely tear themselves out of bed for bomb warnings.
Stephen Rea is the chronically dull husband who believes his wife's unfaithfulness is just what he deserves.
The dialogue is heaven (''Henry prefers habit to happiness,'' ''The war was the greatest pimp of all,'' ''I knew that nothing in this world would make sense to me again'').
This is a poetically old-fashioned romance, right down to Ms. Moore's delicate little (uh-oh) cough -- Sunday and Wednesday at 10 p.m. on Cinemax.
Rain also plays a role in Frank Capra's IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT (1934).
A washed-out bridge forces Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert to share a room at a $2-a-night ''auto camp'' (motel, to you and me).
She's a runaway hieress whose cash has been stolen; he's an unemployed reporter down to his last $10; they fall comically in love on the Miami to New York bus.
It's impossible to resist either Gable (''Perhaps you're interested in how a man undresses'') or Colbert (''I proved once and for all that the limb is mightier than the thumb'').
No screen couple has ever met cuter, and the film has all five major Oscars to prove it -- Thursday at 1:45 and 8 p.m., Thursday/Early Friday at 2:45 a.m. on AMC.
To the Editor: Lynne Abraham (Op-Ed, Aug. 13) contributes needed balance to the record on the Mumia Abu-Jamal case but omits the middle ground.
While a new trial might not be warranted, neither is a death sentence.

Though recent arguments for Mr. Abu-Jamal's innocence (like the reports of a mismatching bullet in the corpse) may be explainable, the jury should have weighed such evidence, and didn't because of a judge whose behavior remains extreme.
Retrials after 14 years are properly discouraged; they are an unpromising path to justice.
In this case, who pulled the trigger is already fairly clear; why is unlikely to be clarified.
But regardless of whether the judge's conduct warrants a retrial, we must still recognize a margin between the certainty required for conviction and that required for execution.
Such margins are what allow society to live comfortably with the need for justice in many cases where the facts are incomplete.
Legitimate doubts remain about Mr. Abu-Jamal's intent.
Accepting the prosecution's evidence, the possibility persists that he made a terrible split-second misjudgment while trying to rescue his brother, who he thought was being unjustly beaten.
We can't permit police officers to be shot while making arrests.
LEAD: To the Editor: The way Mr. Leavitt uses labels and language implies that he believes that such usage makes them truth.
In short, his article reminds one of Jesse Helms.
