I have no way of knowing whether my notions of sexual behavior are ''correct,'' but apparently if they are not open and receptive to the likes of Robert Mapplethorpe or Holly Hughes's challenges to sexual behavior, I am a ''right winger.''
From Mr. Leavitt's tone, I assume this is not a good thing to be.

Even more surprising was Mr. Leavitt's assertion of the ''extreme right wing's determination to terrorize an already ambivalent American population by manipulating its entrenched fears of anything foreign, unfamiliar or explicitly sexual.''
I wasn't aware that I was ''terrorized'' or that such an assault was directed at my ambivalence and ''entrenched fears.''
Nor was I conscious when I ''terrorized'' someone's ''ambivalence,'' sexual or otherwise, being the possible right winger I have unknowingly become.
When did this happen to me?
There are things about which I am ambivalent and I have my share of terrors, but human appetites are not, as far as I know, one of them.
I admit I don't like movies wherein human parts are separated from each other with lots of detail.
Like countless ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, Albin Kurti spent the weekend glued to his television set, watching President Bush's visit to Albania.
He was eager to see what Mr. Bush would say from just across the border about Kosovo's efforts to gain its independence from Serbia.
Mr. Bush did say that he supported independence for Kosovo as soon as possible, but Mr. Kurti, who opposes the United Nations' role in determining the status of Kosovo, was unimpressed.

He says he believes that the United Nations plan for the province would leave the United States and Europe with too much power, noting that it would allow an appointed figure to intervene in Kosovo's police and judiciary matters. ''
This is a typical colonial situation,'' he said in an interview on Saturday. ''
Of course it has modern wrapping, but it remains a colonial situation.''

Mr. Kurti, a former dissident who was jailed for his opposition to the former Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic, has urged that Kosovo's future be decided in a referendum rather than in the Security Council.
He has led a series of demonstrations against the United Nations, and was sent to prison in February after one violent protest in which two people were killed and 82 wounded.
Last Thursday, he was released and placed under house arrest while awaiting trial.
The treatment of Mr. Kurti has increased nervousness among Kosovo politicians and international officials here as the status of the province remains up in the air.
The opening moments of the Jets' training camp this morning were quiet.
No one, except for a few players who had been with Bill Parcells in Super Bowls past, knew what to expect.
The silence was quickly broken.
Within a few minutes, Parcells was yelling.
As the players pounded tackling dummies and skipped over pads in agility drills, he yelled at them more than the benevolent Rich Kotite did through much of last year's 1-15 season. ''
Brady, get off the field,'' Parcells screamed during a line-up shift when tight end Kyle Brady was supposed to shuttle to the sideline.
Verbally throttling another tight end, Fred Baxter, he yelled: ''Where are you lining up?
Don't you know where you're supposed to be?''
Parcells wielded a heavy whistle, at one point stopping three straight plays before they could be brought off because players were not lined up properly.
Afterward, he described his first two hours with his team as ''a little bit sloppy.''

Military attacks to punish Baghdad for its refusal to grant United Nations inspectors full access to suspected weapons sites would jeopardize the intricate web of monitoring and relief operations the United Nations has built across Iraq with Washington's encouragement, some United Nations officials and diplomats say.
The inspections for proscribed weapons of mass destruction rely on 24-hour electronic monitoring.
They  could be put at risk, these officials say, as would physical searches of suspect installations.

In addition, the food, medicine and other commodities whose distribution is financed by restricted sales of Iraqi oil would be less likely to reach the ordinary Iraqis suffering from more than seven years of economic sanctions. ''

It's not a problem that people address directly,'' said a diplomat from one country on the Security Council, who described it as woven into the concern about what could follow if Secretary General Kofi Annan's mission to Baghdad fails. ''
I'm hearing people say that the whole thing could break down,'' said an Asian diplomat, who added that many governments are worried about the fate of the monitoring and relief network. ''
If there's a military strike,'' he said, ''it could fall apart.''
The interviewed diplomats insisted on not being identified by name or country.
The United Nations has begun thinning out its presence in Iraq, with 60 members of its relief staff leaving Baghdad on Thursday and Friday.
Juan Carlos Brandt, a United Nations spokesman, described their departures ''basically as a precautionary measure.''
What a glorious time of year this is.
The trees are showing off their splendid fall colors.
The leafy canopies range from the bright reds to golden hues to several shades of bronze.
And when the hillsides are interspersed with the green of conifers, nothing can match nature's palette.
Even the asters and chrysanthemums remain in bloom.
And though most of the birds have gone, winter residents are hanging around to keep up their happy chatter.
The squirrels are especially busy making noises as they flick their tails and wonder where they will bury the nuts they are carrying in their mouths.
The farmers are happy.
Their grain fields are ripening and the ryes, sorghums, wheats and oats are coming in.
And the silos are getting filled with food for the herd.
To the Editor: Pennsylvania landfills receive enormous volumes of New York and New Jersey garbage, and the citizens of Pennsylvania are not happy about it.
They don't want their state-of-the-art facilities filled with other people's trash.
Pennsylvania officials have taken measures to keep out their neighbors' waste, but they do have a point: New York and New Jersey need to develop more waste-disposal capacity -- now.
As both states wrestle with their predicament, along comes a member of Congress from Pennsylvania who would limit their options.
In "Incinerators: A Problem, Not a Solution" (Op-Ed, Sept. 21), Representative Peter H. Kostmayer argues for an eight-year national moratorium on new waste-to-energy incineration plants.

His arguments ("poisonous" air emissions, "toxic" ash and conflict with recycling) have surface appeal, but they have been discredited by scientific studies and real world experience, much of which comes from Europe and Japan, where recycling and incineration are more advanced than in the United States.
My association represents the entire waste industry -- transporting, recycling, landfilling and waste-toenergy incineration.
We do not endorse one disposal option over another, but we fully support waste reduction and all the recycling that is feasible.
Developing an integrated waste-management plan is necessarily a local process, reflecting economic, social and political priorities.
Waste-to-energy incineration is not the right choice for every community, but it is a critical ingredient of responsible waste management for some.
LARGE-BLADED ceiling or paddle fans are easy to connect to existing ceiling wiring like that of an overhead light.
But to comply with electric codes in many communities, the electrical box containing the wiring, and to which most fans are attached, has to be a special kind.
Using a code-approved box makes a fan less likely to fall from the ceiling.
Unfortunately, installing such a box to replace an existing unapproved box usually makes the job of installing a fan more difficult.
There are two types of electrical boxes approved for use with ceiling fans.
For replacing an existing box that is mounted against a ceiling joist, a box having long bolts attached to it for fastening the fan is used.
The box is attached to the joist with lag bolts, which anchor the box more firmly than nails or screws.
Be sure the box is labeled for fan support and carries a mark like that of Underwriters' Laboratories.

For replacing an electric box suspended from a hanger bar, a metal bar that spans the space between two joists, or for use when a joist-mounted box cannot be easily removed, use a telescoping fan brace.
That is a sturdier version of a hanger bar.
Propelled by strong growth in both subscribers and advertising, America Online Inc. reported quarterly profits yesterday that sharply exceeded analysts' expectations.

The company, the leading on-line service company, also announced that it had acquired Netchannel Inc., a company that has developed technology to allow people to surf the Internet on their television sets, for $20 million.
America Online's growth in the quarter ended March 31 came despite the prospect of a 10 percent increase in its monthly fee, to $21.95, which took effect in April.
The company's flagship service added a net 1.2 million new members in the quarter, bringing the total to 11.9 million.
As a result, the company reduced its spending on marketing from 21 percent of revenue a year ago to 12 percent. ''
We really hit our stride in subscriber growth and advertising revenue,'' said Stephen M. Case, the company's chairman. ''
And we have done a great job in restraining costs.''
Mr. Case said that subscriber growth continued in April, despite the fee increase.
Over all, America Online earned $18.6 million in its fiscal third quarter, or 9 cents a fully diluted share, compared with a loss of $4.7 million in the quarter a year earlier.
The quarter included $45 million in charges related to acquisitions and layoffs in its AOL Studios division, which produces certain content sections, and it included a tax benefit of $24 million.
Many mutual fund investors and advisers have been beating the index fund drum lately.
The argument goes that because more than 80 percent of diversified equity funds trailed the Standard & Poor's 500 last year, why not simply buy the index?
Depending on how you invest, that may not be a bad idea.
A study by Morningstar Inc., the fund researchers in Chicago, shows that funds that invest  in large-capitalization stocks have generally not outperformed the overall market over the last 10 years.
But many mid-cap and small-cap funds fared much better than their market indexes.
In its survey, Morningstar used the S.& P. 500 for large-cap funds; the Wilshire Mid-Cap 750 for mid-cap, and the Russell 2000 for the small-company funds.
Morningstar sorted the funds into three groups according to their median  market cap at year-end 1995.
In 1995, only 8.5 percent of large-cap funds beat the index, and the majority did so only one year out of the last 10, and not by much.
So it makes sense to stash some money in an S.& P. index fund, concluded Jeff Kelley, author of the study.
Mid-cap funds did a bit better.
BISTRO M has put Glen Head on Long Island's culinary map.
The restaurant's stylish, contemporary American food has turned a cozy cafe situated in a quaint cottage alongside the railroad tracks into a dining destination.
That food is among the best being served on the Island today.
The man responsible for this diners' delight is Mitchell SuDock, the chef and co-owner. (
Neil M. Frank is another owner.)
Most recently, Mr. SuDock was the chef de cuisine at Mirabelle in St. James.
Before that he cooked at Gotham Bar & Grill and Gramercy Tavern in Manhattan.
He learned his lessons well at those renowned spots, and now, at his own place, is pulling out all the stops.
The tiny Bistro M has a simple, straightforward decor featuring dark wood wainscoting, creamy stucco walls, a few large mirrors and pictures of Parisian street scenes.

The service staff looks casual in their blue shirts and bistro aprons tied at the waist but is a hardworking, professional crew, and these agreeable, efficient waiters were mere acolytes for the food and the pleasant, cozy atmosphere was a backdrop for it.
THE highly colored terra cotta of the 1927 Fred F. French Building at 551 Fifth Avenue, at 45th Street, has been wrapped in scaffolding for two years.
This fall, as a $9 million facade restoration is completed, it will reappear.
A fresh look at the building's ancient styling and skyscraper modernity should give anyone a start.
Fred Fillmore French, developer of the building, began his real estate career in 1908.
In 1921 he hit on the "French plan" to finance his development activity -- each project was sold as common stock to small investors.
By avoiding traditional bank financing he was able to maximize both control and profits, a goal he furthered by organizing his own departments for architecture and property management.
By the mid-1920's French had built a dozen good-sized apartment houses this way.
In 1925, he began the project bearing his name.
The 38-story building was unusual in many respects.
According to "New York 1930," by Robert A.M. Stern, Gregory Gilmartin and Thomas Mellins, it was an early example of the new rectangular skyscraper at a time when towers were usually square.

Just a week ago, Tyre was an idyllic seaside town on the Mediterranean Sea, a fledgling tourist spot with everything from scuba diving to fishing cruises, populated by a mixture of Christians and Shiite Muslims.
Posters herald a concert by Nancy Ajram, one of the hottest pop singers in the Arab world.
But this town is also the gateway to Hezbollah country, where Hezbollah controls everything from local administration and schools to security.
Hezbollah has its footprint everywhere here, from its signature yellow banners to portraits celebrating fallen martyrs.

So since the current conflict began, Israeli aircraft have sought to bomb Tyre and the area south of here into submission, while refugees fleeing the bombing have turned the town into a way station on the path to safety in the north. ''
This is a war of nerves,'' said Khalid Mehdi, 50, a fisherman who sat near the city's harbor with several of his friends on Monday in a rare moment of quiet. ''
Don't be fooled by quiet.
Be afraid of it.''
On Saturday and Sunday, Israeli warplanes carried out their heaviest bombing yet of southern Lebanon, and there was enough horror to go around.
On Sunday, at least 10 people, including children, were killed when a bomb aimed at the civil defense headquarters here demolished the top two floors of the building.
Fred Colby has been getting a lot of fan letters these days.
Mr. Colby is not a movie star or even a famous violinist.
He is the energetic and visionary director of the San Diego Foundation for the Performing Arts, perhaps the most established presenter of dance in the western United States.
The 10-year-old foundation has put on highly regarded yearly series of dance by major ballet, modern and ethnic troupes from around the world in two theaters in San Diego.
But last week Mr. Colby announced the cancellation of its season, which was to have included performances by the companies of Mark Morris, Paul Taylor and others.
Unless it can raise $200,000 by Oct. 20 , Mr. Colby contends, the foundation will have to close permanently.

American dance companies have long used revenues from touring to subsidize their New York seasons and keep their companies solvent, particularly as performances throughout the country have dwindled during the recession.
But the letters that have been pouring in to Mr. Colby since he announced the impending close have suggested that dance companies have a special fondness for the institution.
A Letter From Arpino Gerald Arpino, the director of the Joffrey Ballet, wrote, calling the foundation "the kind of arts presenter we need in America -- honest, practical, thoughtful."
Jill Satterfield, the director of the Momix modern dance troupe, wrote, "It would be an indescribable loss to not have you there, for both audience and performer."
For Pino Cinquemani, a butcher in Little Italy, selling prime cuts to families for Easter dinner has been part of a family tradition for three generations.
Mr. Cinquemani, 49, has been a butcher since he was 9 years old, when he began working with his grandfather in Sicily.
Ten years ago, he took over Pino Prime Meats on Sullivan Street from his uncle.
During the rush to fill orders for Easter, he still manages to take time out to greet and embrace a loyal customer whom he calls Ms. Juliet.
Mr. Cinquemani then goes back to work.
He removes a baby lamb from his refrigerator and prepares a rack of lamb for a customer.
The rack, or rib section, and the customary leg of lamb prove to be popular again this year.
Mr. Cinquemani had received 41 orders for cuts of the meat by 8:30 on Saturday morning alone.
In a final rush, customers are still calling in, placing last-minute orders.

While Michael Douglas thumbed through his employer's secret files with ease in "Disclosure" using a virtual reality program, the actual applications of that technology are are more suited to the fields of architecture, electronic games and business presentations.
But everyday users cannot create virual reality scenes easily.
Conventional  virtual reality applications require huge amounts of computing power to generate realistic scenes.
Trying to generate scenes in real time on a computer is akin to trying to stuff an elephant into a hall closet.
A scaled-down alternative is  Apple's Quicktime VR, a technology for creating and displaying scenes made from  photographs, video stills or computer renderings.
Programmers are just beginning to use the technology for games and architectural applications.
Each scene is roughly 500 kilobytes, about one-third of a floppy disk.
Programmers can link one scene to another to create a virtual world, or house or factory.
Strata Studio Pro and Metatools KPT Bryce allow the user to export files into Quicktime VR for virtual worlds.
The technology's overall effect, while comparatively low-techology, bypasses most the limitations of today's computing platforms.
WHAT'S in a name?
When the name is New York, apparently not too much.
Here is the Big Apple, pretty well convinced it is the center of everything, the capital of the world.
But does anyone out there buy it?
Not if you measure its fame by the frequency with which its name is invoked outside its borders.
There are New York bagels, New York cheesecake and New York-cut strip steaks.
There is beer from the Manhattan Brewing Company and even Brooklyn Lager, from that other borough.
There is a cocktail, the Manhattan, and, stretching the point, the Bronx, a gin-based concoction dreamed up, legend has it, at the old Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan.
Bagels From Bulgaria After that, the list gets very thin very fast.
And even those few famous New York items are derivatives.
Visitors may well be impressed by the prodigious talents on display in a fascinating show, ''Being William Morris,'' at Manhattan's Morgan Library.
Shown in several galleries are the works and memorabilia of this British poet and artist who died a century ago.
His attending physician remarked at the time that he died ''simply being William Morris and having done more work than most ten men.''
He designed furniture, tapestries and wallpaper, and his wonderful floral style is back in favor.
His eminence as an author prompted an invitation (which he declined) to be poet laureate.
An ardent left-winger, he wrote many pamphlets, including ''Why I Am a Communist.''
Paradoxically, he also was a printer and businessman whose elegant books set a standard yet to be surpassed. (
The Morris exhibit, be it noted, is paired with ''Documenting The Times,'' celebrating another printer, Adolph S. Ochs, who acquired this newspaper 100 years ago yesterday.)
How did Morris manage to do it?
Like other productive Victorians, he possessed a vitality that was seemingly inexhaustible and an output that was prodigious.
THE sunflowers are filling out, coming into their own with golden ray petals circling the brown center, or disk, flowers.
Quite often the flower heads flop over because they are so heavy with the rich seed that will make superb winter bird food.
If the plants are being raised for their valuable seed, however, it is helpful to put a cheesecloth or old potato bag over the flower as it ripens to keep the flocks away for now.
The signal to harvest comes when the backs of the flowers are brown and appear dry.
Then the flower head can be cut from the plant and hung upside down to dry thoroughly.
When the flower is completely dry, place newspapers on the floor of a garage or basement, and rub the  heads together to release the seed.
Or use an old brush to release the seeds and store them dry.
As snack food, sunflower seeds are rich in many nutrients, including protein and iron.
Some gardeners never plant sunflowers because they find the old-fashioned plants attract too many winged invaders.
Another reason is that the plants are so enormous they never seem to fit into a garden scheme.
DESPITE my less than stellar success last year with agastaches, sun-loving members of the mint family, the signs were nevertheless auspicious with regard to increasing their numbers this year.
Agastaches are not popular with the deer or rabbits I increasingly see munching through my front garden in central New Jersey.
Agastaches are also drought tolerant.
Agastaches encompass both shrublike plants, primarily found in the Southwest and Mexico, and perennials, which are native in the northern United States and in Asia.
Members in the Southwest group generally have thin stems, which wave in warm summer breezes much as ornamental grasses do, and desert-sunset-colored flowers.
The perennial kinds usually have sturdier stems and blue-toned flowers.
All agastaches feature buds that are encased by what is botanically called a calyx and which looks like a small cap.
The calyxes on the Southwestern agastaches are often a different color than the tubular petals that blare forth from them.
The flowers on agastaches growing elsewhere generally have calyxes in shades similar to that of the petals.
Last summer, I succumbed to catalog descriptions for three Southwest agastaches.
The Boeing Company has proposed modifications to all 747 jumbo jets to make engines less likely to fall off in flight.

Engine mounts on the four-engine 747's have come under scrutiny since they were implicated in the crashes of an El Al cargo jet in Amsterdam on Oct. 4 and of a China Airlines cargo plane in Taiwan on Dec. 21, 1991.
In both crashes, investigators said, the two engines on the right wing fell off.
But regulatory agencies have not determined the causes of the two crashes.
No passenger 747 has crashed because of an engine loss.
But 50 people died in the Amsterdam crash when the plane struck an apartment house.
The three crew members were killed in the Taiwan crash.
Before the proposed modifications can be made, they must be approved by the Federal Aviation Administration, which has them under review.
Making the changes to the 948-plane fleet would take several years.
Meantime, the F.A.A. has ordered more frequent inspections of the engine mounts.

Robin Moonasar and Shiraz Baksh were the best of buddies, fellow computer hackers and high school classmates in Toronto who decided to come to New York for a week of excitement before classes started on Wednesday.
But a fight outside a wedding party in Richmond Hill, Queens, early yesterday ended Mr. Moonasar's life and nearly finished Mr. Baksh's.
Mr. Moonasar, 18 years old, died of stab wounds at 3:45 A.M. yesterday at Jamaica Hospital.
Mr. Baksh, who, like his friend, was stabbed, was listed in fair condition at the hospital.
The police arrested Ramesh Ramdowe, 20, of 131-11 95 Avenue in Richmond Hill, who was charged with second-degree murder and first-degree assault.
No weapon was recovered. '
Keeps Saying Robin's Name' "Shiraz is in shock," said Sheik Baksh, his father, who arrived with his wife from Toronto yesterday after being told his son was injured. "
He keeps saying Robin's name and crying."

Mr. Baksh, who is of Indian heritage and who emigrated from Guyana to Canada 18 years ago, said his son had visited New York several times, often when the family came for a wedding of one of the dozens of relatives who live in Queens.

This time, the younger Mr. Baksh and Mr. Moonasar were simply coming to enjoy a delayed summer vacation, because they had taken summer school classes in business administration to earn extra credit before their senior year.
In 18 years as a Senator from New Jersey, Bill Bradley said, he has never seen such a passionate response to any issue.
What has prompted thousands of letters, postcards and phone calls is Mr. Bradley's bill to force health insurers to pay for at least 48 hours of hospital care for newborn babies and their mothers.
It is co-sponsored by Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, a Republican of Kansas.

Many letters are from women whose insurance companies or health maintenance organizations forced them out of the hospital less than a day after they gave birth and whose babies became critically ill or died of causes that a nurse or doctor would have spotted with an extra day's hospital stay.
In June, New Jersey enacted a law forcing insurance companies to cover at least 48 hours of hospital care for uncomplicated births and at least 96 hours for Caesarean sections.
The Connecticut and New York legislatures are considering similar laws.
Maryland is the only other state that mandates a two-day minimum maternity stay.
On Friday, Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut began paying for an extra day of care for patients whose insurance companies refused to cover more than a 24-hour stay after delivery.
Earlier in the month, three Westchester hospitals did the same: Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco; St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers and New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center.

While some managed-care trade organizations have spoken out against legislation mandating 48-hour minimum maternity stays and have defended the practice of early releases, Senator Bradley expressed surprise at how muted the opposition to his bill had been. "

Shares in the Sangstat Medical Corporation gained 23 percent today after Abbott Laboratories Inc. agreed to distribute the company's generic versions of a drug that helps prevent organ rejection in transplant patients in the United States.

Sangstat, a biotechnology company based in Menlo Park, Calif., received approval from the Food and Drug Administration in November for Sangcya, its liquid form of the anti-rejection drug cyclosporine.

But shares of Sangstat have declined from a high of $32.125 in January because of concerns that Novartis A.G., the Swiss pharmaceuticals giant that invented cyclosporine, would be able to block Sangcya sales through patent litigation and superior marketing muscle.
Sangstat shares rose $2.75, to $14.5625, in Nasdaq trading.
Abbott fell 37.5 cents, to $46.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The American depository receipts of Novartis fell 62.5 cents, to $76.375. ''
I think it's a very intelligent move for Sangstat,'' said Sergio Traversa, an analyst with Mehta Partners. ''
The old story is alive again.''
Abbott, based in Abbott Park, Ill., will co-promote and distribute Sangcya and cyclosporine capsules, which Sangstat said it expected to introduce next year.
Abbott will buy $14 million of Sangstat stock, give up-front and milestone payments and make a long-term loan to Sangstat.
Choreographic rigor dominated Leslie Satin's ''Blind Summit,'' which Leslie Satin and Dancers presented on Saturday night at the Joyce SoHo.
The rigor sprang from a specific source.
Ms. Satin said in a program note that she had been inspired by Agnes Martin, an abstract artist whose meticulously constructed paintings are often based on grids.
Ms. Satin's dance, for herself, Erin Crawley-Woods, Rennie Greenberg Gallagher and Petra Martin, was equally meticulous.
The dancers frequently stayed close to the walls of the space.
But there were times when they lined up center stage, turning from side to side and stretching their arms as if carefully signaling in a private gestural language.
They also posed on white chairs.
Except for a few passages of brisk runs, most of the steps were evenly paced.
Video close-ups of the dancers by Andrew Gurian appeared on the back wall.
One ingenious sequence showed them moving around a television set displaying still other images of them.
When the brokerage business was populated by dozens of small companies, three firms in St. Louis made the city the industry's biggest center west of Wall Street.
Now, only two remain independent.
The Wachovia Corporation swallowed up A. G. Edwards yesterday in a $6.8 billion cash and stock deal that highlights the continued consolidation of the retail brokerage sector.

Bringing together more than $1.1 trillion in client assets and nearly 15,000 advisers, the move aims to expand Wachovia's reach in the securities business as it faces more difficult times in other parts of the banking industry.

The deal will make Wachovia Securities the country's second-largest retail broker after Merrill Lynch, allowing it to take advantage of the cost efficiencies that come with size and to sell bank products to a bigger base of affluent clients.
It also could enhance the capabilities of its fledgling investment bank, giving clients access to a broader network of retail investors for distributing new securities offerings. ''
This is an end game for us,'' G. Kennedy Thompson, Wachovia's chairman and chief executive, said on a conference call with investors. ''
We have everything that we need to grow this business organically.''
For A. G. Edwards, the deal is the end of an era.
Ever since a friend of Abraham Lincoln founded the securities firm more than 120 years ago, it remained fiercely independent.
Just as the poet Wallace Stevens never made it into the textbooks for his work as an insurance lawyer, Robert Gurland has not attracted wide attention as a commercial litigator.
He has as a jazz vocalist, though.
In addition to performing on stage with musicians as diverse as the Kinks and P. D. Q. Bach, he has "done entire horn sections on albums," he said.
That is to say he has the unusual talent of making his voice sound like a trumpet.
But most of the time he represents publishers and insurance companies as a lawyer with Lane Felcher Kurlander & Fox in Manhattan.
He has practiced law for most of the last 23 years and has no plans to stop.
It's hardly unusual to find a lawyer who is also an accountant or a real estate broker.
And the country is full of former lawyers, some who are now painters, chefs, musicians or, especially, writers.
But in addition to those, there is a much smaller group of practicing lawyers who are also living the sort of artistic dreams that most like-minded people gave up when they moved out of the dorm.
They are often asked why, aside from the obvious (law pays; art doesn't), they continue to be lawyers.
The golden era of North America, in the eyes of today's North Americans, was about 200 years ago, when bison roamed the Great Plains by the millions.
But even that is a watered-down memory.

Thirteen thousand years ago, truly mega fauna, including lions, cheetahs, camels and five kinds of elephant, also walked the land -- and still would today, had humans not come along to speed their extinction.
Why not bring 'em back?
In August, in a paper titled ''Re-Wilding North America,'' a team of naturalists led by Josh Donlan, a Cornell University graduate student, proposed to do exactly that.
Many of these large vertebrates now face extinction in Africa and Asia, the authors note; meanwhile, the Great Plains area is slowly emptying of its people.
No time like the present to restore the Pleistocene-era wilderness.
Ecotourists and dollars would flock to the region.

More important, the plan would aid the global conservation effort and simultaneously serve as an antidote to ''the 'pests and weeds' (rats and dandelions) that will otherwise come to dominate the landscape,'' the authors wrote.
Of course, the reintroduced beasts wouldn't be the exact same species as the originals, merely their closest living kin.

Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it earned $369 million in the third quarter, with the cable, cable networks and publishing divisions posting substantial gains while the music and filmed entertainment divisions showed losses.
Net income per diluted share was 27 cents, in contrast to a loss of 3 cents a year earlier.
Time Warner's combined cash flow -- earnings before interest, taxes and amortization -- for the period was $1.6 billion, up 49 percent from $1.08 billion a year earlier.
Revenue grew 3 percent, to $6.71 billion, from $6.59 billion for the same period in 1998.
Dennis Leibowitz, a senior vice president at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said that the report had no surprises. ''
The expectations had been lowered because of a recent downturn in the music business, which showed a pretty big decline,'' he said. ''
But everything else was pretty much in line with their expectations.''
Time Warner's stock closed at $62.625, down $1.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Gerald M. Levin, the chairman and chief executive of Time Warner, said yesterday in meetings with analysts and reporters that he expected the company's overall growth rate for 1999 to be similar to that of 1998, about 14 percent.
The earnings at the cable networks grew 21 percent, to $328 million, in the third quarter; part of that growth was driven by double-digit growth at Turner Cable Networks and HBO.
The French see themselves as a people who appreciate method and logic.
Their  teen-agers are taught logic and philosophy in school.
Intricate discourse fills  as much television time as any national sport.
And this year the country is making a fuss over Rene Descartes, France's emblem of rational thought, who was born 400 years ago.
Yet a contradiction arises that the great philosopher himself might have liked to consider: Why are the French spending so much time with seers and psychics these days?
A recent poll showed that more French men and women believe in the devil today than a decade ago.
The French are reportedly consulting clairvoyants and numerologists in greater numbers than ever.
Demand is also up for people who seek underground water with a dowsing rod, heal the sick by telephone and interpret handwriting. "
It's bizarre, but it's very clear that the more machines we build, the less  we know how to live and the more we are all searching," said Ange d'Orment, a psychic.
The Government has evidence that magic is thriving.
The eight-member presidency of this country split in half today, leaving two bodies asserting that they hold Yugoslav sovereignty.
One, composed of Serbia and its three allies on the old presidency, has declared itself to have superseded the practically defunct federal Parliament.
The other comprises representatives of four republics.
It is headed by Branko Kostic, a Serb, and is nominally headed by President Stipe Mesic, a Croat, who had been the head of the old executive.

Mr. Mesic, whose Croatian Republic says it is independent and sovereign, and Mr. Kostic, convened sessions of the divided Federal presidency today, one on the Croatian island of Brioni and the other in Belgrade, which is the federal and Serbian capital.
Mr. Mesic said he did not dare come to Belgrade.
He denounced the appropriation of parliamentary powers by the Serb-led half of the presidency as a coup.
The dispute took place as the Serbian-dominated federal army fought Croatian forces around Dubrovnik, the Adriatic port. [
The Yugoslav Army, firing mortars and rockets, has cut off Dubrovnik from the outside world by land and sea, Reuters reported. ]

Deal for European Observers As fires raged around the medieval city of carved limestone, the leaders of Serbia and Croatia agreed to an "immediate cease-fire" -- the sixth since Aug. 7 -- in The Hague, where they met under the auspices of Lord Carrington, the European Community's Yugoslav crisis negotiator.
GADGETRY, the source of inspiration for many a holiday gift, is no longer just for the home-entertainment altar or car dashboard.
In fact, it is now enhancing objects like shower mirrors, refrigerators and  rabbits.
LG's icebox TV is one of this year's biggest examples: a 26.2-cubic-foot titanium-finished refrigerator-freezer with a 15-inch liquid-crystal-display screen in the door.
Although LG first released a refrigerator-TV unit in 2004, this model includes an additional four-inch weather and information L.C.D. screen above the ice dispenser. ''

We wanted to provide some of the interactivity and function that people might get from a computer, while doing it in a relatively cost-effective way,'' said Tim Kavanaugh, the director of merchandising for LG's digital appliance division.
The smaller screen includes an electronic bank of recipes and a U.S.B. port that can be used for transferring images into the appliance's personal digital photo album.
More information on this model is in the home appliances section at us.lge.com; the unit itself costs about $3,500 at Best Buy or other appliance stores.
Smaller and less expensive appliances are also fusing the outside world with the inner sanctum of the kitchen.
The Melitta Smart Mill and Brew coffee maker displays weather conditions, forecasts and other information from the MSN Direct wireless data-cast network on its L.C.D. screen.
The weather function does not require an Internet connection, so there are no monthly fees.
She sneaked onto the ice a day before, at 2 in the morning, when the temperature and spectators had dropped to zero.
Today, Nancy Kerrigan went public on skates for the first time since being clubbed in the right knee on Jan. 6 at the national championships.
She stroked around the rink without so much as a jump, not an axel or lutz or a salchow or a toe loop, yet the curious showed up to chronicle her every spin and spiral.
Before 8 A.M., cars filtered down Nancy Kerrigan Way to Stoneham Arena, north of Boston.
The parking lot filled.
A pool of reporters and photographers was ushered in.
Others pressed their faces like orphans to the arena's glass doors.
A patrol car circled.
A couple of prep school teams waited impatiently outside in the snow, their hockey game suddenly taking a backseat to figure skating as a full-contact sport.

A continent away, in Portland, Ore., Tonya Harding also resumed her training for the Olympics next month in Norway, refusing to withdraw after proclaiming her innocence in the Kerrigan attack through her coach, attempting with her post-midnight workout to turn a crime story back into a skating story.

Alfred Bernstein, a New Deal lawyer who led the movement to unionize government workers and later helped desegregate the lunch counters, restaurants, public swimming pools and playgrounds of Jim Crow-era Washington, died on Friday at his home in Washington.
He was 92.
Mr. Bernstein attended public schools in Manhattan and graduated from Columbia College and Columbia Law School.
Inspired by the social ferment of the New Deal, he moved to the capital in 1937 to work as an investigator for the Senate Commerce Committee's inquiry into the monopolistic railroad industry. ''

What all of us were interested in was the transformation of the political process -- drafting regulations, establishing Social Security, making regulatory agencies work,'' he once told an interviewer. ''
There was a lot of idealism at the time.''

After serving in the Army Air Transport Command in the South Pacific in World War II, Mr. Bernstein returned to Washington where he helped lead the successful effort against Jim Crow laws in the capital.

In the late 1940's, Mr. Bernstein defended scores of government workers brought before what were then called Loyalty Review Boards after they had been accused, often vaguely and usually anonymously, of disloyalty.
He was successful in most of the cases.
He also lived in San Francisco for a time, where he worked as a leader of the West Coast labor movement, organizing guards at Alcatraz prison, among other workers.
The day before, while discussing injuries and the danger of a long playoff series, Devils Coach Larry Robinson had said: ''Every extra game you play is a chance for somebody to get hurt.
The sooner you get it done, the better off you are.
You're less likely to get hurt if you're not playing.''
Tonight, Robinson and the Devils got the worst of both scenarios.
They failed to clinch their first-round playoff series, losing by 3-2 to the Carolina Hurricanes in overtime.
This sends their Eastern Conference quarterfinal series back to New Jersey for Game 5 on Friday night with the Devils leading by three games to one.
And they lost Scott Niedermayer, one of their best defensemen, with what the team called a bruised right knee early in the third period.
Niedermayer, who works on the power-play and penalty-killing teams as well as at even strength, underwent arthroscopic surgery on that knee in February.
He hurt it again tonight when he was bumped by Craig Adams of Carolina high in the Hurricanes' zone after Niedermayer had taken a shot.
The Devils said it was not a serious injury, although Niedermayer did not stay around the dressing room very long to elaborate.
SUMMER'S almost over, and I keep looking for celebrities on Main Street in Westhampton Beach, but they never come.
Well, that's what happens when you're on the wrong side of the tracks -- or, in this case, the canal -- in one America's most famous resort areas.
Welcome to Wronghampton.
I haven't always spent summers here.

For many years, I shared East Hampton rentals with friends, paying dearly and happily for the privilege of running into Paul McCartney at the market, Gwyneth Paltrow at the organic restaurant and Steven Spielberg in front of the overpriced fancy-food store.
After a while, though, it didn't seem so special anymore.
Maybe it was one too many dysfunctional functions I attended, or, worse, was not invited to attend.
Maybe it was one too many petite women lurching at me in S.U.V.'s as I biked past their driveways to get the paper in the mornings.
Or maybe it was just the fact that I had become exhausted from constantly measuring myself against people who are richer and thinner than I will ever be.

For whatever reason, a simpler if slightly less gorgeous life beckoned in Westhampton, where some lovely, very well-situated cottages were renting for prices that would have been available next to the dump in the East Hampton area. ''

Within the next few weeks, Barbara Principe, a 73-year-old South Jersey woman who still lives near the chicken farm where she grew up, will begin receiving payments from millions of dollars in real estate in the former East Berlin.
The land was lost to her family 67 years ago.

It was then, when Ms. Principe was 6, that she and her brother were rushed out of Berlin in the dead of night by their mother and their father, a partner in the family-owned department store chain, A. Wertheim, a leading high-end retailer.

At that time, Hitler's ''aryanization'' of businesses in Germany was forcing Jews to turn their companies over to non-Jews, and the threat of concentration camps and death hung over all Jews who remained in the country.

Last month, Germany's restitution court, set up after World War II to provide restitution for property seized during the Nazi regime, validated the claim of the Wertheim heirs, Ms. Principe and about 24 others, to a number of properties owned by her father's department store chain.
Those properties are now valued at about $350 million, making her family's restitution award one of the largest since the Holocaust.
A. Wertheim bought the properties in the 1920's and 30's largely in an attempt to block competitors from acquiring sites near its flagship store, near Leipziger Platz in central Berlin.
One of the parcels became the site of Hitler's Reich Chancellery and the bunker where he took his own life.

The tracts now sit in the midst of a bustling commercial area in the shadow of the modern glass and steel corporate offices of Sony, A T & T and DaimlerChrysler, and the Canadian Embassy and the German Finance Ministry.
Because the sites were all in East Berlin, restitution became possible only after the reunification of the country in 1990. ''
Fourteen Mets games on SportsChannel will be blacked out by Time Warner's New York City cable systems starting tonight if a payment dispute is not resolved.
SportsChannel added 25 Mets games to its original schedule of 75 this season, but it could not negotiate a deal with Time Warner to pay for the extra telecasts.
Time Warner has shown 11 of the 25 additional games, leaving 14 that may not be available for 1.1 million local cable subscribers.
After several months of negotiations, Time Warner said yesterday that it will not pay the $3.4 million being asked by SportsChannel to carry the extra 25 games. ''
We thought we were on the right track, but today they called up and said, 'Go ahead, we won't pay,' '' said Mike Bair, executive vice president of Rainbow Media Holdings, which runs SportsChannel.
He called the extra fees ''competitive, and not out of line.''
He said SportsChannel ''wants to make the most games available, but we have to be fair to our other distributors, who have all paid for the games.''
But Barry Rosenblum, president of the city's Time Warner systems, said he would not accede to ''outrageous'' demands that would be an ''unfair burden to all our subscribers.''
He added, ''We want a reasonable contract.''
Besides tonight's game against the Colorado Rockies, games on Sunday, Tuesday and Wednesday are among those that might be blacked out.
Their trains and their buses were not running.
Their flights were canceled.
Their cars were moving a couple of blocks an hour.
They were trapped in elevators.
Even hotels would not take them.
They were stuck, all stuck.
They spilled into the streets, fleeing office buildings and sweltering subway stations, swimming around cars and buses like ants at a feast.
They had no idea how they would ever get home.
So they trudged.
They flagged down cars.

The Iraqi Government is blocking attempts by international relief organizations to distribute food and medicine directly to hundreds of thousands of Iraqis suffering from poor health and malnutrition in the aftermath of a war and a trade embargo, relief officials and Iraqi authorities say.
Iraq's Minister of Health, Abdul Salam M. Saaid, said in an interview he would not allow food distribution by relief agencies except through the Government's distribution and rationing system.
He accused the relief agencies of food distribution "gimmicks" that he said were "designed to keep quiet the good people in the United States who don't like to see others suffer."

The minister indicated that if the people of Europe and the United States saw a vast and direct food distribution effort under way in Iraq, it would quiet their consciences and "shut up" their opposition to continuing United Nations sanctions.
These, he said, are the ultimate cause of suffering in Iraq.
Mr. Saaid's remarks, made in an interview this week, reflect how much the struggle to provide emergency care to Iraq's 18 million people has become politicized in the wake of the Persian Gulf war.

The United States and its allies are seeking to maintain tight economic sanctions until the Government of President Saddam Hussein fully complies with all of the terms of the cease-fire resolution that ended formal hostilities last winter.

Food Stays in Warehouses As a consequence of the Iraqi Government's policy against third-party food distribution, food worth about $4 million, including infant formula and high-protein food packages specially prepared for children under 5, has been sitting in warehouses in Baghdad and Jordan for weeks, relief officials said.

Most of the food belongs to the United Nations Children's Fund, which in August proposed the idea of setting up special nutrition centers across the country to help about 340,000 Iraqi children who are believed to be most vulnerable to dying of malnutrition or infectious disease.
The Government rationing system provides only one-quarter of what is generally acknowledged to be an infant's requirement of powdered infant formula.

To the Editor: Kiren A. Chaudhry ("In Pakistan, A Candidate Flees," Op-Ed, Oct. 26), as a dutiful and loving daughter, has given only her father's version of events in Shakargarh, a remote region in Pakistan's Punjab province.
Her account is as objective as might be one by Amy Marcos about her father, Ferdinand E. Marcos.

Ms. Chaudhry tries to play on the Western sentiment against Islamic fundamentalism when she writes: "During the campaign, the President of the Islamic Democratic Alliance, Nawaz Sharif, publicly targeted my father as part of his 'holy war' against secular forces in Pakistan."

She omits to mention that Anwar Aziz Chaudhry was elected to Parliament in 1988 as a member of the Islamic Democratic Alliance and was among a handful of members who switched over to Benazir Bhutto's secular Pakistan People's Party under allegations of seeking personal benefit.
Mr. Chaudhry's politics are local and have little to do with Islamic or secular ideology.
Mr. Chaudhry has in the past been charged with using strong-arm tactics in his district.
His political position is used to accuse the administration of persecution each time he is charged with a criminal offense.
This time, Mr. Chaudhry and his supporters are charged with the murder of his opponent candidate, Idris Taj.
On Monday, Oct. 22, supporters of the two candidates exchanged gunfire, in which five supporters of Mr. Chaudhry and one of Mr. Taj were killed.
The police were immediately approached, and they duly registered the case and started an investigation.
The city budget remains unresolved, with less than two weeks before the next fiscal year begins.
Tensions with the City Council are running high.
And yesterday Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took some time out for a little midweek golf in Westchester County.

Back at City Hall, some saw the mayor's escape to the links as evidence of his almost stubbornly nonpolitical side: he has a staff to work out the details of the budget, he can be reached by cellphone, and who cares about appearances?
Others saw it as evidence of Mr. Bloomberg's political tin ear: the mayor bogeys while the budget waits.
And given that Mr. Bloomberg played in the same tournament during last year's budget wars, others suggested it was simply, excuse the expression, par for the course.
In the past, city budget negotiations have often been likened to a highly ritualized, choreographed dance.
But this year's negotiations have been more like another kind of dance: a high school sort of the ''she didn't call me first so I won't call her'' variety.
For days, City Council officials have complained that the mayor's team would not meet with them.

The mayor's side, for its part, counters that it has been unable to meet with the City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, charging that he is more interested in news conferences and photo opportunities than in negotiating the budget.
Rachmaninoff's Third Piano Concerto was one of Vladimir Horowitz's specialties.
In fact Rachmaninoff himself, not overly generous with praise, thought the pianist played it better than he did, which would have been no mean feat.
So it is perhaps no accident that the young Russian-born pianist Yevgeny Kissin has turned his attention to this work.
Mr. Kissin has been compared again and again to his countryman, by virtue of his dazzling technique and a temperament that is imposing in one so young (he is 21).

On Wednesday night he played the concerto with Seiji Ozawa and the Boston Symphony in Carnegie Hall; last week, the collaborators recorded the work for future release by BMG Classics (which has also, coincidentally, re-released Rachmaninoff's own recording in an invaluable set of the composer's piano recordings).

The only problem was that while Mr. Kissin could easily handle the exceptional difficulties of this showpiece -- scampering chord clusters, knotty cross rhythms, breakneck runs -- on this occasion he did not meet the composition's demands for another sort of virtuosity.
He impressed but he did not engage: a crippling problem in music that is meant to display personality, fantasy and longing.
There was plenty to beguile the ears: a nuanced, lyrical opening, passage work that seemed like digital prestidigitation, a love for climax and exclamation that never eclipsed pianissimo moments.
But the Steinway tone tended to be brittle, lacking warmth or penetrating power.
There was little imagination displayed in the long passages of figuration.
In general a defender hopes that the declarer will err in his play of the hand.

But he may, in rare situations, end up regretting the error: If it opens up the opportunity for a brilliant defensive stroke, and it is missed, the other defender may start screaming in the post-mortem.
