Few parts of President Clinton's health plan sound so simple as the idea of charging the same insurance premiums to all people in a geographic area, whether they are young or old, sick or healthy.
The goal is to return health insurance to "what it was meant to be: a fair deal at a fair price," Mr. Clinton said last week.
But in health insurance, nothing is simple.

While many Republicans agree that the Government should limit the variation in premiums, the idea of such "community rating" raises a host of political, philosophical and technical questions, like these: *How much will rates go up for young, healthy people, whose premiums are now below the average?
Are these people prepared to pay higher premiums in return for greater security? *
Is it fair to raise premiums for young people while lowering premiums for their parents, who often have higher incomes and greater assets? *
Is it right to charge the same premiums to smokers and nonsmokers?
Should insurers be allowed to give a discount to people who take responsibility for their health, watch their diet and exercise regularly? *
How should the Federal Government and the states divide responsibility for regulating the price of health insurance, a field long dominated by state officials?
Spreading the Risk The move toward community rating is a reaction to the experience of the last decade, in which health insurance became prohibitively expensive for many people.
The White House said today that President Clinton may travel to North Korea later this year, in what would be the first visit by an American president to the Communist country.
The presidential trip, still tentative, would follow a visit by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who plans to visit Pyongyang by the end of the month, officials said.
The announcement came as Gen. Jo Myong Rok, first vice chairman of North Korea's National Defense Commission, wound up talks in Washington with Mr. Clinton and his top national security aides.
Developments were few but the very fact of the meeting signaled the changing relations between the United States and North Korea.
During Mr. Clinton's first term, he ordered military reinforcements to South Korea after North Korean leaders refused to allow international inspectors access to its main nuclear weapons complex.
The North eventually agreed to freeze its nuclear program.
At a news briefing today, Dr. Albright described differences between North Korea and the United States as ''extensive and of long standing'' and noted that ''they will not be erased overnight.''
But she said recent talks had led to ''a very substantial step away from the frozen and distant relations of the past.''

In recent months, the Clinton administration has lifted a broad set of economic sanctions against North Korea that had been in place since it invaded the South 50 years ago, setting off the Korean War.
In a joint statement released today upon General Jo's departure, the two countries signaled their desire for a new direction. ''
The Senate's promising start in reforming its ethical shortcomings is showing signs of slippage.
Senators ducked a worthy amendment that would bar members from putting family members on campaign payrolls, or see kin become lobbyists.
The proposal was ruled unrelated to the debate over lobbyist and ethics reforms, which is hardly the case.
Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, insisted that there's no such problem in the Senate.
Critics instantly noted that her fellow Californian, Senator Barbara Boxer, paid $130,000 from her campaign funds to her son's political consultant firm.
In the House, the campaign kitty of Representative John Doolittle, Republican of California, paid $200,000 to his wife as a designated campaign consultant working at home.
Congress's reputation cannot afford more such embarrassments.
As the Senate debate continues, there are key proposals that will test how real all the talk is about reform.
Some lawmakers are already trying to water down the proposal of the majority leader, Harry Reid, which would stop senators from accepting the nearly free use of corporate jets.

Opponents on both sides of the aisle are also intent on blocking a measure from Senators Barack Obama and Russell Feingold, which would force lobbyists to disclose the vast campaign funds they routinely raise from corporate donors eager to grease access to lawmakers.
These are heady days for the former guerrilla who runs Uganda.
He moves with the measured gait and sure gestures of a leader secure in his power and in his vision.
It is little wonder.

To hear some diplomats and African experts tell it, President Yoweri K. Museveni has started an ideological movement that is reshaping much of Africa, spelling the end of the corrupt, strong-man governments that characterized the cold-war era.
These days, political pundits across the continent are calling Mr. Museveni an African Bismarck.
Some people now refer to him as Africa's ''other statesman,'' second only to the venerated South African President, Nelson Mandela.

Not only has Mr. Museveni resurrected his own impoverished nation from two decades of brutal dictatorship and near economic collapse, but he is also widely seen as the covert patron of rebel movements like the one that has just toppled Mobutu Sese Seko, the longtime dictator of Zaire. ''
It appears Museveni is the regional power broker who has emerged as a result of all this,'' said one diplomat in the region, speaking on the condition of anonymity. ''
He seems to be relishing his role.''
In a recent interview, Mr. Museveni shrugged off this characterization with a smile.
THE Bush Administration is proposing to simplify one of the most vexing tax regulations faced by small businesses.
But the effort has come under an unforeseen barrage of criticism from small business advocates in industry, in Congress, and within the Administration itself.
At issue is the notoriously complex regulation that governs how frequently companies must give the Government the money they withhold from wages.
The rule is so hard for the average business to cope with that the General Accounting Office estimates one-third of all businesses in the nation fail to comply with it in any given year.
Virtually everybody agrees that the current system for making payroll tax deposits is in need of reform.
As part of his regulatory overhaul started earlier this year, President Bush has pledged to revise or abolish regulations that are unduly burdensome on businesses, and this one was high on his list.

In May, Mr. Bush announced at a Small Business Administration awards ceremony in the White House Rose Garden that the Internal Revenue Service's proposed revision of the payroll deposit regulations would provide "faster, cheaper and simpler ways for businesses, large and small, to deal with the payroll tax system."

The basic idea was to let many small businesses make tax deposits on a monthly basis, rather than forcing them to make complicated calculations of how often the deposits are required -- sometimes semiweekly or even more frequently.
But it now turns out that the Small Business Administration opposes the proposals from the I.R.S., calling them unnecessarily complicated. "

While we strongly support simplification, we do not support the proposed regulations," said Thomas P. Kerester, the small business agency's chief counsel for advocacy, in a July 20 letter to the I.R.S. As written, he said, the regulations would "have a detrimental effect on small businesses."

A federal appeals court on Friday overturned a clean-air regulation issued by the Bush administration that would have let many power plants, refineries and factories avoid installing costly new pollution controls to help offset any increased emissions caused by repairs and replacements of equipment.

Ruling in favor of a coalition of states and environmental advocacy groups, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit said the ''plain language'' of the law required a stricter approach.
The court has primary jurisdiction in challenges to federal regulations.

The ruling by a three-judge panel was the court's second decision in less than a year in a pair of closely related cases involving the administration's interpretations of a complex section of the Clean Air Act.

Unlike its ruling last summer, when the court largely upheld the E.P.A.'s approach against challenges from industry, state governments and environmental groups, the new ruling was a defeat for the agency and for industry, and a victory for the states and their environmentalist allies.

In the earlier case, a panel including two of the three judges who ruled on Friday decided that the agency had acted reasonably in 2002, when it issued a rule changing how pollution would be measured, effectively loosening the strictures on companies making changes to their equipment and operations.

But on Friday, the court said the agency went too far in 2003 when it issued a separate new rule that opponents said would exempt most equipment changes from environmental reviews -- even changes that would result in higher emissions.
With a wry footnote to Lewis Carroll's ''Through the Looking Glass,'' the court said that ''only in a Humpty-Dumpty world'' could the law be read otherwise. ''
We decline such a world view,'' said their unanimous decision, written by Judge Judith W. Rogers, an appointee of President Bill Clinton.
Judges David Tatel, another Clinton appointee, and Janice Rogers Brown, a recent Bush appointee, joined her.

In a sharp denunciation of Arab claims to three disputed islands in the Persian Gulf, Iran's President reasserted Iranian sovereignty by warning neighbors on Friday that they will have to "cross a sea of blood" to reach the islands, the state-run press reported today.
The Gulf Arabs "must not repeat the mistakes of Saddam, who tried to make Kuwait a province of Iraq," President Hashemi Rafsanjani told an audience attending Friday Prayers at Teheran University.
He said that Iran was "much stronger" than its neighbors.
Today his comments were bolstered by the Supreme National Security Council, Reuters reported.

In a radio broadcast the council recalled the eight-year war with Iraq, which, it said, "proved to the world that our brave nation will never hesitate to defend the sovereignty and safeguard the territorial integrity of Iran.
Abu Musa, Greater Tunb and Lesser Tunb, which have been under the joint control of Iran and the United Arab Emirates since 1971, lie in the middle of vital shipping lanes.
In April, Iran began to expel certain citizens of the Emirates from Abu Musa, citing security reasons.
In August, 100 foreign workers on a United Arab Emirates ship were kept from the island because they did not have Iranian identity cards.

The dispute has heightened at a time of renewed diplomatic isolation for Teheran: According to analysts, Iran's growing assertiveness to establish its dominance in the Islamic world -- backing radical fundamentalist groups in the region and buying sensitive Western technology to rebuild its military -- has scared would-be allies.
In response to United States warnings about Teheran's weapons buildup, Japan and some Western governments this month implemented stricter export controls of high technology to Iran.
To the Editor: After reading your news article on the risks associated with the drug ritrodrine, used to prevent premature births (front page, July 30), I was left with a flood of emotions.
I am among the lucky.

My only cross to bear for having been born to a mother who took the drug DES in the 1950's to prevent miscarriage was to remain on strict bed rest for the last six months of my two pregnancies, to have two sutures surgically placed around my cervix and to take ritodrine.
At the end, with much praying, I had two glorious children.
The scars of others run deeper: malformed reproductive organs, multiple miscarriages, premature births, vaginal cancers and the curse of sterility.
And yet, lucky or unlucky, the feelings of having been indelibly damaged by a drug whose effectiveness was ultimately found to be nil persist in all of us who were exposed.
Given my history and knowing I took ritodrine while pregnant, imagine my terror as I read your report.
The word ritodrine popped out, my pulse began to race, and I began to shake, not knowing what fate awaited me.
Was it to happen to me again -- a "double dose," as my physician husband called it?
What would it be this time -- my health, my children's, some other hidden time bomb?
When President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa said last year that AZT was too dangerous to give to H.I.V.-infected pregnant women, AIDS researchers and activists were taken aback.

The drug is commonly used to prevent transmission of the disease to newborns, and many of the people who advocate its use said thousands of lives would be lost in a country where the epidemic is burning at white heat.

That reaction turned to shock when Mr. Mbeki appointed an AIDS advisory panel that included researchers who have postulated that H.I.V. does not cause the disease, a position long rejected by the overwhelming majority of scientists.
Now Mr. Mbeki is embarking on his first state visit to the United States since succeeding Nelson Mandela as president last year, and activists and those who treat AIDS are wondering how to greet him.
Most seem to have decided that the best offense is to give no offense, an approach that they say is being counseled by the Clinton administration. ''
The suggestion has been not to press him hard,'' said Martin Delaney, founding director of San Francisco-based Project Inform, a treatment information and advocacy group. ''
The fear here is that he'll dig in worse if he gets pressured.''
Some activists are preparing a statement to be signed by prominent scientists worldwide reaffirming their view that H.I.V., or human immunodeficiency virus, causes AIDS.
Others are planning to try to speak to Mr. Mbeki when he appears in San Francisco on Wednesday, two days after meeting President Clinton at the White House. ''
We're all struggling with how best to make a difference,'' said Jane Silver, vice president for public policy at the American Foundation for AIDS Research in Washington. ''
Talk about a turnaround.

Bond fund investors who were burned last year -- and that includes just about everyone who owned a bond fund -- might be astounded to learn that no taxable bond funds lost money in this year's second quarter.
And near the top of the list of stars are some Latin American specialists that were whacked only a few quarters ago.
The best performers over the first six months, meanwhile, have been the Benham Target funds that bet on zero-coupon Treasury bonds with the longest possible maturities.
Those bonds are among the most volatile available, but, as this year's numbers demonstrate, they do extraordinarily well during bond market rallies.
Municipal funds turned in the weakest performance among the four major bond and equity categories.
Fallout from the Orange County debacle and concerns about the flat-tax proposal, which would endanger the tax-free attractions of the bonds, have put a damper on the muni market.
Bond fund investors should not be lulled by the fact that every bond fund tracked by Morningstar Inc. has posted a positive return the last five years.
When inflation is taken into account, those on the losers lists look worse.
EDWARD WYATT  MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT
IT is Phil Griffin's habit to surprise Kory Apton on her birthday, Jan. 31.

When she turned 30, for instance, he left a plane ticket to the Virgin Islands and a book about scuba diving on her bed, with instructions to catch the plane, read the book and meet him at the airport in St. Thomas.
This year on Jan. 31, Ms. Apton's 33d birthday, he organized an even bigger surprise -- a wedding.
While most brides spend months, sometimes years, planning the big day, she did not even know about hers.
At about 7 that evening, 50 guests, invited by telephone by Mr. Griffin and instructed to keep the wedding a secret, gathered in Joe's Fish Shack on Columbus Avenue and 85th Street.
The restaurant is decorated with driftwood, conch shells, starfish, anchors, seaweed and other things that look as if they washed up on the sand in the Caribbean. ''
Kory has always said she wanted to get married in a bikini on the beach,'' said Mr. Griffin, 40, who is the executive producer of ''Internight,'' a talk program on MSNBC. ''
So I wanted to do a beach party on the Upper West Side.''
At 7:30 the couple arrived.
Ms. Apton, a freelance television producer, thought they were just stopping in for some seafood.
David J. O'Reilly, those who know him contend, is an exceedingly nice man.
Considerate, they say, down to earth, a good listener.
He is also chairman of Chevron, which last week agreed to take over Texaco to create the world's fifth-largest oil company.
Is a nice guy up to the task?
Shareholders and experts credit Mr. O'Reilly's charm and powers of persuasion for sealing the deal.

But now, as Mr. O'Reilly, 53, takes the helm at the combined concern, to be called Chevron Texaco, some ask if an affable, relatively young executive who introduces himself as Dave can forge a corporation lean and mean enough to thrive.
Much of the concern stems from Mr. O'Reilly's short track record, since he became Chevron's chairman only in January.

Yet the merger has vaulted him into the ranks of oil chiefs like Sir John Browne of BP, Lee Raymond of Exxon Mobil and Thierry Desmarest of Totalfina Elf, men whose flair for taking risks harks back to the bold oil magnates of a century ago.
Some experts question if Mr. O'Reilly fits the bill.
Oil companies must become bigger and offer better earnings to attract investors enamored of the new economy. ''
There is not a catchy name for the heavyweight bout between Shannon Briggs and Francois Botha.
But the promoter Frank Warren came up with an apt description of the bout. ''
It's two guys who nearly did it in their last fights,'' Warren said.
Both Briggs and Botha were leading in their respective fights, but became fifth-round knockout victims.
Briggs was stopped by Lennox Lewis in a World Boxing Council title bout on March 28, 1998.
Botha was caught by a devastating right from Mike Tyson on Jan. 16.
But yesterday, the ''two guys'' got together for a news conference at the Trump Tower in Manhattan to announce their fight, which will be held at Trump's Taj Mahal in Atlantic City on Aug. 7. ''
It's now or never for me,'' said Briggs (31-2). ''
I feel like this is a new beginning for me.''
First, he will have to get past Botha (39-2), the former International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, whose only losses have been to Tyson and Michael Moorer.
To the Editor: Re ''Contracts So Complex They Imperil the System'' (Feb. 24), which discussed how derivative contracts helped conceal Enron's problems.
Many suggest similarities between the Enron collapse and the failures of Drexel Burnham Lambert in 1990 and Barings in 1995.
But Enron, unlike the traditional commodity markets, operated without a clearinghouse.
As a result, it became the guarantor on a huge number of its electricity, oil and gas contracts, spot and derivative.
Other markets long ago developed clearinghouses to settle trades and manage the resulting open positions in derivative contracts.
These clearinghouses keep problems from building by marking positions to the  market at least once a day and collecting losses promptly.
If a firm gets into trouble, as with Drexel and Barings, the clearinghouse prevents spread of risk.
The tried-and-true procedures of traditional marketplaces and of clearing and settlement organizations have enhanced the markets' safety and soundness for over 75 years.
An important lesson will be learned if future financial innovators keep these principles in mind.
DENNIS A. DUTTERER  Chicago, Feb. 28 The writer is the chief executive of the Board of Trade Clearing Corporation, a clearing organization for futures and options contracts.

Robert A. DuPuy, Major League Baseball's chief legal officer, told a Senate panel in Washington yesterday that the Florida Marlins and the Tampa Bay Devil Rays were among the teams considered for contraction.
DuPuy said about 18 of the 30 teams had been on a tentative list of teams that might be folded.
The Montreal Expos and the Minnesota Twins have been considered the most likely to be dropped. ''
There were a number of teams that were contraction candidates, including teams from the state of Florida,'' DuPuy said.

The hearing, which lasted nearly three hours, was convened to consider a bill that would strip baseball's antitrust exemption as it relates to decisions on the elimination or relocation of major league teams.
The legislation was introduced in November after the league owners said they intended to reduce the number of teams for the 2002 season.
Commissioner Bud Selig, who did not attend yesterday's hearing, has since abandoned the plan, but has stated his intention to cut at least two teams and as many as four for the 2003 season.
Bob Butterworth, the attorney general of Florida, called for firm and decisive action from Congress on the matter.
A similar session was held in December by the House Judiciary Committee, which is also considering legislation to restrict the antitrust exemption.
The committee was scheduled to vote on the measure this morning, but its sponsor, Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, requested more time to rally support.

Walt Harris, a football coach who talks as if he is five minutes late for his next appointment, actually gave himself some time to listen to sports-talk shows and pore over the newspapers in the off-season.
He was soon incredulous.
Just about all the doomsayers -- his word -- were either hollering or intimating that his Pittsburgh football program was doomed.
Miami and Virginia Tech were leaving the Big East Conference for the Atlantic Coast Conference, and that would be it for Pitt.
Harris had already heard what coaches who hunch on the other side of the recruiting line of scrimmage were saying.
Six years of Harris's hard work, they suggested, would be a big waste at a program with an uncertain future.

They acknowledge that Pittsburgh has a cherished football history, and it shares a handsome practice facility and a gorgeous stadium with the Steelers, but what good would those things do without a guaranteed Bowl Championship Series berth? ''
I was amazed -- amazed -- how much negativity there was,'' Harris said, as he sat in his office. ''
I kept hearing about how all of this was going to blow up.''
Harris still has his ear cocked for the detonation, but he has heard no big bang.
AS THE Rev. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr. finishes his fiery address at William Paterson College in Wayne, N.J., he readies himself for the inevitable Farrakhan question.
A middle-aged white man leans into a microphone set up for the audience.
Does he, Chavis, refute the anti-Semitism of the Nation of Islam minister?

Doesn't Chavis think it unusual that he, the leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the nation's oldest and largest civil rights organization, would invite Farrakhan to a conference of national black leaders?
Chavis (pronounced CHAY-vis) moves stiffly away from the podium, his arms folded across his chest.

He reminds the questioner that in a speech at the Smithsonian Institution in January -- just weeks after a senior Farrakhan aide had delivered a hate-filled speech at Kean College in Union, N.J. -- he had denounced anti-Semitism as a "hideous form of racial hatred and bigotry."
The N.A.A.C.P., Chavis continues, does not condone bigotry of any kind.
Then, with his right arm slashing the air, he asserts, "The N.A.A.C.P. will not be dictated to."
The blacks in the auditorium, most of whom are middle-aged and middle-class, pepper their applause with shouts of "Amen."
Earlier that evening, as we drove from Newark Airport to the college, Chavis had predicted just such a response.

As world education ministers gather in Senegal today to discuss how they have fallen far short of their targets in poor nations, the World Bank plans to announce a broad new commitment to schooling and literacy programs.

James D. Wolfensohn, the World Bank president, will announce in a speech Thursday at the World Education Forum in Dakar, the Senegalese capital, that the bank is prepared to lend ''multiples'' of the $2 billion it now devotes to education programs each year, bank officials said today.

The resources will focus on poor nations that produce a comprehensive blueprint for enrolling more children in school, for eliminating illiteracy and for ensuring that girls have equal access to education.
The initiative will be the bank's second sweeping commitment in two weeks to fighting poverty at the grass-roots level.
Last week finance ministers endorsed a World Bank plan to spend much more to fight AIDS in developing countries.
The bank has pledged to shift resources it once devoted to large-scale projects like dams and highways to programs that directly help poor people.
In total, it makes about $30 billion in loans each year.
The commitments have come at a time of unusual public pressure on the bank and the International Monetary Fund, its sister lending agency, to do more to alleviate poverty and protect the environment.
Protesters declaring that these lenders often do more harm than good tried to shut down the spring meetings of the institutions in Washington this month.
Bank and fund officials say they are wary of a backlash against globalization that could undermine their political support in the richer countries that provide their money.
IT was a race with stakes as high as they get in the beleaguered biotechnology industry.
The clue was there to find an elusive blood-cell hormone, and the prize for the company that got it first could be a patent for a billion-dollar-a-year drug.
The many losers would get nothing.
And the trick to finding the hormone would be to use methods that had never before succeeded in molecular biology.
Last week, the race seemed to be neck and neck.

Teams for two biotechnology companies, reporting separately in the British science journal Nature, described how they had managed to isolate the hormone, thrombopoietin, which sets off the production of blood-clotting cells.

It is not yet clear which of the companies, Genentech of South San Francisco or the ZymoGenetics Corporation of Seattle, will get the patent, or whether it will go to one of several other companies rumored to have found the hormone.
The drug could help rejuvenate an industry that has disappointed investors with its failure to come up with the expected array of blockbuster drugs.
Rebecca Eisenberg, a law professor at the University of Michigan, notes that the United States Patent Office will have to determine who was the first to invent the method of producing the hormone.
That means deciding which company was the first to conceive of the idea and also which was the first actually to produce the hormone.
One of the first babies born since the eruption of Mount Nyiragongo last week was named Volcano by a woman who was still in search of two of her other boys.
Men with sledgehammers helped build a road across the mound of lava dividing the town.
In these and other ways, life began returning to normal in Goma today as residents lined up by the thousands for the first food and water that many had received in days.
But normal is a relative term for Goma's people, who have lived through a long string of miseries in recent years.
Through dictatorship and disease, rebels and Mother Nature, the people have endured.
Nowdays the town is controlled by the Rally for Congolese Democracy, whose mission to overthrow Joseph Kabila, the new president, has been dramatically upstaged by Mount Nyiragongo's eruption. ''
Not everybody supports us,'' acknowledged a rebel commander who identified himself only as Frank. ''
If people are starving, they don't want us.
If they're O.K., they do.''
The eruption and its aftermath have indeed left people desperate and near-starving, which may explain why the rebels have been eager to coordinate the relief effort since the eruption last Thursday.

ON May Day, the historic workers' holiday, the European Union will expand to 25 countries, bringing increased competition that forces economic liberalization in the comfortable countries of old Europe.
Or so they say.
Forecasts of structural change in Europe have been plentiful -- and wrong.
The changes that economists support are a hard sell to voters even in good times, and petrify many of them when unemployment is high.
A decade ago, as Europe prepared for monetary unification, it was widely predicted that that step would be the incentive for change.
The common currency would mean that a country could not just devalue its way to competitiveness.
Instead, it would have to attack structural issues, knowing that inaction would risk leaving a country behind.
Action would mean freeing the labor market to let companies become more competitive.
And it would mean doing something to bring down high tax rates and deal with soaring costs of public pension plans.
Governments tried.

When Adrian Wojnarowski started following the basketball team at St. Anthony High School in Jersey City in the fall of 2003, it wasn't a sure thing that the school, let alone the team, would survive for another year.

Severe debt had saddled St. Anthony, and each year since 1991, the school has had to raise at least $500,000 on its own to keep up operations because its parish has declared it an independent school that it will no longer finance.
Yet every year, Bob Hurley returns to St. Anthony for a few thousand dollars, and coaches boys out of poverty and into the spotlight.

Mr. Wojnarowski's new book, ''The Miracle of St. Anthony'' (Gotham), chronicles a couple dozen of Mr. Hurley's on-court victories but, more important, some of the many off-court victories he has had with students and athletes at the inner-city school.

While the St. Anthony team won the New Jersey state championship the year Mr. Wojnarowski, a sportswriter for The Record in Hackensack, followed it, the story he wishes to impart is less basketball than real life.
The book plows much of the ground broken by ''Hoop Dreams'' and ''Friday Night Lights,'' but Mr. Wojnarowski handles the material deftly.
Mr. Hurley's 800-plus basketball victories, the five first-round N.B.A. picks he has coached and the eight state championships he has won are important facets of the book.
It probably would not have been written if Mr. Hurley were a good person and a mediocre coach.
So it is all the more inspiring to see Mr. Hurley also goad his players to academic and social success.
That Mr. Hurley himself has stayed put in Jersey City is also instructive.

Kansas City Southern Industries said yesterday that it was considering selling its railroad, the nation's 12th largest, a move that would enable the company to focus more on mutual funds and other financial services.
The company also said it would increase its ownership of Berger Associates, a Denver-based mutual fund manager, to more than 80 percent from its current stake of about 18 percent. "
This transaction represents a fur ther expansion of our commitment to the financial services industry," said Landon Rowland, chief executive of Kansas City Southern.
Although the railroad industry has made steady gains in profitability in recent years, analysts said it apparently lacked the potential that Kansas City saw in the mutual fund business.
The Kansas City, Mo., company bought an 81 percent stake in the Janus Capital Corporation, a mutual fund company, in 1984 for $16 million as part of an effort to diversify.
That stake in Janus, which manages $22 billion through 13 funds, accounted for $39 million, or more than 40 percent, of Kansas City Southern's earnings last year.

If Kansas City finds a buyer for its railroad business, industry analysts said the sale, which might fetch $1.4 billion to $1.5 billion, would probably be the last large merger in an industry that started consolidating rapidly in the 1980's following deregulation. "
The number of railroads left that can be digested in bite-size pieces is dwindling," said Scott Flower, a railroad analyst at Kidder, Peabody. "
Folks are looking long and hard as to whether this snack makes sense for them."
Industry experts suggested that the most likely suitors for Kansas City Southern would be Burlington Northern, Santa Fe Pacific and Canadian Pacific.

New York City's foster-care system often fails to provide abused or troubled children with services required under state and local laws, according to a two-year audit by the State Comptroller released today.

After what officials described as an extensive review of city records for 80 foster children, the auditors found widespread evidence of poor record keeping, inadequate monitoring of foster children and their caretakers, slow placement of children up for adoption and slipshod handling of accusations of abuse involving children in foster care.

No Follow-Up In one such case, the auditors found that city child welfare officials became suspicious that a foster mother was using drugs in December 1990, but failed to report those concerns for six months.
The child was later placed in another foster home.
A subsequent psychological examination of the same child found evidence of sexual abuse.
But the auditors could find no evidence that the city did a follow-up investigation to determine whether abuse had occured.
The 80 cases reviewed by the auditors were chosen randomly from the 31,686 children who were in the city's foster care system as of May 31, 1992.
Though the sample was relatively small, the Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, said there was sufficient evidence to believe that the system suffered broad-based problems. "
Thousands of New York City children are not receiving their legal entitlements," Mr. McCall said. "
They are the innocent victims of an overburdened and ineffective billion-dollar bureaucratic system."
IT is all about relativity in the National Football League, a week-to-week proposition, the ongoing search for someone in a more vulnerable position than yourself.
All things considered yesterday, Danny Kanell could have been Ryan Leaf.
He could have been faced with the burden of grand, second-pick-of-the-draft expectations, along with a persistent pass rush in front of opportunistic defensive backs.
He could have set himself up for ridicule the previous week by publicly conducting himself like a jerk.
He could have thrown four interceptions and wound up being benched for someone named Craig Whelihan, a development that drew a convulsive roar from the home-team crowd.
Kanell, conversely, had one of those games when he plays well enough, shows just enough, to make people believe the Giants can dream on with him as the starter.

Relative to Leaf, Kanell was the epitome of poise and experience as the Giants defeated the San Diego Chargers, 34-16, at Qualcomm Stadium by utilizing their, in Kanell's words, ''formula for success.''

Just six days after doomsday at home versus Dallas, a turnover-inducing defense plus 313 yards of adequate, balanced offense equaled a 2-2 record and a share of first place in the extremely forgiving N.F.C. East.
As we said, this is week-to-week, particularly in the case of a Giants offense that features Kanell.
It is going to be a while, if ever, before he isn't considered as good as his last series of downs.

Vertex Pharmaceuticals Inc. announced yesterday that it would acquire the Aurora Biosciences Corporation for about $592 million in stock, combining two biotechnology companies with expertise in different aspects of developing drugs.
The deal could presage additional biotechnology mergers, analysts said, as stock prices have sunk and it has become difficult for companies to raise money by selling shares.
In addition, many biotechnology companies specialize in one technology out of many needed to develop drugs, making it hard to build a business without merging.
Companies might seek to merge to take advantage of the potential gold mine of information made available by the sequencing of the human genetic code -- one factor behind yesterday's deal. ''
We are going to seize as much of this ground as we can,'' Joshua Boger, chairman and chief executive of Vertex, said in an interview. ''
This is not something we can come back to in 20 years.
The fun will all be over.''
Aurora shareholders will get 0.62 share of newly issued Vertex stock for each Aurora share held.
Based on Friday's closing price, that would mean a price of $24.34 per Aurora share, a 44 percent premium.
Yesterday, Aurora's shares shot up $6.35, or nearly 38 percent, to $23.20.
From the elevated expressways that lace this city, Miami seems all glitter.

But below the main ramp that leads downtown lies a shadowy shantytown, swirling with smoke and mosquitoes, where people like Andrew Johnson struggle to live in a city that has long refused to care adequately for its homeless. "
We're just trying to survive," said Mr. Johnson, who calls himself A.J. and has initialled gold caps on his front teeth to prove it.
He said he got the teeth when times were good and when, as a Coast Guard veteran and long-haul truck driver, he was doing all right.
Now the slim 45-year-old man lives in an eight-square-foot hutch of old plywood and cardboard under the Interstate 395 overpass a few yards from Miami's showcase, Biscayne Boulevard. "
Miami doesn't make it easy for us."

Plan for a Large Program But this week, under persistent prodding by a Federal court, city officials tentatively agreed to a plan intended to establish Miami's first large-scale program to help the homeless.

The plan, which still must be approved by the city commissioners, would provide accommodations for 30 days for as many as 500 homeless people at Bobby Maduro Stadium, an open-air baseball stadium, about a mile from the overpass, that a few years ago housed Nicaraguan refugees.
The plan is seen as a first step toward a permanent program.

City officials said the state had committed as much as $300,000 for the project, which, along with city and county involvement, would provide shelter, showers, food, medical care and counseling to help the homeless find jobs and a place to live.
After a sting operation, a New York City police officer was arrested yesterday on charges that he took money from a safe in a Greenwich Village apartment while responding to a report of a burglary.

Earlier yesterday in Brooklyn, the 29-year-old officer, Peter Parisi, a member of the Police Department for nine years, was charged in a Federal complaint with acting as an intermediary in an automobile insurance fraud.
The arrest in Manhattan grew out of an investigation by the department's Internal Affairs Bureau in cooparation with the Manhattan District Attorney's office.
The sting, which involved calls to the same East Village address on three occasions, was aimed at Officer Parisi after allegations of corruption surfaced about him, the authorities said.

Prosecutors released three photographs taken with a hidden camera that they said showed Officer Parisi taking an envelope containing $1,100 from a safe that had been broken open during a bogus burglary.
His lawyer, John Patten, who said he had not seen the photos, entered a plea of not guilty for Mr. Parisi, who resigned from the department on Aug. 31.

Officer Parisi, who has been assigned to the Ninth Precinct in the East Village for five years, appeared in Criminal Court in Manhattan yesterday, where he was charged with second-degree burglary and fourth-degree grand larceny.
Earlier, he was arraigned in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on conspiracy to commit mail fraud in the auto insurance scheme.
If convicted in both cases, he faces up to 20 years in jail.

An assistant district attorney, Thomas Hickey, told Judge Rosalyn H. Richter of Criminal Court that "in conversations with myself and Internal Affairs Bureau investigators, the defendant admitted to a host of other corrupt acts," including "thefts, brutality and bribe receiving."
"Electing Little-Known Candidates as Judges"  [ Oct. 20 ]  addresses a major flaw in our electoral system.
The candidates are relatively unknown to the voters, and on Long Island the only selection process takes place within the political hierarchy.
This makes the rules of journalistic fair play crucial to the operation of a decidedly imperfect process.
You list 3 Supreme Court nominees out of a field of 24 who have "come under scrutiny."
This pregnant phrase is followed in the first instance by a paragraph devoted to Edward Hart.
The only fact set forth is that he, as a lawyer, represented the Republican Party in the 1 percent case.
One can only draw the inference that the author considers this to be adequate grounds for denying a vote to Mr. Hart.

The same logic would result in the denial of the bench to any of our distinguished criminal lawyers who have represented individuals or groups who were ultimately adjudged to have involved themselves in reprehensible activities.
As a long-time Democrat, I have a high level of tolerance for barbs pointed toward the local ruling party.
The reader should not be left with the impression that this was his only case in 35 years.
A GALLERY'S regular artists are often referred to as a stable.
Jacques Kaplan who is known for drawing from many quarters, has a gallery in Kent (called Paris-New York-Kent) that is in a space something like a stable: a retired wooden train caboose.
With the current exhibition, ''The Horse in Contemporary Art,'' the equine notion has come to life.
Mr. Kaplan freely borrows from his own large collection.

Susan Rothenberg was known early in her career, in the 1970's, as belonging to a group of artists who were bringing recognizable images back into contemporary art, then ruled by the canon of Minimalism.
Mr. Kaplan says he bought two paintings from Ms. Rothenberg's debut show, and he includes one in this exhibition.
In the picture is a black curved area, the kind of shape Ellsworth Kelly, a major Minimalist, might draw.

But in Ms. Rothenberg's work, a rudely drawn horse, shaped like a wishbone, appears to be careering around the shape's edge, an announcement of a brash new attitude, that an artist could turn a geometric form into a racetrack.

Mr. Kaplan reached farther back to present several other pieces, including an elegant bronze horse by Elie Nadelman, a sculptor known for having wed the simplicity of folk art to the Art Deco style prevalent in the 1920's.
It may be an interloper, but it's a gorgeous one with a rather massive body on slender legs.
Over the years some of us have often given police officers the benefit of the doubt.

When three cops were acquitted of assaulting Juan Rodriguez in Brooklyn, when Nicholas Bartlett was shot to death by officers in Harlem, when Luis Baez was killed after he brandished what turned out to be a putty knife at police, we could always remind ourselves of one undeniable fact: It's a tough job.

But today some of us have nothing but doubt about some members of the New York City Police Department, doubt about whether arrogance, immaturity and bigotry have taken them over the line from protectors to punks.
A week ago several thousand off-duty cops showed up at City Hall to protest a plan for an all-civilian complaint review board.
The mob scene that ensued made the best argument possible for civilian review of police misconduct.
Some of the police protesters blocked traffic on the Brooklyn Bridge.
They jumped on parked cars, harassed passers-by and left City Hall Park littered with beer cans.
They used racist language, carried racist signs and called the Mayor a nigger.
All those years when we gave police the benefit of the doubt seemed extraordinarily naive in retrospect.

Phil Caruso, the longtime president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which continues to have an all-white executive board though almost a third of its members are African-American or Latino, described what had happened as a "gut, visceral reaction."

The repeal of a Maine law prohibiting discrimination against gay men and lesbians in housing, employment and public accommodations is a disheartening step backward for a state that prides itself on tolerance.

The surprise outcome shows that broad but complacent support for gay rights is no match for a grass-roots campaign that plays to anti-gay feelings and the public's general reluctance to politicize sexual matters.

The repeal effort was led by the Christian Civic League of Maine, a local group known also for crusades against pornography and shopping on Sunday, with help from national groups such as the Christian Coalition.
This is not the first time Maine voters have been asked about gay rights.
In 1995, they responded quite differently when they rejected a ballot measure that would have barred communities from enacting laws to protect homosexuals from discrimination.
That measure was rejected even in conservative, rural Catholic communities.
Last year, the Legislature passed a law prohibiting discrimination with bipartisan support.
Gov. Angus King, an independent, supported that law, and opposed its repeal.
Early polling indicated that 60 percent of the public also opposed the repeal.
Interestingly, a similar margin did not think that homosexuals suffered discrimination in the state.
This week's meetings between mainland China and Taiwan mark a welcome return to negotiations in a sometimes dangerously tense relationship.
Only two and a half years ago, China test-fired missiles across the Taiwan Strait to protest Taipei's assertions of greater diplomatic independence.
That astonishingly reckless move led the United States to respond with a show of naval might.
Talks, not force, are the way to resolve deep differences between China and Taiwan over the issue of eventual reunification.
Both Governments agree that they are part of a single Chinese nation.
But Beijing interprets that ''one-China formula'' as giving it a right to complete the Communist victory in the 1949 civil war by ''liberating'' Taiwan when it is militarily able.
Taipei argues for keeping two separate governments until the mainland becomes as democratic and prosperous as Taiwan.
Stripped of the semantics, this argument contains one very dangerous element -- Beijing's refusal to renounce the threat of force.
Except for a brief interlude in the 1940's, Taiwan has not been ruled by Beijing for the last century.
That period includes almost 50 years as a Japanese colony, and then decades of martial law under Chiang Kai-shek.

SPRAWLING into the Towns of Huntington and Smithtown, the 12-square-mile hamlet of Commack offers access to major roads, abundant shopping, neighborhood parks, a well-regarded school district and a range of housing choices to fit almost all pocketbooks. ''

The crime rate is low, the people are nice, the community is well established, and you can get to just about anywhere from here,'' said Fred Monner, the president of the 74-home Mayfair Woods Civic Association. ''
You could say all roads lead to Commack.''
Mr. Monner, a retired school administrator who now does public relations and writes do-it-yourself books with his wife, Linda, moved to Commack from the Bronx 29 years ago. ''
Commack has everything you could want, good shopping and restaurants,'' he said.
Among the hamlet's amenities is the Hoyt House on the 133-acre Hoyt Farm Preserve.
The three-bedroom farmhouse built by the Wick family in 1780, is now a museum housing furniture and artifacts representing late 18th century through early 20th century rural life.
The house is open on weekend afternoons Memorial Day through Labor Day.
Admission is free.
By 1783, there were enough residents to form a Methodist congregation.
Two suicide car bombers tore into a central checkpoint for Baghdad's airport on Sunday, setting off blasts that killed at least 14 people and wounded 16, the military and the police said.
It was the first bomb attack in nearly a year aimed at the airport, the capital's main gateway.

The attack also was the worst in a string of violent assaults that left at least 32 people dead, including 2 American soldiers and 2 British soldiers, and more than 60 wounded, making Sunday Iraq's deadliest day in weeks.

The first airport checkpoint bomber struck at 10:50 a.m. in a dirt parking lot roughly the size of a football field, where throngs of Iraqis and foreigners waited for rides to the airport and to the largest American military base in Baghdad, Camp Victory.
Shortly after, the second bomber detonated his device near another cluster of vehicles, scattering human remains into the dust.
One airport taxi driver said he found the head of a colleague in the wreckage.
The bombings were a brazen strike at one of the capital's most heavily guarded areas.
Foreigners, members of the military and hundreds of Iraqi workers and travelers move through the area daily, waiting in cars between two roads and giant slabs of cement.
The ease with which the two bombers drove into the parking area, just east of a statue and a larger, more secure lot, demonstrated how far Iraqis still have to go to improve security.

The checkpoint was closed for several hours, blocking the one route into the airport, which remains the only reliable point of entry to Iraq for foreigners, who no longer travel to the country by road from Jordan or Kuwait, because that has become too dangerous.

As senior vice president for corporate affairs at the St. Paul Companies, an insurance conglomerate in Minnesota, Karen Himle totes the predictable accouterments of her trade, from pens to legal documents.
But the other contents of her Louis Vuitton purse say almost as much about the local climate as they do about her job.
Inside are two tubes of hand cream, six tubes of lipstick and two containers of lip balm. ''
Winter is very dry,'' she says.
The bag was a Christmas gift she requested for its ample interior; her old one couldn't handle all the stuff she likes to have on hand for her two daughters, Lauren, 9, and Kirsten, 5.
On this day, out tumbled a grape Juicy-Juice box drink, a lollipop and a canister of undeveloped film from a snowmobile vacation and Lauren's birthday party.
The purse also holds many business cards, which she keeps not only as a record of whom she has met but also for scrap paper. ''
I always take notes on the back,'' she said.
It is clear that Ms. Himle, 43, wasn't prepared for the recent increase in stamp prices.
The bag contains a variety of unpaid bills, each awaiting an extra penny of postage.
A suspect was being questioned in a number of attacks on prostitutes in Manhattan that have left two women dead and four others injured, the police said last night.

Thomas Kelly, a deputy police commissioner, said the man was being interrogated at the Seventh Precinct station house on the Lower East Side, where victims who survived the assaults were to view lineups to determine whether he was their attacker.

Another police official, who insisted on anonymity, said the suspect, a 39-year-old Harlem man, was spotted late Sunday night by one of his victims as she was working the streets in Chelsea, where several of the attacks occurred.
The man disappeared after the woman called the police, but she saw him again, and officers then moved in to detain him.
The police official said detectives recovered a gun and a length of rope that the man had been carrying, indicating that he was possibly preparing to attack again.
During a day of interrogation, the suspect admitted his role in the attacks,  the police official said.
However, he said the man had not yet been arrested because detectives wanted all the surviving victims to have a chance to view him in a lineup.
The police were searching for the three other survivors, but they declined to say yesterday whether they had found any of them.

In the most recent attack, the victim, described by the police as a 21-year-old prostitute, was choked and left for dead in the bathroom of a Lower  East Side hotel in the early morning hours of Oct. 14.
But she regained consciousness and is expected to be a witness against the suspect.

The nearly 6,000 pilots at Delta Air Lines, proving resistant to a second round of concessions, voted overwhelmingly to approve a strike should their contract be voided by an arbitration panel, the pilots' union said yesterday.
The panel is expected to issue a ruling by April 15.
The decision by the pilots gives negotiators on both sides more than a week to narrow their differences and avoid a work stoppage that many believe would lead to a liquidation of Delta.
Among the issues is the company's request for $305 million in annual pay cuts; the pilots have offered $140 million. ''
The Delta pilots will strike if their contract is rejected,'' said Lee Moak, a pilot and chairman of the Delta chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association.

Delta filed for bankruptcy protection in September, and after the filing both sides agreed to arbitration rather than have a bankruptcy judge rule on management's motion to void the pilots' contract and impose lower wages and other conditions.
Like the judge overseeing bankruptcy, the arbitration panel was supposed to issue a ruling on whether the contract should be thrown out.
But the pilots have vowed not to work without a contract if the ruling goes against them.
The panel has encouraged both sides to settle the matter rather than wait for the panel to either void or let stand the pilots' contract.

The chief executive of Delta, Gerald Grinstein, said last week that the airline, entirely dependent on lenders who could withdraw financing in the event of a strike, could not survive a shutdown lasting even 24 hours.
LEAD: To the Editor: To the Editor: I was upset to read ''China's Use of Forced Labor Questioned by Import Study'' (Business Day, Sept. 18), which is not true to the facts so far as I know.
The function of labor-reform departments in China is to enforce penalties imposed on criminals, to educate and reform prisoners in accordance with law.
Labor-reform departments in China are not allowed to engage in foreign economic and trade activities, and China has never granted any labor-reform department a permit to engage in foreign trade.
No products made in prison are exported.
In China, specialized import and export companies are responsible for import and export.
The Chinese Government arranges for prisoners to take part in productive labor with the aim to educate them and help them acquire working skills.
What they produce is mainly for meeting their own consumption needs.
Only a small quantity of surplus products goes to the domestic market through normal channels.
About 70 percent of their products are consumed by prisoners themselves, while 30 percent are provided for the domestic market.

In order to make prisoners readily meet the employment requirements when they are released after having served the sentence, we get prisoners to engage in production, and we run technical training courses in prisons to develop their working skills, according to their specific conditions.
The Communist Party-controlled legislature has indicated that it is preparing to enact a law against secession, possibly mandating military action if Taiwan were to declare independence.

A draft law forbidding secession by any part of China, announced Friday by the New China News Agency, suggests that President Hu Jintao is seeking to eliminate any lingering doubts that the Chinese military would attack Taiwan if the island formally severed ties with the mainland.

China's top leaders have said consistently that they would wage war against Taiwan if it were to declare itself an independent state, so the passage of such a law basically reiterates existing policy.
But outlawing secession may be an attempt to counter skepticism in Taiwan that China would really start a war it might not win.
The United States has pledged to defend Taiwan if the mainland attacks, and China would risk derailing its trade-dependent economic growth if it launched an attack. ''
This is a step the people have been demanding for many years,'' says Yu Keli, a Taiwan expert at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences in Beijing. ''
There can be no ambiguity that China will fight Taiwanese independence no matter what.''
The New China News Agency report said committee chairmen of the National People's Congress had submitted a draft of the measure on Friday.
It is to be considered by the standing committee of the legislature during the period Dec. 25-29.
The report provided no details of the legislation.
A United States Bankruptcy Court judge approved US Airways' restructuring plan yesterday, clearing the way for the airline to emerge from Chapter 11 protection by March 31.
The judge, Stephen Mitchell, approved US Airways' plan after it received a strong endorsement from the airline's creditors' committee.
Last week, the group voted in favor of the proposal.

The judge's action came despite objections from US Airways' pilots, who were upset by the airline's bid to set aside their pension plan and replace it with a program that would pay up to 75 percent less in benefits.
Judge Mitchell had ruled that US Airways could dissolve the plan but asked the two sides to negotiate a replacement.

In a statement, US Airways' chief executive, David N. Siegel, said yesterday that the airline would try to resolve the dispute with the pilots and would meet with federal pension officials to discuss its proposed plan.

Once US Airways emerged from bankruptcy, it would be able to draw on $900 million in loan guarantees from the federal Air Transportation Stabilization Board, which had given the airline provisional loan approval, pending its reorganization.
The airline, based in Arlington, Va., will also be able to obtain $240 million in financing from its primarily lender, the Retirement Systems of Alabama, a pension fund.
In that role, Retirement Systems had outbid an earlier contender for the airline, the Texas Pacific Group, an investment group led by David Bonderman.
The pension fund, based in Montgomery, Ala., would have the largest stake in the airline, 36.6 percent.
THE figure model Susan Wiebe, 51, has suffered for the sake of art.
To hold a pose, she has endured exhaustion, shooting pain and loss of circulation to body parts she never knew could go numb.
But when she discovered a tour group of senior citizens peering through the window at the Silvermine School of Art one day as she posed nude for a sketch class, all bets were off. ''
I was shocked and kind of upset,'' she said. ''
I didn't know what else to do, so I stood up and sarcastically waved at them.
And they all waved back.''
A decade has passed since that busload of visitors, on a New England leaf peeping trip, stopped at the arts center in New Canaan to tour the gallery but happened upon a more intriguing display. ''
We hadn't gotten curtains yet,'' Ms. Wiebe said. ''
But even now, sometimes if there's a little crack, people have to look in.
People are curious.''
Rockets 124, Suns 100 The 3-point sniping of Vernon Maxwell and Sam Cassell and Hakeem Olajuwon's strength inside led the Houston Rockets to a 124-100 rout of the Suns in Phoenix yesterday.

The Rockets, who knocked the Suns out of the Western Conference semifinals in six games last season and beat them, 114-106, at the Summit on Dec. 22, became only the third team to defeat Phoenix at home this season.
Olajuwon had 28 points, 11 rebounds and 3 blocks as the Rockets won their fourth straight game, ending a three-game streak by Phoenix.
Maxwell and Cassell scored 19 points apiece, with Maxwell hitting 5 of 9 from beyond the arc to Cassell's 4 of 5.
SuperSonics 136, Heat 109 Shawn Kemp had 26 points and 11 rebounds and Seattle set a team record with its 10th consecutive road victory, this time in Miami.
With every Seattle starter scoring in double figures in the first three quarters, the SuperSonics won for the 14th time in their last 16 games.
Kemp, Sam Perkins and Kendall Gill combined for Seattle's first 23 points as the Sonics hit 6 of 8 3-pointers and built a 30-15 lead that was never challenged.

Hornets 111, Bullets 105 Robert Parish hit two free throws and Dell Curry sank a long jumper in the final 38 seconds to seal Charlotte's home victory over Washington and extend the Hornets' winning streak to six games.
The Hornets let 7-foot-7-inch Gheorghe Muresan intimidate their inside game, and he produced just enough offense to keep the Bullets close.
He scored 5 points at the start of the fourth quarter to cut into Charlotte's 90-82 third-quarter lead, and Chris Webber's inside move gave Washington a 96-94 lead with 7:29 to play.

Federal health officials have threatened to cut off all financing for a breast cancer project coordinated at the University of Pittsburgh unless the university takes further steps to revamp the flawed project's leadership.
Specifically, officials of the National Cancer Institute said they objected to retaining the project's two top scientists, Dr. Bernard Fisher and Dr. Carol Redmond, in leadership roles.
Acting under orders from the cancer institute, University of Pittsburgh officials last month removed Dr. Fisher as administrative head of the studies.
Dr. Fisher, a surgeon who is 75, had earned many tributes for his leadership of the studies for nearly 30 years.
Dr. Redmond is the project's chief statistician.

And responding to another Federal directive last week, university officials began steps to determine whether there should be a formal investigation into possible scientific misconduct by Dr. Fisher and Dr. Redmond.

The inquiry was ordered because the two had published articles in medical journals after learning that data had been falsified by a Canadian researcher and because they had not disclosed that to co-authors and editors of the journals.
On April 20, the University of Pittsburgh submitted a plan intended to meet the cancer institute's criticisms.
Under the plan Dr. Fisher would become the project's scientific director.
But this week the cancer institute objected.
ON July 18, Israeli warplanes leveled a multifamily villa in Hosh, a Lebanese village a mile southeast of the coastal city of Tyre.
Soon after, rescue workers arrived.
They could hear voices from under the rubble.
But the continuing bombardment made it impossible to conduct the rescue effort, says a Lebanese Army soldier who was at the scene.
Other buildings and targets in the area were also hit by Israeli aircraft seeking Hezbollah leaders thought to be in the area.
Returning last week, Chinese United Nations workers, top, finally began to dig through the rubble, searching for the bodies of a Nigerian United Nations worker and five members of a Lebanese family.
The body of one family member, middle, was carried out on Wednesday.
A photo album, bottom, was found among the belongings.
The excavation was supervised by the Lebanese Army.
Because of the number of strikes against the roads by Israeli aircraft, it is extremely difficult to move south or east of Tyre.
IN the early days, Tito Briccetti, the founder of a modest country store in northern Westchester, made home deliveries by horse and wagon.
And while the area was still largely rural, local people sold their own baked goods, eggs and fruits from the store.
Briccetti's Bedford Market attracted seemingly everyone -- farmers, homeowners, local merchants, estate owners and summer residents.
Jackie Gleason stopped in a few times.

Gertrude Berg, a radio and early television actress and writer known for her Molly Goldberg character, would sit in a corner, observe patrons and take notes, perhaps gathering script material, locals say.
Frank Sinatra bought grape jelly and Wonder Bread.
Today, people still gather and free home delivery -- now by car, of course -- is a big part of the business.

But along with things like Bird's (''Since 1837'') custard-style pudding mix, canned deviled ham, corned beef hash, fresh produce and cut-to-order meat, a grocery order may contain bottles of Perrier and the latest cleaning products.
The market, operated by one family since it was founded in Mount Kisco in 1908 and then relocated to nearby Bedford Hills in 1929, has stood the test of time, making but a few concessions to it.
But last month, the business, was sold.

''Momijigari: The Japanese Autumn Garden,'' a vibrant exhibition of Japanese autumnal plants, is on view through Nov. 25 at the New York Botanical Garden, with a wide variety of Japanese and fullmoon maples in the courtyard of the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory.
Visitors pass through a tei-mon, or garden gate, marking the transition from the outside world to the spiritual realm of the garden.
Inside, a stone path leads viewers past a collection of maples ablaze with color, including the delicate, drooping Garnet and the intertwined and rosy Pixie.
Japanese painted ferns and Hakone grass, as well as black mondo grass and Afghan carpet (Persicaria capitata), serve as ground cover.
Dotted throughout the garden are carefully sculptured cascades and columns of Japanese chrysanthemums, coming into bloom at the beginning of November.
The exhibition also features a variety of Japanese conifers.
In the center of the garden, a reflecting pool harbors a selection of waterlilies and lotus.
A nearby viewing pavilion, constructed in traditional Japanese style, is a peaceful resting place.

The New York Botanical Garden, at Bronx River Parkway and Fordham Road in the Bronx, is open Tuesday through Sunday, and on holiday Mondays, from 10 a.m. until 6 p.m. In November the garden closes at 4.
Admission to the grounds and conservatory is $10, $4 ages 12 and under.

The Sprint Corporation raised fears on Wall Street yesterday that it was setting off a bigger price war in the long-distance telephone industry by offering flat prices to replace the highly complex discount programs that have long been the staple of the industry's big companies.

The seemingly simple move -- announcing a flat price of 10 cents a minute for nighttime and weekend calls and 22 cents on weekdays -- offers only a modest reduction in the average prices charged by AT&T and MCI Communications.

But the move represented a potentially big departure in strategy, laying prices out in the open rather than cloaking them behind a blitz of volume discounts, rewards of "frequent flier" airline miles and $50 checks to people who switch carriers.
Sprint's move, announced late Thursday as a counterattack to AT&T's huge and highly successful marketing campaign of recent months, jolted the stocks of both AT&T and MCI.
In heavy trading, AT&T's shares dropped $1.375, to $48.25, while MCI's shares fell 93.75 cents, to $18.0625.
Sprint stock, by contrast, gained 50 cents, to $27.125. "
The big event is Sprint's new fixed-price scheme, since base rates will no longer be invisible to customers," said Daniel P. Reingold, a telecommunications analyst at Merrill Lynch. "
If ATT and MCI find themselves having to match Sprint's fixed-price scheme, then base rates will no longer be invisible to customers and it will be very difficult to raise them."
The new twist comes as the three long-distance carriers are embroiled in a fierce marketing war.

Earlier this year, AT&T rolled out a $150 million advertising campaign, offered an aggressive new package of discounts called True Savings and literally bought thousands of customers by offering them checks for as much as $75 to abandon MCI or Sprint.

Seventeen years after Los Angeles County formed the country's first division of prosecutors to investigate every shooting by a police officer or death of a suspect in custody, budget cuts have placed that responsibility back in the hands of the police themselves.

Last week, District Attorney Gil Garcetti, who originally formed the unit, announced its end, meaning that after Sept. 1, no one from his office will investigate whether an officer acted properly in pulling the trigger.
Since there is no civilian review board, the only inquiry into a shooting by an officer would come from the police department's internal affairs division.

The cut is the latest in a summer of financial bloodletting in Los Angeles, as the Board of Supervisors has tackled a $1.2 billion deficit by furloughing thousands of county workers, closing more than 30 health clinics and nearly closing the Los Angeles County-U.S.C. Medical Center, the nucleus of the area's trauma care system.

Mr. Garcetti, faced with a $4 million deficit and $2 million in new computer upgrading costs, said he had no choice but to cut the four deputy district attorneys and four investigators in the unit, known as the "roll-out team."
Other prosecutorial units losing deputy district attorneys and investigators include major crimes, environmental crimes, Asian crimes, gang prosecutions and the bad checks division. "
There was a lot of pain and sacrifice that went into starting that team," Mr. Garcetti said. "
So you can imagine the difficulty I had in suspending it indefinitely.
But what it's come down to is I would rather prosecute any case rather than simply going out and ratifying that police did not commit an improper shooting."
A spokeswoman for the Los Angeles Police Department said the police "have no comment on the decision" until after Sept. 1.
Two years ago, Federal railroad regulators approved, with hardly a blink, Union Pacific's acquisition of Southern Pacific to form the nation's largest railroad.
The result was one of the nation's worst rail tie-ups, costing businesses billions of dollars throughout the West.

Today and tomorrow, the Surface Transportation Board is holding  hearings on plans by two other railroads, Norfolk Southern and CSX, to take over Conrail, the only major freight carrier serving the Northeast.
While approval of those plans is expected, the board, striving to make amends for the Union Pacific debacle, has already attached tougher conditions and oversight to Conrail's acquisition.

The railroads said that the takeover of Conrail presented far fewer threats to competition, reliability and safety than Union Pacific's $5.4 billion acquisition of Southern Pacific, and that their preparations have been far more thorough.

Businesses throughout the Northeast will enjoy much smoother, faster shipments from other regions, they said, and motorists on the interstates will enjoy reduced traffic as 1.1 million truckloads of freight each year are diverted to the rails.
Although the railroads plan to assume Conrail routes by Sept. 1, executives say they will take more time, even into next year if necessary.
While shippers and labor unions generally supported the acquisition, some said that it would present them with higher shipping costs and unacceptable risks.
The railroads, they said, cannot reliably or safely handle the extra freight they expected the merger to generate.
Conrail is a monopoly by design, created by the Government in 1976 from the failed Penn Central, itself a combination of the New York Central and Pennsylvania railroads.
THE stock market has turned ugly, cutting off potential cash for Internet companies, many of which can measure their life expectancies in months.
And accounting concerns, so often ignored when stocks are rising, are again becoming an issue in corporate America.

In a speech last Wednesday, Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, threw a harsh spotlight on the often close relationships between accounting firms and the companies they audit.
Mr. Levitt warned that accounting firms doubling as consultants might be tempted to go easy on audits to keep clients happy and the consulting business flowing.

A dispute among athletes hoping to make the United States Olympic team as bobsledders ended yesterday when the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York State overturned a lower-court ruling that had effectively blocked two of the athletes from competing.

There's been a lot of name-calling and backbiting," Gault said yesterday. "

The dispute began last July, when Gault, Harrell and Edwin Moses, the world-class hurdler, failed to make the cut by one one-hundredth of a second.

To the Editor: In "Cows, Bulls and Clean Air" (advertisement, Op-Ed page, Dec. 13), the Mobil Corporation bemoans that Congress "hastily" passed a clean air bill that could cut into Mobil's profit margin and not improve air quality.
The ad seems to credit Congress with good intentions, but suggests that intent led to a precipitous and imprudent result.
Mobil's answer is more study and further delay.
Let's examine the facts.
The Clean Air Act amendments of 1990 were the first revision of the act since 1977 and only the second in its 20 years.
The bill was the most extensively debated legislation considered by the 101st Congress.
It was the primary subject of Senate floor debate from January until April.
The conference between the House and Senate lasted almost five months.
The final conference bill received overwhelming bipartisan support in both houses.
Mobil suggests that Congress and the President should have waited until the petroleum industry could come up with its own answers to our air-quality problems.

Bill Clinton has invited 50 un-famous, un-rich Americans to lunch in Washington on the eve of his inauguration this month -- another sign he means to be a President with an ear for what's on people's minds.
But he is not the first to cast a populist image at the outset of his Administration.
What counts is what he does in the Oval Office.
Jimmy Carter introduced America to the South's easy informality with nicknames; he took the oath of office as "Jimmy," not "James Earl."
And then, leaving the inaugural platform at the Capitol, the new President proceeded to walk down Pennsylvania Avenue hand-in-hand with his wife -- the very image of a regular fellow.
He even took questions on an "Ask President Carter" call-in broadcast with Walter Cronkite, years before Ross Perot teamed up with Larry King.
The best-known example of Presidential folksiness was, of course, Andrew Jackson's first inauguration, and quite unintentional.
He had planned a dignified White House reception for invited guests.
But his popularity as the first common man to be elected President drew thousands of uninvited admirers who raised havoc until they were finally lured outdoors by moving the punch bowls to the lawn.
Jackson escaped through a window.
Barbara Bonney has been bringing her radiant lyric soprano voice and fair-haired beauty to the opera stage for some 20 years.
In recent seasons she has been increasingly devoted to the song recital.
She is not going to disappear from opera: in December she sang a much-praised Susanna in Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro'' at the Metropolitan.
Still, lovers of fine vocal artistry should be cheered by Ms. Bonney's increasing involvement with the song literature.
Her recital at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night, with the pianist Warren Jones, was exquisite.

The program of songs by Stenhammar, Sibelius and Grieg was drawn from Ms. Bonney's recent Decca recording, ''Diamonds in the Snow,'' songs by Nordic composers, with the conductor Antonio Pappano at the piano.

Here, with the technically elegant and imaginative Mr. Jones as her pianist, Ms. Bonney sang with scrupulous musicianship, exceptional sensitivity and, at least to this non-Nordic listener, convincingly idiomatic delivery of the Swedish, Norwegian and German texts.
Thanks to the advocacy of Swedish singers like Anne Sofie von Otter and others, the songs of Wilhelm Stenhammar, who died in Stockholm in 1927, are becoming better known.
Those Ms. Bonney performed here were enchanting, like the wistful ''Adagio'' with its lapping piano accompaniment and plaintive melody.
When a soprano has a voice as sheerly beautiful as Ms. Bonney's, the temptation to show it off in each phrase must be hard to resist.
The president of Italy on Tuesday pardoned Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish gunman who tried to kill Pope John Paul II on May 13, 1981, clearing the way for his extradition to Turkey.
As President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi signed the order, the Italian Justice Ministry put the extradition in motion.
Mr. Agca, 42, was convicted in absentia in Turkey of the murder of a Turkish journalist in 1978, and could face more prison time there.
He left Italy late Tuesday and arrived at Ataturk International Airport in Istanbul early this morning. ''
This is a dream, I cannot believe it,'' Marina Magistrelli, Mr. Agca's lawyer, quoted him as saying on Tuesday when she told him the news.
He had long hoped to be sent back to Turkey to finish paying his legal debt and retire to a rural village, she said.
She said he thanked ''the Holy Father, the Vatican and the president of the republic.''

The pardon, presented as a ''humanitarian'' act by the government, seemed prompted by Italy's close relations with the Vatican, which has campaigned for Mr. Agca's release and made forgiveness a theme of this Roman Catholic Holy Year.

The clemency was granted exactly one month after the Vatican revealed the so-called Third Secret of Fatima, saying that the long-suppressed prophecy by the Virgin of Fatima foretold the 1981 attempt on the pope's life.
The Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, said, ''The pardon, which took place during the celebration of the Holy Year, makes the personal satisfaction of the Holy Father even greater.''

Chris Chandler threw for two touchdowns and ran for another and the rookie Rodney Thomas ran for a season-high 108 yards as the Houston Oilers beat the Browns, 37-10, before a Cleveland Municipal Stadium crowd bracing for more bad news Monday.

The game seemed to be a sideshow to the 57,881 fans who attended -- there were an uncharacteristic 7,868 no-shows, not counting Modell -- in a stadium where the capacity is 78,512.
