The airline industry is beginning to see what was supposed to be a promising year slip away, because of rising fuel costs, brutal competition -- especially on cross-country routes -- and its own lingering financial headaches.

While no one is predicting this summer will be as bad operationally as the infamous ''summer from hell'' in 2000, when one of four flights was delayed, canceled or diverted, there are fears that a difficult season lies ahead. ''

In the past, a good summer could have paved its way to a break-even year; this summer, it probably won't,'' said Darin Lee, senior managing economist with LECG, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. Problems are already appearing.
Yesterday, Delta Air Lines said it lost $387 million in the first quarter, kicking off what analysts fear will be a string of poor quarterly results for major airlines.
Some industry analysts say first-quarter losses could reach $1 billion or more for the carriers, even though traffic is rebounding to levels last seen before the September 2001 terrorist attacks.
Delta's loss, though an improvement from its $466 million shortfall in the quarter last year, came as its cash dropped by $500 million in the quarter, to $2.2 billion.
The performance was labeled ''clearly unsustainable'' by its chief executive, Gerald A. Grinstein, who took charge of the airline this year.
Speaking to analysts and reporters, Mr. Grinstein repeatedly pushed for concessions from Delta's pilots, whom he called the ''major boulder'' blocking competitiveness.
Delta is trying to win a 30 percent reduction in pay and benefits from its pilots, who have said they are willing to take a 9 percent cut and give up a wage increase scheduled for next month.
But the pilots, whose contract expires in 2005, are not required to open negotiations before August.

The explosion in the number, size and complexity of networks makes managing them rough. "

We've got several thousand PC's and several hundred Macs talking to 75 LAN servers and I.B.M. mainframes and DEC minis," said Dan Kohner, manager of network services at the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center at the University of Texas. "
Managing it all keeps me up nights."
Though standards abound in networking, they apply to specific applications rather than to the broader concept of network management.
And vendors' solutions to various problems do not always work elegantly in tandem.
For example, Novell's Netware, which dominates LAN operating systems for PC's, is incompatible with the Appletalk system used with Apple Macintoshes.
A network administrator must intervene.

But Novell Inc., a vendor of networking products in Provo, Utah, is trying to make the task of management much easier via its Netware Management System (NMS) series, to be released over the next few months.

The series, one of the first products designed for comprehensive network management, will help network administrators with five basic functions: user management, auditing, monitoring, troubleshooting and growth management.
The first part of it, the Network Services Manager, lets an administrator view the network from a single PC rather from a bank of them.

Despite two Federal Reserve rate cuts and a big technology stock rally in January, the three major stock indexes have now given up all their gains for the year.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 3.6 percent yesterday and is now ahead just 0.02 percent for the year.
Two and a half weeks ago, it was roaring ahead with a 15.7 percent gain.
Smaller declines yesterday in the Dow Jones industrial average, off 0.9 percent, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index, down 1.3 percent, nudged those indexes to slight losses for the year.
Since the technology rally peaked last month, investors have begun to grapple with two disappointments.

The second is drooping earnings reports in the technology sector, capped this week by a jolt from Cisco Systems.
After 44 quarters of consecutive revenue growth, Cisco said its revenues would decline as much as 5 percent this quarter and be flat in the next quarter.

With Wall Street forecasters already predicting that corporate earnings will fall 1.2 percent in the first quarter and 0.2 percent in the second quarter, the Cisco forecast, weak reports from other companies and layoff announcements are making investors doubt whether the economy and  corporate profits will recover by the second half of the year.

A judge issued an order yesterday temporarily blocking the start, scheduled for today, of stricter no-fault auto insurance regulations in New York State that the Pataki administration says are needed to fight fraud.
But the administration said later that the regulations would still go into effect today because it had given notice that it would appeal the court order, thus staying the order.
In fact, the issue of whether the stricter rules go into effect today will be settled in further court action.

The order was issued by Justice Alice Schlesinger of State Supreme Court in Manhattan and was intended to delay the new regulations until the judge permanently assigned to the case could hear it on its merits.
Justice Schlesinger's ruling came in a lawsuit brought by a coalition of legal, consumer and medical groups  to permanently block the new rules.
The critics say the new regulations  penalize honest auto accident victims and the medical people who treat them and will not deter fraud.

The regulations reduce to 30 days from 90 the period an injured party has to report an accident to the proper insurance company, and to 45 days from 180 the time for doctors to submit compensation claims.
Under the new regulations, policies written or renewed starting today are to  carry the shorter deadlines; existing policies retain the old deadlines until renewal.
An attempt to put the tighter deadlines into effect last year was blocked by another judge on procedural grounds.
The State Insurance Department has said the new attempt addresses the objections that the court raised at that time.

If you aim to impress by sheer size, consider The Silver Spoon (Phaidon, 2005, $39.95), at 1,263 pages.
The English translation of a book that has been a basic in Italian households for 50 years, it is actually as useful as it is encyclopedic, thanks to the editors who compiled it decades ago.
The book's well-articulated philosophy of cooking translates into a seasonal and enjoyable way to eat.
The approximately 2,000 recipes, given American style in cups and spoons, are concise and easy to follow.

Pasta with pesto or veal Bolognese are as Italian as can be, but the book is international enough to offer an Irish stew and a French shoulder of lamb boulangere alongside mouthwatering photographs of the dishes.
In contrast, Eggs by Michel Roux (Wiley, 2006, $24.95) might appear to be too modest as wedding gifts go.
But looks can be deceiving.
Without fanfare, this book opens the door to all manner of sophisticated cooking and baking (without eggs, after all, there is, more or less, no baking).

With Mr. Roux, a Michelin three-star chef, at the cook's side, an invitation to friends for a spectacular brunch of poached eggs on potatoes with smoked fish, or Parmesan and fontina flans, can go from dream to reality.

Patrick J. Walsh, the director of human resources at Merrill Lynch & Company, was shocked.
With business booming, the investment bank's plans had called for hiring a few more people.
But for the first quarter, employment actually fell -- a testimony to the company's success in streamlining the way it does its work.
Step by step, like private investigators, Merrill Lynch staff members had traced the paths that documents traveled, items from stock and bond purchases to new customer accounts to resumes.
They were amazed to discover how many unnecessary places and hands they passed through.
Like the rest of Wall Street, Merrill Lynch has long been using computers.
But also like many others in the securities industry, it has discovered that it was not using them effectively.
Two mainframe computers -- in lower Manhattan and Staten Island -- now comfortably handle whatever remains of the tasks that seven service centers throughout the country had once performed.
And the service centers are gone.
Far fewer clerks scurry about, filing, retrieving, faxing and delivering documents.

Glen Ridge is the kind of town where garish displays are so poorly tolerated that there's an unwritten rule prohibiting multicolored lights at Christmastime.
So how is it that flocks of plastic pink flamingos are showing up in yards all over town?
It's all in the name of raising money to build a new playground for the town's upper elementary school.
Laura Buchmann, who introduced the faux Phoenicopteridae to this upscale Essex County borough last spring, discovered the fund-raising prank on the Web.
It was so popular last year, raising $2,500 over three months, that she brought it back this fall.
In addition to the birds themselves, Mrs. Buchmann introduced a new verb to residents of Glen Ridge: to be ''flocked.''
A resident of the town can call the Flamingo Hotline (which rings inside Mrs. Buchmann's house) to flock a friend ($10), flock their own house ($10) or purchase flock insurance (any donation).
People who are flocked can pay $5 to have the offending birds removed -- even though they will be anyway in 24 hours. ''
I just thought it was cute,'' said Mrs. Buchmann, whose husband is, in fact, a landscaper. ''
I thought it would be funny to have somebody come home and find flamingos on their lawn.''

A long-awaited independent audit of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield concludes that the management of New York State's largest health-insurance company has been slow to react to accelerating changes in the insurance marketplace.

Among other findings, the audit maintains that Empire trailed the rest of the industry in expanding its managed-care programs and in developing modern computer systems, both of which contributed to heavy losses in recent years.

But the executive summary of a draft of the report, based on an audit ordered by the State Legislature last year and performed by Arthur Andersen & Company, maintains that Empire's poor financial performance has resulted primarily from economic forces beyond the control of management. "

Empire's current financial straits are the result of the inevitable conflict between the historic social mission of Blue Cross Blue Shield and the modern reality of spiraling health-care costs and heightened market competition for low-risk customers," according to the draft report.
The final report is due on May 1, but officials with Empire and the state began receiving copies of the draft on Thursday night.
The Daily News reported some of the audit's findings today.

Empire Officials Find Support Empire officials said today that they were gratified by the audit's support for their contention that the company's losses of $250 million over the last two years were largely unavoidable.
But the audit stops far short of giving Empire's management a clean bill of health. "
In a dynamic, volatile health care market, Empire has been an autocratic, functionally organized, hierarchical organization that has been slow to react to the pace of change," the report states. "
In an earlier era -- when the pace of change was slower and competition less intense -- Empire's culture and operating environment may have served it well.

The Energy Department has a new idea for what to do with derelict, polluted urban industrial properties that no one wants to pay to clean up: cover them with solar panels.

Energy Secretary Bill Richardson will unveil the first step in a project to use solar panels at polluted sites to make much-needed electricity without disturbing buried contaminants on Wednesday in Chicago.
The department, the city and the local electric utility, Commonwealth Edison, will announce that they have induced a solar panel manufacturer to set up shop on a 17-acre former dump site.
The city and utility have promised to buy $8 million worth of solar panels, some of which, department officials say, will cover derelict sites and feed energy into the local electric grid. ''
It's going from the worst old stuff to the best clean stuff,'' Mr. Richardson said in a telephone interview. ''
It's a win-win for everyone, because it addresses job creation, air quality and contaminated sites.''
The panels produce electricity with no pollution, officials say.
Chicago plans to use some of its cells to light parks, municipal buildings and transit stations.
Panels installed on contaminated sites can be trucked away and set up elsewhere if a better use is found for the land, officials involved in the project said.
The Energy Department is discussing similar projects in Los Angeles, Stamford, Conn., Washington and other cities.

A DOZEN years ago, while visiting a client in Minneapolis, Frederic W. Cook, a pay consultant, was considering a problem: How could corporate executives be persuaded to own large amounts of stock in their own company, rather than mainly stock options?
Options carried little risk, Mr. Cook knew.
If the shares of a company dropped, executives simply decided not to exercise their options.
With actual stock, executives gained and lost money as their shareholders did.
The solution that Mr. Cook hit upon that day has swept across corporate America over the last decade, and one in five large companies now uses it: reload options.
They encourage managers to exercise their options by giving them a new one every time they turn one in.
In effect, they let executives minimize risk and maximize gains.
Here is how they work: A company gives reload options to its executives with the stock trading at $20.
If the shares rise to $30 and the executives exercise their options, they would pay $20 and, in exchange, receive both a share of stock and a new option at $30.
Because executives typically exercise options by turning in a smaller number of more valuable shares, reload options allow them to increase their holdings and still hold onto an option.
WITH more Americans traveling to Spain and more Spaniards coming to New York on business or as tourists, the midtown offices of the Consulate of Spain faced overcrowding.
So earlier this year, with its lease about to expire, its senior diplomats started looking for additional space.
And a few weeks ago they signed a $5 million, 15-year agreement that gives them the 30th floor and part of the 31st floor at 150 East 58th Street.
With a total of 12,500 square feet, the new lease will provide a third more space than in the past.
The Spanish are far from an exception.
In fact, the diplomatic community as a whole has become a welcome source of demand in an otherwise bleak landscape for commercial space in Manhattan.
According to the New York City Commission for the United Nations and Consular Corps, there are now 88 consulates in New York City and 178 United Nations missions.
They pay more than $100 million annually in rent for commercial and residential space, a number that has been rising.

Moreover, they are now being eagerly courted for their stability in hard times, when in the 1980's they were shunned by many landlords because of the potential for terrorism and because their activities generated a higher-than-normal level of traffic. "

As more of our regular tenants default, the default rate of foreign governments began to look better and better," said Robert Billingsley, a partner with Abrams Benisch Riker, the management company that represented the owners at 150 East 58th Street.

EVER since Robert Siegel, the editor of The Onion, the satirical weekly, was a boy of 8 or 9, he has wanted a medal.
Wars both fascinated and terrified him. ''
I was sort of an uptight nerd and was afraid of the draft,'' said Mr. Siegel, who grew up in Merrick, N.Y., the son of school psychologists. ''
I'd have nightmares about being in the front line of war, where they'd charge, swords drawn, into the fire, and I'd dream about how I'd sneak away and hide in the woods.''
He read ''The Red Badge of Courage'' and became a Civil War buff.
He read about the Revolutionary War and memorized all the presidential assassins.
He visited Ford's Theater in Washington and the house where Lincoln died. ''
I saw the pillow with his blood still on it,'' he said. ''
I was sort of a dark little kid.''
When his grandparents went on their annual cruise, he would ask for a medal, but what he got was souvenirs. ''
The TD Waterhouse Cup lost its top-seeded player tonight when Tommy Haas withdrew from his semifinal match against Paradorn Srichaphan because of pain in his right arm.
Haas, seeded third for the United States Open, said he would decide whether to play in that tournament right before his first-round match. ''
I'm living day by day with this,'' he said.
Dr. David Dines, the TD Waterhouse Cup physician who examined Haas, said the Open's three-of-five-set format would put even more pressure on Haas's ailing arm.
Haas's tendinitis-plagued arm swelled up Friday night after his third consecutive three-set victory here.
He woke up this morning in pain and tried hitting later in the afternoon before spasms halted the practice.
Haas, the defending champion, then withdrew from his match.
Srichaphan will face Juan Ignacio Chela, a 6-2, 2-6, 6-4 winner over Alex Corretja, in Sunday's final. ''
I don't want to risk it,'' said Haas, the 25-year-old German who reached a career-high No.
2 in the world this year before health and family problems set him back.
Derek Jeter tested his neck during a batting practice session today and declared himself ready to play shortstop for the Yankees in Saturday's spring training game.
Jeter, a player who hates to discuss injuries, could finally admit how much the injury had unnerved him. ''
When it first happened, I thought I'd broken my neck,'' Jeter said. ''
I'd never hurt my neck before, so I didn't know what to think.''
Jeter felt a sharp pain in his neck when he turned left to swing at an inside pitch during batting practice last Sunday.
He went to the trainer's room instantly.
While the Yankees called the strained neck muscle a minor injury, one team official said Jeter had experienced temporary numbness in his fingers and toes.
But an M.R.I. test was negative and Jeter showed rapid improvement after wearing a heated neck wrap for several hours a day and using muscle relaxants.
On Monday, the Yankees said that Jeter would miss at least five days.
Today was the fifth day he did not play.
AT the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven, the exhibition ''Call and Response: Journeys in African Art'' doesn't sit still.
It takes great leaps geographically and through different modes of art, and requires similar mental leaps on the part of viewers.
The show is inspired by a widespread practice in African communities: a leader begins a song and is answered by a supporting chorus.
Sometimes there is overlap with the chorus breaking in before the soloist has finished.
This results in innovation and intriguing new art forms.
The curators, Sarah Adams, Lyneise Williams and Barbaro Martinez-Ruiz, have applied this dynamic mode to African art objects.
Exhibitions that are rooted in concepts rather than in tangible works of art are often incoherent with little to anchor them. ''
Call and Response'' avoids this problem by having plenty of intriguing and unusual objects and by explaining the cultural implications in great detail (an ample catalog accompanies the show).

An array of sculptural objects including ''power figures,'' three-dimensional objects studded with nails and used for healing purposes, is given added dynamism through the placement of a mirror at the back of the display that reflects the often-forbidding figures in the round.
Benign, but intriguing objects include a ''maternity figure'' composed of a series of energy-giving circles.
Spain's Interior Ministry announced Monday that the No.
2 leader of the militant Basque separatist group ETA had been arrested during a police raid in southwestern France.
Harriet Aguirre Garcia, said to be in his mid-20's, was arrested Monday morning after police raided his apartment in Aurillac, France, the ministry said in a statement.
The raid, which also captured two other ETA suspects, followed several major arrests in the past year that Spanish investigators say have decimated the group's leadership ranks.
ETA has not carried out a fatal attack since May 2003, and Spanish officials say that the organization is rudderless, divided and weaker than it has ever been.

After the arrests, Jose Antonio Alonso, the interior minister, said during a news conference in Madrid that Mr. Aguirre was the leader of ETA's so-called commando units, which are responsible for carrying out the group's bombings, assassinations and other attacks, which have killed more than 800 people since 1968.
Spanish officials describe him as the most-wanted member of ETA after Garikoitz Aspiazu, also known as Cherokee, who is suspected of being ETA's top leader.
Mr. Aguirre is ''of maximum importance in the top circle of the terrorist group ETA,'' Mr. Alonso said. ''
He is in the most important part of the circle, its military apparatus.''
The raid on Monday also led to the arrests of Idoia Mendizabal Mugica, identified as a subordinate of Mr. Aguirre's in her late 20's, and a third person yet to be identified, the ministry said.
New Yorkers have an amazing knack of creating their own problems, then setting up cottage industries to solve them.
They purposefully live in a place 20 miles from any true food source and have farm-picked vegetables delivered monthly to their apartments.
They park their cars in the cheapest garage they can find, then have to take a cab to them.
They choose to sit for 12 hours a day craning their necks at a computer screen, and then get an expensive massage to feel better.

Now, stores that have been sprouting up all over the nation to cater to those with back, neck and shoulder pain have made their way to New York, following on the heels of the 10-minute massage industry pioneered by the Great American Backrub chain.
In the last few months, two new stores, JoAnne's Bed and Back Shop and Relax the Back Shop, have opened in Manhattan, the first of several stores each company is hoping to open in the region.
The theory is simple.

People who spend all day staring at computers, perhaps following up with a gym workout, are time bombs -- minutes from a strained lumbar region, a throbbing trapezius and a neck with a permanent crick. ''
A lot of the injuries and problems we see in New York are related to posture and to people sitting for a longer period of time,'' said Susan Bergholtz, a licensed physical therapist in Manhattan. ''
With typewriters, people used to get up and walk around.

It will be a few more weeks before Long Island feels the real impact of the Supreme Court decision that sanctioned the ban on abortion information and counseling within federally funded family planning programs  [ "5 Agencies Adapt to Abortion Ruling," July 7 ] .
As we await word from Washington on the specific follow-up to this decision, one thing is clear.
If these dangerous regulations survive the storm of opposition sweeping across the nation and through Congress, their effect will be swift and devastating.
Planned Parenthood of Nassau County stands to lose over $150,000 annually because of our refusal to comply with this "gag rule."
It will be difficult if not impossible to replace these vital funds.
However, more is at stake here than money -- much more.

While the White House, with the blessing of the Supreme Court, sees fit to trample upon the First Amendment and the rights of all women who turn to Planned Parenthood in their hour of need, our commitment is to our patients who deserve to hear the truth from their medical provider.

Therefore, we will continue to give pregnant women and teen-agers information and counseling on all their options, including abortion -- so that they can make responsible decisions about their health care and their lives.
No dictate from Washington will change this stand.
But what I fear will change is our capacity to respond to the ever increasing demand for our services.

Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld arrived at this Caspian Sea port on Wednesday to warn that the inland ocean, which produces oil as well as caviar, is also a transit route for terrorists, unconventional weapons and narcotics.

In meetings with the new president, Ilham Aliyev, and the defense minister, Gen. Safar Abiyev, Mr. Rumsfeld also opened a fresh dialogue on how this former Soviet republic could fit into the United States military's changing global structure.

Azerbaijan provided overflight rights during the war in Afghanistan, and Pentagon officials have said they might consider asking for increased access to its military bases and even permission to rotate American troops across its soil.
But Pentagon officials have given no indications that requests would be made to base large numbers of troops permanently here.
Instead, the goal would be to guarantee speedy access to bases so that the American military could respond more quickly to a crisis than is possible today.
At an evening news conference, Mr. Rumsfeld stressed that the Pentagon is only discussing with its allies a set of concepts that ''have not yet evolved into specific proposals.''

In addition to straddling territory considered an arc of instability by Bush administration officials, Azerbaijan is strategically located along the Caspian Sea, which officials describe as an ungoverned waterway for America's adversaries.
Mr. Rumsfeld said the United States would work with Azerbaijan to improve its ability to secure its territorial waters.
Speaking of the Caspian Sea more broadly, he said those waters had provided transit for unconventional weapons and narcotics.
Senior Pentagon officials went further, saying they have intelligence pointing to terrorists who have traveled the Caspian as well.
Pedro Martinez received intravenous fluids at a local hospital Friday after complaining of a fever, apparently the result of food poisoning.
Martinez also underwent testing, including a CT scan of his abdomen, to confirm that his stomach ailment was not caused by appendicitis, General Manager Omar Minaya said.
Martinez was released Friday night and rejoined the team before Saturday's game against the Cubs. ''
The IV made me feel better,'' he said.
Minaya said: ''We just wanted to make sure that everything was O.K. Everything was clear and everything was fine.
It was precautionary more than anything else.''
Minaya said Martinez complained of a fever after Friday afternoon's game and was taken to Northwestern Memorial Hospital.
He was accompanied by the head trainer, Ray Ramirez.
Martinez had not been feeling well since Tuesday evening, when he ate contaminated chicken.
He had lost at least three pounds and was not in his usual good spirits Friday.

Ever since President Bush was forced to admit that he was spying on Americans' telephone calls and e-mail without warrants, his lawyers have fought to keep challenges to the program out of the courts.
Yesterday, that plan failed.
A federal judge in Detroit declared the eavesdropping program to be illegal and unconstitutional.

She also offered a scathing condemnation of what lies behind the wiretapping -- Mr. Bush's attempt to expand his powers to the point that he can place himself beyond the reach of Congress, judges or the Constitution. ''
There are no hereditary kings in America and no powers not created by the Constitution,'' wrote Judge Anna Diggs Taylor of the United States District Court in Detroit.
Her decision was based on a lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union.

She said Mr. Bush violated the 1978 Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act when he ordered the National Security Agency to spy without a warrant on international phone calls and e-mail by Americans and foreign residents of the United States.
She noted that the surveillance law was passed to prohibit just this sort of presidential abuse of power and provided ample flexibility for gathering vital intelligence.
She also said that the program violated the Fourth Amendment, which prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures, as well as the rights of free speech and association granted by the First Amendment.

The ruling eviscerated the absurd notion on which the administration's arguments have been based: that Congress authorized Mr. Bush to do whatever he thinks is necessary when it authorized the invasion of Afghanistan.

Anyone who has ever been trapped in voice-mail hell -- when a computer-generated voice answers the phone and gives five minutes of options you can't escape -- will latch onto the neat, technophobic idea behind "The Net."
Sandra Bullock, as a meek computer expert named Angela Bennett, stumbles across a program so powerful it can tamper with Wall Street, air-traffic control and the Federal Government.
When the program's vile owners come after her, they create a big-time equivalent of the machine that ate your bank card: the computers eat her identity.
Her fingerprints, Social Security number and picture I.D. are transferred to someone else, and Angela Bennett vanishes.
If the computers say you don't exist, how can you prove that you do?
This paranoid fantasy is so resonant that it makes "The Net" an enjoyably creepy thriller, even though Irwin Winkler belongs to the nothing-is-too-obvious school of directing.
To understand Angela, imagine Ms. Bullock's character in "While You Were Sleeping" if her life had turned into a nightmare instead of a fairy-tale come true.
She has the same lank hair, the same baggy sweaters whose arms are too long.
Her idea of dinner is pizza and M&M's.
Ms. Bullock probably should retire her sweet and lonely type after this, but here she still makes the character plausible and appealing.
The main street of this tiny village, as with many towns in the arc of destruction throughout southern Lebanon, looks as if several tornadoes crashed through it.
Most of the houses have been reduced to heaps of rubble or hollowed-out shells.

Although nearly all of the roughly 900,000 refugees -- about a quarter of the Lebanese population -- who fled the monthlong war between Israel and Hezbollah guerrillas have returned over roads pocked with bomb and artillery craters, fully a third cannot move back into their family homes, aid agencies say.
The homes are ruined or are too dangerous to inhabit because of unexploded cluster bombs, which have killed 11 people and wounded 43 since the cease-fire began 10 days ago, the agencies say. ''
The main problem is their houses are destroyed or its too dangerous because of unexploded ordnance,'' said Reem Alsalem, a spokeswoman for the United Nations High Commission for Refugees.

Lebanon, the United Nations and independent aid agencies are totaling an enormous tally of damage that includes airports, ports, water and sewage treatment facilities, electrical plants, 80 bridges and 94 roads, more than 25 gas stations, 900 other businesses and 30,000 homes or shops.
The war destroyed a major piece of the economic recovery in Lebanon, which was counting on a record year for tourism.

But here, far from the glitter of Beirut, what surprises the villagers is what they see as mean, gratuitous destruction by Israeli soldiers still stationed nearby after the cease-fire took effect: water and electricity systems smashed, furniture and valuables shattered or burned, cars shot up or destroyed. ''
They took the imam's car and returned it completely ruined,'' said Muhammad Hamoud, 40, the village mayor. ''
They want us to be afraid.''
Lawrence Taylor has tried everything possible for his ailing hamstring.
Ultrasound, massage, even stretching.
So now, desperate for an answer, he is going to try acupuncture.

Taylor is scheduled to visit Dr. Nan-sung Chu on Tuesday to try the treatment in which slender needles are inserted in specific areas of the body to relieve muscular spasms and speed the healing process.
He got the idea from talking to Jets safety Ronnie Lott after Sunday's Giants-Jets game.
Taylor has been ineffective recently with just two tackles and no sacks in his last three games.
He had just one tackle against the Jets.
The hamstring in his left leg has bothered him for most of the season and is raising questions about how much longer he can play the game. "
It is a non-traditional approach and we don't feel it's going to be harmful," the Giants' head trainer, Ronnie Barnes, said of the acupuncture, not exactly giving the procedure a ringing endorsement.
Taylor, when asked how the hamstring felt, said: "Fine, I guess.

Vicente  Fox Quesada, the next president of  Mexico  a land he envisions far closer to the United States, with borders no more than lines on a map -- started laying out his vision to the present and future leaders of the United States today.
Mr. Fox, who takes office on Dec. 1, met with President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore; he is to meet Gov. George W. Bush in Texas on Friday.

At the White House, the State Department and the vice president's residence, he was congratulated for winning the fairest election in Mexican history on July 2, defeating the ruling party and ending its seven decades of often authoritarian and corrupt government.
President Clinton called the Mexican leader's victory ''a truly historic affirmation of genuine democracy.''
A measure of good will -- rare among many of the two men's predecessors -- appeared to flow between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Fox. ''
You're walking on clouds,'' President Clinton told Mr. Fox during their private meeting, according to aides.
The thorniest issues dividing the two nations -- drugs, migration, trade disputes -- were discussed, but not debated, aides on both sides said.
Mr. Fox's vision of a future in which people and their possessions can move far more freely across the 2,000-mile border is not shared by official Washington, or by either presidential contender.
That frontier has become a battle front, as the United States fights its long and often unsuccessful war against drug traffickers and illegal immigrants heading north.
Mr. Gore found the idea of open borders ''clearly problematic,'' said his national security adviser, Leon Fuerth, and Mr. Bush repeated today that he thought ''we ought to enforce our borders.''

Even with Pentagon attention riveted on Yugoslavia, the United States has quietly stepped up what amounts to a low-level conflict with Iraq, with almost daily skirmishes that have resulted in destroying Iraqi radar sites and reports of the deaths of dozens of Iraqi civilians.
The Pentagon accused President Saddam Hussein of Iraq this week of placing air-defense missiles and radar sites in civilian neighborhoods.
By endangering civilians, the tactic could be seen as an attempt to hinder American attacks on those sites.
The move would also make it easier for the Iraqis to hide their weapons and  have a clear shot at American warplanes that are patrolling northern and southern Iraq.

Administration official said they feared that Mr. Hussein might be planning a major confrontation with the United States in the belief that the American military is stretched thin and distracted as a result of the Balkan conflict.
Reports in the Middle East last week quoted the Iraqi leader as predicting a ''crucial'' showdown with the United States.

Despite the strains on United States forces, American officials said, the United States can wage war against both Yugoslavia and Iraq, and the number of American planes on patrols over Iraq is nearly at full strength.

On Monday, American jet fighters launched missiles against an air-defense site in a civilian area of northern Iraq, after the pilots had reported that they had come under fire by surface-to-air missiles.
Iraq said two civilians were killed and 12 were wounded in the raids near Mosul, 220 miles north of Baghdad.
Other accounts of civilian deaths in Iraq have also circulated.
When reporters entered the Toronto Raptors' locker room and descended on a smiling Vince Carter before the game, the locker next to him was conspicuously empty.
Tracy McGrady did not need the attention.
He needed to give himself a pep talk. ''
Don't go out there and try to do too much and make a fool out of yourself,'' the 20-year-old McGrady was whispering to himself hours before his first playoff game. ''
You've played on national TV before, and this is just another level.''
Later, in a Madison Square Garden hallway after the Knicks' 92-88 victory, McGrady would elaborate on his own advice. ''
I just wanted to play smart and not force anything,'' he said.

While Carter was melting under the spotlight and suffocating under the Knicks' double-teaming, trapping defense, throwing up air balls to finish 3 for 20 from the field with 16 points, McGrady was thriving from the lack of attention.
Carter came in to his first playoff game with the expectations that cling to the last anointed Olympian and newest league icon.
But it was McGrady who scored a game-high 25 points and pulled down 10 rebounds yesterday.
General Motors and a battery technology company will start commercial-scale production of nickel metal-hydride batteries for electric cars next year, the companies announced yesterday.
Nickel metal-hydrides store about twice as much electricity per pound as lead-acid batteries, and can deliver the energy quickly.
A Geo Metro converted to electricity with nickel metal-hydrides won an electric car race in Phoenix early this year by traveling more than 200 miles at highway speeds without recharging.

The batteries, already in wide use in laptop computers, were developed by Ovonic Battery, a subsidiary of Energy Conversion Devices of Troy, Mich. John W. Adams, president of GM Ovonic, a joint venture of the two companies, said that in tests, batteries sized for automobiles had been recharged to 60 percent capacity in less than 15 minutes.
The batteries are maintenance-free and are expected to last the lifetime of the vehicles, he said. "

Our objective is to advance the technology for electric vehicle application on a global scale," Mr. Adams said at a news conference during an electric vehicle conference in Anaheim, Calif. He said the batteries would be offered for sale to all takers.
GM Ovonic did not say where it would build the batteries, or how much they would cost.
The nickel used in the batteries is substantially more expensive than materials used in most other batteries.
They are not now commercially available for cars, but one expert on electric cars, Robert Wills, an engineer in Temple, N.H., said they would cost roughly four times as much as lead-acid.
The price would fall with mass production, he said.

Three companies and an academic center said today that they were forming a $40 million research consortium to take information now pouring in from human genome research and use it to identify possible new drugs and treatments.

The new consortium will be based at the center, the Whitehead Institute/M.I.T. Center for Genome Research, in Cambridge, Mass., a leading group in the current global project to map humans' entire genetic complement.

The three businesses involved are the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company of New York, Millenium Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Cambridge and Affymetrix Inc., of Santa Clara, Calif. They will initially contribute $8 million annually for five years to the consortium, as well as make some of their own scientists and resources available to it.
In the venture, Bristol-Myers Squibb, the pharmaceutical giant, is joining two less-well-known companies, each of which held initial public stock offerings within the last year.
Millenium researches genes associated with a range of diseases such as cancer, type II diabetes and asthma.
Affymetrix develops and makes a genetic information system that analyzes genetic data to better monitor and treat certain diseases.
Shares of all three companies rose today.
Bristol-Myers Squibb shares jumped $3.125, to $65.625; those of Millenium climbed $1.75, to $14.875, and those of Affymetrix advanced $1.50, to $22.25.

The consortium is the first of its kind, though it is unlikely to be alone in the field long, according to Dr. Eric S. Lander, the director of the Whitehead center and the scientist designated to lead the laboratories of the new consortium.
Dr. Lander has divested himself of his stock in Millenium and Affymetrix to run the consortium from his academic post.

To the Editor: "When the Geneticists' Fingers Get in the Food" states, "scientists keep insisting that there is nothing to be concerned about" when bovine growth hormone is used to make cows into "veritable milk machines" (The Week in Review, Feb. 20).
But many scientists are very concerned.
Forget about the question of hormones in the milk.
It's a diversionary issue, the least of our worries about bovine growth hormone.
We are concerned about the health of the cows: excessive milk production reportedly makes them suffer continuously from bruised udders and brings on an early death from metabolic stress.
This is a cruel way to treat a gentle creature.

And we are also concerned because the increased incidence of infection among herds receiving the hormone requires increased use of antibiotics, which in turn raises the specter of transfer of antibiotic resistance from cow bacteria to human pathogens.
There are several known ways for this to happen.
Antibiotic resistance is a real threat to human health.
We are concerned about stimulating hormone-treated cows to eat more fodder to produce more milk when there is already a milk surplus, which taxpayers are subsidizing.
The MetroStars put their new triple threat  Rodrigo Faria, Diego Serna and Clint Mathis -- on display tonight, and the New England Revolution had no solution or response.
The MetroStars, trailing New England, 1-0, scored three unanswered goals in the second half before 13,234 shivering fans at Giants Stadium for an emphatic 3-1 victory in their season opener. ''
I just can't say enough about Diego, Clint and Rodrigo up top,'' said MetroStars defender Steve Jolley, who marked New England's dangerous Mamadou Diallo for most of the match. ''
It was fantastic.
I haven't seen that kind of work on this team in a long, long time.
They just have so much speed up there and they work so hard, it's just so nice to see.''
Faria, last year's Major League Soccer rookie of the year when he scored eight goals, scored twice tonight.
Mathis, playing in his first league match since last May because of surgery on his right knee, scored the third goal for the MetroStars.
The threesome combined for 12 of the MetroStars' 19 shots, 6 by Faria and 3 each by Serna and Mathis. ''
It was really our first game together, and I think you could see that some of the guys were nervous early,'' Mathis said. ''

Cable cars may look quaint swooping up and down the streets of San Francisco, but for Dorcey Winant, the white-and-black streetcars that began passing beneath her windows in April hold far less charm. ''
They're huge, and they sound like an 18-wheeler with flat tires,'' said Ms. Winant, a television director. ''

These are no Rice-a-Roni trolleys, especially when they wake you up at 5:45 a.m.'' For those who live along the route of the new Hudson-Bergen Light Rail line, the return of the streetcar after a half-century's absence is igniting more anger than nostalgia.
Claiming that the trolleys are destroying their quality of life, a group of residents is taking legal action to force New Jersey Transit to reduce the noise the trains make.
They say the agency lied when it told them the system would be unobtrusive.
The wheels screech and thump, the overhead electrical equipment howls and even the heaviest sleepers say they are roused by the bells and horns that sound at every intersection.
For those who live near the stations, high-powered station lights fill their apartments with a charmless, round-the-clock glare. ''
I feel like I'm living in a subway tunnel,'' said Donna Gloeckner, an executive at the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund. ''
I've become very cranky.''
Even her cat, Max, has been adversely affected, she said. ''

Liz Claiborne Inc., one of the largest fashion apparel companies in the United States, bought the clothing manufacturer Ellen Tracy yesterday for $170 million, plus the assumption of $10 million in debt.
Ellen Tracy, a working partnership between Herbert Gallen, the chief executive, and his wife, Linda Allard, the chief designer, had sales last year of $171 million.

The acquisition brings Liz Claiborne -- which had sales of $3.45 billion last year -- up a notch in prestige, analysts said, landing a manufacturer that sits at the high end of what is called the bridge market in the fashion trade.
Bridge companies like Ellen Tracy sit between less-expensive ''better and moderate'' labels like Jones New York and the luxury designer labels, like Ralph Lauren and Calvin Klein. ''
Herb Gallen has been a fixture in New York retailing since 1949,'' said Gilbert W. Harrison, chairman of Financo, the investment bankers that represented Ellen Tracy in the deal.
Within the industry, the company is known for selling most of its clothes at full price -- without resorting to discounts and promotions.
Ellen Tracy, which is a privately held company, was almost sold seven years ago to Bain Capital, but the deal collapsed, much to Mr. Gallen's disappointment.

Mr. Harrison said that one reason this deal worked was that Paul R. Charron, Liz Claiborne's chief executive, had become friendly with Mr. Gallen over the last six months, ''which enabled obstacles and hurdles to be overcome.''
Rumors of the negotiations between the companies had been in the wind for months ''and it almost blew the deal,'' Mr. Harrison said.
To preserve a secrecy that was already at risk, the companies signed the formal purchase agreement late Sunday night -- and closed on it early yesterday morning.

Frederick M. Lussen, a police detective who investigated many of the city's most famous cases in the 1960's and 70's, from gangland shootings to the Mad Bomber, died on Oct. 4, at his home in Nanuet, N.Y. He was 91.

As the son of a police officer and the father of another, Mr. Lussen was so loyal to the force that he stayed on well past retirement, despite being eligible for a pension that would have been equal to his salary, his son, John said.
From 1964 until early 1971, he served as chief of detectives, an exceptionally long tenure in the highly visible post.
He commanded 3,481 detectives.
Two of his most famous cases involved shootings of mobsters.
One was the nonfatal shooting of Frank Costello, known as ''the boss of racketeers,'' in 1957.
The other was the slaying of Albert Anastasia, chief executioner of Murder Inc., in 1957.
As often happened in organized crime cases in those days, there were arrests and press conferences, but no convictions in either case. ''
You don't solve those cases,'' his son said.
Another case he was involved in was that of the bomber who planted as many as 37 bombs that injured at least 10 people in the 1950's.
In its fight to fend off a hostile takeover by Computer Associates International Inc., the Computer Sciences Corporation said yesterday that it would go as far as selling itself to another company.
In a letter formally rejecting Computer Associates' $108-a-share tender offer, Computer Sciences said that the offer ''does not represent fair value for our company.''

And in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, it said that it expected ''to engage in discussions and may engage in negotiations with other parties regarding strategic alternatives, including a possible merger of the company.''
Such an explicit discussion of selling itself ''went a little further than I expected,'' Stephen T. McClellan, an analyst for Merrill Lynch, said.
He said that it indicated the vehemence with which Computer Sciences objected to being taken over by Computer Associates, which sells software used primarily by big organizations.
Computer Sciences offers consulting and custom programming and operates computers on behalf of corporations and governments. ''
The trench warfare has begun,'' Mr. McClellan said.
Even so, analysts and investment bankers said that it seemed unlikely that another bidder for the company would emerge.

Most of the large potential buyers for Computer Sciences, including I.B.M. and Electronic Data Systems, are believed to have already decided not to bid for the company, which is based in El Segundo, Calif. ''It's very difficult for me to see a white knight emerging,'' said Thomas T. Rooney, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin, & Jenrette.
Computer Sciences may, however, use other tactics to fend off Computer Associates, analysts said.
The battle between the city and community gardeners goes on.
Bette Midler put a spotlight on community gardens in May 1999, when her group, the New York Restoration Project, raised $1 million to help buy 114 gardens on city-owned lots.
The city had wanted to auction those properties for development.
In February 2000, a state court ordered officials not to uproot any gardens until a lawsuit brought by the state to protect green spaces was resolved.
But the city has selected dozens of other gardens for destruction, and has been lining up developers, hoping for a favorable legal outcome.
Garden advocates say that about 500 of 700 gardens on city lots could still be developed. ''
There are 50 or more that are in danger at the moment,'' said Eric Goldstein, director of urban programs at the National Resources Defense Council, an environmental organization.
Among those are 10 in the South Bronx, including Franklin Memorial on Cauldwell Avenue near 165th Street, which was founded in 1976 and is the borough's oldest community garden.
The City Council Land Use Committee recently approved a plan to build 196 moderate-income homes on those sites, but the plan faces an uphill battle before the Finance Committee.

More than 25 gardens are scheduled for destruction in Bedford-Stuyvesant and other Brooklyn neighborhoods, including one in East New York that provides produce for sale on Saturdays at the farmers market at nearby New Lots and Jerome Avenues.
FINALLY, it seems, value matters.

After years when indiscriminate investors were willing to ignore matters like competitive strategy and profit -- driving stock prices to unsustainable levels -- a focus on business fundamentals is coming back into style.
And that is a good thing as far as Richard A. Mayo is concerned. ''
We always had trouble seeing how you value companies that earn no money and might not earn any for three years,'' said Mr. Mayo, who runs the $120 million Pelican Fund.
''What we can see in the marketplace now is that valuation matters and will continue to matter for a long time.''
His unwavering attention to value has served him well in a declining market.

The fund returned 5.6 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended Thursday, versus 2.1 percent for its large-value peers and 2.9 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500 index, according to Morningstar Inc. For the last 12 months, it returned 15 percent, versus a 0.2 percent loss for its peer group and a loss of 23 percent for the S.& P. His investment style is opportunistic, Mr. Mayo said, like its namesake's fishing style. ''
Pelicans fly around until they see fish, and then swoop down and gobble them up,'' Mr. Mayo explained from his office, which overlooks Boston Harbor.
Pelican is the only retail fund offered by Grantham, Mayo, Van Otterloo & Company, which also manages about $20 billion in institutional accounts.

Mr. Mayo, 58, works with six analysts to select the 100 or so stocks in the fund from roughly 3,000 United States companies with market capitalizations of more than $350 million; the fund's weighted average market cap is $35.6 billion.

Federal prosecutors in Washington State today charged an abortion rights supporter with criminal violations of the Federal abortion clinic access law for making threatening telephone calls to anti-abortion groups.

In a two-count indictment returned by a Federal grand jury in Yakima, in south-central Washington, prosecutors charged that the man made threatening telephone calls to a counseling service that encourages pregnant women to consider alternatives to abortion.
The charges represented the first case in which the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act has been applied to a person advocating abortion rights.
The law was enacted last year after longstanding complaints of violence and accusations that anti-abortion demonstratators had intimidated women seeking abortions.
Representatives of abortions rights groups expressed surprise at the charges, and several said they were reviewing the indictment before making a comment.
A representative of the National Abortion Right Action League in Seattle said a clinic in Yakima had been the scene of protests by abortion opponents.
The charges were announced here this evening by the Justice Department in a statement that suggested that the case had been handled under the supervision of the department's headquarters.

The law, the statement said, permits the Government to prosecute people who use force or threats against any health care organization that provides reproductive services or counseling, even counseling against abortion.

The indictment charged that the abortion rights advocate, Daniel A. Mathison, telephoned the office of First Way, an anti-abortion counseling group in Wenatchee, Wash., on Jan. 2, threatening to kill workers at the office.

The indictment also said Mr. Mathison called the National Life Center hot line in Wooodbury, N.J., telling an operator that he had a gun and would shoot anti-abortion demonstrators at abortion clinics. "
AIRLINES and the travel industry have usually supported taxes earmarked for improvements in aviation or infrastructure.

But President Clinton's recent proposal to raise the tax on international departures from $6 a passenger to $16, with the money used to help offset the cost of attending college, has gone  over with the business travel community like the proverbial lead balloon.
The Air Transport Association termed the proposed increase "an absolute outrage  to air travelers who already pay a long list of taxes and fees totaling more than $6 billion annually."

Carol Hallett, the association president, said the proposal would cost an additional $500 million a year, "and not a dime will be used to fund runways, radar systems, or anything else that benefits aviation safety or overall system capacity."
She added that the tax would lead to a new round of bankruptcies and layoffs by aircraft makers.
The Travel Industry Association of America said travelers "should not have to shoulder a disproportionate part" of the President's initiative.
And the National Business Travel Association, which represents more than 1,650 corporations, vowed to fight the measure in Congress.

In a letter to President Clinton, the association's executive director, Norman R. Sherlock, wrote: "Raising the departure tax would substantially increase the financial burden on  business travelers and would impact the operative balances of many corporations  who operate in the global arena.

This type of measure is counterproductive since the overriding policy of the United States should be to promote business enterprise and travel because of the enormous benefits this generates for the economy."

In a separate statement, Judie Shyman, the executive director of the National Business Travel Association, declared, "Washington must learn that business travel is a national asset, not a gold mine of last resort."
PERHAPS if Guam contacted Japan or China, asking to be invaded, its complaints would be taken more seriously by Americans.
But Guam is a dependable American base, ever loyal, and no one in Washington pays attention to a quiet little mouse.
So these days, the mouse is wondering whether to roar.
Guam is America's military outpost in the Pacific, a beautiful island that is a crucial link in a chain of bases allowing the United States to project its power in Asia and beyond.
But the residents want the military to hand back land and the Government to hand over more political autonomy.
And local officials warn that unless the Pentagon pays them heed, it should not assume that Guam can always be counted on. ''
We're going to be thorns in the lion's paw,'' grumbles Gov. Carl T. C. Gutierrez, who, like nearly all locally elected officials, wants a better deal from the Defense Department. ''
We're going to make it difficult.''
There is no crisis on this tranquil island of sand, sun and palm trees.
But there are plenty of uncertainties for security planners around the region.
LEAD: Pamela Alexandra Milch and Paul Johnson were married yesterday at Overlook, the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Milch of Baltimore.

The bridegroom is a son of Mary Lou La Pierre of Seattle and W. Morgan Johnson of Sacramento, Calif. Pamela Alexandra Milch and Paul Johnson were married yesterday at Overlook, the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Milch of Baltimore.

The bridegroom is a son of Mary Lou La Pierre of Seattle and W. Morgan Johnson of Sacramento, Calif. Tom L. Freudenheim, the assistant secretary for museums of the Smithsonian Institution, and Margaret M. Obrecht, a Presbyterian chaplain, officiated at the interfaith ceremony, and Cantor Judi Porecki signed the marriage certificate.
Mrs. Johnson, who will retain her name professionally, graduated from the Bryn Mawr School and Trinity College in Hartford.
She is a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at New York University.

Her father, a former professor of orthopedic surgery at Johns Hopkins University, is the chairman and president of Igene Biotechnology Inc., an industrial and agricultural chemical company in Columbia, Md. He was a special assistant in the White House Office of Science and Technology in the Johnson Administration.
Her mother, Margot Wurtzburger Milch, is a consumer affairs specialist in the Office of the Attorney General of Maryland and a former president of the trustees of the Baltimore Museum of Art.
The bridegroom, a vice president in research at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, graduated from the University of California at Berkeley.
His father is the senior partner of the law firm of Johnson, Fort, Meissner & Joseph in Sacramento.
His mother is a development officer at Washington State University.
IN 1992, Larry Saez, a Secret Service agent since 1980, was assigned to the protective detail for Bill Clinton, presidential candidate.
Several years later, he was assigned to the White House.
But guarding the president is an intense task, with long hours and frequent holiday and weekend work.
So Mr. Saez was delighted when he was named resident agent in charge of the White Plains bureau.
From the start, he enjoyed the shift in emphasis from protective to investigative duties.
He was also thrilled with the more regular hours.
Then he got the phone call that the first family was moving to Chappaqua.
Mr. Saez' laughter at this twist of fate fills his White Plains office.

Although the Secret Service remains highly guarded about its operations -- particularly its protective measures for the president and his family -- Mr. Saez spoke willingly about the focus of his office, both before and after the Clintons' arrival in Chappaqua.

Beforehand, Mr. Saez estimated that 90 percent of the work of his bureau -- which has jurisdiction over Westchester, Putnam, Dutchess, Rockland, Orange and Sullivan Counties -- was investigative, with only 10 percent protective.

WITH the Victorian and Greek Revival homes of Harbor Road, a legacy of seafaring men, behind them and views of Southport Harbor in front of them, picknickers and artists gather on balmy fall weekends at Perry's Green in Southport.
Like many other activities in this tiny unincorporated village in the southwest corner of the Town of Fairfield, Conn., the gatherings are linked to the water.
One of the best-known local figures is Howard Burr, 92 years old, who smokes a corn-cob pipe and has been looking after Ye Yacht Yard for 65 years.
His birthdays are celebrated at the municipal dock. "
Southport is not a made thing," said V. Louise Higgins, the village historian. "
It's not a Disneyland, it's not a museum.
You don't have to invent it.
This is where people live."
In 1661, the area was a marshy part of Fairfield -- Sasqua Fields -- that settlers from elsewhere in New England bought from the Paugussett Indians.
Within a year, farmers were tilling the soil and grazing their sheep and cattle and Perry's Mill was grinding oats, rye and corn along Mill River.
Romeo Salta, one of the first Manhattan restaurateurs to introduce fine Italian cuisine, died on Aug. 31 at his home in Manhattan.
He was 93.

Mr. Salta's namesake restaurant, Romeo Salta, on West 56th Street, opened in 1953 and was one of the first in Manhattan to offer elegant  Northern Italian cooking, although Mr. Salta was equally proud of the many Southern Italian dishes on his menu.
Pasta was prepared at the table and served fresh and hot, and dishes such as gnocchi, scampi and risotto were introduced, accompanied by fine Italian wines.
The northern origin of much of the food aside, patrons were greeted in an expansive Southern Italian manner and the decor was elaborate.
At the time that Mr. Salta operated the restaurant, there were only two establishments favored by serious Italian food lovers, Romeo Salta and San Marino, and each had its loyal devotees. ''
New York has never had an Italian restaurant as good as Romeo Salta was in its heyday,'' Mimi Sheraton, a former restaurant critic for The New York Times, said upon hearing about Mr. Salta's death.
Mr. Salta was born Romeo Saltalamacchia in Taranto, Italy, on Sept. 27, 1904, and raised in a state-run institution in Florence after his father's death in an Italian Navy submarine in 1910.
As soon as he was able, he, too, joined the submarine service.
After his discharge, he became a cabin steward and kitchen boy on several Italian liners, where he learned to cook.
Ballet Hispanico is looking better than ever these days.
There is an extra softness to the stretch of the dancers' bodies.
And the dancers' look of enjoyment was infectious in Pedro Ruiz's ''Guajira'' and David Rousseve's ''Somethin' From Nothin','' presented on Thursday night at the Joyce Theater.
The two dances have a ritualistic quality and suggest communities.

But Mr. Ruiz's stylized formal patterns and body shapes have a stark beauty that is quite different from the sultry vibrancy of the Latin dances Mr. Rousseve and the performers pour out across the stage.
Mr. Ruiz's 1999 ''Guajira,'' whose title refers to the women of the Cuban countryside, is set to music by Los Activos, Conjunto Cespedes and Jose Maria Vitier.
It is a slow, almost stately processional for lithe bodies through a day in what appears to be farm country.
The day begins with silhouetted, reclining bodies at dawn, arms up and forming birds' beaks to quiet percussion music and the distant crowing of roosters.
By day's end the eight men and women will have worked the fields, washed laundry in baskets and found lovers in one another.
Jeff Segal's lighting subtly suggests each shift in time.
Scotty Schulhofer, a man of few words, said it in a very few words before they ran the Tom Fool Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. "
There is no sure thing in horse racing," he said. "
There is only one way to win a race, but a thousand ways to lose one."

True and trite, but a 10-1 shot named Birdonthewire proved it all over again a few minutes later, when he circled a traffic jam that seemed to involve all five horses in the race and outran Schulhofer's 4-5 favorite Fly So Free by nearly two lengths.
Since there were only five horses on the track, it seemed unlikely they would get gridlocked entering the homestretch, but that apparently was one of the thousand ways you can lose a race.

Steppping Up Julie Krone finally bulled her way through the pack aboard Fly So Free, but it was late in the game because Craig Perret had already called an end run that sprang Birdonthewire into the lead.

And in the chase to the wire, Fly So Free generated his long-striding pursuit but missed by a length and three-quarters while the second favorite, Take Me Out, came flying home two more lengths back in third place.
Who is Birdonthewire?

A good allowance horse owned by Robert Kaufman and trained by Phil Serpe, an upwardly mobile horse making it for the first time in stakes company after running in the money 13 times in 18 lesser races.
This time, he ran the seven furlongs in a snappy 1 minute 204/5 seconds, matching the record for the race set in 1978 by J .O. Tobin.
LEAD: Paul Ludick, a 31-year-old furniture terrorist, designs chairs that cause occupants to sit up and shudder.

The back of his Apartheid Chair is fashioned from black-and-white chain link fencing.

His Chair-Noble, a play on Chernobyl, is a wooden stool shaped like a nuclear power plant.
The back of his Apartheid Chair is fashioned from black-and-white chain link fencing.
Pistols point from the Arms Chair, an easy chair calculated to make the sitter uneasy.
Yet some find security in guns, Mr. Ludick notes, even cap pistols like the ones in his chair.
He echoes this feeling with a homey upholstery fabric reminiscent of his childhood in Kent, Ohio: ''The colors, warm browns and yellows, are McDonald's colors.''
A one-of-a-kind design, the Arms Chair was featured in HG magazine as a ''Chair of the Month'' and sold to a collector for $4,200.
I spent seven years as an outdoor leadership instructor, starting at age 19.
I took people through storms, over passes, up technical rock climbs.
I once climbed 70 feet with no rope protection to get a rappel rope that was snagged on a little piece of rock.
In Yellowstone, I rescued two people with frostbite; I had to get them out before their feet thawed, because when that happens you're in screaming pain.
I was responsible for the group's safety, but also for their thriving as a community.
A lot of my passion for community came from seeing these strangers come together, help transform one another, then part.
I carried this idea forward to iVillage.com.
It's the real issues that make it happen.
Thousands of things in a person's life go right to the bone: your child has an illness, you hate your job, you have breast cancer.
Sometimes, it's not your friends who can help you, but others who have been through the same experience.
THERE'S nothing soft about the politics of hard science, as James E. Woods has recently discovered.

Last month, Dr. Woods, an engineer who studies indoor air quality and teaches at the Virginia Polytechnic Institute, received a $1.2 million grant to study building ventilation -- from Philip Morris, the big tobacco company.

Bad form and perhaps a conflict of interest, cried anti-smoking groups, citing his membership on the Environmental Protection Agency's science advisory board, which addresses issues relating to tobacco smoke.
Unfair, replied Dr. Woods, who says his belief that tobacco smoke is best controlled by eliminating smoking is well known. (
He quit smoking in 1974.)
Last year, while applying for the grant, he signed off on a science advisory board report that concluded that environmental tobacco smoke is a carcinogen.
Dr. Woods, 52, wants to compare two types of ventilation systems to see which is more effective in preventing exposure to all types of contaminants, not just tobacco. "
It is impossible to dictate in all places, at all times, that people won't smoke," he said. "
Do you do nothing and let exposure increase, or do you do exposure control?"
He stands on his credentials as a consultant for the American Lung Association and his years of research and teaching. "
Four men from Pennsylvania involved in a shootout with a New Jersey police officer on Friday were charged yesterday in the case, the police said.
Another police officer fatally shot a fifth man.
The four surviving suspects were charged with unlawful possession of a weapon, the Hunterdon County prosecutor's office said.
One of the men, Andre O. Warren, 22, was also charged with attempted murder of a police officer, cocaine possession and being a fugitive from justice.
All of them were from Allentown, Pa., and they were in custody last night.
The police said the dead man, Oneil T. McKoy, 21, was killed during the shootout in Clinton, N.J., after he fired a handgun at Steven Sexton, an officer from the State Department of Human Services.
Officer Sexton had encountered Mr. McKoy in a thicket around 6:30 a.m. Friday near the Hunterdon Developmental Center, the police said.
Officer Sexton ordered Mr. McKoy to freeze, police officials said, but the man opened fire.
When the officer returned fire, he struck and killed Mr. McKoy, the police said.
Earlier, Officer Sexton had been part of a manhunt for the five men after they were involved in another shootout with another police officer, the police said.

The trial of Marion True, a curator at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles charged with conspiring to import illegally excavated antiquities, was postponed here Monday after a brief hearing in criminal court.
The trial, which is being closely watched in the art world because of its potential repercussions for other museums with recently acquired antiquities, is now set to open on Nov. 16.
The court said it was deferring it because the defendants had not received notice of the charges translated into English.
Neither Ms. True nor her co-defendant, Emanuel Robert Hecht, 86, an American art dealer based in Paris, attended the hearing in a drab, low-ceilinged courtroom near the Vatican.
Both have denied the charges through their lawyers.
As the Getty's antiquities curator, Ms. True, 56, oversees a vast collection of Greek, Roman and Etruscan objects that began with purchases by J. Paul Getty in the 1950's.
During her two decades at the Getty, it has expanded to 50,000 objects through ambitious purchases and gifts from donors.
Italy has adopted tough new policies to thwart the trade in looted and illegally exported antiquities, which often eventually find their way to museums and private collectors in other countries. ''
This case is a signal to those who have despoiled Italy's underground patrimony,'' said Maurizio Fiorilli, a lawyer for Italy's Culture Ministry. ''
It's telling them we've noticed.''

Dell Inc., the largest personal computer maker, reported on Thursday that its first-quarter profit rose 28 percent on an increase in demand outside the United States and a strong finish to the quarter.
The company, based in Round Rock, Tex.,
said its profit increased to $934 million, from $731 million a year ago, and earnings increased to 37 cents a share, from 28 cents a year ago. ''
We remain confident and optimistic about our business,'' said Kevin B. Rollins, Dell's chief executive, in a conference call with analysts. ''
Dell continued to grow faster than the rest of the industry.''
Mr. Rollins said the company's sales outside the United States grew 21 percent in the quarter, which ended April 29, and now account for 42 percent of total revenue.
First-quarter revenue rose 16 percent, to $13.39 billion, from $11.54 billion in the period a year ago.
Dell experienced slower sales in February and March, then sales picked up in April, executives said. ''
By and large, my concerns for the quarter did not play out,'' said Brent Bracelin, an analyst at Pacific Crest Securities. ''
Dell shined in a very challenging quarter.''
For GLORIA STEINEM, it could have been "This Is Your Life."

A parade of friends and colleagues showered Ms. Steinem, the feminist leader, with praise at a tribute given by the Veteran Feminists of America on Wednesday  night at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue.

Speakers ranged from PHYLLIS ROSSER, Ms. Steinem's friend from their days at Smith College in the mid-1950's, who reminisced about singing "I Like Ike" songs, to REBECCA ADAMSON, who went with Ms. Steinem to Botswana in June to try  to help the Bushmen of the Kalahari Desert.
Ms. Adamson described how they had fought off fierce mosquitoes. "
Never did I imagine that I'd be sitting next to Gloria with smoldering elephant dung," she said.
But most of the speakers focused on the numerous causes for women, children and minorities they had worked on with her and on the ways in which she had helped them through personal crises. "
When I was diagnosed with breast cancer, it was Gloria who went with me to see that I had what I needed," BELLA ABZUG said.
One table was filled with the women who started Ms. magazine with Ms. Steinem in 1972.
One of them, PATRICIA CARBINE, said, "She allowed us to understand that leadership is strong, constant, funny, vulnerable and in no way afraid of loving and accepting love."
What was it like to listen to such a torrent of accolades? "
New Jersey's fiercely competitive health insurance market will soon become even rougher.
Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey yesterday agreed to merge with Anthem Inc., a big, diversified Midwestern insurer.
The merger will create  the nation's second-biggest holder of Blue Cross and Blue Shield franchises.

The deal will help give New Jersey Blue Cross, which already covers 1.9 million residents, the financial heft to slug it out in the managed-care market with the likes of U.S. Healthcare, Prudential and Oxford Health Plans.
The combined company would have more than $9 billion in combined annual revenues.

That would help the Newark-based Blue Cross company finance the costs  of moving thousands more New Jersey residents into health maintenance organizations and other managed care plans that help employers slow the growth of health costs.
Managed-care networks are costly to organize and to run, requiring extensive gathering and monitoring of costs, doctors' records and medical results.

There are 26 health maintenance organizations in New Jersey, and the new company hopes to grow even bigger by luring some into additional mergers, said William J. Marino, chief executive of New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield.
Mr. Marino said 400,000 more managed- care enrollees could be added over the  next few years to the 750,000 currently in the Blue Cross H.M.O. and discount network of doctors and hospitals.
He said that could bring more jobs to Newark,  which will be the administrative headquarters of Anthem East, the regional division that he will head as president. "
Lenovo, the Chinese computer company, said yesterday that it had recruited a senior vice president from a rival, Dell, as its new chief executive and president.
The management move comes seven months after the Chinese company completed its purchase of I.B.M.'s personal computer business.
Analysts say the arrival of the executive, William J. Amelio, suggests that Lenovo wants to move swiftly to generate growth to try to match Dell's prowess in global operating efficiency. ''

Clearly, Dell is targeted by this move,'' said Rob Enderle, principal analyst at the Enderle Group, a research firm in San Jose, Calif. Mr. Amelio succeeds Stephen M. Ward Jr., who led the management team that came from I.B.M. The Lenovo purchase of I.B.M.'s PC business, a $1.75 billion deal announced a year ago, has been widely seen as a sign of China's economic rise and the global ambitions of its corporations.
But while I.B.M. played a crucial role in creating the PC industry when it entered the market in 1981, the company rarely made money selling personal computers.
So there was a question about whether an I.B.M. executive like Mr. Ward was the right person to lead Lenovo.
Mr. Ward will remain a consultant to Lenovo.
Under Mr. Ward, Lenovo assembled an international management team from a variety of companies.
It attracted a $350 million investment from three private equity firms.
And the market share of Lenovo, the world's third-largest PC maker, after Dell and Hewlett-Packard, has increased slightly since the merger.
The political centerpiece of the Republican crime legislation passed by the House is the proposal for $10.5 billion in grants for the states to build prisons.
The operative word is political.
Because there is a deep public fear of violent crime in this country, every politician wants to look "tough" on crime.
What better way than building more prisons to house violent criminals for longer sentences?
But if you actually look at the facts, a huge prison-building program is not a rational way to fight crime.
Indeed, it will take us in the wrong direction -- and lock us into the mistake for a long time.
The rates of violent crimes that especially alarm us -- murder, robbery, rape -- are leveling off or going down.
Then why are the prisons so crowded?
Because they are full of non-violent drug offenders.
It is hardly a secret that severe drug laws, with long mandatory sentences for non-violent offenses, are the reason for the enormous increase in our prison population in recent years.
A day after a confrontation left five people injured in the Stapleton housing project on Staten Island, police officials and residents offered sharply different accounts of the scuffle yesterday.
Residents said the officers used excessive force, while police officials accused several people of inciting the violence.

Chief of Department Louis R. Anemone criticized the behavior of more than a dozen Stapleton residents, who he said first cheered the assault of a man on the street and then threw bottles and bricks at responding police officers.
Some witnesses, however, characterized the police as abusive to several people, including a woman whose son had died in police custody only a week before.
A total of 100 officers were eventually involved in the melee; four suffered minor injuries.

It was the most serious encounter between the police and residents of Staten Island since a drug-dealing suspect died in police custody two years ago at a nearby housing development, prompting a night of violence and protests.
The latest confrontation led about 80 people to march on the 120th Precinct station house in St. George and the offices of Borough President Guy V. Molinari on Sunday evening.
But yesterday, despite the heat, the Stapleton projects were quiet and police patrols were light.

The confrontation -- and another disturbance two weeks ago in Crown Heights,  Brooklyn -- have provided early tests of the leadership of the new Police Commissioner, Howard Safir, who has shown a willingness to rely on his top uniformed subordinate, Chief Anemone, to run day-to-day operations and supervise crises.
Mr. Safir said last night: "I believe the police have acted with restraint and the incident was resolved by dialogue between the department  and the community.
You didn't make it to the party?
Don't despair.

Last week Nabisco brought its yearlong celebration to its bakery in Fair Lawn in Bergen County, where more than 1,000 employees help make some of of the 7.5 billion Oreos eaten each year.
Employees were invited to share in the festivities by creating recipes featuring -- you guessed it.
Top honors went to this Oreo Rum Strawberry Pie, created by Gordano Aniscenko, who is involved in quality control for the bakery's first shift.
