LEAD: To the Editor: To the Editor: Norman Podhoretz, in ''Israel Isn't Suicidal'' (Op-Ed.
Oct. 22), makes it easy to prefer the status quo in the Middle East, but only by offering the worst-possible-case scenario as the sole alternative to it.

Of course, Israel and its friends do not, will not and should not support an independent Palestinian state run by the Palestine Liberation Organization that invites or permits Israel's enemies to use that new state to wipe out Israel.
But it is improper and unfair to suggest that anyone offering ideas about how to get an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue going is in favor of such a state.
Whatever the dangers may be in any kind of new Palestinian state -and nobody should ignore them - the issue is more immediate and more limited.
Although Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir once opposed implementing Camp David's commitment to autonomy for the Palestinians in the administered territories, he calls for it now.
He thus follows in the footsteps of Menachim Begin, the author of ''autonomy,'' who endorsed the ''legitimate rights of the Palestinians.''
Does Mr. Podhoretz believe these Israeli leaders were wrong in doing so?

The Shamir election proposal received general acclaim, across a wide spectrum of opinion in Israel and the United States, because it offered the possibility of resuming the peace process and providing self-governance for the Palestinians for at least an interim period.
Mr. Shamir has stated that after a period of autonomy there would be further discussions about unresolved issues.
This week Binney & Smith Inc., the manufacturer of Crayola crayons, brought back eight colors from retirement, albeit temporarily.
Last year, with much hoopla, the company stopped using maize, violet blue, raw umber, orange yellow, blue gray, green blue, orange red and lemon yellow and replaced them with neon colors.

The crayons, now called "classics," will be packaged separately from a box of 64 in a special commemorative tin with notes about the crayons and their retirement, said Mark J. O'Brien, a company spokesman.
The tin will retail for $6.99 and be available until January. "
The response has been amazing," said Mr. O'Brien, speaking of the withdrawal of the eight. "
You just have to watch an adult open that box and sniff it.
It's like a time machine."
For some, opening the green and yellow box is like Proust discovering 64 madeleines.
Mr. O'Brien, 32 years old, said he gets the feeling each morning in Binney & Smith's headquarters in Easton, Pa. As he opens his car door, he smells a billion crayons melting.
Some who protested the withdrawal of the eight said it was like removing a favorite baby blanket or toy.

Having beaten back price controls on prescription drugs in the United States, the American pharmaceutical industry is trying to roll them back overseas, with help from the administration and Congress.

In talks over a free trade agreement with Australia, American officials are pressing to water down the system under which the Australian government negotiates the prices it pays for prescription drugs, Mark Vaile, the Australian minister for trade, said here Wednesday.
Mr. Vaile said that the American negotiators had raised this ''in amongst a range of issues, not as a core issue.''
If successful, the United States could use this agreement as a benchmark for trade deals with other rich nations.

Loosening price controls is a priority for the drug industry, which gets most of its profits in the United States and argues that prices here could be lower if other nations paid their share of the cost of developing drugs.

Mr. Vaile, in a briefing for reporters, said that his government would stand firm against any terms that would affect ''the ability of the Australian government to provide inexpensive medicine to its citizens.''

He met here this week with Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, and confirmed that the issue would be on the agenda for formal talks between the countries in Washington next week.
The negotiators have set a Dec. 31 deadline for completing an agreement.

Analysts say that the drug issue could be part of the horse trading over Australia's desire to export more agricultural products to the United States and Washington's push to ease access to Australian markets for the American entertainment and service industries.
The legislation passed by Congress this week to establish a prescription drug benefit in the Medicare program specifically forbids the government to use its influence to negotiate lower drug prices.

At bars, restaurants and delicatessens around New York City yesterday, managers and patrons reacted with dismay, indifference and even relief to the news that a popular video lottery game would come to an end at midnight last night.
While the reactions were mixed, many bet that the game would re-emerge from the fractious budget dispute in Albany that led to its demise.
Gov. George E. Pataki, bowing to pressure from the State Legislature, withheld a provision to extend the keno-style game, Quick Draw, beyond its March 31 deadline.
This 11th-hour Albany brinkmanship left others to contemplate the loss of a far simpler game. ''

It's a game that a lot of the old-timers really like,'' said Raul Montero, the manager of El Barrio Sneaker Plus at 116th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, which operates a Quick Draw machine outside the store. ''
It's kind of like horse racing for them without the trip.''
At Mulvey's Tavern on Staten Island, the owner, John Mulvey, said it was the sad end to a civilized game. ''
Some customers don't even drink, but it brings them into the establishment to play,'' he said. ''
Maybe they drink coffee and soda.''

But Michael Keane, the bartender at the Blarney Stone restaurant at 48th Street and Eighth Avenue in Manhattan, celebrated Quick Draw's demise as the end of a hassle for his staff members, who had to take time to feed players' game cards into a lottery machine. ''
A new political party has come storming out of the Canadian west, riding some of the same gusts that Ross Perot rode as an independent candidate in last year's American Presidential election.

The Reform Party, building on anti-tax sentiment, strong feelings against immigrants and traditional opposition to Ottawa-based politicians, virtually swept Canada's two most western provinces, taking 46 of 58 Parliamentary seats in British Columbia and Alberta on Monday.
The western victories put the party just two short of being the official opposition in Canada.
Bloc Quebecois finished with 54 seats, all of them from its French Canadian stronghold of Quebec.
The Reform Party took 52 seats in all.
The Liberal Party gained 178 of Canada's 295 Parliamentary seats.
Polls showed the Reformists were expected to get just 12 seats.
But they wiped out the Conservatives and overwhelmed the left-leaning New Democratic Party.
Nationally, they received about 18 percent of the popular vote.
Eyes on Ottawa "We expect to be the governing party in four years' time," said Gordon Shaw, executive director of the party. "
With the playoffs looming, this is the kind of efficient work that Knick Coach Pat Riley wants to see.
After losing three of their last four games at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks needed a solid showing before the home crowd last night against the young and mistake-prone Detroit Pistons.
That's exactly what the Knicks turned in during their 113-96 victory.
New York's overall team play was enough to douse the sporadic brush fires provided by the Pistons' Grant Hill, Joe Dumars and Allan Houston.
Patrick Ewing scored 19 points, Hubert Davis had 18 and Anthony Bonner added a season-high 15 points along with 6 rebounds to lead the Knicks to their fifth victory in six games.
Houston had 28 points, Dumars 24 and Hill 15 for the Pistons, who led briefly in the third quarter, but faded in the end.
The Knicks outscored the Pistons by 28-17 in the final quarter. "
Coach said before the game that we needed an all-around team effort," Knicks guard John Starks said. "
We needed a blowout-type game, which we haven't had in a while."
The Knicks led by 69-49 at halftime and by 85-79 after three quarters before putting the game away with an 11-4 run.

Trustees of the State University of New York said today for the first time that they would close or merge eight campuses or hospitals and raise tuition $1,600 a year, to $4,250, if Gov. George E. Pataki's budget cuts were approved.
But Mr. Pataki and leaders in the Republican Senate accused the university officials of engaging in scare tactics over what is a sensitive issue for Republicans.
They oppose closing any of the university's 34 campuses, nearly all of which are in Republican districts and are highly prized for the local jobs they bring. "
I think it's unfortunate when some use what has often been called the Washington Monument strategy," Mr. Pataki said at a news conference. "
When you make a cut, you immediately say you are going to cut the Washington Monument because it is the most visible way to get public attention."

It is impossible to say whether any closings will happen: despite increasingly rocky relations between SUNY trustees and Senate Republicans, even Senate leaders have said they expect some softening of what would be the largest single cut in SUNY history.
The Governor has called for a $290 million cut in state money, a 31.5 percent reduction, out of a total budget of $1.5 billion.
Today was the first time that SUNY officials, despite heavy pressure from Republicans, outlined definite steps they would take under Mr. Pataki's proposed budget.
However, at a news conference here, Frederic V. Salerno, the SUNY board chairman, refused to say which campuses or which of the three university-run hospitals might be closed.
Mr. Salerno said he did not want to create panic in case the cuts are averted, although critics said the strategy was aimed at keeping Republicans with campuses in their districts jittery. "

With the opponents of President Hugo Chavez seeking to remove him through a recall referendum, the Supreme Court is expected as early as Monday to choose a new electoral board that would oversee the voting.
Mr. Chavez's government has not offered explicit support for a referendum.
But under the Constitution, a referendum can be convened halfway through his six-year term, a point reached last Tuesday.
In his drive to remake Venezuela, Mr. Chavez rewrote the Constitution and packed Congress and other institutions with his allies.
The Supreme Court, several of whose members were handpicked by the interior minister, was considered as beholden as any.

The government's adversaries, who had already failed to overthrow Mr. Chavez in a coup last year, had as recently as January dismissed the Supreme Court as just another puppet of the leftist president.
But after a two-month national strike failed to oust Mr. Chavez, the court has the last option.
To hold the referendum, the court must select five electoral board officials who would verify the validity of 3.2 million signatures, collected by the president's adversaries, that demand his ouster.
If the signatures are authenticated, the board would then organize a referendum for as early as the end of November.
Polls indicate that two-thirds of Venezuelans may vote to remove Mr. Chavez.

Gov. George E. Pataki today vetoed a bill that would have required the state to continue paying for the care of severely retarded and handicapped New Yorkers who have been living in institutions outside the state.

The Governor's decision leaves in doubt the future of about 30 profoundly disabled adults who as children were sent to institutions outside New York because the state did not have adequate long-term treatment services to deal with their problems.
The bill was written in response to the concerns of a group of parents who had lost their legal battle to force the state to continue paying for the out-of-state care of their children.
The parents contend that New York does not have adequate institutions to care for their children despite the Pataki administration's insistence that it does.
In a message to the Legislature explaining his veto, the Governor cited technical problems with the way that the bill was written.
But he also said he was planning to have his own legislation introduced this session to address the concerns of the parents.
He did not specify how he would do that. ''
My deep concern and sympathy for these persons and their families remains undiminished,'' Mr. Pataki said in his message.

But supporters of the legislation, particularly the parents of the disabled adults, expressed disappointment and sadness over the Governor's decision and wondered whether he could push his own bill through the Legislature before it adjourns in the next few days, as it is expected to do. ''
I just can't believe he would veto this bill,'' said Clarice Florence, whose 29-year-old son, David, is autistic and lives in an institution in Pennsylvania.
The Chinese finesse is neither Chinese nor a finesse: It is the lead of an unsupported honor that can gain only if the defense slips and fails to cover the honor.
A related position is the heart layout shown in the diagram.
If South leads the heart queen, he can gain legitimately if West has a singleton jack.
He can also gain Chinese-style if East has a doubleton king and fails to cover the queen.

The deal was played Wednesday night in a social game in Hobe Sound, Fla. The hostess, sitting South, was Helen Walsh, who has an international reputation as an advocate for people with physical disabilities.
Now a youthful 95, she likes to sit up half the night playing bridge.
She likes to compare her style of play to that of the old-style riverboat gambler, and proved it here with her bidding.
When her overcall was raised, her leap to game was distinctly exuberant, but a modest invitation would have led to the same result.
A diamond was led, and East's ten was taken by the queen.
South cashed the club ace, ruffed the ten and confidently led the heart queen.
In Miami Wednesday a visitor from Germany began his Florida vacation by being shot to death driving to his hotel.
It happened after a van rammed his car from the rear a few times, apparently as a signal for him to pull over and be robbed.
To Florida's credit, the visitor had been warned of this local custom.
While the ramming was going on, his wife was reading him instructions from an official pamphlet on how to save your valuables and possibly your life in this very situation.
The instructions said: Do not pull over.
Uwe-Wilhelm Rakebrand, for that was the visitor's name, followed the advice and did not pull over.
This must have vexed the van's occupants exceedingly, for it pulled alongside Mr. Rakebrand and one of those inside shot him fatally in the back.

Florida has lately had a bad press suggesting that foreign tourists are especially attractive to the Sunshine State's more murderous felons, yet only eight such tourists have been killed in the past year.
Yes, "only eight" sounds callous when we speak of the murdered, but by American murder standards eight is a trifling number.
Frank Zahn, manager of a Berlin agency specializing in travel to Florida, was quoted in The New York Times saying, "There is almost no country in the world where a tourist is absolutely safe."

Despite its growing economic power, China is at least two decades behind the United States in military technology and ability, according to a report released yesterday by the Council on Foreign Relations.
The report also says that China is far from becoming a global military power, and that the United States would ultimately prevail if a conflict over Taiwan broke out with China.
While China has the world's largest standing army and continues to acquire advanced weapons systems, the task force said China did not have enough advanced equipment to rival the United States. ''
There is a significant group of people out there who say that China is going to be a military super power and it will be an adversary to the United States.

And it may well turn out that way, but not in the near future,'' said Harold Brown, who served as Secretary of Defense under President Jimmy Carter and was a member of the task force that drafted the report.
Other members included John M. Deutch, a former director of central intelligence, and Thomas S. Foley, a former speaker of the House of Representatives.
In recent years, some military experts have warned that China poses an imminent threat to the sovereignty of Taiwan.
Those experts fear that the United States is underestimating China's military strength and China's resolve to reunify Taiwan with mainland China, possibly through a surprise military attack.

The report took issue with those theories, saying that even though China has become a center for software and semiconductor research and its acquisition of advanced weapons systems should not be underestimated, the United States clearly has superior air, naval and technological power.
It added that this military lead could last for decades.
The BankAmerica Corporation is near an agreement to buy the First Gibraltar Corporation, a Dallas-based savings institution, according to an investment banker familar with the sale.
The purchase of First Gibraltar, which has 131 branches in Texas and $7.3 billion in deposits, would at least partly satisfy BankAmerica's longstanding desire to expand in Texas.
Although First Gibraltar has few business customers or loans, BankAmerica has experience in converting savings associations into commercial banks in many other states, including Arizona and Oregon.
Earlier this year BankAmerica bought Sunbelt Savings, another Dallas-based company, which has 111 branches and $3.8 billion in deposits.
No agreement on price or method of payment has been reached, the investment banker said, and officials at BankAmerica and First Gibraltar declined to comment on any aspect of the sale.
A preliminary agreement on the sale was reported Tuesday by The Dallas Morning News.
First Gibraltar, which has been for sale since March, is owned by McAndrews & Forbes, an investor group controlled by Ronald O. Perlman.
Many other companies, including Nationsbank, Banc One and GE Capital have considered buying it.

The initial asking price for the company, between $800 million and $1 billion, deterred many investors, analysts said, and led First Gibraltar's owners to follow a policy of selling the company in pieces.

Earlier this year they sold 28 branches in Oklahoma, and have plans to sell First Gibraltar's mortgage business to Lomas Financial, a Dallas company, and to keep some bad loans that BankAmerica is unwilling to buy.
At the sound of the tone: Call me, Ishmael.
With little fanfare, voice mail has spread throughout American business, if not literature.
More and more people encounter voice mail, a kind of answering machine on steroids, whenever they call a travel agency, a bank, a car dealership or, especially, a co-worker down the hall.
Market research indicates that 70 percent of a typical company's phone traffic is internal.
Thus, the thick handbooks of voice-mail instructions are mostly designed to send a message to Harry down the hall.
It seems hard to believe that like answering machines, voice mail barely existed a decade ago.

What led to voice mail's ubiquity was less a revolution in telephone technology (the handset has changed little in basic principles since Alexander Graham Bell) than a drop in the cost of computing power and clever devices that convert voice into numbers.
As recently as 1987, only 7,000 voice systems were sold.
After this slow start, the voice-messaging business is growing quickly, with more than 38,000 systems expected to be sold this year.
The North American Telecommunications Association, a trade group, estimates that sales of voice-messaging systems will exceed $1 billion by 1994, up from less than $800 million in 1990.
LOOKING like endangered birds, the drag queens tottered on their heels as they entered -- "a bit early in the day for we girls," said one.
It was noon on a recent Saturday at the Sound Factory Bar on West 21st Street, and they were attending a memorial for Angie Xtravaganza.
One of her children, Hector Xtravaganza, kept breaking down in tears. "
It's not just her, it's all of them," he said. "
My entire gay childhood is disintegrating before my eyes."
Indeed, as some of the 100 mourners rose to reminisce, it was as if their whole world, the world of drag queens and voguing and ecstatic, elaborate balls, had died along with Angie.
Though she was only 27, Angie had been a mother more than a dozen times.
Not in the usual way; she was biologically male. "
But a mother is one who raises a child, not one who borns it," Hector pointed out.

And as mother of the House of Xtravaganza, Angie had taken many rejected, wayward, even homeless children under her wing; she had fed them, observed their birthdays, taught them all about "walking the balls."

By doubling mileage requirements for city taxicabs, Mayor Michael Bloomberg seems to have locked in one piece of a potentially historic environmental legacy -- not the most ambitious piece, but a significant one nonetheless.

His action will transform New York's taxi fleet from the most polluting in the nation to one of the cleanest, and do so in five years, making the city a leader as municipalities compete to cut carbon emissions.
Most city cabs are Ford Crown Victoria sedans, which get a measly 10 to 15 miles a gallon in city driving.
Taxis will have to get 25 miles per gallon by the end of next year and 30 miles per gallon the following year.

Because individual taxis are replaced every three to five years, the new vehicles will need to be high-mileage hybrids, the only car that currently meets the stiffer mileage standard and is suitable for the work demanded of a taxi.
The idea of an environmentally friendly fleet is not new, but Mr. Bloomberg's full embrace of it is.
The Bloomberg administration had been at best deliberate in moving on a City Council mandate two years ago to bring some green into the yellow cab ranks.
In that time, only about 375 hybrids have joined a fleet of more than 13,000 cabs.
The Taxi and Limousine Commission had long defended the status quo, noting the extra legroom in the Crown Victoria.
But that's just two inches more than the hybrid Ford, and the commission's latest message is more positive.

An appeals court here today mostly upheld a crackdown by the Environmental Protection Agency on pollution from 392 Midwestern and Southern factories and power plants, based on petitions by Connecticut, Massachusetts, New York and Pennsylvania.
In 1997, those states argued they could not bring the air within their borders into compliance with national standards unless the E.P.A. acted against pollution sources in upwind states.
The four petitioned under a provision of the Clean Air Act of 1990.
In 1999, the agency accepted the states' arguments and ordered hundreds of industrial polluters to cut emissions of nitrogen oxides, which cause smog.
The polluters sued.
Businesses and state officials in the upwind states had argued that the E.P.A. could not directly regulate the factories and that it should leave the work to the states.
In fact, the agency is already requiring ''state implementation plans.''
Upwind polluters fought that, too, but they lost that case last June.
The upwind industries appealed to the Supreme Court, but it refused to hear the case.
Environmental groups say direct regulation through petition is surer and faster. ''
Joe Roth, the former head of Walt Disney Studios, has obtained backing for his new movie company from Sony Pictures, the Starz Encore Group and Fox Entertainment.
Mr. Roth said the three backers would put in $250 million for a combined equity stake of just less than 25 percent in the company, Revolution Studios.

But the three companies, plus other partners in Germany and Japan, have committed themselves to finance both the production and marketing costs of at least 36 movies that Revolution Studios plans to make in the next six years.
That would bring the total financial commitment to about $3 billion, he said.
Sony will gain the movie and home video distribution rights in the United States and overseas except in Germany and Japan.
Starz Encore, a pay television company that is part of Liberty Media Group, will receive domestic rights for pay television.
Fox, which is controlled by News Corporation, will have other United States television rights.

Because of his track record at the helm of Disney Studios, leading it to the top position at the box office in five of his six years, Mr. Roth gained concessions that few other independent producers have.
He will have autonomy to choose films and the budgets.
And Revolution Studios will retain ownership of the movies, putting it in position to benefit from new ways of distributing movies in the future. ''

The two candidates for attorney general spent their last full day of campaigning yesterday at vastly different paces, with Jeanine F. Pirro trying to close a stubborn gap in the polls that shows her far behind the Democratic candidate, Andrew M. Cuomo.

Mr. Cuomo had just one public appearance yesterday, with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton outside a police precinct station in Lower Manhattan, where New York City fire officers and detectives endorsed him.

That was in sharp contrast to Ms. Pirro, who spent the day campaigning almost nonstop, with five appearances, beginning at a subway station in the Parkchester section of the Bronx and ending in the evening at the entrance to the Staten Island Ferry.
At the same time, Ms. Pirro's campaign kept up its steam in issuing stinging critiques of Mr. Cuomo, accusing him of ''concealing his 2005 tax returns.''
The Cuomo camp noted, however, that he had already released 14 years of tax returns.
Ms. Pirro said she remained upbeat about today's election. ''
I feel great; I'm getting tremendous response from people all over the state,'' she told reporters near City Hall Park. ''
I'm still campaigning, and I'm working hard.
I'm optimistic.
The only poll that matters is when the voters go into the voting booth.''
New Jersey's Education Commissioner barred a suburban school board today from using tax money for vouchers that would pay for private school tuitions.
The plan, encouraged by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, would have been the first suburban voucher plan in the nation.

Commissioner Leo Klagholz said that the plan by the Lincoln Park board, which could have authorized using thousands of tax dollars to send hundreds of high school students to private schools, violated state law.

Citing a ruling on April 4 by State Attorney General Peter Veniero, the Commissioner said that public funds could not go to ''children who have been withdrawn from the public school to which they are assigned.''

The Commissioner's ruling came on the eve of a Lincoln Park school board meeting at which the board was planning to vote to transfer funds from next year's budget to the initial phases of the program.
Two months ago, officials in the school district, in northeastern Morris County, had defiantly trumpeted their intentions to create the program.
Afterward, the Governor had personally signaled her support for the idea as one of the ways to seed educational competition and to provide more educational choices.
The decision also came on a day that opponents had begun legal challenges of the plan, calling it destructive to public education and in violation of the New Jersey and United States Constitutions.
School Board members said they were undeterred by the ruling.

The board said it would seek to raise private funds to provide vouchers to families who wanted to send their children to a private high school rather than the public high school to which they were assigned.
An explosion and fire from leaking propane caused heavy damage to a wing of one of the Ozark region's most popular hotels Thursday night.
Eighteen people were injured, at least one of them critically and two seriously, at the hotel and convention center, the Lodge of the Four Seasons, on Lake of the Ozarks.
About 600 people were attending a highway engineers' conference at the hotel, on the lakefront about five miles from this central Missouri town.
The fire was extinguished about two hours after the blast, the authorites said.
The hotel's manager, Frank Maloney, said two dozen of its 311 rooms were heavily damaged.
State Fire Marshal John Coburn attributed the explosion to a leaking underground propane gas line, with the fumes apparently ignited when someone lit a cigar.
He said the leak had resulted from natural deterioration of the gas line.
The injured were on three floors on the north wing of the building, and most of them suffered from burns, smoke inhalation and lacerations from flying glass.
Eleven of the injured were treated at a hospital and released.
The critically injured victim and one in serious condition were flown to a hospital in Columbia.
To the Editor: I was recently traveling in Eastern Europe with a group of friends and feel obligated to report on an incident so that others may avoid the problem.
Before boarding an overnight train from Prague to Budapest, a guide had warned us about being robbed.
I assumed he was referring to passengers sitting up all night in second-class cars, not to those of us traveling behind the locked and chained doors of first-class compartments.
We were due to hit the border at around 5 A.M., so to avoid any confusion I put my passport case in the net holder above my berth. (
This case contained my traveler's checks, credit cards, passport, airplane tickets, dollars and German marks.)
I awoke as the train hit rough track and also because the light was on in the compartment.
In a second I realized that a man was going through my bags and I saw that my passport case was on the floor.
I screamed and the man left, shutting the door behind him.
I put on my robe and ran down the corridor to get the attendant, but he was asleep and his door locked.
By this time friends on either side of my compartment were in the corridor.

''If I could erase this year and do it over, I would,'' said Anthony Boyce, a heroin addict who wanted to check into a detoxification program and celebrate the dawn of the new year by sleeping through it. ''
I need to clear my head and not think about what to do next,'' said Mr. Boyce, 47. ''
When you're carrying a load on your shoulders 24 hours a day, it gets to where you can't think of a way out.''

At the Positive Health Project, a walk-up sanctuary at 305 West 37th St., some of the homeless and destitute shared their modest hopes and considerable fears as a few blocks away Times Square was being readied for New Year's Eve.
The project dispenses more than 13,000 clean syringes and 36,000 condoms a month, along with advice about staying healthy on the street.
Dolores Serina, 35, said that she had to move into a women's shelter after her husband went to prison for selling drugs and city officials declared their basement room an illegal dwelling. ''
Going into the New Year, I'm scared,'' Ms. Serina said. ''
A lot of these people haven't slept last night,'' she said. ''
They depend on this place for safety.''

For the first time, the project's executive director closed the needle exchange and other services this New Year's Eve for fear that his drug users would get swept up by the officers patrolling the celebration at Times Square.
SUMMER HOTEL RATES Inter-Continental Hotels offers discount programs in Europe, Asia and North America this summer.
In Europe, where the program runs June 19 to Sept. 7, there are 37 participating Inter-Continental and Forum hotels in 29 cities.
For example, the rate is $119 a night at the Athenaeum in Athens and the Inter-Continentals in Cologne and Helsinki, and $269 a night at the Metropol in Moscow.

In Asia, where 12 hotels are participating in the Summer Spectacular program from June 1 to Sept. 7, sample rates are $125 at the Siam Inter-Continental, Bangkok, and $195 at the Inter-Continental Sydney.
In both Europe and Asia, rates are guaranteed in United States dollars.
They are per room, single or double occupancy, and include tax, service charge and American breakfast for two.
The North American program, called Spectacular Summer Options, runs May 22 to Sept. 7.
Sample rates are $149 at the Mark Hopkins Inter-Continental San Francisco, $159 at the Maui Inter-Continental Resort, and $199 at the Willard Inter-Continental Washington.
Guests also get a free option such as an upgrade to a suite or a 50 percent discount on an adjoining room.
Tax and tips are extra.

WHEN the heavyweight fighters Mike Tyson and Lennox Lewis traded blows on a stage in a Manhattan theater last week, it signaled the low point of a pre-bout performance ritual that has been part of American popular culture since Muhammad Ali ruled the ring.
Tyson and Lewis had come to hype a fight planned for April in Las Vegas.
But Tyson, lacking the finesse Ali displayed at such events, lunged at Lewis and, by some accounts, bit him.
Tyson then launched into an unprintable tirade involving orifices.
It was another black eye for boxing.
Yet this idea of showman-style intimidation outside the ring began with Ali.
He turned verbal sparring into an art form that legions of admirers, from pacifists to pugilists, have tried to emulate.
Part circus act, part performance art, part psych job, part street hustle, it combined to become as essential to the Ali myth as his grace in the ring.
These performances mask the sport's brutality, now personified by Tyson.

While Tyson is considered by many to be boxing's nadir, the embodiment of its violence with none of its elan, Ali has continued to grow in stature, even as his revered verbal wit has slowed with illness.
Tired and sweat-soaked, the big men left the basketball court.
Within seconds, their smaller shadows  -- boys ages 8 to 13 -- had taken their place.
They hustled and bumped and called plays like pros, capturing the attitude, if not the shooting acumen, of their elders.
These boys spend their summer playing basketball, moving from open court to open court.
But when they can, they settle here, at the Brownsville Recreation Center on Linden Boulevard in Brooklyn.
Its courts have the only fiberglass backboards in the neighborhood, but perhaps the real draw is less concrete.
There are about 1,600 parks and playgrounds and innumerable community centers that provide summer homes to young people throughout the city.
The Brownsville Recreation Center also provides a second family.
It originally housed the legendary Brownsville Boys Club, then declined as the neighborhood did.
Now the center is a vibrant institution in its own right, and the neighborhood is experiencing something of an upswing, too.

CONSTRUCTION cranes quickly disappeared from the skyline of this affluent city near Seattle, office vacancy rates shot up as high as 28 percent and developers postponed once-ambitious projects when the dot-com boom went bust six years ago.
Bellevue had become a city where no developer seemed to want to be. ''

Everything was too good to be true, and then reality came through,'' said Kemper Freeman, the president and chief executive of Kemper Development, one of Bellevue's largest land owners and developers.
But this city, whose fortunes rose and fell with those of the technology industry, has been staging a comeback.
Nowadays, a dozen or so construction cranes loom over work sites in Bellevue's downtown.

Some 2.2 million square feet of office space, some of it speculative, and more than 2,500 apartments and condominiums are under construction, according to the Bellevue Downtown Association, a nonprofit group.
Projects like Mr. Kemper's Lincoln Square, a 1.4-million-square-foot development with hotel rooms, condominiums, an office tower and a shopping mall, have been restarted and are near completion.
Already, companies are planning to move into Bellevue, which is about 10 miles east of Seattle and, in the 2000 census, had a population of almost 110,000.
Microsoft is expanding its offices here, while Eddie Bauer has chosen the city for its new headquarters and Neiman Marcus is opening its first Pacific Northwest store here. ''

If you look at the companies leasing downtown, these aren't imaginary companies,'' said Matt Terry, the director of planning and community development for Bellevue, referring to some of the dot-com businesses that once set up headquarters in the city, then quickly folded. ''
Fur and feathers may be the signature style of many women in hip-hop, but Dawn Robinson prefers a more offbeat look inspired by punk and rock.
Lately, on the street and on stage, Ms. Robinson, a singer and songwriter in Lucy Pearl, has been wearing black leather boots by Sky because their S-curve platform heels are unusual. ''
Everyone in R&B is into high couture,'' said Ms. Robinson, who was in the glamorous girl group En Vogue from 1989 through 1997.
Divas like Lauryn Hill, Madonna and Jennifer Lopez have already discovered the sculptural footwear sold at Jeffrey, at 449 West 14th Street.
It costs $230 to $380.

Ms. Robinson dresses down the high-style boots by wearing them with a black, asymmetrical Goth skirt by Martin Margiela and an old Sting T-shirt on which she performed a few alterations, cutting off the sleeves and tapering the waist with safety pins. ''
The rock T-shirt is antifashion, and I like that the skirt looks like they took it off the bolt,'' she said. ''
It's unfinished.
It's not perfect.
I'm a little punk.
Last week, when the government reported that the economy had slowed to a crawl in the first quarter of the year, any lingering hope for robust employment growth was tempered accordingly.
But no one was quite prepared for a job report as weak as the one released yesterday.
Only 88,000 jobs were created in April, the smallest gain in nearly two and half years and a sharp deceleration from job growth in the recent past.
Predictably, the slowdown was reflected in Americans' paychecks.
Weekly earnings are up over the past year.
But of late, the rate of increase has dropped significantly.
A squeeze on jobs and paychecks is the last thing Americans need right now.
Though the economy has been expanding for more than five years, wages and salaries for most workers have picked up in earnest only in the past year.
And now hiring and pay increases appear to be slowing before many families have had the chance to rebuild their finances.
For many people, mortgage payments are also being adjusted upward as home prices fall, making it harder for them to refinance their debts.
Carlos Beltran has not changed one aspect of his daily routine, even as speculation about where he might be continuing that routine intensifies.
Beltran still analyzes videotapes of his at-bats, he still listens to his iPod to relax and he still spends hours trying to help the Kansas City Royals win.
He does not focus on whether he will be playing center field for the Royals next week, next month or after the July 31 nonwaiver trade deadline.
As someone whose name has surfaced in trade discussions for years, Beltran says he has conditioned himself to ignore everything about where he could eventually be relocated. ''
For me, it's easy,'' Beltran said Wednesday before the Royals beat the Texas Rangers, 5-3. ''
Last year, I really allowed myself to deal with the trade rumors.
I was traded to every ball club in the major leagues and I ended up with the Kansas City Royals.''
Still, this year is much different.
Beltran can be a free agent after this season, and General Manager Allard Baird has indicated that the Royals will not be able to afford a player who can command as much as $15 million a year.
Beltran said the Royals had made it evident ''that next year I'll be too expensive and they won't have the money.''

THE mood at the bingo tables in the North White Plains community center seemed placid, even sleepy, on a recent afternoon last week until Rob Astorino, the Republican candidate for Westchester county executive, bounced into the room.
Ears began to perk up, eyes opened wide, and the bingo chips came to a standstill.

Within what seemed like seconds, Mr. Astorino was drawing enthusiastic nods of agreement from the small crowd of seniors as he lashed out at his opponent, Andrew J. Spano, and quickly pounced on one issue he insists has created enough countywide angst for him to capitalize on this November: property taxes. ''
It's becoming increasingly difficult to live in Westchester because of Andy Spano's tax increases,'' said Mr. Astorino, speaking softly but intently. ''
I have a wife and two kids and we're struggling like everyone else to keep pace with these taxes.
Everywhere in Westchester, I see people putting up for-sale signs in their yards.''
From the warm reception among the audience, it might have been hard to tell that Mr. Astorino is facing a task this November that has been called all but impossible.
In challenging Mr. Spano, he has set out to dethrone a well-financed, well-liked incumbent whose eight years in office, despite a few recent trouble spots, have been relatively crisis-free.
Crime is low.
Fiscal indicators suggest the economy is strong.

Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation today that will require health maintenance organizations to offer policies allowing individuals to use the doctors of their choice and not just those who are members of the H.M.O.'s network.
Managed-care companies will also have to offer individual policies covering prescription drugs.

The legislation was prompted by concerns that individuals could not purchase comprehensive managed-care coverage after Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield stopped offering such policies to new customers last year.
Other companies offered more limited plans, and most were not available for individuals. "
This law will make health-care coverage more affordable for people who truly need it," the Governor said in a statement.
Mr. Pataki said that about a million people in the state purchased health insurance for themselves instead of through group plans.
Typically, such individual purchasers are not employed, are self-employed or work for small businesses that offer no health coverage.
On average, they are believed to be less healthy than the general public and therefore have higher health care costs and higher insurance premiums.
Also, individuals have less bargaining power with insurers than do companies with group plans.
Both the New York State Health Maintenance Organization Conference and groups representing health insurance policyholders supported the legislation.
The Jets have not been this bad in running the ball since 1963.
And if they are to have the slightest hope of salvaging the season, they will have to begin churning out ground yardage on Sunday at Indianapolis.

In a season in which they have been forced, by injury or a dearth of talent, to reconfigure the offensive line, the quarterbacks, the wide receivers, the tight ends and the running backs, the point of attack has suffered.
The running game is averaging only 76.3 yards a game.
It ranks 29th (behind only the Saints) and is the second-lowest figure in Jets history.
No team is going to win games consistently with that sort of performance.
The Colts, meanwhile, are one of the league's top clubs in stopping the run, permitting under 90 yards a game. "
It starts and ends up front," said Coach Rich Kotite today after a practice in which the tackles, James Brown and Everett McIver, originally penciled in as backups, were the starters on the line. "
That's it.
That's the crux of it."
