More than a half-century ago, Melvin Sylvester chose Rocky as a nickname for himself on the basketball court.
The name stuck, and everyone in his Harlem neighborhood called him by it -- even the day after a police detective shot him dead.
The police said Mr. Sylvester had rushed at the detective early Friday morning with a knife.

Carrying signs reading ''Rocky -- Harlem Will Miss You'' and ''Rest in Peace Rocky,'' about two dozen of Mr. Sylvester's family and friends marched yesterday from the site of the shooting on 200 W. 131st Street to the 32nd Precinct station house four blocks away.
The marchers said they could not understand why Mr. Sylvester, 65, had been killed. ''
I'm furious,'' said Tyrone Sylvester, Mr. Sylvester's nephew. ''
Even if he had a knife, why was he shot in the chest when he could have been shot in the arm or the leg?''

But some residents of St. Nicholas Houses, where the shooting occurred, said that they did not have enough information about Mr. Sylvester's death to take part in the march, which was organized by Calvin B. Hunt, Jr., the founder of Harlem Community Watch. ''

The police know there's adrenaline, and they know they have to act before they're acted upon,'' said Dameon Reid, 31, who rushed to her second-story window after hearing the shot about 12:15 a.m. on Friday and saw Mr. Sylvester lying on the ground.
Mr. Sylvester was shot once in the chest by the detective, who was investigating a gun complaint.
A man and a woman move from left to right or right to left in apparent harmony before a stage curtain.
Later, another couple fills the same trajectory with tension and ambiguity.
Susan Marshall's always experimental choreography provides food for both the eye and the mind, as these two new duets showed again at Serious Fun on Friday night.
Both premieres, commissioned by Lincoln Center Productions from Miss Marshall and company for the current series at Alice Tully Hall, are brief and pungent explorations of personal relationships.
Created for the occasion, they were presented seemingly as bridges between older Marshall pieces.
Aptly and slyly, each duet is entitled "Entr'acte" and looks similar but different.
Each has a score by Philip Glass. "
Entr'acte 1" was performed as the interval piece between "Contenders" (1990) and "Untitled" (1992). "

Entr'acte 2" was given between "Untitled" and the now-classic "Kiss" of 1987: a duet for a couple whose harness-equipped choreography sends them into space with centrifugal force and finally into a locked aerial embrace.
The idea that the "Entr'acte" dances merely connect the other acts on a program is furthered by their performance downstage before the curtain.
The Yamhill County Juvenile Detention Center, an 18-bed, $1.2 million facility in McMinnville, Ore., represents a new, pre-emptive style in juvenile crime control.
Here, teen-agers who are awaiting adjudication -- that is, who are still legally innocent -- are tossed in with repeat offenders for four days of tough love.

McMinnville, not far from Portland, isn't particularly cursed with youth crime, but county officials believe this get-toughism makes sense, and that it will appeal to many other towns and cities as the number of 12- to 17-year-olds rises over the next five years.
Youth advocates call the strategy dubious at best.
Glen, a pimply 15-year-old assault suspect, says it was ''hell.''
Here's a look.
11:32 A.M. On this day, new arrivals like Glen were greeted by Cully Desmond, a 215-pound, 6-feet-6 ''detention technician'' wearing combat boots. (
Girls are processed by female technicians.)
The kids are patted down for weapons, handcuffed to a stainless-steel bench during processing (top left) and taken to individual showers for a strip search.
Guards check mouths, armpits and the space behind boys' genitals and then each kid takes a shower. ''
If it can be seen, heard or read, the impulse these days is to turn it into a digital data file and sell it to someone willing to pay good money to see, hear or read it.
Little surprise, then, that the technologies to watch in 1994 involve the storage or transmission of information. (
Although in one case, the information transfer occurs not between computers but within the cells of the human body.)
From interactive adventure games like Activision's "Return to Zork" to the film clips and reviews of Microsoft's "Cinemania 94," CD-ROM titles are finally creating excitement and sales.
And the silvery disks do promise a sharp break with the nerds-only tradition of the computer industry: software that is intended to be fun to use.
This year, software on CD-ROM (short for compact disk, read-only memory) will really start to become a mass market.

Three forces are working together: the falling prices and rising production of personal computers equipped with CD-ROM drives, the increased number of CD-ROM titles and the technology's ability to deliver high-quality video, sound and text at once.

In 1994, 35 percent of all personal computers sold in the United States will have built-in CD-ROM drives, up from 4 percent two years ago and 19 percent in 1993, forecasts Link Resources, a consulting firm.
The new sales will help raise the number of computers equipped with CD-ROM readers by 54 percent to more than 10 million, according to Infotech, a market research firm.
The number of titles in print will rise by more than 30 percent, to more than 9,400, Infotech says. "
The Chrysler Corporation will soon begin selling cars that can run on methanol as well as gasoline, Lee A. Iacocca, the company's chairman, said yesterday.
Unlike some dual-fuel cars now being sold, the Chrysler models will be offered at no additional charge, he said.
The feature will cost the company several hundred dollars a car, automotive engineers say, but it will give Chrysler valuable credits in meeting Federal gasoline mileage requirements.
In a breakfast speech in which he dwelled on environmental matters, Mr. Iacocca described the offer to reporters who had gathered for a preview of the New York Auto Show.
The offer, which will cover the Plymouth Acclaim and Dodge Spirit models, was first announced in January.
The cars will go on sale in July.
They can run on gasoline or a blend of gasoline and as much as 85 percent methanol, the standard at pumps where the fuel is sold.
Methanol, also known as wood alcohol, causes less air pollution than gasoline.
Predicts Move by Competitors Mr. Iacocca predicted that Chrysler's competitors would eventually have to offer the option free too.
General Motors now sells "variable fuel vehicles," in the form of the Cheverolet Lumina mid-size model, in California.

Two European agency companies, one based in France and the other in Britain, are expanding further in North America in separate deals that exemplify the growing globalization of the advertising industry.

Publicis S.A. in Paris is scheduled to announce today an agreement to acquire a controlling interest in BCP, the seventh- largest agency in Canada, with billings estimated at $181 million (United States).

The acquisition is the third for Publicis in less than a month as part of an escalating game of ''chicken'' after the termination of a worldwide cooperative agreement with True North Communications in Chicago.

And Aegis Group P.L.C. in London, which owns Europe's largest media services agency, Carat, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire, subject to a final contract, Media Buying Services International, an independent New York shop that handles media accounts with billings estimated at $160 million.
Both acquisitions are indicative of how agencies are continuing to expand internationally to meet the demands of multinational marketers. ''
This is an avenue to the future for us,'' said Matthew Bryant, president and chief executive at Media Buying Services in New York, ''because we are in a global media world now.''
Seth Goldschlager, a spokesman for Publicis in Paris, said the acquisition of BCP would give Publicis ''a more direct ability to manage global accounts.''
He declined to disclose the terms of the agreement, but discussed some aspects of it yesterday.
The announcement is to be made today in Paris, as well as in Montreal and Toronto, where BCP has offices that handle advertising, direct marketing, promotion and the buying of ad space.
Publicis intends to acquire 70 percent of BCP, Mr. Goldschlager said, while Yves Gougoux, president and chief executive, will retain a 30 percent stake in what will be renamed Publicis-BCP.

Juan Bosch, a prolific writer who in December 1962 became the first freely elected president of the Dominican Republic in 38 years -- only to be toppled by a military coup after seven months in office -- died yesterday in the capital, Santo Domingo.
He was 92.
At its start, Mr. Bosch's presidency appeared to promise a more hopeful future for his impoverished and deeply troubled country.
His election had been made possible by the assassination in May 1961 of Gen. Rafael L. Trujillo, the dictator who had ruled since 1930.

That also let the Organization of American States lift sanctions imposed on the country in 1960 because of General Trujillo's complicity in a plot to assassinate President Romulo Betancourt of Venezuela.
The Kennedy administration welcomed Mr. Bosch's election and sent Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson to represent the United States at his inauguration in February 1963.
Washington also promised increased aid under the Alliance for Progress.

But Mr. Bosch quickly provoked his rightist opponents, introducing constitutional changes that included limiting the size of landholdings and strengthening industrial and agricultural workers' rights.
His performance as president had other problems, too.
Caught between the remnants of General Trujillo's forces and Communists inspired by Fidel Castro, he often appeared indecisive and unable to delegate responsibility.

Paul Williams Thompson, a brigadier general who led a unit in the D-Day invasion of Normandy and a publishing executive who built up Reader's Digest in  Europe, died on Feb. 9 at Mariner Health of Port Orange in Daytona Beach, Fla. A former resident of Chappaqua, N.Y., he was 89 and lived in Daytona Beach Shores.
Mr. Thompson joined Reader's Digest in 1946 as head of its European operations and started foreign-language editions in Belgium, France, Germany and Switzerland.
He moved to the company headquarters in Pleasantville, N.Y., in 1957 as director of international operations and oversaw the Digest's expansion in the Far East.
He was later named executive vice president and general manager, retiring in 1971 as executive director of the Reader's Digest Foundation.
Before joining the Digest, Mr. Thompson was a highly decorated combat engineer who had served in the Army for 17 years.
He was born in Alliance, Neb., and graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1929.
He received civil engineering degrees from State University of Iowa in 1932 and Tulane University  the following year.
In World War II, he organized and commanded a training center in England, helping to develop the tactics and techniques employed by the assault units in the invasion.
Mr. Thompson is survived by his second wife, Josette Berkland, whom he married in 1983.
His first wife of 43 years, Elfriede Greimelmeier, died in 1980.

A battle to control what is expected to become the next big form of personal computing begins in earnest this week with the introduction of software for operating small computers that are controlled by writing with a pen rather than typing on a keyboard.

The Go Corporation, a start-up based here, is scheduled to demonstrate its Penpoint software, which is designed to serve as the operating system, the basic controlling software, for pen-based computers.
Hot on the heels of Go is the Microsoft Corporation, which dominates the market for personal computer operating systems and is developing its own operating system for pen-based computers.
Microsoft plans to demonstrate its pen-based software next month.
Big Market Expected Both Go and Microsoft have said they will be finished with their operating systems by the end of the year.
That means that computers manufactured by companies licensing the software should begin appearing late this year or early next year.

Pen-based computers are small, lightweight machines that allow the user to perform tasks by writing on the screen with a pen-shaped instrument, instead of by typing on a keyboard or pointing with a piece of equipment known as a mouse.
For instance, a person editing a document can cross out a word by drawing an "X" through it, rather than by typing a delete command.
New words can be entered by printing them, though the computers cannot understand cursive writing.
Pen-based computers are expected to appeal to people who do not now use personal computers, creating big new markets.

The J-Phone Company, Japan's second-largest cellphone carrier, announced today that it was pushing back the introduction of its third-generation phones by six months, to December, the latest snag in the industry's rollout of the high-speed service.
J-Phone had planned to start its so-called 3G service last December but then delayed the introduction until June.
Now the company says the handsets will not be ready, so it will conduct six months of customer trials in Tokyo before a full commercial introduction at the end of the year.
The market leader, NTT DoCoMo, took similar steps last year before starting its 3G service in October.
Still, consumer interest in the service, which can send data up to 40 times the speed of conventional phones, has been disappointing.
The faster speeds allow users to download audio, hold videoconferences and make and send 30-second movie clips.
J-Phone and its parent, the Vodafone Group, are also aiming to link customers in nearly 30 countries in three continents, something DoCoMo has not done yet.
But J-Phone's president, Darryl Green, said that preparations for this feature had not been completed and that the company was reluctant to introduce a half-finished product. ''

Third-generation phones are about 10 times more complex than the current 2G service,'' Mr. Green said, adding that J-Phone was still working with handset makers to come up with a universal standard to allow for ''global roaming.''
When released, J-Phone's handsets, which will be made by NEC and Sanyo Electric, and perhaps by Nokia, will include so-called SIM cards.

Faced with the unusual legislative task of choosing a new state comptroller, Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin wants to use committees of the Assembly and the Senate to interview candidates for the job, his aides said today.

Because the new comptroller will almost certainly be a Democrat, many of the candidates and their political strategists believe the decision will ultimately be made by Mr. Weprin and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
But the method Mr. Weprin proposes would give the selection process at least the appearance of openness. "
The main point is that the Speaker wants the selection process for the new comptroller to be as open and public as possible," said Steven A. Greenberg, Mr. Weprin's spokesman. "
There shouldn't be a name that the public hasn't heard that suddenly we're taking a vote on."
At Least 11 Candidates Edward V. Regan, the State Comptroller for the last 14 years, announced on Thursday that he would resign at the end of April.
His unexpected decision to leave office in the middle of his term set in motion a flurry of intense politicking, and at least 11 people have already expressed interest in the job.

After four days, the leading contenders seem to be the New York City Board of Education president, H. Carl McCall, and former New York City Council President Carol Bellamy, who lost to Mr. Regan when she ran for the post in 1990.
If selected, Mr. McCall would be the first black statewide official.
Mr. Cuomo said on Saturday that Mr. McCall's candidacy presents a "unique opportunity," although he said he would not publicly endorse a candidate.
To the Editor: Shelby Steele, in "Race and the Curse of Good Intentions" (Op-Ed, Oct. 24), oversimplifies the problem of how to remedy violations of rights based on skin color.

His position is that all affirmative action remedies are "a stunning mistake" because, though well intentioned, they reinforce the idea of "using race as a distinction of convenience in American life."
Mr. Steele would like us to become a colorblind society.
But in attacking remedies for discrimination based on skin color, he blames the victim for the crime.
He himself reinforces what he says he wants to avoid when he concedes that race is "a biological fact."
It is not.
Skin color is a biological fact, but "race" implies more. "
Race" implies that skin color is linked genetically and biologically to other characteristics, such as intelligence, responsibility and moral capacity.
There is no credible evidence for that, and most biologists have rejected the notion of race as a biological fact.
Race is a social and political construct created and maintained to subjugate people based on their skin color.

A public opinion poll two weeks after Mossad agents bungled an attempt in Jordan to kill a leader of the militant Islamic movement Hamas suggested today  that the affair had not hurt Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu politically at home.
But new reports indicated that King Hussein of Jordan remained furious at what he saw as a betrayal of his friendship.
For the moment, the debate over the failed operation came to a halt in Israel as the Jewish state virtually closed down to observe Yom Kippur.
Israeli television and radio stations went off the air, and traffic came to a halt, while Jews flocked to synagogues and to the Western Wall for the Day of Atonement.
As usual, Israeli security forces barred Palestinians from the West Bank and the Gaza Strip from entering Israel for the duration of the holiday.
Large contingents of the police dispersed through the Old City of Jerusalem, and civil guards in synagogues were armed with weapons against the possibility of a terror attack.
According to the Religious Affairs Ministry, 69 percent of the Israeli public attends a synagogue on Yom Kippur, far more than for any other  holiday.

Despite all the furor over the failed raid, a Gallup Poll commissioned by the newspaper Maariv showed that Mr. Netanyahu had pulled virtually even with the leader of the opposition Labor Party, Ehud Barak.
Asked whom they would vote for if elections were held today, 39 percent of those questioned said Mr. Netanyahu, and 40 percent Mr. Barak -- a statistically insignificant difference.
Mr. Barak had led by wider margins in all previous polls.

Art Bridgman and Myrna Packer assembled an impressive group of collaborators for a suite of theater and dance vignettes called ''Rapid Eye Movement,'' presented by the Danspace Project on Friday night at St. Mark's Church.
But the evening's strongest and least dated-looking  moments were by Mr. Bridgman and Ms. Packer.
Half dream, half surrealistic circus, ''Rapid Eye Movement'' began promisingly with a duet choreographed by Mark Dendy to music by John Adams, with a haunting visual design by Jonathan Belcher.
Ms. Packer was a dead woman come alive.
Mr. Bridgman was her mysterious companion along the journey from death to life and misadventures with bizarre objects.
Vicky Shick created an unclear set to soupy music by Don Ho.
Ann Carlson contributed a solo for a glowing clock face that trudged across the dark stage space to mystifying scraps of conversation.
Bill T. Jones created a dance for two swimmers, set to music by the Fleetwoods and John Oswald, that included a too-brief passage of simple dancing for the husband-and-wife duo.
Marta Renzi's segment, in which a seeming priest and a widow engaged in a dark sensual encounter, was the best conceived and realized.
It was danced to music by Tony de la Rosa and Peter Groll, with visuals by Carol Galione.

Still reeling from a violent change of government last week, Kyrgyzstan faced new uncertainty on Wednesday after the ousted president withheld his formal resignation and the man who has emerged as the most powerful politician in the country quit the new government.
The president, Askar Akayev, who fled Kyrgyzstan a week ago, continued to jockey for some political influence but acknowledged having lost real power to those vying for control here in Bishkek.
In a telephone interview from a house outside of Moscow he said he was prepared to step aside officially, but only if he received guarantees of security and immunity from prosecution. ''
I am prepared to help so that it would go into constitutional channels,'' he said of the new government, which has yet to respond to his demands.
Mr. Akayev's refusal to resign has created a constitutional crisis for the new government, which has struggled for legitimacy after stepping into the vacuum that followed his hasty departure.
Without his resignation, Mr. Akayev stressed, the country's newly named acting president and prime minister, Kurmanbek Bakiyev, has no constitutional foundation.
In the absence of clear legitimacy, Mr. Bakiyev has made compromises that have narrowed the circle of his support.
This week, for example, he was forced to recognize the Parliament chosen in the flawed elections that stirred the popular resentment that propelled him to the president's seat in the first place.
Mr. Bakiyev suffered another blow on Wednesday when Felix Kulov abruptly resigned as coordinator of security services, a job he was given after being freed from prison during last week's uprising.
Mr. Kulov said he was quitting because he had finished the job he had been called on to do: restore order in the country after looting broke out in the wake of the uprising.

Two former executives at the McKesson Corporation were acquitted of a conspiracy charge yesterday, but might be retried on six other charges involving a $9 billion accounting scandal at the country's biggest pharmaceutical distributor.

The two former executives, Charles W. McCall and Jay Lapine, were acquitted on one charge of conspiracy, but a mistrial was declared on six counts of securities fraud after the jury failed to reach a verdict.

Mr. McCall, the former chairman, and Mr. Lapine, the former general counsel, were charged with falsely booking $100 million in revenue and then covering up a conspiracy to inflate McKesson's profit shortly before its 1999 merger with HBO & Company, a health services software maker based in Atlanta.
The McKesson case was one of the biggest accounting scandals at the time, causing investors to lose billions of dollars and at least four former McKesson executives to plead guilty to fraud charges.
The verdict was the second time that prosecutors were defeated in a trial involving former McKesson executives.
The company's former chief financial officer was acquitted in a nonjury trial last year.
In other major accounting scandals, several former corporate executives have been convicted. "
We've been sandwiched between so much negative press about corporate executives that to get an acquittal in that environment was just amazing," said Ted Wells, the lawyer representing Mr. McCall. "
I would hope that upon reflection the U.S. attorney's office would decide not to retry the case given the acquittal on the conspiracy count and also the age of the case."
Mr. Lapine's lawyer, Marcus S. Topel, could not be reached for comment.

A unanimous Suffolk County Legislature voted on Tuesday to override nearly all of Robert J. Gaffney's budget vetoes, leaving his successor as county executive, Steve Levy, with a $2.32 billion spending plan for 2004.
The legislature voted 17-0, with the 18th legislator absent, to override 25 of Mr. Gaffney's 27 line-item vetoes.

The budget will cut spending next year by $19.4 million more than Mr. Gaffney's proposal but maintain his proposed countywide tax increase of $17.5 million, or slightly more than 4 percent, from this year.
Where those taxes will be collected did change though, said Fred Pollert, the county budget director.

By shifting $2.6 million in tax revenue from the countywide general fund to the police district, the legislature placed a greater burden on the five western towns than Mr. Gaffney's plan would have, he said.
The five eastern towns have their own police departments.
A Republican who leaves office at the end of the year, Mr. Gaffney warned that the final budget might contain hidden pitfalls. ''
I had hoped my successor, Steve Levy, would not take office with his hands tied,'' he said on Wednesday. ''
Consequently, I'm disappointed but not totally surprised at the legislature's actions.''
David Bishop, a Democratic legislator from Lindenhurst, said this year's override was consistent with the outcomes of past budget battles. ''
Today is June 6, 2006, also known, if you drop the zeroes, as 6/6/6.
It's a number that is either portentous or meaningless, depending on who's counting.
Those who are intrigued by its devilish pattern -- including evangelicals, movie studios and a club in TriBeCa -- are abuzz.
Given that 666 is referred to as the ''number of the beast,'' or Antichrist, in the Book of Revelation, commercial outlets have taken advantage of the curiosity or fear linked to the date. ''
The Omen,'' a remake of the 1976 horror film that begins with the birth of the Antichrist, opens today nationwide.
Tim LaHaye, a co-author of the best-selling ''Left Behind'' series, is promoting his new book, ''The Rapture,'' with the tagline ''06.06.06.
Will You Be Ready?''
Whatever today's 666 may bring, one dance club, the Mocca Lounge on Reade Street in Lower Manhattan, promises a party that will ''either get the demons out or invoke them.''
Ori Raz, the owner of the club, said that to him, 666 signifies ''no borders, no boundaries, everything is possible.''
Rose Welsh, a numerologist who works from her TriBeCa apartment, said the number 6 has much more to do with desire, on a individual level, than with the broader forces of good and evil.

Erica Van Acker, whose experience was the basis of a pioneering public television documentary on rape in 1971 and who became an early public spokeswoman for those who had been raped, died on Sept. 11 in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.
She was 62 and lived in Manhattan and Sag Harbor, N.Y. Details of her life came to light in research for a biographical sketch.
Ms. Van Acker, who was 30 when she was attacked in the hallway of her apartment building, became pregnant and had an abortion.
The documentary, ''No Tears for Rachel,'' was made for Channel 13/ WNET and was broadcast nationally on ''Bill Moyers' Journal.''
After the showing of the documentary, she became an advocate.
She would visit hospital emergency rooms to work with doctors to sensitize them to the feelings of those who had been raped.

Mr. Moyers said Ms. Van Acker ''took the chance because she really did want the public to know that rape is a crime where the victim is often made to feel guilty of the crime and to encourage others not to let the imposed sense of shame prevent them from talking to the police or the press.''
The documentary appeared not long before the rape law in New York State was changed to ease the requirement for corroborating evidence to prove a rape.

Before the change, legal experts had argued that it was nearly impossible to convict someone of rape, because each aspect of the crime had to be corroborated by evidence other than the victim's testimony.
Though she acted as a child and trained in drama at the Guildhall School of Music and Drama in London, Ms. Van Acker made her career in business.
The 11-day Tour Du Pont, America's premier bicycle race, will begin here Thursday night with a 3.1-mile time-trial prologue.
The favorites, according to one expert, are Erik Breukink of the Netherlands, Phil Anderson of Australia and Atle Kvalsvoll of Norway.
The expert could have added Sean Kelly of Ireland and Steve Bauer of Canada.
He could also have added himself, because the expert was the world's most successful and highest-paid rider, Greg LeMond. "
I don't know," LeMond said today.
Then, with a typical self-deprecating grin, the 29-year-old American promised little. "
This is not my best time of year," he said. "
But I'm months ahead of last year."
When the Winning Is Easy LeMond's time of year is summer, and his best race is the most important in the sport, the Tour de France.
He has won it three times in the last five years -- in 1986, 1989 and 1990 -- and he will try again July 6 through 28.

Three days before the season opener, the agreement for Cablevision to carry Yankees games on the YES network this season unraveled yesterday, with each side accusing the other of causing the collapse.

Barring negotiations that would revive the deal announced with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at Gracie Mansion 17 days ago, subscribers in Cablevision areas will not see Yankees games starting Monday -- an instant replay of last season when Yankees games were not available on Cablevision. ''
It comes as a complete shock that this is not happening,'' Leo J. Hindery Jr., the chairman and chief executive of YES, said during a news conference in Manhattan. ''
I don't have a clue what just happened.''
He said he was told yesterday morning by Bloomberg, who brokered the deal, ''that Jimmy told us to take a hike,'' a reference to James L. Dolan, the president of Cablevision.

Hindery denied Cablevision's accusations that pressure from George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, and Goldman Sachs, the investment banking house that owns 40 percent of YES, caused him to demand major changes in the tentative handwritten agreement announced on March 12.
Such claims, he said, are ''wrong and rude.''
But Dolan said that when YES sent him a revised typewritten draft on March 14, it contained alterations that he found unacceptable.
But he did not blame Hindery. ''

As badly as Leo acted, six times in the last two weeks Leo agreed to accept the March 12 document, and six times went back to his board and they sent him back with a new document,'' Dolan said during an interview. ''

The mother of the complainant in the Glen Ridge sex assault case ended four days of testimony today by enduring more intense cross-examination about her daughter and sex, then telling the prosecution that she was "totally horrified" by the details of what prosecutors say was the attack.
As she has since taking the stand, the mother remained calm under a two-hour barrage of sex-oriented questions by a defense lawyer, Michael Querques.
But her composure wavered and she wept quietly as she began telling a prosecutor, Robert Laurino, her thoughts about the case.

The state has charged four former football teammates at Glen Ridge High with assaulting the young woman, who is mildly retarded and has an I.Q. of 64, with a broom handle and a narrow baseball bat on March 1, 1989. "
Who would believe anyone would do this to anyone?"
the woman's mother said.
Calls Incident 'Unbelievable' Before she could add anything else, a defense attorney, Thomas Ford, requested a private conference among the lawyers and the judge, R. Benjamin Cohen.
As the judge and the lawyers talked quietly for about five minutes, the witness sat erect and silent, occasionally wiping her eyes and glancing at her folded hands.
By the time the meeting ended and Mr. Laurino resumed his questioning, the mother had regained her poise. "
The incident itself is unbelievable to me," she said.
MOST manufacturers recommend washing vinyl or aluminum siding twice a year to remove dirt, grime and mildew.
Generally a forceful spray from a garden hose is enough.
Areas with thick accumulations of grime may have to scrubbed with a brush and cleaning agent.
Use a non-abrasive household detergent mixed with water for this.
Connect an extension pole with a brush attachment to your garden hose for scrubbing areas that are out of reach.
These units have a reservoir that adds detergent to the water and sprays the mixture through the brush attachment.
After scrubbing the siding, rinse off the detergent with clear water.
In some places, the siding may have dark gray or black patches that resemble soot, and resist cleaning with ordinary detergent.
These spots are most likely caused by mildew.
Mildew can be eradicated by washing it with a bleach solution, 3 parts water to 1 part chlorine bleach.
FOR the innocent Long Islander, one of the many hazards of midtown Manhattan is the cast of strange characters who lurk on every city block, distributing free literature.
As a spectator sport, it's quite entertaining to watch the dance duets of the touts and the pedestrians who are trying to avoid them.
But personally, being a polite suburban person and an avid reader, I find it hard to say no to anything in print.
The result is that, within a few blocks, I become a walking scarecrow bulging with scraps of multicolored paper.
This makes me a magnet for every other street person with a message.
It seems an awful waste of paper, and I feel that all this throwaway literature should be recycled.
If I had the nerve, I'd stand on a the corner of Seventh and Thirty Fourth, handing out my accumulated pamphlets to tourists and foreigners who are too courteous to refuse.
But usually I dump the lot in a trash can at Penn Station, when nobody is looking.
One sunny day last week, moved by sheer curiosity, I decided to keep all my mystery messages and read them on the train going home.
Perhaps I'd been missing something by being so self-conscious and puritanical.
IN the near future, scientists should be able to produce a wide range of spare body parts for transplants by growing body tissue.
In fact, some techniques for what is known as tissue engineering are already available in the form of skin grafts and bone cartilage.
Dr. Steven B. Zelicof, associate professor of orthopedics at New York Medical College, performs Carticel cartilage repair at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains.
The procedure, which was developed and registered in Sweden, permits the removal and re-implantation of a patient's own cartilage cells to fill a cartilage defect.
The technique, which a group of researchers developed in collaboration with the Genzyme Corporation of Cambridge, Mass., made it available to the public in Sweden in 1987.
The procedure was recently introduced in this country and is being performed at a handful of medical treatment centers.
Dr. Zelicof, also chief of orthopedics at Sound Shore Medical Center in New Rochelle, said the procedure is done in three steps.
First, a small sample of healthy cartilage tissue is removed from a patient's knee by arthroscopic surgery.
The recovered tissue is then sent to a specialized processor, Genzyme Tissue Repair, and under strict sterile conditions the cartilage cells are grown in culture.
The cells reproduce themselves many times in this environment and take several weeks to grow to the point where they can be returned for reimplantation.

NATO troops entered Kosovo today as dawn was breaking, hours after Russia's surprise entry into Pristina, the capital, a city that the allied forces plan to make their headquarters for returning a million local Albanians to their homes.
British paratroopers lifted off on schedule to secure hills overlooking the highway to Pristina, only 60 miles away across the border.

And NATO's main advance elements, led by a British armored force, passed the border post here starting at 5:20 A.M. Brigadier Adrian Freer met with the Yugoslavs to discuss last-minute details then led his convoy, numbering about 2,000 troops, toward Pristina.
One paratrooper, Greg Lovell, passed by a refugee camp and said, ''The elation on people's faces was just unbelievable.''
Chinook helicopters swept across the hilly landscape and up a river, sending off defensive flares.
Other members of the contingent here are from France, Italy and the United States.
But the Russian troops' arrival in Pristina only hours before had thrown the operation into doubt.
The Russians, greeted joyously by the remaining Serbs in Pristina, came from Bosnia, where they were part of the United Nations peacekeeping contingent.
Some armored vehicles had the Bosnia peacekeepers' insignia, SFOR, hastily painted over by one letter to read KFOR, the initials of the new Kosovo deployment.

Friday was a jittery day, with allied paratroopers and others at first standing on alert to enter Kosovo to block the Russians, but then backing off as senior Russian officials gave their word their troops would not move in from Serbia, where they first arrived from Bosnia.
CHARLES E. SCHUMER  From a speech in Manhattan yesterday morning: '' Al D'Amato will not keep his promise to retire unless we do it for him.
Now, let's turn back the clock: Six years ago, on this day, Al D'Amato said he would not run again.
And the voters essentially gave him a 'Bye.'
They said: 'O.K., let's give him six more years.
That's all he's asking for.
That's all he'll serve.
And maybe he'll change his ways and be a better public servant and less of a politician in the Senate.'
But six years later, Al D'Amato is still at the table asking for more.
And we have learned our lesson.
We can't afford to give Al D'Amato another six years.
The Government announced today that it had broken up a ring of North Korean spies, one of whom was identified as an eminent scholar known as the father of sociology studies in South Korea.
The arrest of the scholar, Koh Young Bok, a 69-year-old professor emeritus at Seoul National University, sent shock waves through the Korean establishment.
He had served as director of a government research center and had made two official trips to North Korea in 1973 as a South Korean adviser.
The authorities said today that on those occasions he had actually briefed the North on the South's bargaining position.
Professor Koh has been spying for North Korea for the last 31 years, South Korea's intelligence agency said.
In that time he has also written two dozen sociology works, including standard Korean textbooks, and served as mentor to many of the country's scholars.
The reported spy ring was broken up when a leftist reported to the South Korean authorities that he had been approached by two North Koreans and asked to spy for the North.
That led the counterintelligence police to detain the two North Koreans, Choi Chung Nam, 35, and his wife, Kang Yun Jung, 28.
Ms. Kang committed suicide a day later.

The police had searched the two carefully for any suicide capsules, X-raying them and examining their mouths, but when Ms. Kang went to the bathroom with an escort she removed a cyanide capsule that she had hidden in her vagina and killed herself with it.

WHEN Genevieve and Morrell Trimble cast their eyes on 250 acres of rubble and overgrown landscape -- the remains of Afton Villa, a Louisiana ante bellum mansion with lavish gardens -- they decided to pre-empt its inevitable takeover  by real estate developers by buying it themselves.

Since the main house had burned to the ground in 1963, their architect, Barry Fox, helped turn the pool house into charming living quarters for the Trimbles, who in 1972 embarked on their huge, 20-year project to restore the lost gardens.

Thanks to their dedication, their gardening skills, and the quality of the original landscape architecture, Afton Villa again offers visitors to Louisiana a taste of the golden age of Southern living.
The estate is about half an hour south of Baton Rouge, near the small town of St. Francisville.
As my companion and I turned off the main road, our first view of it signaled something extraordinary ahead.
Many landscape architects believe  in emphasizing the entry to a property.

At the villa's Gothic gates we admired a pond with a three-tiered fountain at its center; beyond it a half-mile of gently winding road unfolds under a canopy of 258 live oaks, double-planted to intensify the dramatic arboreal archway.
Lining the drive are large bushes of a brilliantly translucent red azalea, called Afton Villa in honor of its native habitat.
Thanks to the withering winter of 1996, these early azaleas, as well as wisteria, fruit trees and bulbs, were not as spectacular when we visited as they usually are.

But dogwoods, white azaleas, some hardy bulbs, late tulips, perennials and annuals are still bringing color to the elegant landscaping, which, owing to its "good bones," depends less on flowers than do many gardens.

Rejecting demands by jobless workers' groups for large increases in benefits, the leader of France's left-wing Government pleaded on national television tonight for enough time for his policies to start cutting the 12.4 percent unemployment rate. ''

This Government needs a minimum of time to make its policies work,'' Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, elected last June on a promise to make jobs the Government's first priority, said in an hourlong interview on France's most-watched prime-time news program. ''

It isn't these people who will determine French policy,'' he said, referring to demonstrators whose sit-ins in welfare offices, banks and lately, luxury restaurants in Paris like La Coupole and Fouquet's have attracted widespread public sympathy. ''
It is the voters, who gave us a mandate,'' he said.

Mr. Jospin had told Parliament earlier that raising welfare payments by $250 a month, as the unemployed workers' groups have been demanding, was ''not possible'' because the Government did not have the money. ''
We cannot increase the budget deficit by 70 billion francs,'' he said, putting the cost of the measure at $11.7 billion, ''nor ask the French people to pay 70 billion francs more in taxes.''

But he told the private TF1 television anchor Patrick Poivre d'Arvor tonight that the Government would index welfare payments to inflation, now running at barely 1 percent a year, retroactively to 1994.

Mr. Jospin's left-wing coalition Government of Socialists, Communists and Greens, like the conservative-led Government they defeated at the polls last year, has to keep the budget deficit this year to 3 percent of gross domestic product to qualify France for a planned common European currency.
Prime Minister Jospin said in Parliament that putting welfare payments much closer to the minimum wage could discourage people with few skills from working. ''
We don't want a society of assistance, but one based on work and productive activity,'' he said, and even some members of the conservative opposition applauded him.
Lakers 117, Kings 107 It has been Shaquille O'Neal's season, and if what happened yesterday is an accurate indication, the playoffs may be his, too.

O'Neal, a virtual lock for his first National Basketball Association most valuable player award, equaled a career playoff high with 46 points, and he also had 17 rebounds and 5 blocked shots as the Los Angeles Lakers opened the playoffs with a 117-107 home victory over the pesky Sacramento Kings.
Many in the sellout crowd of 18,997 at the Staples Center chanted, ''M.V.P., M.V.P.,'' in the final minute of play, after O'Neal had been taken out of the game.
The 28-year-old O'Neal hasn't won an N.B.A. championship and has said repeatedly that it is his main priority.
His chances right now look pretty good under the Lakers' first-year coach, Phil Jackson, who guided the Chicago Bulls to six titles in the 1990's -- none before Michael Jordan turned 28.
The Lakers, 67-15 in the regular season, have the home-court edge throughout the playoffs. ''
We played our A game today,'' O'Neal said. ''
It's a different season, a different kind of focus.
We're on a mission here.''
Game 2 in the three-of-five-game series will be Thursday night, and Sacramento is home for the third game next Sunday.
To the Editor: The passing of Jerry Garcia (front page, Aug. 10) and his legacy is a hotly debated topic in the wake of his premature demise.
The Grateful Dead symbolize much more than a counterculture phenomenon that detractors link to promiscuity and drug abuse.
The personal foibles of Mr. Garcia, or other band members, of this most famous vestige of the 1960's, should not subvert the true message and beauty of his music.
The 60's were a magical time of idealism, civil rights, love, peace and freedom.
The Grateful Dead does not endorse drug abuse in its followers.
The likes of Vice President Gore and Senator Patrick Leahy appreciate the music for what it is: a celebration of life, freedom and a glimpse of a more idealistic era.
The 60's ethic rejected establishment views of materialism, politics, prejudice and the meaning of life itself.
That many youth of this era, as well as bygone eras, abuse drugs or alcohol has nothing to do with any perceived "endorsement" of this behavior by the Grateful Dead.
The music itself has an uplifting, improvisational quality.
No two concerts were ever alike.
In life, Inna Kuperman is a 23-year-old graduate student with a soft voice and an aptitude for behavioral neuroscience.
But in a poster-size photograph gazing out over Mulberry Street, she is immortalized as a pouting teenager, ''Miss New York City,'' the Lolita of NoLIta.
In a neighborhood that changes at the speed of chic, Ms. Kuperman's photograph and the accompanying caption have endured, becoming a billboard for all things beautiful and bizarre.
The simple picture of a 15-year-old has spawned a small cult revolving around Miss New York City.
The tale of Ms. Kuperman's photo begins one September day eight years ago, when she ducked into a clothing shop to look around.
The shop's owner, Makau Nzomo, said he was struck by the girl, and saw in her an avatar of New York's beauty.
Ms. Kuperman's first impression was more muted. ''
He didn't seem like he was a bad person,'' she said.
After getting permission from Ms. Kuperman's mother, Mr. Nzomo threw together a studio in his store and selected a tank top for Ms. Kuperman to wear.
He snapped a few shots and hung one in his window, adding the caption ''Miss New York City.''
''WE haven't had any body shots yet,'' said Greg Harrington, corporate beverage director for Dos Caminos, a new Mexican restaurant in New York.
A body shot is a tequila drinker's technique -- a shot of tequila, served with salt, on someone else's neck, and a wedge of lime, in someone else's mouth.
You lick the salt off and bite into the lime, exchanging it as a kind of ''Mexican kiss.''

With 100 tequilas on his menu, Mr. Harrington is trying to introduce young and excitable New Yorkers to the concept of tequila as an adult's drink, along the lines of other distilled connoisseur items like Cognac and grappa.
He has his work cut out for him. ''
She fell asleep on me,'' a patron at Mr. Harrington's bar shouted to a drinking colleague on Wednesday night.
The context was unclear. ''
I like my health club,'' his companion roared back.

Dos Caminos, on Park Avenue South at 26th Street, is a large, loud establishment behind two tall black doors with brushed-chrome ''D'' and ''C'' door pulls that look like the world's biggest Banana Republic belt buckle.
The crowd inside could have been a reunion party for a batch of genetic clones.

H. Carl McCall said yesterday that upstate and suburban New Yorkers should have a direct say in planning the reconstruction of Lower Manhattan, and that the state agency overseeing the rebuilding effort should be enlarged to include members from outside New York City.

Mr. McCall, a Democratic candidate for governor, said he would revamp the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the 16-member agency created by Gov. George E. Pataki to help New York recover from the Sept. 11 attack.
He also said Mr. Pataki had excluded ''too many important groups'' from the agency, which will shape the future of downtown New York.
In particular, Mr. McCall said, new members should represent hotel and retail workers, religious and civic groups, and ''upstate and suburban interests.''
Mr. McCall's remarks were part of a speech at Pace University in Lower Manhattan intended, he said, to lay out his views on how to rebuild downtown New York and the state economy.
Mr. McCall also echoed an attack that his Democratic rival, Andrew M. Cuomo, made in a similar speech three weeks ago by criticizing Mr. Pataki's role in overseeing the redevelopment effort. ''
We need a long-term vision for the future of New York,'' Mr. McCall said. ''
And the governor, I believe, has failed to provide that vision and that leadership.''
In his speech, Mr. McCall, the state comptroller, sketched out a vague vision of what a rebuilt Lower Manhattan should look like.
It reflected what has already emerged as a rough consensus among New York officials and planners: a mixture of residential and business development, along with a memorial.
Five striking images of Terri Schiavo appeared on television yesterday.
One showed a beaming young woman with long, wavy hair, apparently in front of a Christmas tree.
Another showed a bride in a lacy high-collared dress, flanked by her parents, no groom in sight.
In a third portrait, Ms. Schiavo, in a spiky haircut and heavy makeup, wore an ambiguous expression.
A fourth showed a wide-necked woman in bed, regarding a visitor blankly.
None of these pictures were dated.
But the final image, a video clip, came with a date: August 2001.
In the video, Ms. Schiavo has her head tilted back at an odd angle.
She can be seen smiling and looking up at her mother in what might be described as wonderment.
The images were significant because they hinted at what all the pundits failed to address: the human-interest side of Ms. Schiavo's story.
To the Editor: There's a ''smile on the Governor's face,'' but it's not ''for the whole New Jersey human race'' as she signed her school financing bill.

She opted to sign the bill, passed by her subservient Republican-controlled Legislature, not in the presence of some of the poorest school districts, but instead she chose the safe confines of the State House.
The bill makes absolutely no meaningful effort to raise school spending for poorer school districts to the level of the state's wealthiest districts.
Say the Republicans in defending the right of richer school districts to outspend the poor, ''it's called America and capitalism.''
This philosophy clearly illustrates where the agendas of the Governor and her political cronies are entrenched.

Never having found it personally necessary to tighten her own belt, the Governor has, these past three years, required New Jersey taxpayers to find ways and means to cut the cost of education, regardless of the dire consequences.
If homeowners took a closer look at their property tax bills, they would understand the enormous impact that school taxes place on their pocketbooks.
School districts are now attempting to survive on less state aid, 38 percent of their budgets, compared with 42 percent three years ago.
Efforts to make up the difference must, of course, find their way into higher property taxes.
Thanks to the current Trenton leadership, property taxes in central and northern New Jersey have the dubious distinction of being among the highest in the nation.
Just about everything in the new Getty Center's first year of operations has been larger than life, but one of the more revealing developments at its spectacular campus here took place quietly.
The Getty had previously agreed to bring an exhibition on Sigmund Freud to its campus.

But several months ago Getty officials called the nearby Skirball Cultural Center and asked if it wanted to be the host of the exhibition, which is now at the Library of Congress in Washington, adding that the Getty would still foot the cost, roughly $300,000. ''
They approached us, which I think was a very important statement,'' said Dr. Uri D. Herscher, president of the Skirball, which is dedicated to Jewish-American culture.
It was the first time the Getty had engaged in such a cooperative venture with another museum here.
When the J. Paul Getty Trust opened its $1 billion hilltop home last Dec. 16 after 13 years of planning and construction, it was one of the more celebrated cultural events in the nation.

Visits to the museum are running about 50 percent ahead of what had been expected: close to two million people will have made the trip in the first year, even though parking reservations have been almost impossible to obtain, and the museum can be reached only after a tram ride.
As a result, the Getty's first new construction project involves an additional set of restrooms.
But behind the big numbers and public enthusiasm, the Getty, one of the wealthiest private arts institutions in the world, has been rethinking its mission and its role in Los Angeles.

For good or for ill, the once remote and self-contained museum is reaching out in new ways, as it did to the Skirball, however slowly at times; it is also turning from unfettered growth to an era of limits on what it can do by itself.
It takes only two big spenders to push the price of an artwork to stratospheric levels, but three determined telephone bidders declared war last night at Christie's sale of 20th-century art.
So eager were they to take home Picasso's ''Nude on a Black Armchair'' that they were still fighting it out at $36 million.
In the end, the winner paid $45.1 million, nicely above Christie's high estimate of $40 million.
So tense was the bidding that the salesroom burst into applause when the winner was finally declared.
Of the 53 works offered, 38 found buyers.
The sale totaled $99.9 million, well above Christie's low estimate of $89.2 million.
The sale exceeded Christie's auction of Impressionist and post-Impressionist art on Monday night by more than $11 million.

The Picasso, a 1932 portrait of the artist's mistress Marie-Therese Walter asleep with her arms stretched over her head, was one of 12 works being sold from the estate of Madeleine Haas Russell, one of San Francisco's most important philanthropists.
Mrs. Russell, who died in April at 84, was a great-grandniece of Levi Strauss, and the Picasso was the jewel in her collection.
Painted in just one day -- March 9, 1932 -- it is the first in a series of portraits of Walter that the artist made that year while he was living in Boisgeloup, outside Paris.
Pope John Paul II urged his fellow Poles today to reject the sensual, secular culture of a Western Europe that he contended had betrayed the roots of Christendom. "
Do not let yourself get caught up by this civilization of desire and consumption," the Pope said, his voice filled with emotion.
He offered his vision of a post-Communist Poland that could stand as a spiritual exemplar for the continent. "
Is it civilization or an anti-civilization, a culture, or an anti-culture?"

Since the fall of Communism in 1989, Poles often speak wistfully of their hopes for returning to Europe, which means everything from the chance to enjoy political freedoms to the purchase of imported goods from the West.
But the Pope said that amounted to striving toward a false god if it amounted to abandoning the teachings of the church in this predominantly Roman Catholic nation. "
My dear brothers and sisters, I wish as Bishop of Rome to protest at such a definition of Europe, of Western Europe," the Pope told an open-air Mass in the city of Wloclawek in central Poland. "
This insults this great world of Christian culture from which we have drawn, from which we had co-created for the price of our sufferings."

Personal Pleas for Morality "We do not have to enter Europe, because we helped to create it and we did so with greater effort than those who claim a monopoly on Europeanism, on exclusiveness," the Pope said to a rain-soaked crowd estimated at 150,000. "
And what should be the criteria of Europeanism?
In the cosmic cast of characters, there are shining stars and an assortment of planets orbiting some of those stars like bit players.
And there are very faint objects of intermediate size, brown dwarfs, that have been stepping out of the wings with increasing and mystifying frequency.
But what are these brown dwarfs?
Failed stars, giant planets or something entirely different?

Astronomers today reported on new telescope observations providing the first strong evidence that most, if not all, brown dwarfs appeared to have formed like stars but lacked sufficient mass to ignite and sustain the thermonuclear reactions that make larger stars shine.
The evidence even suggested that some brown dwarfs, which presumably can range in size from 10 to 70 times the mass of Jupiter, might have planets of their own.

An international team of astronomers reached that conclusion from an examination of 100 young brown dwarfs in the Orion Nebula with a near-infrared camera on the New Technology Telescope, operated by the European Southern Observatory in La Silla, Chile.
The findings were described here at a meeting of the American Astronomical Society.
This was the largest population of brown dwarfs ever studied in one region.
It is a region where stars are being born in abundance.

La Boheme 24 Minetta Lane, near Avenue of the Americas (212-473-6447) - This lively bistro has a barnlike setting with plank floors, wood and stucco walls and a roaring pizza oven.
Roasts, seafood and thin-crusted pizzas make for enticing fare at moderate prices.
Fine bistro dishes include crispy roast duck; roast chicken with green peppercorn and canteloupe sauce, and monkfish au poivre.
