North Carolina A Bit Early, Helms Opens Fire Senator Jesse Helms's election campaigns are almost always a case study in take-no-prisoners politics.
His new television commercial, touching on the combustible issues of affirmative action and gay rights, suggests that this year will be no different.
Mr. Helms, a 74-year-old Republican seeking his fifth term in the Senate, decided not to wait until the Democratic primary on May 7 to begin defining his  opposition.

His new commercial attacks both leading candidates for the Democratic nomination: Harvey Gantt, former Mayor of Charlotte, and Charlie Sanders, former chairman of the pharmaceutical company Glaxo Inc. "Harvey Gantt and Charlie Sanders are hiding a big secret on the issues -- they are almost exactly the same," declares the narrator of the advertisement, which began running on Tuesday. "
Liberal Sanders supports racial preferences in  hiring like Harvey Gantt does.
Extending health insurance to homosexual partners -- liberal Sanders and Gantt say yes."
The accusations against Mr. Gantt are a reprise of those that Mr. Helms made  in a previous matchup, in 1990, when Mr. Gantt was defeated by 53 percent to 47  percent.
At the time the Senator accused Mr. Gantt, the first black Mayor of Charlotte, of supporting racial quotas and criticized him for raising campaign money in gay bars.
Mr. Gantt and Mr. Sanders say they support affirmative action but oppose racial quotas in hiring.
Mr. Sanders supports the policy of his former company,  Glaxo, of extending health care benefits to the partners of gay employees.
The UAL Corporation and Delta Air Lines reported improved results yesterday for the most recent quarter, but still lost money in what is usually a money-losing quarter for airlines.
UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, said it lost $64 million in the fourth quarter of 1993, while Delta reported a loss of $141 million.

Losses for both airlines were narrower than in the similar quarter of 1992, in part because of lower fuel prices, improved productivity and an increase in traffic in November during the strike by American Airlines' flight attendants.
United competes with American at O'Hare Airport, Chicago's and the nation's busiest field, and Delta has a hub along with American at Dallas-Fort Worth. "
They're getting there," said Kevin C. Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, "but they are still digging themselves out of the hole."
Separately, leaders of the Air Line Pilots Association at United voted in favor of a plan to exchange wage and work-rule concessions for control of the carrier.

With approval by the pilots yesterday and the International Association of Machinists late Wednesday, the only remaining hurdle to completing the $5 billion buyout is a vote by shareholders this spring.
The unions are trying to gain control to block a threatened restructuring that would result in thousands of layoffs and in the sale of some assets.
UAL's fourth-quarter loss of $64 million, or $3.02 a share, compared with a loss of $224 million, or $9.27 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year ago.
Revenue rose 13.7 percent, to $3.64 billion from $3.20 billion.
HAVING MORE THAN ONE, WITH NO side effects, is now easier than ever.
There are at least three dozen nonalcoholic beers and wines on the market, and some are extremely good.
They allow people who want to limit their alcohol intake to have a glass of something more interesting than mineral water at a dinner party or to segue from regular beer or wine to a healthier drink.
The demand for nonalcoholic beverages began about a decade ago and has been growing here and abroad ever since.
They are consumed mostly by people who sometimes drink alcohol but who, for various reasons, prefer not to have it on particular occasions, according to beer makers.
Limiting alcohol helps control calories: 12 ounces of regular beer have 120 to 150 calories, whereas nonalcoholic beer contains just 60 to 75 calories.

In addition, certain people are advised not to drink alcohol, including pregnant women; diabetics; older people, whose tolerance for alcohol tends to decrease, and many patients on chemotherapy or taking antidepressants, antibiotics or muscle relaxers.
Public awareness of the hazards of drinking and driving, coupled with designated-driver programs and random alcohol testing on highways, also influences the choice of a nonalcoholic beverage.
Some recreational boaters are choosing beer without alcohol, because drinking is as incompatible with safety on the water as it is with safety on the road.
Recent statistics show that alcohol is responsible for most boating fatalities. "

Lisa Jeanne Therese Domingo, a daughter of Bernadette and Dr. Rodolfo T. Domingo of East Islip, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Murray Parizeau, a son of Sheila M. Parizeau of Westfield, N.J., and the late Douglas G. Parizeau Sr.
The Rev. Peter Gerhard, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.
The Rev. Dr. Clark Cahow, a Baptist minister, took part in the service.
The couple graduated from the University of Vermont.
Mrs. Parizeau, 30, is a registered nurse at Youville Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. She received her nursing degree magna cum laude from Northeastern University.

Her father is a senior attending vascular surgeon at the Good Samaritan Medical Center in West Islip, N.Y. Her mother retired as an operating room supervisor at the Kings County Medical Center in Brooklyn.
Mr. Parizeau, 32, is a law student at Boston College.
He received a master's degree in comparative Canadian and American history from Duke University.
His mother retired as a sales associate at Rorden Realty in Westfield.
His father owned the Murray Company, which was a pharmaceuticals consulting and sales company in Westfield.
BLIZZARDS swept through Wall Street last week -- bonus blizzards, that is.
Henry M. Paulson Jr., chief executive of Goldman Sachs, received $37 million in shares and options.
Richard S. Fuld Jr. of Lehman Brothers got $15 million in restricted stock, while John Mack, Morgan Stanley's new chief executive, pocketed an $11.5 million stock grant for six months' work.
But one Wall Street executive atop a fast-growing firm is saying no to the piles of pay that make corporate America's world spin so splendidly.

In a remarkable two-page letter to the chairman of his company's compensation committee, this executive requested that he receive no increase in salary, zero stock options, a smaller bonus than last year and a piece of the company's profit-sharing pie equal to that received by all employees.
This, in a year when his company's revenue grew by more than 40 percent.
Who is this magnanimous executive?
Ethan Berman, founder and chief executive of RiskMetrics, a private company that was formed at J. P. Morgan Chase and spun out to private investors in 1998.
RiskMetrics, based in Manhattan, helps institutions and corporations assess risk in their investments; it is owned by its employees and three private equity firms.
It will generate revenue of $100 million this year.
To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof's column reminded me of my experience as a foreign exchange student to Bandung, Indonesia, during the summer of 1974, after 11th grade.
I grew up in a Long Island suburb and was looking for adventure and a chance to test myself.
I lived with a local family without running water, refrigeration or toilets, and the bugs were fierce.
I went to school with my Indonesian sister, traveled throughout Java and Bali and became familiar with Muslim traditions.
Many locals had never seen a Westerner before, and they would chase me in the street to touch my blond hair.
It was a challenging experience for a typical American teenager, but it changed my life forever and influenced my attitudes and values about the world and my place in it.

It may be a bit masochistic to opt out of the typical foreign study or summer travel option in countries like Italy or France, but the benefits of living with local families in developing countries are enormous.
Currently, my 11th-grade son is looking for community service opportunities in a foreign country.
The brochures look more like travelogues.
I will try to encourage him to enter the contest to win a trip with Mr. Kristof, but I don't think that it's his cup of tea.
LEAD: To the Editor: To the Editor: Why not follow up ''Plain Speaking in the Supermarket'' (editorial, March 10) with ''Fair Packaging in the Supermarket''?
Coffee weighing 13 ounces is put into the same can that used to hold 16 ounces - a not-too-subtle price increase (even though the price is shelf-marked - the intended deception is evident).
Cans of a product from one maker, shelved next to one another with similar labels, come in weights varying by fractions, such as 11 1/4 ounces, 13 ounces, 14 ounces.
Who needs these minute gradations?
Carrots are packaged in transparent plastic bags imprinted with carrot-colored parallel lines, which optically create a farm-fresh appearance.
Open the bag and the real, less appealing carrot appears.
I'm sure other consumers could provide dozens of their own examples.
Give us a break.
Have different label designs - or color-code - size variations.
Print the weight of the contents in suitable-size type - on the top of the label, not the bottom.
Higher gas prices might not be making Americans rush to buy small cars, but William Clay Ford Jr. says his company is preparing for a future of more sticker shock at the pump.
Mr. Ford, the chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, said yesterday that his company now planned to make three hybrid vehicles, two by the 2007 model year.
He also said it would redouble efforts to build more efficient vehicles.
This year, Ford, if it sticks to its current product plan, will become the third automaker to sell a hybrid vehicle, offering a version of its Escape sport utility vehicle.

Mr. Ford also reiterated Detroit's past support for substantially higher gas taxes -- a notion recently pilloried on the campaign trail -- as well as incentives for consumers buying vehicles like hybrids, which supplement internal combustion with electric power. ''

The importance of fuel economy will only increase as we go forward,'' Mr. Ford said at a press preview of the New York International Auto Show, which opens to the public tomorrow at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. ''
The question is how high are they going to get and will they remain high.''
But the allure of size and horsepower remains the dominant force in the American market.
To that end, Ford showed a high-performance prototype of its redesigned Mustang, the GT-R. Fuel economy was not among the talking points in the nine-page press release for the 440-horsepower vehicle.
Yesterday, General Motors introduced the first sport utility vehicle from its Saab division, the 9-7x, which will share the manufacturing base used for the Chevrolet Trailblazer and the GMC Envoy.
For the fourth consecutive quarter, the Hewlett-Packard Company has reported earnings that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates.
Hewlett-Packard officials who announced the figures today also predicted that the company would see 11 to 13 percent revenue growth in the next quarter.

Hewlett-Packard also said today that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the initial public offering of its subsidiary, Agilent Technologies Inc. Agilent is the name given to Hewlett-Packard's original business in electronic test and measurement gear as well as its medical imaging and patient monitoring business.
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Goldman, Sachs are the lead manager and co-lead manager for the offering.
Hewlett-Packard reported its results after the close of the market.
But positive news was broadly anticipated, and Hewlett-Packard shares closed at $110.25, up $4.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. ''
It was altogether a good quarter,'' said Daniel Kunstler, an analyst with J. P. Morgan. ''
The place where they just blew the cover off the ball was in printers.
They've got very little to apologize for.''

For its third fiscal quarter, which ended July 31, Hewlett-Packard reported earnings of $853 million, or 81 cents a diluted share, up 37 percent compared with $621 million, or 58 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.
The Senate today rejected, 52 to 46, an attempt to slash the Seawolf submarine program by eliminating two of three vessels now budgeted.
The Bush Administration had recommended that the Seawolf program be cut to save $2.8 billion because it was not needed in the post-Cold War era.
The Seawolfs were designed to monitor Soviet submarines.
The Senate Appropriations Committee, however, voted last week to restore the two Seawolfs and cut funding for the B-2 bomber and the Strategic Defense Initiative instead.
The Seawolf program, which is based in Groton, Conn., and provides more than 15,000 jobs, is strongly supported by the New England delegations in both the House and Senate.
The submarines are built by the Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corporation.

Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, proposed to overturn the Appropriations Committee decision and restore the Administration cut, arguing that the issue was "a choice between billions of dollars worth of pork and billions of dollars worth of national security."

Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, disagreed, saying that for "little or no money" the decision to restore the submarines protected the industrial base and guaranteed an important program for national security.
The vote broke mostly on party lines, with only seven Republicans voting with 45 Democrats to vote down the McCain amendment.
The Administration has threatened to veto the full measure, which the Senate is expected to act on Wednesday.

In a bit of good news that left the retailing world cheering yesterday, a Federal bankruptcy judge in Cincinnati said he would confirm a reogranization plan that would allow the Campeau Corporation's Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corporation units to emerge from bankruptcy court protection next month.
Retailing experts said it would be the first large department store chain ever to emerge from a Chapter 11 bankruptcy. "
This is the biggest Christmas present that Seventh Avenue has received in the past two years," said Alan G. Millstein, the publisher of The Fashion Network Report, a retailing newsletter. "
No retailer this size has ever come out of bankruptcy before."

Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. said from the bench that he planned to confirm the plan, which calls for the retail chains to emerge from bankruptcy protection by issuing stock to creditors, but did not issue an order formally approving the plan.
He is expected to sign the order early next week, after a change in the wording of a passage. "
That's a technicality in my mind," David Heiman, the lead bankruptcy counsel for Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, Federated's law firm in Cleveland, said.
The retailers' dress makers and other suppliers will be fully repaid in cash.
Most other creditors will be paid in a combination of cash, notes and new shares in Federated Department Stores Inc. Creditors forgave about $3 billion of the $8 billion owed by the store chains.
Allied and Federated were dragged into bankruptcy court in January 1990, a victim of a costly takeover by Campeau.
THURSDAY, I walked into a hardware store in suburban Maryland to buy de-icing crystals in advance of a predicted weekend snowstorm.
Lines of customers waiting to pay snaked through the aisles, dozens of men and women with shopping carts full of duct tape and plastic rolls.
Needless to say, I left without de-icing compound.
I also left thinking, What's the point of this?
Flashing ''threat level'' warning boxes on newscasts.
Police officers with shotguns wandering Times Square, antiaircraft missiles near the Washington Mall.
Federal instructions to stockpile water and batteries and obtain plastic and tape for a ''safe room.''
Yet it's far from clear that this security rush will help anyone.
Government cannot, of course, know what will happen or when.
During the 1960's, when the menace was missile attack by the Soviet Union, citizens were urged to do both the useful (stock fallout shelters) and the useless (crouch under the desk at school).

Senator John Edwards of North Carolina walked into a senior citizen center here on Tuesday and took in yet another packed house: every chair was filled, and an overflow crowd upstairs peered over the balcony at the presidential candidate dressed in a suit and sneakers. ''
Do you think they can get any more people in here?''
Mr. Edwards asked.

After six months in which he visited all 99 Iowa counties, as he reminded his audience again on Tuesday, and spent nearly $2 million on television advertisements, Mr. Edwards is roaring toward the end of his battle here.
He is packing halls across Iowa.
He is finding what many Democrats say is the stride that eluded him for much of the year.
And he was attacked by name in a new television advertisement released Tuesday by Howard Dean, a development that Mr. Edwards's advisers celebrated as a sign that he had arrived.
In the process, Mr. Edwards is forcing opponents who had once paid little mind to his candidacy to factor him into their calculations.
He is threatening to siphon away support from candidates like Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, who appears to be in a fight for first place with Dr. Dean.
Mr. Edwards is drawing attention as he contrasts his sunny campaign appeal with what he describes as the sniping of his rivals. ''

The bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City on April 19 has forced network and studio executives to take a second look at plans for films and television series whose plots could now appear tasteless or highly disturbing.
In some cases, programs related to bombings or the activities of terrorists have either been canceled or are hastily being revised.
In the case of two films, "Top Dog" and "Die Hard With a Vengeance," executives, after some soul searching, have decided stick to their release schedules.

Home Box Office had planned to show "In the Line of Duty: Ambush in Waco" on Monday and Thursday on supplementary channels but pulled the film, which tells the story of the 1992 raid by government agents on a compound occupied by members of the Branch Davidian sect in Waco, Tex.
The authorities investigating the Oklahoma bombing have said they believe that anger over the Waco raid may have been a primary motivation for the Oklahoma City bombing.
Quentin Schaffer, HBO's vice president for media relations, said: "Instinctively, everybody felt it was insensitive to have it on at that time.
It was a little exploitative."
Oddly, HBO also found that a young comedians' special that it had taped in March included a routine on Oklahoma with jokes that Mr. Schaffer said were "just a little derogatory."

HBO plans to run a disclaimer at the beginning of the program, which was originally broadcast in March and is now scheduled for rebroadcast in July, stating that the show was taped before the bombing. "
We don't want people to think this was made afterward," said Mr. Schaffer. "
Fresh from its merger with A.T.& T., the NCR Corporation will introduce its first mainframe machine today.

The company's computer line will now stretch from pen-based notebooks to its new NCR 3600, which is built from standard industry parts unlike the traditional mainframes from the International Business Machines Corporation, Hitachi Electronics Ltd. and the Amdahl Corporation.
NCR officials say they do not expect to find new business by competing directly against existing mainframe computers and applications.

Instead they hope to profit from what is known as distributed computing, in which networks of personal computers and more powerful work stations store and retrieve information from centralized data base and file systems. "
We don't look at this as a mainframe computer," said Gilbert P. Williamson, NCR's president.
He said the NCR 3600 will be used for tasks other than the big bookkeeping jobs that many mainframe computers now do.
Differentiating its new product from existing mainframes is critical for the computer maker, analysts say, because the mainframe business is maturing, with single-digit growth.

NCR's new systems will be composed of 8 to 288 of the Intel Corporation's 486 microprocessors, and will use standard I.B.M. computer designs, like the Microchannel data highway, to move information in and out of the computer.
The system will also use arrays of hundreds of small disk drives, like those used in personal computers, rather than larger disks used by mainframe systems.

Mr. Williamson said the NCR 3600, whose prices start at $850,000 and go as high as $8 million, will be able to take advantage of the much faster growth curve of the microprocessor-based computing industry.

Bowing to Greek pressure, the European Community has once again postponed recognizing the independence of the Yugoslav republic of Macedonia but has left open the possibility of doing so in the coming months.
Greece has strongly opposed recognition of the southern Yugoslav republic on its borders as long as it uses a name that Athens sees as historically Greek.
Athens also fears that nationalist groups next door will rekindle the violent fights of earlier this century over reuniting the fractured parts of Macedonia.

Since the 12-nation European Community, which includes Greece, recognized the independence of the former Yugoslav republics of Croatia and Slovenia, it has been under pressure to do likewise with Macedonia.
But at three sessions of the community foreign ministers, Greece has managed to block action on the issue.

Officials in several capitals said today that they were still hoping to reach a common position, and France and Germany appeared particularly anxious to avoid a public rift of the kind that arose earlier this year over recognizing Croatia and Slovenia.
But if no consensus is possible, officials said, several countries are likely to ignore Greece and recognize the tiny republic individually.
So far, only Bulgaria and Turkey have recognized Macedonia. "
It's a delicate situation for the community," a German official said. "
We recognize the sensitivities of Greece, but sooner or later we need a decision."
To the Editor: Don't take away my ''Sesame Street.''
I quit my job to be a stay-at-home mommy and now spend the bulk of my days sitting on the living room rug with my 1 1/2-year-old daughter.
We do puzzles, we blow bubbles and I've taught her to ''moo'' and ''neigh'' and ''itsy, bitsy'' with the best of them.
But I also let my daughter watch some ''Sesame Street'' every day, hoping that it might be educational, and understanding that it's at least entertaining.
And now the experts are tell me that's wrong?
That I'm not doing enough?
That I should stimulate, teach and perform for my daughter ever waking hour?
I'm sorry.
Sometimes mommies need a few minutes to themselves, and sometimes television is an easy answer.
So what if my daughter's limited vocabulary includes words like Elmo and Big Bird?
The dismal performance of the Tokyo stock market -- especially while the rest of the world has rallied -- has been a pesky irritant to those money managers who have been positive on Japan.
It has not been fashionable to be, as it is often put in the industry, "constructive" on Japan, but there are those who are. "
I think about it every day," said Richard H. King, the manager of the Counsellors International Equity mutual fund, which is managed by Warburg, Pincus Counsellors Inc. in New York. "
I look every day and wonder if the policy is right.
I read conflicting views and wonder if the policy is right."
He has plenty of reason to scratch his head.

Despite reductions in interest rates and signs of moderating inflation, which in the United States have helped push the Dow Jones industrial average to record highs, the Japanese market is in decline.

Last Tuesday, the market's blue chip index, the Nikkei 225, closed at 20,858.30, just 636 points, or 3 percent, above its lowest level since the market crashed after reaching a record high of 38,915.87 at the end of 1989.
In two years this is a plunge of 46.4 percent.
But, what is worse, the market seems unable to revive.
Colombia's first steps toward talks aimed at ending  its civil war stumbled today as the commander of the largest rebel group did not appear at an opening ceremony with President Andres  Pastrana.
The commander, Manuel Marulanda, has not appeared in public since his movement began in 1964.
Rebel leaders in attendance said he had stayed away because he had received death threats.
They added that he had never explicitly said he would appear at today's gathering, which had become the main event animating the country and this town of 45,000 peasants on the edge of the jungle.

Flying here from Bogota, the capital, President Pastrana sat alone at a table on a stage decked with the colors of the Colombian flag and with smaller flags strung by the insurgents reading, ''Opening Paths to a New Colombia.''
At the foot of the stage, presidential bodyguards stood shoulder-to-shoulder with rebels.
Above the gathering, overlooking the town's main square, guerrilla sharpshooters watched from windows, rooftops and the church belfry.
The seat for Mr. Marulanda, who is 68, was left empty at the President's side.
The 43-year-old President, inaugurated just five months ago, has made peace with the rebels a priority of his administration.
The Government evacuated security forces from a vast swatch of southeastern Colombia two months ago to allow the talks to proceed.
A DECADE ago, when Rockefeller Center began assembling land at Seventh Avenue and 49th Street, it had in mind a 1.6 million-square-foot office tower.
Four months ago, it opened a parking lot instead.
Edison Parking, which has the contract to manage it, agreed to a 30-day cancellation clause.
That means that Rockefeller Center can quickly revert to Plan A as soon as it pre-leases enough space in the proposed building to warrant breaking ground. "
Sure, we'd rather have a building, but for now a parking lot is nice income," said William J. Maloney, president of the Rockefeller Center Development Corporation.
Parking, the bane of Manhattan drivers, is becoming a boon to all manner of Manhattan business people.
Developers, investors and garage operators, many of whom treaded water in the recession, are again pursuing garage properties and contracts. "
When a garage comes on the market these days, it spikes huge interest," said Robert A. Knakal, president of Massey Knakal Realty Services, a sales broker. "
Well-located parking properties definitely command a premium," said Edward S. Gordon, the real estate executive who owns a controlling interest in Myers Parking.
Parking's attraction is understandable.

The New York Times Company reported a rise of 24 percent in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, exceeding analysts' estimates, on gains in advertising for technology products, financial services and Internet sites.
At the company's flagship newspaper, The New York Times, advertising revenue growth continued to accelerate as the year ended, increasing 35.5 percent in December, compared with December 1998.
As an industry, newspapers have long been classed by investors as mature, with limited growth potential.

Reflecting investors' surprise that even the optimistic December revenue estimates had understated the 1999 performance of several newspaper companies, Kevin Gruneich, an analyst with Bear Stearns, said: ''You call this mature media?
It's going through the ceiling.
These are the good old days.''
Excluding one-time charges, the Times Company earned $108.4 million, or 61 cents a share, compared with $87.3 million, or 47 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
The company took a charge of $3.1 million after taxes to pay for expenses related to work-force reductions at The Boston Globe and at the company's regional newspaper group.
Revenue rose 12.8 percent, to $882.5 million, for the quarter.
Analysts had expected the company to earn 57 cents a share, according to a survey by First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks corporate earnings.
Tennessee has collected nearly $3.5 million since it began enforcing its tax on illegal drugs two years ago, officials from the Department of Revenue said Wednesday.
The state's Unauthorized Substances Tax, passed by the Legislature in 2004, requires anyone in possession of an illegal drug to buy and affix stamps to the drugs' packaging.
Under the law, information provided to the Department of Revenue to buy stamps cannot be used in criminal prosecutions.
There is a toll-free number for stamp application requests, and stamps are doled out based on type of drug and weight.
As is the case in some two dozen other states with similar laws, however, the stamps have become curiosities bought by collectors and lobbyists who campaigned for the bill.
Of the 726 stamps sold so far, none have turned up on seized drugs, said Loren Chumley, commissioner of revenue for the State of Tennessee.
While many think that the idea is inspired, others object to it. ''
It's almost like the law wasn't written to be construed seriously,'' said Gregory P. Isaacs, a lawyer in Knoxville. ''
It's like asking for someone to get a special permit before they drive drunk.''
The real money the law generates comes from penalties assessed on people caught with unstamped drugs.

Having already cracked down on the biggest sources of smog, like cars and factories, New York State is now moving to limit emissions from a variety of consumer products, from hairspray in aerosol cans to all-purpose cleaners in plastic bottles.

The proposal would require manufacturers to reformulate the products they sell in New York -- product changes that would be different from those made in aerosol cans in the late 1970's, when the Federal Government banned the use of a class of compounds known as chlorofluorocarbons.
The concern then was the depletion of atmospheric ozone; the issue now is ground-level smog.
Manufacturers Opposed But consumers would pay for the cleaner air.
Reformulated products would cost more.

Hairsprays, deodorants, antiperspirants, air fresheners and all-purpose cleaners would rise an average of 45 cents for a 6- or 8-ounce container to cover increased manufacturing costs, the State Department of Environmental Conservation says.
The makers of these products are expected to fight to keep the regulations from being imposed.
They say that their products are very small contributors to pollution and that in any case it makes more sense to wait for national standards.
If the regulations are approved after hearings in October in Albany and in New York City, the reformulated products would be phased in between Jan. 1, 1992, and Jan. 1, 1996, officials said.
That the state must try to limit emissions from such mundane products as deodorants demonstrates just how intractable the smog problem has become in the state, particularly in the metropolitan area.

Anne Woolliams, a British ballet teacher who played a major role in the international success of the Stuttgart Ballet and who became artistic director of the Australian Ballet and the Vienna State Opera Ballet, died in Canterbury, England, on July 8.
She was 72 and lived in Canterbury.
The cause was cancer, said her husband, Jan Stripling, a former principal dancer with the Stuttgart Ballet.
Ms. Woolliams, who was trained in England and Germany as a dancer, gained her reputation as a distinguished ballet mistress and teacher during her years in Stuttgart from 1963 to 1975.
John Cranko, who left the Royal Ballet in Britain to head the company in what was then West Germany, made her his assistant from the start.
Soon after his arrival in Stuttgart, he and Ms. Woolliams founded the Stuttgart Ballet School, the first school in West Germany with an integrated program of ballet and academic classes.
As company teacher and ballet mistress, Ms. Woolliams taught many of the company alumni who now direct major companies, including Jiri Kylian, William Forsythe and John Neumeier.
Mr. Cranko named Ms. Woolliams assistant director in 1969, the year the Stuttgart Ballet made its highly acclaimed debut in New York.
Born in Folkestone, England, on Aug. 3, 1926, Ms. Woolliams studied modern dance as a child in Germany and ballet in England with Judith Espinosa, Noreen Bush, George Goncharov and Vera Volkova.
In London she danced, in 1943, with the Kyasht Ballet and then the Russian Opera and Ballet Company, the St. James Ballet and in the film ''The Red Shoes.''

ASK Computer Systems Inc. said today that it had completed the acquisition of the Ingres Corporation for $9.25 a share, or bout $110 million, and had concurrently sold 5.6 million of its own shares to the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Electronic Data Systems Corporation.
The sale will give Hewlett- Packard 9.8 percent of ASK and E.D.S. 19.7 percent.
ASK, based in Mountain View, Calif., is the leading provider of computer software for managing manufacturing.
Ingres, based in Alameda, Calif., produces software for managing large databases.
ASK's latest programs are written using Ingres software.

James P. Lennane, a dissident shareholder who opposed the Ingres acquisition and stock sale, has mounted a proxy fight to gain control of the ASK board at the company's annual meeting later this week.
Mr. Lennane held about 9.7 percent of ASK's outstanding common stock before the sale.
ASK reported first-quarter earnings of $711,000, or 5 cents a share, up 28 percent from $552,000, or 4 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.
Revenues rose 17 percent, to $44.5 million, from $38 million in the first quarter of the 1990 fiscal year.
ASK's shares were unchanged today at $5.625 in over- the-counter trading.
In a victory for the Bush Administration, the Senate Energy Committee voted today against imposing higher fuel economy standards for automobiles.
Shortly before the vote, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins wrote the committee that "no feasible combination of conservation efforts, by itself, can substantially reduce U.S. oil imports."
Just after the vote, Deputy Energy Secretary W. Henson Moore said, "We don't think there is any need for legislation."
First, the committee on a 15-to-5 vote killed a proposal that would have raised the required corporate fleet average to 40 miles per gallon by the year 2001 from the current 27.5 miles.

Then it voted 13 to 7 to reject a measure proposed by Senator J. Bennett Johnston, the Louisiana Democrat who is chairman of the committee, that would have raised the standard to 34 miles per gallon by 2001.
The committee's nine Republicans opposed both proposals.
The 11 Democrats were unable to agree on either proposal, with majorities of them opposing the 40 miles per gallon standard as too severe and the 34 mile per gallon rule as too weak.

First Major Tests on Energy Bill Mr. Johnston had urged passage of his measure on the ground that a bill without specific higher standards would not survive before the full Senate, where a 40-mile-per-gallon proposal by Senator Richard D. Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, was beaten last year only by a filibuster.
Today's votes were the first major tests in what all sides say will be a long, arduous road toward adopting an energy bill.
The committee next faces an equally contentious question, whether to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to exploratory oil drilling.

One day after the National Football League called for a vote by its owners on whether to use instant replay during the playoffs, it became clear that the short time frame involved could hinder its passage. ''
We're not going to cure anything by going into it half-cocked,'' Wellington Mara, the Giants' co-owner, said in a statement.
An opponent of replay in the past, he added, ''We're absolutely opposed to rushing into replay.''

But even an advocate of replay like Dennis Green, the Minnesota Vikings' coach, said he wondered if the league wasn't moving too quickly, reacting too fast to criticism of calls that might have been reversed if replay were in place. ''
There are some people who are for it but won't vote for it because they don't want to rush something in,'' he said. ''
I've looked at the lay of the land, and it does not look good.''
The N.F.L. knows that its quick and unexpected decision to seek a vote on post-season replay may not succeed.
The league announced its intentions Monday, a day after a head linesman at the Jets-Seahawks game incorrectly ruled a touchdown for the Jets' Vinny Testaverde on a 5-yard quarterback sneak. ''
Having replay in the playoffs remains a possibility, not a probability,'' said Joe Browne, the league's senior vice president of communications.
So far, teams have not received the league's proposal, because it is not complete, but a detailed plan was expected to be ready for an anticipated vote next week.
In five tiny rooms on the fourth floor of a glassed-in building in the middle of downtown Rio de Janeiro is a little stock exchange with large pretensions.
Despite plummeting trade volumes around the region, the Sociedade Operadora do Mercado de Ativos, or Soma, wants to be the next Nasdaq -- and not just for Brazil, but for all of Latin America. ''
The recent volatility of stock markets abroad only shows how companies need to have a local listing,'' Romeu Pasquantonio, Soma's managing director, said in a recent interview. ''
Besides, for many companies, listing on the Nasdaq is just not feasible.''
Starting in the fall, the exchange plans a series of conferences in Brazil and other Latin American nations to bring technology and Internet companies together with investors.
In the first steps, private companies would offer blocks of shares and seats on their boards to experienced venture capitalists in exchange for seed financing.
The shares, which would then be listed on Soma, would be open for trade periodically -- anywhere from once a week to once a month, Mr. Pasquantonio said. ''
There are many venture capital companies entering the market now that don't have any way to exit their investments,'' Mr. Pasquantonio said. ''
We want to provide that exit.''
Soma was founded in 1996 by a group of brokerage houses that wanted to create a market for small-capitalization companies in Brazil.
Chris Calabrese lighted a cigarette, straightened his tie and turned his face to the warm afternoon sun. ''

Sometimes people tell me I dress like a Republican,'' said Mr. Calabrese, who stood outside a nondescript storefront here where he has spent months working on behalf of Ned Lamont, the upstart Democratic Senate nominee.

Mr. Calabrese, a former supporter of Mr. Lamont's opponent, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, quit his job at a marketing firm last summer to devote his spare time -- he's also a student -- to the campaign.
Monday was his 27th birthday.
It was also the eve of Election Day, and so, like every other person in Mr. Lamont's Watertown office, he had only one hope. ''
I don't care about my birthday,'' said Mr. Calabrese, who started the day with a morning French class, and planned to end it with phone banking. ''
The thing that would make me happiest is a Lamont victory.
I'm going stay up all night and do what I can to make him win.
I couldn't see myself doing anything else.''
But the Lamont campaign -- built on volunteers with a fondness for long shots, and on many millions of Mr. Lamont's own money -- did not let the day pass unmarked.

As two prominent New Jersey Republicans prepare for what is likely to be an expensive and contentious primary battle for governor, a single piece of campaign-finance reform legislation is suddenly taking on heightened significance.

The bill, which was introduced on Dec. 4 in the State Senate, would alter the state's 26-year-old public financing system for governor's races to counterbalance the advantages held by candidates with large personal fortunes or unusually potent fund-raising operations.

As the law stands, candidates who accept public financing for the 2001 race to succeed Gov. Christie Whitman will get matching funds from the state on a 2-for-1 basis and then may not spend more than $3.8 million in the primary or $8.4 million in the general election.
Candidates who opt out of the system get nothing but are not bound by spending limits.

The bill under consideration, however, would allow a candidate who accepts public financing and faces someone who does not accept it to spend up to $6 million in the primary and $11 million in the general election.

Its sponsor, Senator Gerald Cardinale, a Republican of Cresskill, originally described the bill as a response to Jon S. Corzine, the Democrat who spent more than $62 million on his winning campaign for the United States Senate.

But Bret D. Schundler, the mayor of Jersey City, argued today that the bill was aimed squarely -- and transparently -- at him and that its real author was the Senate president, Donald T. DiFrancesco, his chief rival for the Republican nomination for governor.

Mr. Schundler, a favorite of the party's conservative wing who may be able to raise millions from his ideological soul mates across the country, has said he is likely to bypass public financing, at least in the primary election.

Mr. Schundler says he will need to spend heavily in a primary, in part, to make up for Mr. DiFrancesco's power as an incumbent officeholder with much influence in state government, not to mention his early support from a number of county organizations.
But the bill, which was approved, 5 to 0, by the Senate Committee on State Government today, would throw large obstacles in Mr. Schundler's path.

For the fourth time in a year, Venezuelan voters have eagerly endorsed President Hugo Chavez's promise of a ''peaceful revolution,'' voting overwhelmingly today in favor of a new Constitution that gives him sweeping powers that he says he will use to transform the country's political and social structure.

Brushing aside predictions by the opposition that Mr. Chavez would use the new charter to give himself near-dictatorial powers, 71 percent of voters cast their ballots for the new Constitution, according to partial official results announced this evening.
As that tally was announced, fireworks were set off in neighborhoods all over the capital, and supporters of the president took to the streets to celebrate.

The new Constitution, drawn up by an assembly in which supporters of the president hold more than 90 percent of the seats, increases Mr. Chavez's term of office from five years to six and allows him to succeed himself.

It also eliminates one chamber of Congress, reduces civilian control of the military and significantly expands government management of the economy, which is based on the largest reserves of oil outside the Middle East.
Mr. Chavez, a 45-year-old former army colonel who was jailed after leading an unsuccessful coup attempt in 1992, was elected president a year ago this month.

His platform called for junking the 1961 Constitution, which he dismissed as ''moribund,'' and replacing it with a new charter that he said would eliminate corruption and strengthen democracy by weakening the 40-year stranglehold on power of the country's two traditional political parties.
In April, voters approved Mr. Chavez's proposal to authorize a National Constituent Assembly to draw up a new Constitution.

In another round of balloting in July they elected 131 delegates to the body, which convened in August and, after spending its first month trying to supplant Congress and the courts, drafted a text with 350 articles in less than three months.
Mr. Chavez's resounding victory means that virtually every feature of the political structure here will undergo a change, beginning with Venezuela's name.

Dodgers 19, Pirates 2 Cory Snyder went 3 for 4, all home runs, and drove in 7 runs yesterday as the Dodgers matched their highest run total since moving to Los Angeles by beating the Pittsburgh Pirates, 19-2, at Three Rivers Stadium.
Snyder had a pair of two-run homers, then added a three-run drive during a nine-run seventh inning.
Snyder was advised by the Dodgers' batting coach, Reggie Smith, to keep his head down and to alter the position of his hands during his swing.
Giants 9, Marlins 8 At Miami, Mark Portugal (2-0) won his 14th consecutive decision, and Barry Bonds and Matt Williams hit two-run homers as San Francisco withstood Florida's eighth-inning rally.
Portugal, who gave up five runs in seven innings, was backed by Williams's 4-for-5 performance.
Florida scored three runs in the eighth after a bench-clearing fight that began when Kevin Rogers brushed back Benito Santiago, who charged the mound and tackled the reliever.
Santiago, Rogers and Giants Manager Dusty Baker were ejected.
Braves 4, Cubs 2 Atlanta tied a club record with its 10th consecutive road victory, and the Braves' John Smoltz (2-1) allowed five hits in seven innings, striking out eight.
The Braves, who own the best record in the majors at 12-1, also won 10 straight on the road in July 1992.
Rockies 6, Expos 5 Ellis Burks hit his fifth home run of the season with two outs in the 10th inning as Colorado went above the .500 mark for the first time ever.

There are still doubters left over from Feb. 3, 2002, when New England quarterback Tom Brady and an underappreciated defense walked over the St. Louis Rams and danced on a carpet drenched in confetti.
Brady has a Super Bowl ring from that night and the Patriots' owner, Robert Kraft, owns a shiny trophy, but skeptics can be hard to shake, the facts notwithstanding. ''
Whether they respect us or not, it doesn't matter,'' Brady said after the Patriots' 12-0 victory over the Miami Dolphins here Sunday. ''
I am proud of this team.
I am proud of the guys.
They have a lot of heart and a lot of fight.
And whether we need to drive down the field with hardly any time to score a touchdown, we figure out how to do that.
We find ways to win.''
The Patriots have emerged as a familiar juggernaut in the American Football Conference.

Though many eyes have, understandably, been focused on Kansas City, Indianapolis and Tennessee, the Patriots (11-2) have strung together nine victories in a row to claim their second division title in three seasons and edge ahead of the Chiefs in the race for the top seeding in the conference.
WORK was scarce one recent morning, so Javier Gomez volunteered his services as an interpreter. ''
Rosa is saying she needs to feed her kids,'' said Mr. Gomez, a 24-year-old unemployed construction worker from Ecuador. ''
That's why she stands here every day, waiting for a job, just like the rest of these ladies.''
On a crowded corner at 37th Street and Eighth Avenue, beneath a sign for ''Wonder Foods,'' a long line of Hispanic immigrant women leaned against the wall, saying little to one another.
With a lot of coffee and maybe a bit of luck, they hoped to find a day's worth of work. ''
Yesterday, I took a job in a factory, cleaning floors,'' said Rosa Vega, an Ecuadorean who lives in Ridgewood, Brooklyn. ''
The man pay me $9 an hour.
I hope he come back today.''
As she spoke, her dark eyes panned the bustling streets for potential employers.
Like everyone else, she hoped to be among the few sent to work, either at a factory, an office building, a restaurant, or any place where cleaning, sewing and stocking shelves needed doing.
It is not always going to be this way, Hubie Brooks knows.
It won't always be this sweet.
He cannot give the Mets the stuff of storybooks every day.
He cannot make the ball park tense and electric and occasionally furious the way his predecessor in right field could.
He isn't Darryl Strawberry, never will be, doesn't want to be. "
Were you trying to hit a home run?"
someone asked Brooks after his fly ball settled into the left-field loge seats and gave the Mets a 10-inning, 2-1 victory over the Phillies yesterday at Shea Stadium.
Sitting at a table in the middle of the Mets' clubhouse, his head resting on his left hand, his face a mask of stoicism, Brooks said, "If you can't hit a hundred, don't even try."
A Modest Celebration He wasn't trying to be cute, or curt, as much as he was trying to be low-key.
His delayed steal of home turned out to be the winning run in the season opener on Monday.
THERE is still time to plant bulbs, but hurry.
Election Day is considered by many to be the official bulb planting cutoff date.
The reason is that the soil has to be warm enough for the bulbs to grow roots.
When the soil starts to cool down, the growth rate slows.
Bulbs planted after Tuesday will probably make it through winter.
But the root system will have less time to develop.
If bulbs are forgotten and left in the back of the garage and planted in late December, there will not be much time next spring for the bulbs to form a strong root system and send up flowers.
Since the flowers are already formed in the bulb when you buy it, there is no reason to worry about bloom.
As long as top-quality bulbs have been purchased and planted properly, the bulbs will flower.
But there are a few instances when bulb planting has been disappointing.
Antony Todd, the Manhattan event and floral designer who opened a store with Nina Griscom in Southampton, N.Y., last year, is expanding into furniture and interiors.

The Brodsky Organization, developer of 4W, an apartment building by the architect Hugh Hardy at 4 West 21st St., hired Mr. Todd, above, to consult on the look of the lobby, the hallways and the kitchens and baths.

Mr. Todd's design for a sample apartment at the 4W sales office includes 10 pieces of furniture that are now available through his company, Antony Todd Inc. Mr. Todd conceived the furniture, which is classically modern with a touch of 1970's glamour, as the equivalent of a bridge line of clothing, covering the gap between Crate & Barrel-style designs and custom furniture.
Delivery time is approximately eight weeks. ''
The pieces have clean, simple lines that will work with most interiors,'' said Mr. Todd, 43. ''
They are not about making great design statements.
They are peaceful, they don't scream at you.''

The collection includes several Parsons-style lacquered pieces, including a square 52-inch dining table, top right, in high-gloss China Red ($2,880), and a 48-inch-long console ($1,490), at top left with a pair of coffee tables with steel bases and high-gloss inlay tops ($1,250 each).

There are also upholstered pieces, including a 6-foot-6-inch long sofa (above in linen; from $8,500, depending on fabric); a 4-by-8-foot mirror edged in quarter-inch-thick metal (behind Mr. Todd, $1,650); and a whitewashed oak desk ($1,890).

The Administration has notified members of the Senate that Richard C. Holbrooke is close to a deal with the Justice Department to settle conflict-of-interest allegations, and that his nomination as chief American delegate to the United Nations is likely to be sent to the Senate within days for confirmation, Government officials said today.

Under terms of the agreement, they said, Mr. Holbrooke will pay a penalty of a few thousand dollars to settle Justice Department allegations that he violated Federal lobbying laws in his contacts with the American Embassy in South Korea in 1996.

Officials said negotiations between the department and Mr. Holbrooke, the architect of the 1995 peace settlement in Bosnia, were down to their final hours, with both sides close to the final wording of a settlement. ''
It's very close,'' said a Justice Department official.
A friend of Mr. Holbrooke's, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that the diplomat continued to believe ''he's done absolutely nothing wrong.''
But the friend said he had agreed to a settlement to put the seven-month inquiry behind him and to allow the White House to move forward with his nomination.

Prosecutors had asserted that Mr. Holbrooke's contacts with the Ambassador in Korea, weeks after he resigned from the State Department to join an investment banking firm, amounted to a civil violation of laws that bar officials leaving the Government from a variety of lobbying contacts with their former colleagues.
Congressional officials said Administration officials had informally notified Democratic members of the Senate that a deal with the Justice Department was close. ''
We were told to be ready, and that none of the allegations were serious enough to pose any threat to the nomination,'' said a Congressional official, speaking on condition of anonymity.

Another Congressional official said Senator Jesse A. Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, would doubtless call for a review of the information turned up by prosecutors, but expressed the hope that ''we will probably be able to deal with this fairly quickly and get him confirmed.''
The Roman Catholic bishops who have recently suggested that Catholic politicians who support access to abortion are not fit to receive the sacrament of communion are few in number.
But their words have stirred strong passions among Catholics far and wide, prompting discussions that raise questions about the meaning of being both an American and a Roman Catholic.
In interviews with two dozen Catholics, plenty of anger streamed toward the church's hierarchy for what was seen as meddling in politics.
But there was also a sense of comfort among some that bishops were taking a stand on an issue -- abortion -- that has become so firmly fixed in the American landscape.

The effects of the clergy sexual abuse scandal on the current debate were inescapable, with a number of people faulting the bishops for cracking down on politicians while looking away from the sexual assaults of minors by some priests. ''
I mistrust the bishops so much that I'm kind of cynical,'' said Daniel W. Sexton, 41, a lawyer in Jersey City.
He described himself as strongly opposed to abortion and as an orthodox Catholic who attends a traditional Latin Mass. ''We've got enough problems of our own.''

But reflecting the ambivalent feelings of many Catholics, Mr. Sexton said there was a place for both Christian teaching and moral preaching in the public square and, principally, among all Catholics, not just office-seekers. ''
You have to articulate what the teaching is,'' he said.

Catholic politicians, abortion and communion merged into a recent subject of attention in the pews with the Democratic presidential candidacy of Senator John Kerry, a Roman Catholic who believes in the right to abortion.

LEAD: To the Editor: To the Editor: Although I have no major quarrel with Ian Hamilton's critique of Linda Wagner-Martin's ''Sylvia Plath,'' I must protest the protracted apologia for Ted Hughes embedded in and often overwhelming his peculiar review.
Mr. Hamilton's intimate knowledge of the English-American poetry scene makes it seem disingenuous of him to claim that there have been ''one or two full-length biographies'' of Plath to date.
As he should be aware, my controversial ''Sylvia Plath: Method and Madness'' (1976) was the sole biography to appear before Ms. Wagner-Martin's.

More relevant, several other substantial biographies in the works over the last decade never saw print, largely because of the obstructionist tactics of Olwyn Hughes, Mr. Hughes's sister and manager of the Plath estate.
In my own case, Olwyn Hughes was initially cordial, even generous.

This situation altered dramatically, however, after she read the galleys and began demanding numerous changes, the bulk of which entailed excising any negative references to the Hughes family and modifying several remarks about Plath's mother.
Acute criticisms of Plath herself occasioned no similar objections.
It was evident that Olwyn Hughes intended to protect her family name at all costs, threatening to withhold reprint permissions if I did not capitulate.
Thanks to the generous ''fair use'' provision of our copyright law and a shrewd (and expensive) lawyer, I was eventually able to persuade Seabury Press to publish my book without the permissions.

I do not wish to further hector Ted Hughes -several female critics have, in fact, charged me with being too ''soft'' on him - and regard as disgraceful the many vicious attacks against him by the lunatic fringe of the feminist movement.

To the Editor: I do not believe that Salman Rushdie's situation should be considered a conflict between the right to protect and defend one's religion versus free speech, as a United Nations official suggests to Leslie H. Gelb (column, Dec. 29).
While in no way diminishing these freedoms, I believe the issue is over the right of the government of one country to control an individual over whom it has no jurisdiction.
It is one thing if the mullahs of Iran want to punish Mr. Rushdie for a religious offense with a corresponding punishment, for example, excommunication.
But it is entirely another matter when a government condemns a foreign national to death and seeks to enforce the sentence by extralegal means: a bounty.
I do not believe the issue here would be any different if the alleged offense had not involved speech.
For example, if Mr. Rushdie had been accused of defrauding Iran and condemned.
The West is getting a taste of its own medicine.
Witness most recently our invasion of Panama and abduction of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.
And this is why such extraterritorial activity must stop.

A state judge in California heard arguments on Friday in a lawsuit brought by Apple Computer to force three Web site publishers to reveal the names of confidential sources who disclosed to them Apple's plans for future products.

The outcome of the lawsuit, which was filed in December, could have far-reaching ramifications for the ability of bloggers to maintain the confidentiality of unnamed sources, which news gatherers often depend on for information.

Judge James Kleinberg of the Santa Clara County Superior Court in San Jose, Calif., told the lawyers in the case late Thursday that he was leaning toward permitting Apple to issue subpoenas to the three publishers, Powerpage.org, Apple Insider and Think Secret.
He is expected to issue a formal ruling as early as next week.

In the case, Apple Computer v. Doe 1, Apple wants to force the sites to turn over documents related to an unreleased Apple product called Asteroid and certain other Apple technology under development.

The Electronic Frontier Foundation, a civil liberties group that filed a motion last month to block the subpoenas, argued in court on Friday that online publishers have the same legal protections as traditional journalists, who are shielded under state law from being forced to divulge the names of confidential sources. ''
If this ruling goes in favor of Apple, it will have a chilling effect on the use of confidential sources,'' said Kurt Opsahl, a staff lawyer with the foundation, which is based in San Francisco.
Once the judge rules, the defendants will have five days to decide whether to appeal.
After that period, Apple can issue the subpoenas.

In a separate case, the publisher of Think Secret, a Web site for Macintosh enthusiasts, asked on Friday that Judge Jamie Jacobs-May, also of Santa Clara County Superior Court, dismiss a lawsuit Apple had brought against him.
SEVEN years of apprenticeship, starting at age 11, was how Joseph Gresia honed his tailoring skills in Italy.
Mr. Gresia would go to the tailor's shop in his hometown, Potenza, every day after school at 1 and work until 8 P.M., without pay.
Fifty years ago such arrangements were the norm, Mr. Gresia said. ''
You were trained by a master tailor who took the time to teach you everything he knew,'' he said. ''
It was a fair exchange.''
Yet that was then and this is now, and Mr. Gresia, the owner of Gresia Custom Tailoring in Harrison, worries that he and others who practice his craft are becoming extinct.
He is also an adjunct professor at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan, and he observed that many of his undergraduate students want to become designers without mastering the basics. ''
They don't want to become tailors,'' he said. ''
Students in continuing education classes are different. ''
They are upgrading their skills to get ahead.

With only four months left before most Europeans are forced to give up their rainbow of marks and francs and pesetas and start using euros, the European Central Bank let people actually see their new money today.
But not touch it.
And certainly not take any home.

Rather, in kicking off an intensive advertising campaign to make people realize that their virtual currency soon will be real, officials kept the bills and coins between plexiglass sheets and surrounded by security guards. ''
In some 100 days' time, the euro will be in our pockets,'' said Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank. ''
It will be our money, a tangible reality and not just the 'virtual' market currency which has thus far been perceived to be.''
Starting on New Year's Day, bank machines in 12 countries will stop dispensing national currencies and start pumping out euros.
Stores are to accept the old money for a few more months, but most will give change in euros.

Today, the European Central Bank began the last, most formidable phase of preparations, part of which included opening a continentwide advertising campaign to hammer home that the new money is coming and explain its elaborate holograms and watermarks aimed at foiling counterfeiters.
In the next few days, national central banks across Europe will start shipping the currency to private banks in the first stage of what officials call ''front-loading.''

As a result of a public outcry, Calvin Klein Inc. has canceled its new advertising campaign -- including a controversial billboard in Manhattan's Times Square -- for a line of children's underwear.
The ads showed children actually wearing the underwear, a fact that astonished and appalled conservative groups, psychologists and others.

The odd thing about this latest business capitulation to fin de siecle Puritanism is that hardly any of those guardians of public morals have raised a voice against the everyday commercial abuse of children.

TV series and advertising subject young viewers to a never-ending procession of violence and hucksterism, but it is only ads like Calvin Klein's -- decried as giving comfort to pedophiles -- that are removed from view.
Consider the data.

New York City's procedures to weed out fraudulent welfare claims are so rigorous that thousands of eligible people have been denied benefits, a report released yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission said.

The screening process is intended to uncover fraudulent claims, but has removed some people from the welfare rolls who were not home when  an eligibility specialist paid an unannounced visit, or as a result of  administrative errors, the study said.
A vast majority of people who were taken off the rolls by the screening procedure were actually entitled to benefits and had not committed fraud, the study found.
Since the inception of the city's rigorous procedures in February 1996, social service agencies, union leaders and recipients have complained about the system.
But yesterday was the first time that a group like the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonpartisan watchdog group financed by businesses, had spoken out against the program.
The program has been trumpeted as a success by Mayor Rudolph W.  Giuliani's administration for reducing the welfare rolls.
Anthony P. Coles, senior adviser to Mayor Giuliani, criticized the report in a statement, saying that Mr. Giuliani had moved almost 300,000 people off the welfare rolls since taking office.
Mr. Coles said the concerns raised by the Citizens Budget Commission showed that its leaders were unfamiliar with how the administration's program works, and said the criticisms were unfounded.
Mr. Coles also accused Ray Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, of playing politics.
Mr. Coles said that Mr. Horton has an unofficial advisory role in the mayoral campaign of Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President.

In New Jersey's rich -- and deer-rich -- suburbs, the guns of winter are now silent, momentarily marking the end of a debate that has pitted neighbor against neighbor and drawn crowds to normally sleepy township meetings.
More and more suburbs are ignoring pleas from animal rights supporters and choosing instead to solve problems of shrubbery raids and deer-car collisions by hiring professional sharpshooters.
The list of towns that have adopted this approach now includes Summit, Millburn, Bridgewater, Princeton, Scotch Plains, Springfield and Berkeley Heights.
In addition, state wildlife officials say they have have fielded inquiries from another 30 towns. ''

They're grappling with these issues, but most townships see shooting as the most efficient and economical solution,'' said Susan Martka, a wildlife biologist who oversees New Jersey's Community-Based Deer Management Program, which was approved by state legislators two years ago.
Just last month, a state appeals court dismissed a challenge by antihunting groups to overturn the deer program, which sets guidelines for municipal deer hunts.
In the past year alone, about 700 deer were shot in local culling programs.
In Bernards Township, the conflict erupted into a colorful campaign with signs cropping up on front lawns like so many daisies protesting the culling of 93 deer in recent months.
ON a South Shore islet just barely off the Long Island mainland, Island Park is an eminently homey place, a bit insular-feeling and, for Nassau County, still within reach for people of middle income.
Single-family houses, though more expensive than five years ago, are still around for less than $200,000.
Homes with water or canal views, while also rising in price, are still far less costly than in most waterfront communities on Long Island.
The village, which is in the town of Hempstead, began around 1900 as summer resort popular with people from New York City, particularly Brooklyn.
They built modest bungalows, then eventually moved in permanently as the village evolved into a year-round community in the 1950's and 1960's. ''
People liked it so much, they decided to stay,'' said Henry Hastava, a broker and the president of Hastava Real Estate, whose family arrived in the 1920's.
Mr. Hastava, now nearly 65, said he had not spent significant time away from Island Park since his birth except for two years in the Army.
The bungalows, typically dating to the 1920's, have long since been winterized, otherwise renovated and, in most cases, expanded.
Now called ranches or Capes, they account for the bulk of the village's most affordable housing.
More expensive single- and two-family houses built in the 1950's and 1960's make up most of the rest of the housing stock.

Hours before President Clinton arrived this weekend, bringing reassurances that Seoul's military ties with the United States were stronger than ever, Government auditors here recommended criminal charges be filed against two former South Korean defense ministers over a $6 billion purchase of American-made F-16 fighters.
The investigation is part of an anticorruption drive that President Clinton praised during his visit as a "very good example" for "budding democracies throughout the world."

But the complicated case, which has been brewing for months, is being compared to the Lockheed scandal in Japan in the 1970's, and is raising many questions about back-room dealings in one of the United States' largest weapons sales.
The scandal centers on the Korean Fighter Project, a key to South Korea's efforts to upgrade its air defense capacity against North Korea.
A Switch in the Contract In 1989 South Korea selected the F/A-18, made by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, as the next-generation fighter for its air force.
But in 1991, the decision was reversed, and the contract was suddenly awarded to General Dynamics, maker of the F-16.
Korean officials said that McDonnell Douglas's contract was ended because the company changed the terms of the deal and wanted to raise the price.
But there have been other suspicions.

In a report issued on Friday, Lee Hoi Chang, chairman of South Korea's Board of Audit and Inspection, said large, unexplained sums had been discovered in the bank accounts of several top Government officials who were instrumental in the decision.
He called for punitive action against 53 officials, including many in the military.

THERE'S a whole world of steamed mussels beyond white wine, parsley and garlic.
Don't misunderstand: you can't go wrong with this traditional approach.
But you can't go too far with it, either.
With favorites like mussels, a little adventure takes no more effort than the tried-and-true.
The basic trick is to use distinctive Asian seasonings like ginger, soy or curry powder.
And to omit the cooking liquid, to make the sauce more intense.
Mussels generate so much good-tasting broth of their own during cooking that additional liquid is superfluous.
By relying only on the mussels' natural juices, you can use fewer seasonings (and less of them) to produce a flavorful sauce that is also less watery than the usual one.
These are mussels to eat on a flat plate, rather than in a bowl.
Theoretically, any mussel recipe will work equally well for clams.
IT would be hard to imagine a more promising middle-class shopping Mecca than this Gloucester County suburb.

At least that is what Wal-Mart -- at once the world's largest retailer and avowed enemy of the union worker -- is thinking these days as it considers how to carve a supersized slice of this suburban pie.
If viewed like a middle school science class pondering a cross-section of the Earth, the Deptford Mall sits at the core, with 155 stores, 4 of them department store anchors.
Surrounding the mall in an inner ring are the big-box stores -- Best Buy, Sports Authority, Dick's Sporting Goods -- along with the Deptford Six multiplex movie theater.
Just beyond that is the usual panorama of modern-day suburban America -- an unhealthy smattering of fast-food restaurants and strip shopping plazas.

Finally, in a thin outer crust are the more traditional and increasingly endangered mom-and-pop stores as well as a couple of ubiquitous diners -- all which pre-date the retail extravaganza that began spreading like Japanese barberry in the 1970's, when the Philadelphia suburbs pushed beyond the first post-World War II settlements of Cherry Hill and Pennsauken.

In those days, Deptford Township was mostly a loose collection of small villages and truck farms, known primarily as the place where the first balloon flight in America landed in the 18th century and where pig farmers sold their slop to enhance the soil of the Garden State.

Today it is home to a confluence of several major highways -- Interstate 295, the North-South Freeway, and State Routes 41, 47 and 55 -- all of which funnel into the overloaded shopping district at the center of this unpretentious town of 28,000.
Wal-Mart could hardly help noticing, and as a result, the giant chain has proposed not one but three stores for the area.

And were Wal-Mart to have its way -- which remains to be seen -- none would be of the old average variety, or what the company calls discount stores, but supercenters, stores of no less than 100,000 square feet or perhaps twice that size.

Don King's insurance fraud case in Federal court in Manhattan features the same judge and witnesses and similar evidence from the 1995 trial that ended in a mistrial.

This time, Federal prosecutors have indicted not only King but also his company, Don King Productions, for allegedly submitting a forged contract and faked expenses to Lloyd's to recover $350,000 in nonrefundable training expenses after the cancellation of a 1991 bout between Julio Cesar Chavez and Harold Brazier.
By making King's company a co-defendant, the United States Attorney for the Southern District hopes to hold at least one entity responsible, even if it cannot directly link King to any fraud.
It is possible for the jury to acquit King but convict his company, which would keep King from having to serve up to 45 years in jail.
But it was unclear from yesterday's opening statement by Baruch Weiss, an assistant United States Attorney, whether the Government would directly connect King's employees to the charges.
The Government is charging that a $1.5 million contract, which Chavez signed, included no provision for King or his company to reclaim nonrefundable training expenses.
But the contract Lloyd's based its claim on included a typewritten rider with the unusual nonrefundable provision.
Weiss is seeking to use King's testimony in the first trial against him this time. ''
Although he was trying to get himself off the hook, King made numerous admissions which corroborated and support the other evidence,'' he said.
The prosecutor said King admitted that the fake contract was wrong and deceptive, even though he knew nothing about it.

United Airlines will once again push back its target date for emerging from bankruptcy, as a government board considers asking the company to trim its request for $1.6 billion in federally backed loans, people close to the company said yesterday.

The airline, which lost $2.8 billion in 2003 despite a deep round of cost-cutting and labor contract concessions, has yet to clear a series of hurdles, including securing loan guarantees, that are blocking its emergence from bankruptcy protection.

That is why United, which has already revised its bankruptcy timetable twice, plans to outline yet another timetable for Judge Eugene R. Wedoff of United States Bankruptcy Court at a hearing in Chicago tomorrow.

United, which had most recently estimated that it would emerge from bankruptcy protection by June 30, now does not expect to until later in the summer at the earliest, according to people who have been briefed on its plans.
A spokesman for United declined to comment.
Not long after filing for bankruptcy protection in December 2002, United, the second-largest airline behind American, said it might emerge as early as December 2003.
But it subsequently pushed the date back to this June.
United, which has identified savings of $5 billion through next year, including $2.56 billion in annual wage and benefit cuts, has the exclusive right to file a reorganization plan through April 8.
After that, United's creditors, its unions or outside investors could have the opportunity to file their own plans for reorganizing the airline.
Tomorrow, it is expected to ask Judge Wedoff to retain that right for an additional 30 to 60 days, people told about United's thinking said.
As allied forces arrayed against Iraq prepare to shift the war from the air to the ground, an American tactic called "AirLand Battle" is expected to undergo its first trial in real combat.
If the tactic succeeds, victory may be swift and allied casualties minimal.
If it fails, battlefield confusion could greatly complicate fighting and prolong the war.

AirLand warfare -- a tactical doctrine the Army eccentrically persists in spelling as one word -- was developed in the 1970's as a defense against a hypothetical Soviet invasion of Western Europe, in which Soviet armored forces would greatly outnumber those of the defenders.

In essence, a force using the tactic would concentrate its heaviest fire on the enemy's rear lines, long-range artillery, reserves and supply routes, crippling reserve tanks and armored vehicles before they could be brought to the front.
Political Factors Involved The object is to so weaken the underpinnings of a large army that its cutting edge can be shattered relatively painlessly.

In an assault against the large and well-equipped Iraqi force in Kuwait, believed to number about 400,000, this could be achieved by planes, helicopters, battlefield missiles and large shells, like those fired from the Persian Gulf by the 16-inch guns of the battleships Missouri and Wisconsin.

By eliminating the need to wage a protracted land war along a static front line, the allies could greatly reduce their casualties -- one of the main objects of a strategy that must take political as well as military factors into consideration.

Punishing air strikes against Iraq's dug-in tanks and armored personnel carriers have already been in progress for the last two weeks, and will intensify as the ground war approaches, military officials say.

President Bush has not said whether he will order the start of a land war and is to hear the recommendations this week from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

LEAD: To the Editor: To the Editor: I am writing to express my concern over the recent wave of publicity that has been given to anti-fur organizations.
The foremost example was the season premiere of ''L.A. Law,'' which was aired on Nov. 2 on NBC television.
The show presented the fur industry in a very bad light, without the chance to defend itself.
The main focus was several video clips of animals being caught in traps.
After viewing this it is hard to make the audience realize that only a small percentage of furs are obtained in this manner.
The majority of the furs come from ranch-raised animals treated with the utmost care and respect.
There is no difference between a fur farm and a poultry farm, a cattle farm or a fish farm, and what is the difference between fur and leather?
Fur sales are down a bit, mostly due to overproduction, but also in part because of the furor caused by the anti-fur movement.
There is still a demand for high-quality pelts like those produced in North America.
The drop in the return on pelts has forced many trappers to go out of business.
Erich Honecker, the stolid Marxist who ruled East Germany for 18 years until a people's uprising swept him aside in October 1989, died yesterday in Chile.
He was 81.
His doctor said the cause of death was liver cancer.

It took the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe and the absorption in 1990 of his country by the larger, immensely richer West Germany to lay bare the extent to which the Honecker Government had mismanaged the economy and the environment.

To the dismay of western Germans and the federal Government in Bonn, eastern Germany's infrastructure, from telephones to railroads, needed to be rebuilt, and vast sources of contamination had to be cleaned up -- all at enormous expense.
Like other members of East Germany's upper echelon, Mr. Honecker faced charges in the united Berlin.
He spent time under house arrest and in prison, but his trial was halted by a higher court, which ruled that prosecutors had violated the civil rights of a very sick man.
He was freed in January 1993 and allowed to fly to Chile to join his wife and daughter.

Mr. Honecker's orthodoxy as a Communist leader did not keep him from risking the Kremlin's displeasure with his own brand of "Westpolitik" toward Bonn, tapping its wealth to strengthen his country's faltering economy and living standards.

After coming to power in 1971, he maintained East Germany as the industrial dynamo of the Soviet bloc, and he received international recognition and won a coveted prize when Bonn and Paris received him as a head of state with full honors.
APPLE-GREEN paint fascinates John R. Stilgoe, the professor of landscape history at Harvard.
