He sometimes finds it inside the cupboards or broom closets of old kitchens, a token of the 1920's, a time when that color was thought to be soothing to the soul.
Public schools wore that green; its relative survives in too many halls under the name ''landlord green.''
Professor Stilgoe's eye for such things begins in the home, strides across the porch, strolls Main Street, and bicycles breezily past strip malls to the edge of the Interstates.

His evocative new book, ''Outside Lies Magic: Regaining History and Awareness in Everyday Places'' (Walker), is less a guide than a tool for seeing, like a pair of binoculars taken on vacation for bird-watching.
It's also a clarion call to what he calls, almost mystically, ''exploration'' -- wandering on foot or bike, in search not of cardiovascular fitness but of mental agility.
Ultimately, it's about becoming the proverbial person on whom nothing is lost. ''
Get out now,'' he exhorts readers, ''not just outside, but beyond the trap of the programmed electronic age.''
Professor Stilgoe is part of a new flowering of interest in looking at how culture shapes the wide, mundane world around us.
The principal founder of modern landscape thinking and looking was the late J. B. Jackson, the author of ''The Necessity for Ruins, and Other Topics'' and the founder of Landscape magazine.
Despite a decent rise in household incomes last month and the lowest mortgage rates in 14 years, sales of new homes fell sharply in September.

Since the housing sector has led the way since January in pulling the nation out of recession, economists see the plunge as strong evidence that Americans' confidence in the sluggish recovery is fading.
Home sales plunged 12.9 percent last month, the biggest drop in two and a half years, to their lowest level since the depths of the recession in January, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. "
The picture is really, really bleak," said Michael D. Hobbs, a contractor in New Canaan, Conn. "There was a real flurry of activity a few months ago, but that certainly has not been sustained."

People Are Nervous Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch, said, "The fact that people aren't willing to lock themselves into 30 years of mortgage payments shows that they're very nervous about layoffs."
Ronald R. Foell, president of Standard Pacific, a home-building company based in Costa Mesa, Calif., said: "Only those people who really need housing or are very secure in their jobs are buying.
Everybody else seems to be staying on the sidelines."
Mr. Foell's company is one of the lucky few whose sales actually climbed in September.

After a spate of weak economic data, including Tuesday's gloomy consumer confidence report from the Conference Board, the Federal Reserve apparently eased short-term interest rates once more yesterday -- the 11th time it has done so in two years.
The move helped to lift the price of short-term securities, but was not as well received among long-term investors.
A 3-year-old Brooklyn girl died yesterday morning after a neighbor found her unconscious and bruised in her East New York apartment, the police said.
The girl, Kiana Rosado, was taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center in Queens and pronounced dead at 9:54 a.m. The city medical examiner's office said an autopsy would be conducted today.
Last night, detectives were questioning the girl's 18-year-old mother, Jessica Rosado, and the mother's 23-year-old boyfriend, Ruben Pagan.
No criminal charges had been filed.
A city official said Ms. Rosado had not been the subject of any allegations of child abuse, and the police said they had not been called to the address to settle any domestic disputes.
The girl lived in a fifth-floor apartment at 70 Hill Street.
A neighbor, Celenia Morales, said she heard a woman screaming in an apartment across the hall.
Through the apartment's open door, she saw Ms. Rosado standing over Kiana's still body, Ms. Morales said. ''
She was laying on the floor motionless, gasping for air,'' said Ms. Morales, 45. ''
The child's mom was screaming, saying she wouldn't wake up.
ANYONE who believes that respectability is priceless has not been to Japan lately.
Here it sells for $100 a month.
While the Japanese economy remains a mess, one type of business seems to be doing well: the alibi-ya, whose name comes from the English word alibi and the suffix ya, meaning a seller.
In essence, they are conjurers who make people at the margins of Japanese society look dignified and respectable.
The alibi-ya are the marketplace's way of reconciling a shame society -- one that emphasizes peer pressure and public shame to achieve good behavior -- with what are regarded as shameful industries.
Japan, more than most industrialized countries, has strict bounds of propriety and plenty of minders to see that they are adhered to.
As everywhere, they often are not.
Women in the sex industry are frequent clients of the alibi-ya, which enable them to tell mom and even boyfriends about their fine jobs in a trading company.
The alibi-ya provide name cards, pay stubs and an impressive position in a decent line of work -- all totally fictitious.
If a caller tries to reach the young woman while she is at her nonexistent job, a polite receptionist will explain that she has stepped out but will return the call shortly.
A Williamsburg rabbi has pulled out of a project to rehabilitate an apartment building that would have been shared by Hasidic and Hispanic residents, saying he could not trust his Hispanic partners.
The move comes nearly two months after 200 Hispanic squatters took over a new housing project out of fear that the majority of the apartments would go to Hasidim.
The event highlighted the anger between the two groups, as they continue to grow at about the same rate and clash over housing.

The rabbi, David Niederman, director of the United Jewish Organizations of Williamsburg, said he would reconsider if leaders of the group he was working with, the Southside Housing Development Fund Corporation, or Los Sures, would denounce the Oct. 1 protest.
But if not, he plans to work with other Hispanic organizations to build housing, he said. "
What went on there was pure anti-Semitism," Rabbi Niederman said last week of the protest. "
We have rights to housing just as much as they do.
If Los Sures denounces this protest, then I will know that I have a partner.
The way things stand now, I don't know if they would alert me if they saw someone running at my back with a knife."
David Pagan, administrator of Los Sures, said that the project was still alive as far as he was concerned.
The 20-year old Mexican pop singer Natalia Lafourcade released a startling first album last year.

She cut a charming figure of an ingenue writing self-possessed journal entries about the way stations before adulthood, and the irresistibility of mangoes, strumming her acoustic guitar with learned skill at the center of the action.

Around her bright voice were pop's riches of the New World: broad choruses, dance grooves, hand-clapping, bossa nova, little chunks of metal guitar, boogaloo and ska and grainy sound montages edited into the bubbly flow.
And for a hit record, this self-titled album, released in Mexico by Sony, was human, too.
One song, ''Manana Olvidare,'' even has a mistake that stayed on the record.
But it ended up being one of those virtual-world victories.
Her producers, Aureo Baqueiro and Loris Ceroni, manipulated the studio so adeptly that a live performance would be only a faint echo.
At least that's what her show at S.O.B.'s on Thursday night implied. (
She also played in Prospect Park's Celebrate Brooklyn concert series the next night.)

Ms. Lafourcade brought a four-piece touring band, and the keyboardist couldn't come close to replicating some of the far-flung instrumentation that flitters through the album: vibraphone, accordion, Farfisa organ, small and high-pitched guitars.
Albert Haas, a specialist in heart-and-lung disease and the physical rehabilitation of the patient, died on Aug. 12 at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York.
A resident of Greenwich Village, he was 85.
Dr. Haas was a retired professor of medicine at New York University and its Rusk Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine.
He was also a former director of cardiopulmonary service at Bellevue Hospital.
He retired from N.Y.U. in 1979 and from Bellevue five years later.
He was a native of Hungary and graduated from the Royal Hungarian Medical School in 1937.
He moved to France and then trained at the Institute of Tropical Diseases in Antwerp, Belgium.
He and his wife, Sonja Nadel Haas, joined the French Resistance in World War II, were captured by the Gestapo and sent to separate concentration camps.
He began his career in pulmonary rehabilitation in postwar France, beginning with an institute near Paris.
It offered physical, psychological and vocational recovery to camp survivors who had contracted tuberculosis.
Jim Fassel knows what they are saying about him as his unraveling Giants lurch into the second half of their season. ''
Sometimes I have to laugh,'' he said, standing beneath the Giants Stadium grandstand after Friday's practice. ''
Last year, I'm the coach of the year.
Half a season later, people are wondering if I have any clue what I'm doing.
How did I get that dumb that fast?''
There are other things they are saying about Fassel.
Why is his offense so conservative?
Why can't he fix this mess of a Giants season?
Has he, in his second year as the coach, lost control of his team?
Or lost the magic that put a glow on last season?

The Devils' decision to start this season with three defensemen born in the spring of 1964 could haunt them next spring in the playoffs -- unless Coach Larry Robinson gives Scott Stevens, Ken Daneyko and Tommy Albelin plenty of rest this winter.
Defense has been the Devils' trademark since 1993, when Jacques Lemaire arrived to coach the team and hired Robinson to be his assistant.
Robinson, now the head coach, also likes experienced defensemen, which prompted the signing of Albelin and the re-signing of Daneyko in the off-season to form the defensive base with Stevens. ''
These guys take care of their body and it shows on the ice,'' Robinson said after the Devils' 5-4 loss to the Flyers on Saturday night in their final preseason game. ''
They're dedicated to their work and I'm happy with the way they've performed in training camp and the way they've played in the exhibition games.''
Robinson said he was not planning to play those three as much as Scott Niedermayer and Brian Rafalski, who are 28. ''
With the addition of Albelin, we have a pretty experienced corps of defensemen,'' he said.
The loss of Sean O'Donnell and Ken Sutton to free agency this summer forced the Devils to look for experience on defense.
General Manager Lou Lamoriello turned to an old friend in Albelin, a  Devils defensman for eight seasons before being traded to Calgary in 1996.
Albelin signed a two-year contract, and Lamoriello re-signed Daneyko to a two-year deal.
It will be two against one when 28-year-old Tami Whitlinger Jones meets 16-year-old Martina Hingis in the first round at the United States Open this week. ''
Yes, it's true, I'm pregnant,'' said Whitlinger Jones, who lives with her husband, the doubles player Kelly Jones, in San Diego. ''
This will be my last tournament.''
Whitlinger Jones, who won the junior singles title at the United States Open in 1986, is ranked 102d on the WTA Tour. ''
Her doctor told her to keep a lot of liquids in her at all times,'' said Angel Lopez, Whitlinger Jones's coach. ''
If she feels lightheaded, she'll have to stop.
Her whole family is coming, so she's got nothing to lose.
She'll have fun and try to beat her.''
The Joneses have asked the United States Open selection committee for a wild-card berth into the mixed doubles competition.
It would be the first time they have played together on the same side of the court in their professional careers.

In a glum post-mortem to the presidential campaign, senior advisers to Senator John Kerry said Monday that Mr. Kerry lost because he had failed to turn the election into a referendum on the economy, a problem they attributed to a barrage of foreign policy news and the success of the White House in wielding cultural issues.

A pollster for Mr. Kerry, Stanley Greenberg, said that the campaign saw evidence that its position was slightly deteriorating among white rural voters 10 days before Election Day and that the erosion began ''cascading from group to group.''

At a breakfast meeting with reporters, Mr. Greenberg said voters had been open to backing Mr. Kerry but pulled back after he failed to convince them to make their decision based on economic issues. ''
Voters were very concerned about the economy,'' Mr. Greenberg said, ''but in the end, they did not respond to John Kerry on the economy.
And after that, they voted their values.
And that produced a cultural polarization of the electorate. ''
These voters were waiting to hear an economic choice before the election, and they didn't get it.''
Mr. Kerry's aides said his efforts to turn the election to the economy were drowned out by news from Iraq as well as Mr. Bush's focus on cultural issues.

The slide worsened as the final days of the campaign were dominated by two overseas topics, Osama bin Laden's videotaped message that was released on the weekend before the election and the missing explosives in Iraq. ''
News events were driving this, including the Osama bin Laden tape, at the end,'' said Robert Shrum, a senior adviser to Mr. Kerry. ''
An unlikely season for Connecticut was extended tonight in the most improbable way.
Frequently, the Huskies have built big leads this season only to lose them before holding on for a victory.
Tonight, at the Final Four, they won in a different, far scarier manner.
Trailing by 50-41 with 12 minutes remaining, UConn rallied behind the brilliant insistence of Diana Taurasi.
The national player of the year, who scored 26 points after struggling mightily in the second half, helped give her team a heart-stopping 71-69 victory over Texas.
Still, nothing has come easy for the young, inexperienced Huskies this season, despite a 36-1 record.
The freshman forward Wilnett Crockett had played unevenly in her first year, but she rescued her team tonight with 10 rebounds and 9 points.
With 8.2 seconds left, however, Crockett missed a pair of free throws and Texas had a chance to force overtime or win with a 3-pointer.
The Longhorns didn't call a timeout, and guard Alisha Sare set up above the arc, but the ball either slipped from her hands or was deflected.
Taurasi held on for dear life, and so did UConn.
The first-round playoff fight between the Knicks and the Detroit Pistons will go the distance.
Holding off a furious fourth-quarter rally, the Pistons survived tonight with an 86-82 victory at the Palace of Auburn Hills.
That tied the three-of-five-game series at 2-2 and forced a fifth game to be played at 1 P.M. Sunday at Madison Square Garden. "
When the series opened, I suspected it might be a five-game series, and fortunately for us, it turned out that way," said Pistons Coach Chuck Daly. "
It's on their court and it's an advantage to them, but hey, I know we'll show up and play hard.
We've kept it alive, and now we've got a shot."
The Knicks had a shot tonight.
Trailing by 84-81, they had a chance to tie on their final posession.
With 5.2 seconds left, Kiki Vandeweghe inbounded at midcourt to Greg Anthony, who started to drive on Joe Dumars.
Dumars grabbed Anthony around the shoulders as he made his move, trying to foul Anthony before he could get off a game-tying 3-pointer.

President Bush left the Earth Summit today firing parting shots at his many critics, saying Americans are "the leaders, not the followers," on environmental issues and will be "pre-eminent" in carrying out accords signed here.

Speaking at a news conference at his seafront hotel, Mr. Bush dismissed suggestions that his appearance here had not gone well and reserved some of his criticism for domestic rather than global issues.

Mr. Bush, who agreed to sign only a watered-down version of the summit treaty to reduce the threat of global warming, proposed on Friday that the nations gather on Jan. 1 to report specific plans to reduce emissions of pollutants that trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere.
The treaty sets a deadline of the end of the century for meeting emission control goals.
At the news conference, Mr. Bush rejected the notion that his call for an early start on the global warming issue was not welcomed by world leaders. "
The developed nations want to meet the commitments they've signed up for, so I've not found that it wasn't well received at all," Mr. Bush said. "
In fact, Bill Reilly told me it was well received, and we will be there with specific plans."

Support for Meeting Seen Administration officials said today that some other leaders had told Mr. Bush and William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, that the President's plans for the meeting had merit.
But they said they knew of no specific commitments by any nations to attend such a meeting.

Nor could they report any assurances yet that other developed nations will support the other major initiative Mr. Bush brought to Rio, a proposal to double spending to conserve and restore the world's dwindling forests.
ONE might have questions about a restaurant that calls itself Zero Zero, but at this amiable spot in Stamford, near the Greenwich line, the only question should be, how long to fast before a visit?

Zero Zero, whose name bears no relation to the upbeat decor -- walls and floor hand-painted with stylized flowers, every tabletop painted in different colors with an individualized, cheery motif -- offers a somewhat different concept in dining: not less is more, but more is more.
Every item except dessert bears two prices, the larger one for a family-size portion, the smaller for a single serving.
In fact, the so-called single serving can often accommodate two healthy appetites.

Case in point: We ordered a single portion of grilled portobello mushrooms and eggplant served with warm mozzarella over arugula tossed with a dressing of oil and balsamic vinegar -- a delicious appetizer that was certainly enough for two.

The kitchen in fact scored higher on appetizers than on entrees, prompting us to recommend ordering a family portion of a starter as a main course or sharing two starters, then skipping right down to dessert.

Grilled shrimp sauteed with shallots and champagne vinegar, served on a huge dinner plate decorated with orange segments, was a succulent choice; the slightly acidic sauce was zesty enough to mop up with bread.
Fried calamari, also in an elephantine single serving, was another winsome choice.
There seem to be no salad-size plates on the premises, for even Caesar and endive and arugula salad singles arrived on monster-large dinner plates.
The endive/arugula mix was a happy one, enlivened by a raspberry vinaigrette.
Al Montoya, the University of Michigan goaltender who was the Rangers' first-round draft choice last month, said yesterday that he would return to college this year rather than play professionally.
Montoya, 19, a psychology major entering his junior year, was drafted sixth over all and was the first goalie picked.
A potential lockout of N.H.L. players when the collective bargaining agreement expires on Sept. 15 played a part in his decision to stay in Ann Arbor, he said. ''
Going back to Michigan, I knew what was there and what it was all about,'' Montoya said in a telephone interview from his home in Chicago.
Montoya, who could be the first Cuban-American to play in the N.H.L., took awhile to make his decision.
It was, he said, a difficult choice.
Among those he consulted were N.H.L. goaltenders Steve Shields and Marty Turco, both of whom played at Michigan.
Montoya, the top-ranked goaltender in the N.H.L.'s central scouting rating, led the United States to its first gold medal in the world junior championships last winter in Finland.
And he has every intention of playing for the Rangers. ''
It's just that I have things to do at Michigan -- a lot of things,'' Montoya said. ''
The Japanese Government today froze new grants to India as punishment for the nuclear tests, and said it would consider cutting some of its much bigger loan programs.
Germany also suspended some of its aid, but other major trading partners ruled out sanctions.
Japan said that it was canceling $30 million in grants.
Since 1992, Japan has extended $1 billion in aid annually, mostly in the form of loans.

While the sanctions were not tough, they underscored the anger here at the Indian tests, for Japan has seen its role -- as the only country to suffer nuclear attack -- as a leader in efforts to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto called it ''grave'' that India had gone ahead with a second round of tests today, at a time when many countries have condemned the three nuclear tests conducted on Monday.
He said he would call upon the Group of Seven leading industrial nations meeting in England this weekend to condemn India for the tests.

The Japanese Government said it would consider halting part of its lending program, but that is a delicate issue because Japanese businesses are often involved in these lending projects, and freezing loans could have serious effects on the Indian economy.
Among other nations that give aid to India, Germany called off talks scheduled for next week in Bonn, said the German Minister for Economic Cooperation, Carl-Dieter Spranger.
A portion of new development aid for India worth $168 million was put on hold, and no talks will take place anytime soon.
It is perhaps only in car-centric Los Angeles that preservationists and historians could get all riled up over the fate of an old gas station.
The tiny, 81-year-old Canyon Service Station, which closed a few months ago and is now fenced off, its three pumps gone, was always a landmark to its neighbors in Santa Monica Canyon.
They considered it a quaint, playful relic of the days before Los Angeles was overrun by freeways, noise and traffic reports beamed from helicopters.

But then the owners, Monica Queen and four of her relatives, decided to sell the station, which her grandfather built on what is now the last piece of once-vast land holdings granted to their ancestors in 1839.

Ms. Queen, who lives in a small house behind the station and says she subsists on not much more than Social Security, found a buyer: her neighbor, Chris Hoffmann, an investment banker, who agreed to pay $2.1 million for the 16,000-square-foot lot.

Mr. Hoffmann's plan was to expand the small avocado grove in his backyard into what is now the gas station and, in a nod to preservationists, ship the station's building to the Petersen Automotive Museum here.
That is when the problems began.

Alarmed members of the Santa Monica Canyon Civic Association appealed to Los Angeles officials to designate the building as a monument, which would hold up any movement of the station for at least a year.
The proposed designation has been approved in principle by the city's Cultural Heritage Commission but has yet to be acted upon by the full City Council.
It scuttled for now the property's transfer and infuriated Ms. Queen and her relatives. ''

On Sunday, Serbia will make its third attempt this year to elect a new president, but disillusionment with political infighting is so intense that low voter turnout could once again invalidate the ballot.

Opinion polls suggest that Vojislav Kostunica, a conservative nationalist and currently president of the Yugoslav federation grouping Serbia and Montenegro, will pick up two-thirds of the vote to defeat two more radical nationalist candidates.

But unless more than half of the electorate votes the result will be annulled -- as it was in October when Mr. Kostunica won a runoff against Miroljub Labus, a pro-Western liberal, by a similar margin.
Serbia needs a new president to replace Milan Milutinovic, an associate of the ousted Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.
He faces trial on war crimes charges once his term expires at the end of the month.

If a successor is not elected, the speaker of Parliament would take over temporarily under the old Constitution, which would then most likely be amended so parliamentary deputies can choose the new president.
The likely failure of Sunday's vote is the result of a long-running feud between Mr. Kostunica and the Serbian prime minister, Zoran Djindjic.
The two forged a reformist alliance to topple Mr. Milosevic two years ago but have since refused to cooperate, derailing the reform process.

International officials, who argue that Serbia badly needs to resolve its political confusion if it is to attract investment, have put them under heavy pressure to patch up their differences and break the deadlock, but so far to no avail.
Mr. Djindjic, who backed Mr. Labus in the last election, is not fielding a candidate this time.
Blue-chip stocks rose sharply yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to an all-time high.
The Dow jumped 42.27 points to close at 4,747.21, topping its previous record of 4,736.39 on July 17.
Some broader market indicators also gained, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index setting its sixth straight record, rising 2.60 points, to 576.51.
But the Nasdaq composite index, which is weighed with technology stocks, wilted yesterday on profit taking after setting a record on Monday, dropping 1.56 points, to 1,065.00.
The market's rally came in reaction to a buying spree in the bond market, which surged in response to a Government report that producer prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent last month.

This news strengthened the feeling of many stock market investors that inflation remained under control and that the Federal Reserve would reduce short-term interest rates in the fall, possibly at the next meeting of its policy-making committee on Sept. 26.
In addition, the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta reported a slowdown in manufacturing in the Southeast in August.
And retail sales were projected by the Johnson Redbook Service to be on track to advance a seasonally adjusted three-tenths of 1 percent in September. "
Yesterday's numbers indicate the best of all circumstances for the investing public: moderate growth and low inflation," said Edward Nickoski, managing director of Piper Jaffray in Minneapolis. "
The more you see these kinds of numbers, the more the market will get comfort."
For a hurdler, Greg Foster sure has a lot of endurance.
Sixteen years after his career began, Foster is still here and Renaldo Nehemiah is not, which means Foster -- in an inglorious way -- has finally one-upped his archrival. "
No, can't say that," said Foster tonight. "
Renaldo chose to go to football.
He missed five years.
Not like he was forced out of this."
Nevertheless, Foster is the one who runs like it's still 1984.
He is 34 and promising to retire at the end of this season, but tonight he set a meet record of 6.41 seconds in the Sunkist Invitational's 50-meter hurdles at the Los Angeles Sports Arena. "
Thought I ran slow," he said after putting on a bicycle cap.
Presumptious First Step He won the race with a presumptious first step.
COLLEEN AND GREG MILLER of Salem, Utah, are an Internet couple  with an Internet family.
The two met in an online chat room, where Colleen had gone hoping to find someone to take her dog.
After they were married, they used the Internet to buy large items, like cars, and small stuff, like groceries.
They also found part of their family on the Internet.

The Millers adopted four children -- three girls and a boy, all siblings -- after seeing their photographs on the Web site of the Utah Division of Child and Family Services (www.utdcfsadopt.org), which lists children in foster care who are waiting for adoption.

Not long after finalizing the adoptions last month, Mrs. Miller, 44, who along with her husband had nine children from previous marriages, found herself fielding an age-old question, but with a modern twist. ''
My 4-year-old son was asking if we could get a brother for him from the Internet, like we got him,'' she said. ''
I said, 'We can go on the Internet and get a brother for you, just like we got you.' ''
The Millers represent a growing phenomenon in the field of adoption: the use of the Internet to expose adoptable children to potential parents.

Several factors, including the passage of federal legislation limiting the time children can remain in foster care and the widespread use of the Internet, have led 47 states to set up Web sites featuring photographs of foster children available for adoption.
Max Landau never thought he would live his life as a plastics merchant.
Like many of the people who would eventually shop at his store, Industrial Plastics, he was an artist who had a thing for plastic.
Stories had it that during World War II, when the material was hard to come by, a friend who built plastic parts for fighter jets sent Mr. Landau the scraps.
One day, he realized that he had acquired a whole warehouse of such stuff.
And that's how the store began.

The Industrial Plastics Supply Company, which was officially incorporated in 1965 and moved into a former Arnold Constable department store on Canal Street shortly thereafter, soon became a one-stop shopping emporium for all things polymer-based.
But next month, it is selling off its goods and shuttering its doors, and the city's Industrial Plastics faithful are bemoaning its end. ''
People think plastic is made out of plastic,'' said Benjamin Klibanoff, a thick-set man who was formerly the store's accountant, and took it over with his sister when Mr. Landau died in 1999. ''
It's not.
It's made out of oil.''
Nothing discouraged the Devils tonight, not the three losses to Ottawa earlier this month, not even a sore neck to Martin Brodeur that developed just before the game and forced him to sit.
Chris Terreri, Brodeur's understudy, stepped right into Brodeur's skates and came up with an inspiring performance in goal in only his seventh start of the season.
Terreri's timely saves and some effective finishing led the Devils to a 4-1 triumph over the Senators, the team that has been their biggest nemesis the past three seasons.
The victory brought revenge and redemption against Ottawa and Damian Rhodes, the starting goaltender.

The Senators eliminated the Devils in the playoffs last spring and prevented the Devils from making the playoffs in the last game of the regular season in 1996, the year after the Devils captured the Stanley Cup.

Jay Pandolfo, Brendan Morrison, Brian Rolston and Vadim Sharifijanov scored the goals for the team's third consecutive victory, which pushed the Devils (26-14-5) into fourth place ahead of the Senators (25-15-6) in the overall standing in the Eastern Conference. ''
They beat us pretty solidly three times,'' Morrison said, ''so this helped our confidence because there is a possibility we'll play them in the playoffs.
You don't want to lose to a team all four times.''
Scott Stevens, the Devils' captain, said: ''We learned a lot after every loss against them.
We skated much better tonight.
Lennox Lewis's prefight news conference was the antithesis of Mike Tyson's.
Lewis spoke to reporters today, something Tyson, the challenger for the heavyweight championship on Saturday in Memphis, chose not to do a day earlier.
Neither Lewis nor his handlers uttered any profanities, whereas Tyson's handlers had laced their tirades aimed at Lewis with vulgarities.
Yet both sides seem to agree that the stakes are the same.
As Lewis's Hall of Fame trainer, Emanuel Steward, said, ''This is a very crucial fight for both these guys' legacies.''

The financially and emotionally troubled Tyson needs Lewis to reclaim the heavyweight title, earn a huge paycheck (a guaranteed $17.5 million for each fighter) and, maybe most of all, regain some legitimacy in boxing and the world beyond.
But why does Lewis need Tyson? ''
I don't feel I need Tyson,'' Lewis said long after his news conference and workout. ''
But he's the guy in my era who's a misfit that everybody looked up to.
It would be a disappointment for us not to meet.''
SOME historians believe you can't put a price on the past, but Henry F. Ludder knows better.
He has just done the arithmetic, and the price turns out to be $100,000.

Mr. Ludder, who is 72, has been a historic preservationist since the age of 11, when he wrote to Mayor La Guardia protesting the demolition of cottages near his home in Queens to make room for a road to the 1939 World's Fair.
That crusade was fruitless -- the letter got no reply -- but he had better luck in adulthood.
As the official historian of Queens, Mr. Ludder fought to save the borough's old homes from the wrecking ball.
As a member of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, he used his legal authority to protect buildings from owners who wanted to tear them down or add indignities like metal windows. ''

One of the things I've discovered in all the years I've been in my field,'' he said in 1987, ''is that once an old house or building is knocked down, neighbors suddenly discover the place had local historical significance.''
Mr. Ludder has rediscovered that lesson during the city's latest battle over historic preservation.
It concerns his former home, an ornate Victorian house at 15-43 150th Place in Whitestone, where he lived for the last four decades.
It is now set to be demolished, to the amazement of Mr. Ludder's fellow preservationists.
During the last three and a half years, the Brkonic family could look about and count their blessings.
Not a child had been killed, and their apartment had survived the war without a scratch.
But 30 minutes after a cease-fire was called throughout the land, the flick of a switch brought their walls tumbling down and ended their uncommon streak of luck.
The cause was the very product of peace -- gas meant to heat their home during the winter months to come.
They had been eagerly awaiting a return of utilities to Sarajevo and had connected their homemade gas stove just for the occasion.
But in the middle of the night, as celebratory gunfire resounded in the distance, the smell of acid began to permeate the air.
When 19-year-old Namic Brkonic turned on the light in the bathroom to investigate, he blew the place to bits. "
When he arrived in the hospital, I could only recognize him by his blue eyes," said Semira Viteskic, a nurse and Namic's childhood friend.
Namic was burned over 60 percent of his body and has only a 50 percent chance of survival, doctors said.
His parents and younger brother were also burned badly, though they are expected to recover.

Barely a month after taking office, Secretary General Boutros Ghali has announced a sweeping reorganization that streamlines departments and slashes top posts in the unwieldy United Nations Secretariat.

The action, announced on Friday, follows the outlines of a proposal submitted last year by an informal group of representatives from more than 20 industrialized and developing countries, including the United States.
In a change intended to give Mr. Ghali more time to devote to peacekeeping, eight undersecretaries general will report to him directly, down from about 30 top officials under the old system.

But the plan disregards the representatives' suggestion that the five permanent Security Council members -- the United States, Britain, France, Russia and China -- agree not to claim any top posts for a few years.
The changes reflect the emphasis of a Security Council summit meeting last week in which leaders affirmed the role of the United Nations in maintaining peace in the post-cold-war era.

A former Deputy Foreign Minister of the defunct Soviet Union, Vladimir F. Petrovsky, has been named one of two new Under Secretaries General for Political Affairs, the second most important post under Mr. Ghali's.
Mr. Petrovsky will deal with the Security Council and the General Assembly and handle disarmament questions and peacemaking in selected regions.
The other Under Secretary General for Political Affairs will be James O. C. Jonah of Sierra Leone, who will be responsible for peacemaking in Africa and parts of Asia.

Both will be assisted in their mediation efforts by Giandomenico Picco, the Italian official who played a central role in securing the release of Western hostages in Beirut last year, and a Greek official, Sotirios Mousouris, who will have the rank of Assistant Secretary General.
Under Secretary General Marrack Goulding of Britain remains the senior official in charge of peacekeeping operations.
A rare chance now exists to hold Pol Pot, one of this century's most notorious mass murderers, accountable for his crimes against humanity and the Cambodian people.
Many hurdles must still be overcome before he can be brought before an international tribunal.
But current realities of Cambodian politics and international diplomacy make this an opportune moment to try.
America and other countries committed to upholding international law against wholesale murder must do their utmost to see that he comes to trial.
From 1975 to 1979 Pol Pot ordered more than a million people killed as he tried to bend Cambodia to his radical Maoist vision.
People were executed because they owned property, because they lived in cities, because they were professionals.
Even literacy became grounds for execution.

But now, 18 years after invading Vietnamese forces chased him from power and four years after internationally supervised elections left his Khmer Rouge a marginal political and military force, Mr. Pol Pot's former guerrilla comrades have reportedly turned against him and taken him captive.
The United States hopes that Mr. Pol Pot can somehow be delivered to Canada, whose laws permit prosecution for acts of genocide committed outside its territory.
Substantial documentary evidence has already been assembled, relieving prosecutors of any need to grant amnesty to his close collaborators in exchange for their testimony.
Marty Bouquet's special skill is to cut and shave tiny slices from that hardest of all stones until it becomes a shimmering, desirable diamond.
Bent over his workbench in the center of Antwerp, he wields his tools with patience and precision, qualities passed on to him by his father and grandfather. ''
My grandfather would say that you need two lives to understand diamonds,'' Mr. Bouquet said, adding that he is merely 45. ''
The old man was right,'' he said. ''
Every stone is different -- the clarity, the flaws keep changing.
I never get bored.''
The patience of a top diamond worker may be legendary, but it is also costly, so much so, in fact, that here in this city, long one of the world's main polishing centers, diamonds may not be forever.

Antwerp's tradition of cutting and trading the earth's most expensive gems began more than five centuries ago, but the industry is now following the route of many other enterprises in the global market, shifting to the immense reserves of low-cost labor in India.

Around Antwerp's medieval heart, and in the nearby villages of the flat countryside, more than 25,000 diamond workers were still active in the 1970's, often working in small family-owned workshops. ''
Today we are less than 800,'' said Jan Devos, a gemologist who once taught polishing but has found a new career as curator of the Diamond Museum in Bruges.

Priceline, the online travel site that allows bargain hunters to bid for goods and services, yesterday aligned itself with TravelWeb, the upstart hotel reservation Web site, in a deal that will give Priceline a 14 percent stake in TravelWeb.

Along with its $8.5 million investment in TravelWeb, which is owned by a group of five major hoteliers and the hotel reservations company Pegasus Solutions, Priceline will promote TravelWeb's inventory of discounted hotel rooms on Priceline.com and Priceline's Lowestfare.com site.

Priceline will earn a 10 percent commission on sales it generates for TravelWeb, by creating a separate section within Priceline's Web sites for travelers who do not wish to bid for their hotel rooms.
Priceline's chief executive, Jeffery H. Boyd, will also join TravelWeb's board.
Joe Humphry, TravelWeb's chief executive, said he expected such exposure to have a substantial impact on his company's sales.
Like its chief competitor, USAInteractive's Hotels.com, TravelWeb will pursue a strategy of selling rooms on a network of sites other than its own.
Lowestfare.com, an online travel agency, was purchased by Priceline last summer from the financier Carl C. Icahn for an undisclosed sum.
That site currently trails other online travel agencies by a wide margin, placing 28th in monthly visitors last month, according to the research firm ComScore Media Metrix.

Priceline bought Lowestfare.com to try to build a full service travel site that could serve customers when their Priceline.com bids fail, or when customers want to check retail rates before making bids.
TravelWeb, which is scheduled to start in mid-April, is among the most closely watched Internet companies to make a debut in many months.
Despite the close score and the many goals, this one was rarely pretty and seldom exciting, except at the very end.
Nevertheless, the Islanders managed a 5-4 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight in their home opener at the Nassau Coliseum.
Ray Ferraro scored twice for the Islanders and Andrei Lomakin scored twice for the Flyers, who have not won a game this season.
Each also had one assist.
Joe Reekie had three assists for New York, and Steve Duchesne had three for Philadelphia.
Although it was the Islanders' poorest outing of the season, it was their second victory in three games.
They play the Nordiques in Quebec on Sunday night.
The Flyers, with a major turnover in personnel, are 0-3-1.
A crowd of only 10,412 attended the Islanders' home opener.

The Flyers enjoyed a two-man advantage for 41 of the final 68 seconds when Don Koharski, the referee, first penalized Brent Sutter two minutes for interference at 17:33 and then sent off Randy Wood for five minutes for high-sticking at 18:52.

In many societies, the term ''child bride'' calls to mind impetuous sweethearts, a ladder cautiously positioned beneath a bedroom window, a silent kiss in the moonlight and a young couple making an anxious getaway to a justice of the peace.
But this is not a ready image the world over.
In Afghanistan, a child bride is very often just that: a child, even a preteen, her innocence betrothed to someone older, even much, much older.
Rather than a willing union between a man and woman, marriage is frequently a transaction among families, and the younger the bride, the higher the price she may fetch.
Girls are valuable workers in a land where survival is scratched from the grudging soil of a half-acre parcel.
In her parents' home, a girl can till fields, tend livestock and cook meals.
In her husband's home, she is more useful yet.
She can have sex and bear children.
Afghanistan is not alone in this predilection toward early wedlock.
Globally, the number of child brides is hard to tabulate; they live mostly in places where births, deaths and the human milestones in between go unrecorded.
GEOCLOCK puts the world at your fingertips or, rather, just beyond them, on your computer's screen.
Type GEOCLK and a handsome, colorful (assuming you have a color system) map of the world appears, with major cities identified and national borders sketched in.
The time is given for each of the cities, and shades of blue show where it is night, day, dawn or dusk.

Along the bottom of the screen are displayed the current times for sunrise and sunset at the city the program is set for, as well as things like the sun's elevation, latitude and longitude, the date and the time.
The program arrived set for Washington, but it's not too hard to change it to make where you are the center of the universe.
Nor are you limited to viewing the world as a whole.
With a few keystrokes or mouse clicks, you can zoom in on a portion of the map or call up one of 27 other maps.
You can also measure the distance between two points on a map, and there are ways to change the program to suit your preferences.
Pressing the F1 key brings up some fairly terse help.
Although Geoclock is easy to install on a hard disk, which is required, there are a couple of possible pitfalls.

Shamsur Rahman, a prominent Bangladeshi poet, journalist and human rights advocate who in 1999 survived an attempt on his life by an Islamic fundamentalist group, died in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Thursday.
He was in his late 70's.
The cause was heart and kidney failure, his family told The Associated Press.
Mr. Rahman, who had been in declining health for some time, had been in a coma for the last 12 days.
The unofficial poet laureate of Bangladesh, Mr. Rahman was among the country's most important political poets during its independence movement in the early 1970's. (
Amid brutal fighting, Bangladesh proclaimed its independence from Pakistan in 1971.)
Mr. Rahman wrote in Bengali and helped adapt the language to modern poetic forms.
Mr. Rahman published more than 60 volumes of poetry, only a few of which have been translated into English.
These include ''The Best Poems of Shamsur Rahman,'' published last year in New Delhi; and ''The Devotee, the Combatant: Selected Poems of Shamsur Rahman,'' published in 2000 in Dhaka.
Shamsur Rahman was born in Dhaka in the late 1920's.
The victory won by reformers in Iran's parliamentary elections should encourage the Clinton administration to try again to defrost relations between Washington and Tehran.
Earlier efforts were rebuffed, in part because Iran's harshly anti-American clerical leaders limited President Mohammad Khatami's options.
Those leaders, who outrank both Mr. Khatami and the Parliament, may still prove a formidable obstacle.
But their position has been weakened by the parliamentary vote.
They cannot ignore the electorate's clear desire to end Iran's international isolation.
Until the power struggle between reformers and conservative clerics is fully resolved, only limited reconciliation may be possible.
But Washington should use this period to ease some economic sanctions and demonstrate its support for the reform agenda the voters endorsed, including increased trade with the West.

The White House could begin by offering to open discussions about paying off some of Iran's longstanding financial claims against the United States, and selectively easing sanctions on Iranian consumer exports like caviar and pistachio nuts.
Iran's ruling clerics are out of touch with their people's attitude toward the United States.
America's rigid support of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's repressive dictatorship has not been forgotten.
KEEPING cutting tools sharp is a key to using them skillfully and safely.
Chisels, planes and knives are relatively easy to sharpen; other tools, like saws, scissors and drill bits, should be sharpened professionally.
Sharpening involves grinding a thick, dull edge against a harder surface, like a sharpening stone.
Despite the variety of stones and sharpening implements available, the simplest and least expensive for an amateur remains the old-fashioned combination oilstone.
Called a coarse-fine India stone, the oilstone is a man-made block of aluminum oxide abrasives.
One side consists of coarse particles, which remove metal quickly; the other consists of smoother particles, which hone the coarsely sharpened surface to a cutting edge.
The stone must be saturated with lightweight oil during use.
The oil captures metal particles scraped from the blade and prevents them from clogging, and possibly ruining, the stone.
Most hardware stores carry oilstones and cutting oil.
A two-inch-wide stone measuring six to eight inches long is usually adequate, and usually costs less than $15.
''It's almost like a religious occasion,'' said Burt Tansky, the chief executive of Neiman Marcus, in a tone of wonder.
Yes, the nuns and fashion pilgrims were out yesterday, headed for Ralph Rucci.

Sometimes Mr. Rucci's clothes too literally evoke a nunnery (an elegant nunnery, but still), and the music for his show in the tents at Bryant Park had the moodiness, without the irony, of the theme music from ''Six Feet Under.''
But then out comes a tiger-striped coat in silk chenille velvet, and you realize that Mr. Rucci invariably has more up his sleeve than he is prepared to show, at least all at once.
Not everything about his fall collection was special; there were reprises of infanta skirts, now in dusky chartreuse with a wrap shirt.

But when the pieces were special, they were sensational, like a maxicoat in sable tied high on the waist and a little black dress that looked unpromising from the front but was laced across the back, like vertebrae.

As if timed for Valentine's Day, Anna Sui played Cupid to Coco Chanel on Wednesday night, sending out witty takes on the famous cardigan jacket and those indelible images of Chanel looking both pretty and powerful in her many bangles and ropes of chains.

A model, her hair crimped and fried as if from contact with an electrical socket, appeared with a candy-box-shape hat tipped over her brow, and some of the girls swung heart-shaped purses -- a Valentine? --
flecked with stones.
Other designers this season have had Chanel on their minds, most of all Rei Kawakubo at the Paris men's shows, with her shrunken tweed jackets.
Two years ago, Venus Williams made a smash debut at the United States Open, where she was the first unseeded finalist in four decades.

But last year, when she designed a different dress for each of her seven possible matches, Williams fell a round short and never unveiled the red, white and blue costume she aimed to wear in the final.

With the Open set to begin at the United States Tennis Association's National Tennis Center on Aug. 30, Williams, who will be seeded a career-best third with the recent retirement of Steffi Graf, is at it again.
While in search of her first Grand Slam title, she has helped Reebok concoct seven dresses for the tournament, including a one-shoulder outfit she designed herself.

After spending the week hard at practice in Florida for her Open tune-up next week in New Haven, the 19-year-old Williams will put herself and some of her Open outfits on display at the Official All Star Cafe in Manhattan on Sunday afternoon.

Whether or not she wins the Open, Williams said she intended to wind down her 1999 season in October in order to sign on for a semester of fashion design at a Florida college she would not name, the better to keep the paparazzi in the dark.
But yesterday Williams said she hoped to be in the Open spotlight from start to finish. ''
You need to be on top of your game and be ready, and, most of all, mentally prepared,'' Williams said. ''
I'm definitely trying my best to get to No.
1; I'm definitely trying my best to win Grand Slams.
NEW YORK CITY owes its grandeur in part to its early prowess in attracting shipping.
The Erie Canal, which opened the first major commercial artery to the American interior, helped transform New York docks into the springboard of a nation's commerce.

Today, however, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is threatening to cut off the east bank of the Hudson River from the shipping trade, turning New York east of the Hudson, including Long Island and Westchester, into the global shipping equals of landlocked Wichita.
Blame the real estate boom.
Enticed by high property prices, the Port Authority wants to redevelop the piers of the Red Hook Container Terminal in Brooklyn, turning New York's shipping heritage into commercial real estate.
The Red Hook terminal, which handles more than 120,000 containers of goods per year, is the last major shipping entrance east of the Hudson.
The lease of American Stevedoring, the port's operator, expires next spring.
If the Port Authority pursues its redevelopment plan, businesses and residents east of the Hudson will be forced to rely solely on trucks carrying cargo from New Jersey.
American Stevedoring says most of the containers it brings in remain east of the Hudson.
If those goods land in New Jersey instead, they will have to be transported across one of the five bridges and tunnels crossing the river, adding to already heavy congestion.

Along with enthusiasm for their Stars and friendly manners toward visitors, the hockey fans of Texas show a sophistication about the sport that belies their recent arrival in the National Hockey League.

So when the Devils won the Stanley Cup late Saturday night with a 2-1 victory in the second overtime, a group of men and women in Stars jerseys gathered near the glass as the Devils players posed for pictures with the trophy for about half an hour. ''
Skate the cup!''
they chanted, some of them with cameras in their hands. ''
Skate the cup!''
It is a modern tradition for teams to take the silver prize in a long, slow procession, holding it high, passing it from hands to hands.
The Devils, clinching on the road before subdued applause, had simply forgotten.
Finally, with about 2,000 people left in Reunion Arena, somebody remembered to start the parade and the Devils went one, tired lap to the respectful applause of their gracious hosts.
You could excuse their temporary amnesia regarding protocol.
Jason Arnott's goal, at 8 minutes 20 seconds of the second extra session, had ended a grueling six-game series that seemed longer.
I BEGAN this column in the surgical waiting room of Mount Sinai Hospital.
I didn't get far.
There are some places, some situations, where real work is simply impossible, and waiting for your son to have pins inserted into his hand is indisputably one of them.
Evan had been tossing a football with friends a few days earlier, and managed to fracture three fingers.
That's what led him to the O.R., and while the surgeon did his work, I tried to do mine.
I know, I know, in theory this might have been a good time to call an editor and say my column simply wouldn't run this week.
After all, isn't that what I preach here all the time?
And yet, if the lines were clear, we wouldn't fail to see them so often.
Writing while your son is in surgery, O.K., that one is straightforward.
But what about the next day, when Evan would still be in pain, and fumbling with one hand, wanting Mom?

A former business partner of the martial arts movie star Steven Seagal pleaded guilty yesterday to extortion conspiracy, ushering a case that had brought high drama to federal court in Brooklyn into its final act.

The defendant, Julius R. Nasso, who was once a close friend of Mr. Seagal's and produced his movies, admitted that he had conspired to threaten him to collect a debt Mr. Nasso claims the actor owes him for backing out of movie projects.
Under the plea agreement entered yesterday before Magistrate Judge Viktor V. Pohorelsky, Mr. Nasso will be sentenced to a year and a day in jail and fined $75,000.

Mr. Nasso's brother Vincent had also been charged in the scheme against Mr. Seagal, but he pleaded guilty to a single charge of wire fraud in a related organized-crime case involving a health plan of the International Longshoremen's Association.
Under his plea agreement, he will be sentenced to 24 months in prison and fined $250,000.
The agreements must still be considered by the judge presiding over the case, Frederic Block of Federal District Court.
If he decides to impose heavier sentences than those in the plea agreements, Judge Pohorelsky said, the Nassos can withdraw their pleas and proceed to trial.
The government can do the same if Judge Block imposes lighter sentences.

The case against the Nassos stemmed from a larger case against Peter Gotti, a brother of the deceased mob leader John J. Gotti, and six other men who prosecutors said were members of the Gambino crime family.
One of them, Anthony Ciccone, a captain known as Sonny, was convicted of working with Julius Nasso in the extortion attempt.
This university town has been transformed in the last decade by the arrival of companies like Microsoft, along with a bevy of start-ups hoping to follow in its footsteps.
Now it is watching intently to see whether Microsoft's path will be divided. ''

For us, Microsoft is viewed as the archetypical high-tech success story,'' said John Cornish, director of product marketing for ARM Holdings, a designer of microchips for hand-held devices based in Cambridge that itself has become a hometown success story. ''
The antitrust issues are a function of antitrust laws based on U.S. history, which differs very much from the U.K. and Europe.''
In Britain and on the Continent, the latest chapter in the Microsoft tale -- the government's proposal last week to break the company in two -- has received prominent attention in the media.
The French daily newspaper Liberation has even set up a forum on its Web site for Parisian readers to weigh in with their views. ''

We're a bit further removed, but I think there is as much interest here as there is in the States,'' said Derek McAuley, the assistant director of Microsoft's research lab in Cambridge, Microsoft Research Ltd. ''When I talk to my friends at the pub, there is an understanding of the principles of antitrust, but there is some confusion as to why this litigation is being brought to bear against us.''
Indeed, for many of the new-economy start-ups in Europe, Microsoft has served as the ultimate example of an entrepreneurial success story.
William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, has achieved a celebrity status in Europe that rivals the Spice Girls.
And while most Europeans have watched the breakup of state-owned monopolies through deregulation, most have never seen the breakup of a self-made company.
The Georgian authorities said today that they had arrested the man who shot the American diplomat Fred Woodruff this month, but described his death as a "chance killing."

Mr. Woodruff, who according to unconfirmed American press reports was working for the C.I.A., was killed with a single bullet to the head on Aug. 8 while traveling in a car with the security chief for the Georgian leader, Eduard A. Shevardnadze.
On Georgian radio, First Deputy Interior Minister Mikhail Osadze said: "The crime has been solved.
The criminal has been identified, the investigation is proceeding, and we expect him to go on trial."
He added: "The murder was not intentional, although the court will have the last word.
This was a chance killing.
No one knew who they were shooting at, how they were shooting, but the fact remains a crime was committed which had a clear international resonance, and for us, of course, this was most undesirable."
Suspect Not Identified Mr. Osadze, speaking to Reuters later by telephone, said the suspect, a young man, had been arrested.
He refused to identify him.
The man had apparently fired in an attempt to stop the car in which Mr. Woodruff was traveling, but had not intended to kill any of the passengers, Mr. Osadze said. "

Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that critics of his proposal to use  welfare recipients for hallway and lunch room duty in the city schools were giving in to negative stereotypes of people on public assistance. "
This is really a heck of a commentary on what people think of people who are receiving welfare," the Mayor said at a press conference at City Hall. "
That out of thousands and thousands of people that we assign to work, it's not possible to find those who are highly responsible people."
This can be done without all of those fears being ignited," he added.

Later at Board of Education headquarters, David Begel, a spokesman for Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, used the same argument to defend the proposal, even though Dr. Crew himself has not publicly endorsed it and the Board of Education has not approved it.
In fact, some board members complained that they  learned of the proposal only yesterday, weeks after Dr. Crew and the Mayor first discussed the idea.
While Dr. Crew would say yesterday only that he was discussing the idea with  the seven-member board, his spokesman, Mr. Begel, said, "He's generally in support of the plan they talked about."
Mr. Begel also criticized arguments against using welfare recipients in the schools: "You're really stereotyping people.
I think that that's a racist characterization."

The Mayor is pushing a plan to extend his workfare program into the schools,  where people on welfare would replace teachers in monitoring students at lunch and recess, in the hallways as they change classes, and near the school building as school begins and ends.

One hundred and thirty evangelical Christians, including three visiting Americans on a religious mission, were arrested in central China on Wednesday as they attended a revival, according to a human rights monitor and the Americans' pastor in California.

The raid was part of a continuing pattern of arrests, fines and other harassment of so-called house churches, mainly evangelical Protestant groups that have quietly spread their faith to tens of millions of Chinese while refusing to accept the authority of official religious bodies.
It came one day after a top leader of the government-sponsored churches told an audience in Los Angeles that religion in China had entered a ''golden age'' of freer expression.

The detained Chinese are followers of the China Fangcheng Church, which claims more than 500,000 members and is one of the largest of many fervent Protestant groups that meet and evangelize across the country without government approval.
Such groups often receive encouragement and financial aid from like-minded churches in the United States, Europe and Asia.
American evangelicals say the beliefs and practices of the Fangcheng Church fall well within the Christian tradition.
But the Chinese authorities have labeled this and several other similar groups as cults and in December sent two Fangcheng leaders to ''re-education through labor'' camps.

Tonight, the American Embassy in Beijing said it had not yet been able to confirm with Chinese officials that three citizens were in police hands,  but said it was sending a consular officer to the area.
Under an agreement, China must inform the embassy within 96 hours when an American is detained for any reason.
When an American supporter of the outlawed Falun Gong spiritual group was detained this year, she was quickly deported.
A Federal judge yesterday denied Leona Helmsley's request for a new trial and ordered her to begin serving her four-year prison sentence on April 15.

The ruling by Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court in Manhattan appeared to destroy the 71-year-old defendant's last chance to escape beginning a prison sentence, which coincides with the income tax filing deadline, for her 1989 tax fraud conviction.
Seeming to anticipate that the judge would reaffirm his order sending her to prison, Mrs. Helmsley left the courtroom before Judge Griesa reached his decision.
Asked during a recess moments before how she would cope with the prospect of going to prison, Mrs. Helmsley remarked sarcastically, "Maybe I can drop dead."
Appeal Planned Her lawyers said they would appeal Judge Griesa's ruling as well as the one he made on March 15, when he refused to reduce her sentence.
Alan Dershowitz, a lawyer for Mrs. Helmsley, said he would apply for a expedited hearing on the two appeals by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

But court officials said it was unlikely that he would obtain a ruling in time to block the order requiring Mrs. Helmsley to surrender next Wednesday at the Women's Medical Center at Lexington, Ky. Mrs. Helmsley was admitted to New York Hospital for a few days shortly after she left court last month, and her lawyers contend that her heart condition is so grave that she could die in prison.
But Judge Griesa said yesterday that her medical condition would not excuse her from starting her sentence.
Mrs. Helmsley's lawyers argued that they had new evidence that showed several prosecution witnesses perjured themselves during her trial and that Federal prosecutors knew it at the time.

The lawyers also asserted that Mrs. Helmsley, along with her husband, Harry, were innocent victims of a fraud committed by their accountants, one of whom they said benefited from his perjury by having a Federal prosecution against him dropped.

In an unusual setback for Russia's security services, a jury on Monday acquitted a physicist who had been charged with espionage for selling information that he and other scientists argued was not classified.
The physicist, Valentin Danilov, 53, who leads a research institute in Krasnoyarsk in Siberia, was arrested in September 2001, accused of selling information about Russia's space technology to China.

The case was one of a series of espionage cases against scientists that have raised fears of a crackdown by the successor agency to the K.G.B. on poorly paid scientists who in the post-Soviet period turned to commercial ventures abroad. ''
There is a trend to arrest scientists and accuse them of spying without any foundation,'' Lyudmila M. Alekseyeva, chairwoman of the Moscow Helsinki Group, a human rights group, said in July.
Human rights groups and Mr. Danilov attributed the acquittal to the fact that this was a rare jury trial, rather than a trial before judges who could be susceptible to state pressure. ''

After a four-hour-long discussion, 8 out of the 12 jurors declared him innocent on all counts, after which the judge acquitted him,'' Mr. Danilov's lawyer, Yelena Yevmenova, told The Associated Press.
Prosecutors said they would appeal to the Supreme Court, apparently on procedural grounds.
Jury trials have been held on an experimental basis over the last decade in only 9 of Russia's 89 regions. ''
The not guilty verdict was largely thanks to a jury,'' Mr. Danilov told the radio station Ekho Moskvy. ''
When it was only a judge, it was difficult for him to reach such a verdict.''

Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met yesterday morning with the president of Taiwan, referred afterward to the island of 22 million people as a ''remarkable country,'' then scoffed at Chinese reporters who heatedly asked if the mayor planned to recognize Taiwan as its own nation. ''
Well, I don't get to recognize countries,'' an exasperated Mr. Giuliani said at a City Hall news conference after his meeting with the Taiwanese leader, Chen Shui-bian, at the Waldorf Towers. ''
I'm not the State Department.''
He added, ''And the State Department said it was O.K. to visit with him.
So, you can now go out and make a big deal out of it in some distorted way if you want.
That's your job.''

Mr. Giuliani's press secretary, Sunny Mindel, said later that the mayor's reference to Taiwan as a country was ''a manner of speaking'' and not a political statement at odds with the United States policy of recognizing only one Chinese government.
A State Department official  shrugged off the mayor's remarks. ''
Rudy Giuliani doesn't represent U.S. policy,'' said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Although the United States does not recognize Taiwan as a country, critics of China, among them many Republicans, often refer to it as one.

EVEN as American and Iraqi forces move to surround the last large group of insurgents in Falluja this weekend, they are also scrambling to quell fighting that has erupted in many other Sunni towns and cities in Iraq.
That, in turn, has raised questions about whether the 138,000 American troops in Iraq are enough to do the job.

In Mosul, Iraq's third-largest city, as many as 500 insurgents seized and looted a half-dozen police stations on Thursday, stealing police cars, hundreds of weapons and uniforms, and stunning American officials with the size and scope of their attacks.
Iraqi and American officials have suspended Iraqi police patrols for several days, fearing that they would not be able to tell good officers from imposters.

Critics point to the violence in Mosul, which, like most of northern Iraq, had been relatively calm since the United States invasion in March 2003, as evidence American troops are spread too thin to counter the insurgency. ''
In my mind, there's a legitimate issue about the number of troops,'' said Senator Jack Reed, a Rhode Island Democrat and former 82nd Airborne officer who is visiting Iraq this weekend.
On Thursday, 1,500 American soldiers and 1,000 Iraq National Guard troops fought pitched battles in Mosul with groups of militants ranging from 15 to 50 fighters.
Although hundreds of Iraqi and American reinforcements from elsewhere in Iraq were quickly ordered to shore up defenses in Mosul, the top American commander there said he did not need more troops. ''
I'm satisfied that the forces assigned to me are adequate for the mission,'' Brig.
Gen. Carter Ham, who commands 8,000 American troops in northern Iraq, said in a telephone interview.
LEAD: To the Editor: To the Editor: In an Op-Ed piece on Thanksgiving Day (''For the Indians, No Thanksgiving''), Michael Dorris indulges in the popular sport of Pilgrim-bashing.
This is easy if one sufficiently distorts history and readers are not aware of the facts.
Who can quarrel with Mr. Dorris's conclusion that the Indian fared ill because of the coming of the white man?
Of course, he did.
But this does not give Mr. Dorris the right to rewrite Pilgrim history.
He says there was ''a scattering of shirtless Indian invitees'' at the first Thanksgiving dinner in 1621.
Actually, there were 90 hungry braves.
There were a dozen white girls and women from infant to oldest to cook for 41 settlers and the 90 Indians.
Some Indians did go out and shoot five deer.
But the Indians stayed, eating, for three days.

The city-owned radio station, WNYC, has decided to hire one of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's most colorful supporters, Curtis Sliwa, founder of the Guardian Angels, as host of a daily talk program, provoking a protest from its staff.
The move upends a settled afternoon schedule, moving two National Public Radio programs to nighttime slots.
But station executives said the move to hire Mr. Sliwa, whose talk radio program on WABC-AM was canceled several weeks ago, was intended to strengthen finances by increasing listener contributions.
The possibility of Mr. Sliwa's working for the station was first raised publicly by the Mayor himself when he called Mr. Sliwa on the air on Jan. 14, after WABC announced the program's cancellation.
Mr. Giuliani suggested that Mr. Sliwa and his wife, Lisa, who are divorcing, apply for a job with the city's station.

Although members of the Giuliani administration say the Mayor had no hand in the decision to hire Mr. Sliwa, staff members at the station felt otherwise and sent a memorandum protesting the move to Thomas B. Morgan, president of the WNYC Communications Group. "
There is a widely held belief that this sudden decision to implement a new local talk show was greatly influenced by politics," they wrote.
They further charged that the decision to hire Mr. Sliwa cheapened the mission of public radio and violated the usual hiring procedures.
Talk of Walking Out They also charged that affirmative action guidelines were breached, and two women and a black man applied for the time slot offered Mr. Sliwa, who is white.
One staff member, who insisted on anonymity for fear of jeopardizing her job, said she and many employees feel torn.
Paula Cooper Gallery  534 West 21st Street, Chelsea  Through Oct. 14 The pluses and minuses of Meg Webster's current show are blatant: one installation piece is excellent, the other isn't.
Excellent is ''Warped Floor,'' a 20-foot-square, 6-foot-high undulating surface made of largish terra-cotta squares set in sand and supported by a wood infrastructure.
It suggests an enormous mountain desert compressed to bonsai scale -- or a particularly huge Charles Simonds work.
Even when you walk on it, which is allowed, you seem to be viewing it from a great distance.
The second work, which is two pieces, accomplishes no such magical atmosphere or perceptual inversion. ''
Long Pool'' is a Jacuzzi-size reservoir of water surrounded by a dense array of tropical plants, including orchids, ferns, a pineapple tree and a water lily.
A narrow channel connects it to a second pool, ''Interacting Falls: Plain and Shooter.''
The title explains the difference between the streams of water emptying into the pool from characteristically low-tech apparatus overhead, while also suggesting a sexual pun.
With all the spritzing and greenness, these pieces have their soothing aspects; with a little polishing they would be at home in a shopping mall.
But mainly they heighten the experience of the terra-cotta terrain of ''Warped Floor,'' making it seem even stranger, like a mirage encountered at the edge of a jungle.

After three weeks of delays caused by rough seas, efforts to recover the remaining sunken wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 returned to high gear yesterday, with at least two more days of calm conditions in the offing, Navy officials said.

Nonetheless, crash investigators said they were growing increasingly concerned that a significant portion of the airplane may still be missing even after the wreckage from the last significant debris field is completely recovered.
Investigators said that more than 70 percent of the plane had been salvaged, and that they had located 15 or 20 percent more on the seabed.
But, they said, at least 10 percent of the jet -- more than 17 tons  -- is still unaccounted for. ''
We keep recovering wreckage daily, but the amount is getting less and less,'' said a senior official working on the salvage operation.
Like most crash investigators, he spoke on condition of anonymity.
The sense of discouragement stems from the knowledge, investigators said, that they have scoured the seabed more thoroughly than in any previous crash.
Some places have been scanned by sonar three or four times, said an underwater search expert involved in the operation.
In fact, the search has been so complete that it has turned up not just wreckage from the T.W.A. Boeing 747, but also a part that apparently fell years ago from a Boeing 707 jetliner.
The barnacle-encrusted part had puzzled investigators until specialists recognized it as a piece of the older aircraft, investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board said.

Manhattan Chamber Orchestra Symphony Space The Manhattan Chamber Orchestra, one of New York's many ensembles of eager young freelancers, opened its sixth season on Wednesday evening with a program of accessibly melodic concertos by David Amram and Jacques Ibert.
Both composers seem to be specialties of Richard Auldon Clark, the orchestra's music director.
Mr. Amram's works have figured into many of the ensemble's programs, and the orchestra has just released a compact disk devoted to Ibert works it played last season.
Mr. Amram's "Honor Song for Sitting Bull" was the program's most exotic and inviting work.
Long before it became fashionable to think multi-culturally, Mr. Amram began writing works that sought common ground between American Indian themes and European orchestral coloration.
This latest installment in that series is a cello concerto, based on a traditional Sioux melody.
The theme's contours have a mildly Oriental tinge, and its long phrases end with a quick, descending slide that recalls recordings of whale song.
First stated in the winds and brass, it becomes the subject of the solo cello line, which explores it in a series of variations.
The orchestra moves gradually toward European colorations and rhetorical gestures, but the flavor of the Sioux melody resurfaces frequently.
Nathaniel Rosen gave a warm, rich-toned account of the solo cello line.
Pog has been called the tiddlywinks of the 1990's, heir to mumbletypeg and marbles.
But the explosive popularity of this simple children's game, and its profit potential, have ignited a legal dispute so intense that it has at times erupted into adult violence.
At issue is one company's claim of exclusive rights to the name Pog, the name by which the game is now almost universally known by the children who play it and by the adults who market it.
The game dates to the Depression, and was then called Milk Caps because it was played with the cardboard disks that were used to seal glass milk bottles.
The disks are stacked, and then a thicker disk, called a "slammer," is thrown at the pile.
The thrower wins points for every disk that is flipped over.
In more aggressive versions of the game, the thrower keeps the flipped disks.
In 1991 the game was revived by Blossom Galbiso, a teacher at an elementary school in Oahu, with the children replacing the milk covers with cardboard caps from a popular fruit juice beverage.
The drink was called POG because of its ingredients -- passion fruit, orange and guava.
And as the game spread throughout Hawaii, children started calling the game Pog and the disks pogs.
Zigmund Palffy shook his head and muttered to himself in Czech after today's game.
He could have been thinking about any one of several crucial moments during the Islanders' 4-1 loss to the Flyers at the Core States Center.
Maybe it was his three blown scoring chances.
Maybe it was his watching from the penalty box as John LeClair scored the third-period goal that put Philadelphia ahead for good.
Whatever it was, Palffy blamed himself for today's loss.
No one is tougher on Palffy than he is himself. ''
We had a lot of chances to win the game,'' he said. ''
But I took a stupid penalty, and they scored a goal for that.
It's my fault.''
Palffy was called for high sticking moments before LeClair gave the Flyers a 2-1 lead 6 minutes 32 seconds into the third period.
Citing the economic crisis in Turkey, Procter & Gamble warned yesterday that its profits would fall as much as 4 percent in the third quarter and about 1.5 percent for the entire year.
Turkey is Procter's 12th-largest market, the value of its currency, the lira, had declined 32 percent in less than a week.
The free fall began when the country decided to let the financial markets set the value of its currency, rather than keep it tied to the euro and the dollar.

Because Procter & Gamble, which makes Tide, Pampers and Crest, has repeatedly warned Wall Street over the last year to scale back its expectations for the company's performance, some analysts questioned whether it might have overemphasized the impact of the Turkish currency crisis, hoping to mask more deep-seated problems.

In particular, some analysts could not help but wonder if the aggressive cost-cutting strategy put in place last fall by Alan G. Lafley, Procter's chief executive, has failed to reverse the company's fortunes. ''
There's something else going on, which they haven't discussed,'' said David Kerans, an analyst with Argus Research. ''
It shouldn't make much difference that the Turkish economy's in collapse.''
Turkey accounts for only about $400 million of the company's $40 billion in annual sales.
Company officials said that they could probably compensate for the slowdown in consumer spending that is expected in Turkey but only by cutting back on other spending, like advertising.
P.& G. expects profits of 69 cents to 72 cents a diluted share for its fiscal third quarter ending in March.
USUALLY, when a mayor dismisses people from their jobs, there is a tangible reason.
A bridge collapsed.
Or a budget wasn't balanced.
Or someone was accused of malfeasance.
