What's so baffling about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's housecleaning is that there is no clear explanation of what most of the dozens of people dismissed did to attract his ire.

Some spokesmen were caught telling the truth, awkward as the truth may have been, and the Police Department's spokesman not only balked at trimming his staff but also burnished to a bright shine Police Commissioner William J. Bratton's image, which apparently did not please the Mayor.
But what wrongs did everyone else commit, exactly?

Answers to that question have been ambiguous at best, which suggests that the dismissals of about 40 people so far may reflect less about past deeds than the Mayor's fears of what is to come as he prepares to announce his latest budget.
THE economy is no better, spending cuts are getting deeper, the state and Federal governments are cutting, too, and city agencies are already suffering.

The Mayor prides himself on being a good manager, but some of his agencies, including the Youth Services Department and the Human Resources Administration, are in disarray, and with a city budget gap of $2.7 billion, more may follow.

Anthony J. Ingrassia, a playwright, producer and director whose works were produced on and Off Broadway and abroad, died on Saturday night at Brunswick Hospital in Amityville, L.I. Mr. Ingrassia, who lived in Massapequa Park, L.I.,  was 51.
By his own admission a compulsive eater who weighed about 600 pounds and suffered from a breathing disorder and a heart ailment, Mr. Ingrassia died of cardiac arrest, said a friend, Jill Johnson.
Mr. Ingrassia was a fixture of the nonmainstream performing arts of the 1950's and 60's.

He was a member of the Ridiculous Theater Company, founded by a fellow Hofstra University student, Charles Ludlam, and the impresario of Company One, whose number changed with each production, until it finally became Company  Seven.
But it was on Broadway that Mr. Ingrassia's career reached its devastating zenith in 1974.
On Nov. 18, his play "Fame," about Marilyn Monroe, opened and closed at the John Golden Theater.
Clive Barnes of The New York Times called it a "limp rag of a comedy."
Smarting from the failure, Mr. Ingrassia accepted a German grant that included a round-trip ticket and a monthly stipend for a year.
He went to Berlin, appeared in a revue with a transsexual performer, Romy Haag, and wrote radio plays. "
Fame," all 80 scenes, was one of them. "

Performing music with fresh vegetables brings certain occupational challenges, like the tendency of the instruments to fall apart suddenly. ''

We have to be flexible,'' said Matthias Meinharter, a member of the First Viennese Vegetable Orchestra, who awkwardly lost the mouthpiece for his hollowed-out carrot during a recent concert here, and had to improvise by nibbling at the carrot even as he blew into it.
Carrots, which make fine whistly wind instruments as well as having impressive percussional uses, are the least of it.

The orchestra, made up of nine black-clad avant-garde artists from Vienna, uses everything from tiny kidney beans to hefty pumpkins in its work -- beating, shaking, blowing, peeling, spitting, snapping, grating, poking, rubbing and mushing them in startlingly ingenious ways.
The sensitive microphones onstage pick up even the softest hint of vegetable noise, and somehow the result suggests that the musicians are more than just people publicly playing with their food. ''

They're very enthusiastic, talented and artistically minded,'' said Franz Hautzinger, a trumpet player and abstract composer in Vienna, whose compositions for the vegetable orchestra include ''Five Improvisations for Mixed Vegetables.''
Speaking of one of his favorite vegetable instruments, he added, ''You can really write for the cucumber-o-phone -- it's an instrument with many, many possibilities.''
In Hamburg, the orchestra played in a bohemian-minded arts center and then served post-performance bowls of vegetable soup.

The audience seemed to take the whole thing in stride, even when Mr. Meinharter grated carrots so zealously in one piece that the shavings sprayed across the front row (the orchestra also uses kitchen utensils, including knives and blenders). ''
I expected it to be just fun and games, but it's really interesting experimental music,'' said Hartwig Spitzer, a 64-year-old physicist who nonetheless said he would be loath to try it at home. ''

SEVERAL new studies of radon, the radioactive gas known to cause cancer and found to be seeping into millions of homes across the country, have uncovered little evidence linking household exposure to disease, raising questions about how much risk radon poses to humans at very low levels.

Researchers say these studies have in most cases failed to show an association between lung cancer and household radon levels at or even slightly higher than the level at which the Environmental Protection Agency recommends taking corrective measures.
The continued lack of evidence of a significant risk from radon at these levels raises questions about how aggressively the nation should try to lower radon levels in homes and buildings.
The ultimate cost to meet the E.P.A. standard is estimated at $50 billion or more, critics say.
But the E.P.A. and other scientists contend there is enough indirect evidence that radon is a major cause of cancer at levels found in many homes to take action.
The design and limited number of participants in some of the new studies fail to give them sufficient power to assess the true risks, they say.
Radon is an odorless, colorless gas that arises naturally from the ground because of the decay of radioactive elements commonly found in rocks and many types of soil.
In a chain of radioactive decay, uranium produces radium, which gives off radon, which in turn produces radioactive breakdown products that are harmful if inhaled.
Almost all scientists agree that prolonged exposure to high levels of radon is hazardous, but uncertainty remains about the risks of low-level exposure.

Worldwide studies of lung cancer in underground miners, backed by animal research, show that long-term exposure to high levels of radon and its breakdown products causes lung cancer and that the effect is heightened by cigarette smoking, researchers say.
It's catalogue time again and we're all awash in glossy booklets offering holiday consumables.
As the tide grows more tsunamic each year, the game becomes more subtle.
Whispering Pines of Piermont, N.Y., sells Adirondack-cabin nostalgia in the form of things made from twigs, or bearing moose motifs.

Daily Planet markets a style best described as International Ironic, offering obsolete Communist lapel pins from the former Soviet Union, French Foreign Legion capes and Afghan carpets with AK-47's woven into the design.
The American West is big and getting bigger.
There must be at least 20 catalogues flying through the mails this year selling yards of turquoise necklaces, deerskin garments, long three-tiered skirts for dancin' in and "genuine" Indian pottery.
A big element in this particular nostalgia package is the trade in ersatz Native American spirituality.
We've lost track of the number of mail-order houses offering genuine "dream catchers" -- a sort of woven net affair made of hide with feathers.
Every silver bangle, every sandstone cocktail coaster is assigned deep significance. "

A shield was a Cheyenne warrior's most sacred and valued possession," reads the copy in a catalogue from Coldwater Creek of Sandpoint, Idaho, "giving him psychological protection from visible and invisible foes. . . .
In a makeshift temple at the foot of a rocky cliff in the Gobi Desert, four aged lamas in saffron robes sat cross-legged on carpets before a shrine to Buddha.
They were fasting, meditating in silence and perusing sacred texts of Tibetan Buddhism.
Outside under a harsh sun lay the crumbling mud-brick ruins of the Ulgii Khiid Monastery, which once held more than a thousand monks.

It had been sacked by the repressive Communist Government that ruled Mongolia for 70 years, a Government that destroyed more than 700 monasteries in the 1930's, burning books and executing thousands of lamas.
Now some surviving lamas are returning to occupy Ulgii Khiid and several dozen other monasteries.
They live and worship in yurts, the customary dome-shaped dwellings of Mongolian nomads.
They are teaching younger men to be monks and making plans to rebuild the temples.
Resurging Nationalism The scene of religious revival amid revolution's ruins illustrates the extraordinary changes under way in Mongolia.

In yet another reverberation from the collapsing Soviet empire, the dictatorship tied to Moscow was ousted in March 1990 and replaced with a more reform-mined Communist Government and a Parliament that includes increasingly assertive democratic opposition parties.
With that new political freedom has come a resurgence of Mongolian nationalism.
Gram Parsons was just short of 27 when he died of a drug overdose in a California motel room in 1973, but his posthumous legend shows no signs of growing old.

If anything, his plain-spoken, poetic folk-country songwriting style has undergone something of a revival recently as alt-country musicians like Gillian Welch and Lucinda Williams absorb his influence and invoke his name. ''
Grand Theft Parsons,'' directed by David Caffrey from a script by Jeremy Drysdale, is an odd, heartfelt contribution to the Parsons martyrology.
While Parsons's living voice, usually entwined with Emmylou Harris's, occasionally wafts across the soundtrack, the movie is mostly concerned with his dead body.
What drama there is in ''Grand Theft,'' which opens today in New York, revolves around the disposal of that beloved, prematurely deceased corpse.

Parsons's road manager, Phil Kaufman (Johnny Knoxville), honoring what he believes were the dead man's wishes, wants to take the body out to Joshua Tree in the Southern California desert and set it on fire.
Meanwhile, one of the singer's former girlfriends (Christina Applegate), in possession of a scrap of paper she says is Parsons's will, needs proof of death to collect her supposed inheritance.
And Parsons's father (Robert Forster) has arrived at the Los Angeles airport to collect his son's remains and fly them home to Louisiana.

Arriving at the airport with a bright yellow hearse (whose suspicious owner is a spaced-out hippie played by Michael Shannon), Kaufman gets to Parsons's body first, and what follows is a ragged, meandering chase.
Mr. Knoxville, best known as the head prankster on MTV's ''Jackass,'' shows some promise as an actor, balancing Kaufman's sleazy fecklessness with his keen sense of cowboy honor.

Over and over this season, Rangers Coach Tom Renney has made the right call at just the right time, which is why he deserves strong consideration for the Jack Adams Trophy, given to the N.H.L.'s coach of the year.

Weekes, 30, had particularly struggled at Nassau Coliseum in his only two starts against the Islanders as a member of the Rangers.

We knew it was not going to be easy for him,'' Jaromir Jagr said of Weekes. ''
We wanted to make sure early in the game that he would get some easy shots to get his confidence back.
It's not easy when you don't play for such a great time.
And he did a great job.
And we did a great job, too.

A virulent form of strep throat, similar to the kind that killed 11 people in Britain this year, has hospitalized two residents of Norwalk, Conn. The cases are the first reported in the United States this year, but health officials said yesterday that there was no reason to fear a widespread outbreak.

The two cases were reported late last week by Norwalk Hospital after a man and a woman, both in their 30's, were admitted to the emergency room suffering from a Type A subgroup of streptococcus, said Diana Karish, acting vice president of the hospital's nursing division.
Tests showed the man suffered from necrotizing fasciitis, which at its most virulent can destroy flesh.
He remained in critical condition, Mrs. Karish said.
The female patient, suffering from pyomyositis, which can destroy muscle tissue, was in satisfactory condition.
Both patients were being treated with antibiotics, Mrs. Karish said.
Neither of the patients was identified.
Mrs. Karish said that the patients had come to the emergency room at separate times last week and that their illnesses did not appear to be related.
Common Bacteria "There is no reason for the public to be alarmed," Mrs. Karish said. "
Remember, it's a common bacteria.
GREEN DAY FORFEITED ANY underground cachet when its third album, "Dookie," sold 10 million copies worldwide over the last year.
There's no way the three-man band from the San Francisco Bay Area can act like an underdog when "Insomniac" is released this week to salivating radio stations and retailers.
Right now, the world is its mosh pit.
Along with fellow California punk-rock bands like the Offspring and Rancid, Green Day has carried late-breaking 1970's punk to a mass public.

Green Day plays by-the-book punk rock, true to the Ramones' circa-1976 blueprint: catchy ditties about alienation, resentment and self-destructive kicks, driven by speed-strummed guitars and walloping drums.
The songs blare for two or three minutes and stop dead; on "Insomniac," 14 of them, including one that slows down to something like a heavy-metal tempo, blast by in just under 33 minutes.
Green Day has also, like the Ramones, made its albums nearly interchangeable, beyond variations in the sound mix and the lyrics.
But with its 1970's-punk purism, Green Day has made punk rock a matter of fulfilling expectations, not shattering them.
To some longtime punk fans, Green Day is suspect, or worse, by the mere fact of its popularity; those fans, like Groucho Marx, would never join any club that would accept them.
Yet Green Day has fulfilled a not-so-secret ambition of New York's punk originals: to rule the pop charts while making nose-thumbing music.
EVEN in an age of terror, I find it hard to muster a fear of flying.
In the abstract, I know I ought to be afraid.
But for too many years, the air was my element -- a carefree place of glorious freedom.
It was the ground I feared: The moment I stepped off the plane I would start to sweat as I walked toward the uncontrollable, the unknown.
On landing, I became a marked man.
I traveled on a South African passport throughout the 1980's, the years in which opposition to apartheid ballooned into a global cause.
In many countries, handing my passport to an immigration official guaranteed me the kind of welcome ordinarily reserved for someone who announces: ''Hello.
I'm a refugee.
I want to live in your country.''
My love of travel was perverse for somebody shackled to one of the world's most immobilizing passports.
SCOTT LEE is long and skinny, just like the duplex railroad apartment he has lived in for 30 years.
The apartment's 10-foot ceilings make it higher than it is wide, with much more wall space than floor space.
The front room, with two windows on the street, spans nine feet, wall to wall.
About 50 feet and three rooms back, the seven-foot-wide rear wall is barely able to contain a loft bed.
Mr. Lee, who is six feet tall and weighs 146 pounds, can hold out his arms and nearly touch both sides of his bedroom at the same time.
But for Mr. Lee, 56, the beauty of this Chelsea apartment, which he shares with his wife, Sue Anne, 51, and their 10-year-old daughter, is in its depths.
Their tiny living-dining room has a table, a loveseat and a ladder that leads through a hatchway to a subterranean space where the uninitiated might imagine rats scampering freely.
Mr. Lee knows better.
He plays bass for a living, and he likes climbing down there to make noise.
The various people he rehearses with can drag their instruments in from the street through an exterior doorway that's down a flight of stairs from the sidewalk, well below grade.

There are a lot of reasons to be positive about the outlook for tax-exempt municipal bonds, including the prospect of a decline next year in new issues, which reduces supply, and a jump in Federal tax rates, which makes tax-exempt securities even more attractive.
But analysts warn that there is also an issue to worry about: credit quality. "

The quality of municipal risk has been deteriorating because of the deteriorating condition of state and local governments," said Peter B. Coffin, a senior vice president and municipal bond portfolio manager at Massachusetts Financial Services in Boston. "
You simply cannot take it for granted that because it is a municipal bond you are going to get paid."

William T. Reynolds, director of the municipal bond division at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore, said the yield spread between bonds with top credit ratings and those with medium ratings was narrow "and can only widen in the next few years."
The credit problem has several facets.

One is seen in Brevard County, Fla., the home not only of Cape Canaveral but also of a taxpayer revolt that could lead the county to refuse to pay the interest and principal on bonds, called certificates of participation, that it used to finance a county office building.

Possibly Widespread Impact The impact of such a refusal could be felt well beyond Brevard County because this is not a case of being unable to pay; the county has the money, but may refuse to pay because it is caught in a political battle.

Another site of concern is California, where the state's fiscal problems, which led to a prolonged budget crisis this year, are expected to continue, resulting in a further downgrading of the state's credit ratings.

A third area is hospital bonds, especially for big city hospitals, whose credit quality could be damaged by cost-containment programs that will accompany President-elect Bill Clinton's effort to revamp the American health-care system.
DEAR DIARY: This is a tale of two cities.
At the age of 3, I made my entry into Manhattan when my mother moved back from California.
I spent the next 15 years living in poverty in a rooming house.
This gave me the opportunity, as a young impressionable lad, to explore Gotham on foot.
One day en route to Central Park, when I was 10 years old, I saw a large black limousine pulling up in front of a Park Avenue hotel.
The uniformed doorman threw open the door, saluted and welcomed a distinguished looking man in a dark suit carrying a briefcase.
When the door of the hotel closed, I was left marveling at what wonders awaited this person who disappeared under a sparkling crystal chandelier.
Forty years later, I was in Paris on a business trip, and my large black limousine pulled up in front of the Hotel Ritz.
A uniformed doorman saluted as he opened the car door.
Clutching my briefcase, I noticed out of the corner of my eye a small boy staring at me in much the same way I, as a young boy, had stared outside the Manhattan hotel.

With more than 30 players in a Giants uniform for the first time, including nine new starters, the Giants' opening preseason game Friday night is far more than the first round in the celebrated competition between quarterbacks Kurt Warner and Eli Manning.
Coach Tom Coughlin has revamped the team at several positions, and although many auditions for jobs will involve new names for Giants fans, the most significant tryout will not.
That is because Friday night's game at Giants Stadium against the Kansas City Chiefs is Stage 1 in the latest, and last, chance the Giants will be giving running back Ron Dayne.
The Giants' top draft pick four years ago, Dayne has been Coughlin's primary reclamation project this summer.
He pointedly referred to Dayne, who did not dress for a single game when Jim Fassel was the coach last season, as a key to the team in his first speech as Giants coach in January.
And since training camp opened in July, Coughlin has made sure that Dayne is a featured part of every practice.
It is a near certainty that Dayne, a Heisman Trophy winner who is in the last year of his contract, will have dozens of opportunities to carry the football throughout the preseason.
Tiki Barber, the leading rusher on the team every season since 2000, said last week that he would not be shocked if Dayne ultimately led the team in carries in 2004.
Dayne and the Giants have been through this dance before, in 2001, 2002 and to a lesser extent in 2003.
The focus has usually been Dayne's weight, and with good reason.
Associations between the structural logic of Bach's music and notions of the mystical perfection of nature may be fanciful and romantic, but many a writer has made this poetic link.
Others have offered a more rationalist view of Bach and nature as polar opposites, the music's supreme artifice and intellectual rigor contrasting starkly with nature's randomness and chaos.

Listening to Tsuyoshi Tsutsumi play three of Bach's Suites for Unaccompanied Cello here in a rustic, barnlike concert hall that was partially open to the wooded countryside, it seemed not to matter which model was correct.
The salient point was that whether they are counterparts or antitheses, Bach and nature have a peculiar way of enhancing each other.

Mr. Tsutsumi, a Japanese cellist who won the International Casals Competition in Budapest in 1963 and is on the faculty of Indiana University, played the odd-numbered Suites on Saturday evening and returned on Sunday to round out the set.
He was the guest of Maverick Concerts, a series that was started here in 1916 by Hervey White, a poet and novelist who dreamed of turning his farm into an arts center.
Maverick's concert hall, which was restored in 1977, has retained its rough-hewn character, and it boasts fine acoustics despite its open back.
It has also seen plenty of history.
Portraits of soloists and chamber groups from decades past hang on its walls, and it was for a Maverick concert that John Cage composed his silent ''4'33'' '' in 1962.

Accounts of that work's first performances note that nature took a hand, filling the silence of the premiere with the sound of rustling wind and lending the patter of rain to the next day's presentation.
On the first day of the baseball players strike, with more than 700 major leaguers scattering to all parts of the country and beyond, negotiators for the players and owners did not rest yesterday.
But they also did not, in a two-hour bargaining session, close the gulf that separates them and imperils the remainder of the season.

Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, and Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, did agree on one matter: They accepted an offer of assistance from the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. "
I don't know whether they're going to be any help or not, but at this point no harm can be done and maybe some good will come of it," Fehr said at a news conference.

Ravitch voiced a similar thought but added a note of caution, lest anyone think that mediators will perform a miracle and jump-start the season by solving the dispute, which centers on the the owners' demand for cost control by putting a limit on player payrolls. "
At this point," he said, "until the union tells us what they want to get paid, it's going to be hard to make progress."
Fehr and Ravitch expect to meet separately with representatives of the mediation service today.
The service's function is to facilitate an effort to reach agreement.

The representatives will listen to each side's position, assess each, determine how seriously separated the players and owners are in their efforts to forge a new collective bargaining agreement and then decide how to proceed.
Meanwhile, schedules of games will be wiped out on a wholesale basis.
The House has passed a much-needed minimum-wage increase of $1 over two years, but the bill is fatally tainted by $123 billion in tax cuts that mostly benefit the wealthy.
President Clinton has vowed to veto the bill unless Congress strips away  the tax cuts.
Republican leaders have resisted increasing the minimum wage, which at $5.15 an hour is well below its buying power in 1980.
But now they have modified their game plan, trying instead to hold a wage increase hostage for tax breaks for high-income individuals.
The Republicans claim that the tax cuts  are intended to help small businesses, which would have to pay their lowest-wage workers more.
But in fact, more than $78 billion of the tax cuts over 10 years comes from reductions in estate and gift taxes.
Only $19 billion of the cuts counts as small-business tax relief, according to the Joint Committee on Taxation.
Other provisions in the bill could reduce employer-paid pension coverage for low-paid workers.
Citizens for Tax Justice, a liberal research group, estimates that nearly 90 percent of the tax benefits would go to the wealthiest 5 percent of taxpayers.
The House bill will now have to be reconciled with a Senate bill that raised the minimum wage by $1 over three years and included an equally objectionable, though smaller, package of tax cuts.
TED BLEW, who owns Oak Grove Plantation in Hunterdon County, N.J., with his wife, Susan Blew, did not mince words. ''
This is the worst year in 45 years,'' he said. ''
There was a tough, cold winter.
Then the rain started and didn't stop for a month.
Everything now is two to three weeks late.''
Most of his income comes from selling his tomatoes, peppers, squash and melons at New York City's Greenmarkets, and he estimates that he'll lose 55 percent of it.
His litany continued.
Greenhouse costs have tripled because of the cold and a rise in fuel prices; he had to replant some fields because of the rain, and simply abandoned planting others. ''
Once the pestilence sets in, it doesn't give up,'' he said.

THE CLAIM -- Pricking a stroke victim's fingers can help delay symptoms.
THE FACTS -- A recent, widely circulated e-mail message proposes an unusual way to help the victim of a stroke. ''
Help the victim sit up to prevent him from falling over,'' the message states. ''
Then sterilize a needle and use it to prick the tip of the person's finger.
After a few minutes, the victim should regain consciousness.''
The message says that doing this somehow relieves blood pressure and eases symptoms.
Like most medical advice dispensed in the form of a chain e-mail message, it has no scientific basis.
In fact, following its advice can do harm.
Forcing a stroke victim to sit up is never a good idea, because it can cause a drop in blood pressure, says Dr. Larry B. Goldstein, director of the Duke Stroke Center.
It would be better to help the person lie down.

When it happens, we're going to be delighted," said Morris (18-12). "
We'll take it, whether it means another victory from us or a Chicago loss.
Whichever way it happens first.

LEAD: Christie's in New York will auction the largest number and greatest variety of early American bank notes ever offered starting on Friday at 10 A.M. The auction will continue through the afternoon and evening.

The second half of the auction will start at 10 A.M. Saturday and will continue that afternoon at 2 P From the beginning of the 19th century until 1861 when the United States Government took responsiblity, all bank notes were printed privately and the number of banks was astronomical.
There were banks for farmers, for whalers, for machinists and for chemical manufacturers.
Most towns had their own banks, each with a uniquely designed bank note.
The designs often tried to portray some peculiar trait of the bank or the town.
Banks in agricultural areas depicted pastoral scenes.
Banks that courted manufacturers showed factory machines.
Paterson, N. J., which billed itself as the Cataract City, showed waterfalls on its notes.
Bridgeport, Conn., portrayed P.T. Barnum, a resident, and Jenny Lind on notes of the Pequonnock Bank.
Some towns got a little carried away.
To the Editor: Zoe Baird was not sponsoring her Peruvian household workers for citizenship.
An applicant for citizenship is already a permanent resident of the United States and thus entitled to work.
She was sponsoring them for legal permanent residence.

If Ms. Baird had obtained a certification from the Department of Labor, she would have had to advertise the position in a newspaper and found no willing or qualified worker, thus establishing a shortage of these workers.
Why not permit employment at this stage and reflect the reality facing two-income families who need a live-in nanny?
Congress should take another look at these regulations and permit a worker whose job has been determined not to displace a United States worker to obtain work authorization.
In most of these cases if the United States employer waits until the alien obtains a green card.
the children have grown up and no longer need a nanny's services.
This is a law in need of change.
TANIA M. ALVAREZ  San Francisco, Jan. 29, 1993 The writer is an immigration lawyer.
From the air, the lush forest of northern Colombia looks endless and serene.
It is broken only by a wide strip of prairie, slashed from the jungle by my grandfather more than 50 years ago, stretching out to a blue backbone of hills.
The only other signs of civilization are a reservoir, a few head of grazing cattle and some glinting rooftops made of zinc.
For the most part, the forest stretches like a great, green shroud, concealing a civil war that has raged beneath the canopy for years and years.
The pilot circles a few times and then settles into his approach to an airstrip that is nothing more than a narrow dirt path surrounded by high grass.
Security has been arranged.
Two jeeps, four motorcycles and a dozen men, some wearing camouflage, await our landing.
Stepping out of the plane, I pass four young men in military uniform holding semiautomatic rifles and carrying grenades in their vest pockets.
The soldiers are just 4 of 35 the army has provided me and my uncle, Hernan, for the day's visit.
As landowners, we can request such protection because the guerrillas have declared us ''enemies of the people'' who must pay ''a peace tax'' or face being ''retained,'' which means kidnapped.

Congressional support for the embattled Stealth bomber eroded further today as the radar-eluding aircraft only narrowly survived an effort in the Senate to cancel the program.
In the B-2's closest call with termination, the Senate voted 51 to 48 against an amendment to limit production of the bat-winged plane to the 15 aircraft Congress has already ordered.
The Senate last month defeated the same measure, but by vote of 57 to 42.
The same measure received only 29 votes in favor in 1989.
The narrowing margin of support for the B-2 in the Senate is important because the House of Representatives has already voted to cancel the program.
The Senate supports the Bush Administration's request to buy four B-2's in the 1992 fiscal year, at $865 million a plane.

Today's vote, on an amendment to the military spending bill for fiscal 1992, is likely to damage the bargaining position of Senate negotiators who are trying to reconcile their differences with their House counterparts on the B-2 and other programs in the military budget bill -- the legislation that authorizes the military what to spend.

Already imperiled by its steep price tag and a seemingly obsolete primary mission to drop nuclear bombs on the Soviet Union, the B-2 has recently been reeling from the Air Force's admission that the plane flunked a trial of its radar-evading cabilities.

Classified Briefings Air Force Secretary Donald B. Rice and other senior Pentagon officials have sought to minimize the flaws as technical growing pains, and have held several classified briefings on Capitol Hill to allay worried Senate supporters.

Today's vote, though, bodes ill for the aircraft in an increasingly uphill battle to justify its existence in a era of budget pressures and easing tensions with the Soviet Union and its breakaway republics. "
Six score and 13 years ago, city fathers here brought forth a new custom, an annual dinner, conceived in sorrow over the assassination of a President and dedicated to his memory.
This year the tradition will continue.
After 133 annual dinners, without ever having missed one, the Lincoln Association of Jersey City will sponsor its 134th dinner on Feb. 12 to mark the birthday of Abraham Lincoln.
And once again it will be able to claim that no other organization has a longer record of annual dinners honoring the 16th President. ''
We don't know of any group that's older,'' said Dennis Doran, the group's historian and a past president. ''
I suppose there have been older ones, but this is the one that has met every year without interruption.''

The group is older, for instance, than the Abraham Lincoln Association in Springfield, Ill., an international organization established in 1908 and situated in the center of Lincolniana where Lincoln practiced law for a quarter-century and served as a state legislator.
There are 750 members in the international group.
As for this city's association, its membership rolls -- like voter registration lists in the halcyon days of Hudson County politics when even the dead could be counted on to vote -- are fluid.
It consists of about 40 officers and trustees who plan the ceremonies, and mostly, says Mr. Doran, anyone who shows up for either the dinner or a memorial service earlier in the day or both.

AS you might imagine, these are heady days at the Pressure Sensitive Tape Council in Northbrook, Ill. As hardware stores around the country experienced runs on duct tape, Glen Anderson, the council's executive vice president, voiced mixed feelings about the tape's sudden summons to national security.
With due respect for the Department of Homeland Security, he said, duct might not be the best tape for the job. ''
Polypropylene tape would be most acceptable,'' Mr. Anderson said. ''
Duct tape will leave a residue, whereas polypropylene will not.''
Duct tape, indispensable to handymen, preppies and drug smugglers, has long been an emblem of American ingenuity and quick fixes.
Now it stands as a marker of national anxiety.
In the course of a day, it went from national security warnings to jokes on late-night television.
On Wednesday Tom Daschle, the Senate minority leader, used the tape as a rhetorical wedge.

Responding to recommendations that people buy duct tape and clear plastic to seal rooms in the event of a terrorist attack, Mr. Daschle said, ''This administration is going to have to do better than that.''
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg cautioned against duct tape hysteria. ''

Italian newspapers have less to say about clothes this week than about bickering among the Milan designers, the elites who for this city carry the combined clout of Washington's politicians, Hollywood's movie stars and Wall Street's Masters of the Universe.
What is being reflected in the sniping is a chasmlike generational shift.
The new success of Prada and Gucci, until recently more renowned for fashionable luggage than for what the fashionable might carry inside, has been a double insult.

Those companies are not only stealing the runway spotlight, customers and magazine editorial pages, but have also done so with a concept deemed "the good taste of bad taste," an embracing of updated 1970's style that makes taste  makers like Giorgio Armani cringe.
Mr. Armani has battled the bad-taste trend in words.
Tonight, he did it in deed.

He has over the last year sounded at times angry, at times embattled and at times just plain cranky about the rise of a new generation of designers who do not look to him for direction, but to England and their childhoods in the late 70's when he was already a rising star of fashion.

But his collection closed the Milan shows with a touching display of strength, finesse, elegance and even acknowledgment that there is a sleek, streamlined mood of men's fashion today that makes his revolutionary soft suits something to leave behind.
In a way, it is as if he had won the war.

The most influential young designers here, Tom Ford at Gucci, Miuccia Prada and Stefano Gabbana and Domenico Dolce, are now sounding a bit like Mr. Armani when they talk about the  need for elegance in men's dressing.

The Nasdaq Composite average finished with a narrow gain of nearly a point, to 698.13, another record.
The Dow Jones transportation average, however, jumped 13.90 points, to 1,520.11, the equivalent of about 30 points for the industrial list.

Despite higher newsprint costs and circulation declines at its large newspapers, The New York Times Company reported third-quarter profits yesterday that exceeded analysts' expectations.
Though net income fell sharply, the company's earnings excluding some one-time gains actually rose 73 percent.

The stronger results, the company said, reflected rising revenues from advertising and circulation that were attributable to higher prices, as well as lower taxes, and newsprint conservation and cost controls.
Net income totaled $32.2 million, or 33 cents a share, compared with $120.6 million, or $1.16 a share, a year ago.

The 1995 results include a pretax gain of $11.3 million from the sale of six small newspapers, while the 1994 results included a pretax gain of $204 million from the sales of the company's Women's Magazines Division and British golf publications.

Excluding those gains, the Times Company said, third-quarter earnings for 1995 would have totaled $27 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with $15.6 million, or 15 cents a share, in the 1994 quarter when more shares were outstanding.
Some analysts had forecast earnings of 20 cents a share or less in the latest quarter.
Revenue for the quarter rose 8.6 percent, to $572.7 million. "
Maybe the worst is over," said Kenneth T. Berents, a newspaper industry analyst at Wheat First Butcher Singer.
But Mr. Berents and other analysts warned that the company's performance would probably be pressed in the fourth quarter because of weakness among retail advertisers in the New York area.

This month for the first time, parents are receiving report cards grading New York City high schools, with consistently high marks going to specialized institutions like Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan and Bronx Science.
Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines is issuing the report cards to show parents how individual schools are doing in areas like standardized test scores, graduation rates and the ability to keep teachers.
Although the information is not meant for comparison, it is clear that some schools are doing better than others.
The Scholastic Assessment Test is one measure of how well students in a particular school are performing.

For example, the reports indicated that the top scorer on the S.A.T. combined verbal and mathematics tests was Stuyvesant High School, followed by the Bronx High School of Science, Townsend Harris High School in Queens, Staten Island Technical High School and Brooklyn Technical High School.
Those schools also ranked among the top 10 for graduation rates.
The reports, for 121 of the city's 167 high schools, contain information from the 1993-94 school year.

Because data is not yet available, reports were not issued for schools that were created in the last year as part of a reform movement toward smaller institutions, said Robert Tobias, director of research for the school system.

Parents receive information related only to their children's school: the reports are intended to help them begin to track how the school is performing from year to year -- not to compare one school to another, school officials said.
It is considered likely, however, that some parents -- especially those with junior high school children preparing to select a high school -- will compare schools.
All airports but Washington's Reagan National have reopened in the aftermath of last week's attack, but commercial aviation in the United States has been forever altered.
The premium is now on security instead of convenience and speed.
That is the only sensible course after hijackers seized control of four passenger planes and turned three of them into weapons of mass destruction.
Few freedoms are as vital to the nation's character, and essential to its economy, as the freedom to travel.
But to ensure that it is preserved, the rules and expectations of flying have to change.
The freedom to wake up in New York and get to San Francisco in time for lunch is going to have to give way to the freedom to get to San Francisco safely, even if it takes all day.
Americans should accept more stringent security not as a short-term inconvenience but as a permanent redefinition of the flying experience.
No longer can passengers expect to arrive at the airport 30 minutes before departure or check in at an automated kiosk that handles security questions the way A.T.M.'s ask if you want a receipt.
The Federal Aviation Administration has banned curbside check-in and will allow only ticketed passengers to go to the gate.
It has called for more uniformed law enforcement agents, individual searches and luggage-matching to ensure that everyone who checks a bag boards the flight.

A decline in drug, food and retail prices helped to push the Dow Jones industrial average down 1.68 points, to 3,566.02.

Analysts said that much of the trading was "window dressing" -- a traditional end-of-quarter technique involving the sprucing up of portfolios to make them appear more attractive to investors.
Among the news events noted by traders was a report from the Conference Board that consumer confidence improved slightly in September, but the overall level of confidence continues to be fragile.

To the Editor: John Rocker was in town for the first time after expressing negative stereotypes about New Yorkers Sports pages, July 3.
Officials feared that there would be violence.
But you can count on New Yorkers to offer the right response.
Shea Stadium was filled with placards and chants to tell Rocker, and others like him, how wrong he is.
The weekend ended with the arrest of Gregory Sweeney for throwing back a ball that Rocker tossed into the stands.

Jim Abbott is pondering the next baseball season with the Yankees, and change is central to his thoughts.

He is discussing changing his attitude and approach, changing his address from the city to the suburbs, trying to change his frustrating struggles with the strike zone and getting friendlier with his changeup.
Actually, Abbott does not want to change his attitude as much as he wants to refine it.
He is an intense pitcher who has conceded he sometimes lets a misplaced cut fastball, a meager hit or a critical newspaper article upset him for hours or even days.
The altered Abbott does not want those worries.

After observing the unflappable Jimmy Key last year, remembering how Marcel Lachemann, his pitching coach with California, recommended that he be easier on himself, and hearing similar suggestions from the Yankees, Abbott has decided to change.
He wants to avoid being caught in self-imposed mental headlocks.

A Different Approach "That's one of the things I'm working on, not being hard on myself," said Abbott in a recent telephone interview from his home in Newport Beach, Calif. "I used to wear that as a badge of courage.
You should be hard on yourself.
That's what got you here.

But the police, intervening Wednesday night for the first time in response to requests from college administrators, ended occupations at the New York City Technical College in downtown Brooklyn and at Bronx Community College in the University Heights section.
No arrests were made as the students left peacefully, the police said.
Yesterday, however, the protesters at Bronx Community College reoccupied the main classroom building, Colston Hall.
3 School Suspend Classes Hostos Community College joined City College and Borough of Manhattan Community College in suspending classes as students barricaded themselves inside buildings.
At Lehman College in the Bronx, student protesters reclaimed Carman Hall, the main classroom building, which they had seized and then given up on Tuesday.

New York landmarks are born at 1 Centre Street, home to the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
But preservation itself, staving off the effects of time and ignorance, falls to a grass-roots army of watchful neighbors and civic groups.
The process may be cheap, but some suggest it is flawed. ''
There is only so much enforcement the civics can do,'' said Simeon Bankoff, executive director of the Historic Districts Council. ''
A huge number of small violations of the landmarks law happen constantly, which result in a slow eating away of the historic character of areas.''
Mark Silberman, the Landmarks Preservation Commission's general counsel, said: ''For the most part the system works very well, especially for those communities where citizens are very involved.
Sure we could use more inspectors.
However, given the city's fiscal situation, I don't foresee more inspectors being hired in the near future.''

For most of its history, the commission had no effective means of enforcing the landmarks law, which dictates that property owners must receive the commission's approval before making exterior alterations to a historic building.
In 1998, the law was amended, giving the commission the power to fine violators.
On some days, "when people shake my hand and think they'll glow in the dark," John Weingart does not feel very loved.
On other days, when his office phone doesn't ring, he seems as lonely as the Maytag repairman.
What makes the responses -- or lack of them -- so odd is that Mr. Weingart has millions of dollars to give away.
The catch is that he will give it only to a community that agrees to become  home to a storage site for low-level radioactive waste for the next century.
Almost every state has someone on a mission like Mr. Weingart's.

The goal is  a particularly hard sell in New Jersey, New York and the rest of the Northeast,  where dense populations give pause to those being asked to play host to a well-heeled but radioactive guest for 100 years.

Federal law makes each state responsible for the safe disposal of low-level radioactive waste -- materials like clothes and equipment exposed to radioactivity at nuclear power plants, hospitals and research institutions.
The  category does not include more dangerous material, like spent fuel rods from the cores of nuclear reactors.

Low-level wastes from the Northeast and elsewhere used to be shipped to Barnwell, S.C. Last year, that storage site was closed to all states outside seven in the Southeast, but reopened this year, for a maximum of 10 years, with  stiff new surcharges imposed on shipments. "

A lot of generators of low-level waste have resumed shipments to Barnwell, but it's not a long-term solution," said Mr. Weingart, a former assistant commissioner in the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection and Energy who is the director of the State Low-Level Radioactive Waste Disposal Facility Siting Board. "
To the Editor: I read your Oct. 7 installment of "The Good Mother" series, on family leave, with anger.
I am sick and tired of the problems we face as women.
Economically, politically and socially we mothers are damned if we do and damned if we don't hold jobs outside the home.
When I was a young mother in the 1970's, many of us could still stay home with the kids -- one paycheck could maintain the basics.
Less than 20 years later most mothers must work outside the home.
Yet we are made to feel selfish and inadequate by politicians and so-called "men of God."

What is wrong with a society and an economic system that punishes women and their children by forcing mothers to go into the workplace, work a 40-hour week, come home and then with minimal male assistance, conduct the work required at home?
What kind of a society are we that we require most women to return to work six weeks after the birth of a child?
What kind of family values do we really hold as a society?
It now generally takes two incomes to support a family.
The rocky road to the Triple Crown tripped another candidate yesterday when the colt Three Peat was withdrawn from Saturday's Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct after developing a cough. "
He's on antibiotics," said John Sadler, who trains the horse for Gary Biszantz of California. "
He started coughing after Monday's workout.
But he jogged today, and we'll keep giving him light exercises for a couple of days and see how he is.
We're greatly disappointed to miss the Gotham.
Depending on how he responds, we'll see if he can come back in the Wood."
The Wood Memorial, two weeks from Saturday, is one of the last major stepping stones to the Kentucky Derby on May 2.
But it seemed certain that Three Peat would skip the Derby, in any event, and aim instead for the Preakness Stakes on May 16.
The colt has raced only three times, but he has won twice and missed by half a length the other time.
And in the Bay Shore Stakes two weeks ago, he zipped seven furlongs in 1:213/5 for the third-fastest time in the history of the race.
Karen Graham, 'The Thief'  Danspace Project It's not often that a dance appears designed for bookworms and librarians.
But such a piece was ''The Thief,'' which Karen Graham presented on Thursday night as part of the Danspace Project's City/Dans series.
Ms. Graham, who provided both the choreography and a text, sometimes ran restlessly about.
At other times she perched atop an enormous pile of books.

The other performers (Emily Coates, Allyson Green, Charlotte Griffin and Dan Illian) lugged books, dropped them and restacked them while uttering repetitive and deliberately enigmatic statements about a search for something unspecified though clearly important.
As they moved to a score by Geoff Gersh, which combined taped sounds with live guitar music played by the composer, they occasionally took books from one another.
Ms. Graham grabbed some of the books, as if she were a thief of other people's ideas.
Sometimes everyone turned so introspective that ''The Thief'' threatened to become uncommunicative.
Yet everyone moved and spoke well.
And at its best Ms. Graham's ever-changing choreography suggested the twists and turns of thought.
LEAD: To the Editor: To the Editor: ''Waiting for the Big One,'' Tom Wicker's Oct. 20 column on California earthquakes, succinctly describes the infrastructure problems in the United States.
All one need do is drive from New York City to Connecticut to experience the full extent of the highway mess our Federal, state and local governments have given the public.
We have allowed our highways to approach the condition of those in third world countries.
The arteries in and out of New York City are not only a disgrace, but also life threatening to their users.
In addition to the uneven, potholed road surface, the absence of lights along these major highways is a real hazard.
Interstate 95 is a prime example.
In inclement weather or simply dark nights, the road condition is exacerbated by awkwardly marked road work and construction.
Add to this speeding behemoth trucks, piloted by tailgating drivers, emboldened by the absence of highway patrols, and you have potential tragedy.
Having just returned from an extensive driving trip in Europe, I have experienced a contrast to our highways that is a glaring indictment.
The eroding ability of this country to compete in an ever-more-competitive world is increased by infrastructure rot.

More than 10 weeks after the start of the fiscal year, Congress and the Clinton administration are poised to finish the government's $600 billion annual spending plan, but the White House and a powerful Alaska senator squared off today for one more fight -- over sea lions.
House and Senate leaders said they expected to approve the final spending bill on Friday, clearing the way for adjournment of the 106th Congress.
Most of the disagreements melted away today.

Representative C. W. Bill Young, the Florida Republican who is chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, said, ''We are pleased to have reached agreement with House and Senate Republicans and Democrats, as well as the administration, on a final appropriations package.''

But the Alaska senator, Ted Stevens, a Republican who is chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, was holding out for legislation that would ease restrictions on how much pollock and cod could be harvested from Alaskan waters by commercial fishermen.
White House officials said such fishing threatened the food supply of the Steller sea lion, an endangered species.
The sea lions, which can be 10 feet long and weigh up to a ton, need enormous amounts of food because they are so huge.
Mr. Stevens demanded that the final budget agreement block new restrictions on fishing proposed by the Clinton administration.
In effect, he said, Alaskans need jobs on trawlers more than sea lions need a few more cod.
Angrily pounding his desk on the Senate floor, Mr. Stevens denounced the administration's plan. ''

Jerry Bergonzi  ''Tenorist''  (Savant Records) A strange development in jazz over the last 30 years has been that many of its players with the most actual, documented influence on other players aren't that well known to the larger world.
They are usually teachers in New York or Boston and authors of books on harmonic theory.
An axiom of the American respect for show business is that one's reputation as a great teacher can hinder one's reputation as a great player.
The tenor saxophonist Jerry Bergonzi, who has written seven volumes of an influential series called ''Inside Improvisation'' and -- but? --
is a masterly improviser himself, could serve as the prime example.
Since the early '80s he has made a lot of decent records for tiny labels that might have been great with some extra attention or with top-of-the-heap rhythm sections.
But as the years go by, as he grows more profound and as his circle of collaborators remains close, a Jerry Bergonzi record is becoming a more desirable thing. ''
Tenorist'' is a casually great jazz record.

Made with the guitarist John Abercrombie, the bassist Dave Santoro and the drummer Adam Nussbaum -- all longtime collaborators -- it refers constantly to older models but doesn't beat you up with them; there's no harrumph or anxiety anywhere.
Even in the record's original pieces Mr. Bergonzi has taken in the language of John Coltrane, Dexter Gordon, Sonny Rollins, Joe Henderson and Warne Marsh.
Eugenia Lynn Giordano and Charles Axel Poekel Jr. were married yesterday in Manhattan.
The Rev. Andrew St. John officiated at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, with the Rev. Herbert M. Groce Jr., a priest of the Anglican Province of America, taking part.
Mrs. Poekel, 58, is a founder and the chief creative officer of Gotham Inc., a Manhattan advertising agency, which is part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
She graduated from the University of Wisconsin.
She is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Giordano of Southern Pines, N.C. The bride's father retired as the sales manager at R. W. Sidley, a construction materials company in Painesville, Ohio.
Her mother, Eugenia S. Giordano, owned My Lady Shoppe, a rdress store in Brecksville, Ohio.
Mr. Poekel, also 58, is the director of legal services at Local 74 of the Service Employees International Union in Long Island City, Queens.

He is a trustee of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York, the organization that owns the Fraunces Tavern Museum in Manhattan, and the author of ''West Essex'' in the Images of America series (Arcadia Publishing Company, 1999).
He graduated from George Washington and received his law degree from American University.
He is the son of Mr. Poekel Sr.
Unless Mike Piazza's fractured left big toe heals enough to allow him to catch on Sunday, Piazza is very likely to skip Tuesday's All-Star Game in Seattle.
Piazza was elected to start for the National League, but the Mets do not want him to go to the game if he is not on the active roster.
There is only one other catcher on the roster, Florida's Charles Johnson, and Mets Manager Bobby Valentine, who will manage the team, said Johnson will not catch nine innings.
He also will not ask a former catcher such as San Diego's Phil Nevin to catch in the game.
So, unless another player comes down with an injury, Piazza will probably be kept off the roster if he is unable to catch.
The N.L. would add a reserve catcher, eliminating the possibility of Piazza starting at designated hitter.
Valentine discussed the situation with league officials yesterday and said the N.L. will not add a 31st player to the roster. ''
We're not trying to keep him out of the All-Star Game,'' Mets General Manager Steve Phillips said. ''
I'd like him to go and participate in any fashion he can.
But if he can't play and they're going to replace him, our preference would be that he stay and take three days to get the toe ready.''
Phoenix defenseman Ossi Vaananen spun around in disbelief and looked for a teammate, as if he needed someone to verify what he had just done.
Defensemen do not usually beat stingy goaltenders with slap shots from the blue line with five minutes to go in a game.
These were the no-luck Islanders that the Coyotes played tonight, and the Islanders are always finding new and interesting ways to lose.

Less than two minutes after Vaananen scored, Trevor Letowski beat Islanders goalie John Vanbiesbrouck again, and Phoenix held on for a 2-1 victory that would be hard to believe were the opponent not the Islanders. ''
I don't even know what to say anymore,'' Islanders center Dave Scatchard said. ''
I'm just really frustrated right now.''
This frustration might take a while to melt away.
Mariusz Czerkawski, who scored the Islanders' goal, was asked how a team that has won 6 of its past 30 games could rummage up any confidence. ''
It's not easy, to be honest with you,'' he said.
The Islanders (11-23-4-2) outshot Phoenix by 28-24, outhit the Coyotes and had more power-play chances, but they still lost their fourth game in a row and seventh in eight games.

A Brooklyn man who punched his former girlfriend in the face after his release from jail by a judge who has since come under fire for his handling of domestic violence cases has pleaded guilty to assault.

Maximo Pena, 35, faces at least eight years in prison on assault and criminal contempt charges after admitting in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Monday that he had burst into the apartment of Evelyn Molina on Feb. 15, dragged her down two flights of stairs and hit and kicked her.
The Pena case came to light after Judge Lorin Duckman of Brooklyn Criminal Court was criticized earlier this year for his handling of a domestic violence case that had ended in murder.

In that case, Judge Duckman had freed a convicted rapist with a history of domestic violence, who then killed his former girlfriend, Galina Komar of Brooklyn, at a Queens car dealership on Feb. 12, and turned the gun on himself.
The slaying occurred three weeks after she had sought protection from the courts.
Judge Duckman has been reassigned to Manhattan Civil Court.
Mr. Pena was convicted last July of 11 counts of attacking and harassing his  former girlfriend, including hitting her over the head with a bottle.

But moments after the jury verdict, Judge Duckman said that the 41 days that Mr. Pena had spent in jail before his trial were enough, according to people familiar with the case who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Mr. Pena's bail was reduced to $750, from $1,000, and he posted bond within hours of his conviction.
Five weeks later, Judge Duckman denied a request by prosecutors to send Mr. Pena to prison for two years.
The General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday that it would shift its headquarters from St. Louis to the Washington area, a move that is likely to cost St. Louis more prestige than dollars.
The company, the nation's second-largest military contractor, said the decision made sense in light of the heightened competition among contractors as the Pentagon cuts costs.
While no specific location has been determined, the company said it was considering sites in suburban Virginia and Maryland. "

With the end of the cold war and increasing pressure on the Federal budget, the defense industry of the future will be characterized by reduced Government spending and increased competition," said William A. Anders, the chairman. "
Consequently, we believe that the company can operate more effectively by having our headquarters and our leadership closer to our principal customers and policy makers."
The change comes amid considerable strife for General Dynamics and for the miltary industry.
Last year, General Dynamics lost $578 million, or $13.86 a share, on revenues of $10.2 billion after taking a $700 million charge on the A-12 Avenger attack plane, which was canceled by the Navy.
The move, to be completed by the fall, will affect a small number of the company's 90,000 employees.
About 275 people work in the St. Louis headquarters, with only 115 to be transferred.
Thirty people will stay in St. Louis, General Dynamics said, and the rest are being encouraged to remain during the transition.
Why, it's all Japan's fault, barks Chrysler's chairman, Lee Iacocca.
Fresh from President Bush's dismal trip to Tokyo, he insists that "We do not have idiots running General Motors, Ford and Chrysler, or our suppliers.
And our workers are not lazy and stupid."
Detroit has declined, he says, because of unfair Japanese trade practices and "insidious Japanese economic and political power within the United States."
These accusations are worse than wrong.
They're reckless.
For someone so well known to make them is to incite chauvinism, even xenophobia.
Something is wrong in Detroit, and for Mr. Iacocca to blast Japan is to dodge his, and his industry's, shortcomings.

The next stage of irresponsibility will be new calls for protectionist legislation -- some has already been proposed by members of Congress from Michigan -- that would rescue Detroit by making U.S. customers pay more for cars, and by destroying jobs in U.S. export industries like agriculture and computers.
Mr. Iacocca is right that the problem is not inept workers.
Mark McClellan, a physician and health economist, announced his resignation this week as head of the agency that oversees Medicare and Medicaid.
He will be missed.
As a pragmatic expert embedded in a fiercely ideological administration, he brought uncommon intelligence, good humor and dispassionate judgment to politically charged issues.
True, there were blemishes on his record.

As head of the Food and Drug Administration from late 2002 to early 2004, he oversaw the agency's first postponement of a decision on whether to make the controversial morning-after contraceptive available without a prescription.
This led to a prolonged effort by the administration to placate religious conservatives by keeping the pills restricted despite overwhelming evidence that they are safe.

Then, as administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services since March 2004, he failed to anticipate the administrative glitches that marred the beginnings of the new Medicare prescription drug program.
Tens of thousands of people were initially overcharged or unable to obtain essential medicines quickly.
But Dr. McClellan stepped in to solve the problems and seems mostly to have succeeded.
A June poll showed that 80 percent of those enrolled in a Medicare drug plan said they were satisfied with it.

A day after disclosing plans for an overhaul of the Coca-Cola Company to make sure minorities and women are promoted and paid fairly, plaintiffs' lawyers and company officials said many of the details were still unclear and cautioned that tangible results could be a long way off. ''
You can plant the seeds today, but you may not see the fruits for a couple of years,'' said Coretha M. Rushing, a senior vice president for human resources.
On Thursday, the two parties announced a record-breaking settlement, valued at more than $192 million, to resolve a 1999 federal discrimination lawsuit filed by black employees at Coke.

Beyond a cash award of $113 million, to be divided up among roughly 2,000 current and former employees and their lawyers, the settlement calls for a panel of outsiders to spend the next four years monitoring Coke's treatment of women and minorities.
To the plaintiffs, the panel was nothing short of a coup.
Only once before has a company agreed to relinquish oversight of its methods of evaluating, compensating and promoting employees.
And that was in the Texaco settlement in 1996, a case in which plaintiffs caught executives shredding legal documents and making derogatory racial comments on tape.
As in the Texaco settlement, the Coke panel will have seven members: three appointed by the plaintiffs, three by the company and a chairman agreed on by both parties.
Neither Coke nor the plaintiffs' lawyers have disclosed whom they will appoint to the panel, which may not be convened for several months.
But plaintiffs' lawyers have indicated a desire to name civil rights and labor leaders, while Coke is leaning toward business experts and human resources specialists.

After a week of chaos in the streets, the competing rowdy demonstrations and the violence that have paralyzed the capital began to take on a ritual flavor today as postelection maneuvers moved toward the bargaining table.

More than 10,000 highly organized pro-Government marchers filled the streets in the morning, chanting obediently at the orders of men with bullhorns and escorted by armed and helmeted security forces.

In the afternoon the opposition demonstrators, whom the pro-Government marchers have been mimicking, paraded around the central market, their numbers swelled to more than 5,000 by bystanders, until  police officers fired automatic weapons in the air to disperse them.
There was a degree of stone throwing, clubbing and shooting, and at least one man was reported to have been shot in the leg.
But by the standards of the last week, today was not a violent day.

With a round of meetings among political leaders scheduled for this week, King Norodom Sihanouk issued a statement suffused with weary pragmatism that supported the victory of the country's strongman, Hun Sen, in the parliamentary election on July 26. ''

In a Cambodia that is not a state of law and not a fully fledged democracy, I have no other choice than to advise the weak to choose a policy that avoids misfortune for the people, the motherland and themselves,'' he said.

It was a call to his son Prince Norodom Ranariddh and to the other opposition leader, Sam Rainsy, to  accept the election results and to reach an accommodation with Mr. Hun Sen. The new Parliament is to convene  on Sept. 24.
The two challengers have vowed to boycott it, contending that fraud and intimidation skewed the election.
Although Mr. Hun Sen's party won the most seats, it needs to form a coalition with the Prince's royalist party to reach the two-thirds majority needed to form a Government.

The Sony Corporation earned plaudits, from us among others, for putting life into the barren space at the base of its U.S. headquarters building, the former home of AT&T on Madison Avenue in New York City.
But the Sony-fication of this atrium has become overwhelming.

No one says Sony Plaza is violating city regulations, but it hardly fits the spirit of open spaces that builders create in exchange for a permit to build higher -- spaces where people can escape the hustle of city commerce.
A recent lunchtime stroller found a striking contrast of glitz and tranquillity in Sony's neighborhood.
I.B.M.'s large plaza, wrapped in glass, lies directly across the street.
In a setting of bamboo trees it offers chairs, tables, a food stand, a garden shop, an entrance to a department store -- and stillness.
In Park Avenue Plaza, two blocks south, Chuck Folds played light music on a grand piano.
And then there is Lever House, the model for modern open spaces on private property.
Its glass enclosure was filled with schoolchildren's art, and the outdoor plaza with New Yorkers soaking up sun.
Sony Plaza has tables, chairs, food and trees too, and entrances to two Sony retail showrooms.
Fernando Londono, the outspoken and contentious interior and justice minister who has frequently clashed with Congress, resigned Thursday after making remarks disavowed by President Alvaro Uribe.
Mr. Londono had been under pressure to resign after a complicated, 15-part referendum that would have given the president more fiscal powers failed in an Oct. 25 national vote.

On Wednesday, Mr. Londono prompted nationwide consternation when he told Conservative Party congressmen that Mr. Uribe might quit and call early elections if they did not support the president's fiscal reforms. ''
This political crisis cannot be resolved, I think, without extreme options that the president has considered, including anticipating elections,'' Mr. Londono told lawmakers.
Mr. Uribe quickly contradicted Mr. Londono, saying that he planned to ''work day and night'' until his four-year term ends in 2006.
Mr. Londono later retracted his comments, but the gaffe prompted Colombia's peso to fall temporarily and stunned millions of Colombians who strongly support Mr. Uribe.
On Thursday, with reporters accosting him outside the presidential palace, Mr. Londono said: ''I resigned my position.''
The president, who won election 15 months ago after pledging to battle Marxist rebels aggressively, enjoys at least a 70 percent approval rating in most polls.
But Colombians failed to vote in sufficient numbers to approve a range of belt-tightening measures that Mr. Uribe wanted so he could free up money for security measures.

The president now plans to push through Congress a fiscal austerity program that includes new taxes and spending cuts as well as anti-terrorism legislation that gives more police powers to the armed forces.
The first time Jeret Peterson tried the jump he has since named the Hurricane, he landed face-first in the snow.
Peterson, an aerialist from Boise, Idaho, ended up woozy, with a concussion and a shoulder injury, but he was not deterred. ''
It was painful, but aerialists are used to injuries like that,'' said Peterson, the reigning World Cup champion, who is nicknamed Speedy. ''
I knew that I had to keep trying it if I wanted to win a gold medal someday.''
So Peterson, 24, kept practicing the trick, which is five twists and three flips, the most difficult jump performed on the World Cup aerials circuit.
Soon, he began to land the jump that makes him look like a blur as he contorts his body 55 feet in the air. ''
I call it the Hurricane because you feel like you're in hurricane and can't see anything,'' he said. ''
Doing it can really make you feel disoriented, but you have to learn how to deal with that.''
The inspiration for Peterson to try the trick came when he saw Ales Valenta, a Czech aerialist, win the 2002 Olympics with a huge jump.
Valenta was fifth after the first round but shot to first when he landed a quintuple-twisting triple flip, his own Hurricane before Peterson came up with the name.
MORE than 50 years ago, George Heath inadvertently began the creation of a lovely border of daffodils that have stood the test of time.
The bulbs were what he called ''rogues,'' the occasional ones that were misidentified when planted in the long single-variety rows at his commercial bulb farm in eastern Virginia.
Thus, when a white Thalia would appear among a row of two-toned yellow Carltons, he would move it to an area along a stream or near a grape arbor.
Even though he called the misplaced plants rogues, he still treasured them and could not bear to throw them away.
The bulbs flourished in both places, which had good drainage and sun throughout the spring.
And they did so with minimal care.

Mr. Heath's son Brent, who took over the family business after his father died and renamed it Brent and Becky's Bulbs, said that every few years an application of slow-release bulb fertilizer heavy in potash is thrown down in late fall, and that's it.
I went to the Heath homestead the middle of last March to see the display gardens of new and unusual daffodils and other bulbs.
But then I came upon those old-time daffodil borders -- untouched since the 1950's -- bursting with flowers and color.
There was the all-yellow February Gold, a 12-to-14-inch beauty.

Evacuation workers struggling through the night in a dark and cold Alpine tunnel began extracting the bodies of about 155 people, including eight Americans, who perished on Saturday when a cable car they were riding to a ski run was destroyed in an inferno of flames.
Officials said the bodies of those killed in Austria's worst Alpine disaster were so badly maimed that they could be positively identified only by DNA testing, which is expected to begin on Monday.

The rumble of rescue helicopters could be heard through the day over this mountain village, population 3,500, as about 80 rescue workers entered the tunnel to begin carrying out the bodies on stretchers.
The bodies were then transported by helicopter to a tent at the foot of the cable car rails, which stretch about two and a half miles to an Alpine glacier favored by skiers.
On Saturday morning, the cable car, which can transport as many as 180 people, wormed its way through the tunnel that pierces the Kitzsteinhorn mountain.
Skiers and snow boarders, many of them teenagers and younger children, were traveling to the snow-dusted glacier for a morning of skiing.
But as the cable car moved through the mountain, fire broke out, transforming the tunnel into a chimney of fierce smoke and flames.

The Austrian government declared a state of mourning, and in Vienna, the capital, dignitaries including the Austrian president, Thomas Klestil, joined thousands of people at a service in the city's cathedral.
Public buildings, including the Vienna State Opera, were draped in black, and flags flew at half staff.
The deaths ''leave us speechless, since nothing more now can be done,'' the chancellor, Wolfgang Schussel, said at an ecumenical service here, near the foot of the cable car tracks. ''
The sequins glittered, the fabrics glowed, the lace was exquisite and the embroidery sublime.
Yet for all its resplendent elements, the collection Christian Lacroix showed here today did not add up.
Whether it's the times or his touch, the collection appeared too sumptuous for its own good.
The clothes were overtly complicated, when in much of fashion  one prefers not to see the effort.
Mr. Lacroix has an artist's touch when it comes to mixing colors and combining pattern-drenched fabrics.

As is his signature, he combined in one outfit three or four colors in couture-like fabrics, re-embroidered lace, duchesse satin in a theatrical shape like a bell-shaped skirt, and a ruffled portrait-collar blouse.

As an example of craftsmanship, each piece in the collection is exemplary, from an asymmetrical sequin skirt with a square of fabric that snaps away, to a green and beige striped three-piece wide-leg pants  suit.
But as today's fashion, they are a challenging proposition.

At the show's midpoint Mr. Lacroix sent out a fabulously sleek navy gown with a plunging neckline, its only adornment a glittering gold zipper that extended from its daring decolletage to a slit halfway up the leg.
The simplicity was welcome, but it was merely a pause in an extravagant promenade of exaggeration.
I was interested in Glenn Collins's About Men column "Pop's Bequest" (April 12) because I faced a similar situation 20 years ago -- except that the body to be donated was my own.
I was a member of a church in Springfield, Mass., at the time.
Several of us had been faced with deaths in the family.
We were devastated by the personal loss and shocked at the cost of a simple funeral.
We founded the Springfield Memorial Society and began informing ourselves about the laws governing cremation, body donation, etc.
We realized that the time for planning was long before the need.
I decided to donate my body to Harvard Medical School and made arrangements to make it legal.
After my death, the funeral director will send my body to the medical school.
After a period of study, it will be buried there.
There is the option of having a religious service or of having the remains returned.
