Eight days after he was convicted on a raft of federal charges of corruption, racketeering, mail fraud and extortion, Joseph P. Ganim, Bridgeport's first sitting mayor in memory to become a felon, announced today that he would resign.
Mr. Ganim will step down next Friday, according to a faxed statement from the mayor's office.
That is three days later than the date Mr. Ganim had originally told city officials would be his last.
Mr. Ganim has been criticized for not leaving office immediately after his conviction on March 20.

Though the mayor gave his reasons for staying on this long, city officials, including many fellow Democrats, have pointed out that he stands to gain roughly $10,000 in extra pay from unused vacation time if he remains in office through at least Tuesday.
Today, after a week of public silence, Mr. Ganim said that he would not accept any pay accrued as a result of his staying in office past Tuesday. ''
I inquired regarding a series of departure dates, but never applied for said benefits as a consequence of remaining through April 1,'' he said in the statement.
He added that he had stayed on this long only ''to ensure an orderly transfer with regard to the budget.''
The city charter requires the mayor to submit his recommended budget for the coming fiscal year to the City Council by April 1, Mr. Ganim noted.
A federal jury convicted Mayor Ganim, 43, of 16 felony corruption counts for leading a six-year scheme to collect kickbacks from contractors doing business with his city.
In the future, as today, a newt will lose a power struggle with a predator -- a lizard, say.
The lizard will make off with a newt leg, but the rest of the newt will stay behind.
There's a bit of blood, but belly to the ground, the newt will retreat to a damp spot under a rock.
Several weeks will pass, during which the newt will make its living barely hindered by an incrementally growing stump.
In six weeks, the lizard conflict will be nothing but a bad memory: the newt will be walking and swimming with a new limb indistinguishable from the original.
In the future, man -- severed from limb -- will do just the same.
In the new paradigm, a traveler who loses his arm in a power struggle with, say, his jetpack, will be rushed to a hospital to have his wound cleaned.
But instead of pulling mature skin over the amputation plane, doctors will bathe the area with growth factors.
In newts, growth factors are derived from nerves.
Humans lack this combination of molecules, but researchers will, by this point, have produced a human homologue to the newt's special juice.

To the Editor: One problem with the analysis of the North American Free Trade Agreement by the academic community is summed up in a revealing phrase by Prof. Paul Krugman, "on the average" (front page, Sept. 17).
Like the river whose average depth is one foot, there are some very deep areas that cannot be easily crossed.
Thus, economists speak of tariffs "averaging 4 percent."
But some tariffs, like those on apparel, are much higher.
They have been kept high because of the product's high labor intensity and resulting sensitivity to competition from low-wage imports.
While there will be winner and loser industries in a deal like this, that does not mean employment will average out.
A victory in machine tools helps an industry whose employment is reported by the Commerce Department as less than 40,000.
But a loss in apparel jeopardizes the jobs of nearly 1 million.
Even economists seem to agree that the industries at greatest risk are those with the highest labor intensity.
They, and the President, talk about new hi-tech jobs, but there are fewer of these than of more basic jobs, which we must assume will persist for years.
The cotton was grown on the arid plains of West Texas where it was reaped by machines and lifted onto trucks, mostly by Mexican immigrants, for minimum wage.
It was ginned clean of seeds and packed into bales by semiskilled Americans earning, on average, less than $10 hour.
The bales were shipped to Belgium where Turks and Moroccans spun them into yarn for 415 Belgian francs -- or about $9 -- an hour, and then woven into bolts.
The bolts were shuttled across a factory floor where Flemish women, paid $8.70 an hour, cut and hemmed them.

The new linen was shipped across the Atlantic, stored in a warehouse in Newark and sold to The Stanhope hotel, located across Fifth Avenue from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, for a price ranging between $21 and $27 per sheet.
The Stanhope considers itself one of the finest hotels in the city.
Its credo: a fine hotel catering to refined patrons must absolutely have fine linens.
The hotel guest is paying $325 to $3,000 a night for the privilege of sleeping between them.

An entire economy revolves around these sheets, from the hotel that must have a large supply of them to the business executive who sleeps on them to the laundry worker who earns $6.75 an hour cleaning them.
Numbers are abstract and ephemeral, slippery like soap bubbles, and they do not tell stories.
In the history of the Willamette Meteorite, there are at least two memorable photos.
The first shows the meteorite in Oregon, resting on a rough sledge made of logs, its inertia almost palpable.
The second shows the meteorite chained to a heavy dray, about to be unloaded at the American Museum of Natural History in 1906.
Somehow, it looks even heavier in New York.
Since 1935 the Willamette Meteorite, the largest ever found in the United States, has been housed in the Hayden Planetarium.
Now it is mounted beneath the Hayden Sphere in the new Rose Center for Earth and Space.
But last week, just as the Rose Center first opened, the Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde Community in Oregon asked the museum to turn the meteorite over to them.
They say that when it still lay in the hills southeast of modern Portland, the meteorite was an important object of tribal culture.
They argue that it falls under the Native American Graves Repatriation and Protection Act, which is designed to restore historic Native American artifacts in museums to the tribes themselves.

The Museum of Natural History has gone to court to legally establish its ownership of the meteorite based on a clear succession of title back to 1855, when the land on which the meteorite rested was obtained by treaty.
The United Way of America announced today that it was no longer paying the $390,000 salary of its former president, William Aramony, who resigned under pressure last month.

The announcement, by the group's interim president, Kenneth W. Dam, came more than a week after the organization revealed that Mr. Aramony was still receiving a salary while the details of his severance package were being worked out.
Anthony DeCristofaro, a spokesman for United Way of America, said Mr. Aramony would not be receiving severance pay.
His pension plan, Mr. DeCristafaro said, is still being negotiated.
In most cases, he said, pension plans are based on pay and years of service.
Mr. Aramony led the group, an umbrella organization of local United Ways, for 22 years. "
I have no idea what kind of numbers would be associated with" the final retirement agreement, Mr. DeCristofaro said.
Mr. Aramony was forced to resign in the wake of revelations about his expense-account life, which included trips on the Concorde and a chauffeur-driven car.
Mr. Aramony also helped established a group of private spinoff companies that sold products and services to United Way affiliates.
Questions about the financing of these companies and the benefits Mr. Aramony received from them are still under investigation by lawyers hired by the board of United Way.
The New York/New Jersey Knights could be hauled up on charges of aiding and abetting in the demise of their season.

After blowing a 17-0 second-quarter lead and two fourth-quarter scoring opportunities today, the Knights allowed London to steal a 42-26 victory in a World League of American Football semifinal playoff game before 23,149 fans at Giants Stadium.
With the loss the Knights finished their first season with a 5-6 record.
The Monarchs (10-1) will return to London for the W.L.A.F. championship game, the World Bowl, against Barcelona at Wembley Stadium next Sunday. "
We were right there; we had the chance to win it," said Knights quarterback Jeff Graham, who was 19 of 35 for 399 yards, two touchdowns and three interceptions.
Trailing by 28-26 in the fourth quarter, the Knights suffered turnovers on two consecutive possessions after they drove to the Monarchs' 24- and 25-yard lines, respectively.

Graham Fumbles Snap The first turnover came on a first-and-10 play at the London 24 with 9 minutes 4 seconds to play when Graham fumbled the exchange from center and Monarchs linebacker Marlon Brown recovered the ball at the 26.

The second turnover came on third-and-4 at the London 25 with 3:38 to play when Graham, throwing to Lonnie Turner, had a pass intercepted at the 7 by cornerback Corris Ervin, who returned it to the 13.
Mouse Davis, the Knights' coach, was asked why he chose to pass on third-and-4 instead of running the ball to keep the team in field-goal position.
A field goal would have put the Knights up by 29-28 with a little more than three minutes to play. "
Tyco International said yesterday that it had lined up debt financing of $5.25 billion -- $500 million more than it had previously expected -- in an effort to forestall a cash crisis.
The financing involves the sale of convertible bonds offered to large investors in a private placement, as well as a $1.5 billion unsecured line of bank credit.
The moves could be a crucial step in restoring shareholder confidence in Tyco, which is obliged to repay $5.8 billion in debt next month and more than $11 billion in debt by the end of 2003.
The bond sale is the first major financial deal for Tyco's new chief executive, Edward D. Breen.
He took over the company in July after the company's former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, was indicted on charges that he looted the company of millions of dollars.

Mr. Breen has spent the last several months trying to reorganize the company's board and governance procedures as investigators hired by Tyco completed an inquiry into the company's accounting practices.
Tyco said last week that the investigation had uncovered a series of accounting tricks that were used to inflate its earnings under Mr. Kozlowski.
Still, Mr. Breen was able to persuade investors yesterday to bet on Tyco's future.
Tyco said it sold $2.5 billion of 15-year convertible bonds and $1.25 billion of 20-year convertible bonds.
The 15-year bonds carry a 2.75 percent coupon and are convertible into Tyco shares at $22.78, a 32 percent premium over yesterday's closing price, $17.26.

Later Mr. Nixon ordered George Shultz, then Secretary of the Treasury, to audit the tax returns of Mr. In 1971, President Nixon became obsessed with the idea that Jewish officials in the Bureau of Labor Statistics were out to hurt him politically.
He demanded a list of names, promptly supplied by the White House personnel chief, Frederic V. Malek.
Later Mr. Nixon ordered George Shultz, then Secretary of the Treasury, to audit the tax returns of Mr. Nixon's ''enemies.''
Mr. Shultz flatly refused.
These quite different responses to two equally distasteful directives offer a lesson about the perils of bending principle to loyalty.
Mr. Shultz, whom Mr. Nixon called a ''candy ass'' for his refusal to play ball, is today Secretary of State.

Mr. Malek, whose 1971 survey of Jews in the statistics bureau was disclosed by The Washington Post over the weekend, has now been removed from a senior post in Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign.
Mr. Bush's swift response was not only commendable but inevitable; this was the second time in less than a week that accusations of anti-Semitism had brushed his campaign.
The clues are there, right in front of Jorge Posada, some as obvious as a black eye, others more subtle.
The Yankees' catcher crouches behind home plate and looks for the clues and tries to figure out a way to conquer the hitter who looms in the batter's box.
These are some of the lessons Posada has learned since he switched from second base to catcher.
Look at the hitters' hands; they will tell you something, Posada says.
If the batter holds his hands high as he prepares to swing, then he is almost certainly a low-ball hitter, because of the downward arc his bat must take.
He is probably more vulnerable to the high fastball.
If the batter holds his hands close to his body, then he is probably not very good at hitting pitches inside.
Look at a hitter's feet, to see how he moves and shifts from pitch to pitch.

Roberto Alomar will edge toward the front of the batter's box sometimes when Mariano Rivera is pitching, which would seem counterintuitive; Rivera throws very hard and when Alomar moves toward him, he is sacrificing milliseconds of reaction time.
But Posada knows that what Alomar is trying to do is hit Rivera's hard-breaking cut fastball before it veers.

In a move intended to appease his predecessor, Italy's new Prime Minister, Lamberto Dini, said today that he and his Cabinet of "technicians" would stay in office long enough to enact its program, and then make way for a newly elected government.
The outgoing Prime Minister, Silvio Berlusconi, said on Tuesday that he would not support Mr. Dini's new Government in Parliament unless he was assured that it would lead to new elections soon.

Today, Mr. Berlusconi said he wanted a public commitment not only from Mr. Dini but also from President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro, who he said had promised a mid-June election date in private conversations last week.

In a statement read at his first news conference, Mr. Dini said his Government has a "duty to carry out its unavoidable emergency task until the political forces freely chosen by the voters are able to form a government which is more representative of popular sovereignty."
Mr. Dini, who had been Treasury Minister in the outgoing Government, avoided mentioning any date, noting that only President Scalfaro has the constitutional authority to call an election.
But he said he would hand in his mandate as soon as his Government accomplished its objectives, which he said could be a matter of "a few months."

The new Prime Minister, a former general director of the Bank of Italy who kept the job of Treasury Minister for himself, said he was keenly aware of the "restlessness on national and international markets," as a result of Italy's political crisis.

Thus, he said, there is an urgent need for "an effective Government of action which must be carried out with full responsibility, and thus with the loyal support of the widest possible parliamentary majority."
Members of Parliament said today that the debate on the new Government will begin early next week, with a confidence vote in the Chamber of Deputies likely to come as early as Wednesday.
The new Government has 10 days from the date of its appointment to win approval from both houses of Parliament.
You need only watch the cable-television-staple classics of the 1980's like ''Caddyshack,'' with their damp-chinned, swampy streak of anarchy, to see the influence of Bob Hope.

Maybe because Mr. Hope, too, was a golfer, and ''Caddyshack'' is set in the grubby world of a country club, one could imagine him teeing off during the middle of the Tet offensive as Joey Heatherton and Ann-Margret serpentined through rice paddies for cover.
Mr. Hope's spunky confidence epitomized the brazen cool that became the province of bad-boy comic actors like Bill Murray and inspired the marksman's precision of Rodney Dangerfield.
Like Mr. Murray as the muttering, dangerous groundskeeper in ''Caddyshack,'' Mr. Hope provided a consummate commitment to character.
In Mr. Hope's case, though, it was to the only character he ever played: Bob Hope.
Mr. Dangerfield, Hope-like, spritzes one-liners through ''Caddyshack'' as if he were hissing jokes between his teeth to put out a fire. ''
This meat still has marks from where the jockey was hitting it,'' he barks while swinging through a bad sirloin, functioning as his own best audience.

It was something that Mr. Hope was able to do in some of his most enjoyable work, a raffish detachment that was both stylized and stylish: a lowlife sophistication, bridging the gap between actor and performer, that has nearly vanished from movie screens.
Most important, his physical arrogance gave him a command that contrasted with the mealy, darting-eyed schemer he often played.
He had the confidence of an athlete with unshakable trust in his body, despite fleeing into corners and hiding behind his leading ladies (and getting in a leering appraisal of them while he did).
KASMIR-Cyril David, age 52, left this world on August 28, 1997.
He was comfortable and surrounded by his family.
He chose to leave us when we were all smiling, laughing and basking in the joy that he had brought to all of us.
Cyril's strong will and undying spirit will continue to live on in his children Darren, Justin and Sean, and his memory will perpetually provide comfort and guidance to all whom he touched.
In addition to his children, he is survived by his loving wife Brenda, his parents Frank and Celia Kasmir, his brother Sam, sister Susan, extended family and many loving friends.
Words fail us at this time of great loss, end of suffering, and start of a peaceful rest.
We can honor and celebrate a good life, full of passion during which he loved and was loved completely.
His youth never left him.
Cyril worked tirelessly to provide for his family and to take care of his friends.
He was always there for us.
MARLA RIVERA's right hand guides the big, tilted wheel.
Her left clutches a wad of transfers.
Outside the city bus moving five miles an hour, the cabs she detests slice around her like ravenous piranhas.
Horns squawk on the too-crowded street.
And she'll be very lucky if this day doesn't include someone berating her because she tells them they're a coin or two short of the $1.25 fare.
But Marla Rivera is smiling sweetly. "
I'm happy to have a good job," she says.
"And hard work never killed anyone, I don't think."
And so it goes for the drivers of the city's 3,000 buses.
Together they carry 490 million people annually over 104 million miles.
To the Editor: I was sad to read of the closing of the Olympia, the site of one of my all-time-best celebrity sightings.
I had gone to the late show Steven Spielberg film ''Saving Private Ryan'' the Monday after it opened.
The theater was mostly empty.
Halfway through, Mr. Spielberg entered with his wife, Kate Capshaw, and sat in the last row.
I found it hard to concentrate on the movie and even harder to resist the urge to shout, ''Spielberg in the house!''
Ten minutes later, Ms. Capshaw passed me on her way out.
A fantasy flashed before my eyes.
I'd go for popcorn and linger in the lobby.
When the director exited, I'd turn to him nonchalantly and say, ''Are you leaving because you didn't like it or because you know how it ends?''
Charmed by my wit, he'd offer me a lifetime writing contract.
RICKY SMITH'S dreams are stacked in a pile of empty mesh oyster cages resting against the wall of his Central Islip home.
His hopes of making them come true are strung eight feet under water, dangling between two buoys in the middle of the Great South Bay.
Mr. Smith, 37, had all the trappings of an old salt.
He started clamming at 14 after school in search of a shellfish bounty.
After high school, he kept at it full time.
But by the time he was 22, after paying for his boat slip and fuel, the bayman was coming up empty. ''
It didn't work out,'' Mr. Smith recalled. ''
You couldn't make a living.
There weren't any clams left.''
To stay close to the water, he took a job in a marina doing boat repairs.
ABOUT a year ago, the New York State Legislature made a number of revisions to the Rockefeller drug laws.

The most significant changes involved reducing sentences for nonviolent drug offenders, raising the amount of drugs required for top-level possession charges and allowing defendants serving a life term to apply for a reduced sentence.
The primary goal was to grant low-level drug dealers relief from overly harsh sentences.
These measures were a step in the right direction, but they fail to take into account drug kingpins.

As the new legislative session begins this month, the priority should be to retain severe sentencing for major drug dealers while providing more alternatives to incarceration and more treatment options for low-level addicts and small-time dealers.
To do this, we must provide judges with greater discretion in determining which defendants should be placed in alternative sentencing and treatment programs.
We must pass legislation that provides for more such programs.
And we must enact a kingpin statute to ensure that major and violent drug predators are sentenced appropriately and cannot have their sentences reduced.
I was the judge who presided over many of New York City's most serious drug cases in the 1980's and 90's.
In a number of these cases, judges, after a resentencing hearing mandated by the changes to the Rockefeller drug laws, have reduced these sentences -- inappropriately so.

Despite assurances of their determination to continue the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Bosnia, European Governments hinted today they were considering the possibility of pulling back or pulling out after Bosnian Serb troops overran the "safe area" of Srebrenica on Tuesday. "
Withdrawal must remain an option," the British Foreign Secretary, Malcolm Rifkind, told the House of Commons today in London.
Other Members of Parliament warned of further disasters in other parts of Bosnia. "

We are sitting on a ticking time bomb," said David Howell, a Conservative M.P. who suggested United Nations troops should pull out of other enclaves in Bosnia rather than wait for possible attack by the Bosnian Serbs.
One alternative to withdrawing United Nations troops from Bosnia is pulling them back from towns that are considered indefensible and consolidating them.

Those options notwithstanding, France pressed, with little success, for support from Western allies to send more troops to try to retake Srebrenica and re-establish it as a refuge for the tens of thousands of Bosnian civilians who fled. "

If we do not react -- I mean the international community, since France obviously cannot act alone -- then we have to ask ourselves what purpose the United Nations Protection Force is serving there and draw the appropriate conclusions," President Jacques Chirac told French legislators.

In a resolution adopted unanimously today, the United Nations Security Council asked Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali "to use all resources available" to restore Srebrenica's status as a safe area under United Nations protection.
But the resolution stopped short of recommending the use of force.
Instead, the Council demanded that Bosnian Serb forces cease their offensive, withdraw immediately from Srebrenica and release the Dutch soldiers they have detained.

Two days before leaving office in January, Housing Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo announced an ambitious plan to cope with a home mortgage scandal that had embarrassed him just as he was preparing to enter the race for governor of New York.

Mr. Cuomo pledged that the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development would pay to rehabilitate hundreds of dilapidated brownstones in Harlem and Brooklyn and would turn them over to reputable community groups to increase the stock of low-cost housing.
At the time, Mr. Cuomo said that his agreement with the community groups would be binding on the incoming Republican administration.
But more than two months later, the future of Mr. Cuomo's plan is uncertain. ''
The entire issue is under comprehensive review,'' said Sean Cassidy, the new deputy commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, which is part of HUD. ''
It has been the focus of intensive discussions for the last several weeks here at the department.''
According to people familiar with some of those discussions, HUD officials have raised questions about the cost of the Cuomo plan, which by one estimate could be as much as $100 million.
And there is also speculation that the new administration in Washington would be loath to spend such a considerable sum to help Mr. Cuomo save face and improve his chances of becoming governor.
Officials of the groups covered by the agreement say they are waiting for direction from the housing department. ''

We're not making any presumptions, other than the hope that we can work with this administration,'' said William Frey, a senior vice president of the Enterprise Foundation, a national community development organization.
After the Giants' 27-20 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals Sunday, Mike Sherrard called home to California.
His mother, who had watched the game on a satellite dish, could not resist needling her fleet son. "
I couldn't believe that guy ran you down," she said. "
What happened?"
Sherrard knew he was being had. "
I told her I had no excuse," he said. "
She was laughing."
Cherrie Sherrard could afford to laugh because she provided her son with speed genes.
She was a national champion and 1964 Olympian in the 80-meter hurdles.
Her son played a memorable game against the Bengals, another example of how dangerous he can be when plays, especially long passes, are designed for him.

A scientific study commissioned by the Bush administration concluded yesterday that the lower atmosphere was indeed growing warmer and that there was ''clear evidence of human influences on the climate system.''

The finding eliminates a significant area of uncertainty in the debate over global warming, one that the administration has long cited as a rationale for proceeding cautiously on what it says would be costly limits on emissions of heat-trapping gases.

But White House officials noted that this was just the first of 21 assessments planned by the federal Climate Change Science Program, which was created by the administration in 2002 to address what it called unresolved questions.

The officials said that while the new finding was important, the administration's policy remained focused on studying the remaining questions and using voluntary means to slow the growth in emissions of heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide.
The focus of the new federal study was conflicting records of atmospheric temperature trends.
For more than a decade, scientists using different methods had come up with differing rates of warming at Earth's surface and in the midsection of the atmosphere, called the troposphere.

These disparities had been cited by a small group of scientists, and by the administration and its allies, to question a growing consensus among climatologists that warming from heat-trapping gases could dangerously heat Earth.

The new study found that ''there is no longer a discrepancy in the rate of global average temperature increase for the surface compared with higher levels in the atmosphere,'' in the words of a news release issued by the Commerce Department and approved by the White House.
The report was published yesterday online at climatescience.gov.
The report's authors all agreed that their review of the data showed that the atmosphere was, in fact, warming in ways that generally meshed with computer simulations.
A powerful earthquake rocked Bam, an ancient city in southeastern Iran, early Friday morning, killing thousands and destroying 70 to 90 percent of the residential areas.
Bam is 610 miles southeast of Tehran, in Kerman Province.
The official Islamic Republic News Agency said the earthquake registered 6.3 on the standard magnitude scale.
The United States Geological Survey put the magnitude at 6.7.
Several aftershocks during the day, one measuring 5.3, jolted the city.
The provincial governor general, Muhammad Ali Karimi, put the initial number of dead at 5,000 to 6,000, but said the toll was expected to rise as high as 20,000.
Some 30,000 were reported to be injured, many in critical condition. ''
Many people have died and people are buried under the rubble,'' Mr. Karimi said on Iranian state television. ''
We are doing everything we can to rescue the injured and unearth the dead.''
Details on the scale of damage were skimpy, he said, because telephone communication was cut off with Bam and nearby towns, including Jiroft and Kohnouj.

If you suspect that all those electronic gadgets for children are only good for wasting time with games, check out the FlashMaster, a digital alternative to flashcards that helps teach basic math skills.
This 7-by-4-inch hand-held device can be set for practice sessions or for tests in addition, subtraction, multiplication or division at various skill levels.
Once an activity and a skill level are selected, a series of problems appear on the screen.
A row of numbers along the bottom of the device is used to enter answers.
Its gamelike attributes make arithmetic surprisingly engaging.
The FlashMaster responds to answers with screen messages and sounds that can be muted when necessary -- say, during a long car trip. (
There is also a headphone jack, although headphones are not included.)
If the user enters a wrong answer, the problem is displayed again.
After two misses, the correct answer is prompted (but the user must enter it to move on).
At the end of a practice session or a test, the total score is displayed.

LEAD: To the Editor: To the Editor: The report that some co-op buildings in New York City are struggling in a weakening real-estate market (Jan. 13) misrepresents the threat of defaults facing co-ops, perhaps causing unnecessary alarm for owners and providing an undeserved bargaining chip for potential purchasers.

You report defaults by holders of unsold shares in several buildings (that is, apartments owned by the original sponsor or an investor and usually occupied by a rent-stabilized or rent-controlled tenant).
You suggest that any building with more than 30 percent unsold shares is a poor investment.
I am president of a large Upper West Side co-operative and have spent a great deal of time thinking about these issues.
Merely looking at the percentage, without any other figures, is meaningless.
The potential purchaser should consider the following: (1) The differential between the rents collected from the tenants in those apartments and the maintenance due on them.
Where there is little or no negative differential (that is, they pay for themselves), the risk of the sponsor's defaulting is minimal. (
Of course, where there is a negative differential, the holder of the shares is still obligated to pay the full maintenance.
I consider here only the ease with which it can be paid.) (
2) One should inquire about the vacancy rate.

ZIPPING THROUGH SECURITY -- Indianapolis International Airport is the latest airport to sign on for the federal Registered Traveler Program, which aims to move frequent fliers through security faster.
The airport selected the Clear plan, developed by Verified Identity Pass, which introduced it at Orlando International Airport in Florida last July.
A third airport, Norman Y. Mineta San Jose International, has reached an agreement with Clear to start the program this spring.
By then, competitors to Verified Identity Pass are expected to be in business.
Under the Registered Traveler Program, fliers submit basic information that enables them to be cleared for expedited screening by the Transportation Security Administration.
Once they pass that test, they must pay an annual fee (currently $79.95 at Orlando) and use an identity card encoded with their fingerprints and iris scans to gain access to designated checkpoints.
The security administration is expected to announce details on procedures for expediting the passage of registered travelers within two weeks.
By summer, 30 to 40 airports are expected to be participating.
ANOTHER BRITISH AIRWAYS BARGAIN -- British Airways continues to offer fare sales in the fiercely competitive trans-Atlantic business-class market.
The latest, announced yesterday, is a $1,998 round-trip ticket in Club World business class between Kennedy International Airport and Manchester Airport in England.
A crucial tenet of the camp esthetic holds that we are all mud-spattered brothers and sisters in the sludge heap of popular culture.
A good comic wallow in the trough of bad taste is supposed to be a purgative, liberating immersion that transcends all sexual and social taboos and permits anything to be said.

But in ''Highway of Heartache,'' a Canadian spoof of a country singer's tear-drenched up-from-Tobacco Road memoir, ''anything'' includes racial epithets cheerfully slung by caricatures made up to look like pornographic rag dolls.
The very frivolity of the movie makes these remarks seem as casually offensive as the racist jokes in an old-time minstrel show.
This seam of racial humor lends an ugly undertone to a movie whose gratingly hysterical pitch makes a John Waters romp look like a Merchant-Ivory reverie. ''

Highway of Heartache,'' which opens today at the Lighthouse Cinema, follows the adventures of Wynona-Sue Turnpike (Barbara Chamberlin), a luckless country singer who by the end of the story has to be a candidate for most abused woman in the history of professional victimology.

Wynona's troubles begin when she shoots her philandering husband, Clive, and follows it up by wailing ''I've Got a Ring on My Finger and a Stiff on My Hands,'' the first of the character's several musical numbers.

While hitchhiking her way to Nashville, a fling in a motel leaves her with a venereal disease, which is treated by an Elvis-imitating gynecologist in an office where a button on the wall lights up to announce a ''slut alert.''
Eventually, she marries Crawfish Crenshaw, the host of a television talent show, whom she shoots after catching him in bed with her black  illegitimate daughter, Ester-Ruth.
Throughout her travels, Wynona-Sue is accompanied by the Big Wigs, a pair of smirking, high-haired drag queens who sing backup.
To the Editor: I read David M. Raddock's Sept. 2 letter on China with amusement.
Yes, we are still eating dogs in China.
What's wrong with that?
I used to feel the same as May-lee Chai (whose Aug. 26 letter Mr. Raddock replied to) whenever I read or heard Americans talk about this Dog Thing.
I do not feel angry anymore.
This is not a matter of who is more civilized or less civilized.
It is simply a matter of different tastes.
Why is eating dog meat less dignified (at least that is how it is portrayed in the news media here) than eating beef?
Does one kind of animal enjoy more rights than another?
Who decides that?
Mary Berner, the 36-year-old former publisher of TV Guide who takes over the  helm of Glamour today, does not exactly fit the expected image of a publisher of two of the leading magazines in America.
At TV Guide she made her managers wear red high-top sneakers to monthly meetings -- "a bonding experience," she called it.
She once dressed as an Indian and rode a horse into a meeting in Arizona.
She even conducted a session for her 11 managers at her parents' home in Illinois and turned the event into a pajama  party.
It evidently worked.
TV Guide's annual revenue increased 22 percent last year and 17 percent the year before.

To reward her troops, Ms. Berner has twice  flown her managers and their spouses to Britain for a four-day holiday, including a night in period costumes at Hever Castle, the 13th-century home of Anne Boleyn when she was being courted by Henry VIII.
Little seems to faze Ms. Berner -- including possible arched eyebrows at the  News Corporation, the owner of TV Guide -- over this kind of expense.
TV Guide,  she points out, accounted for more than 15 percent of the company's profits in 1994.
Ms. Berner, who looks more like a college student than an executive, is one of the young publishers livening up the magazine industry.
THE giant Western dams of the 20th century are a civics class and epic novel in one.
They are both public and private, each needing the other -- colossi that made the desert bloom, at a cost measured in sweat and sometimes lives.
A dam is not always concrete, but it is never abstract.

There is something deeply American about these dams, and nowhere are they better described than in a  University of Virginia American Studies Program site called The Hoover Dam: Lonely Lands Made Fruitful (xroads.virginia.edu /1930s/DISPLAY/hoover/front2 .html). ''
Almost from the beginning of its construction,'' the introduction says, ''the Hoover Dam possessed an epic quality that animated the national imagination.''
There are sketches of proposed designs, and an article about Boulder City, Nev., which grew from workers' tents and shantytowns.
There are slides of the diverting of the Colorado River, the tunnels at night, the miners, the drillers.
President Franklin D. Roosevelt's 1935 dedication is online.
The dam was an icon of modernism, according to the site.
It became ''a metaphor for the positive power of big government,'' the site says.
Deni Lamont, a member of the New York City Ballet's artistic staff who formerly danced with that company and the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 59 years old.
He died of lung cancer, a spokesman for the New York City Ballet said.
Mr. Lamont performed for six years in the 1950's with the Ballet Russe, which promoted him to principal dancer.
He danced with American Ballet Theater for a year before joining the New York City Ballet's corps in 1958.
Mr. Lamont was promoted to soloist in 1964 and gained attention with roles he created in George Balanchine's new ballets.
The most notable was the 1965 "Harlequinade," in which Mr. Lamont's melancholy Pierrot was also required to display considerable technique.
A lanky, mercurial dancer, Mr. Lamont attracted notice in major supporting roles.
He was Puck in Balanchine's "Midsummer Night's Dream," and as the Harlequin in Balanchine's "Sonnambula," he displayed the artistry that he once said should not be subordinate to virtuosity.
His execution as the leader of the male corps in "Stars and Stripes" was nonetheless brilliant.

To the Editor: The great masterworks of the Old World and the New World are not medicines to be swallowed because they're good for you; they are exciting examples of mankind's highest achievements in art.
Our concert halls celebrate the heights to which we can soar -- a welcome respite from the daily reminders of war and bigotry and avarice and hate.
If we cannot sell this vintage, let us find a solution other than diluting it with soda pop.
Here are two remedies.
The first is incorporated in the American Symphony Orchestra League's report and requires better education in the arts in general and music in particular.
Community outreach is important, as is acceptance by schools and neighborhoods.
A second remedy is to effectively market the product.
We need not apologize because it can sometimes be more challenging for listeners than popular tunes.
To the managements in the league, I say: Physician, heal thyself.
Believe in your product in its traditional and contemporary living glory.
LEAD: SHARES of the General Electric Company took a bumpy ride last week, first hitting a record high of $103.75 and then finishing at $101 for a net loss of $2.50.

The sudden downturn reflected investor concern that G.E. might face liabilities stemming from its 80 percent ownership of Kidder, Peabody & SHARES of the General Electric Company took a bumpy ride last week, first hitting a record high of $103.75 and then finishing at $101 for a net loss of $2.50.

The sudden downturn reflected investor concern that G.E. might face liabilities stemming from its 80 percent ownership of Kidder, Peabody & Company amid allegations of insider-trading improprieties by the investment firm acquired in 1986.

Most Wall Street analysts are optimistic on prospects for G.E.'s stock, which rose $1.625, to $102, yesterday, and they tend to dismiss any further market repercussions from the Kidder, Peabody situation. ''
Any worst-case scenario involving Kidder, Peabody is already reflected in the stock price,'' said Nicholas P. Heymann of Drexel Burnham Lambert.
He believes the stock remains ''a compelling buy.''

E. Robert Quasman of Oppenheimer & Company said: ''While concerns about G.E.'s Kidder-related exposure could continue to cast a pall on the stock near term, we continue to believe G.E.'s stock is more attractive than the market and would regard any current weakness as an opportunity to add to positions.''
Both analysts predicted higher profits for G.E., which earned $5.46 a share last year.
For the first quarter of 1987, Mr. Heymann estimates earnings at $1.39 a share, up from $1.18 in the comparable 1986 period.
His full-year estimates call for $6.50 a share in 1987 and $7.75 in 1988.
On a muggy afternoon, James Gandy, 38, cleared debris from the installation of his new $55,000 Fleetwood double-wide mobile home.
He has a side-by-side refrigerator; wood-burning fireplace; two bathrooms, with his-and-her sinks; and a game room with a pool table and a wet bar.
Mr. Gandy, who is divorced and is a sales manager for a company nearly an hour away in Brunswick, lives there with his two teenage sons. ''
You hear people say, 'I'm not going to live in a trailer,' '' Mr. Gandy said. '' '
I'm living in a house.'
I want the yard to look nice.
I want to be able to have company come in.''

A Political Puzzle AFTER THE TALIBAN -- One week after the bombs started falling on Afghanistan, the United States military campaign has run ahead of Washington's political strategy to install a new regime in Kabul.

While United States has pursued Osama bin Laden and sought to neutralize the Taliban that shelters him, the behind-the-scenes effort to organize a regime that would replace Taliban leaders has made no discernible progress.
A1 A MISSING VOICE -- The recent assassination of the Afghan rebel leader is being felt most deeply in the alliance's efforts to persuade Taliban commanders to defect.
B3 IN PLAIN SIGHT -- Where do Taliban soldiers hide from American bombs?
At the front line, say commanders, soldiers and refugees.
Political factors appear to have made the front lines north of Kabul one of the least bombed places in the country.

A1 WAR AND SACRIFICE -- The president faces a dilemma that none of his precursors encountered.

Now, seven weeks into the city's new fiscal year, Mayor Terence M. Zaleski and the City Council have yet to agree on a budget that will satisfy the state agencies charged with overseeing the city's financial health since 1984, when it almost went broke.
One of those agencies, the State Emergency Financial Control Board, has ordered the city to cut its spending by 30 percent if a budget is not in place by Sept. 1.

To comply, Mr. Zaleski's aides have said that the Mayor would be forced to lay off 350 city employees; reduce garbage collection from twice a week to once a week and close libraries, centers for the elderly and parks.
The city has so far avoided layoffs by simply not paying many of its bills, mayoral aides said.

Political Differences Cited With the differences between the Mayor and the City Council relatively narrow -- the gap between their competing budget proposals has closed to $1.3 million, or three-tenths of 1 percent of the budget -- the squabble is more firmly rooted in the city's governance structure.
In 1989, voters replaced the city's 50-year-old form of government, headed by a city manager who was appointed by the City Council, with a "strong mayor" who would be elected.
Mr. Zaleski, the city's first strong mayor under the new charter, was elected to a four-year term in 1991.

Mr. Zaleski, a Democrat, and the seven-member City Council, which has a Republican majority, have grappled ever since for control of the state's sixth-largest city, with the budget only the latest sticking point.

'Square Dance'  New York City Ballet New York State Theater George Balanchine was famous for tinkering with his ballets, sometimes long after they were created.
But the changes he made in "Square Dance," -- the elimination of a caller and an onstage fiddle ensemble -- were profound.
Or were they? "

Square Dance," presented by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night, now looks like a modern-day "white ballet," with the dancers dressed in soft white ballet practice clothes and the choreography now looking a good deal more abstract, or less referential.
There is a solo for the male lead that recalls a dance in Balanchine's "Four Temperaments."
But it is now possible to see, perhaps even more clearly, the inspiration of Balanchine's witty and perceptive affection for the vernacular.
In the 1957 ballet, Balanchine managed to blend forms and specifics of American square-dancing and European classical ballet, a blending echoed in the Vivaldi-Corelli score.
The vernacular emerges most obviously toward the end in a passage for the corps de ballet, when the dancers shift fluidly through circles and crossing lines, arms companionably around their partners.
One can hear the caller's "do-si-do" as vividly here as the ballerina's quick-working feet bring back his "wickety-wack."

Margaret Tracey was first-rate as the ballerina, flying playfully through the demanding choreography yet allowing the dance to bloom within her, as in jumps where she seemed to expand luxuriously at the height of her leap, landing simultaneously with the corps women but appearing to spend extra time in the air.

The name, New York City Opera Orchestra, stood at the head of Carnegie Hall's program page on Friday night, but it became evident after a while that the primary purpose of this event was to promote a young Japanese violinist named Hideko Udagawa in some kind of style.
Independently produced under the auspices of Panasonic, this generally ragtag affair ended with results its sponsors might not have intended.

As to Miss Udagawa, she proved a violinist of bull-like technical strength, not a lot of grace or sophistication, but possessed of a determined will to pour into Bruch's G-minor Concerto every ounce of Romantic weight it would bear.
The results were not always displeasing even when the tone spoke more of sinew than of resonant beauty.

Miss Udagawa has all the interpretive gestures down and the technical puzzles solved, but she tends to overdo: portamento stretched out a little too far, accents relentlessly aggressive, sweeps of the bow just the wrong side of exaggeration.
Perhaps in a more modest recital setting, one would have heard qualities not apparent on Friday.

The City Opera players, here conducted by Guido Ajmone-Marsan, are professionals who can get through almost any piece; in the case of Stravinsky's Divertimento from "The Fairy's Case" and the Mendelssohn "Italian" Symphony, this is pretty much what happened.
Everyone, however, rose to a different level of refinement in Ravel's wonderful vocal piece for soprano and orchestra, "Sheherazade."
This isolated elevation in quality had a lot to do, I suspect, with Renee Fleming, who was the real beneficiary of Friday's concert.
Operating without the natural voluptuousness of sound Ravel's music asks for, Ms. Fleming had the character and the style to embrace all its sensual, dreamlike ecstasy.

In a forest clearing outside Berlin a few weeks ago, a giant cross was set aflame as several dozen spectators in white robes and hoods cheered and shouted racist slogans.
The demonstrators were German, but the organizer was Dennis Mahon, a prominent Ku Klux Klan leader from Oklahoma who was visiting Germany to build links between the Klan and neo-Nazi groups here.
A German television reporter, Harald Spiegel, was the only journalist at the cross-burning.
His film, broadcast Oct. 8 on German television, offered visible evidence of the Klan's efforts to build a presence in Germany. "
I couldn't believe my eyes," Mr. Spiegel said in an interview. "
These young German kids were looking to Mahon as a guru.
They want his advice on how to get rid of foreigners in Germany."
A 'Propaganda Tour' Mr. Spiegel said Mr. Mahon had told him that he was on a "secret propaganda tour" of Germany.
A wave of violent bigotry has swept through Germany in the last two months.
More than 200 arson attacks have been reported in that period on buildings in which foreigners live, compared with just 19 such attacks in all of 1990.
Corporate America has had little appetite lately for mergers and acquisitions.
In fact, 2002 is already shaping up as one of the slowest years in overall activity in recent years.
But a new study suggests that a turnaround could be ahead.
About 30 percent of 150 Fortune 1000 executives interviewed recently by Accenture, the management consulting company, said they expected to pursue more deals in the next six months.
Eighteen percent said they expected to pursue fewer, while nearly half said they foresaw no change in such activity.
That, of course, is encouraging news for deal makers who languished through a slow first quarter, when just $89.2 billion in deals were announced, according to Thomson Financial.
It was the first time since the first quarter of 1995 that merger-and-acquisition activity failed to break the $100 billion threshold, the company said.
The Accenture survey also tried to identify the reasons for the success or failure of mergers.
About half the executives interviewed attributed unsuccessful deals to their own poor evaluation of the potential synergies and benefits of a merger. ''
They focus on financial due diligence and historic data instead of focusing on future trends and the sources of future revenues,'' said Justin Jenk, a partner in Accenture's corporate practice.
THE only clear thing about the critical reaction to ''The Clearing'' at Hartford Stage Company is that history repeats itself.
The new play about the crushing of the Irish rebellion by Oliver Cromwell's parliamentary forces in the mid-17th century opened last month.
It was clearly not meant as a textbook case study or as a history lesson.
And it wasn't ethnic cleansing in Kosovo and the question of coexistence between the Serbs and the Albanians that the playwright Helen Edmundson had in mind when she wrote the play. ''
The Bosnia crisis was happening then,'' she recalled on a recent Saturday morning after participating in one of the theater's educational programs, ''Critical Eye.''

During the program she was interviewed by the theater's literary director, Christopher Baker, before 36 teachers from high schools and middle schools in more than 25 towns including Hamden, Redding, West Hartford, North Haven and Wethersfield.
Ms. Edmundson flew to Hartford for two days from London where she lives.
She saw the play performed the night before. ''
It was an emotional experience for me,'' she said. ''
Tonight I'll look at it with colder eyes.'' ''

The change in ownership of the Italian phone company Telecom Italia coming so soon after a turnover of control at Montedison, the Italian chemicals and power conglomerate, suggests that big changes are afoot in the way Italy Inc. operates.
But a closer look finds that less may be changing than meets the eye.
Investors appeared today to reject the industrial strategy behind the takeover of Telecom Italia by Pirelli, announced Saturday.
They bid Pirelli's shares down 18 percent, to 2.55 euros ($2.23).
Meanwhile, minority shareholders in Telecom Italia, shut out in the deal, protested that it was fundamentally unfair, even if legal under Italian law.

The takeover is an indirect one, involving a block of shares in Telecom Italia controlled by Olivetti; Pirelli and Benetton have offered an 80 percent premium to the owners of a 26 percent stake in Olivetti, and nothing to other Telecom Italia holders. ''
This is unconscionable,'' said Tony Leggett, a fund manager at TIAA-CREF, the big institutional investor, which is a longtime investor in Telecom Italia.

The old cliche had it that in Italy more than most European countries, real corporate power was wielded through cozy shareholder agreements that gave effective control of large companies to small groups of insiders.
Through complex networks of cross-shareholdings, families like the Agnellis of Fiat, the Pirellis and the Benettons, and their companies and banks, held the reins on huge swaths of the economy.
And behind them all lurked the influential investment bank, Mediobanca, and its secretive chairman, Enrico Cuccia, who masterminded the system until his death last year at the age of 92.
BECAUSE of abundant rainfall, most soil in the Northeast is acidic.

That is why Northeastern gardeners and their counterparts in the Pacific Northwest are relatively successful growing rhododendrons, azaleas, heaths, heathers and other plants that thrive in acidic soil.
The rainfall has a leaching effect, dissolving the soil's alkali nutrients and leaving acidic residue, which is essentially organic matter.
Acidic soil is also the reason gardeners in the Northeast apply lime every few years, especially to lawns.
Grass plants need a soil pH that is somewhere between 6 and 6.5.
When the soil pH is not within this range, problems can occur.
Fertilizer nutrients may not be available.
Soil microorganisms may not be able to operate at full capacity.
Roots may not be able to grow.
Most garden plants also require a soil that is slightly acid, with a pH between 6 and 6.5, the same as given for grass growth.
Chad Curtis felt he could afford to gamble while leading off first base in the bottom of the ninth inning yesterday.
The Yankees and the Seattle Mariners were tied, 1-1, both managers manipulating their lineups and formulating strategy from batter to batter, pitch to pitch.
But Curtis figured he could dictate what might happen; he could create opportunity.
If he was thrown out, well, they would play a 10th inning.

If Curtis could navigate his way around the bases, making that crucial journey from first to second base, the Yankees would win -- as they did, 2-1, when Curtis scored on Scott Brosius' two-out single, before 54,787 at Yankee Stadium.
And so the spectacular performance of the Yankees' Orlando Hernandez -- 13 strikeouts and only three hits allowed in eight innings -- was not wasted.
Hernandez struck out Alex Rodriguez three times, among others. ''

Mariano Rivera relieved Hernandez, who had thrown 136 pitches, in the top of the ninth and was credited with the victory.
In the bottom of the ninth inning, Tino Martinez reached base leading off, after Seattle catcher Tom Lampkin could not catch the third strike thrown by Jose Paniagua.

He placed the smoking sticks into a Styrofoam cup before a picture of his son, Lance Cpl.

Jim Brock, the Arizona State baseball coach who turned an interim assignment as a fill-in with a championship team into a 23-year career as one of the nation's most successful college coaches, died Sunday night at Desert Samaritan Hospital in Mesa, Ariz. He was 57.

An Arizona State spokesman said the cause of death was liver and colon cancer, the disease Brock had been fighting for 11 months, most spectacularly during the early rounds of this year's College World Series in Omaha.
Until he was forced to return to the hospital before last Tuesday's game against Miami, the only concession Brock made to the disease was to install a plastic lawn chair in the dugout.
The empty chair was there when the Sun Devils beat the Hurricanes, 9-5, for Brock's 1,100th victory, a plateau only six other coaches have ever reached.

Eighth Among Active Coaches A 6-1 loss to Oklahoma, the tournament's eventual winner, on Thursday, brought his record to 1,100-440, a .714 winning percentage that is the 16th highest among all coaches and eighth among those active last season.
For Brock, a native of Phoenix and a 1958 graduate of Arizona State, his career was largely an accident.
Brock, who had coached Mesa Community College to back-to-back national junior college championships, was working on a doctorate in educational administration at Arizona State in 1971.

That happened to be the year when Bobby Winkles, who had pioneered in the Sun Devil baseball program, winning three national titles in 13 years, left after the season to become a coach for the California Angels.

Unable to find an experienced Division I coach with sufficient stature to take Winkles's place, the athletic director, Fred Miller, hired Brock as a temporary replacement while he continued his search.
Twelve World Series After Brock steered the team to a 64-6 record and second place in the College World Series in 1972, he had all the Division I stature he needed.

Call it coincidence, but Sean Bennett, the Giants' rookie who is the last healthy, every-down running back left on the roster, was escorted onto the practice field today by the head trainer, Ronnie Barnes.
If Barnes was Bennett's bodyguard, the 23-year-old, soft-spoken Bennett did not need one.
Through two practices today, Bennett's teammates did not seem to want to be anywhere near him.
Nobody wanted to be the guy who stepped on his toe or tripped him and caused a dislocation.
Not with the first preseason game Friday against Minnesota and Bennett the only running back -- besides the third-down back Tiki Barber -- who is not injured.
Bennett would be handed the ball in the backfield today and it appeared the defensive players would temporarily freeze, then gingerly attempt to stop his progress.
Coaches blew their whistles at the instant of contact.

With Gary Brown and LeShon Johnson recovering from surgery performed in the last week and with the rookie running back Joe Montgomery out at least another two weeks after reinjuring his hamstring Tuesday, the theme of today's practices was caution, not contact.
Most plays were run at half-speed, drills tended to be more instructional than confrontational and there was plenty of stretching, stretching, stretching.
And nobody hit the running backs.
REFORM Albany: a good thing, no doubt, and given the legacy of the Pataki years, a popular thing as well.
The cumulative weight of late budgets, spiraling debt and legislative gridlock has led to a consensus that something is seriously wrong with the way Albany functions.

And, for a series of good and bad reasons, more blame -- words like ''dysfunctional,'' ''corrupt'' and ''ineffective'' -- has ended up attached to the Legislature rather than to former Gov. George Pataki.
Now Gov. Eliot Spitzer has seized on that reality, waging rhetorical and political war on the members and the institution with his usual energy and focus, and occasional profanity.
In fact, the Legislature's record is a good one.
A lot depends on how you measure success.
A successful legislature will do three things well: pass laws; provide ordinary people access to power and enable them to influence decisions; and, most important, check abuse of executive power.
By those standards, New York's Legislature is doing well.
The least successful of the goals has been passing laws.
Budgets were late, and important issues like rethinking the Rockefeller drug laws, electoral reform and changes in education financing were slow to happen.
THE Yadkin Valley in the fall invites not only wine-and-barbecue tours, but also side trips to see brilliant autumn color.
For a leisurely drive with plenty of scenery to enjoy, avoid the Interstates and instead take State Route 268, which North Carolina calls the Upper Yadkin Way, from east to west.
Starting about 20 miles north of Winston-Salem, the road makes a gentle, rolling ascent westward from the Piedmont Plateau into the Blue Ridge foothills.
A drive can take you to three state parks that are home not only to majestic rock formations and waterfalls, but also a variety of deciduous trees in fall show.
More information about North Carolina state parks is online at ils.unc.edu/parkproject/ncparks.html.
HANGING ROCK STATE PARK Just southeast of where Route 268 begins, Hanging Rock is known for its cliffs and waterfalls, and for Hanging Rock -- a quartzite formation jutting 200 feet out over a cliff.

For good views without leaving the car, Erik Nygard, superintendent of the park, recommended drives along Mickey, Hall and Moore's Springs Roads, all off state Route 66 and all flanking the park's northern border.
PILOT MOUNTAIN STATE PARK From Hanging Rock, Routes 268 and 52 carve a beautiful drive into the foothills on the way to Pilot Mountain Park.
Even better, for country beauty, are the back roads -- Highway 66, Chestnut Grove Road and Old State Highway 52.
Once you've made it to the park, you can either hike 2,420-foot Pilot Mountain, its sole peak, for the views, or stay in the car and explore.

Black Ice Q. Is black ice really black?
What is it, exactly?
A. What weather reports call black ice is not black at all; it just looks that way because it is transparent and whatever color the road's surface is shows through. ''
If the roadway were maroon, I guess we would call it maroon ice,'' said Fred Gadomski, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University.
Whether ice on the road is visible depends on how it is formed, he explained.
Rime ice, which is visible, forms when droplets of freezing drizzle adhere to the roadway with air trapped inside because the drops do not splatter when they hit.
Black ice, which is not easily seen, is a coating of thin ice that is often the result of thawing and refreezing roadside snowbanks.
It may also come from freezing drizzle or rain that splatters when it hits the road, so that no air is trapped inside.
In daylight, black ice may look like a dull patch of road surface that is darker than the rest of the highway.
It is most treacherous at night, when it is difficult or impossible to spot.
The United States Tennis Association is set to unveil a statue commemorating the late tennis champion Arthur Ashe by the American neo-expressionist artist Eric Fischl.
The statue will be revealed on Aug. 28, the first day of the United States Open.
A seven-foot tall figure of a nude black man, it is cast in the heroic tradition of ancient Greek statues of athletes.
One arm soars toward the sky as if tossing a ball to serve and the other arm is behind the figure, as if weighted down by an imaginary racket.
It will stand outside the Arthur Ashe Stadium at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, in Queens.
The statue, made of roughly modeled bronze, is not intended to be a likeness of Mr. Ashe, said Mr. Fischl, but rather a metaphor for his bravery and spirit.
Mr. Ashe, the only black man to win Wimbledon and the United States and Australian Opens, died of complications of AIDS in 1993 at the age of 49. ''
I was trying to find a way through the language of tennis and the language of the body to express some of what I thought were the attributes and values he represented,'' Mr. Fischl said.
Mr. Ashe campaigned against discrimination and on behalf of those suffering from AIDS.
At the base of the statue are carved his  words: ''From what we get, we make a living; what we give, however, makes a life.''

Teaching cardiac patients how to manage stress may be as effective as aerobic exercise in decreasing the long-term risk of further coronary illness, and it may also reduce medical costs, researchers at Duke University Medical Center have found.
The idea that lowering stress can improve outcomes for heart patients is not new.

But the Duke study, which followed heart patients for five years, is believed to be the first to measure the benefits of stress management over a sustained period and to demonstrate its potential economic benefits. ''

Lots of physicians remain very skeptical about the value of psychological interventions in treating patients with medical disorders,'' said Dr. James Blumenthal, a Duke psychologist, who was the lead author. ''
Our data suggest that these interventions do affect the process, and the benefits seemed to be maintained over time.''
The study, done in cooperation with the American Psychological Association, was published this month in The American Journal of Cardiology.
It followed 94 men with previous heart problems and evidence of continuing ischemia, an insufficient flow of blood to the heart.
The subjects were divided into three groups.

One group attended a four-month aerobic exercise program; a second participated in weekly stress management classes for the same period, and a control group received just the usual care for cardiac patients, including medications and regular visits to doctors.
Aerobic exercise has long been considered a key to cardiac health.
With energy talks in Congress mired, Senate officials warned on Thursday that talks on a national energy plan could go into next year, even as President Bush called for an accord this year.

A spokeswoman for the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee told reporters that divisions between House and Senate Republicans over rules for the electricity industry, gasoline additives and subsidies for a gas pipeline in Alaska might not be resolved before Congress adjourned for the year. ''

We recognize the possibility that this may take us into January,'' said Marnie Funk, who works for Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Senate panel and the House-Senate conference committee on the bill.
That idea stunned lobbyists, who had expected the measure with dozens of provisions favorable to American power producers to be wrapped up in a few weeks.
It also angered House officials, who said lawmakers there were ready to proceed.
It arose as Mr. Bush repeated in a speech in New Hampshire his call for the negotiators to finish the bill quickly. ''
They must come together and get a bill to my desk before they go home for Christmas,'' he said.
Mr. Domenici had said that the plan might not be ready until spring.
But the blackout on Aug. 14 gave new urgency to the measure, and lawmakers had been aiming to complete it by the end of this month.

Although Senate aides rejected the idea, the threat to delay the conference was viewed by people following the negotiations as an effort by Mr. Domenici to force House members led by Representative Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana, to give ground on some positions or risk seeing the measure unravel.
A prominent resident of this bedroom community west of Denver recently gave the town a scruffy five-acre strip of abandoned clay pits, once used for making bricks.
Local officials are planning to include it in Golden's first public 18-hole golf course.
Now, if they could just do something about William T. Caneer.
Mr. Caneer is a retired geologist who is fascinated by dinosaurs.
Long ago, this part of Colorado was flush with them, and judging by tracks discovered here in the 1980's the clay pits were part of their itinerary.
To some scientists, including Mr. Caneer, the footprints are priceless, dating from a time perhaps 60 million years ago when dinosaurs were dying out.
Along with other dinosaur tracks and bones, believed to be 150 million years old, discovered 10 miles away in Morrison, Colo., the clay pit tracks ''represent the end of the era,'' Mr. Caneer said.
So it galls him that plans for the golf course are proceeding without efforts to preserve all the footprints, which have been found at five sites  on the land.

City officials say they intend to preserve three sites, including one that contains four tracks from the same four-toed triceratops, a 5 1/2-ton, 39-foot-long beast, as well as sharp impressions of ancient palm fronds.
But the two other sites, near the 13th tee, will be buried ''as a way to preserve them,'' said Vince Auriemma, the city's deputy director of public works.

To the Editor: Your first article in "The Bush Record" series (front page, June 25) singles out the President's handling of China policy as an area where his approach has failed and states that conciliation after the 1989 events in Tiananmen Square produced no tangible results.
This is untrue.
China released some political prisoners and allowed some dissidents to leave the country.
More important, it is again embarked on reform and openness, perhaps more forcefully than before.
It is to Mr. Bush's credit that his Administration has tried to work with China, rather than isolate it.
Imagine what a nonconciliatory or, worse, a hostile policy would do.
China would have stepped up its repression of political dissent, and the hard-liners would have an excuse to slow down, if not nullify, the reforms.
To be sure, China's human rights record leaves much to be desired.
Pressure can produce results, and the Bush Administration has quietly put pressure on China.
The United States is the only Western power that has not yet fully normalized relations with China.
Downtown Jamaica is facing a paradox.
Thousands of people each year take overnight buses from around the Northeast to scoop up the inexpensive, urban-style goods found in its stores.
But many shoppers who live right next door to Jamaica, in places like St. Albans and Hollis, don't go there.
Instead they drive to the Green Acres Shopping Mall in Valley Stream, L.I. The reason is a shortage of parking that itself poses a paradox.
The more that local groups like the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation stimulate economic growth by improving parking, the more parking is needed.
The cycle began in the late 90's, when the city ran the area's parking stock of two garages and two lots.
Lamont Bailey, a board member of the development corporation, said the lots were dirty and the garages poorly lighted. ''
On top of that,'' he added, ''the 103rd Precinct, which was right next door, took up half the spaces in one of the lots.''
The city wanted to privatize the operations, but local businesses feared higher prices.
So the corporation offered to fix up and operate the facilities, charging lower rates as a nonprofit group, and paying taxes to the city in the bargain.
The Boston Celtics' coaches had spent countless hours studying film, scouting every tendency, to find a way to slow down the offensive schemes of the Nets, who use a system made famous at Princeton.
But as much as the Nets' intricate offense hurt Boston, it was the defenses that had been relegated to the college and high school levels until this season that confounded the Celtics.
The Nets' zone slowed the Celtics' offense and put an end to their season.
Zone defenses were legalized by the N.B.A. this season, and the Nets turned to a variety of them against Boston.
That was a tactic rarely employed by the Nets and most other teams during the regular season.
But the Nets used the zone as a changeup, confusing the Celtics on Friday night just long enough to turn Game 6 and the Eastern Conference championship series in their favor. ''
I thought it bothered them a lot,'' Nets Coach Byron Scott said. ''
I thought it enabled us to get back into the game.
Sometimes I go with it because I know they have a nice little rhythm going, a nice little flow in their offense, and I want to disrupt that. ''
I'll stay in it as long as they're not scoring.
Taiwan's government has stunned its freewheeling news media by seeking to ban a weekly magazine that was about to publish an article potentially damaging to the island's president, Chen Shui-bian.

Declaring that the article contained information that would jeopardize Taiwan's national security, the police and prosecutors confiscated 160,000 copies of Next magazine, after searching its offices and the home of one of its reporters.

Despite the raid, Next has been able to distribute 220,000 copies of the magazine, which reports on a secret $100 million fund reportedly used by the former president, Lee Teng-hui, and officials in the current government for diplomatic missions and policy initiatives.

Tsai Chao-ming, the head of Taiwan's intelligence agency, the National Security Bureau, said the article contained information that ''reveals international cooperation networks and threatens the security of our employees.''
Journalists dismissed that claim, and accused the government of trying to suppress an article it knew would embarrass Mr. Chen.
The crackdown has alarmed the news media in Taiwan, which has become a boisterous symbol of the island's evolution from a police state to one of Asia's most vibrant democracies. ''
It's pure intimidation,'' said Sun Yang-ming, a senior reporter at The United Daily News, a leading newspaper in Taipei.
Taiwan's move is the latest gust in an ill wind that is blowing on journalists across Asia.
Thailand recently threatened to expel two foreign correspondents for writing about tension between the country's king and the prime minister.
It also investigated the bank accounts of Thai editors deemed to be critical of the prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra.
How many lives did Melido Perez have tonight against the Red Sox?
How many pitches did his right arm have?
How many Yankees were finally smiling after another one-run game was completed at Fenway Park?

The answers are several lives for the shifty Perez, 140 pitches for the durable Perez and 25 Yankee players beaming because the stopper named Perez helped them erase a 4-0 deficit, snatch a 5-4 victory from Boston and avoid a sweep in the four-game series.
All six games between the teams this year have been decided by one run.
How dreary did it look for the Yankees when Perez walked three batters and allowed three hits as Boston eased to a 3-0 lead in the first?
So dreary that Shawn Hillegas was warming up.

Oil prices climbed more than $1.50 a barrel on the futures market yesterday, but then lost a large part of that gain in after-hours trading when a news report indicated that Iraq might leave Kuwait.
The benchmark grade of crude oil settled at $30.66 a barrel, up $1.51, at the New York Mercantile Exchange on contracts for January delivery.
Later contract months all settled higher, mostly by more than $1 a barrel.
But soon after the Mercantile Exchange had closed for the day, oil traders were jolted by a British television news report indicating that Iraq might have a plan for pulling its army out of Kuwait.

Sky television news said Iraq might be ready to withdraw from most of Kuwait if it is allowed to keep the disputed Rumaila oilfield and if it received a guarantee that Western forces would not attack.
A State Department official said the United States was unaware of any such Iraqi position.
Prices for petroleum at loading platforms and docks, commonly called the cash or spot market, tumbled by more than $1 a barrel minutes after the Mercantile Exchange closed, traders said.
The cash market ordinarily follows the behavior of prices in the futures market at the exchange. "
That's a lot," said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. "They usually don't move as dramatically as on the futures market."

In early afternoon trading on the exchange, oil prices had fallen on a report indicating that Kuwait might be willing to negotiate on the future of some of its islands if Iraq withdrew its troops, which invaded the country on Aug. 2.
ENCYCLOPEDIA PREQUEL -- In another example of the Internet turning academic publishing on its head, MacMillan Reference is pre-releasing parts of its massive Encyclopedia of Life Sciences on the Web.

The encyclopedia won't be completed until 2001, but in September 1999, MacMillan will begin previewing more than 700 articles in an electronic version, the Embryonic E.L.S. (www.macmillan-reference.co.uk).
That will let academics and scientists  participate in the evolution of what MacMillan is calling ''the most ambitious reference source ever to be published in the biological sciences.''
AIMING HIGHER -- Is technology education in decline in the United States?

It might seem so after a glance at a recent report from the American Electronics Association that found a 5 percent drop in the number of math, physics, engineering and computer science degrees from 1990 to 1996.
A closer look, however, reveals many signs of good health.
Most of the decline is due to a drop in associate and bachelor degrees: Master's degrees are up 10 percent and Ph.D.'s up 29 percent.
The report also found an increase in the number of advanced high school technology courses.
So what happened to those undergraduate dropouts?
The report didn't speculate, but a few of them may be software millionaires by now.

Charles Rosen and Rolf Schulte Kathryn Bache Miller Theater The pianist Charles Rosen and the violinist Rolf Schulte opened Columbia University's Music Uptown series on Tuesday night with works by Arnold Schoenberg, Elliott Carter and Donald Martino.
One could not ask for players with stronger affinities for this music.
Mr. Schulte has devoted himself almost exclusively to 20th-century music over the last 20 years.
Mr. Rosen's horizons have been notably broader, but his associations in the post-Schoenberg world are strong, and he has been an eloquent advocate of Mr. Carter's work.
The players were well into their opening work, the Schoenberg Phantasy (Op.
47), though, before Mr. Schulte settled in fully, and the first part of the work was laced with intonation problems.
In a way, those early flaws provided a certain excitement by making it clear that the evening would not be one of clinical dissections.
Here and also in the Carter Duo that concluded the program, Mr. Schulte's playing was fiery and passionate and often seemed to be at the edge of a precipice.
Mr. Rosen offered a more firmly rooted counterpart, which mirrored the violin line's live-wire emotionalism without losing sight of structure.

On his own, Mr. Schulte played Mr. Carter's "Riconoscenza per Goffredo Petrassi," a virtuosic work that contrasts chordal themes with anxious, angular solo lines, and sweet-toned melodies with violent bursts.

In her blackest moments, Loretta Ann Rosales can recall what it felt like as electrodes were tied to her fingers and toes, her body doubled over in a muscle-numbing convulsion from the jolt of electric current.
It was only the start of an interrogation by Philippine soldiers in August 1976.
A rug was draped over her head and water dripped on it, so that she began to gasp for breath as the damp rug molded itself to her face.
She was molested by her interrogators. "

I can still smell them," said Mrs. Rosales, whose account of her torture is confirmed by other witnesses, her tale little different from that offered by thousands of other human rights victims in the 1970's and 1980's.
She avoided being raped, she said, "only because I was having my period."

For nearly two decades, Mrs. Rosales has waited for an apology and some sort of compensation from the family of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, the dictator who directed his soldiers to imprison and torture thousands of suspected leftists and others.
Mrs. Rosales, now 56, will probably never hear that apology.

But to the surprise of many Filipinos who thought the victims of the Marcos tyranny would never see a penny of the late dictator's ill-gotten fortune, the long wait for compensation may finally be over.

A sizable chunk of the Marcos loot has been located in Switzerland and is apparently on its way home to this destitute nation, to be shared between the Government and nearly 10,000 Filipinos who asserted in court that they were the victims of rights abuses in the Marcos era.
