The Islanders took sole possession of the eighth playoff position by coupling two straight victories for the first time since last month with the Rangers' loss Monday at Boston.
For two periods, a charitable Islanders defense kept goalie Rick DiPietro busy.
FOCACCIA, a type of Italian flat bread that was virtually unknown in this country five years ago, has taken America by storm.
Italian restaurants offer it in the breadbasket and some bakeries prepare it with assorted toppings.
Stale focaccia, sliced and toasted, becomes Genoa toast, a type of Italian melba toast.
Few breads are simpler to make.
Focaccia essentially involves preparing a type of pizza dough, rolling it out, topping it with some seasonings and serving it warm or reheated.
Focaccia is actually good for almost any occasion.
A flat of focaccia covered with artfully arranged tomato or mushroom slices makes an arresting appetizer to cut in squares and serve at cocktail time.
It is also suitable for lunch, with a salad, or, with enough topping, as a first course at dinner.
Even breakfast focaccia is a possibility, with cheese or smoked salmon.
And with a simple dusting of herbs it can replace bread.
COOL mist from the nearby Caucasus Mountains enveloped the stately Sveti-tskhoveli Cathedral as a bus full of Orthodox monks pulled up in front one afternoon last spring.
After stepping off, they formed a single file led by the local bishop.
Bearded and clad in flowing robes, they walked slowly around the cathedral, their chants adding to the evocative spirituality that surrounds this place.
After completing their circuit, the monks entered the cathedral and greeted priests inside.

As they offered a benediction beneath the frescoes and towering dome, three young nuns beside the altar began to sing in lilting harmony, sounding as if they could compete with any doo-wop combo in the world.
A while later the monks filed out, stopping to kiss gold-framed icons of Georgian saints.
A mystic aura hangs over Sveti-tskhoveli, about 15 miles north of Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia, and over the many other churches and monasteries that dot Georgia's verdant countryside.
During a 10-day trip there, I made a special effort to visit these sites.
Taken together, Georgia's famous religious buildings constitute a magnificent  architectural and ecclesiastical heritage.

Their ascetic facades, great domes, towering round spires, intricate relief sculptures and majestic interiors have made them a central part of the Georgian consciousness, contributing to a sense of nationhood that has held this land together through successive invasions and conquests.
EVERYTHING has come down -- prices, profit margins, everything," said Leo D.  Fakler, an architect in Fresh Meadows, Queens, who for years has been designing  houses for Queens builders.
Although this has been true for at least six years, it triggered a modest revival of home building in Queens only a year or two ago, the builders say.
Now it is possible to drive through Flushing, Bayside, College Point and other erstwhile centers of spot development and see sites with two or three two-family houses in construction.
Because land prices are down by as much as 30 percent, buyers are paying less for new houses now than they did in the 80's.

The new mode of construction  is an old standby, the two-family house -- usually a lower level plus a basement and garage level for the owner, and an upper-level apartment for a renter or relative -- rather than the three-family condominiums of the 80's.
And gone is the house that was overtly designed for three-family use despite  its illegality in the low-density zones -- the celebrated Illegal Three. "
Builders won't touch it," said Ralph E. Price, a Flushing land broker. (
He was  less confident that buyers won't sometimes install a kitchen and bath at the garage level to allow an additional renter in.
There are sometimes about 400 square feet available that could be used for the purpose.)
What has not changed is the conventionality of the housing design, seemingly  locked in place by the rules of zoning and the preferences of purchasers.
Tiny has always been just that.
He's 14 years old and about four feet tall.
His gray Levi's hang off him despite the belt he wears wrapped around his waist twice.
He looks about 8, and no one would suspect him of inflicting harm.
That's one of the reasons Tiny -- as his street name is translated -- makes an effective assassin.
I met Tiny one afternoon not long ago in Medellin, Colombia.
He strutted up to me on the street and stood on his toes to kiss my cheek.
Then he handed me two warm Chiclets.
I had come to Colombia to report on a legal loophole in its Minor's Code that allows kids under 18 to kill without being held responsible.
After weeks of trying to persuade gang bosses to let me spend time with their young charges, I was finally introduced to Tiny, who told me his story over the next six weeks.

In 1852 a wealthy Mississippi cotton planter, Robert Hairston, suddenly fell ill.
With death overtaking him, he frantically dictated a will in which he revealed that he had a child, his only one, a 5-year-old girl who was a slave.
With his last breath he commanded his family to have the girl set free and bequeathed to her his entire estate -- land, cash and slaves worth over $1 million.
Hairston's white relatives, all quite wealthy, could not bear to see that much money pass to a black.
They decided to make her disappear and divided up her property among themselves.
To cover their tracks, they called the father a lunatic and stuck to that story for generations.
They told a judge the girl was dead and sent her off to a distant plantation.
One hundred and sixty years later, while researching a book, I discovered through court records and oral history in the area what had really happened.
This tale of theft on a massive scale has a deeper significance; it reveals some of the psyche of the masters.
The white family could never claim they did not know what they were doing, that through some defect in their perception they did not comprehend that this slave was a human being.

Not all immunity is equal.
Having been granted what lawyers call transactional immunity, Monica S. Lewinsky is off the hook as long as she tells the truth.
With transactional immunity, which prosecutors give only when they want someone's testimony very badly, Ms. Lewinsky cannot be prosecuted for the wrongdoing she testifies about.
To put it another way, she is safe not only from being incriminated by her own words, but also from the words of others.
That last point is crucial in understanding the difference between transactional immunity and the more common use immunity.
When granted use immunity, witnesses may not be incriminated by their own testimony, nor are prosecutors supposed to use that testimony to gather other evidence against witnesses.
But prosecutors can and do use other avenues to gather evidence against witnesses who have use immunity.
A quarter-century ago, more than two dozen witnesses were granted use immunity so they would testify before a Senate committee investigating the Watergate scandal.

Two of the most important witnesses, John W. Dean 3d, President Richard M. Nixon's White House counsel, and Jeb Stuart Magruder, deputy director of the Nixon re-election committee, then pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice.
Prosecutors had gathered plenty of evidence against them before their Senate testimony.

President Bush's call for a mandate to use force if necessary to provide relief supplies in the Balkan conflict has opened a three-way split at the United Nations over the role of its peacekeeping forces in the region, diplomats and United Nations officials say.

While the United States has pressed for blanket authorization from the Security Council for the use of force to insure that relief supplies get through, Britain and France favor a more graduated response that would initially authorize light military protection for the supply convoys.

At the same time, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and his staff oppose involving the United Nations any more deeply in the Balkan conflict and say that its forces there cannot simultaneously act as peacekeepers and enforcers of the peace.
The Secretary General has also accused the Council of overspending the organization's resources in Balkan conflict while neglecting third-world crisis spots like Somalia.
And he said European countries should do more to end this European conflict.

Talks on resolving the dispute over how force should be used to get relief supplies to Bosnia's besieged civilians continued here today involving the United States and Britain and France, and President Bush and his top aides also consulted with their counterparts in foreign capitals.
Diplomats agreed with President Bush's prediction, made at a press conference in Kennebunkport, Me.,
today, that those three permanent members of the Council would reach a compromise proposal.
The diplomats at the United Nations said they expected to see a proposal by Monday that would be given to Russia and China, the other two permanent members with a veto on decisions.
Once all five permanent Council members have a joint position they will present it to the remaining 10 rotating members.

Just as business travelers are becoming accustomed to security lines, baggage restrictions and the other vexations of flying in an era of heightened security -- or at least, just as they are beginning to think things cannot get worse -- the familiar old headache of flight delays is throbbing again.
More than 400,000 flights have been delayed or canceled so far this year, more than one of every five that take off, according to the federal Bureau of Transportation Statistics.
Delayed flights -- defined as those reaching their destinations more than 15 minutes behind schedule -- have increased 34 percent so far this year from the corresponding period of 2003.
That reverses a two-and-a-half-year trend of fewer delays set in motion as airlines cut back service and passenger traffic fell sharply.

Weather, as always, is a major reason for delays and diversions, but the Federal Aviation Administration says that reviving air traffic and a shift toward smaller planes are also contributing to the problem. ''

Last week, it took me 18 hours to get back from Phoenix'' to New York, said Francesca Raminella, the general manager in New York of Matrix USA, a unit of L'Oreal that makes hair-care products for salons.
Because of bad weather, her flight was diverted first to Chicago and then to Philadelphia, she said.
Rather than wait for the plane to complete the trip to New York, she said, ''I finally got in a car and drove because it didn't make much sense to keep going up and down.''

Today, with passenger loads again increasing, the chances of experiencing an unexpected wait are approaching the levels of the ''summer from hell'' in 2000, when one in four flights was delayed, canceled or diverted.
At 10 big hub airports, including O'Hare in Chicago and McCarran in Las Vegas, peak-hour traffic has already surpassed summer 2000 levels, the F.A.A. says.
This once independent city-state, proud of its reputation as an outpost of Islam in Asia, has lived an uneasy existence within Buddhist Thailand for more than a century.
The restless peace here and in the surrounding region in southern Thailand has been severely strained after the burning of schools, the killing of Buddhist monks and an assault on an army camp.
The government says the attacks were carried out by Islamic militants in a region that in the last decade has become visibly more influenced by Islam from the Middle East.

But some experts say that it is not so simple and that the government may have made mistakes in administering the region that enabled militants and criminal elements to create religious tension for their own purposes.
Now, police officers in black jumpsuits squat in the back of pickup trucks, automatic weapons at the ready, as they patrol the streets.
Public school teachers carry handguns.
A prominent Muslim university professor, Peerayot Rahimulla, who is trying to help calm the tense atmosphere, travels everywhere with a bodyguard. ''
We don't know who's who,'' said Professor Peerayot, who teaches regional studies at the Prince of Songkhla University, as he left a meeting on a recent day trailed by his protector.

For Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, who wants to make Thailand the engine of economic growth in Southeast Asia, the unrest in these majority Muslim southern provinces is an embarrassment at home and abroad.
Almost all of Thailand's estimated six million Muslims -- of Thailand's 66 million people -- live in the fishing and rubber-growing provinces bordering Malaysia, which is predominantly Muslim.

Tiptoeing through the thickets of Britain's ambiguous relationship with Europe, the Government revived its support for the euro single currency today without venturing away from its caution about joining.
Robin Cook, the Foreign Secretary, chose a business audience in Japan -- a major source of investment in Britain -- to laud the eight-month-old currency as a positive economic force. ''
It's too early to reach a firm view,'' Mr. Cook said, ''but already there are signs that the euro is bringing a new strength to the economies that are part of it.''
Anywhere else, such remarks might be depicted as innocuous.
But the euro is a deeply divisive issue here, and the Labor Government is worried that it could forfeit its broad electoral support by pushing British voters too fast toward joining it.

Britain remained on the sidelines when the euro was introduced last January, saying it would consider joining only if economic conditions seemed propitious and only if British voters approved the idea in a referendum after the next general election, which must be held in May 2002 at the latest.

Since then, the Government's apparent support for the idea has been jolted, first by European parliamentary elections in June, when the Conservative opposition scored surprising gains with an anti-euro ticket, and by what seem to be stubborn economic differences between the Continent and Britain.
Most significantly, British benchmark interest rates are twice as high as those in the countries that use the euro.
Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, has said the economic gap would make British membership risky.
Even though Mr. Cook's remarks in Tokyo seemed almost hesitant, skeptics on the euro immediately labeled them extremist.
From the start, safety Jon McGraw noticed something different at Jets training camp.
A roster with nearly four-fifths of the players having fewer than five years of professional experience meant an infusion of youth and energy at practices.
And for veterans, the arrival of the youngsters meant competition. ''
The last couple of years, we've had such a veteran football team a lot of the jobs were secure coming in,'' said McGraw, a third-year player. ''
And when you know that, there's this tendency to get into that cruise control and do what you're supposed to do, but maybe not go quite as hard you can.

Everyone's been having that sense of urgency about themselves.''
It remains to be seen how well the Jets' rookies, especially on defense, will fare in the regular season.
But they have already made their presence felt by seemingly energizing veterans and inspiring a couple of the most intense battles for jobs in years.
Entering the final week of the preseason, at least two rookies, safety Erik Coleman and linebacker Jonathan Vilma, are serious contenders for starting jobs.

Drawing up a partition for peace is admittedly a tricky business, but it can work -- provided each party gives the other what it needs: sovereignty, security and a workable arrangement for building a state.
Although securing partitions in places like Bosnia and Kosovo is not easy, one can at least see on a map how such an arrangement could work.
The question is, can President Clinton's recently offered partition plan bring peace to Israelis and Palestinians?
Does the geography allow it?
It's hard to see how.
Because of security needs, Israel cannot grant the Palestinians a truly independent state of their own.
Without a viable state, however, the Palestinians will not agree to end the conflict.
American commentators have painted the Clinton plan as fairly generous to the Palestinians.
After all, Palestinians would control roughly 95 percent of the West Bank and all of the Gaza Strip, including Palestinian neighborhoods in East Jerusalem.
Palestinians would also have some jurisdiction over important holy sites in Jerusalem.
In a Jets locker room in which Otis Smith grimaced and Vinny Testaverde and Leon Johnson hobbled around on crutches, Wayne Chrebet today wore his broadest smile in a month.

IN the last year and a half, at least four Southern-style restaurants have opened in Manhattan.
Each has a different approach, as defined by their owners and chefs.
But none is pure Ma and Pa's home cooking.
What unites the four restaurants is that their sources -- recipes, flavors and memories -- are from the South.
Some of the recipes were passed from generation to generation, changing only slightly over time.
Others have been transformed.
Lard, along with salt and sugar, have all but disappeared at Toukie's in the West Village.
At Mekka on the Lower East Side, cheese sneaks its way into the mashed potatoes, while at Cafe Beulah, in the Flatiron district, rosemary flecks yeasty biscuits.
At the Savannah Club, on the Upper West Side, sweet potatoes seasoned with cinnamon, nutmeg and allspice are whipped into butter.
The food at the Savannah Club (2420 Broadway, near 89th Street) is prepared by two chefs, one self-taught in the black soul-food tradition, the other professionally trained in Paris.

Ten days after the incident touched off a melee between the Mets and the Braves at Shea Stadium, Mets outfielder John Cangelosi was suspended for four games by the National League today for charging the mound after he was hit by a pitch from John Smoltz of Atlanta.
Smoltz, who had yielded a grand slam to the previous batter, Ryan Thompson, was suspended for eight games for intentionally hitting Cangelosi, guaranteeing that he will miss a start.

Four days is crazy.

Theodore McCarty, president of Gibson guitars in the 1950's and 60's and designer of iconic models revered by the likes of Carl Perkins and B B. King, died on Sunday at a retirement center in Twin Falls, Idaho.
He was 91.
Mr. McCarty earned an engineering degree and later worked for Wurlitzer as an accountant and a merchandise manager.
In 1948 he moved to Gibson as head of the company.
When he began, Gibson had 150 employees; when he left 18 years later it had nearly 10 times as many and sales had increased by more than 1,000 percent.
Mr. McCarty pursued the expanding market for electric guitars, some say at the expense of the quality of Gibson's acoustic guitars.
A result of this interest was the creation, during his tenure, of electric guitar models that remain among the most widely sold today -- the Les Paul, ES-335, Flying V, Explorer and Firebird.
He also introduced innovative guitar devices, including an intonation adjuster. ''
He was the only guy in guitar history who was both a hands-on designer as well as a company manager,'' said Walter Carter, a former historian for Gibson.

The company started designing the solid-bodied Les Paul in 1950, when country-western musicians had begun using solid-bodied electric guitars for their brighter tone, which could cut through a loud dance-band ensemble.
Isiah Thomas continued his dramatic reconstruction of the Knicks yesterday by dismissing Coach Don Chaney, who had failed to come anywhere near a winning record in two-plus seasons with the team.

Seeing the bottom line that was dropping lower every day, Thomas replaced him with Lenny Wilkens, a member of the basketball Hall of Fame and the coach with the most career victories, and defeats, in the National Basketball Association.
Chaney's departure was painful, and at times almost humiliating.
He was left to preside over the team's morning practice session yesterday despite widespread speculation that a replacement for him had been found.
Late yesterday afternoon, the 57-year-old Chaney reported for work at Madison Square Garden -- where fans had chanted ''Fire Chaney!''
in recent games -- only to be informed at 5:15 p.m., two hours before the Knicks were to play the Orlando Magic, that he no longer had his job.
Chaney, carrying his black work bag, walked out of the Garden with his wife, Jackie.
They were escorted by two Knicks officials.

Moments later, Chaney's top assistant coaches, Brendan Malone and Lon Kruger, arrived at the coaches' office at the Garden, whereupon Thomas, the team's president of basketball operations, told them that they, too, had been fired.
In bringing in Wilkens, 66, Thomas is turning to a respected N.B.A. figure who was born in Brooklyn and starred at Boys High 50 years ago.
With all the hype about corporate computer break-ins, is it any wonder the insurance industry is getting into the act?

The International Computer Security Association, which is not really an association but a for-profit corporation, says it is working with several insurance carriers to sell policies that would insure corporations in the event an intruder wreaks havoc on their computer systems.
The catch, however, is that before a customer can obtain a policy from I.C.S.A. or another carrier it must first earn the I.C.S.A. ''True Secure'' seal.
That means, in other words, they first have to be a customer of I.C.S.A.'s computer security services.
I.C.S.A., based in Carlisle, Pa., declined to discuss details of the program, saying it wanted to brief the news media later this week.

I.C.S.A., like I.B.M.'s ''Ethical Hacker'' service announced earlier this year, along with several other security companies, operates by unleashing programmers to break into a customer's computer system to find its vulnerable spots.
And such spots there are.

The Computer Security Institute, a nonprofit research group in San Francisco, reported this spring that 24 percent of respondents to its annual security survey said they had experienced a computer break-in from the outside last year.
An additional 44 percent reported unauthorized access to their systems by employees.
But while interest in selling hacker insurance is on the rise, not everyone is ready to go along.
Rudulph Ellis Carter, a former Foreign Service officer and a political adviser in the United States Mission to the United Nations, died last Tuesday in Newport Hospital in Rhode Island.
A summer resident of Newport, he was 68 and lived in Dallas.
The cause was cancer, his family said.
Mr. Carter joined the State Department in 1951.
His foreign assignments included Stockholm and London.
During his time at the United Nations from 1969 to 1977, he served as an aide to George Bush when he was the American delegate to the United Nations.
A native of Bryn Mawr, Pa., Mr. Carter graduated from the Groton School and the University of Pennsylvania.
He was president of the United States Croquet Association, representing 350 clubs in North America.
He served as United States representative to the World Croquet Federation in London and in 1992 helped to bring the World Championships to this country for the first time.
He was elected to the Croquet Hall of Fame in April.
IF you're tired of New York's post-Sept.
11 halo, if you're sick of all the nice things that other Americans have been saying about us, pick up the June issue of The American Enterprise.
The magazine is devoted to New York City, and to what they really think of us out there.
The magazine, published by the conservative American Enterprise Institute in Washington, does not rhapsodize about the great links between New York and the heartland.
Instead, it asks whether a multitude of American flags would be on display in downtown Manhattan if the planes on Sept. 11 had crashed not in New York but Philadelphia or Boise. ''
I think we all know the answer,'' writes Bill Kauffman, an associate editor at the magazine who lives near Attica and remembers the reaction to the prison uprising there three decades ago. ''
The widows and orphans of the slain guards were not showered with flowers and quilts and charitable millions by the touched hearts of Manhattan,'' he writes. ''
Whatever kindnesses we in the hinterlands have extended to Manhattan in the wake of that black day in September are emphatically not in return for past favors.''
Of course, you wouldn't expect a conservative magazine to look uncritically at New York.
This is the same publication, after all, that hailed Gerald Ford as a savior of urban America for telling us to drop dead. (
REGARDLESS of what the traditional calendar indicates, summer officially begins next weekend with the 23rd Annual Strawberry Park Bluegrass Festival in Preston.

Operating under the shadow of the larger Winterhawk Festival (which will be held July 28, 29, 30 at Long Hill Farm just outside Hillsdale, N.Y.), Strawberry Park Bluegrass Festival offers 20 hours of live entertainment, as well as instrumental workshops both Saturday and Sunday. ''
We've been growing steadily through the years,'' said Buck Biber, owner of Strawberry Park and its festivals organizer. ''
It's as big as anything we do.''
Mr. Biber has assembled a dozen acts to keep bluegrass music flowing through the 77-acre campground from 6 p.m. Friday through 5 p.m. Sunday.

This year's performers include Amy Gallatin, Blueridge, Breakaway, Dry Branch Fire Squad, Jonathan Edwards, Laurie Lewis and her Bluegrass Pals, the Lonesome River Band, Ralph Stanley, Ryan Holladay, the Seldom Scene, Shankman Twins and Traver Hollow.
Since few families can live for three days on bluegrass alone, the rest of the park's recreational attractions will operate in full swing.
Situated about 10 minutes from the Foxwoods Resorts Casino, Strawberry Park accommodates campers, day visitors and offers a variety of athletic events for the family.
Perhaps the biggest-name act on the roster is Ralph Stanley, widely recognized as a bluegrass living legend.
Mr. Stanley, 73, and his brother Carter began working in 1946 and developed their band the Stanley Brothers and the Clinch Mountain Boys.
As The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund nears the end of its annual drive, Wednesday's mail brought an envelope stuffed with hundreds of checks from Wall Street financial analysts.
The gifts, which totaled $93,972.80, put the fund's 1990-91 drive about $50,000 ahead of the amount raised at this time last year.

But with 11 days left in the appeal, it is difficult to predict whether the fund will collect the $133,000 needed to surpass the previous drive's total -- the largest amount raised in the fund's 79-year history.
Since mid-January, the fund has received half the number of donations it did last year in the same period.
Charity officials and fund-raising experts attributed the decline to layoffs and concerns about the recession.
And they said that some potential donors were probably distracted by the war in the Persian Gulf.
But they added that these conditions did not necessarily mean a drop in fund raising for the Neediest Cases and other charities. "

There are fewer people with money to give, but the rest now feel more compelled to contribute," said Jimmie Alford, the chairman of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel Trust for Philanthropy.
The donations that arrived last week from Wall Street may be a case in point: an example of how a bad economy can actually increase donations.
The gifts were collected and sent by the Financial Analysts Seminar Committee, a group that organizes seminars on professional topics for employees of Wall Street investment-banking firms.
Free-Roaming Chickens in Town The newest chickens in town are from Murray's Chickens of the Amish country in Pennsylvania.
They take eight weeks to reach market weight, compared with six weeks for regular commercial chickens, and have excellent flavor and texture.
Gray Kunz of Lespinasse, one of several Manhattan chefs who have tried the chickens, was impressed. "
We have not had a whole roasted chicken but we might with these," he said.
Murray's, which are bred without hormones or antibiotics, are called free-roaming rather than free-range chickens.
The Agriculture Department says free roaming applies to chickens kept indoors in the winter.
A free-range chicken must have access to the outdoors all year.

Murray's Chickens, $1.79 to $2 a pound, are available at a number of markets, including Broadway Butcher, 2446 Broadway (at 90th Street); Todaro Brothers, 555 Second Avenue (at 31st Street), and Dean & DeLuca, 560 Broadway (Prince Street).

At Les Friandises, 972 Lexington Avenue, a cake for six to eight people is $25.
IT'S the bottleneck that bedevils businesses everywhere: the ''last mile'' of wire connecting offices to a phone company's switching station.
In most of America, one carrier -- typically a Bell company -- maintains the high-capacity data and calls over that route, which means little competition and high prices.

But Lou Slaughter, the chief executive of GigaBeam, a technology company in Herndon, Va., has come up with an alternative: millimeter-wave technology, which transmits data over wireless connections at one gigabit per second -- 1,000 times as fast as a D.S.L. connection. ''
Anywhere you want capacity and you don't want to install fiber, you can use our technology,'' said Mr. Slaughter, whose company went public in October 2004. ''
We could carry all of a company's traffic in Manhattan and get it to New Jersey without touching the ground.''
The idea of commercial high-speed wireless connections is not new.
Companies like Sprint, Winstar and Teligent made stabs at developing similar line-of-sight technology a few years ago, but the projects were stopped for various reasons.
GigaBeam's proprietary technology, though, may be a more elegant -- and potentially more durable -- solution.

Unlike many other high-speed wireless technologies, including Wi-Fi and WiMax, GigaBeam's pencil-thin signals travel over licensed spectrum, which is regulated and thus requires paying fees and much paperwork.
Using this spectrum also means that GigaBeam's signals do not interfere with other signals and are thus more secure.

He was rusty and tight, but Montana gave himself a passing grade after throwing for more than an hour during a minicamp. "

It was a little different having to throw the ball with timing.
I almost tripped over my feet a few times, but other than that, I felt good about the session."
Montana, who will turn 36 years old in June, has been tossing the ball lightly since January, but today marked the first time he threw to receivers running routes against defensive backs.
He threw at least one pass of 40 yards. "
It was basically a test for me," he said. "

I've been doing the throwing, and I knew that my arm could handle it, but there's always that one time where you have to drop back and have to throw it a little quicker and with more torque on your arm.
BILL Ryall, a Manhattan architect, is about to build an addition to a client's house on Shelter Island, at the east end of Long Island.
In the living room, a series of sliding glass panels, each eight feet wide, will disappear into a wall. ''
The effect,'' he said, ''will be dramatic.''
But the windows Mr. Ryall wants to use have not been proven to resist flying debris, a requirement of residential building codes in effect on eastern Long Island since 2003.
To comply, a sample window would have to withstand a ''missile test,'' deflecting a two-by-four fired at the speed of 50 feet a second.
After Hurricane Andrew caused billions of dollars in property damage in 1992, Dade County, Fla., began requiring wind-resistant windows in new houses.
The requirement was incorporated into residential building codes adopted, with some amendments, by Florida, Texas, South Carolina, Georgia, New York, New Jersey and Rhode Island.
In those states, hurricane-resistant windows are required in houses built in many coastal areas.
The windows are made from layers of glass laminated onto sheets of plastic. ''

The idea is to keep the building envelope secure,'' said Anthony Head, the regulatory product planner for Marvin Windows and Doors, a manufacturer in Warroad, Minn. Not surprisingly, insurance companies favor the rules, because broken windows can lead to extensive damage inside.

Community leaders in Harlem walked up and down 125th Street yesterday, seeking to calm shoppers and store owners in the wake of a racially motivated arson attack on Friday that destroyed a white-owned clothing store and left eight people dead, including the attacker.
During their tour, they made a point of stopping at the white-owned Bargain World.

City Councilwoman C. She said that the timing of the protest bothered her. "
Given the tragedy that had just happened, and people grieving and sorting things out and working together for the harmony of business, I was very concerned," Ms. Fields said.
She also said that others had expressed concern. "
We had received some calls from several of the businesses out there regarding safety issues," she said. "
Carol Blazejowski raised a few eyebrows at the first Women's National Basketball Association draft in 1997.

Blazejowski was the new general manager of the Liberty, one of the eight charter members of the W.N.B.A. With her first four picks, Blazejowski chose Teresa Weatherspoon, Kym Hampton, Sue Wicks and Sophia Witherspoon.
To her, they were seasoned veterans, with experience playing overseas.
In the eyes of some other professionals, the four were has-beens. ''

This was a whole new experience,'' said Blazejowski, who rounded out the roster by selecting Vickie Johnson, a promising young guard with a year of pro experience in France, and by signing Rebecca Lobo, the University of Connecticut star who was assigned to the Liberty by the league. ''
I felt if we were going to get out of the box quick, we had to go with people who knew pressure; people that were proven.
I didn't care about how old they were.

They had played a certain number of years overseas, so they were flexible, amenable to change and would probably thrive best under this new experience instead of a bunch of youngsters out of college.''
Blazejowski's instincts proved right.
That first year, the Liberty advanced to the W.N.B.A. championship game, where it lost to the Houston Comets.
From a Ranger fan's perspective, Referee Bill McCreary could have been named one of the three stars of last night's game.
And if the New Yorkers indeed make the playoffs, McCreary might just deserve an assist, as well.
In another must-win situation for the Rangers, it was a McCreary non-call that not only enraged Washington Coach Jim Schoenfeld, but also allowed the Rangers to score their second goal.
McCreary noticed Schoenfeld complaining, however, and assessed the Capitals a two-minute bench infraction.
Forty-six seconds later, the Rangers had a power-play goal, and a 3-0 lead at 6 minutes 25 seconds of the first period.
The Rangers would extend their lead to 5-1 in the second period and then nearly squandered it, holding on for a 5-4 victory at Madison Square Garden. "
I felt it was a miscall," said Schoenfeld. "
And then, when your players are being injured, like Calle Johansson was, you have to at least bring it to the referee's attention."
McCreary refused to comment afterward but his non-call figured strongly in the game's outcome.

With the Rangers leading by 1-0 early in the opening period, Johansson was the first player to reach a loose puck in the right corner of the Capitals' zone after the Rangers' Nick Kypreos had dumped it in.

NICHOLAS REICHMANN, 19, who has cerebral palsy, and Alice Szaluta, 28, who has a learning disability, had worked part time at the Blockbuster store in Port Washington, Mr. Reichmann for two and a half years and Ms. Szaluta for almost eight years.
Their duties included greeting customers and rewinding and restocking tapes.
Mr. Reichmann also ran a cash register.
Both got raises during their tenure, they said, and Ms. Szaluta (pronounced SAH-loo-tah) received a five-year service award from the company in 2000.

When a new manager took over last August, their hours were gradually reduced and then in October, they were not scheduled to work at all, they said in a complaint filed with the state's division of human rights.

The company never officially notified them that they were being fired, the complaint said; instead, they found out only when work schedules were posted in December, and they found the word ''terminated'' next to their names.
Mr. Reichmann and Ms. Szaluta contended that they were fired because of their disabilities, and their complaint accused Blockbuster of discrimination.
After three weeks of negotiations, the two got their jobs back last week. ''

We've reached an agreement in principle that includes both being hired back,'' said Christopher Murray, a partner in Reisman, Peirez & Reisman, the Garden City law firm that is representing Mr. Reichmann and Ms. Szaluta at no charge. ''
We're just waiting to put it into writing.''

IF you were lucky enough to run an N.B.A. franchise, there would normally be no better feeling to have, no more enviable position to be in, than to start a season with the Los Angeles Clippers' first-round draft pick in your back pocket.

No matter how many defeats piled up, on those freezing February nights when no shots were falling, there would inevitably be hope, always that draft choice, a charmed lottery ticket at the end of the tunnel.
There would -- until this season, as the Nets' luck would have it -- always be the Clippers, predictable as the sun, rising in the draft as they were sinking in the West.

1 pick from Denver in the Kenyon Martin trade in the summer of 2004.
For financial reasons beyond Thorn's control, he had to surrender Martin, his macho forward, his defensive stopper.
But among the three future draft choices he received was a rerouted pick from the Clippers, stamped as lottery unprotected, meaning no safeguards were in place, for June 2006. ''

It was one of those picks you obviously hope will turn into something special,'' Thorn said in a telephone interview as the Nets prepared to face the team we are trying to get used to calling the first-place Clippers tonight at Continental Arena.
When Thorn made the Martin deal, the Clippers had won 28 games.
The season before that, they won 27.
If reactions to the new installation in the traffic island at Fifth Avenue and 23d Street, at the foot of the Flatiron Building, prove anything, it's that public art does indeed involve the public.
In one 45-minute period recently, the following responses to the 19-foot-tall bluish-gray tower and base were noted. "

Born in Ireland, she recalled that her brother, Niall, a sculptor, had made a huge metal dinosaur that was placed along the coast of County Clare. "

Sheung Li, on business from Boston, tied it in with the surrounding traffic. "
It looks like a mechanism," he said. "
Is this a bus stop?"
Mr. Li, who had just been to the top of the Empire State Building with a colleague, Beth Areglado, mused: "I could imagine poetry coming out of it.
Since its inception, the fortunes of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia have been entwined with the image of its founder, Martha Stewart.

Now, as legal troubles continue to swirl around Ms. Stewart and her ImClone trades, some analysts are envisioning a future for the public company without Ms. Stewart at the helm and suggesting that could even help.

Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia has been looking for a chief executive to possibly succeed Ms. Stewart, a person who was briefed on the matter reiterated yesterday after the search was reported by The New York Times.
The company's board denied yesterday that it was involved in such a search.
In a statement, the board said it ''felt it appropriate to categorically deny the report contained in today's New York Times that any search for a new chief executive has been initiated.''
The statement also said that the board ''actively monitors the business needs of the company on an ongoing basis as well as in relation to the investigations involving Martha Stewart personally.''
Shares in Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia closed yesterday at $7.80, up 15 cents.

The company's prospectus, which warned investors that ''business would be adversely affected if Martha Stewart's public image or reputation were to be tarnished,'' announced a strategy of reducing its dependence on its founder.

The prospectus went on to describe the company as ''increasingly focused on team-based content development,'' and pointed out how Ms. Stewart had all but ceased to appear on the cover of her own magazine, where she was once a fixture. ''

Doctors at Yale believe that a brain abscess in a woman in her 20's was caused by an infection she suffered after having her tongue pierced.

One of the doctors, Dr. Richard Martinello, said in an interview that he was not aware of any other similar cases, but he cautioned that physicians and piercers should consider the possibility of piercing-related infections if they hear of strange symptoms.
In the case he handled, the woman first reported that her tongue became swollen and produced a sour taste a few days after it was pierced and a stud put in place.
She took out the jewelry and the symptoms quickly disappeared, Dr. Martinello said.
About a month later she began suffering from headaches, fever and vomiting and had trouble with her balance.
A CAT scan performed in a local hospital revealed a brain abnormality in the cerebellum, which is associated with coordination.
The woman, whose name was withheld, was referred to Yale, where doctors looked for signs of infections in the middle ear or sinuses, the usual sources of infections that develop into brain abscesses.
When they found none, they drained the abscess.
Tests showed the presence of four types of bacteria commonly found in the mouth, Dr. Martinello said.
After six weeks of antibiotics, the woman made a full recovery.
WHEN the numbers stop making sense, maybe it is time to stop believing them.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported far fewer net new jobs in May and June than Wall Street expected.
If it happens again when July data are issued on Friday, Edward E. Yardeni, chief investment strategist at Oak Associates, will assume that there is something wrong with the report, not the economy.
A Bloomberg News poll of economists estimates that 145,000 jobs were added in July.
Mr. Yardeni, who said that he had overestimated the figures announced in the two previous reports, is aiming high again. ''
I'm going to take a chance on making a third mistake and go with 180,000 to 200,000,'' he said.
Most evidence aside from the government report suggests that jobs are plentiful, Mr. Yardeni said in explaining his prediction.
If fewer people are getting hired than economists expect, he is inclined to attribute it to too few prospective workers, not too little work. ''
If I'm wrong, I'm going to start to wonder if we've run out of able-bodied people to hire rather than worry about whether the economy is slowing,'' he said. ''
In this economy, we need more skilled workers and knowledge workers, and they're getting harder to find.''
Move over Bruce Springsteen and Jon Bon Jovi, New Jersey has put out a CD that has hundreds of residents leaping from their (lily) pads to gobble up.
Sixteen of the state's most popular frogs and toads teamed up to create the 40-track CD -- Calls of New Jersey Frogs and Toads -- which consists of their unique croaking.

A Franklin Township sixth grader, Ryan Herpen, was one of the first to receive the CD.
He uses it to identify the croaks he hears near his home when he goes out on reptile and amphibian hunts. ''
I'll bring my portable CD player when I go out looking for stuff,'' said Ryan, a sixth grader from Franklin Township who hopes to become a herpetologist. ''
I bring a net, identification books and the CD.
A letter mailed to Chile has tested positive for anthrax, the director of a Miami laboratory affiliated with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said yesterday.
The agency has not yet verified the finding in its own laboratories.
Dr. Antonio Banfi, a professor of pediatric diseases at the Calvo Mackenna Hospital in Santiago, Chile, received the letter at a laboratory where he does research.
He regarded it as suspicious because the return address in Florida differed from the Zurich postmark.
A Chilean laboratory found anthrax spores in the sample and the Centers for Disease Control was asked to confirm the result.
Because the C.D.C. is overburdened, it has asked the Miami-Dade County Health Department to conduct anthrax testing on all suspect packages from abroad.
Until now, all have turned out to be false alarms.
Dr. Segaran Pillai, the director of the Miami laboratory, said he was surprised to find that the sample from Chile turned out to be anthrax, as judged by standard tests.

The agency expects to receive samples from Miami shortly and will test them in its own laboratories to ascertain whether the strain of anthrax is the same as that used in the tainted letters mailed within the United States.
The agency is in touch with the Chilean department of health but has no immediate plans to send a response team to Santiago.
Before deciding whether to file formal charges, prosecutors are taking the unusual step of hearing evidence from both sides in the reported rape of a woman at the Kennedy family compound.
Prosecutors usually decide whether to press charges on the strength of a case built by the police without reviewing the defense evidence.
But a veteran defense lawyer said the practice is not unheard-of in sensitive cases.
David H. Bludworth, Palm Beach County State's Attorney, said his office will set up a meeting with the police to discuss the case.
The meeting had not yet been scheduled. "
Our office will review all evidence submitted," he said Friday. "
We will give all parties involved an opportunity to present evidence they wish to be considered before a final decision is made in this matter."
The Palm Beach police chief criticized the decision on hearing evidence from both sides. "
That's crazy," Chief Joseph Terlizzese was quoted as saying Saturday in The Miami Herald. "
I've never seen this kind of procedure before."
ABOUT three weeks ago, when both the Giants and the 49ers were unbeaten, Bill Parcells was addressing his players. "
If I asked you guys," the Giants' coach said, "why San Francisco wins all the time, you'd answer the same way fans would. '
They have great leadership.

But you really know why San Francisco wins?
Because three-quarters of the teams don't think they can beat 'em. "

Daisuke Matsuzaka received his first tour of Fenway Park on Thursday afternoon, even though the fabled ballpark looked like a construction site.
A chain-link fence encircled the field, a Dumpster was filled with debris, and a tarpaulin covered the outfield and the plate.
But the mound was uncovered.
Matsuzaka, who held a baseball, noticed that the mound was one of the only places at the 94-year-old park that looked the way it will look next April.
John Henry, the principal owner of the Red Sox, encouraged Matsuzaka, his new $103.1 million pitcher, to test out the dirt hill that will become his new home.
So Matsuzaka strolled to the mound, a gloveless Henry crouched behind the plate and Matsuzaka threw his first pitch at Fenway to the man who will sign his lucrative paychecks.
Matsuzaka's pitch was high and Henry leaped for it, tumbled backward and narrowly missed landing in a puddle. ''
We didn't go over the signals,'' Henry explained.
Henry smiled as he recounted Matsuzaka's errant pitch; Matsuzaka smiled then and throughout most of his introductory news conference.
After 29 days of negotiations that veered from stagnant to tense to successful, the Red Sox and Scott Boras, Matsuzaka's agent, agreed to a six-year, $52 million contract late Wednesday.

Howard Gordon, 84, has recovered nicely from open-heart surgery.
But as Valentine's Day approaches he feels a familiar sadness that he never married or had children.
Rose Straub, 81, reports the death of her gentleman caller who constantly talked about his late wife.
Optimistic she's not about another boyfriend.

Gloria Bobrofsky, 76, wants a good friend,  but isn't desperate.
Standing outside of a Baskin-Robbins ice cream store in a strip mall in Co-op City, City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook seemed proud to be recognized by a steady stream of lunchtime shoppers. ''
I think that people have come to get a sense of who I am and that I am someone they can come to,'' Mr. Seabrook said, smiling at each shopper who waved at him. ''

While Mr. Seabrook is in his first term on the Council, he has run for office in the Bronx consistently for nearly 20 years, beginning with his election to the Assembly in 1984.
