But Mr. Seabrook is not the only candidate running for Council who is well known to voters.
In the Democratic primary on Sept. 9, Mr. Seabrook is facing Shirley Saunders, who also has a long history of running for office and of political involvement.
Ms. Saunders is a Democratic district leader and an aide to United States Representative Eliot L. Engel.
The race in the 12th Council District is something of a reprise of the Council race of two years ago, when Ms. Saunders came within 103 votes of winning.
Every two years for the last 24, voters here went to the polls and gave the job of tax collector to James Branca.
A gentle man, Mr. Branca did little to keep pace with technological advances, but treated residents with the warmth and deference to which they are accustomed.
But in June, he died of pneumonia with 18 months left in his latest term, leaving town officials with the sticky question of whom to appoint to dog their 58,000 constituents for money.

After one member's late-night brainstorm, the Board of Selectmen decided to pass the job to another local institution: Louis C. Caravella, 72, who for years has carried the affectionate but unofficial title of Mayor of Cos Cob, a section of Greenwich.
From 1953 until he sold it in 1988, he owned a store that was officially called Post Stationery but was known universally as Lou's.

Besides selling stationery, Mr. Caravella also made house calls to install hearing-aid batteries, fixed radios and flashlights, and tried to teach responsibility to children at the nearby school by automatically offering one day's credit on candy.
Mr. Caravella's wife, Judy, had retired in May from teaching nursery school, and they had planned to travel.
But Mr. Caravella dutifully answered his town's call.
In July he was sworn in for the $60,000-a-year job of managing six employees and collecting $169 million a year in town taxes and sewer fees.
He expected to serve out Mr. Branca's term, which will end in December 1999.
The two most prominent Serbian leaders are involved in a confrontation so intense that it may result in a fall from power for one of them.

When the president of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, announced last week that he was ending all political and economic support for his Serbian allies in Bosnia, he effectively severed his ties with the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic.

He is demanding that Dr. Karadzic accept the latest international peace plan, knowing that United Nations diplomats are moving ahead with tighter sanctions that could have a devastating effect on Serbia's already crippled economy.
The only way the Serbs in Belgrade can avoid such sanctions, diplomats here say, is to persuade their Bosnian allies to accept the plan. "
Milosevic has to get the Bosnian Serbs to sign the plan, and if this group won't sign it, he has to replace them," one European diplomat said. "
Something dramatic has to happen, and given the fact that the U.N. sanctions are going to be imposed this week or next week, it has to happen quickly."
Not everyone here believes a confrontation between Mr. Milosevic and Dr. Karadzic will come so soon, but few doubt that it will come. "
There can't be two top guys," said Predrag Simic, director of the Institute for International Politics and Economics, an independent research center. "
One of them has to go."
Mr. Milosevic, a veteran Communist apparatchik and shrewd behind-the-scenes operator, holds a strong hand.
It is too late for Patrick Rafter to whisper in the tournament director Paul McNamee's ear about changing the Australian Open this year.

Too late to suggest nicely -- this is Rafter, after all -- that the hardcourt surface be made quicker and the balls lighter so that Rafter's serve-and-volley style can play as well at home as it does in New York.
Friday, it was Thomas Enqvist's turn to remind the third-seeded Rafter, and the nation that admires him, of his limitations.
Along the way, the straight-talking and flat-hitting Swede reminded the tennis world that he is playing as well as anyone this January.
Rafter has won the United States Open the past two years, but in eight appearances in Melbourne he has never advanced past the fourth round.

His legs are still powerful, his reflexes still quick and his hair still a little too long and unkempt for the taste of some older Australians, yet his game is not quite the same at Melbourne Park. ''
I think the conditions suited him really well, and I think he played too big and strong for me,'' Rafter said after Enqvist dismantled him, 6-4, 4-6, 6-4, 6-4.
His loss means that Pete Sampras, who chose to skip this tournament to rest, will remain No.
1 when this Grand Slam event ends.
Nonetheless, it was hardly a reaffirming day for the pecking order.

The Bush administration is preparing to discuss for the first time details of the early fruits of its efforts to join forces with other nations in intercepting weapons and missile technology bound for Iran, North Korea and Syria, according to several administration officials.
Some details are expected to be presented to foreign diplomats at the State Department on Tuesday by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, the officials said.

Many of the diplomats are from the 60 or so nations that have joined President Bush's Proliferation Security Initiative, an effort to use a patchwork of national laws and agreements with other countries to intercept suspected weapons shipments in ports and on the high seas.

The timing of the presentation is significant because Mr. Bush's aides, in conversations where they insisted on anonymity because of the sensitivity of the subject, are talking with increasing urgency about using similar techniques to cut off North Korea's main sources of hard currency: shipments of weapons, illegal drugs and counterfeit currency.

The administration officials said that Ms. Rice would be joined by the new director of national intelligence, John D. Negroponte, and that they would announce that Iraq, Georgia and Argentina were joining the effort to stop weapons shipments en route. ''
What we are looking to do is make clear that we have had many quiet successes that no one has heard about,'' said a senior official who has been involved in the program since it began. ''
This is the time to make it clear that there are many ways to stop proliferation activities.''

Ms. Rice is expected to cite about a dozen cases in which material was either intercepted -- largely at ports, during the transfer of containers -- or Washington notified other countries that a shipment was about to leave their waters.
But according to officials who are familiar with her presentation, she will be vague about most of the details.
They say that is partly because some foreign governments are concerned about retribution if they are seen to be closely cooperating with the United States and other Western nations.
''But he wouldn't do that.''
That sentiment is what made it possible for President Bush to stampede America into the Iraq war and to fend off hard questions about the reasons for that war until after the 2004 election.
Many people just didn't want to believe that an American president would deliberately mislead the nation on matters of war and peace.
Now people with contacts in the administration and the military warn that Mr. Bush may be planning another war.
The most alarming of the warnings come from Seymour Hersh, the veteran investigative journalist who broke the Abu Ghraib scandal.

Writing in The New Yorker, Mr. Hersh suggests that administration officials believe that a bombing campaign could lead to desirable regime change in Iran -- and that they refuse to rule out the use of tactical nuclear weapons. ''
But he wouldn't do that,'' say people who think they're being sensible.
Given what we now know about the origins of the Iraq war, however, discounting the possibility that Mr. Bush will start another ill-conceived and unnecessary war isn't sensible.
It's wishful thinking.
As it happens, rumors of a new war coincide with the emergence of evidence that appears to confirm our worst suspicions about the war we're already in.
Like a visiting dignitary, Hideki Matsui made the rounds in the Yankees' clubhouse this morning, going by each locker to formally greet teammates with his interpreter by his side.
Then there was his Jason Giambi encounter.
Giambi was last year's snazzy addition to the lineup.
This year, that role is Matsui's.
The two also share an agent and a hitting style and have an easy familiarity.
When Giambi spotted Matsui today, he casually saluted and called out, ''Hideki, what's up, baby?''
More than any other Yankee so far, Giambi has advised Matsui, who signed as a free agent after a decorated career in Japan.
Giambi dined with him in Japan last November during an All-Star series, talking up the Yankees and answering Matsui's questions about where to live and what to expect. ''
I told him, those standing O's when you strike out -- that stuff's gone,'' Giambi said.
That will be something Matsui did not experience in Japan. ''

LEAD: FOR years newspapers have fought with mixed results to get special shield laws passed in state legislatures to protect reporters from being forced by the courts to reveal the names of confidential sources.

While no other citizens are afforded similar privileges, journalists have often seen themselves as unelected public servants, members of a special Fourth FOR years newspapers have fought with mixed results to get special shield laws passed in state legislatures to protect reporters from being forced by the courts to reveal the names of confidential sources.
While no other citizens are afforded similar privileges, journalists have often seen themselves as unelected public servants, members of a special Fourth Estate.

Thus it came as a shock when the two largest newspapers in Minnesota, The Minneapolis Star Tribune and The St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch, were recently ordered to pay $700,000 to a source because they had broken their promise to keep his name a secret.

While heavy fines against newspapers generally elicit warnings that First Amendment freedoms are in jeopardy, a number of newspaper editors and journalism professors argued that, in this case, it was the behavior of the newspapers that could have a chilling effect.

On the one hand, it was disturbing to see an oral agreement between a reporter and a news source treated as though it were, as Tim McGuire, the Star-Tribune editor put it, ''a contract to sell paper clips.''
But some journalists were just as concerned that publicity over the case would discourage future news sources. ''
Certainly there were no heroes here on either side,'' said Tom Goldstein, dean of the Graduate School of Journalism at the University of California.
His conclusion: Bad journalism followed by bad law.
During the trial, which ended this month in Minneapolis, editors for the newspapers argued that contract law as currently construed should not control news-gathering. ''

In what often looked like an oversize rugby scrum, hundreds of Israeli soldiers and police officers scuffled with Jewish settlers today as they dismantled a small hillside settlement, the first populated one to come down as part of a Middle East peace plan.
Twenty-five miles to the north, a Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up just after daybreak, killing an Israeli shop owner in a farming community.
With peace efforts sputtering, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell was scheduled to hold separate talks with Israelis and Palestinians on Friday.
The two sides have been attempting to work out a cease-fire agreement.

In Mitzpeh Yitzhar, the young, bearded settlers used large rocks to construct barricades, lighted hillside brush fires and threw themselves in front of army vehicles in an attempt to prevent soldiers and police officers from taking down several tents and huts.
For the last year, up to 10 settlers have been living at the site, just south of Nablus, the largest Palestinian city in the West Bank. ''
In the Bible, it says this land is for us,'' said Moshe Cohen, 27, a university student who came from Tel Aviv to protest the dismantling of the settlement. ''
This land belongs to Israel just as much as Tel Aviv.''

Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, has supported the building of settlements for decades, but the new Middle East peace plan known as the road map requires Israel to take down dozens of small settlements that have cropped up since Mr. Sharon came to power in March 2001. ''

I'm telling the young men to hold strong to the land of Israel and not let anybody take it away from them,'' said Rabbi Eliyakim Levanon, who came from a nearby settlement to protest the government action. ''
The number of fuel-efficient hybrid models available in the United States will more than double in the next year, to seven from three, with new entries coming from Toyota, Honda and Ford Motor.

Two of the new vehicles were announced at the North American International Auto Show -- one of the auto industry's most important annual product previews -- which opened here Sunday for the news media.
But the news from Japanese automakers was hardly all green.
They are redoubling their efforts to take on the Big Three in the market for pickup trucks.
Toyota, for example, unveiled a gigantic pickup truck prototype, called the FTX.
The truck, which Toyota said it modeled after a clenched fist, appears to be its answer to the biggest offerings from United States automakers as well as to Nissan's burly new Titan pickup.
Nissan also showed a new version of its compact Frontier truck.
Honda, the only one of the six largest automakers in the United States market that does not sell a pickup truck, said on Sunday that it would build its first pickup truck by 2005.
It pitched an early prototype of the truck, which looks like a cross between a car, a truck and a spaceship, as a quirky vehicle that is more for ''cool dads'' than construction workers.
Tom Elliott, executive vice president of American Honda, said that many consumers now look at trucks ''not as work vehicles but instead as products to support their active lifestyles.''

As mysteriously as he disappeared a week ago, a popular high school coach from Milltown, N.J., has resurfaced, but no one -- neither law enforcement authorities nor family members -- was saying yesterday where he is now or where he had been.

Milltown police officials said that they had closed their investigation into the disappearance of the coach, William Visokay Jr., 41, who vanished after spending the morning of Aug. 5 golfing with friends and visiting an appliance store. ''

The missing persons investigation of William Visokay by the Middlesex County Sheriff's Department has been closed, since contact has been established with him,'' said a news release issued by Raymond Greibel, the Milltown police chief. ''
Out of respect for Mr. Visokay's privacy and the privacy of his family, no further comment will be provided.''
Friends and family members spent a week looking for Mr. Visokay, who is a teacher and coach at Spotswood High School.
He also serves on the school board and works as a volunteer fireman.
His father and other family members had offered a $1,000 reward to anyone with information about Mr. Visokay's whereabouts.

The coach's former students and players, co-workers and fellow firefighters plastered this town of 7,500 with posters about the disappearance and searched the woods around town and Dumpsters for signs of him.
Debbie Visokay, his wife, answered the telephone at the couple's home yesterday, sounding exhausted.
But she would not say where her husband was or whether he was safe. ''

Seeking to combat the persistent underrepresentation of minorities in their offices, 35 major law firms in New York City pledged yesterday to hire more black, Hispanic, Asian-American and American Indian lawyers and to treat them equally in assignments and promotion once they arrive.
The law firms set a goal of hiring one minority lawyer for every 10 new lawyers they recruit over the next five years -- almost double the current rate.
They also pledged to address systemic problems that have seen minorities fare much worse, and stay more briefly, than their white counterparts at New York's most prestigious law firms.
The moves are part of a City Bar Association initiative to enhance opportunities for minorities. "

There are problems at every level -- at recruitment, at retention and promotion, and the only way to make sure that changes occur is to address them all at the same time," said the president of the City Bar Association, Conrad K. Harper.
He said he hoped that other firms and corporate legal departments would join the initiative, which he called "a major step toward the complete integration of the legal profession in New York City." "

These firms are more committed than I've ever seen them to doing something significant, and doing it now," said Mr. Harper, a partner at Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, who is the bar group's first black president. "
Bleak as the situation is, it has gotten better in the last few years and with this kind of commitment I expect it to get better still."
Mr. Harper maintained that the sour state of the legal marketplace, which has seen many of the 35 firms curb hiring and lay off record numbers of lawyers, would in no way blunt the initiative. "
The firms," he said, "clearly recognize that we're looking toward the long term, and the economy of the moment will not be the economy over the next five years."
Alfred Hitchcock, known for his gourmandise as well as his suspenseful thrillers, would probably approve of a new San Francisco restaurant named for his 1958 spellbinder, "Vertigo."
The 200-seat restaurant, which opened Feb. 13, sits at the base of the Transamerica pyramid, the city's tallest building and a spire-shaped icon in the skyline.

Tucked along the structure's base under concrete pylons 13 feet high, Vertigo artfully embraces its massive partner, tempering the geometry of the pyramid with the whirling motifs of the film, which was set in San Francisco.
Vertigo welcomes the visitor along an inviting doglegged path through a grove of redwoods.
Hanging lanterns give the walkway the feel of a Japanese garden, creating a refuge in the dense pack of buildings at the edge of the financial district.
Inside, the curves and spirals of Vertigo appear everywhere: on fabrics, in carpeting, on menus and wine lists.
Chartreuse chiffon curtains flounce along a glass wall, giving a soft Kim Novak chic to the mass of glass and concrete.
People-watching comes naturally in the open, multilevel dining room, and the open kitchen adds drama but not noise.
If the crowd does not inspire, two room-size skylights pull the eye up to the peak of the pyramid.
For all the whimsy in the air, though, the menu is more likely to cure dizziness than to cause it.
DAVID GEFFEN, the entertainment baron, has turned down many a would-be biographer.
Now, he has agreed to allow THOMAS R. KING, 32, the chief entertainment reporter in The Wall Street Journal's Los Angeles bureau, to write the story of his life.
Random House is planning to publish the book in 1999. "
I approached him earlier this year with the idea," Mr. King said yesterday.
"Initially, he hung up the phone on me and said, 'No, I don't want anybody writing a book about me.'
I kept after him and convinced him that a biography was inevitable and that now, with Dreamworks starting a new studio, was a good time and I was the man to do it.
I guess he may now just feel powerful enough or rich enough or invulnerable enough to take a chance."
Mr. Geffen founded Dreamworks SKG with Jeffrey Katzenberg and Steven Spielberg in 1994.
Mr. King, who will take a two-year leave of absence from The Wall Street Journal, says the book will deal candidly with Mr. Geffen's professional and personal life. "
I told him, 'David, you will cringe when you read some parts of  this book,' " he said. "
Super Bowl Quarterbacks Q. In Phil Simms (1987) and Jeff Hostetler (1991), the New York Giants had two Super Bowl winning quarterbacks as teammates for the entire regular season of 1991.
Has any other National Football League team been so fortunate?
A. Having two such qualified passers on one roster is somewhat of a passing fancy, for only one other team can brag about it in the 24 seasons it has been possible.
When the Miami Dolphins opened the 1973 season as defending Super Bowl champions, their starting quarterback was Bob Griese.
He had called the signals in the Super Bowl VII victory over the Washington Redskins eight months earlier.
Behind Griese was the veteran Earl Morrall.
He was the winning quarterback for the Baltimore Colts against the Dallas Cowboys in the 1971 Super Bowl.
The Griese-Morrall Miami crown machine won another Super Bowl, against the Minnesota Vikings, after that 1973 season, and stayed together through the 1976 season.
Which meant that for most of four seasons, Coach Don Shula had on hand two quarterbacks who had on their hands the rings that denote Super Bowl champions.
Visitors on Home Field Q. Whenever the New York Jets play the New York Giants at Giants Stadium, one of them is the visiting team in its home park.

To the Editor: We are writing from New Dramatists, a 50-year-old organization dedicated to cultivating playwrights, in order to challenge Richard Schech ner's dismissal of contemporary writers [''Already Reworking the Classics of Modern Realism,'' Feb. 13].

Mr. Schechner's article, an analysis of directorial responses to modern classics, veers into an unfounded explanation starting with ''each crop of playwrights from about 1970 on is less impressive than the generation before.''
His digression amounts to an attack on the voices of American playwrights.
We invite Mr. Schechner to our doors, where he can read and hear plays from such writers as Paula Vogel, Doug Wright, Diana Son, David Greenspan, Kia Corthron and many others.

We would also encourage him to learn about the work of some of the writers who have passed through this building since 1970, including Mac Wellman, John Patrick Shanley, Emily Mann, Suzan-Lori Parks, August Wilson, Elizabeth Egloff, Donald Margulies, Eduardo Machado and Romulus Linney.
Of course, the abundance of gifted and influential playwrights spreads far beyond this organization.
Mr. Schechner's article pits directors against writers by trying to link a creative response to the classics with an alleged dearth of new work.
His glib hypothesis is inaccurate.
Our experience is different: we live surrounded by a profusion of talented artists writing for the theater.
Careers fall in and out of favor and greatness gets redefined over time; all we know is that playwriting in America is as vibrant as ever.

Those who wonder how Thomas F. Reilly, the Massachusetts attorney general, will conduct the criminal investigation into the sexual abuse scandal in the Boston Archdiocese might consider the case of Janet Downing.
Ms. Downing had been stabbed 98 times when she was found dead in a pool of blood in her dining room in working-class Somerville in the summer of 1995.
The fingerprints and DNA pointed to her son's best friend, the chubby, 15-year-old former altar boy next door.
Under state law, he would be tried in juvenile court.
But Mr. Reilly, then the Middlesex County district attorney, looked at the stabbings and decided that this was a young man who would kill again.

He pushed to the state's highest court to win the right to try him as an adult, then took the unusual step of prosecuting the case himself, ultimately convicting the teenager of first-degree murder, sending him to prison for life.
The case gave Mr. Reilly the statewide attention that would help him win his current position as attorney general in 1998, but critics accused him of grandstanding.
It was the same charge that had been leveled against him when he prosecuted a family that ran a day care center in a controversial child sexual abuse scandals of the 1980's.
It was the same one that would be leveled again when Mr. Reilly brought murder charges against the British nanny Louise Woodward for shaking a baby to death.
The judge seemed to side with the critics, reducing her sentence to manslaughter.

Fairchild Publications is expected to announce on Monday that it will purchase Elegant Bride, a quarterly magazine owned by Pace Communications, according to an executive at Fairchild and others involved in the transaction.

The acquisition would put Fairchild, a division of Advance Publications that produces fashion-oriented consumer and trade magazines, in competition for wedding advertisers with its sibling division, Conde Nast Publications, which owns Bride's and Modern Bride magazines.
A Fairchild spokeswoman declined to comment.

Pace, a custom publisher in North Carolina, had retained the Jordan, Edmiston Group to sell Elegant Bride in June, in part because Conde Nast, which already owned Bride's magazine, had come to dominate the market after its purchase of Modern Bride from Primedia Inc. in 2002 for $52 million.
An executive at Pace did not return a call for comment and a spokesman at the Jordan, Edmiston Group declined to comment.
Pace is primarily known for in-flight magazines, including Attache, Hemispheres and Navigator.
Elegant Bride, which has a circulation of 142,000, is intended for upscale brides-to-be and could serve as a nuptial companion for W, Fairchild's high-end fashion magazine.
So far this year, bridal magazines have struggled in a difficult publishing and bridal market.

Bride's magazine's advertising pages are down 8.67 percent through the first half of the year compared with the comparable period last year, while Modern Bride is down 7.05 percent in the same period.

With revenue of what a publishing executive estimated at under $10 million a year, Elegant Bride is not a major player, but its arrival at Fairchild could create some sibling rivalry between the two Advance divisions.
STEVEN KOUTSOUMBARIS , left, the former chef de cuisine at March restaurant, is now the executive chef at Agata & Valentina, the Upper East Side fancy-food shop.
But his responsibilities will go beyond making shrimp salad and lasagna to take out.
In the spring, he will also run the kitchen at AGATA & VALENTINA FOOD BAR , which is to open opposite the store at 1513 First Avenue (79th Street), with a restaurant, a cafe and a wine bar.
AQUAVIT , the Scandinavian restaurant in a town house at 13 West 54th Street, will move in about a year when its lease is up.
HAKAN SWAHN , the owner, and his partner, the chef MARCUS SAMUELSSON , will relocate to 65 East 55th Street.

MARIO LOHNINGER , the executive chef at DANUBE , is leaving for Frankfurt, where he plans to work on a culinary project with his father, Paul, a chef who was his first teacher in their native Salzburg, Austria.
A replacement has not been named.
With big mirrors, charcuterie hanging on a rack and signs for aperitifs, LA BOTTEGA  is more like a French brasserie than an Italian trattoria.
But the restaurant, newly opened in the Maritime Hotel, Ninth Avenue and 16th Street, offers a long antipasto list, pizzas, pastas and traditional Italian main courses.
Its chef is JOHN DELUCIE  and its owners are SEAN MacPHERSON , ERIC GOODE , RICHARD BORN  and IRA DRUCKIER .
It arrives on the whims of the sun, land and sea, tickling the tops of fescue, haunting a golfer's dreams.
It comes in bursts and then disappears, waiting for the next moment to grab a golf ball by the dimples and hurl it into the hay.
It is wind -- breathy, full-bodied and unpredictable.

And unlike water, rough and undulating greens, it is the one element that the golfers at the United States Open at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club cannot see, while knowing it may decide the winner of the tournament beginning Thursday. ''
It is very British out there,'' said the Englishman Justin Rose, sitting in the clubhouse Wednesday, taking a break from wind-blown preparations along the 6,996-yard links-style course. ''
It feels similar to Muirfield.''
Muirfield is the British Open course in Gullane, Scotland, where, two years ago, golfers thrashed about on a wet, chilly and windy Saturday. (
Tiger Woods's bid for a calendar-year Grand Slam ended that day in a miserable 10-over-par 81, his worst round as a professional.)
At Shinnecock Hills, where it is warmer than Scotland, winds forecast for up to 15 miles an hour with gusts up to 20 m.p.h.
will keep golfers guessing and caddies reaching for clumps of grass to toss toward the heavens, trying to follow the winds of change.
American troops took firm action this week against one of the most dangerous problems now confronting NATO in Kosovo.

In a series of raids, they seized weapons and ammunition that ethnic Albanian guerrillas in the American-patrolled eastern part of the province have been using to launch cross-border raids into Serbia.
Unless the guerrillas are forcibly disarmed and turned away from the border, their actions could embroil NATO in an unwanted new war with Belgrade.
Ethnic tensions have been building in Kosovo.

In the city of Mitrovica, Serbian militants supported by Yugoslavia's president, Slobodan Milosevic, have been blockading bridges and streets to keep Albanians away from their homes on the north side of the Ibar River and have been trying to partition the province along ethnic lines.
With French and Italian reinforcements on the way to Mitrovica, NATO troops began pushing back against the blockades.
Gen. Wesley Clark, NATO's military commander, would like to see American reinforcements sent to eastern Kosovo as well.
Most citizens of Kosovo would like to focus on re-establishing personal and economic security.
But those who try to cooperate with their neighbors across ethnic lines face threats and intimidation from extremists in both communities.
Militant leaders do not really want to see the United Nations succeed in building a civil society in Kosovo.

Belmont Park opened its 72-day spring and summer season yesterday with a burst of speed that matched one track record and broke another but that probably produced no major new candidate for the Preakness Stakes next week.

In the day's most memorable demonstration of speed, the 10-1 long shot Williamstown, a son of Seattle Slew, outran a band of favorites and won the 118th Withers in faster time than any other horse in the track's history had run one mile.
He shot the distance on a fast but moist track in 1:32 3/5 with Craig Perret riding and, like everybody else in the race, carried 124 pounds.
He sliced two-fifths of a second off the record of 1:33 set in 1982 by Conquistador Cielo, who was carrying only 111 pounds at the time.

Not taking anything away from Williamstown, who underwent throat surgery in December and missed four months of racing, the world record for the mile was set in 1968 by the distinguished war horse Dr. Fager, who sped the distance in 1:32 1/5 at Arlington Park toting 134 pounds.
Williamstown's trainer, Peter Vestal, reacted afterward the way most of the opening-day audience of 11,381 reacted: with disbelief. "
I got to tell you I'm surprised," he said. "
Not by his ability; I know he's got talent.
But I am surprised he could put it all together against a field like this one.
He's come a long way."

Russia deported 153 citizens of Georgia on Friday as a wave of punitive measures against Georgian migrants and businesses grew, prompting criticism that the government is carrying out an ethnically motivated campaign of harassment.

The deportations came at the end of a week of political and diplomatic conflict between Russia and Georgia that began with the arrests of four Russian military officers for espionage, and has shown little sign of easing despite the officers' release.

The police, who had already begun to shutter some businesses linked to Georgians, searched and closed still more on Friday, including two more casinos and two of Moscow's better-known Georgian restaurants, according to officials and news reports.

At least some schools in Moscow received requests from the police to list students with Georgian names, presumably to help in identifying illegal immigrants, prompting a complaint from an education official, Lyubov Kezina.

And one of the country's most famous writers, Grigory Chkhartishvili, a Georgian native who writes under the pseudonym Boris Akunin, told a radio station that tax inspectors questioned his publisher about his income from his hugely popular novels.

Yuri Dzhibladze, an ethnic Georgian and president of the Center for the Development of Democracy and Human Rights in Moscow, described the authorities' actions as an unjustified overreaction to political disputes with Georgia's president, Mikheil Saakashvili. ''
It smacks of racism and xenophobia,'' he said in a telephone interview.

Russian officials have cited legal or procedural violations as justifications for their actions, accusing the casinos and restaurants of violating health or other regulatory standards and the deportees of breaking immigration laws. ''
Everything that is taking place today is exclusively within the framework of the law,'' the prosecutor general, Yuri Y. Chaika, said on Friday, according to Interfax.
Officials' remarks, however, have left little doubt that they have singled out Georgians for enforcement.
What's wrong with the proposed constitutional amendment to make Congress balance the budget each year?
Only that it's wrong in principle and destructive in practice.
It may sound like a direct remedy for Washington's toying with trillions in deficit spending.
In fact, such an amendment would threaten precisely the long-term investments society needs most and risk pushing a soft economy into icy recession.
These risks aren't warranted.
Congress has to get control over spending on medical care and other entitlements.
But that can be done without perilous grandstanding.
The amendment is no solution; it's an unbalanced problem.
Different versions of the amendment are moving briskly in both the House and Senate.
Each would require Congress to match cash outlays with cash revenues each year unless a supermajority of, say, 60 percent votes otherwise.
Hours after her son was delivered by Caesarean section, a woman struck by a hit-and-run driver died yesterday at Brookdale Medical Center in Brooklyn.
Surgeons were able to save the 4-pound, 14-ounce boy, but not his mother, Ava Hope Jones.
Ms. Jones, 25, was fatally injured by a speeding car as she crossed Linden Boulevard at Milford Street in the East New York section of Brooklyn on Wednesday night.
The infant is Ms. Jones's fifth child, according to her grandmother, Helen Jones, who said she did not know who the fathers were.
Two boys -- Tarlene, 4, and Terrell, 3 -- live with Helen Jones at 1200 Sutter Avenue in the Cypress Hills housing project in East New York, where Ava Jones grew up.
Two girls -- Stefanie, 8, and Lokemia, 7 -- live with another grandmother.
The life that ended yesterday was, by all accounts, troubled and difficult.
Helen Jones, 59, said she had heard that her granddaughter "lived on the streets" and took drugs.
She said that Ava came home only when she was hungry and sick, and then would "stay for a couple of days and eat and eat and eat."
Ava Jones's newborn was four to five weeks premature, according to Kim Flodin, a spokeswoman for the hospital.
Paula Radcliffe's strategy for the New York Mini Marathon 10K race in Central Park yesterday was to take it steady and keep relaxed until she hit the first two hills.

But Radcliffe, the two-time Olympian from Britain, was feeling so good when she hit the hills at the one-mile mark that she decided to keep pushing, and she pushed her way to a course record of 30 minutes 47 seconds.
The old mark of 31:00 was set in 1980 by Grete Waitz, one of Radcliffe's idols.

Radcliffe's time was the second-fastest 10 kilometers ever, 8 seconds off the world record of 30:39 set by Elizabeth McColgan of Scotland in 1989 in Orlando, Fla. At the start, the 30th running of the Mini Marathon appeared to be a two-woman race.
Radcliffe likes to start fast, but Restituta Joseph of Tanzania beat her to the front of the field.

The stock market steadied itself yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average regaining a quarter of the ground it lost in Friday's drubbing.
Action on the New York Stock Exchange was hectic again, with volume surpassing even the heavy trading of the previous session.
After plummeting 120.31 points on Friday, its worst one-day loss in two years, the Dow regained 29.52 points yesterday, to 2,972.72.
But much of the buying was concentrated in blue-chip issues; more Big Board stocks showed losses than gains.
Friday's plunge raised investor concerns about further losses, but Robert C. Walberg, an equity analyst with MMS International, said sanity had returned to the market. "
It appears investors have learned from the 1987 and 1989 crashes, which afterward offered good buying opportunities," he said.
But investors' fears about the economy and its effect on corporate profits was still apparent, analysts said, in the focus on blue chips.
241.9 Million Shares Traded One trader noted that even with the market's sharp decline last week, interest rates are so low that stocks offer attractive returns in comparison.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 241.9 million shares, up from 239.3 million on Friday.
Declining issues outnumbered those that rose by 989 to 723.
Tens of thousands of anti-Government protesters rallied in major cities across South Korea today, demanding the resignation of President Roh Tae Woo.

Estimates of the total number of demonstrators ranged from 100,000 and 400,000, and the rallies were probably the largest since the student and worker uprising in 1987 that helped lead to democracy here.
One million people were said to have walked off the job or to have boycotted classes.
Clashes between protesters and the riot police were reported natiowide.
Seoul's city center was brought to a standstill by fighting between students armed with firebombs and stones, and riot police officers who retaliated with volleys of tear gas.
A police spokesman said 28 police officers were wounded nationwide.
There were no reports on injuries to protesters, and no arrest figures were provided.
The demonstrations are the latest in a series provoked by the killing of a student protester on April 26.
The protester, Kang Kyong Dae, died after being beaten by the riot police.
The killing has aroused such passions that in the last two weeks three people, including two students, have committed suicide in protest by setting themselves on fire.

Amid fears of a new increase in fighting, the European Community today agreed to expand its cease-fire monitoring activities in Yugoslavia, but it again delayed a decision on whether to send a military peacekeeping force to the region.

The Community's 12 foreign ministers approved an increase in the number of unarmed cease-fire observers from around 100 to 200 and instructed them to patrol the area bordering on Hungary and the republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina as well as Croatia.

But while military experts have offered the Community four possible courses of action, ranging from beefing up its observer mission to deploying a 30,000-man peace force, the foreign ministers left the choice to Lord Carrington of Britain, who is trying to mediate a Yugoslav peace accord.

Germany's Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, said the Western European Union, a regional military group, would consider any request for military or other extra support that Lord Carrington felt was needed to reinforce the shaky cease-fire and promote the peace process.
The Western European Union has been activated during the Yugoslav crisis because the Community has no authority to act militarily.
Since 9 of the 12 Community members also belong to the union, however, both organizations were able to meet at the ministerial level here today.

European officials said that if the union were to become involved in Yugoslavia, it was unlikely to send a huge armed force, but would probably choose between sending a lightly-armed corps to protect civilian observers or a smaller peace-keeping force of fewer than 10,000 men.

While France wants to send troops and Britain is opposed, all Western European governments have insisted that no armed force would be deployed unless an effective cease-fire was in place and all warring factions in Yugoslavia approved of the intervention.

Community foreign ministers, who had a full agenda to deal with today, were also able to settle a dispute over meat imports from Eastern Europe and set the stage for the signing next month of association agreements between the Community and Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary.
Negotiations on the agreements were suspended early this month after France, anxious about protecting its own farmers, vetoed increased meat imports from the three countries.
The opera program at the Tanglewood Music Center, the training institute run by the Boston Symphony Orchestra at its summer home here, attracted international attention early on.
In 1946 it presented the American premiere of Britten's ''Peter Grimes,'' a work commissioned by the conductor Serge Koussevitzky.
That performance was conducted by a promising Koussevitzky protege, Leonard Bernstein, and opera continued to be a major component of the center for 20 years.
But the program then languished until the late 1980's, when the conductor Seiji Ozawa spearheaded its revival.

On Sunday and Monday nights the center again attracted international attention through an ambitious offering: the world premieres of one-act operas by Robert Zuidam and Osvaldo Golijov, both alumni of the institute.
The works were commissioned by the Boston Symphony.
At Sunday night's performance ''Rage d'Amours,'' by the Dutch-born Mr. Zuidam, 38, though a grim tale and a slow-paced score, seemed a formidable work.

Mr. Golijov, 43, the Argentine-born composer of Eastern European Jewish descent, could not be hotter right now, having won throngs of admirers for works like his exuberant ''Pasion Segun San Marco'' that elegantly draw from Latin American, Hebrew, ethnic folk and Western classical traditions.
Given Mr. Golijov's high promise and enormous gifts, his one-act opera ''Ainadamar'' was a major disappointment.
He has conceded in recent interviews that he was late in composing this 70-minute score and that it had the earmarks of a rush job.
Six million Americans hold jobs they do not consider permanent, far fewer than experts expected, the first Government survey of its kind has found.
These workers are markedly youthful and slightly more likely than workers over all to be female and black.

Only a third of these so-called contingent workers, a group that includes students, were satisfied with their situation, while the rest said they would prefer permanent jobs, according to the survey, released today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
And relatively few had their own health insurance.

But while the study confirmed that such workers are much more common in the United States than in Europe and other industrial countries, specialists said the results tended to undermine a popular conception that the number of workers with indeterminate job futures was growing rampantly.
Some estimates have placed the share of contingent workers, who are not necessarily part-time employees, as high as 35 percent instead of the 4.9 percent found by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Time magazine, for example, estimated in a prominent 1993 article entitled "The Temping of America" that contingent workers would make up half of the labor force by the year 2000.

Speaking of the Labor Department survey, Mitchell S. Fromstein, chairman of Manpower Inc., the Milwaukee-based temporary-help company, said, "It sets to rest a lot of notions of a work force dominated by temporary and contingent workers."
His company sent W-2 tax statements to 750,000 people last year.
Mr. Fromstein said the Government figures, collected in February 1994 and analyzed over the last six months, closely matched those of his own company.

To the Editor: ''Play About Iraq War Divides a Connecticut School'' (news article, March 24) left the impression that our administration reacted in a bureaucratic style to avoid a controversial issue.
We supported the student play about Iraq, but we have concerns about its drafts.
Book, film and Web site source materials are cut and pasted together in a way that does not give them attribution or cite the viewpoint of the authors.
Students directly act soldiers' parts rather than read the sources, an approach that sensationalizes the material.
Schools have a unique obligation to their audiences.
Most people understand that school performances cannot contain vulgar language or strong sexual content.
Our community, like many, is grieving the loss of our own and feeling anxious about those in harm's way.
As a school, we have a responsibility to ensure that the Iraq war, the lives lost and the sacrifices made by soldiers are presented in an educational context with appropriate support and guidance.
In its present form, the play does not meet those standards.
We want to continue the dialogue by working with the students.

With British-American relations at their lowest point in years, President Clinton and Prime Minister John Major emerged from nearly three hours of meetings today and declared that the two countries had largely patched up their differences.
Seeking to put the best face on their recent quarrel over Northern Ireland, the two acknowledged that some disputes were inevitable. "
It's honest and open and it endures occasional disagreements," Mr. Clinton said of America's relations with Britain at a news conference. "
But the agreements are far more numerous, and over the long run should be the shaping factors of our relationship."
Although the two leaders tried to give the impression that they had buried their differences, they could not help but squirm when a reporter asked about the health of their personal relationship. "
I think we have a good personal relationship," President Clinton said.

Mr. Major was less bullish, saying, "We know one another well enough, and the relationship is good enough, to have those disagreements, and it doesn't affect the broad swath of agreement that exists between the two countries."

Relations took a serious turn for the worst last month when President Clinton, rejecting Mr. Major's recommendations, invited Gerry Adams, the head of the Irish Republican Army's political wing, to the White House and allowed him to raise funds in the United States.

Mr. Clinton's aides said those moves would nudge the Northern Ireland peace process forward, but many Britons expressed outrage that Mr. Clinton was embracing someone they viewed as a supporter of terrorism.
Despite the good will that both men displayed publicly, officials said that in one or two private meetings Mr. Major made it clear that he still resented the President's invitation to Mr. Adams.
Re ''The Conservative Beat: Is It Working?'' (
March 12): As a former executive editor for two major metropolitan newspapers, I have generally been impressed with your detached analysis of the political coverage of The New York Times.
But you have bought the ''spin'' on why The Times created the conservative beat.
You say that conservatives were part of a ''movement'' and indicated that this ''movement'' was (gasp) trying to get conservative justices on the Supreme Court.
First, conservatives are not a ''movement.''
They are the backbone of the Republican Party and not something new, like a fringe group whipped up into a ''movement'' in recent years.
Second, conservatives were a driving force in securing the elections of Ronald Reagan, George H. W. Bush and George W. Bush.
Conservatives have long voted like the establishment they belong to and not that of any ''movement.''
I reluctantly believe that you, as the public editor, have become part of the problem instead of the solution in rectifying a biased newsroom.
WILL JARRETT  Dallas, March 12, 2006 The writer was the executive editor of The Dallas Times Herald and The Denver Post.

The Goldman Sachs Group plans to promote the top two executives of its brokerage business to be the co-heads of its investment management division after John P. McNulty retires at the end of the month.

Philip Murphy, 44, and Peter Kraus, 47, who have been the co-heads of what Goldman calls its private wealth management unit, will succeed Mr. McNulty, who, at 48, is retiring after 21 years with the firm.
Their promotion comes as Goldman faces increasing competition from financial firms that have started catering to wealthier investors.
Mr. Murphy, a member of the firm's management committee, has run the brokerage unit since he returned from overseeing Goldman's Asian operations in Hong Kong two years ago.
In February, Mr. Kraus left the firm's investment banking division, where he worked with companies in the financial services industry, to join Mr. Murphy.
Mr. McNulty said in an interview that he had been discussing his retirement with Henry M. Paulson, the firm's chairman, for a while.
About a year ago, rumors of his departure circulated, but Mr. McNulty said he waited until the firm had lined up his successors.
He said he had no plans to work elsewhere, but would spend time with his family, which includes three children.

Since 1999, Mr. McNulty, once a  broker, has run the investment management division, which comprises the firm's mutual funds, private equity investments and its brokerage services for wealthy investors.
Before that, he was a co-head of the asset management unit of the investment management division.
For a brief moment after the attacks, Hollywood was a kinder, gentler place.
Premieres of action films like ''Collateral Damage,'' starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, were delayed.
And highly competitive and backbiting studio executives exchanged niceties between bites of lobster salad at Spago in Beverly Hills. ''
There was such a fear no one was going to the movies that people were rooting for one another,'' said Sherry Lansing, the chairwoman of Paramount Pictures.
That fear proved unfounded.
Domestic box office receipts for 2001 totaled a record $8.13 billion, said ACNielsen EDI, beating 2000's $7.7 billion.
This year through March 3, receipts are up 3 percent compared with the similar period in 2001, to $1.38 billion.
It didn't take long for Hollywood to settle into its old ways.
Money spent campaigning for Oscars is up as much as 50 percent from two years ago.
Big-budget action films returned. ''
